Country Forecast India August 2019

Full text: India--highlights: Political outlook
The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) secured a second consecutive majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house) in the April-May 2019 general election. The prime minister, Narendra Modi, will retain tight control over the government in the next five years. The government's move to revoke the special status of the state of Jammu and Kashmir will lead to an escalation of violence in the region and a deterioration in relations with Pakistan. The risk of related terrorist attacks in the state and in India's big cities will rise. The government's Hindu-nationalist agenda will cause social tensions within India to rise over the longer term. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to tighten controls over the media gradually in the next five years.
India--highlights: Business environment outlook

The business environment will improve in 2019-23, owing in part to increased political effectiveness and the gradual implementation of reforms that will both open up the economy and boost investment in infrastructure. The rise in India's overall score is driven by higher scores for infrastructure, policy towards private enterprise and competition and foreign exchange and trade controls. However, its scores for many aspects of the business environment are still poor by global standards, and its economy will retain a relatively poor ranking in 2019-23, at 60th out of the 82 economies assessed.

Economic growth in fiscal years 2019/20-2023/24 (April-March) will be below potential, averaging 6.6% annually, owing to the government's hesitation in undertaking productivity-enhancing structural reforms and its market-distorting support for small businesses. The Indian rupee will face downward pressure over the next five years, owing to the country's chronic current-account deficit and relatively high rates of inflation. However, it will strengthen against the US dollar in 2020, owing to loosening in US monetary policy. We expect the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to hold policy interest rates unchanged during the remainder of 2019, but to implement a cut in the first half of 2020. Recent erosion of the RBI's independence will result in consumer price inflation trending slightly above the central bank's target of 4% over 2020-23.

India's economy will benefit from a growing population, and the labour force will expand by 1.3% a year on average in 2019-23. However, reaping the full benefits of its young population will prove immensely difficult amid a shortage of suitable employment opportunities. Large skills gaps will persist owing to inadequacies in the education system. The tertiary education sector will broadly under-perform, with the exception of a few pockets of excellence. Underemployment and unemployment will add to social tensions. This will be exacerbated by a wide gender imbalance and the government's Hindu-centric policy focus. Continued migration into towns and cities from the countryside will also generate economic and social stresses.

Strong GDP growth will support the outlook for wage growth and assist the expansion of the middle class, even as average national GDP per head remains low, at US$3,008 in 2023. The consumer market will continue to grow, supported by rapidly rising income levels among the huge population of around 1.4bn. We also anticipate rapid growth in the number of households able to afford relatively high-value products. The e-commerce sector will expand strongly on the back of higher smartphone and internet penetration rates and rising urban demand.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
We expect India to become the world's third-largest economy by 2031, supported by a shift in employment from rural to urban areas. However, a divergence in economic fortunes at individual and state levels will lead to social and political tensions. India's growing economic might will make it an increasingly influential diplomatic force. Owing to shared strategic geopolitical and economic interests, India will move closer to the US and Japan. The continuing rivalry for influence in South Asia will weigh on ties with China.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.34bn people in 2017, according to the UN. Its economy was the sixth-largest in the world in 2017 when measured in nominal US dollars, but the third-largest at purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the Westminster model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: Progress on economic reform is constrained by a lack of consensus across the political spectrum over its nature and scope, and by a lack of will within the government to undertake politically risky structural reforms. The NDA administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will remain a priority in the next five years. However, progress on more contentious issues, such as land and labour reforms, will be shallow.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2019-23, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's trade deficit widened to US$186.7bn in 2018, from US$148.1bn in 2017, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$75.9bn to US$80.8bn.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
India's constitution came into effect in 1950, underpinning the country's democratic system of governance. The state is technically secular, giving no preference to any of the manifold religious or social groups. India's democracy is well entrenched, and free and fair elections for the national and state parliaments have been held for decades. The country's two major political parties are the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), the dominant component party of the ruling National Democratic Alliance (NDA), and the Indian National Congress, which governed the country for decades, often in coalition with smaller regional parties. Regional parties are prominent in many state assemblies, enabling them to wield significant influence on national politics through the Rajya Sabha (the upper house of parliament). The BJP holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house) and governs with the support of smaller parties in the NDA.
The BJP's ideological approach leans towards Hindu nationalism, mixing social conservatism with a more aggressive foreign and security policy. Its growing dominance of national and state governments has thus challenged India's secular tradition. The party has moved recently to extend its vote base beyond its roots in the urban middle class by adopting more rural-focused policies. Congress has a more centre-left ideological approach to socio-economic issues.

Political outlook: Political stability
The BJP won the majority of seats in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) in the general election that took place in April-May 2019. The party and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) grouping control 352 of the 543 elected seats in the lower house (the largest majority since 1984). In addition, they control governments in a majority of states. This will underpin broad political stability. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any threat to the BJP's dominance of the central government at any point during its full term (2019-24). This will ensure consistency in policy, particularly as this is the second consecutive term for the BJP.
The results of the recent election were testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi. He will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised around the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers and officials whom Mr Modi trusts. The PMO and the National Security Advisor played a key role in the outgoing government, and we believe that they will continue to dominate the policy agenda in the next five years.
Sporadic instances of street violence occurred during the term of the first Modi government, directed particularly towards minority groups. The BJP's right-wing affiliates and sister organisations within the larger Hindu right-wing ecosystem (colloquially known as the Sangh Parivar) used the BJP's political power to pursue their socio-cultural agenda. This includes a goal of recasting India as a Hindu state-a view that puts them at odds with the country's large Muslim minority. Such attacks will persist over the forecast period, but we do not expect them to have a major impact on the business environment.
There is a risk that clashes between religious groups will intensify in states with a history of communal violence, such as Uttar Pradesh and Assam. Tensions between Hindus and Muslims have increased in recent years amid concerns among some Hindu groups about an influx of people from the neighbouring Muslim-majority nation of Bangladesh. However, state governments (which control the local police in India) will be keen to restore order quickly following any instances of communal violence, in order to avoid public criticism and international scrutiny.
The government's decision in August 2019 to revoke the special status accorded to the state of Jammu and Kashmir will result in a marked deterioration in political stability in that region. Despite the deployment of large numbers of troops and the arrest of many local leaders within the area, we expect violence to escalate. It will persist over the medium term, with immigration by Hindus into Muslim-dominated parts of the Kashmir valley likely to be a particular source of tension. The government's move will also increase the risk of related terrorist attacks in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The outlook for political and institutional effectiveness in 2019-23 is mixed. The BJP dominates the political landscape at national and-increasingly-state level. The party has full control of the lower house, and its re-election in 2019 will help to bolster policy effectiveness. It has also been able to expand gradually its presence in the Rajya Sabha, where it is likely to gain a majority (with its NDA allies) in 2021. It will then be able to pass legislation without approval from the opposition. This will ease the passage of laws in parliament, although we believe that the BJP's growing dominance will also result in greater levels of corruption within the party.
Over the next few years the BJP is likely to suffer from anti-incumbency sentiment, which will be aggravated by increased collaboration between regional parties to oppose it at state level. This is likely to result in a weaker performance in state elections over the next five years, although the party will remain the dominant force within government in many states and its capacity to drive policy at the regional level will remain powerful.
The BJP has been an advocate of so-called competitive federalism, which encourages competition between India's states. We believe that this approach will lead to a notable improvement in political and institutional effectiveness in reform-oriented states, particularly in the south and the west. However, it is also likely to deepen economic disparities between India's more economically successful states and its laggards, increasing social friction, competition for fiscal resources and pressure for migration between regions.
The BJP's dominance of national and state politics will have a corrosive impact on institutional checks and balances within India during 2019-23. There have already been signs that the government has successfully pressured media groups to rein in critical coverage. The independence of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) has also been eroded. There remains a significant risk that the government will engage in a major confrontation with the judiciary at some point in the next five years, particularly if judges overturn a key policy decision, such as the move to revoke the special status of Jammu and Kashmir. Judicial challenges to the government's policies towards minority religions could also be a point of friction.
Political outlook: Election watch
In the second half of 2019 assembly elections will be conducted in three states-Jharkhand, Maharashtra and Haryana. The BJP and its allies currently have over 85% of all available Lok Sabha seats in these three states, and we expect the outgoing BJP governments in all three to secure a second term in office.
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they are significantly short of a majority. Given the BJP's strong performance in the general election, we now believe that the party will dominate the upcoming state elections, enabling it to nominate more members to the upper house (Rajya Sabha members are elected by state assemblies). The NDA is therefore expected to achieve a majority in the Rajya Sabha by mid-2021. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval.
Political outlook: International relations
A major attack in February 2019 by separatist militants on military personnel in Indian-administered Kashmir raised tensions between India and Pakistan and resulted in clashes between the two nations' military forces. Tensions will be heightened further by the India government's revocation of the special status granted to Jammu and Kashmir. Pakistan's response will be constrained by its foreign-exchange shortages, which will limit it to low-cost strategies. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir in the short term. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors there, similar to the incident in February. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2019-23, we believe that the two governments will ensure that these do not escalate into a full-blown conflict.
Trade tensions between the US and India will persist over the next few years, slowing the expansion of bilateral trade flows. However, they are unlikely to escalate into a serious deterioration in relations. In general, ties will remain cordial, underpinned by a mutual desire to counter China's growing influence. To this effect, India has boosted security co-operation with the US in recent years, and this will continue in our forecast period.
China's growing influence in South Asia and its close ties with Pakistan will remain a bone of contention between China and India. Despite some attempts at a reset of bilateral ties in recent years, territorial disputes between China and India will persist, and relations will remain tense in 2019-23.

India's overall score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings rises to 5.76 in 2019-23, from 5.24 in 2014-18. However, improvements elsewhere mean that its global ranking rises only marginally to 60th out of the 82 countries assessed, from 61st in the historic period. Among its BRICS peers, India scores better than Russia (5.47) but fares worse than Brazil (6.25), China (6.13) and South Africa (6.10). India's score is dragged down by weak ratings for infrastructure and the labour market. Despite improvements in these scores in 2019-23, they will remain the worst-rated areas of the business environment.
The huge opportunities presented by India's enormous population and rapidly growing economy contribute to a strong score for market opportunities: indeed, India ranks third in the world in this field in 2019-23. The country will also score relatively well in terms of technological readiness, largely reflecting its well-developed telecommunications and internet sectors. Political effectiveness will be bolstered when the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) secures a majority in the Rajya Sabha (the upper house) in 2021, improving the political environment.
Restrictions on foreign investment will be liberalised modestly
We see the score for foreign trade and exchange controls improving in 2019-23 as the government looks to support India's development as a centre for export manufacturing. However, the modest liberalisation of restrictions on foreign investment that we expect will not be sufficient to raise the score for policy towards foreign investment. Indeed, in the areas of financing, taxes and policy towards private enterprise and competition India will remain a global laggard. While the country will still draw high levels of inward investment seeking to tap its huge market opportunities, the difficult business operating environment for both foreign and local firms will serve as a drag on productivity, holding back the economy's potential.

Business environment outlook: India's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The government remains protective of local businesses in certain sectors, leading to disputes with foreign countries. However, efforts are made towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies.
2021-23: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closing of loss-making businesses and their merger or acquisition by other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The government seeks to promote foreign investment in some sectors, such as renewable energy. Restrictions on foreign investment in sectors such as insurance, aviation and media are eased. Sourcing controls on foreign investment in single-brand retail are also liberalised.
2021-23: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few geographic regions. Foreign firms become a more notable force in Indian e-commerce, prompting a politicised pushback by some local players.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: A limited trade war with the US continues, despite the damage it inflicts on bilateral strategic ties.
2021-23: The government makes some efforts to further ease the process of borrowing overseas for companies, and to reduce capital-account restrictions. However, full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes
2019-20: The number of firms eligible to benefit from a reduced tax rate of 25% (against the norm of 30%) increases as the revenue threshold is raised. Effective tax rates for high-earners rise significantly.
2021-23: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the goods and services tax (GST). The GST is rationalised, with the number of tax rate bands being reduced. The government moves to lower tax rates for smaller firms.
Financing
2019-20: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks, raising risks to banking sector stability but improving the availability of finance for corporate borrowers.
2021-23: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, as most public-sector banks struggle with lingering bad-debt issues.
The labour market
2019-20: Reforms to labour laws move at a glacial pace owing to obstruction by trade unions and opposition groups.
2021-23: Some labour reforms make headway at the state level. However, reforms at central-government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus behind the changes.
Infrastructure
2019-20: The government increases its budgetary allocation for projects such as the Bharatmala road connectivity scheme.
2021-23: Construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its completion target of August 2022.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore.
2021-23: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

The erosion of the central bank's independence will push up inflation
India's score for the macroeconomic environment remains at 6.6 in 2019-23, and the country's global ranking in this area remains unchanged. Although we have recently revised down our medium-term growth forecasts for India, we still expect it to be among the fastest-growing economies in the world during the period. Twin deficits on the fiscal and current accounts will remain one of the weakest aspects of India's macro-economic environment. Nevertheless, the current-account deficit will be significantly lower as a share of GDP in the next five years than it was in the previous five, which will help to improve exchange-rate stability. Fiscal pressure will persist, despite rising tax collection, as the government outspends its receipts to fund burgeoning development projects. Nevertheless, we anticipate that consolidation efforts will intensify in fiscal year 2021/22 (April-March) resulting in a modest narrowing of the budget deficit. The erosion of the independence of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) in recent years will weaken the management of monetary policy. We thus expect that consumer price inflation will remain relatively high in 2019-23. Asset prices are also likely to become increasingly over-inflated as interest rates are kept low by a compliant RBI.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.5 5.3 58 56 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition improves to 5.3 in 2019-23, from 4.5 in 2014-18, largely owing to privatisation efforts (which will reduce the distorting impact of the state sector on the economy) and efforts to trim bureaucratic regulations. However, owing to progress elsewhere this significant improvement in the score has little impact on India's global or regional rankings in this category.
The government has made progress on streamlining the bureaucracy and merging some ministries, easing the approval process for industrial and infrastructure projects. It has also encouraged competition among states by devolving power to them to experiment locally with pro-business liberalisation. The pioneers in this process have been the southern states of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu, as well as the western state of Gujarat and the northern state of Haryana. Tamil Nadu, for example, is in the process of implementing its Business Facilitation Act of 2018, which seeks to integrate many approval processes (such as building permits and water connections) into a single portal. Despite these state-level measures, however, the scope for improvement remains immense.
The government's privatisation plan will achieve some notable successes
The government has gradually raised targets for disinvestment (a term that includes privatisation receipts) and seeks to raise Rs1.1trn (US$15.8bn) in 2019/20. The National Democratic Alliance (NDA) administration has habitually fallen short of its disinvestment targets, and delays to planned sales will continue amid opposition from unions and other vested interests. Nevertheless, we expect the government to achieve substantial levels of privatisation in 2019-23, including the sale of loss-making entities such as Air India and a telecommunications firm, MTNL.
The government's drive to expand the use of public-private partnerships (PPPs), notably in rail and digital communications infrastructure projects, will create opportunities for private firms in the next five years. However, there is a substantial risk that firms will experience problems in correctly pricing bids for such projects, which may render many unprofitable.
We expect the protection of intellectual property in India to improve over the next five years. This will reflect pressure from domestic companies to toughen the enforcement regime as local levels of investment in research and development increase. The regime is nonetheless likely to remain patchy, with courts in more developed parts of the country offering better levels of protection than those in poorer regions.

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India's score for policy towards foreign investment is unchanged at 5.5 in 2019-23. However, its global ranking drops from 62nd to 65th as other countries make greater headway in their efforts to attract foreign investors. The NDA government, led by the BJP, has pursued gradual liberalisation of the foreign-investment regime in recent years and has clarified in the 2019/20 budget that this will continue over its current term. Nevertheless, some important sectors of the economy, such as multi-brand retail and banking, remain subject to foreign investment caps. Partly in response to liberalisation (as well as India's rapid economic growth), levels of foreign direct investment (FDI) in India have increased, from an annual average of US$31.3bn in the five years to 2010 to US$41bn in the five years to 2018.
The government will seek to give added impetus to its "Make in India" campaign, which seeks to boost local manufacturing over 2019-23. Notably, it will offer added tax incentives to major foreign investments in advanced production fields such as semiconductors, solar cells, lithium batteries and servers. We expect these efforts to achieve some success, but the overall impact of Make in India will remain limited, partly owing to continued problems with the business environment in fields such as land acquisition.
More restrictions on foreign investment are being pared away
The 2019/20 budget highlighted the government's plans to liberalise foreign investment restrictions in the insurance sector, as well as for firms engaged in animation, gaming, comics and visual effects. It will also ease local sourcing requirements for firms in the single-brand retail sector, while also liberalising restrictions on foreign portfolio investment in fields such as real-estate investment trusts (REITs) and infrastructure investment trusts. We believe that these changes will be implemented over the next two years.
India's new e-commerce rules, which came into effect in February 2019, have generated opposition from foreign investors in the sector. The rules notably bar companies from selling products via firms in which they have an equity interest and from establishing special arrangements with suppliers to sell exclusively on their sites. A news agency, Reuters, reported in mid-2019 that a US retail giant, Walmart, had argued that the rules discriminate between large foreign e-commerce companies and their domestic counterparts. The issue is likely to be a point of discussion between negotiators seeking to resolve India-US trade tensions. Given the evolving state of e-commerce legislation in India, the rules are likely to be revised in 2019-23 in a way that addresses some of the complaints of foreign investors.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.1 6.9 70 61 16 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for foreign trade and exchange controls improves significantly to 6.9 in the forecast period, from 5.1 in 2014-18, resulting in an improvement in India's global and regional rankings in this category. This progress is due to significant improvements in trade-related bureaucracy and modest deregulation of capital-account restrictions. In addition, some headway will be made on reducing tariff and non-tariff barriers in 2019-23. In recent years the government has lowered an array of export subsidies and harmonised them under two general schemes-one for goods and one for services. It has also invested in improved infrastructure; it has reduced costs through greater use of online and mobile platforms, permitted the electronic submission of documents with digital signatures and allowed exporters to self-seal their containers using radio frequency identification (RFID) technology. These measures have formed part of a broader effort to stimulate exports through supply-side reforms that are intended to boost the competitiveness of Indian exporters.
Full liberalisation of capital controls remains unlikely
The RBI has relaxed rules on overseas borrowing on several occasions in recent months, partly in order to offset relatively tight domestic credit conditions. The liberalisation of rules governing outward investment and overseas borrowing will continue in 2019-23, but numerous restrictions on the free movement of capital will remain in place.
Negotiations between India and the EU on a proposed free-trade agreement (FTA) have been stalled since 2013 owing to disagreement on a few contentious issues, and the deal is unlikely to be revived in the forecast period. We also believe that Indian objections will prevent the conclusion of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), an Asia-focused multilateral FTA, in 2019-23. India has a patchy record on trade liberalisation, and the government has often resorted to protectionism in the face of threats to domestic industry from foreign competitors.
India and the US have engaged in a low-level trade conflict during 2019. The US announced in March that it would be withdrawing India's access to its preferential Generalised System of Preferences (GSP) trade scheme, and India in return imposed tariffs on a number of US products, such as almonds and apples. We do not expect this issue to be resolved as long as Donald Trump remains the US president. However, based on our forecast that a Democrat candidate will win the presidency in 2020, we expect the US to reprioritise the strategic relationship over its bilateral trade deficit and to come to a negotiated settlement that will see India's GSP status reinstated in return for relatively minor concessions.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.0 5.6 71 65 15 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India's score for taxes rises to 5.6 in 2019-23, from 5 in 2014-18. As a result, the country's global and regional rankings improve. The nationwide goods and services tax (GST) introduced in July 2017 was one of India's biggest tax reforms in decades. It replaced a slew of indirect central and state taxes and marks a significant step towards the creation of a single national market. Since the roll-out of the tax, the GST Council has met regularly and taken measures to simplify the tax and cut its rates. (The GST Council comprises a group of ministers authorised with deciding changes to the rate and structure of the tax.) Several landmark tax disputes between the Indian authorities and major foreign investors have arisen in recent years, involving claims of expropriation and retrospective changes of tax regulation. Some have been resolved (a major case with Nokia of Finland was settled in 2018), but several cases remain in the courts and continue to cast a cloud over the country's reputation as an investment destination.
As collections from the new tax pick up, the government will continue to rationalise GST rates and to bring more items into lower tax brackets, although multiple tax slabs will remain in place. Several key items, including alcoholic spirits and petroleum products, will remain outside the GST net.
Foreign investors will remain wary of the government's opaque tax regime, highlighted by the risk of retrospective changes to tax laws. Public concerns over tax evasion have led the government to increase the regulatory power of tax authorities, raising concerns of overreach in a country where tax laws remain complex.
Corporate tax rates will fall for smaller firms
The NDA government will continue to reduce corporate taxes, particularly for smaller companies. In the budget for 2018/19, the reduced 25% corporate tax rate applicable for businesses with turnover of up to Rs500m (US$7.2m) was extended to firms with turnover of up to Rs2.5bn (US$35.8m). The 2019/20 budget extended this to those with turnover of up to Rs4bn. Meanwhile, efforts to widen the tax base by increasing the capacity of tax authorities and identifying non-compliers will continue.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.1 5.5 57 65 12 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for financing improves from 5.1 in 2014-18 to 5.5 in 2019-23. However, India's position in the global rankings deteriorates from 57th to 65th as other countries make greater progress in this area. A number of massive bank fraud cases have emerged in recent years, including an alleged US$1.4bn fraud at Punjab National Bank. In connection with this, charges have been laid against a jewellery mogul, Nirav Modi (no relation of the prime minister). As regulatory scrutiny was toughened, more than 6,800 cases of alleged fraud involving Rs715bn were uncovered in 2018/19, according to the RBI. The bad debts associated with these (and other pre-existing problems in the banking sector) are beginning to recede, aided by reforms that have helped to smooth the judicial process associated with bankruptcy procedures. In its biannual Financial Stability Report published in June 2019, the RBI indicated that it expects the non-performing loan (NPL) ratio in the banking sector to fall to 9% by March 2020, from 9.3% a year earlier. Unfortunately, as bank lending has slowed in recent years, companies have turned to non-bank financial companies for credit, and problems in this segment of the financial sector are now emerging as well.
We expect financial regulation in India to improve throughout the forecast period. However, the insolvency law will probably need to be amended: as court cases involving the relatively new law are decided, they will set precedents that could underline the effectiveness of the law. Better bad-loan provisioning and stricter regulation will support an improvement in the sector's health towards the latter part of our 2019-23 forecast period, improving the availability of financing.
A massive recapitalisation of state banks looms
Public-sector lenders will continue to account for the bulk of total lending, especially in rural areas. The capacity of state-owned banks to increase lending has been held back in recent years as they sought to address balance-sheet weaknesses. However, in the 2019/20 budget the government announced plans for a Rs700bn capital injection into public banks, which should help to reinvigorate their lending over 2019-23. Worryingly, there is little chance that this will be accompanied by reforms to improve lending practices. However, we expect the largest public-sector lender (also the overall largest bank), the State Bank of India, to perform better than smaller state-run lenders, owing to its better bad-loan provisioning and significant improvements in its corporate governance standards.
Priority-sector lending (minimum mandated lending to specific sectors aimed at achieving socio-developmental objectives) will remain a feature of government policy throughout the forecast period. The RBI will continue to push both state-owned and private banks to meet priority-sector targets. Indian commercial banks and foreign lenders with more than 20 branches in the country are currently required to provide 40% of their net bank credit to the priority sectors, which include agriculture, housing and renewable energy. A significant reduction in this target is unlikely in 2019-23.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.0 5.1 72 72 16 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India's score for the labour market improves marginally from 5 in 2014-18 to 5.1 in 2019-23. However, the country remains the second-worst performing economy in Asia on this metric. India took some limited steps towards overhauling its outdated array of labour laws (many of which have not be comprehensively revamped in decades) under the previous NDA admini-stration. For example, it moved to allow all industrial establishments to hire workers on fixed-term contracts, previously permissible only in the textile industry. We expect this trend to continue broadly in 2019-23, but progress will be inhibited by opposition from trade unions-including those affiliated with the ruling coalition.
A major reason for the slow progress on labour law reform is the government's lack of a majority in the Rajya Sabha, which means that it depends on the support of opposition parties to get legislation approved. We expect the NDA to obtain a majority in the upper house from 2021, which should speed up the legislation process.
Labour laws will undergo substantial reform in 2019-23
The government has prepared a Code of Industrial Relations, representing the consolidation of over 40 different labour laws under four major codes covering wages, industrial relations, social security, and occupational safety, health and working conditions. Given strong resistance from opposition parties and trade unions, passage of these changes will not be swift. However, parliament passed the first code, on wages, in July 2019 (although it has not yet become law). This includes clauses that allow the government to set national minimum wage floor rates for various regions and industries. We believe that the other codes are likely to be passed in the period to 2021, with the code on occupational safety likely to be the next one approved. Among other things, the new legislation on industrial relations will significantly curb the power of unions and their ability to call strikes.
Some state governments, particularly in the west and south, will continue to implement labour reforms throughout the forecast period. Rajasthan, for example, has exempted establishments with up to 300 workers from the provision of the Industrial Disputes Act that requires government permission before laying off workers. Meanwhile, Maharashtra has set self-certification systems for business units covered under 16 different acts, with a view to reducing the interference of government officials and expediting the process of certification. Although the central government is harmonising and simplifying many labour regulations at national level, the states will still retain considerable autonomy to advance their own reforms in this field.
The government's budget for 2019/20 contained notable promises to improve education policy, in order to provide the workforce with the skills necessary to supply talent to emerging sectors such as artificial intelligence, 3D printing, robotics, virtual reality, the internet of things and Big Data. We do not believe that these commitments will result in much change on the ground in 2019-23, and the shortage of workers with suitable skills will remain a problem for many industries.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.0 4.3 77 72 16 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Significant gaps between demand supply in infrastructure will persist
The score for infrastructure improves from 3 in 2014-18 to 4.3 in 2019-23. This is driven by higher scores for road density, railways, distribution networks and air transport. However, India remains a laggard in this category, ranked 72nd out of the 82 countries in 2019-23, owing to weak scores for internet speed and the quality of port infrastructure, as well as the relatively high cost of good-quality office space. Infrastructure improvements and expansion remain key priorities for the NDA government. We expect the bulk of public investment to be diverted to transport, energy and urban-improvement projects. However, the pace of progress on projects that are already under way will remain constrained by weak government effectiveness and delays in regulatory clearances (particularly environmental approvals).
Progress on urban civic infrastructure projects, such as water supply, will be hindered by inadequate private-sector involvement. The limited returns on investment in these sectors mean that official efforts to draw in more private-sector participation will struggle. The private sector will instead focus on areas that promise faster returns, like airport construction, and there will be significant progress in these areas in 2019-23. However, demand for infrastructure will continue to exceed supply by a significant margin in the forecast period, placing stress on already scarce resources.
Flagship infrastructure projects are likely to miss completion targets
Two publicly funded connectivity projects, Bharatmala (road construction) and Sagarmala (port construction), will continue to be prioritised throughout the forecast period. The first phase of Bharatmala is aimed at connecting 550 of the country's districts through the national highways network, from only 300 in 2017. The government plans to build a total of 24,800 km of roads by 2022. However, progress on this project will be hindered by limited funds, and it is likely to miss its targets.
The quality and breadth of railway services will remain a challenge in 2019-23. India has one of the largest rail networks in the world, but the quality of the network is inadequate, with frequent accidents and poor speeds that restrain efficiency. A lack of capital investment in the sector constrains the expansion of capacity. Despite piecemeal efforts, the overall quality of the rail network will remain poor in comparison with other countries with large rail networks, such as China and the US. However, rapid-transit projects, including a "bullet train" connecting Ahmedabad with Mumbai, and several ongoing urban mass rapid transit projects, will make significant progress during the forecast period.
Government officials have announced plans for new airports in 70 locations, as well as 30 expansion projects for existing airports, over 15 years from 2018. These investments will be sorely needed. A report in 2018 by a local newspaper, the Hindustan Times, cited a study by the Civil Aviation Ministry indicating that Mumbai, Delhi, Goa, Visakhapatnam, Jaipur, Pune, Ahmadabad, Rajkot, Patna, Kolkata and Bangalore were among the cities that would need a second airport by 2035.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.1 6.1 42 48 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
India scores respectably on technological readiness. However, its score in the category does not improve in 2019-23, which results in its global ranking falling from 42nd to 48th. The country boasts a relatively advanced research-and-development (R&D) infrastructure, partly owing to the fact that the education system has historically been skewed towards higher educational outcomes. This has facilitated the development of relatively research-intensive sectors such as pharmaceuticals and technology. As a result, India files an unusually high number of patents, and R&D spending is quite high as a share of GDP. India has also been an enthusiastic adopter of e-government systems, seeking to improve the effectiveness of public service delivery and reduce corruption. Its Aadhar biometric identity cards are helping to enable this process. Nevertheless, high levels of poverty mean that mobile and internet penetration rates in India are still low compared with global and Asian norms.
Internet speeds will remain slow by global standards
India lags behind in terms of mobile internet speeds. In a report published in May 2019, a market intelligence company, OpenSignal, ranked India 74th out of 87 countries (although 4G services were widely available). In 2018 the Telecom Commission, a government agency, approved the new National Digital Communication Policy, the objectives of which include providing minimum download speeds of 50 Mbps and enabling 10-Gbps connectivity to all rural administrations by 2022. The policy also aims to generate 4m jobs in digital communication and to increase the sector's contribution to India's GDP from around 6% at present to 8% by 2022. However, acquiring spectrum licences and laying the requisite fibre network will create obstacles, and the government is likely to fall short of its targets.
E-commerce has become the focal point of India's digital revolution, owing to factors such as FDI-friendly regulation, a growing middle class, the availability of relatively cheap mobile connections and skilled labour to develop indigenous technology platforms. A report published in 2018 by PWC, a global professional services provider, argued that spending on e-commerce would rise from US$36bn in 2017 to US$105bn in 2022, led by online retail, travel and hotels. The company also expects to see particularly rapid growth in spending on online financial services. At the lower end of the pricing spectrum, the development of online commerce will be facilitated by the government's Bharat-Net programme, which seeks to provide internet connectivity to every village in the country.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The BJP government will enjoy considerable flexibility in determining the policy agenda, given its majority in the Lok Sabha. One area of priority will be resolving bad debt problems in the banking sector that have held back lending to business. In the budget delivered in July 2019, the government announced plans to provide Rs700bn (US$10bn) to help to shore up public-sector banks. We believe that this sum, if delivered in full, would be sufficient to substantially address balance-sheet problems, but implementation may be a challenge.
We expect incentives to be offered to four key labour-intensive sectors: construction, tourism, gems and jewellery, and garments and textiles. However, these incentives will be market-distorting, protectionist and a bone of contention with countries such as the US in 2019-23. More positively for India's economic productivity, the government plans to liberalise foreign investment restrictions in sectors including insurance, the media and aviation.
The government is unlikely to push for radical reforms that are politically contentious, such as a comprehensive overhaul of land-acquisition laws or labour regulations. However, piecemeal changes to such legislation, such as the relaxation of certain regulatory requirements, could be undertaken. Once the NDA has control of the Rajya Sabha, from mid-2021, this will ease the challenges in the legislative process. However we expect only limited gains from this, as the Modi administration will be hesitant to push ahead with productivity-enhancing reforms that could be politically damaging.
Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the Bharatmala roads project and the Smart Cities Mission-will remain a priority, partly as a response to the rapid pace of urbanisation, and partly to boost the business environment. However, many projects are likely to face financing difficulties, as they envision a level of public-private partnership that seems unlikely to be realised, given how subdued private investment activity remains.

The new government's first budget, for the remainder of fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March) was less populist than we had initially anticipated. More firms will be able to enjoy a concessional 25% rate of corporation tax after revenue thresholds were raised, while tax rates for high-earning individuals were increased. The budget also continued the government's efforts to simplify and digitise the tax system, including the regime for the goods and services tax (GST). Over the forecast period, efforts to deepen the tax base and increase levels of tax compliance will continue; India's tax/GDP ratio remains low by regional and OECD standards. More worryingly, there were signs in the budget that the government was seeking to use the customs regime to encourage import substitution-an approach that has failed badly in India in the past.
Welfare payments and infrastructure spending will remain key areas of focus for the government over the forecast period. It will seek to increase the reach of schemes such as the Ayushman Bharat health insurance scheme. We also expect subsidies for labour-intensive small-scale businesses, particularly those that are export-focused, in an effort to promote exports and employment. This will keep the fiscal deficit wide throughout the forecast period, averaging the equivalent of 3.3% of GDP a year in 2019/20-2022/23.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the large deficits being recorded by several state governments, which are not included in the national figure. The deep deficits of some states, such as Punjab, will present implicit liabilities for the central government and could pose downside risks to GDP growth over the next five years by crowding out private investment.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) will keep inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework in the next five years. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range and close to a target of 4% throughout 2019-23. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two heads of the bank under BJP rule-means that inflation is likely to more likely to trend above 4% than below it.
Weak inflation, ebbing growth and pressure from the government have led the RBI to loosen policy several times in 2019. The most recent policy interest rate cut in August, of 35 basis points, took the repurchase (repo) rate to a nine-year low of 5.4%. However, we believe that with inflation gradually recovering and policy rates already low by historical standards, the RBI will hold rates until 2021. The central bank will then undertake some tightening in 2021-22 as demand-side pressures associated with the country's rapid economic growth build. As the pace of growth moderates in 2023, the RBI will adopt a neutral stance.

High-frequency data suggest that the economy is decelerating. We believe that household demand has been adversely affected by rising unemployment and slowing wage growth, particularly in rural areas. Meanwhile, business sentiment remains subdued. Although the 2019 general election results ensure medium-term political stability, we do not expect a dramatic acceleration in private investment. This is because businesses remain sceptical about broader economic prospects. Nevertheless, the govern-ment's focus on infrastructure improvement and domestic market oppor-tunities will provide some support for gross fixed capital formation over the next five years.
We do not expect a significant improvement in job creation in the forecast period, as government efforts will focus on small-scale industries and are unlikely to have the desired effect in boosting employment. The focus on smaller firms will crowd out the larger-scale enterprises that would be more productive and effective job-creators in the longer term. This effect will be aggravated by outdated labour laws that deter companies from scaling up. Economic growth will therefore remain below potential throughout the forecast period, despite stable inflation. Meanwhile, we do not envisage a substantial narrowing in the budget deficit over the forecast period, and so government spending on goods and services will remain supportive of growth. Imports of goods and services will grow more quickly in real terms than export volumes, and net exports will therefore exert a drag on economic expansion. Real GDP growth will average 6.6% a year in 2019/20-2023/24, keeping India among the fastest-growing major economies throughout the forecast period.
In factor-cost terms, the services sector will remain the largest component of the economy and will grow at a relatively brisk pace over the forecast period. Conversely, manufacturing will remain below potential owing to structural limitations such as challenges relating to land acquisition. Meanwhile, the agriculture sector will remain a drag on the economy. Public investment in the sector will be aimed at short-term gains, rather than fostering improved productivity.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
As the economy moves up the value chain and productivity improves, the share of agriculture in total output will continue to decline gradually; we expect it to fall from 16.1% in 2018/19 to 13.7% by 2023/24. The primary sector will remain important, as it will continue to employ around half of the population. As employment opportunities in the secondary and tertiary sectors open up, however, there will be a gradual shift in employment away from agriculture. Reforms to bolster supply-chain efficiency will support the sector's outlook in 2019-23. However, farm-to-wholesale procurement is still dominated by individual middlemen and local traders, with laws inhibiting the entry of companies in many states. This will continue to create inefficiencies in the procurement process.
There is significant scope for investment to enhance the sector's productivity, as close to half of all cultivable land remains dependent on annual monsoon rainfalls, rendering the sector vulnerable to poor or unevenly distributed rains. The government has recognised the sector's vulnerability to monsoon rainfalls and increased funding for irrigation schemes and crop insurance. As agriculture faces growing risks related to the availability of water, the success of these efforts will prove crucial to ensuring long-term sustainability. However, capital investment into the sector remains inadequate, and the bulk of public funding will continue to come in the form of populist short-term subsidies aimed at securing political support from farmers. We forecast that the agriculture sector will grow by 3.2% a year on average in the forecast period.
Land-acquisition challenges will inhibit faster growth in the industrial sector
The industrial sector will expand at a robust pace as the business environment improves and the country's strong economic growth outlook attracts invest-ment, expanding capacity. We expect the sector to grow by an average rate of 6.5% a year in the forecast period. However, the share of industry in total GDP will remain relatively stable, falling slightly from 29.6% in 2018/19 to 29.4% in 2023/24. Manufacturing will continue to be particularly concentrated in a few sectors, such as the automotive industry, and in a few geographic locations. This will render it vulnerable to sectoral swings, such as the downturn in demand for cars being witnessed so far in 2019.
Government efforts to lift manufacturing employment and output-such as the "Make in India" initiative (which targets 100m additional jobs in manufacturing and a rise in its share of GDP to 25% by 2022) and the administration's special-economic-zone strategy, which is intended to develop manufacturing hubs throughout the country-are highly ambitious but will miss their targets. In the absence of greater liberalisation of laws governing land acquisition, industrial expansion will lag behind potential, which will weigh on employment opportunities.
Accounting for 46.3% of GDP in 2018/19, the services sector will continue to be the main engine of economic expansion. The sector has shown itself to be resilient and efficient, and not entirely dependent on buoyancy in external markets. The sector's expansion will continue to be driven by already strong areas of activity such as telecommunications, as well as by services in numerous high-potential but currently underserved areas, including healthcare, retailing, hospitality and education. Information technology (IT) and IT-enabled services will remain a major source of export revenue, even as growth slows in the face of increased competition from countries such as the Philippines. Services will form a key sector of the economy in the forecast period, expand-ing by 7.5% a year on average, and its share of GDP will rise to 49.5% by 2023/24.

Prices of food and oil will remain the key factors driving inflationary pressures in 2019-23. Food and beverages have a weighting of around 45% in the consumer price index, and so any volatility in agricultural output will affect price stability. Food price inflation has been weak in recent months, but we anticipate that it will accelerate in the second half of 2019, as crop yields during the summer harvest are expected to be lower than usual. Nevertheless, headline inflation will cool to 3.6% in 2019 on average, from 3.9% in 2018, owing to weaker crude oil prices this year.
Lower crude oil prices will also have a dampening effect on prices in 2020, but this will be offset by a modest pick-up in domestic demand growth, the RBI's accommodative monetary policy and the lagged effects of seasonal climatic factors from 2019. Average annual consumer price inflation will thus accelerate in 2020, to 4.2%. Later in the forecast period, continued strong economic growth will stoke demand-pull inflation, while a weakening of the rupee:US dollar exchange rate will exert an upward influence on prices in 2021-23, by pushing up the cost of imports. We expect consumer prices to rise by an annual average of 4% over 2019-23 as a whole.

Although the rupee has weakened sharply in the wake of the government's decision on Jammu and Kashmir, we regard this as a short-term effect. We continue to expect that a narrowing current-account deficit and improved investor sentiment will ease downward pressure on the rupee in 2019 as a whole, with the currency's exchange rate set to end the year stronger against the US dollar than it was at the end of 2018. However, in annual average terms the rupee will still depreciate in 2019, albeit mildly, weakening to Rs69.8:US$1, from Rs68.4:US$1 last year.
The rupee will appreciate slightly against the US dollar in 2020, supported by interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) against a backdrop of an economic slowdown in the US. In 2021-23 the rupee will return to a gradual depreciating trend against the US dollar, reflecting India's persistent current-account deficit and relatively high levels of inflation. However, the country's real effective exchange rate will remain relatively stable over 2019-23 as a whole, and benefits to India's export sector from the rupee's weakening against the US dollar will therefore be limited.

India's dependence on imported crude oil for its energy needs will continue to keep merchandise imports high. Imports will also be lifted by growing demand for foreign consumer products and construction-related machinery. Merchandise exports will grow at a faster pace than imports over the next five years, but India's export manufacturing sector will continue to be held back by restrictive labour laws and difficulties in securing land for production facilities.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth of India's key service export sectors, particularly the business process outsourcing and information technology segments. Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit, averaging the equivalent of 1.4% of GDP annually in 2019-23.
Inward direct investment will remain strong in 2019-23, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses. We expect annual direct investment inflows to rise to US$68bn by 2023, from US$42.1bn in 2018. Inward portfolio investment slid into negative territory in 2018, owing to jittery investor confidence amid a currency crisis in emerging markets such as Turkey, which stoked fears of contagion, as well as rising US interest rates. We expect this trend to reverse in 2019-23 as investor confidence is gradually restored.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in India
Stocks and flows
India's large market and growing economy make it a favourable destination for foreign investors. Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows into India have been strong in recent years, and in 2018 the country received US$42.1bn in FDI inflows. This compares favourably with an average of US$17.8bn in 2005-07, before the outbreak of the 2008-09 global financial crisis. Owing to an attractive growth outlook and significant market opportunities, the stock of inward FDI has been expanding rapidly, standing at US$386.2bn in 2018, markedly higher than in 2010, when it stood at US$205.6bn. The 2018 figure was also higher than the corresponding stock in Indonesia (US$268.5bn) but significantly lower than in China (US$1.7trn) and Brazil (US$762bn).
Origin and distribution
According to the Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion (DIPP), the largest source of FDI is Mauritius, which accounted for 31% of FDI inflows between April 2000 and March 2019. Many foreign companies investing in India are incorporated in Mauritius for tax reasons. Singapore was the second most important foreign investor in the same period, accounting for 21.3% of cumulative inflows, followed by Japan (7.3%), the Netherlands (6.9%), the US (6.2%) and the UK (5.9%). The most important sector for FDI is services, which attracted US$74.1bn between April 2000 and March 2019 and accounted for 18% of cumulative inflows, according to the DIPP. The computer software and hardware sector is the second-largest recipient, attracting US$37.2bn over the same period. The country's leading financial centre, Mumbai, is the largest recipient of FDI, and garnered 30% of total FDI between April 2000 and March 2019. This was followed by the capital, New Delhi, and neighbouring areas, which received 20% of total FDI in the same period.
Determinants
India's skilled, English-speaking workforce has been a significant attraction for FDI, particularly in the information technology (IT) sector. Since coming into office the current government has liberalised the FDI regime in a number of areas, including defence, pharmaceuticals, civil aviation and single-brand retailing. It has also done away with the Foreign Investment Promotion Board, an agency that was tasked with considering and recommending FDI on a case-by-case basis. This onus now falls on individual ministries, and the administration will continue to open up the economy to foreign investors. However, more minor bureaucratic restrictions are often left unaddressed and legal uncertainties often persist, impeding the inflow of investment and hampering the ease of conducting business in India for foreigners.
Impact
FDI has had the greatest impact on India's software industry and IT-enabled services. Call centres and other forms of back-office administration have become important industries, but India is moving up the value chain. The financial, pharmaceutical, telecommunications and power sectors have also been influenced significantly by FDI. The online retail sector is likely to be similarly transformed, with US-based Amazon and Walmart (through its Flipkart subsidiary) now having a significant presence in the e-commerce sector. However, in offline retail, a significant relaxation of regulations for multi-brand retailers is unlikely to occur over 2019-23.
Potential
Given the size of its market and rapid economic growth, India is attracting a significant amount of FDI, but the potential for even stronger inflows is reduced by relatively poor infrastructure, excessive bureaucracy and wrangling between government departments. The infrastructure, energy, telecoms, IT and insurance sectors are likely to be the key areas for FDI in 2019-23. Biotechnology and vehicle manufacturing (including parts) could also attract significant interest over the next five years, although the downturn in car sales in 2019 will make some producers wary of entering in the short term.

The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the population will grow by 1% a year on average in 2019-23, down from 1.1% in 2014-18. This slight slowdown is linked to an improvement in living standards, urbanisation and generally improving economic conditions for women, which are resulting in women having fewer babies. According to data from the National Institution for Transforming India (NITI Aayog, the government's policy think-tank), the total fertility rate fell to 2.3 children per woman in 2015, from 3.2 in 2000. India is likely to reach the replacement level of fertility-2.1 children per woman-within our forecast period. In the coastal states, the fertility rate is already below the replacement rate. However, poor and populous states such as Uttar Pradesh and Bihar will continue to see strong population growth, adding to social tensions.
High levels of gender disparity will increase the risk of social unrest
By 2023 men will outnumber women by almost 50m. According to the latest census, conducted in 2011, there were just 919 girls for every 1,000 boys under the age of six, marking a decline from the previous census in 2001, which showed that there were 927 girls for every 1,000 boys. More recent research from the National Family Health Survey, conducted in 2015-16, shows that a skewed sex ratio exists across almost the entire country (the gender disparity is more pronounced in urban regions than rural areas). Historically, countries with wide gender disparities have tended to suffer from higher levels of social disorder, and we do not expect India to be an exception to this trend. Social tensions will be particularly notable in urban areas, fuelled partly by the inability of many men to find suitable employment opportunities.
Caste factors will be another important source of social strains within India in 2019-23. The Hindu-nationalist populism promoted by the Bharatiya Janata Party-led government will have complex effects. On one hand, it is likely to re-energise Hinduism, which could lead to renewed emphasis on traditional caste roles. On the other hand, the government appears supportive of policies that favour caste-based "reservations" (quotas) for jobs and public services such as education, which may help those in low-status castes. Caste groups (including higher-status castes) that do not currently enjoy special job quota allocations, especially in public-sector jobs, will push for them in the next five years. Regardless of the government's policy approach, the ongoing trend for workers to move from more conservative rural regions to more cosmopolitan urban areas will serve to slowly weaken the roots of the caste system.
The agricultural sector will continue to employ the bulk of the labour force
Growth in the working-age population will remain relatively strong, at 1.2% a year on average in 2019-23. However, unlocking the economic benefits from population growth will prove challenging. In the 1990s and 2000s China was able to transfer workers from agriculture to more productive work in the cities, thereby boosting economic growth and exports. However, India's manufac-turing sector has failed to take off in a similar manner. Although it is expected to post strong growth in the next five years, this is still unlikely to be sufficient to provide jobs for all the expected migrants from rural areas, particularly because of advancing levels of automation. Services will also provide new jobs, but many of these will not be of a suitable level for low-skill workers. Agriculture will thus remain the mainstay of employment.
A key challenge for the country's long-term development is the poor state of primary-level education. While enrolment rates have risen in recent decades, educational outcomes remain abysmal, especially in the public sector. This reflects multiple factors, including underqualified and undisciplined teachers, the impact of caste within the education system, poor health among students and bad infrastructure within schools. The situation has resulted in strong demand even among poor households for private education, including online courses.
Weaknesses in other parts of the education system will also come to the fore as more students seek secondary and tertiary education. Few universities operate at world-class levels, and the vast majority of graduates appear unequipped for the demands of employers-even in sectors such as engineering, which are crucial for long-term growth. The growing politicisation of the tertiary education sector and the authorities' lack of clear focus on improving educational standards mean that Indian universities will broadly continue to under-perform. A few clusters of excellence will, however, gradually emerge.

The middle class will continue to grow throughout the forecast period
Even though we have downgraded India's medium-term growth outlook in the last year, we still expect the country to have one of the world's fastest-growing economies. Rising income levels over 2019-23 mean that India's huge population will become an increasingly important market for consumer goods. Household consumption expenditure will rise from US$1.6trn in 2018 to US$2.5trn by 2023. Despite rapid economic growth, GDP per head (at market exchange rates) will remain low at just US$3,008 in 2023, compared with US$12,554 in China and US$10,845 in Brazil in the same year. This will limit the bulk of consumer spending to food and basic necessities. This low average nevertheless masks the presence of a growing number of middle-class households, which offers considerable potential for purveyors of higher-value products and services. The rapid growth in personal incomes, combined with a more open domestic market, will make India an increasingly attractive market for foreign companies. Significant regional economic disparities exist, and the levels of opportunity for retail businesses will vary greatly across the country in the forecast period.
Growth in the e-commerce segment will be robust
Opportunities for e-commerce will grow rapidly in urban areas, owing to their increasingly well-educated populations and growing penetration of broadband and smartphones. Foreign firms are positioning to take advantage of this trend. In 2018 Wal-Mart (US) acquired a controlling stake in Flipkart, an Indian e-commerce company, and it competes aggressively with the local unit of Amazon (also of the US). As India continues on a solid growth path in 2019-23, and as levels of internet penetration deepen, the share of e-commerce in its consumer market will rise, creating opportunities for both domestic and foreign firms. Nevertheless, regulation will provide some obstacles to their competitive capacity. In December 2018 the government introduced measures preventing e-commerce platforms from entering exclusive deals with suppliers to sell products at deep discounts, as well as limiting the amount of inventory a vendor could sell to a single platform. Foreign firms see these measures as discriminatory, and the government will come under pressure to revise them in 2019-23.
As Indian consumers become more aware of international brands, imports of electronics and consumer goods will rise. Urban consumers tend to display more brand loyalty than their rural counterparts and value loyalty programmes. For most Indians price will remain the main determinant of the level of demand. Companies in the fast-moving consumer goods sector tend to address affordability by offering products in smaller sizes. This practice serves as a way to develop brand loyalty among new consumers.

As in most developing countries, food constitutes by far the largest category of consumer expenditure. Indeed, spending on food as a percentage of income will remain relatively stable over 2019-23, as households increase the share of more expensive foods, like meat, in their diets. Spending on leisure and education, as well as health, will also pick up. The relatively poor state of government-provided services means that as Indians become richer, they will spend an increasing amount on private healthcare and education. Growth in the leisure sector will be fuelled by the rapidly expanding middle class, which will spend more on entertainment and holidays.
Local factors will continue to shape consumer preferences
Several non-income-related factors must be weighed carefully when assessing prospects in the Indian market. First, purchasing power is as location-specific as it is income-sensitive, and prices can vary to a considerable degree even from city to city, let alone between urban and rural areas. Second, cultural factors matter to a significant degree. Third, Indian consumers, including those who are moving up the income scale, are highly price-conscious. Fourth, it is important to note that there is hardly a single characteristic that applies across the entire country. India is a widely varying collection of markets, necessitating a strategic approach that takes regional differences into account. Finally, the steady expansion of consumer finance and the growth of a credit-card culture will increase the number of consumers in the forecast period.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook
