From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Initial conditions: The Indian economy began to move away from a state-directed socialist model in the early 1990s, when a balance-of-payments crisis triggered the first round of economic reform and market liberalisation. Since then, India has recorded rapid rates of expansion, with annual real GDP growth averaging 6.6% in fiscal years 1991/92-2018/19 (April-March). However, India's share of world GDP (at market exchange rates) remains low, at around 3.3% in 2018, compared with its 17.9% share of the world's population. This highlights the fact that there is still significant scope for further economic development. Low average productivity in India remains a key reason for widespread poverty. The gap in productivity between the agriculture sector and high-growth industries, such as information technology (IT), is vast. Corruption is still endemic in local authorities, despite the fact that attempts to reduce graft have made progress at the higher levels of government under the Bharatiya Janata Party (which has led the ruling coalition since 2014). India's courts have long suffered from crippling levels of understaffing, and a case backlog has built up over decades. However, the judiciary is independent from the government.
The skills mismatch will persist as education and training remain poor
Demographic trends: Continued growth of the working-age population over 2019-50 will support India's economic expansion. However, even as the economy grows, a large proportion of the workforce will not find employment in productive formal-sector jobs. A mismatch between the skills offered by the country's workers and the demands of employers will persist for at least the next two decades, as the quality of teaching provided by the country's public education and vocational training systems remains poor. The rise of automation and growing use of artificial intelligence will meanwhile dampen employment gains, even as India-based enterprises capture a larger market share of global manufacturing. Reaping the demographic dividend will prove immensely difficult in this environment. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the vast majority of the workforce to be absorbed by low-productivity occupations in the urban services sector in 2019-50. Still, opportunities for better-educated Indians will proliferate amid rapid growth in manufacturing and high-technology areas such as telecommunications, IT and pharma-ceuticals.
Migration from poorer states could cause a spike in social tensions
Divergence in economic fortunes within the country will result in strong pressure for Indians from poorer states to move into more prosperous areas. In the absence of major governance improvements, states such as Uttar Pradesh and Bihar will be a source of internal migrants, putting pressure on scarce resources in more prosperous and economically dynamic cities such as the capital, New Delhi, and the financial hub, Mumbai. There is strong divergence in fertility rates between states, with Bihar and Uttar Pradesh recording high total fertility rates (TFR) of 3.2 and 3 respectively in 2017; the more prosperous state of Kerala had a TFR of 1.7 in the same year. This will continue in the long run, and the population of Uttar Pradesh alone could surpass 400m by the middle of the century. Significant levels of internal migration will be a source of political and social tensions. Meanwhile, some workers will look abroad, to areas such as the Gulf region, for economic opportunities. Inflows from their remittances over the next few decades will be an important driver of economic activity in some states.
The unequal gender distribution of India's population will remain a threat to social stability over the outlook period. According to the latest census, conducted in 2011, for every 1,000 boys under the age of six there were only 919 girls, marking a decline from the previous census in 2001, which showed that there were 927 girls for every 1,000 boys. Child mortality rates are higher for girls than boys, and female foeticide is practised. As this trend continues (and there is no evidence to suggest that it will not), a major imbalance between the numbers of men and women will undermine social stability.
India's diplomatic, economic and military power will increase
External conditions: As its economy expands in size, India will become an increasingly important diplomatic, military and economic power. Successive governments will seek to ensure India's primacy within South Asia and to cultivate ties with regional neighbours-excluding Pakistan, India's long-standing rival. We expect India's relationship with Pakistan to remain tense, as the two countries will struggle to reconcile political and strategic differences. Temporary bouts of high tension are likely. However, the growth differential between India and Pakistan will remain high, suggesting that India's military advantage over its rival will increase. Over time, this should deter Pakistan from initiating conflict. China's influential role in Pakistan and its competition for influence in South Asia with India will weigh on bilateral relations between the world's two most populous nations. Shared strategic and economic interests will bind India more closely with Japan and the US. Still, even as it becomes a major diplo-matic power, India will remain hesitant to align itself fully with the West. This is partially related to India's complex relationship with Russia, which has been a major source of military equipment. Averting the possibility of closer Russia-Pakistan ties will remain a foreign policy imperative. Long-standing links with the Gulf region and Africa and deepening investment ties will provide India with the opportunity to expand its political, economic and cultural engagement in these regions over the period to 2050.
Institutions and policy trends: Although political power will be centralised under the current prime minister, Narendra Modi, we expect this trend to reverse once he leaves office. Differences in policy approach at state level will thus have a significant impact on economic outcomes. Reform-minded states will see growth accelerate, while poorer states will demand increased funds from the central government to reduce economic disparities. The fight over control of the central government will fuel political instability as regional parties increase in influence. Despite state-level differences, India's democratic political system will remain firmly entrenched. The country's legal system will generally remain impartial (if slow) and the constitution will continue to be respected. India's integration into regional and global value chains will nonetheless be constrained by a lingering tendency towards protectionism. New technologies and the emergence of an increasingly vocal middle class will help the authorities to curb graft, particularly at local level.
Services will continue to dominate the economy in the longer term
Long-term performance: We forecast that India's real GDP growth will average 4.9% a year in 2019-50. The country's economic progress is premised on a shift up the value chain in IT, manufacturing, pharmaceuticals, business and information services, as well as other sectors. Continued government-led investment to upgrade infrastructure will improve the business environment and help to enhance the performance of the economy. Improvements in agricultural procurement practices and greater supply-chain efficiency will make rural India more resilient to weather shocks. A stronger agricultural sector will temper the movement of Indians from rural to urban areas, and the urban population will overtake its rural counterpart only by the middle of this century. However, the shift of the workforce from rural labour into more productive urban jobs will remain the main driver of India's economic expansion in the period to 2050. One major concern over the country's long-term economic performance is the extent to which the government can manage this transition. Upgrading the quality of public education will be crucial if the government is to achieve this successfully. Without this, India is unlikely to be able to develop either the low-skilled manufacturing sector that will be crucial to its medium-term growth prospects or the higher-value-added sectors that will be necessary to sustain its growth momentum in the longer term.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
India will be highly vulnerable to climate change, and adverse changes in monsoon patterns could severely affect its agricultural sector, which remains highly rain-dependent. More generally, water scarcity will become a challenge, as has been highlighted in 2019 by a major crisis in Chennai. The government has taken steps to manage the effects of climate change, and more attention will be given to this issue. However, given the scale of environmental challenges India faces, policy measures are unlikely to reduce the country's vulnerability to climate change significantly.
India is already the world's third-largest consumer of energy, and demand will continue to grow over the forecast period. In order to add to its energy capacity while also meeting its commitments under the Paris climate accord, the government is making efforts to diversify from conventional sources of energy, such as coal-fired thermal power stations. India is one of the most active members of the International Solar Alliance (ISA), which promotes the transition to solar energy, and the ISA has established its headquarters in Gurgaon. The ISA aims to raise US$1trn in financing and to install 1,000 GW of solar capacity across its 121 member states by 2030. India is likely to utilise the platform provided by the ISA to leverage funding and assistance from developed nations and multilateral agencies to develop its own solar sector.
The country has also been making strides in developing wind energy. The National Institute for Wind Energy has estimated India's wind-power potential at 302 GW, with the states of Tamil Nadu, Gujarat, Karnataka, Maharashtra and Rajasthan having the greatest potential. Serious efforts in this regard have started; India's installed capacity in wind energy is now the world's fourth largest. According to the National Institution for Transforming India (NITI Aayog, the government's policy think-tank), around 304m people in India lived without electricity in 2017. Consequently, even as renewable sources of energy will make advances, the significant gap between supply and demand in energy will mean that coal-fired thermal power plants remain critical to India's energy mix.
This year The Economist Intelligence Unit has developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we find that the Indian economy will be 3.7% smaller in 2050 than it would have been otherwise without this hit to growth.
Migration and urbanisation
India will continue to see an influx of immigrants to urban areas, as workers move to cities in search of better-paying employment. Increasingly, public policy, which has long been rural-oriented, will tilt more towards resolving overcrowding, poor housing conditions, anaemic infrastructure and declining sustainability in urban centres. The construction of urban mass-transit systems will increase sharply, along with other urban infrastructure such as sewerage and power grids. Demands for more public housing will also grow louder. However, the enormous scale of these challenges and limited government effectiveness will temper the pace of progress.
The biggest challenge for policymakers will be skilling and training the workforce of rural immigrants, as they will largely move from the low-skilled agriculture sector and will be less proficient in the expertise required for productive employability in services and industry. Meanwhile, emigration to Western countries, particularly the US and Canada, as well as to the prosperous states of the Gulf, such as the UAE, will remain strong. Consequently, India will remain one of the largest recipients of remittances in the coming years.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit

Domestic data
GDP: Central Statistics Office; all national-accounts data are for fiscal years beginning April 1st of year shown

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Chile--highlights: Political outlook
Sebastián Piñera of the centre-right Chile Vamos coalition won the 2017 presidential election and took office in March 2018. A change to a more proportional electoral system challenged the traditional domination of centre-left and centre-right coalitions; as a result, no coalition currently holds a majority in either house of Congress. This makes policymaking difficult, and means that the legislative agenda will move slowly and be kept broadly centrist, in order to attract the necessary votes. Government effectiveness will remain the best in the region, owing to competent officials and cross-party support for pro-market policies. The country ranks highly in measures of stability and rule of law.
Chile--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.63 8.01 20 16 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile remains in top position in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings for Latin America over the forecast period. Its strengths include a long-standing, well-functioning market economy, an open foreign investment regime, and deep and sophisticated capital markets. The country will remain at the forefront of regional and Pacific Rim integration efforts, underpinning an already extensive free-trade framework. Improvements to education and infrastructure-including renewable energy supply during the forecast period-will further underpin the environment for business.

Annual growth will average 3.1% in 2019-23. Although a faster pace of growth than the previous five-year period, it is still tepid compared with Chile's growth rates in the 1990s and during the commodities supercycle. Faster growth stems from a recovery in copper prices and investment, and will be supported by Chile's productive capacity, relatively good and improving infrastructure, and prized political and institutional stability. The current account will remain in deficit, even though the trade surplus is trending upwards, owing to higher debt repayments and profit repatriation by multinational firms, but it will remain manageable. Deficits will be financed through capital inflows, particularly foreign direct investment (FDI).
Chile--highlights: Demographic outlook
Population (m) 2013 2018 2023

 Female 8.9 9.5 9.7
Period averages (%)   2014-18 2019-23
Population growth   1.3 0.5
Working-age population growth   1.2 0.1
Labour force growth   1.8 1.0
At an estimated 18.7m in 2018, Chile's small population is growing, but at a slower rate than those of most of its neighbours. Chile's birth rate has fallen steadily in recent years, from 16.4 per 1,000 people in 2002-07 to 13.9 per 1,000 in 2014-18, and is forecast to slow further, to 13.1 per 1,000 in 2019-23. Chile also has an older demographic profile than most in the region, with those aged 65 and over accounting for more than 10% of the total population, a proportion that is set to rise to 14% by 2023. The labour force is forecast to grow by an average of 1% in the forecast period. Health indicators are broadly comparable with those of other OECD economies.

Ample government infrastructure concessions and expansion in the renewables sector will provide opportunities. Chile's market opportunities are constrained by its small population; however, persistently high wages, combined with political stability and effective economic management, will continue to attract investment. Rising household consumption from 2018-bolstered by high employment, increased real incomes and low inflation-will lift consumer expenditure. High income inequality will gradually recede.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Broad consensus in favour of orthodox monetary and fiscal policies will underpin long-term economic growth, but challenges from new left-wing political parties are a risk. Free-trade agreements within and outside the region will help to attract foreign investment. Average annual GDP growth is forecast to reach 2.8% in 2019-30, moderating to 2.3% in 2031-50. The capital stock will continue to grow and investment will rise to 24% of GDP. However, as growth in the working-age population slows, so will the increase in labour supply, causing economic growth to become more dependent on productivity gains.

Background: In 1988 the military ruler, Augusto Pinochet, lost a referendum that would have allowed him to stay in office. Instead, the centre-left Concertación de Partidos por la Democracia coalition (later Nueva Mayoría-NM) won the December 1989 general election and the next four presidential elections. A realignment of forces helped the centre-right to win the 2010 election. Since then, there has been alternation between governments on the right and left. Michelle Bachelet of the NM, who was first elected president in 2006-10 before being succeeded by Sebastián Piñera (2010-14), was re-elected in the 2013 election. In 2018 Ms Bachelet was succeeded again by Mr Piñera, who took office in March 2018.
Political structure: The political system is presidential, with a bicameral legislature that comprises a 43-seat Senate (the upper house) and a 155-seat Chamber of Deputies (the lower house). The presidential term is four years, and consecutive re-election is not permitted. This structure may be subject to change-possibly towards a more prime-ministerial model-as part of ongoing constitutional reform. The judiciary is independent, but the executive exerts some influence through the nomination of temporary judges and the control of promotions to the Supreme Court. Monetary policy is directed by the autonomous Banco Central de Chile (the central bank). Chile has 15 regions, 54 provinces and 346 municipalities.
Policy issues: The two major coalitions broadly agree on maintaining a liberal-market economy, and an orthodox monetary and fiscal policy framework. However, a new left-wing coalition (the third-largest force in Congress) has demanded more social spending. A new proportional electoral system will see issues-such as regional devolution and a conflict involving the Mapuche indigenous people-rise up the political agenda as politics becomes more fragmented.
Taxation: Corporate income tax is assessed at two stages. Declared profit is subject to a 27% first-category tax (FCIT). When profit is distributed to shareholders or partners, a 35% second-category tax applies, minus a credit for FCIT. Tax rate on dividends and interest payments to non-banks is 35%. Royalties and fees transferred abroad are subject to a 30-35% withholding tax. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at 19%.
Foreign trade: The general import tariff rate is 6%, but the trade-weighted effective average rate is below 2%, owing to preferences granted through trade accords. Exports in 2018 were worth US$75.5bn; imports stood at US$70.8bn.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Present government: Sebastián Piñera of the centre-right Chile Vamos (CV) coalition, who served as president in 2010-14, won the December 2017 presidential run-off and took office for a new four-year term on March 11th 2018. CV is chiefly composed of the conservative Unión Demócrata Independiente, and the centre-right Renovación Nacional (Mr Piñera's party), but also includes the smaller Evolución Política (Evópoli). No party holds a majority in either the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) or the Senate (the upper house), but CV holds the largest number of seats in both chambers. The centre-left opposition is comprised of the parties of the former Nueva Mayoría (NM) coalition, which led the previous government (2014-18), and under a previous configuration, the Concertación de Partidos por la Democracia, governed Chile from 1990 to 2010. After the last election, the left-wing Frente Amplio emerged as the third-largest force in Congress. The centrist Partido Democracia Cristiana (PDC) broke from NM in April 2018, and currently forms the fourth-largest bloc in the lower house and third-largest in the upper house. Independent parties, which are largely on the centre-left, also have a congressional presence.
CV holds 19 of 43 seats in the upper house and 72 of 155 in the lower house. It will need to rely on votes from other coalitions or dissident members of the opposition to pass legislation. Votes are most likely to come from the PDC, but support will be on an ad hoc basis, as the PDC has ruled out an alliance with CV and declared itself firmly on the left. Nevertheless, the necessity to win opposition support will keep policymaking broadly centrist.

Political outlook: Political stability
The Piñera government lacks an outright legislative majority and faces a difficult task advancing its reform agenda in the context of a fragmented legislature. Mr Piñera reshuffled his cabinet in mid-June, making changes to six ministries, as he seeks economy-boosting reforms. His priorities include modernising the tax and pension systems, and reducing red tape to stoke investment. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects reforms to be piecemeal and modest, as right-leaning policies will be met with stiff resistance from left-leaning parties in Congress. A change in the electoral process for 2017 produced a more proportional political system, ending the traditional dominance of two (centre-left and centre-right) coalitions. As a result, no coalition presently holds a majority in either the lower house or the upper house, weakening political stability and effectiveness.
The opposition parties of the now defunct NM (2013-18) have failed so far to recover from their 2017 electoral defeat, with no clear leadership or consensus among them on how to approach Mr Piñera's government. Left-wing elements have vowed to oppose the administration, while those in the centre have flirted with being more co-operative. However, such support will be ad hoc, with the legislative agenda prone to blocking tactics. Policy differences between Chile's two big coalitions will widen as decades of broad policy consensus becomes diluted. To date, only the government's proposed pension reform shows signs of advancing, having been approved by the lower house. Other reforms on tax, migration, labour and healthcare have stalled in Congress. The stalemate is undermining support for both Mr Piñera and the government, although the president's support in opinion polls has recovered slightly from its low of 28% in May to 32% in June, after the cabinet reshuffle. The risk of political gridlock will also increase from mid-2020 onwards, as municipal and then general electoral considerations re-emerge and as the economy faces headwinds.
Mr Piñera has taken a progressive stance on indigenous rights, including constitutional recognition for the Mapuche, Chile's largest indigenous group, which should gain cross-coalition support. Progress in this area should help to ease a slow-burning conflict in Chile's southern regions. The risk of renewed protests in other areas will persist, especially regarding education and pensions, but we do not expect demonstrations to reach the same intensity as in Mr Piñera's last term in office (2010-14).
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Chile's system of government is considered the most effective and technically adept in Latin America, owing in part to a high degree of political stability and a highly professional bureaucracy. This is unlikely to change substantively in the forecast period, but there are several risks to political effectiveness. Corruption in Chile remains low, even compared with OECD standards-it is the 27th least corrupt country in the world-according to the 2018 Corruption Perceptions Index prepared by Transparency International (a global anti-corruption watchdog). Nevertheless, recent years have seen several prominent scandals in both the public and private sectors, which have fuelled public resentment. The scale of wrongdoing, however, is not equivalent to current scandals in other countries in the region, and public prosecutors have so far proved energetic in bringing a number of perpetrators to account.
Since the peaceful transition to democracy in 1990, successive administrations have operated with a broad consensus around maintaining the open and liberal economic model instituted by the military regime of Augusto Pinochet (1973-90), while also strengthening democratic institutions. However, the 2017 election, under new electoral rules, resulted in a more fractured legislature, returning Chile to its pre-dictatorship political landscape of coalitions of the right, left and centre. Although this might slow the legislative process, it will also have the effect of promoting consensus (in order to pass legislation), and will result in broadly centrist policymaking. Political engagement and turnout remain low, posing a challenge to long-term confidence in the system. Efforts to promote regional government and divest power to the regions (Chile is highly centralised) could also increase the quality of government. Given that no coalition holds a majority-a situation that could continue in future governments-dramatic policy shifts are unlikely. Changes to organic constitutional provisions require a four-sevenths majority in both houses, while passing bills to reinterpret or modify the constitution require a three-fifths and two-thirds majority respectively.
A civil-service reform in 2003 helped to increase meritocracy by reducing the number of political appointees at the head of government agencies by over 80%, and by making civil servants accountable to an independent directorate. Official transparency and efficiency has also been fostered by the centralisation of the procurement tenders of all government departments and public-sector agencies into a single online platform.
Chile's judicial system is relatively efficient and transparent. The criminal justice system was modernised over a period of six years, following reforms in 1999 that created an office of public prosecutions and established a legal aid service, as well as a new code for penal procedures. Chile ranks highly in most measures of rule of law, protection of private property and overall institutional effectiveness.
Political outlook: Election watch
Presidential and legislative elections were last held in late 2017. The next elections to take place will be regional and municipal polls in October 2020. Traditionally, the coalition that wins these has gone on to win the presidential and legislative elections the following year; the next presidential and legislative elections will take place in late 2021. Consecutive presidential re-election is prohibited; it is too early to predict who the candidates will be at the next presidential election, but there has been alternation between the left and right since 2010.
Political outlook: International relations
The Piñera government will maintain generally solid relations with the US and with other Latin American countries. It will also seek to strengthen ties with Asia, and particularly with China, as a means of accelerating economic growth and investment in 2019-23. Bilateral trade between China and Chile rose by 24% year on year to US$42.8bn in 2018, and will expand further following the enlargement of the reciprocal list of free-trade items, which came into effect in March 2019. Chile will also seek to improve ties with the region through the Pacific Alliance-an integration project that also includes Peru, Colombia and Mexico-and through Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, the members of which are Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay). Relations with neighbouring Bolivia will remain complicated, as they are clouded by border disputes. Chile will continue to condemn the undemocratic Venezuelan regime.

Chile's investment climate will remain the most attractive in Latin America in 2019-23 according to The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings (BER), which compare the quality and attractiveness of investment conditions in 82 of the world's largest economies.
A liberal trade and regulatory regime will support the investment climate
Chile ranks first in the region and 16th globally in the 2019-23 forecast period, boosted by its long-standing and well-functioning market economy, open investment regime, strong fiscal position, sophisticated capital markets, and large network of free-trade agreements (FTAs). In all of the component areas that make up the BER, Chile either consolidates its position or makes marginal improvements during 2019-23, facilitating a slight improvement in its underlying score and rising four places in the global ranking.
Chile's policy towards foreign investment, private enterprise and competition, and its macroeconomic environment, are its greatest strengths in terms of the business environment. This reflects the legacy of a long-running commitment to liberalising the foreign investment regime and opening trade.
A combination of a well-qualified labour force (by regional standards), firm rule of law, a large network of FTAs and a regulatory framework that entices foreign investment has cemented Chile's position in both the global and regional rankings. There are several reforms under debate in Congress that, if passed, would improve the operating environment further, relating to pensions, tax and labour laws. Our underlying expectation is that most of these measures will eventually pass, albeit in a diluted form.

Business environment outlook: Chile's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Government focuses on improving the business climate through simplification of tax processes.
2021-23: Cutting of red tape with investor-friendly measures is possible.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Investment regime remains among the world's most liberal. Investment promotion agency maintains investor-friendly policies, focusing on areas in which Chile has a competitive advantage, seeking to move beyond natural resources.
2021-23: Chile's network of bilateral double-taxation and investment protection accords widens further.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Narrow import-tariff dispersion (0-6%) and free capital flows owing to multiple free-trade agreements.
2021-23: Export development remains a policy priority, and government moves to diversify trade away from its dependence on the US and China.
Taxes
2019-20: Corporate tax structure simplified to boost investment, but tax cuts unlikely. Maximum personal rate lowered.
2021-23: Simplification of tax code, including new tax-savings mechanisms.
Financing
2019-20: Government-backed loan guarantees available. Domestic long-term interest rates are high, and bank lending practices are conservative. Large firms retain reasonable access to bond markets.
2021-23: Further measures to facilitate financing for small businesses, particularly new ventures.
The labour market
2019-20: Reforms to labour regime implemented, strengthening trade unions and reducing flexibility further.
2021-23: Liberalisation of working arrangements, along with performance-related pay in the public sector.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Generally good telecommunications; technological infrastructure is expanded further. Investment in power generation and highway network continues, but energy sector remains vulnerable to shortages.
2021-23: Upgrading of transport infrastructure through concessions. New energy investment comes on stream-following connection between north and central grids-benefiting the expansion of non-conventional renewable sources.
Technological readiness
2019-20: "Start-Up Chile" programme supported by the government continues to attract small technology firms.
2021-23: Government focuses on upgrading digital infrastructure, including an expansion of rural broadband, and public WiFi hotspots.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.3 8.9 10 6 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile's global rank for its macroeconomic environment improves noticeably in the forecast period, lifting it to sixth place in this category (marking one of the strongest areas of the business environment). The country cements its position as the most stable and resilient economy in Latin America. Real GDP growth is forecast to be relatively firm, at just over 3% per year in 2019-23, as inflation-although rising slightly-will remain well within the 2-4% target band set by the Banco Central de Chile (BCCh, the central bank). We expect the government to make reasonable progress on its pledge of reducing the fiscal deficit owing to spending restraint and higher average copper prices from 2020, which in turn will facilitate a drop in already low levels of public debt. Fiscal responsibility legislation has been in place since 2006, backed by two sovereign wealth funds that held combined assets of US$25.3bn in June (around 8% of GDP). This will continue to cushion the economy from volatility in copper prices and the risk of natural disasters by allowing it to implement countercyclical fiscal policies.
Fiscal prudence and low levels of debt support macroeconomic stability
Chile's macroeconomic environment will remain supported by a solid institutional framework and a general consensus favouring orthodox fiscal and monetary policies, free markets, and integration in the world economy. The central bank has been independent for three decades, and its autonomy is unlikely to come under threat in the forecast period. The BCCh is complemented by an efficient banking supervisory body, the Superintendencia de Bancos e Instituciones Financieras, which has helped to maintain a modern and well-capitalised banking sector that remains vigorous and has proved resilient to external shocks. The securities and insurance regulator, the Comisión del Mercado Financiero, and the pensions supervisor, the Superintendencia de Pensiones, are also part of the regulatory landscape.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.5 8.8 8 6 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile will remain the regional leader in policy toward private enterprise
Decades of consistent market-friendly policy and reforms keep Chile in pole position in Latin America, while the global ranking improves by two places for policy towards private enterprise and competition. Following various privatisation programmes-mostly in the late 1980s under the military regime of Augusto Pinochet (1973-90)-Chile has only a small number of companies left in state hands (most notably Codelco, the world's largest copper producer). Governments on both the right and left have pursued market-orientated solutions to economic problems. In recent years red tape has been significantly reduced-for instance, since 2013 a company can be created online in a single day and without cost. According to the World Bank's Doing Business 2019 report, Chile ranked 56th out of 190 countries.
Following a period of strained relations between the business community and the former president, Michelle Bachelet, the return of Sebastián Piñera to the presidency has been largely welcomed by the private sector, given his economic track record during his first term in office (2010-14), as well as his campaign promise to adopt more pro-market policies, including a simplification of the tax rules, modernisation of the environmental evaluation system to speed up the permitting process and a reduction of red tape. Although a fragmented legislature will slow progress, we expect some improvements on these fronts during Mr Piñera's current four-year term.
In an effort to reduce unnecessary bureaucracy, in May 2018 the government launched the Oficina de Grandes Proyectos Sustentables (GPS), which is located in the economy ministry and serves as a one-stop shop for investors. In March 2019 the government estimated that around 220 investment projects have been registered for the 2019-23 period, representing an estimated US$70bn in investment and the potential to create 30,000 new jobs. The government has tasked the ministry with identifying and removing other investment bottlenecks.
The platform "empresa en un día" (company in a day) was launched by the first Piñera government in 2013 to spur entrepreneurship. Since then, over 400,000 companies have been created in Chile. In 2018 over 132,000 new businesses were created-a 12% increase from 2017 and the largest annual registration since the system was introduced. The total number of companies registered in Chile now exceeds one million, of which 95% are small, 4% are medium-sized and 1% are large. According to the national statistics institute, small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) generate around 65% of all jobs.
The state directly controls a handful of companies and holds stakes in another 22 businesses (as of end-2018) operating under the nominal oversight of the Sistema de Empresas Públicas (Public Enterprise System). State-owned companies are meant to generate value through fiscal transfers from their profits and by pursuing initiatives that improve social welfare but are insufficiently attractive to private-sector investors. They contribute to development targets in areas such as communications, defence, energy and natural resources, geographical integration, and transport. There have been no major sales of government holdings since 2012; given the state's generally minor stakes, there is little scope for further privatisations.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
9.6 9.6 3 3 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile's underlying score for policy towards foreign investment is its strongest in terms of the business environment. The country is ranked third globally and remains the top-ranked in Latin America (by some margin) during 2019-23. Policy is open and pro-business, based on a constitutionally guaranteed principle of non-discrimination between local and foreign investors. Inward foreign direct investment (FDI) flows have fallen recently, at US$6.1bn in 2018, from US$20bn-30bn in 2011-15, but a solid track record on this front means that the stock of inward FDI per head is high, at US$11,300 in 2018 (compared with just over US$13,000 in the US). The country's natural resources and its long track record of economic and political stability, along with its openness to foreign investment, will keep it among the largest FDI recipients in the region.
Copper will remain a major investment draw
Chile will remain one of the world's top destinations for copper mining investment. The Comisión Nacional del Cobre (Cochilco, the state copper authority) has previously indicated that it believes mining investment will total close to US$66bn in 2018-28, with firms attracted by the country's vast mineral wealth, close proximity to coastal ports and reputation for political and economic stability. A rebound in metal prices (demand for copper and lithium, for example, is expected to increase in the forecast period)-paired with the government's pro-market policies-is likely to push inward FDI moderately higher during 2019-23. We forecast a gradual increase in FDI in the forecast period, at close to US$10bn by 2023.
InvestChile shifts its focus to attract all kinds of investment
Unlike the previous administration, which adopted sector-specific policies to attract foreign investment-focusing on the mining, energy, food and tourism industries-the Piñera government has adopted more of a non-discriminatory, multi-sectoral approach. The economy minister, José Ramón Valente, has said that the government investment promotion agency, InvestChile, will not just focus on attracting FDI or on greenfield projects, but will also promote external investment through the foreign acquisition of local companies to develop local industry, working closely with the recently created GPS office.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.7 8.7 27 27 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile has more FTAs than any other country
Chile's trade and foreign-exchange regime will remain broadly open during the forecast period, with the underlying score and rankings remaining unchanged. The country has a low trade-weighted average effective import tariff rate as a result of its large network of FTAs and various economic association agreements. As of 2018 these total 26 agreements and involve more than 64 countries, which account for over 86% of global GDP and more than 64% of the global population. The most important are FTAs signed with the EU (February 2003), the US (January 2004), China (October 2006) and Japan (August 2007). Chile also has FTAs with South Korea, Malaysia, Turkey, the European Free-Trade Association (consisting of Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland), Canada, Central America, Australia, Vietnam, Hong Kong and Mexico. Chile is also a member of the dynamic Pacific Alliance free-trade bloc-together with Mexico, Colombia and Peru-and has more limited agreements with India, New Zealand, Singapore and Brunei. These FTAs offer Chilean firms a potential market of over 4bn people, as 94% of Chile's trade is conducted on a preferential basis. Furthermore, Chile offers an unusually narrow range of import tariff dispersion, ranging from zero to 6%. The country has no exchange restrictions affecting capital or trade flows, but there are reporting formalities with respect to foreign investment exceeding US$10,000.
The Piñera government will continue to play an active role in seeking to deepen ties with other Latin American countries. In November 2018 Chile signed an FTA with Brazil, just before the former president, Michel Temer, left office. The new Brazilian president, Jair Bolsanaro, is likely to proceed with efforts to ratify the agreement. The Chilean government also began negotiations with Ecuador towards an FTA. An agreement with Uruguay was signed in October 2016 and came into effect at the end of 2018. Chile has also modernised its FTA with Canada to include a new chapter on investments.
Chile will continue to deepen its regional integration with Asia-Pacific economies. In March a modernised FTA between Chile and China came into force, making Chile the first individual country to upgrade its FTA with China. The agreement deepens trade liberalisation in goods and services, and adds chapters on e-commerce and the environment. Building on its commitment to boosting trade with Asia, in November 2018 Chile signed a co-operation agreement with China on the latter's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), along with agreements to streamline customs procedures and update protocols for the bilateral trade of agricultural products. The authorities are also negotiating a deepening of the FTA with South Korea.
With the failure of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) following the decision of the US president, Donald Trump, to pull the US from the deal, Chile and the ten other remaining countries signed the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) in March 2018. Mr Piñera submitted it to Congress in November and it was approved in the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) after a lengthy debate in April. We expect the Senate (the upper house) to ratify the bill in a vote in August. We believe that Chile will benefit from greater external demand through increased market access, although this will occur gradually as countries incrementally reduce tariffs.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.4 7.8 17 14 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The government is seeking to simplify the current tax system
Chile's score for tax policy improves slightly in the forecast period, allowing it to rise to 14th place globally in the ranking, with the country remaining best-ranked in the Latin America region. Total taxes remain relatively low by international comparison, but filing procedures are onerous. According to the Doing Business 2019 report, it takes 296 hours a year to prepare, file and pay corporate income tax, value-added or sales tax, and labour taxes, compared with an OECD high-income average of 159 hours. The tax regime underwent major reform in 2014. Although the backbone of the reform was an increase in corporate taxes, it created a dual-taxation system that, for many in the private sector, was too complicated to implement fully. As a result, the government signed into law a "reform to the reform" in February 2016 that left only one system in place, the so-called semi-integrated system, in which companies pay a 27% corporate tax rate, and shareholders also pay income tax, but with businesses permitted to deduct some earnings if these are reinvested. The second mechanism of the original system, which establishes a corporate tax rate of 25% along with a 10% income-tax levy on shareholders, remains an option for family-run and small businesses.
During his 2017 presidential campaign, Mr Piñera promised that he would lower the corporate tax rate from 27% to 25%, the average of its OECD peers. However, Mr Piñera has since backtracked, stating that the government will leave the corporate tax rate at current levels, citing a weaker economy and the need to raise additional revenue to fund social programmes and other fiscal spending. A bill submitted to Congress in August 2018 leaves the corporate tax rate unchanged, but this will then serve as credit against income tax. Instead, Mr Piñera is pursuing efforts to simplify the tax code by fully integrating the corporate and personal tax regime. The bill also created a special "SME clause," with a corporate tax rate of 25%, aimed at benefiting companies with annual sales of up to 50,000 Unidades de Fomento (an inflation-linked accounting unit) equivalent to around US$2m. Congress has not yet passed the reform bill, owing to opposition from the political left, which argues that the measures will boost inequality. We expect the bill to come into effect in 2021.
Concerns that meagre pension benefits will force people into post-retirement poverty have led Chilean workers to demand nationalisation of the system. The president is implacably opposed to this idea but has been seeking to address concerns through a pension reform law submitted to Congress in October 2018. Through the proposed reform, the government wants to introduce a new employer's contribution-equivalent to 4% of wages-and beef up a solidarity component of transfers to the poorest pensioners by raising the basic pension rate. Increased payouts for women and those who voluntarily delay their retirement are also possible. However, lawmakers are pressing for further concessions. In July the government conceded that pension fund management would be opened up to new entrants to increase competition; there has been widespread criticism of Chile's oligopoly of six providers. We expect eventual passage of the reform, although the government is likely to make further concessions in order to win the necessary legislative support.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.1 8.5 8 9 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The financial sector is well developed, with a solid institutional framework
Chile remains the leader in Latin America in terms of securing corporate finance, although its global ranking slips by one place in 2019-23. Its capital market is sophisticated, and has been growing in terms of liquidity and market capitalisation, aided by a solid institutional and legal framework. This has involved rapid adoption of new financial instruments, the appearance of new intermediaries and payment systems, and a continued updating of rules, regulations and methods of official supervision. Despite Chile's small population and comparatively low levels of GDP per head, stockmarket capitalisation is high, at around US$246bn at the end of June. The country's privately run pension funds (AFPs) are by far the main players on the demand side. At the end of June 2019 AFPs were managing a total of US$219bn (up from US$202bn a year earlier), of which around 58% is invested in Chile. Insurance companies operating in the country are also substantial investors.
Chilean companies with solid credit ratings will continue to have good access to long-term finance through credits and leasing, and large companies will retain access to a variety of other options, such as stock and bond issues, as well as a competitive and flexible syndicated loan market for maturities of up to ten years. Blue-chip businesses will have access to long-term funding locally-through bank loans with maturities of up to seven years, or local-bond issues with maturities of up to 30 years-owing to the use of the Unidad de Fomento, which eliminates inflation risk.
Healthy economic fundamentals will continue to allow large corporates to access capital and bond markets. Credit terms for companies in Chile will be heavily influenced by shifts in the global financial environment, with the July 2019 cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank)-and the expectation that further cuts are likely-supporting credit access at reasonable rates. Chilean companies will continue to benefit from some of the lowest yields among Latin American borrowers and, even in the event of liquidity difficulties, firms will be supported by Chile's strong international reserves position.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.5 6.8 27 21 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile performs less well in the labour market category. Nevertheless, its score and ranking improve in 2019-23 owing to education reforms, which we anticipate will increase the supply of educated and skilled workers in the forecast period, lifting Chile to 21st place globally (and remaining second in the region). These were initiated under the Bachelet government (2014-18) to address long-running deficiencies in the country's education system, which-although better than that of many neighbouring countries-lags behind that of the developing Asia region and other countries in the OECD (of which Chile is a member). The measures expand access to pre-school, university and technical education. Over the coming years, Chile will see 15 new career and technical-education centres opened across the country (one in each region) for vocational education. Businesses have long complained that the labour regime is too rigid. It offers strong worker protections through restrictive regulations and high firing costs (one month's wage per year worked in the company).
Labour reform is in its early stages of implementation
A labour reform approved in 2017 strengthened unions, as it expanded the categories of workers who can join a union, set a floor for negotiations (not permitting the weakening of workers' benefits) and prohibited the replacement of striking workers. It also prohibited the extension of benefits to non-union members. So far, the impact of the reform has been muted (only 9% of workers belong to a union, although the level is higher in the mining sector).
The government plans to introduce proposals to Congress to address outstanding issues that hamper the labour market. In a three-pronged approach, the first is a proposal to reform the national training and employment system. The goal is free tuition for the majority of students in vocational and technical centres, contingent on economic growth and the state of the public finances. The second prong relates to changes to make Chile's statutory working arrangements more flexible; these proposals were submitted to Congress in May 2019. The third prong, which has yet to be presented to Congress, will deal with modifying collective bargaining and unionisation regulations. Similar to other reform proposals, we expect slow progress on the back of congressional opposition, with eventual passage in a watered-down form.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.8 7.3 28 26 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Chile retains first place in the regional ranking for infrastructure in the forecast period and climbs to 26th in the global ranking. The country's telecommunications and technological infrastructure is modern, particularly by regional standards, as the regulatory system for telecoms encourages competition and the early adoption of new technologies. The transport infrastructure is resilient and mostly withstands regular seismic events and other natural disasters. A series of natural disasters have impacted the country since 2010, including: an earthquake and a tsunami in 2010 in the centre-south region; earthquakes, tsunamis and floods in the north in 2014-15; the Calbuco volcano eruption of 2015; and wildfires in the centre-south in 2017. Virtually all damaged infrastructure has since been restored.
Significant funding will continue to be channelled into transport infrastructure. A new underground railway line in the capital, Santiago, opened in November 2017. The government is planning to complete three new lines (numbered 7, 8 and 9), as well as extending three existing lines, by 2026. This would increase Santiago's urban and suburban rail network-which is already one of the most extensive metro systems in Latin America-from 160 km to 296 km. Additional transport funding will be allocated to the two largest metropolitan areas outside the capital, Gran Valparaíso and Gran Concepción, aimed at alleviating some of the congestion that these areas have been experiencing. Chiloé Island will be connected to the mainland through a 2.8-km bridge within the forecast period.
New infrastructure plan aims to accelerate progress
Chile's robust infrastructure is largely attributable to a successful concession system that was launched in the 1990s. Since the late 2000s, however, the number of new infrastructure investment projects has waned as the original group of projects reached completion. Mr Piñera aims to breathe new life into infrastructure, unveiling an ambitious US$20bn programme in July that will cover the period to 2023. The new investment plan aims to secure US$14.4bn of private capital for investment in concessions, with about 50% of the total being spent on roads. The remainder will go on airports, hospitals, dams, water supply and drainage. To kick-start the programme, the government has announced that it has earmarked almost US$1.4bn of public money to fast-track investment in 2019-20. Almost half of this will be used to accelerate the implementation of complementary improvements to existing concession contracts. In addition, the plan includes US$388m for purely state-funded investment projects. These funds will largely be allocated to hospital projects currently under construction, as well as for improvements to roads, ports, airports, dams, irrigation and rural water systems.
The completion of a key transmission line will reduce costs further
Although energy infrastructure has been seen as the weakest part of Chile's infrastructure matrix, this has changed since Ms Bachelet's second term, with the implementation of a long-term strategy that extends beyond our forecast period (Energía 2050). Other improvements include a decline in the price of renewable energy-which helped to spur an increase in clean energy sources-and the connection between the north and central energy grids. These efforts have helped to contain the price of energy, which for years was a major hindrance to invest-ment.
The completion of a transmission line connecting the main north and central-south electricity grids will boost output from the growing non-conventional renewable energy (NCRE) sector, as the central-south is where most consumers are situated. NCRE projects already account for 18% of the country's energy supply, and are likely to meet a target of 20% of generation in 2020-five years ahead of schedule.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.2 7.8 28 29 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
This section, introduced as part of an upgrade to our rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-orientated the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption.
Chile's score for technological readiness is the highest in the region and 29th in the global ranking, supported by strong internet usage and efforts by successive governments to improve technological and innovative capacity. Nevertheless, investment in research and development (R&D) is low. According to latest OECD data, R&D investment in Chile was 0.4% of GDP in 2016, compared with an OECD average of 2.5%. Following four years of decline, investment in the telecoms sector rose by 9.7% in 2017 and by 6.2% in 2018, according to the Subsecretaría de Telecomunicaciones (Subtel, the telecoms regulator). Internet usage is high. As of March 2019 mobile 4G internet access stood at 82%, up from 66% a year earlier. Mobile subscriptions are also high, with 135 subscribers per 100 inhabitants at end-March, up from 126 per 100 a year earlier.
The local retail sector has made important efforts to strengthen its e-commerce strategy. According to the Cámara de Comercio de Santiago, the chamber of commerce of Santiago, e-commerce growth has averaged around 30% in recent years, with triple-digit growth in sales from sites such as Amazon (US) and AliExpress (China), and an accelerating move into e-commerce by smaller companies. Estimated growth of 30% in 2018 would take the value of e-commerce to US$5bn, accounting for around 6% of national retail sales.
The new science ministry will lead national science and technology policy
The Ministry of Science, Knowledge, Technology and Innovation was created in December 2018 and oversees all policies, programmes and plans designed to strengthen innovation in science and technology. The ministry has a technical advisory committee, which will periodically review its policies, and an inter-ministerial committee-comprised of the ministers of science, finance, economy and education-tasked with developing a national science policy.
As part of the tax reform bill currently before Congress, the government is proposing to introduce a 10% tax on international digital companies, including online retail giants such as Spotify (Sweden), Netflix (US) and the accommodation site AirBnB (US). However, there is speculation that the new rate may be as high as 19%, in line with the rate of value-added tax (VAT) and also with the OECD suggested rate. The bill does not affect ride-hailing services such as Uber (US) or Cabify (Spain), but a separate bill currently in Congress would require them to establish local subsidiaries.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The government led by the president, Sebastián Piñera, has continued with broadly sound macroeconomic policymaking. However, initial expectations of progress on business-friendly reforms under Mr Piñera are wavering, given little concrete progress so far amid pushback from a fragmented Congress. Given a more challenging economic environment for 2019-20-as economic growth in China, the US and Europe weakens-The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that Mr Piñera will make better progress with those aspects of his economic reform agenda that focus on bolstering domestic growth. The reform agenda includes changes to the tax system, but after a year of stalled negotiations in the legislature, the government presented changes in July 2019 that significantly diluted measures. We now expect the advancement of plans to integrate corporate and personal income-tax regimes, but for the impact to be far less business-friendly than the original proposal. Mr Piñera hopes to push the bill through Congress in time for the 2020 budget, although there are still risks to this timeline, given firm opposition from left-of-centre parties.
A pension reform bill is also making its way through Congress, prompted by public pressure for improved pension outcomes. The reform aims to boost the individual pension system by levying a new employer contribution, with the aim of boosting pension outcomes and increasing the amount of transfers to the poorest pensioners. We assume that the pension reform will pass, given its importance as a political issue, but the debate could continue into 2020.
The government aims to address weaknesses in productivity by creating new incentives for entrepreneurship and innovation, and by cutting red tape. To achieve the latter, it will seek to move more processes online and simplify the procedure for establishing small businesses. A major policy challenge is the diversification of the economy away from the dominant copper industry; the government is pushing for more productivity reforms and integration with the global economy. Mr Piñera is also placing great emphasis on infrastructure. His investment plans aim to raise as much as US$20bn-largely from the private sector in exchange for concession contracts-to improve inter-urban transport, water supply and irrigation, and to increase the rural presence of fibre-optic and wireless internet.
Other slated reforms include greater political autonomy for regional governments, allowing them to determine local investment priorities. Reforms to education and healthcare include universal free pre-schooling. In 2018 Congress approved the creation of the new Ministry of Science, Knowledge, Technology and Innovation. It will advise the president on improving science-related policies and increasing investment in research and development, which was just 0.4% of GDP in 2016, compared with an OECD average of 2.5%.
Energy policy will remain high on the agenda, as Chile-a net importer of oil-suffers from high costs and vulnerability to energy shortages; further tax incentives for investors in renew-ables are likely. The government is also likely to continue the controversial use of hydroelectric power in southern Chile. Greater concerns for the environment and better regulation have spurred investment in non-conventional renewables; these types of renewable sources are expected to make up 20% of the energy generation matrix by 2020 (from 17% currently). Mr Piñera has proposed targeting 75% of all energy generation from renewable sources by 2030, and 100% by 2040.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy
Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)
