Central government expenditure 23.5 23.5 23.2 23.6 23.5 23.6
Central government revenue 21.9 22.2 22.1 22.6 22.9 23.2
Central government balance -1.7 -1.3 -1.2 -1.0 -0.6 -0.5
Chile has typically been able to run a countercyclical fiscal policy, owing to its prudent policymaking. Nonetheless, we expect the fiscal deficit to narrow during the 2019-23 forecast period, reflecting changes to the fiscal rule. The rule sets a structural surplus target based on certain economic assumptions, including projected copper prices and long-term potential GDP growth. The finance minister, Felipe Larraín, wants to improve the framework, as overestimation of economic growth and the long-term copper price in recent years has allowed for higher spending and weakened the public finances. Mr Larraín has announced fiscal austerity measures for central government and state-owned companies. Current plans envisage the elimination of a total US$5bn (around 1.8% of 2018 GDP) from expenditure over four years.
Given the gradual nature of the intended cuts, the government's plan appears credible, and we believe that this will help to narrow the deficit over the forecast period. This process will be further supported by our forecast for higher copper prices in 2020-23. On this basis, we project that the fiscal deficit will gradually narrow from 1.7% of GDP in 2018, to 0.5% by 2023, assuming that fiscal austerity proceeds as expected and copper prices materialise as forecast. Following a dip in copper prices during 2019, our forecast is for the copper price to rise by an annual average of 5.9% in 2020-23. Faster consolidation will be precluded by weaker revenue growth in the face of a slowdown in global GDP in 2019-20, partly a consequence of the US-China trade war.
Public-sector debt will stabilise at 26.2% of GDP in 2020-21 (the same as the average for 2018-19), but will ease thereafter as the primary deficit narrows. Only 19% of central-government debt is external. The government will find it easy to access financing: its external bonds traded at yields of just 132 basis points above US Treasury bills in May-the lowest among Latin America's major economies, and well below the emerging-market average. In the event of a shock, the government could tap reserves held in its economic and social stabilisation fund, which stood at US$14.2bn in June, and a pension reserve fund, valued at US$10.4bn.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy

In June the Banco Central de Chile (BCCh, the central bank) cut the policy rate by 50 basis points, to 2.5%, citing the global economic slowdown and weak domestic economic activity, but recently signalled that it is unlikely to make further moves this year. We expect the policy rate to remain at 2.5%, before an expected cycle of 25-basis-point rate cuts in 2020 to counter the local fallout from a global slowdown. However, this is subject to risks if real GDP growth performs significantly below our current expectations (a forecast 2.6% expansion this year). This would bring the start of rate cuts forward to the year-end. Stimulus would then be gradually removed in 2021-22, as policy switches to a renewed tightening cycle.

Solid economic fundamentals support reasonably firm medium-term growth prospects, but Chile's open economy exposes it to global developments, particularly changes in prices and demand for commodities-minerals (mainly copper) account for around 50% of goods exports, and the country depends heavily on imported oil. Real GDP data from the first quarter show that growth remained flat in seasonally adjusted quarter-on-quarter terms, and available indicators for the second quarter were also fairly weak; on this basis we have revised our forecast for GDP growth in 2019 down from 3% to 2.6%. The drivers of this weakness have been both external and domestic. Chile appears to be feeling the effects of a slowdown in global trade growth; its export volumes fell substantially in the first quarter. This will have contributed to a contraction in investment, but the latter also reflects business concerns over a lack of progress on Mr Piñera's pro-business agenda so far. Given a lower base effect and stronger US real GDP growth, we expect growth to accelerate to 3.2% in 2020. That said, there are substantial risks to our forecast, particularly in the form of an intensified bilateral US-China trade war, which could weigh on demand in both countries, with knock-on effects for trade partners such as Chile. A recovery in US growth and rising copper prices will support annual average GDP growth of 3.2% in 2021-23. Although such rates represent a significant improvement from 2014-17, growth will be around half the rate posted during the commodities boom.
Private consumption growth will be supported by low real interest rates and falling unemployment. Fiscal austerity will keep government consumption growth muted. Investment will continue to grow, supported by public investment projects and resurgent copper investment as prices recover. External demand for copper, pulp and fruit exports, particularly from Asia, will make the external sector a net contributor to GDP.
On the supply side, the recent slowdown has been broad-based. A recovery in industrial activity experienced in 2018 has since lost momentum and activity, particularly in manufacturing, will remain tepid in 2019-20 as the external environment worsens. Mining output has also underperformed, but higher copper prices in 2020-21 will put a floor under the downtrend. Construction activity will be supported by investment in commercial projects and public works. Growth in services will be reasonable, aided by Chile's advanced retail, shipping and transport sectors, a growing tourism sector, and the country's role as a regional hub for business and financial services. Barring weather-related shocks, growth in agriculture will remain strong in 2019-23, supported by growing Asian demand for Chilean fresh fruit.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Mining will remain among the largest sectors of the economy over the forecast period. With around 170m tonnes in proven high-grade copper reserves (22% of the world's total in 2018)-which are advantageously situated close to the sea- Chile has been the favourite global destination for copper mining investment over the past two decades. This has made it by far the world's largest copper producer, with output of 5.8m tonnes in 2018, around 28% of the global total. Although copper prices are projected to be lower than in the 2006-13 boom years, the country will remain a competitive mining investment destination because of its favourable geological conditions, as well as its political and economic stability. The market is divided between Codelco, the state copper firm, and private mining companies, with private firms accounting for two-thirds of output. Codelco was nationalised in 1971 and is the largest copper-exporting company in the world. By law, the company is required to hand over all of its profits to the state. Major multinational mining companies with a presence in Chile include BHP Billiton (Australia), Rio Tinto (UK-Australia), Xstrata (Switzerland), Anglo-American (UK), Freeport McMoRan (US) and Grupo México (Mexico). There are also numerous local private companies, such as Antofagasta.
Output has weakened in recent years, mainly reflecting the decline of copper prices and ore grades. Output fell in 2016, and again in 2017 owing to a 43-day strike at Escondida, the country's largest mine, as well as flooding in several northern mines. Growth returned in 2018, as prices and investment recovered. Expected levels of investment should bring total Chilean production above the 6m-tonne mark by 2020, with further gains thereafter.
Declining ore grades have forced mines to invest heavily in order to maintain output and extend the working life of mines. Codelco's output will decline in 2020-21 as the transition to exploit deeper ore reserves temporarily harms production. Codelco estimates that it will need to spend around US$40bn over the next decade to extend the life of its ageing mines and explore for new ore reserves, and it is also exploring outside Chile. In order to support massive investment in Codelco, the government has moved to eliminate the Ley Reservada del Cobre (copper reserve law), under which Codelco hands over 10% of its gross export sales for the acquisition of weaponry and munitions by the military. Transfers to fund military purchases were required irrespective of the copper price and the impact on Codelco's finances, which has undermined its capacity to invest and the company's debt has risen to above US$14bn. However, these payments will be phased out gradually over 12 years and improvements to Codelco's investment capacity will occur in the medium term.
Codelco's investment plan comprises five major projects: the underground transformation of Chuquicamata (due in 2019); construction of a new mine level at the company's underground El Teniente mine (with start-up due in 2023); the expansion of processing capacity at its Rajo Inca and Andina mines (due in 2021 and 2025 respectively); and an expansion at the Radomiro Tomic mine (due for completion in 2021). Codelco's production reached 1.8m tonnes in 2018, down slightly from 1.84m tonnes in 2017. Although the company will struggle to maintain output at current levels in 2019-20, new capacity will steadily boost production from 2021 onwards.
Demand from Asia will continue to drive the market, particularly from a rapidly urbanising China, which currently accounts for around 40% of global copper demand. This will provide support for copper demand, but overall Chinese economic growth is expected to moderate in the years to come, and the price of copper will not return to the historical high of 400 US cents/lb in 2011, during the forecast period. Instead, after a trough to an average of 221 US cents/lb in 2016, copper prices have recovered and our forecast sees them edging steadily higher, averaging 295 US cents/lb in 2019-20, and rising to an average of 344 US cents/lb in 2021-23. Although lower than the 2011 peak, this is still high by historical standards.

Despite signs that monetary tightening will be less sharp in 2019 than initially expected, we nevertheless expect consumer price inflation to remain contained, owing to a relatively steady peso. In June the annual inflation rate was 2.3%, at the lower end of the BCCh's 2-4% target range, but we expect the rate to rise slightly to 2.8% by end-2019. Lower inflation so far this year has been driven by a fall in the price of energy and food products. We expect inflation to remain firmly within the 2-4% target range in 2020-23, reflecting the impact of a weaker economy in 2020 in particular, and strong confidence in the inflation-targeting framework, which helps to contain inflation expectations in the event of supply shocks.

As has been evident in recent months, the currency will remain vulnerable to shifts in copper prices and global risk sentiment. The current-account deficit will narrow in 2019-20 (after peaking in 2018) as import growth eases and higher copper prices in 2020 boost the trade surplus. The deficit will widen to 2.6% of GDP in 2021, owing to a larger primary income deficit-following rising debt-service obligations and profit repatriation by multinational firms based in Chile-before narrowing gradually to 1.9% in 2023. The trade surplus will fluctuate in a narrow range of 1-2% of GDP in 2019-23. The services deficit will remain broadly stable, averaging 1.4% of GDP in 2019-23 owing to steady tourist revenue flows. The secondary income (transfers) surplus will decline slightly as a share of GDP, reflecting higher outward workers' remittance flows due to a rise in inward migration.
Inward foreign direct investment (FDI) will rise in nominal terms, supported by a recovery in copper prices (the mining sector typically accounts for a large proportion of inward FDI flows), as well as renewed business confidence under the Piñera government. Nevertheless, as a percentage of GDP, inward FDI will remain below its highs in 2005-15, reflecting the post-commodity-boom era. Net portfolio inflows are expected to remain elevated in 2019-23. Chile's deep, open financial system will support high debt and equity-investment inflows in the medium term. Foreign-exchange reserves are forecast to rise to around US$43bn by end-2023, while import cover will decline slightly but remain adequate, at an average of 4.8 months of imports in 2022-23.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Chile
Stocks and flows
Despite its small size, Chile has historically been an important destination for foreign direct investment (FDI), particularly in its mining, energy and transport infrastructure sectors. FDI flows can fluctuate widely from year to year, often reflecting the fortunes of the copper mining industry. FDI fell dramatically between 2015 and 2017, from US$21.1bn to US$5.9bn. However, the decline bottomed out in 2018 and a recovery appears to be taking hold in 2019, with first-quarter FDI of US$2.4bn. Chile's favourable climate for foreign businesses pushed the stock of FDI to US$211.8bn in 2018, according to IMF data, resulting in an FDI stock/GDP ratio of 71%, compared with much smaller ratios for Brazil (40.8%) and Mexico (44.7%). Chile's importance as an investor in other regional markets has also increased in recent years, with a focus on the airline, shipping and retail sectors. However, outward flows have declined considerably in recent years, and totalled just US$4.8bn in 2017, down from an annual average of US$15.9bn in 2011-15. This reflected a global decline in crossborder mergers and acquisitions activity, and also political uncertainty throughout Latin America (where most Chilean outward investment flows) ahead of a busy election season in the region. A large stock of outward FDI in 2016 valued at US$95.4bn, equivalent to 34.4% of GDP, according to data from the Banco Central de Chile (the central bank), is testament to the success of Chilean firms abroad.
Origin and distribution
Chile's largest source of accumulated FDI stock was Brazil in 2017, which accounted for 14.6% of the total stock of FDI, up from 14.1% in 2016 according to the latest available central bank data. Argentina, Colombia, the US, Peru and Switzerland combined accounted for a further 35.8%. FDI broadly supports major investments in the mining, energy, agrarian (especially wine), wholesale and retail, telecommunications, financial services, and construction and infrastructure sectors. The latter is driven by foreign firms finding opportunities under the government's public-private partnership concessions. However, much of the FDI flowing into Chile is routed through tax havens such as the Bahamas, Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands, the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg and Panama-which between them contributed a further 28% of the debt stock in 2017-making it difficult to ascertain the true countries of origin. Regarding the sectoral distribution of FDI stocks, financial services accounted for 28.1% of the total in 2017, followed by mining (26.8%) and utilities (electricity, gas and water, at 5.7%). Other important sectors that have attracted significant foreign investment in recent years include manufacturing, transport, communications, real estate and business services, and retail.
Determinants
Chile's foreign investment regime, which has been in place for three decades, is one of the most liberal in the world. There is a well-respected principle of non-discrimination between local and foreign investors, who also enjoy additional protection as a result of the rapidly expanding network of investment-protection accords and double-taxation treaties signed with other countries. Generally sound regulation, combined with political and economic stability, and firm growth, have helped to support FDI inflows since the early 1990s. Moreover, Chile's managerial talent and well-qualified labour force (by regional standards), together with a strong rule of law, low crime rates and a large network of free-trade agreements (FTAs), have attracted a growing number of multinationals to use Chile's capital, Santiago, as a headquarters for Latin America. Moreover, the entry of Chile into the OECD in 2010 made it subject to various investment-related provisions and guidelines relating to liberalisation of capital movements and trade in services (including business and financial services, insurance, culture, tourism, and travel).
Impact
FDI had funded a growing share of gross fixed investment in Chile since the 1990s. In 2001-06 FDI funded 28% of gross fixed investment, contributing to the modernisation of infrastructure, including telecoms. The ratio rose to an annual average of 37.8% in 2007-15, owing to large mining and energy investments. Although it has slipped significantly since, reaching just 9.6% in 2018, it is expected to rise modestly to an annual average of 11.5% in 2019-23. FDI has made a major contribution in terms of the transfer of technology and managerial expertise, and has helped to foster competition between local and foreign firms in most major consumer markets, thereby providing Chileans with wider product ranges and lower prices than in neighbouring countries. Outward FDI has also grown as Chilean businesses expanded abroad, which has helped to establish many local firms as important regional players in their respective sectors. Although outward FDI flows dropped to a lowly US$1.9bn in 2018, from an annual average of US$11.7bn in 2008-17, this is still a robust level (outward FDI stock totalled US$95.4bn in 2017, according to the central bank). The fact that Chilean firms operated in a competitive domestic environment, well before regional peers had liberalised their own economies, has enabled businesses to position themselves successfully in neighbouring countries. This has been most evident in the retail sector, where firms such as Ripley, Paris and Falabella have aggressively expanded into other markets such as Peru, Argentina, Colombia and Brazil.
Potential
Chile will continue to attract large FDI inflows, owing to its transparent business operating conditions, political stability, a fundamentally sound economy, a huge network of FTAs, double-taxation and investment-protection accords, the most modern infrastructure in Latin America, and a growing pool of skilled labour. Nevertheless, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects FDI inflows to average a modest 2.4% of GDP annually in 2019-23, well below the level of 9% of GDP recorded in the bonanza years of 2008-15, during the commodities supercycle. The major acquisitions that have been common in the banking, telecoms and utilities sectors over the past two decades are unlikely to be repeated at the same pace, given already near-complete levels of economic openness and liberalisation. Nevertheless, the services sector (for example) will have ample opportunities in a market in which incomes are expected to continue to grow steadily. Renewable energy and related industries (such as lithium extraction) will also attract significant investment.

Working-age population grows slowly while overall demographic profile ages
Chile's annual population growth rate is forecast to decelerate gradually, from 1.4% in 2018 to close to zero by 2023. This will bring the total population to 19.2m in 2023, leaving Chile the least populated of Latin America's seven largest economies, and the only one of the seven with a population below 20m in 2023. The Instituto Nacional de Estadística de Chile (the national statistics office) projects that the rate of natural population growth-the crude birth rate minus the death rate-will continue to slow, from 8.6 per 1,000 people annually in 2010-15 to 7.4 in 2015-20, and to 6.2 in 2020-25. Although Chile displays a maturing demographic profile, the share of the working-age population will remain roughly stable, at around 68% of the total, in 2019-23. The rise in the share of the population above working age (13.6% will be 65 or older by 2023) will bring this figure to among the highest of the 12 Latin American countries covered by The Economist Intelligence Unit's Country Forecasts.
Chile has traditionally been an immigrant-receiving country, although not to the same extent as other South American nations such as Argentina or Brazil. Before the second world war, migration largely came from Europe and the Middle East, whereas since the 1970s most migrants have come from neighbouring Peru and Bolivia, with migrants often working in low-skilled jobs in agriculture and construction, or as domestic help. However, the pace of inward migration has accelerated since 2005, with the number of foreigners in the country increasing by 123% between 2005 and 2014, to around 416,000. This represented the highest proportion of foreign-born people living in Chile since 1920. In 2017 the government estimated that there were around 1m foreigners living in the country, of which around 300,000 were undocumented.
The surge in immigration is a consequence of the arrival of large numbers of Venezuelans and Haitians, prompted by humanitarian crises in their countries-and an increase in economic migrants from countries such as Colombia, Ecuador and the Dominican Republic-attracted by the higher wages and quality of life. We expect net inward migration to continue, given Chile's relative prosperity, but expect it to proceed at a more moderate pace than in 2015-17, as the government has instituted new laws to control the inward flow. Outward migration from Chile peaked during the 1973-90 dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet, but has slowed since then. The government estimates that around 500,000 Chileans live abroad, largely in Argentina, the US and Sweden.
Inward immigration will not boost overall population growth
Chile's basic health indicators are similar to those of other OECD countries, reflected in an average life expectancy of 80 years in 2019-23 (82.4 years for women and 77.5 years for men) and infant mortality of 6.1 per 1,000 live births. Demand pressures on the healthcare system are more akin to those of an industrialised country than a developing one. Infectious diseases and problems such as malnutrition are largely under control outside of small pockets of extreme poverty. However, age and "lifestyle-related" conditions associated with sedentary living and increased consumption of processed foods-such as obesity (75% of the population are overweight or obese), heart disease, colon cancer and diabetes-are on the rise.
Public healthcare policies will increasingly target obesity and unhealthy lifestyles. Only 2.5% of children under six years old were at risk of malnutrition in 2010, but 13.1% were overweight and 9.7% were obese. A universal healthcare plan, the Plan de Acceso Universal con Garantías Explícitas, was created in 2005 and offers fixed-price treatments for 80 conditions, including many expensive illnesses. The policy is sold at a fixed price and guarantees a maximum waiting time for medical attention for each condition. The public system covers around 80% of the population, against 17% covered by private insurance. The current government has introduced plans to reduce waiting times and increase the accessibility of care in the public system, but no major reforms to the provision of care are being contemplated.
Labour market reform will fail to incorporate informal workers
Modest growth in the working-age population will add some pressure to the labour market in the medium term. The economy was close to full employment in 2013-15, with average unemployment at a historical low of 5.8%. But weaker growth has caused unemployment to rise since then, to 7.2% in May-June 2019. This is still low by regional standards. Informality is estimated to cover around 36% of the labour force, according to the OECD; a low figure by Latin American standards (it is frequently over half, even in large economies). However, the informal sector represents a large pool of untapped labour, which could-if brought into the formal market-boost long-term growth and tax revenue.

After contracting, income per head in US dollar terms will grow in 2017
Chile's market opportunities are constrained by its small population, at 18.7m in 2018 (forecast to grow to 19.2m by 2023), but its high income-combined with a legacy of political stability and effective economic management-will continue to make the country an attractive destination for investment in the region. In the past three decades it has generally outperformed all of the other economies in Latin America in terms of GDP growth, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects slower but still firm expansion of 3.1% on average in 2019-23. Inequality has been decreasing over the past decade, allowing a larger share of the population to access consumer goods and services. Low levels of unemployment and rising real incomes have supported this trend. However, inequality is still pronounced, and there are also income discrepancies between metropolitan and northern regions, and less affluent regions in the centre-north and centre-south.
Potential for more exports and import purchases will remain strong
The impact of weaker economic growth and sharp peso depreciation will begin to ease, with Chile's GDP per head in US dollar terms rising to US$16,441 in 2019 (from US$15,921 in 2018), and forecast to reach US$20,433 by 2023. According to IMF data for 2018, Chile's GDP per head (as measured in US dollars at purchasing power parity) is by far the highest in Latin America (excluding Panama and certain Caribbean countries). Along with rising incomes, consumption will increase over the next five years (albeit at a slower pace than in the previous five-year period), to reach US$12,896 per head by 2023. Chile's open economy and abundance of natural resources have encouraged specialisation in export-orientated activities, particularly mining. Copper and other minerals have long been Chile's export revenue mainstays, but a slump in global prices in 2015-17 provided an additional spur to non-traditional exports after years of policies promoting trade diversification. Chile is the world's second-largest salmon exporter (despite having no native salmon population), the fifth-largest wine exporter (and seventh-largest producer) and the largest regional exporter of fresh fruit. The country also has a fast-growing tourism sector. However, Chile's potential is limited by its small manufacturing base, which is dominated by agro-industrial output. As a result, a large share of consumer goods-such as electronics, cars and clothing-are imported. The share of imports in household expenditure will rise in 2019-23 as higher levels of discretionary spending boost demand for more diverse and expensive foreign goods.

The Chilean market is competitive, with a strong foreign presence
Consumer markets in Chile are well developed and competitive, owing to a free-market-orientated economy that has encouraged participation by foreign firms, as well as import penetration for a wide range of consumer goods. This has helped to bring prices down and attract a large number of participants, despite the small size of the economy, in effect turning it into a showcase market for firms wishing to expand in the region. For example, around 50 car brands compete in the Chilean market, including Chinese and Indian firms.
Other highly competitive sectors include telecommunications and retail. A deep and sophisticated financial sector, which has historically benefited from ample credit supply, relatively low interest rates and narrow loan-deposit spreads, supports consumer expenditure. Large foreign and local firms co-exist in the banking and insurance sectors, with the insurance sector enhanced by high and rising statutory obligations. The private pension market is highly liquid and-uniquely among Latin American economies-has created a large pool of institutional investors, thus deepening local capital markets. Despite this, the conservative lending practices of the banking system mean that small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) often find it difficult to obtain financing; these constraints do not present a problem for larger blue-chip firms, which can access a wider range of financing options. In addition, there has been an expansion by retail chains into consumer lending (and even into mortgage lending and insurance brokerage) in recent years. Although this has helped to boost credit availability to some of Chile's lower-income households, there are concerns over the looser lending standards of retailers.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Chile's long-term outlook benefits from continued adherence to prudent monetary and fiscal policies, coupled with a commitment to the rule of law and protection of property rights. A wide network of bilateral free-trade agreements (FTAs) will continue to help Chile to attract foreign direct investment (FDI), while simultaneously assisting local firms to expand abroad. It has also helped to diversify the economy into areas in which the country previously lacked comparative advantages, although a pronounced bias towards mining-the country's single largest industry and source of exports-will persist. Chile's efforts to become a regional platform for multinational corporations will continue, facilitated by its reputation for stability and security, its well-developed financial system, and the quality of its transport and communications infrastructure, as well as a comprehensive network of FTAs, double-taxation agreements and investment-protection accords. Chile's track record in raising real incomes has made progress, with GDP per head-in US dollars at purchasing power parity (PPP)-increasing from 20% of US GDP per head in 1990 to 40.4% in 2018. This gradual convergence will continue as growth outpaces that of the US, to reach a forecast 43.1% by 2023.
Initial conditions: Chile is a small country, representing only a 0.25% share of the world population in 2018, but it overachieves in its share of world GDP (0.35% at PPP), and global exports are strong (0.4% of the total). Chile's GDP per head of US$15,920 in 2018 at market rates was the highest among Latin American economies (excluding the Caribbean). In PPP terms, GDP per head was US$25,280 in 2018, also the highest among non-Caribbean Latin American countries. In 2010 Chile was the second country in the region (after Mexico) to become a member of the OECD. Chile will continue to attract manufacturing investment, but its competitiveness as a global manufacturing centre will lag behind that of its Asian rivals. Chile will continue to find success in non-traditional production such as agro-industry and fisheries, and possibly some consumer goods, once Asia's labour-cost advantages erode. As a commodity producer, Chile faces more volatile terms of trade than its Asian competitors, whose comparative advantage is founded on low-cost manufacturing rather than raw materials. This implies that Chile's growth will remain strongly linked to international copper prices for the foreseeable future. The peso remains weak against its 20-year average, which will help to boost competitiveness for non-mining exports.
Demographic trends: Although Chile's population is still young by international standards, its demographic profile is ageing. Annual population growth will average just over 0.3% in 2018-30; the working-age population is expected to continue to grow, owing to a drop in young-age dependency. However, the working-age group will start to shrink from 2022, which will bring a rise in the dependency ratio. Despite Chile's relative affluence and the quality of its social services, immigration has not significantly contributed to overall population growth in recent decades. Although it may begin to do so over the next decade, the effect will not be significant. As a result, the demographic outlook will be dominated by trends among the native-born population, whose birth rates will continue to fall.
External conditions: Growth in export industries will be boosted by Chile's large network of free-trade agreements (FTAs). However, the single most important external factor affecting the Chilean economy is the international price of copper. Prices have fallen substantially, from a peak of 400 US cents/lb in 2011 to a low of 196 US cents/lb in December 2015, owing to the global slowdown and the end of the so-called commodities supercycle. The copper price has since recovered to average almost 300 US cents/lb in 2019, but remains at the mercy of global sentiment. In the long term, however, demand growth from China and India, as well as other emerging economies, will keep copper prices high by historical standards. Chile has diversified its export base over the past 15 years, notably into non-traditional sectors such as fruit, salmon and wine. Nonetheless, mining (mainly copper) still accounts for approximately half of total exports, and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this dominance to diminish only marginally, given Chile's unique geological and geographical advantages in natural-resource extraction. Service exports will also grow, benefiting from Chile's position as a regional business hub. Open and liquid capital markets make the country the most developed financial centre in the region-and smaller in size only than Brazil and Mexico-with ample crossborder opportunities in banking, insurance and securities markets arising from deeper regional integration. Finally, growing international awareness of the country's significant natural beauty will provide a major boost to tourism in the medium and long term.
Institutions and policy trends: Chile will maintain its strong pro-market policy direction of the past three decades. However, social pressures and the rising expectations of the middle classes will lead to an increase in public-sector participation in certain sectors. Governments will dramatically extend state funding of university places (tertiary education currently remains highly market-orientated) and renewable energy. Civil-service reforms will support bureaucracy efficiency and transparency, and steps to reduce red tape will benefit the business environment as administrative procedures are simplified. Modernisation of the judiciary will accelerate legal procedures, which already benefit from one of the most independent and least corrupt judicial systems globally. Governance will be characterised by professionalism and credibility, offering investors minimal risks of policy reversals. Public frustration with graft and collusion will prompt reforms to reduce corruption. Constitutional reform will lead to a degree of symbolic decentralisation and a more parliamentary (rather than presidential) system of government.
Long-term performance: Chile's tradition of policy continuity, abundant natural resources, a favourable investment climate and modern infrastructure will be supportive of firm economic growth in the long term. The Chilean economic model will remain investment- and export-led, based on solid macroeconomic fundamentals, monetary stability and countercyclical fiscal management. Productivity growth will be helped by investments in new technologies and a gradual move towards higher value-added activities (made evident by the shift from agriculture to agro-industry). The financial sector will remain competitive, owing to a large pool of institutional investors (private pension funds, mutual funds and insurance companies), providing businesses and households with ample financing through credit and capital markets.
In the long term, modernisation of the education system and a more flexible labour market will be necessary to unlock higher potential growth; both of these issues are being slowly tackled by the current government led by Sebastián Piñera. The linking of Chile's north and central-south electricity grids could prove the catalyst for a revitalisation of the country's fragile energy matrix, which has resulted in Chile having some of the highest energy costs in the region. The lack of major fossil fuel reserves will provide an impetus towards developing renewable energy sources, and the country is on course to meet a target of 20% power generation via renewables in 2020, five years ahead of schedule (a long-term objective of 70% by 2050 appears more than feasible). At the same time, there is significant opposition to major hydroelectric projects on environmental grounds, and some green alternatives such as solar energy remain expensive, suggesting that Chile will be burdened by energy insecurity in the medium term. Overall, we forecast that average annual GDP growth will reach 2.8% in 2019-30, falling to 2.3% in 2031-50. As growth in the working-age population slows, economic expansion will become more dependent on productivity gains and less so on the contribution of labour.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Chile's long coastline and diverse topography leave it highly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Changing climate dynamics will increase the likelihood and severity of natural disasters such as floods, droughts and landslides. These will directly disrupt some sectors of the economy, including agriculture and tourism, and glacial retreat will especially affect water resources. According to climate change projections by Chile's meteorological office, Chile's south-central area and the northern part of Patagonia should see temperatures rise and precipitation fall by around 60% between 2030 and 2059. Given that this is the heart of Chile's agricultural region-and also its farmed salmon industry-this will have a serious impact on the Chilean economy. Temperature rises affecting the oceans will also affect sea life, leading to a reduction in both the abundance and the diversity of species. This has been felt to some extent already in recent years, with an El Niño effect in 2016 disrupting the fishing industry, and a major drought affecting the country in 2018. The drought caused the government to declare a water emergency in 61 communes amid water shortages, and 102 communes declared an agricultural emergency. The Universidad de Chile says that at least 25% of the factors contributing to that year's drought reflect human action.
On June 4th 2019 the government unveiled a climate action plan that would shut all coal power plants by 2040, and target carbon neutrality by 2050, meaning the country would emit no more heat-trapping carbon-dioxide (CO2) emissions than can be absorbed in its forests. Although a climate change law is still in its early stages, it is expected to establish a medium- and long-term framework for climate impact reduction, and create the institutions to manage climate change adaptation and mitigation efforts. This year The Economist Intelligence Unit has developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we find that the Chilean economy will be 2.6% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
An ageing demographic profile
Chile's demographic profile shows an increasing proportion of the population over 65 years old. In 2018 around 11.5% of the population was over 65 years old. This is expected to climb to around 17% of the population by 2030. This makes Chile one of the oldest populations in Latin America and the Caribbean (behind only Cuba and Uruguay). In addition to a lower birth rate, this also reflects an increase in life expectancy in the past 20 years as Chile has become a more affluent society. The ageing of the population presents a unique challenge for a developing country, where (until recently) providing sufficient economic growth and jobs for a working-age population was the biggest task.
The effect of Chile's ageing population has already been seen in the country's politics, with the state of the country's pension system becoming a major issue in the 2017 election. The government has also had to address the fiscal costs of an ageing population by promoting the hiring of senior citizens (to keep them in the workforce) and incentivising the postponement of retirement. The government has also sought to increase the number of doctors specialising in geriatrics working in the public health system, and to adapt urban infrastructure to accommodate the needs of the elderly. The shrinking percentage of the working-age population as a percentage of the overall population has also made immigration more attractive to Chilean policymakers. The country has bowed to political pressure to standardise its immigration system after a large inflow in 2015-17, but still remains committed to welcoming regulated inward immigration.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World GDP and trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Manufactures price: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodities: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
World copper prices: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Ps:US$ exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
GDP growth by demand component: Banco Central de Chile (BCCh, the central bank), Boletín Mensual; 2003 prices
Copper production: BCCh, Boletín Mensual; m tonnes of all copper products
Average copper price: LME, quoted in BCCh, Boletín Mensual
US$ copper exports: BCCh, Boletín Mensual
US$ GDP: IFS; current prices, from local currency at annual average exchange rate
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Chile to prices in the US
Demographic profile data: UN, population projections, medium variant; ILO, labour force projections
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Real GDP growth per head: real growth in GDP deflated by population growth
Budget balance: non-financial public sector (NFPS) balance only; Ministerio de Hacienda
Inflation: BCCh; December 1998=100
Wage and salary inflation: BCCh
Wage costs and unemployment rate: BCCh, Boletín Mensual
Exchange rate: BCCh; market rates expressed as Ps:US$
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity (PPP) for tradeable products to annual average exchange rate
Interest rates: IFS; bank rate offered (charged) on deposits (loans) of 30-89 days; given in annual terms by compounding weighted average monthly rates
Balance of payments: BCCh
Total external debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
Total debt service: World Bank, Global Development Finance; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), is under severe economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit has for some time believed that the Maduro regime's position is unsustainable. We currently base our forecasts on a political transition within our five-year forecast period that introduces an interim administration led by Juan Guaidó, whom we assume will undertake emergency adjustment measures and prepare the ground for eventual free and fair elections. Currently, we expect that there will be some sort of regime change by the end of 2019. The timing and shape of the transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period (2019-23) to be characterised by political instability.
Our expectation of a change of government by end-2019 implies huge changes to policymaking as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms required to resolve the economic crisis.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under the transition and successor governments. Many of these policies have been outlined already, with the Guaidó administration seeking to reassure stakeholders in multilateral institutions and in potential donor nations such as the US and EU members of its capacity to stabilise the economy, address the humanitarian emergency, generate trust and legal security, ensure access to basic public services, and reactivate the oil industry.
The pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of a new administration, and how this stability might be impaired by likely demands by multilateral and bilateral lenders for politically difficult reforms. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and other multilaterals, and by the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, the state-owned oil company, PDVSA, will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.

Venezuela is in 79th position globally in the business environment rankings for 2019-23, up from 80th in the historical period. Assuming regime change, improvements are expected, but it will take time for reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment to bear fruit.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of rollback of interventionist measures such as price controls, but concerns over political instability slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt to attract investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on private-sector access to foreign currency remain.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2021-23: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but declining risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short-term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Large-scale emigration of skilled labour complicates hiring.
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid means that rationing and unpredictable blackouts continue. A new government undertakes some repairs to the power network.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to an estimated US$18.8bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus at 2% of GDP.
