Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), is under severe economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit has for some time believed that the Maduro regime's position is unsustainable. We currently base our forecasts on a political transition within our five-year forecast period that introduces an interim administration led by Juan Guaidó, who we assume will undertake emergency adjustment measures, and prepare the ground for eventual free and fair elections. At present, we assume regime change by the end of 2019, but the timing and shape of the transition process remains highly uncertain. We expect the entire 2019-23 forecast period to be characterised by political instability.
Our forecast for regime change is based on the extent of the economic and humanitarian crisis currently unfolding in Venezuela. This has deeply damaged support for Mr Maduro among the population at large; we believe that it will ultimately erode his backing among key supporters in the military who are propping him up in power. It is less clear, however, what the exact trigger for regime change will be. There are three main paths to a political transition: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action, by the US or Colombia, as very low. Although negotiations are ongoing (in Barbados, sponsored by Norway), we believe that trust issues on both sides are insurmountable and therefore do not expect a negotiated solution to Venezuela's crisis.
We therefore believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup of some kind. Owing to expanding US sanctions, Mr Maduro can no longer guarantee the regime's raison d'être-the enrichment of its members-and so we expect pragmatists within government and within the military to turn on him and pave the way for some sort of political transition. However, a failed uprising on April 30th demonstrated the difficulty of this sort of initiative, and has incurred a heavy political cost, as the regime has become ever more vigilant of discontent among its ranks. Nevertheless, the April uprising, which apparently included the participation of top-ranking government officials alongside Mr Guaidó, confirmed the existence of cracks within the regime's ranks at the highest levels. Our forecast for regime change therefore still stands.
This forecast is underpinned by three key assumptions. The first is that regime pragmatists will prevail over hardliners. Despite the ongoing collapse of the patronage system, there are risks to this assumption, in view of frequent purges within the military and the presence of dozens of important military figures, leading to co-ordination problems. Secondly, we are assuming that regime members will deem amnesty offers credible. Risks to this assumption include a deep-seated distrust of the opposition and fear of being prosecuted outside Venezuela (a credible fear, given accusations of drug- and weapon-trafficking against regime members). The third assumption underpinning our forecast for a government transition is a continued lack of hard currency to sustain the patronage system. Risks to this forecast come in the form of greater than expected support from Russia or China, and from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities that could provide the regime with more hard currency than we currently expect.
We recognise the very high risks to our baseline view, and believe there are two main alternate scenarios. The first, and more likely, of these is the maintenance of the status quo, with the population protest-weary, the regime hunkering down, the opposition deflating, and the country becoming increasingly isolated and impoverished. The second is one of prolonged chaos-including, possibly, armed conflict among regime factions. That said, we expect neither of these scenarios to be feasible in the medium to long term: with no prospect of real reform, we believe that a chronically weak economy will ultimately make Mr Maduro's position untenable. Moreover, violent, chaotic conflict in Venezuela could prove the trigger for some kind of military action by the US and by Venezuela's Latin American neighbours to put an end to the crisis. For these reasons, we continue for now to believe that regime change in the forecast period remains likely, even if it does not occur in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The opposition's recently announced plans for a transitional government call for the renovation of all electoral authorities and for elections within 12 months of the transitional government's formation. Although this timeline is extremely ambitious, given the scale of the task, we tentatively expect national elections to take place by the end of 2020 under a transitional government. International assistance in organising the elections would be necessary (and forthcoming). The task will be huge, as deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority, to the electoral registry and to the voting system will be required, and rebuilding trust in the system will be difficult. If the Maduro regime manages to maintain the status quo, legislative elections would take place in December 2020.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community. Most governments in the Americas, under the banner of the Lima Group, have recognised his presidency. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept him in place of Mr Maduro. Indeed, the US introduced new sanctions in August, the most important of which is a freeze on Venezuelan assets abroad, which will further complicate the regime's attempts to sustain the current patronage system. Moreover, the US administration's hawkish approach introduces risks of a military intervention. We currently do not foresee large-scale military action, in part because such an initiative lacks international legitimacy. However, if tension ratchets up and domestic violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the necessary financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and the state oil company, PDVSA. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but with little apparent success in terms of investment. We believe that Russia and (especially) China would be willing to work with a successor government in an attempt to protect their current investments in Venezuela.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Our expectation of a change of government later in 2019 implies huge changes to policymaking as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. There has been evidence in recent months of attempts to tighten monetary policy to rein in hyperinflation and to abandon foreign-exchange controls (with few foreign reserves left to protect). However, we believe that such efforts are doomed to failure in the absence of comprehensive microeconomic reform and improvements in rule of law and policy predictability that will not be forthcoming under the present regime.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect more orthodox economic policies to be implemented under the transition and successor governments. Many of these policies have been outlined already, with the Guaidó administration seeking to reassure stakeholders in multilateral institutions and in potential donor nations such as the US and European countries of its capacity to stabilise the economy, address the humanitarian emergency, generate trust and legal security, ensure access to basic public services, and reactivate the oil industry. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and how this might be impaired by probable demands by multilateral and bilateral lenders for politically difficult reforms. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and other multilaterals (totalling US$46bn in 2020-23) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. Meanwhile, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself up to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit this year to remain well in double-digit levels as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Under our expectation of substantial currency adjustment, the public debt/GDP ratio will rise dramatically in coming years; however, our forecasts assume that a combination of debt restructuring and deep fiscal adjustment will gradually bring the ratio under control. The process will be complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds and all but one of PDVSA's bonds are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. A US appeals court has ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government; this will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining firm, Crystallex, is seeking to seize shares of Citgo, PDVSA's US subsidiary. That said, the latest US sanctions forbid the transfer of Venezuelan assets, which would, for the time being, shield Citgo and its Caribbean facilities, which the US government now considers to be under Mr Guaidó's purview.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to print money in the short term. However, a significant increase in reserve requirements for the banking sector since the start of the year and a strong contraction in domestic demand have had a temporary stabilising effect, which has slowed hyperinflationary pressures and allowed the bolívar to stabilise to some extent in recent months. We expect monthly inflation to rise again in the short term, given that underlying causes of inflation remain unaddressed. However, given our assumption that a transition government that places a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation will soon come to power, we do not currently project a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of over 1,000,000% experienced during 2018 (although there are substantial political risks to this forecast). Instead, under a new government, we expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of an emergency macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency, a temporary peg or outright currency substitution in such a context is highly likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 18.5% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. Our forecast of an economic recovery in 2021-23 assumes a political transition that, supported by international assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of about 60% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2019, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Moreover, power cuts are now very frequent-owing to severe underinvestment in the country's power infrastructure-and have further damaged Venezuela's overall economic capacity.
Our forecast for a recovery in investment from 2020 assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment. We expect oil output to bottom out at 700,000 barrels/day (b/d) in the coming quarters, prevented by PDVSA's joint-venture partners from slipping lower. In line with our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government later in 2019, oil production will start to recover in 2020 but will end the forecast period in 2023 well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017.
Export volumes will start to recover in 2020 on the back of recovery in the oil sector, but a rise in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb some of the projected increase in oil output. Import demand will rise sharply in 2020. Taken together, this will initially constrain the rebound of GDP, but we expect real GDP growth to gather pace in 2022-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Severely reduced domestic supply, dollar constraints on import capacity, and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official inflation data were recently published by the BCV, but there is a significant gap between these and data from other sources. Amid continuing questions over the data, we will, for now, continue to use the monthly series produced by the National Assembly. These have indicated some disinflation in recent months, with monthly inflation falling below the hyperinflation threshold of 50% per month. Huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand persist, however, and we expect inflation to remain extremely high for as long as the Maduro regime stays in power. On the basis of our assumption of regime change in the short term, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation, but supply bottlenecks and bouts of inflationary pressure are likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our baseline forecast of political transition by end-2019, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) to try to tackle inflation is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such moves is hard to predict. Our forecasts assume extremely large currency adjustments that restore some competitiveness to the local currency in real terms over time. For now, and with few foreign reserves left to protect, the Maduro regime has announced a loosening of currency controls. However, access to dollars via formal means will remain extremely difficult and we believe that the foreign-exchange system will remain highly controlled in practice. In this environment, a strong black-market exchange-rate premium is likely to re-emerge. By end-July the premium had widened but was still small by historical comparison, with the official rate at BsS11,250:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of almost BsS12,600:US$1.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
We have recently revised our current-account data in line with the BCV's publication of official figures for 2017-18. These show that Venezuela continued to post current-account surpluses in this period on the back of higher non-oil exports than we had expected. However, we continue to project a shift into current-account deficit this year, in view of the collapse of export earnings stemming from US sanctions on the oil trade. This deficit will emerge despite the non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2019 alone). We have also excluded repayments to Chinese lenders, to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data, on which our debt forecasts are based. Later in the forecast period we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, but we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been severely reduced. These factors will keep the current account in deficit, although we expect the shortfall to narrow to a manageable level of around 3% of GDP towards the end of the forecast period.
We currently expect that a new administration will secure sufficient finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this outlook. It hinges on substantial IMF finance, rapid macroeconomic stabilisation, speedy resolution of a debt renegotiation process, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Full text: Italy--highlights: Political outlook
The March 2018 general election was a resounding victory for the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won 32.7% of the vote, and the Eurosceptic, anti-immigration Lega, which took 17.4%. After protracted negotiations the two agreed to form a coalition government in late May of that year. The government is led by Giuseppe Conte, an independent close to M5S. Mr Conte's deputy prime ministers are Luigi Di Maio, the leader of M5S, and Matteo Salvini, the leader of the Lega, who has thus far overshadowed Mr Di Maio with his brash, populist rhetoric. Giovanni Tria, a technocrat economist, serves as economy and finance minister. The administration will continue to challenge EU rules on migration and fiscal policy. It has partially reversed recent pension and labour reforms and implemented a means-tested "citizenship income" for job-seekers. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to fall over the coming budget fight, leading to a snap poll in 2020.
Italy--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.60 6.66 36 41 15 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's business environment score remains broadly unchanged during the forecast period (2019-23). The macroeconomic environment score is broadly stable, but owing to improvements in other countries, Italy slips by five places in our global ranking and by one place in the regional ranking. Deteriorations in the scores for political stability and effectiveness, and market opportunities have been offset by marginal improvements in the scores for policy towards financing and the labour market. Italy's tax system remains one of the biggest hindrances to businesses and foreign investment. Compliance is costly and tax evasion remains widespread.

Domestic political uncertainty and policy choices have been weighing on the economy since mid-2018. Real GDP growth is expected to slow from 0.7% in 2018 to about 0.3% on average in 2019-20, owing to a cyclical downturn, policy uncertainty and weaker external conditions. Growth will rise to an average of 1.1% in 2021-23 as domestic and global demand recover. The M5S-Lega administration will seek to loosen fiscal policy as much as possible. Debt/GDP will remain at about 130% for the duration of the forecast period, and we do not expect the M5S-Lega government to enact any meaningful structural reforms. Instead, it has proposed a raft of tax and spending policies and has diluted recent structural reforms.

The population increased at an annual average rate of 0.3% in 1999-2011. Since 2017 the population has begun to decline, falling from 60.7m to 60.6m in 2018, according to the UN's population estimates. We expect the population to continue falling slightly during the forecast period, to 60.1m in 2023, reflecting the natural decline of the Italian population and lower immigrant inflows.

Italy is one of the largest and richest markets in Europe, with a population of about 6om. However, growth potential remains limited because the country is a mature consumer market with weak income and population growth prospects. Income levels differ greatly between the north and the south of Italy, with GDP per head in the south only about 46% of that in the north. Demographic trends will have an important impact on spending patterns, with population ageing driving healthcare expenditure.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Our baseline forecast is that Italy's weak demographic profile will act as a substantial brake on real GDP growth, which we expect to average just 0.8% per year in 2019-50. A more favourable political environment could produce better economic growth performance in the long term, but the chance of improvements in Italy's institutional framework being implemented in the short to medium term is low.

Background: Post-war Italy has been characterised by a weak political structure and, since the 1970s, a declining economic base. Between 1996 and 2011 Italy had a bipolar political system, dominated by a centre-right alliance and a centre-left coalition. Since 2011 the political landscape has become more fragmented, with the break-up of the centre right, the emergence of the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and a recent splintering of the centre left. Since the 2013 general election Italy has had three broad centre-left/centre-right governments. Matteo Renzi's resignation as prime minister-after his flagship constitutional reform was rejected in a referendum in December 2016-led to the formation of a government led by Paolo Gentiloni, a close ally of Mr Renzi. Following the 2018 general election an M5S-Lega government was formed.
Political structure: Parliament, which comprises two houses with equal powers, is elected for a five-year term. In the event of a political crisis the president, who is elected by parliament for a seven-year term, decides whether to call an election or nominate a prime minister to try to form a government. The president also promulgates laws and may return a law to parliament for reconsideration, but has no power of veto. Executive power lies with the cabinet, which is nominated by the prime minister and approved by parliament. The prime minister cannot dismiss ministers without forming a new government. The legislative system remains unchanged following the rejection in the December 2016 referendum of a reform to reduce the powers of the Senate (the upper house). A new, predominantly proportional electoral system was adopted in October 2017.
Policy issues: The main issues are the management of, and attempts to reduce, Italy's large public debt (which stood at 132.2% of GDP in 2018), safeguarding the banking system and keeping Italy in the euro zone. In 2012 the government, led by Mario Monti, carried out a number of structural economic reforms to improve competitiveness. The process has since stalled, and the M5S-Lega government will seek to loosen fiscal policy, stimulate private consumption through tax cuts and income support to low earners, and seek to reverse or dilute recent pension and labour reforms.
Taxation: The top rate of personal income tax is 43%, and social security contributions are high, especially for employers. The corporation tax rate is 24%, reduced in 2017 from 27.5%, but additional regional and municipal taxes are levied, including the regional business tax (IRAP), to fund health services. The basic rate of IRAP is 3.9%. Income earned from most types of financial investment is taxed at 26%. The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 22%.
Foreign trade: The value of exports of goods (fob) stood at US$537.5bn in 2018, and imports (fob) were worth US$481.9bn. In the same year the current account recorded a surplus of US$50.6bn, or 2.4% of GDP.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The March 2018 general election yielded a badly fragmented parliament. The centre-right coalition fell short of the roughly 40% of votes needed to win a majority under the most recent electoral law, the so-called Rosatellum 2, coming in at 37%. Within the coalition, the populist, anti-immigration Lega (17.4%) surpassed Silvio Berlusconi's Forza Italia (FI; 14%), which had previously been seen as the leading party on the right, and polled well ahead of the hard-right, post-fascist Fratelli d'Italia (4.4%). The election also saw a surge in support for the populist, anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won 32.7% of vote, making it by far the country's largest party. After three months of difficult coalition talks, M5S and the Lega agreed to form a coalition government under the leadership of a technocratic prime minister, Giuseppe Conte. Meanwhile the mainstream centre-left Partito Democratico (PD), under the leadership of Matteo Renzi, won just 18.9% of the vote, an all-time low, leading to Mr Renzi's resignation and the election of a new party leader, Nicola Zingaretti, in March 2019. The PD and its smaller coalition partners won a combined vote share of just 22.3%, and Liberi e Uguale (LeU)-a formation made up of primarily left-wing splinter parties that spun off from the PD in opposition to Mr Renzi's leadership-took 3.4% of the vote. In April 2019, LeU was dissolved, with some of its constituent parties realigning with the PD.

Political outlook: Political stability
Just over a year into its five-year term, the coalition government, composed of the anti-establishment M5S and the far-right Lega, is showing signs of strain. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that the leader of the Lega, Matteo Salvini, will engineer a political crisis in an effort to force a snap election later this year, when frictions with M5S and with the EU surrounding the 2020 budget will provide an opportunity to withdraw from the coalition. The president, Sergio Mattarella, would have limited options but to grant Mr Salvini-who tops opinion polls-such a vote, which would probably be held in the first half of 2020. At this contest we expect the Lega to win a commanding majority in parliament at the head of a right-wing coalition, including the centre-right FI and the small, post-fascist Fratelli d'Italia.
Mr Salvini will engineer a political crisis in an effort to force a snap election
The M5S-Lega government-led by Mr Conte, an independent law professor-came into office in the wake of the March 2018 general election. Since then, however, the Lega has dominated the administration under the leadership of Mr Salvini, a deputy prime minister and the minister of the interior. The Lega leader has struck a chord with Italian voters with his round-talking speeches, adept use of social media and a policy agenda focused on security issues, Euroscepticism and combating illegal immigration.
Meanwhile M5S's popularity has ebbed steadily under the leadership of Luigi Di Maio, also a deputy prime minister, and the minster of labour and economic development. Following disappointing performances in a series of regional and local elections in 2018-19 M5S won just 17% of the vote at the European Parliament elections in May 2019, compared with the Lega's 34%.
In early July, following weeks of tensions with the European Commission, the government narrowly avoided a debt-based excessive-deficit procedure (EDP) by adopting measures intended to reduce the 2019 budget deficit by EUR7.6bn, to 2% of GDP. Nonetheless, frictions between the government and EU institutions are likely to resume regarding the draft 2020 budget in October. The Lega and M5S stepped back from the brink of a near-crisis mid-month following the parties' divergent positions on appointments to the Commission, clashes over proposed legislation to deepen regional autonomy and the completion of the Lyon-Turin high-speed rail link, which the Lega and Mr Conte support and much of M5S opposes. The Lega has also sought to deflect attention from a controversy involving the alleged solicitation of illicit funding from Russian businessmen by a former advisor to Mr Salvini.
In this context, drafting and finalising the 2020 budget will be challenging. The government will need to disarm the so-called safeguard clauses written into the country's multi-year fiscal framework. These would raise the headline value-added tax (VAT) rate from an already high 22% to 25.2% if EUR23bn (1.3% of GDP) is not raised through spending cuts or from other revenue sources. However, Mr Salvini is determined to have his costly flat-tax reform-thus far applied only to lower- and middle-income VAT-account holders-extended to the personal income of a portion of Italian citizens. A conflict over the country's fiscal framework would be likely to give Mr Salvini the justification he needs to leave the coalition.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Italy is governed by weak, divided executives, generally comprising multiparty coalitions, in which small parties often wield disproportionate power over policy decisions. Under the bicameral parliamentary system, all bills have to be passed in the same form by both houses of parliament in order to be enacted, often resulting in delays and the dilution of measures. This is unlikely to change following the rejection of the Renzi government's constitutional reform package in December 2016, which sought to reduce drastically the legislative powers of the Senate (the upper house of parliament) and would have effectively made the parliament quasi-unicameral. The new M5S-Lega administration bitterly opposed Mr Renzi's efforts to streamline the institutional framework, and further reforms are not a part of their law-making agenda.
Efficiency may improve in the public administration, but not in the judiciary
Red tape and Italy's inefficient judicial system are likely to continue to pose problems for businesses. However, modest measures introduced in recent years to increase public-sector accountability and efficiency should help to speed up gradually some bureaucratic procedures, although given entrenched resistance to change within the public administration, the implementation of the reforms approved in 2015 is likely to be slow. The M5S-Lega administration has stated its intention to reduce red tape, but has not yet presented an ambitious, credible simplification programme. A partial reform of the judicial system was undertaken in 2014-16. However, many of the problems facing Italy's judicial system have not been addressed, including a fee system for lawyers that acts as a disincentive to concluding cases swiftly, a lack of specialisation among judges and a highly fragmented court system. The average number of days to resolve a contractual dispute in Italy is more than double that in some other EU member states.
Corruption is still rife in business, judging by the number of corruption scandals revealed in recent years. A bill presented in March 2010 containing measures intended to combat corruption among public officials took almost three years to become law. Since then government action appears to have intensified. In June 2014 the powers of the anti-corruption authority were strengthened, and less than a year later parliament approved another anti-corruption law, including provisions eliminating the minimum threshold for the prosecution of accounting fraud and introducing harsher prison sentences for this offense, as well as for corruption of public officials, embezzlement and mafia association. The M5S-Lega government passed further anti-corruption legislation at end-2018, imposing harsher criminal penalties and public-office bans for graft, and, from 2020, applying the statute of limitations only to first-instance trials so that fewer cases are dismissed owing to a lengthy appeals process.
Criminal organisations will continue to pose problems for businesses and deter investment, despite the authorities' efforts to combat extortion and usury, and the arrests of several mafia bosses in recent years.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next parliamentary election is scheduled for early 2023, but we expect it to be held much sooner. The result of the European Parliament elections has raised the likelihood that the Lega will withdraw its support from the government later this year. When combined with the Lega's vote share of 34%, the shares of FI (9%) and Fratelli d'Italia (6%) come to about 50%, which would be likely to produce a commanding majority under Italy's voting law for general elections. This system, the so-called Rosatellum 2, allocates about one-third of the seats in each house of parliament in single-member districts and about two-thirds via proportional representation.
It is possible that M5S and the centre-left opposition party, the PD-having surpassed M5S at the European Parliament elections, with a vote share of 23%-will align in the event of a government crisis in order to avert an election in the near term that returns a right-wing government. However, the parliamentary mathematics would be difficult, particularly in the Senate, and the two parties would struggle to justify such a move to their respective electorates.
Political outlook: International relations
We expect Italy to remain a member of the EU and the euro zone during the 2019-23 forecast period. Other foreign policy mainstays-including a close relationship with the US, and membership of NATO and the UN-will also continue. However, relations are likely to be strained. Mr Salvini has signalled a more confrontational stance towards other EU countries, taking a tough line on migration measures, and has also protested against EU fiscal constraints.
Sino-Italian diplomatic relations will improve in the near term, following Italy's decision to sign in late March 2019 a memorandum of understanding (MoU) to participate in the Belt and Road Initiative, China's flagship global infrastructure integration plan. The MoU is unlikely to increase bilateral trade or investment flows significantly in 2019-23, but it will probably undermine EU attempts to find a common stance on China, and complicate Italy's relations with other EU countries and the US.

Italy's business environment score improves only slightly during the forecast period (2019-23), but because of greater improvements in other countries Italy falls five places in the global ranking and one place in the regional ranking, to 16th. The scores for policy towards private enterprise and competition, taxes, financing and the labour market all improve, reflecting the impact of economic reforms taken by successive governments since late 2011. However, the populist M5S-Lega government, in power since June 2018, is unstable and ineffective. Its repeated push-back against EU fiscal rules has resulted in an upward shift in government borrowing costs, hampering efforts to reduce taxation and weighing on already weak bank profitability.
Italy scores poorly for government effectiveness. Following the rejection of constitutional reforms in a referendum at end-2017, institutional reform is off the political agenda for the foreseeable future, although the M5S-Lega government has pushed ahead with plans to reduce radically the number of members of parliament. Reforms in 2014-16 have failed to resolve entrenched shortcomings in the judicial system. The modest economic recovery that got under way in 2014 has stalled since mid-2018, which will make it more difficult to promote investment and employment, and reduce public debt. These issues, as well as repairing weaknesses in the banking sector, remain the biggest policy challenges facing the government in 2019-23. Italy's tax system remains a hindrance to businesses and foreign investment, and evasion is widespread. The new government's costly tax reform plans have increased uncertainty about the direction of tax policy. Action to encourage bank mergers and support banks' efforts to reduce the level of non-performing loans (NPLs) on their balance sheets has made some progress, but the sector remains vulnerable.

Business environment outlook: Italy's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Significant reforms to improve competition will not be a priority under the administration led by Giuseppe Conte.
2021-23: Improvements in competition policy will depend on stabilisation of the political environment.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Modest reductions in red tape. Government plans to charge penalties to foreign firms that collect state incentives and then relocate production to non-EU countries within five years of the incentivised investment.
2021-23: Organised crime, legal complexity and shortcomings in judicial system remain deterrents.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Quotas and tariffs are in line with EU practice. The Conte government could oppose new EU trade deals. EU focuses on EU-UK trade deal in Brexit negotiations, further bilateral free-trade deals and responding to US tariffs.
2021-23: An EU-US agreement will probably remain elusive. The risk of a euro area break-up, which could lead to capital controls, is low, although The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Greece to leave the bloc in the medium term.
Taxes
2019-20: Automatic rise in value-added tax (VAT) rate is averted in 2019, but implementation of two-rate "flat tax" is delayed owing to cost. Reduction in tax expenditure and some tax rises in order to finance costly social spending plans.
2021-23: Government seeks to implement a diluted corporate and income tax-reduction package.
Financing
2019-20: Bank mergers, recapitalisations and non-performing loan sales are slow, not least because of political uncertainty.
2021-23: Banking sector exposure to the Italian sovereign will persist. Mergers of smaller co-operative banks and possible foreign takeovers accelerate, as does the sale of securitised bad loans. Profitability and credit provision remain weak.
The labour market
2019-20: Firms remain reluctant to increase open-ended contract payrolls. "Citizenship income" is partly introduced. Some aspects of 2014-15 labour market reforms are reversed.
2021-23: Decentralised private-sector productivity-related pay deals and changes to public-sector contracts face resistance.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Lack of fiscal space constrains government plans for higher investment spending.
2021-23: Infrastructure still lags that of other euro area countries, despite some new investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) presses for further digitalisation of public services. A preponderance of smaller and family-run firms, as well as high levels of corporate debt, keep research and development (R&D) spending low.
2021-23: Gradually improving economic prospects (and Brexit) encourage more information and communications technology graduates to seek work in Italy. Slight improvement in R&D and company-level technology investment.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.9 6.6 47 53 12 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's high public debt and political risk pose a threat to euro zone stability
The Economist Intelligence Unit's assessment of the macroeconomic environment focuses not on headline real GDP growth (measured in the market opportunities category), but on economic stability and the underlying policy framework, which influence business planning, hiring and investment. Italy's macroeconomic environment score deteriorates slightly in the forecast period, contributing to a fall of six places in our global ranking and three places in the regional ranking. Italy's biggest macroeconomic policy challenge remains reviving investment and economic growth, making it more socially inclusive, while also putting public debt on a sustainable downwards path. Italy's public debt and political instability will continue to be a cause for concern for the core euro zone creditor countries, as well as a risk to the survival of the bloc and to the stability of its financial sector.
Despite some progress, economic reforms were introduced with a lag relative to most other struggling euro zone economies, and further measures to reverse more than a decade of stagnant productivity growth are unlikely in the current political environment. We expect Italy to keep its budget deficit within the EU's 3% of GDP limit and to continue generating primary surpluses (the budget balance excluding interest payments), but the public debt burden will remain at about 130% of GDP during the forecast period. Weak price growth will also complicate debt reduction in GDP terms. Demand-side price pressures will remain subdued owing to continued moderate household consumption and labour market slack, as well as modest wage growth. Export growth and moderate global energy prices will keep Italy's current account in surplus during the forecast period. Nevertheless, concerns remain over the erosion of the country's export competitiveness, stagnant productivity and escalating global trade tensions.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.8 6.3 43 40 17 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Policy towards private enterprise and competition remains an area in which Italy scores poorly compared with its EU peers, reflecting weak implementation and enforcement of competition rules, and inadequate reforms to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of the public administration and justice system. Generally, EU directives have been the main drivers of liberalisation in Italy, forcing successive governments (which, regardless of their political leaning, have not instinctively favoured competition) to open up markets in several sectors, notably telecommunications, energy and professional services. The powers of the Italian Competition Authority were strengthened and its remit extended to cover the provision of public services in 2010, but political pressure has generally limited effectiveness. This is also true of other watchdogs, including the Commissione Nazionale per le Società e la Borsa (Consob), the public authority responsible for regulating the Italian securities market, and the telecoms watchdog, Autorità per le Garanzie nelle Comunicazioni (AGCOM).
External constraints will continue to be the main drivers of liberalisation
In 2012 the then-technocratic government, led by Mario Monti, which came to power in late 2011 when Italy was threatened with losing financial market access at the height of the euro zone crisis, introduced a range of measures, including provisions to increase competition in retailing, taxi services, the sale of pharmaceuticals, utilities and several professions, specifically law. We expect the M5S-Lega government to resist further liberalisation. Since taking office the government has either diluted or reversed previous reforms, such as the liberalisation of opening times in the retail sector, or blocked further liberalisation of services, including taxi facilities, with its "anti-Uber" decree.
In 2014-16 the Renzi government continued earlier progress in cutting red tape affecting businesses, streamlining the complex tax system and, in particular, simplifying and reducing regulation of the Italian labour market. The introduction of reforms has reduced the influence of minority shareholder local charitable foundations in Italy's co-operative banks (banche popolari), paving the way for greater competition, consolidation and mergers. Consolidation has made some progress, but has been slow owing to reticence to write down bad loans, as well as new EU bail-in rules that require banks to impose losses on shareholders and junior bondholders, who are often retail investors, in return for government support.
Weak contract enforcement will remain a deterrent of foreign direct investment
Weak contract enforcement, few convictions for white-collar crime, and notoriously long court case backlogs will remain a deterrent of foreign direct investment (FDI) and domestic business investment. Improvements introduced in 2014-17 include extended prison sentences for some white-collar crimes such as bribery, the establishment of support offices to reduce the backlog in Italy's Supreme Court and an extension of the statute of limitations for serious crimes. However, political opposition and resistance from the judiciary remain strong, which will hamper implementation. With political instability likely to continue under the M5S-Lega government, further major reforms are unlikely.
Further privatisation of major state-controlled companies is unlikely
The privatisation plan that was re-launched in mid-2015 to highlight Italy's openness to foreign investment and reduce the level of public debt made little progress before the 2018 general election and is unlikely to be revived under the M5S-Lega government. Both parties have strenuously opposed the sale of state assets in the past. This means that the planned public offering of the state's remaining 30% stake in the national post office and financial services group, Poste Italiane, and the mooted sale of a 40% stake in Ferrovie dello Stato, Italy's state-owned railway utility group, are unlikely to happen.
The M5S-Lega government's approach will be to increase the stakes of the Cassa Depositi e Prestiti Spa (CDP)-the state-owned development bank-in state-controlled firms, such as the energy conglomerates, Eni and Enel, in order to boost revenue. The government is also likely to use its powers of appointment to expand its influence at the top of state-controlled companies by replacing senior executives and board members that were put in place by previous governments.
The M5S government's Decreto Dignità (dignity decree) introduced in 2018 contains a mix of measures including provisions to reduce the use of temporary employment contracts and discourage delocalisation (the relocation by firms of jobs to low-wage countries). Compensation for unfair dismissals has also been raised. The decree also requires the repayment of state incentives and subsidies with interest if a firm lays off workers in Italy to transfer production abroad.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.9 6.9 39 39 16 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The positive impact of economic reforms will only be felt incrementally
FDI inflows into Italy have generally been low compared with other similarly sized countries, including those such as France that have traditionally been seen as no more open than Italy. The main deterrents to FDI in Italy relate to complex bureaucratic and legal procedures, barriers to entry in areas of the services sector, inadequate infrastructure, high levels of taxation and energy costs, and labour market rigidities. Under past governments labour market reforms, modest business tax cuts and streamlining of Italy's complex tax system have begun to address some of these issues, resulting in an improvement in Italy's score and rankings in this category. The new M5S-Lega government is more isolationist than its predecessors, and its programme contains no specific policies aimed at attracting FDI. However, in March 2019 Italy became the first G7 country to sign a Memorandum of Understanding to participate in the Belt and Road Initiative-China's flagship global infrastructure integration plan. Given the Italian economy's long-standing structural deficiencies, and the likelihood that the impact of recent reforms will be felt only incrementally, inward FDI in Italy will continue to lag that in other large EU member states.
Judicial reforms introduced in 2014-17 should gradually improve contract enforcement, with signs that they are already reducing civil case backlogs. Legislation passed in 2015 should also encourage further financial sector consolidation, which could eventually attract FDI in the banking sector, although progress will be slow owing to political resistance. Bureaucratic complexity has dogged the sale of banks' securitised bad loans to foreign investors, but intense pressure from financial markets and new EU directives regarding provisioning will help to accelerate the process further. Although less ambitious than hoped for, anti-corruption legislation introduced since 2013 represents a further sign of intent to improve the operating environment for domestic and overseas investors. Over the medium term, the M5S-Lega government's anticorruption law may also have noticeable positive effects.
Foreign takeovers, especially of luxury goods brands, are likely to continue
Corporate balance sheets and the ability to raise capital were severely damaged by the 2011-14 economic downturn. As a result, in recent years foreign companies have acquired or merged with a rising number of internationally renowned Italian corporate brands, particularly in the luxury and consumer goods sectors, such as Bulgari, Valentino, Loro Piana and Luxottica. Despite signs of concerns among some law-makers regarding foreign takeovers, the trend is likely to continue during the forecast period. As illustrated by the Fiat takeover of Chrysler in 2014 and the acquisition by Atlantia in 2018 of its Spanish partner, Abertis, large Italian firms are seeking opportunities to invest abroad.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.7 9.1 27 20 13 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's score in this category improves slightly in the forecast period, leading to large improvements in its global and regional ranking, owing to deteriorations or no improvements elsewhere. EU membership determines for the most part Italy's foreign trade and exchange policy. Full freedom of movement of goods, services, capital and persons exists within the EU (subject to transitional restrictions for newer member states), and we do not expect any exchange controls. Bilateral trade disputes between EU countries are resolved by the European Commission or, in extremis, the European Court of Justice (ECJ), the jurisprudence of which has played a major role in developing the single market. Compliance with judicial or other rulings within the EU is higher than in other regional trading blocs or the World Trade Organisation (WTO). Trade with Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein, and Switzerland is unrestricted under the European Free Trade Association (EFTA). The EU also has a customs union with Turkey and a range of bilateral agreements with Switzerland. All of these arrangements exclude agriculture.
In other sectors trade with non-EU countries is mostly subject to moderate customs duties. The EU takes a liberal approach to trade in industrial goods, with average unweighted most-favoured-nation tariffs, which cover most countries, at about 4%. Trade between member states and third countries has been largely governed by multilateral agreements administered by the WTO. In 2015 the WTO reached an agreement on trade facilitation (reducing red tape at borders, and setting binding standards for customs and movement of goods internationally), but the Doha trade talks have stalled since 2008 and are unlikely to be revived.
The EU will focus on bilateral trade deals
The EU's focus will be on bilateral trade deals, as support for progress through the multilateral trade system has frayed amid heightened opposition to further trade liberalisation in some countries (notably the US). We expect the EU to make advances, but the backdrop will be challenging, given ongoing US-China trade tensions; a broader increase in global trade protectionist measures; a continued risk of a disruptive Brexit on the part of the UK; an increasing threat of additional US tariffs on EU imports, including those of cars (which would trigger a wider trade conflict as the EU defends its interests); and weaker global growth.
Trade deals between the EU and other trade blocs will be implemented gradually
In June 2019 the EU and Mercosur, the South American trading bloc, reached an agreement to create the world's largest free-trade market of almost 800m people, following 20 years of negotiations. Assuming the deal is ratified in national parliaments (which will be a politically complex process, given opposition in some member states), phased-in measures will aim to eliminate about 90% of tariffs and provide greater access to agricultural and services markets, and to public procurement contracts, from 2021 at the earliest.
The EU-Japan economic partnership agreement took effect in early 2019, creating what is currently the world's largest free-trade area. Some tariffs will fall to zero this year, but most measures involve a lengthy transition phase. The Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) between the EU and Canada will gradually come into force in 2019-23. The CETA will eliminate most tariffs, simplify border procedures and increase regulatory co-operation.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.3 4.8 79 79 18 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's tax system remains highly complex, so compliance is costly
Italy's score for taxation improves slightly in the forecast period, but the country ranks third from last in our global ranking and bottom in our regional ranking in 2019-23. Notwithstanding some streamlining under previous governments, the tax system remains complex, making compliance costly and time consuming for private-sector companies. Also, despite some modest tax cuts since 2014, the tax burden has remained high and is unlikely to decline much, owing to Italy's high public debt and EU sovereign debt reduction requirements. Tax policy will remain highly uncertain under the M5S-Lega government.
According to Istat (the national statistics office), total tax revenue/GDP (including social security contributions) stood at 42.1% in 2018-slightly lower than in 2017, but higher than the regional aggregates of about 40-41% for the EU and the euro area. According to Eurostat data, Italy has the second highest implicit tax rate on labour in the EU (aggregate tax revenue from labour as a percentage of the potential tax base), after Greece. This was 42.4% in 2017 (latest available data), down from a high of 44.1% in 2013, but about 6 percentage points more than the EU average and almost 4 more than the euro area average. At 18.3% in 2017, up from 16.6% in 2009, Italy's implicit tax rate on consumption was one of the lowest in the EU and was about 2 percentage points lower than the regional average, highlighting that there is scope to shift taxation towards consumption and away from labour.
Despite promises to reduce labour taxes, they will remain high
Italy's rate of corporate tax for non-financial corporations is 24%, after a cut of 3.5 percentage points in 2017. Banks and most other financial sector firms, however, were excluded from the cut and continue to pay the 27.5% rate. In addition to a corporate tax rate, businesses also pay a regional business tax (IRAP), which is levied at a standard rate of 3.9% (and slightly higher than this for most financial institutions). However, the central government can raise the regional business tax rate as high as 4.4% in regions running budget deficits. Regions and municipalities also apply personal income surtaxes at varying rates to offset the impact of cuts in transfers from the central government, which have been an almost constant feature of budget adjustments in recent years. Companies pay social security contributions at a high rate, by international comparison, of 30% (9.5% for employees). These are unlikely to be reduced significantly unless pension spending, which amounts to about 15% of GDP (one of the highest in Europe), is significantly reduced. Currently the marginal personal income tax rate is 43% on gross annual incomes of more than EUR75,000.
Overhauling the tax system remains one of the policy priorities of the M5S-Lega government. But independent estimates put the cost of its initial reform plan at EUR50bn, making its full implementation unlikely without commensurate expenditure cuts, which would be politically unpopular and difficult to achieve. In the 2019 budget a flat tax of 15% was introduced for entrepreneurs and the self-employed. Plans to expand it in 2020 to small and medium-sized enterprises and to the personal income tax of low- and middle-income employees would cost up to an estimated EUR30bn. Currently the marginal personal income tax rate is 43% on gross annual incomes of more than EUR75,000.
Tax evasion and avoidance is widespread in Italy, encouraged in the past by frequent tax amnesties, a limited number and scope of inspections, and weak political will to close loopholes in tax laws. However, some progress was made during the crisis years. In addition to its costly tax overhaul plans the M5S-Lega government introduced a "tax peace" scheme in 2019, which was essentially an amnesty, and may be repeated in 2020. The government has also raised the limit on cash payments from EUR1,000 to EUR3,000 in 2019. The Lega had indicated that it wanted to abolish the limit altogether, but more recently appears keen to promote the use of electronic payments.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.6 7.4 29 27 11 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Fragmentation remains one of the main weaknesses of the banking sector
Italy's score and global ranking improves substantially in the forecast period, reflecting the impact of a range of measures adopted by recent governments to encourage consolidation, support recapitalisation and try to tackle the issue of high NPLs. Nevertheless, the country still ranks below most other developed countries, which largely reflects delays in introducing reforms to address the Italian banking sector's weaknesses after the 2008-09 global crisis. The sector's major shortcomings are notably fragmentation, with few large banks and many small and medium-sized lenders; high operating costs, because of excessive branch networks and personnel costs; low profitability; uncertainty about the quality of supervision; and heavy exposure to the sovereign, which leaves them vulnerable when concerns about government-debt sustainability increase. NPLs have declined considerably in recent years, but are still high, at 8.3% of total credit as at end-March 2019. This is well down from 16.9% in the third quarter of 2015, but more than double the EU average of 3.1%. Much of the decline is the result of large NPL securitisation operations by a few major Italian banks. The reduction of the high levels of NPLs on the balance sheets of Italy's smaller banks has made much slower progress. Perhaps with a view to supporting these banks' efforts, the government has extended the system of guarantees (Garanzia sulle cartolarizzazioni delle sofferenze, or GACS) until May 2021. The stress tests carried out by the European Banking Authority on Italy's four major banks (Intesa Sanpaolo, UniCredit, Banco Bpm and UBI Banca) in 2018 highlighted the improved health of Italy's banks compared with the EBA's stress tests in 2016.
Despite recent reforms, some consolidation and progress in reducing NPLs on banks' balance sheets, efforts to repair Italy's banking system have been beset with difficulties, largely relating to EU bail-in rules, which require losses to be imposed on shareholders and junior bondholders before government support can be granted. Although the state is ultimately likely to compensate small investors' losses, the bail-in rules have provided political capital for anti-establishment political parties and restricted government willingness to speed up bank resolutions.
Banca Carige, a small regional lender, has been under special administration since the beginning of 2019, but officials have so far been unable to find a private investor to rescue the bank. In order to avoid being wound down, the bank may be forced to request a "precautionary recapitalisation" from the state, as happened with the much larger Monte dei Paschi di Siena (MPS) in 2016.
The return of political risk in May 2018 owing to uncertainty about the future direction of the M5S-Lega government's economic policies has pushed up Italian government benchmark ten-year government bond yields, albeit to still relatively low levels. After several years of contraction or stagnation, bank credit to the private sector has begun to recover. The stabilisation in lending marks an important development for Italy's large number of small and medium-sized enterprises that rely largely on bank borrowing for financing.
Amid global trade tensions and stuttering demand, especially in the euro zone and China, the US Federal Reserve (the US central bank) and the ECB have signalled that policy rates will be cut, reducing pressure on government borrowing costs, which eases pressure on the cost of bank credit. Financial market volatility could increase, however, if political instability continues or rises under the M5S-Lega government.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.4 5.8 59 58 18 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Recent reforms will reduce long-standing rigidities only gradually
Recent reforms have contributed to improving the labour market score and Italy's global ranking in the forecast period, but this category remains an area in which Italy performs poorly compared with its EU peers. The Jobs Act legislative package passed in 2014-15 was a welcome development, but because the main reforms only applied to new private-sector hires, it will only reduce long-standing rigidities gradually. The M5S-Lega government had promised to dismantle the Jobs Act, but its main focus has been to increase restrictions on the use of easily terminated fixed-term contracts. The measures in the government's Decreto Dignità appear to have had some success in this regard. It allows fixed-term contracts to be used for up to 24 months, compared with 36 months under the Jobs Act and 12 months prior to that. It also requires firms to provide a justification for the use of such contracts, which is likely to increase litigation, and pay an additional levy of 1.9% (up from 1.4%) when they extend a fixed-term contract. However, the cap of 20% of the workforce on temporary contracts for an individual firm remains unchanged. The decree also raised the minimum compensation for unfair dismissal from a minimum of four months' salary to six months and from a maximum of 24 months' salary to 36.
Other measures introduced under the Jobs Act that remain intact include reduced employment protection for long-term contracts and a much simplified contract system for labour market entrants by introducing a standard open-ended employment contract with gradually increasing protection. The Jobs Act also increased the availability of unemployment benefits and streamlined the use of wage guarantee funds for temporary lay-offs or firm restructuring. In 2018 the new national agency envisaged under the Jobs Act to co-ordinate the activities of all employment services providers became operative.
Reflecting the impact of a protracted recession, delayed reforms and weak economic recovery since late 2014, Italy's headline jobless rate remains high, at 9.9% in May 2019, compared with the euro area average of 7.5%. Youth unemployment remains high, despite increased emigration of young people, especially graduates. At 30.5%, the youth unemployment rate is the third highest in the euro area, where the average rate is 15.7%. Despite some recent improvement, Italian labour market participation remains low, particularly among women and young people. According to Eurostat, Italy's employment rate was 58.2% in the first quarter of 2019, compared with the euro area average of 67.3%. The female employment rate was 49.6% (62.4% in the euro area).
In 2018 Italy's three main trade union confederations and the business association, Confindustria, agreed a new national wage bargaining framework. It provides the basis for sectoral accords at national level, as well as second-level plant or regional agreements linking wage increases to company performance and productivity gains. However, the M5S-Lega government appears determined to establish a national minimum wage, which could reduce wage flexibility if set too high. There is also some concern that the government's citizenship income scheme, which aims to reduce poverty, will act as a disincentive for people out of work to search for employment, resulting in higher structural unemployment.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.5 6.5 32 40 15 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Infrastructure quality in the south will continue to lag the rest of the country
As reflected in its unchanged score and the decline in its regional and global rankings, the quality of Italy's infrastructure is set to remain below the average of other developed countries during the forecast period. A significant disparity between the north and the south of the country will also continue. Budgetary constraints have limited public investment in the past 25-30 years, and local interest groups have succeeded in blocking or delaying several major projects in the transport and energy sectors. Corruption investigations are another relatively common reason for delays. As illustrated by the collapse of the Morandi motorway bridge in Genoa in August 2018, maintenance of existing infrastructure also remains an issue. Telecommunications costs have fallen and device ownership has risen, along with internet use and broadband penetration, but Italy continues to lag most other developed countries in these markets, and the rollout of high-speed broadband services has been slow.
The economy minister, Mr Tria, has promised to revive public capital spending by curbing current spending, freeing up funds earmarked for infrastructure projects and removing administrative obstacles that have held up investments. However, Italy's high debt servicing costs, combined with competing demands within the coalition, make a radical change in policy direction unlikely. M5S is opposing the continued construction of the high-speed rail link through the Alps, from Turin in the north east of Italy to Lyon, a major city in south-eastern France.
Fiscal consolidation will hold back public investment in infrastructure
Limited domestic energy sources and popular opposition to the development of nuclear-power generation will continue to cause uncertainty about security and diversification of supply. Poor infrastructure in energy distribution is likely to keep upward pressure on costs. Investment will also continue to face strong local resistance.
After a slow start, government efforts to accelerate investment in fibre-to-the-home (FTTH) networks providing high-speed internet access will make progress. Central to the government's plans is Open Fiber, which is now jointly owned by Enel and CDP. Open Fiber plans to build FTTH networks in 270 cities in Italy, investing EUR3.7bn in the development of the network, EUR3bn of this by 2020. In June 2019 Telecom Italia, which plans to roll out its own fibre network, was in merger talks with Open Fiber. Co-operation between Open Fiber and Telecom Italia would avoid unnecessary duplication of the network.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.3 7.8 21 29 11 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Italy's technology readiness score deteriorates in the forecast period compared with the historical period, thereby contributing to falls in both our global and regional rankings. E-commerce is growing rapidly (up by 12% in value terms in 2018, according to Istat), reflecting improvements in the online environment. However, growth is from a low base, with online purchases accounting for less than 10% of retail sales (compared with about 20% in the UK).
Mobile-phone penetration is one of the highest in Europe, and take-up of new technologies such as smartphones and high-speed mobile contracts has usually been impressive. Spending on innovation, and research and development (R&D) low for a developed economy, largely reflecting a preponderance of smaller and family-run firms, high levels of corporate debt, and limited public financial support. According to OECD data for 2017, total R&D spending (for both the public and private sectors) was the equivalent of 1.4% of GDP (compared with an OECD average of 2.4%).
Digitalisation of public services is a policy priority
The implementation of the Three-Year Plan for the Digital Transformation of the Public Administration in 2017-19 has facilitated steady progress. Digitalisation of public services remains one of the M5S's policy priorities.
We expect a slight improvement in R&D and firm-level technology investment, partly supported by the tax credit for R&D investment in effect since mid-2015, but growth will be from a low base. According to the European Patent Office, the number of patent applications in Europe originating in Italy increased by just 0.9% in 2018, compared with average growth in Europe of 3.8%, and only accounted for 2.5% of the total. Relative to population size, patent applications in Italy were low, at just 70.7 per million population, ranking Italy just 20th-well behind other major European economies such as Germany, France and the UK.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The administration of the Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and the Lega has departed from the more orthodox policies of previous governments. With regards to the labour market, the administration passed the so-called Dignity Decree in July 2018, reversing parts of the 2015 Jobs Act, a liberalising labour market reform. In April 2019 the government implemented an expansionary pension reform, easing the conditions for early retirement.
One of the administration's other flagship policies, M5S's citizenship income, provides a monthly stipend or top-up of other benefits of up to EUR780 for poor pensioners and the unemployed.
The government has also implemented a first step towards the Lega's promised 15% flat income tax, applying this rate to VAT-account holders earning up to EUR65,000 beginning in January 2019. Finally, the administration has approved a new anti-corruption law, as well as a security decree containing a series of tougher policing and immigration measures, and a growth decree intended to jump-start business activity.
The coalition's rhetoric has rattled the markets. The banking sector also remains weak and highly exposed to government debt. However, credit quality has improved rapidly in the past two years, owing to regulatory pressures from the European Central Bank (ECB) to reduce stocks of bad loans on banks' balance sheets, as well as the rescue and restructuring of several troubled lenders.
Nonetheless, an abrupt uptick in market perceptions of political risk could still pose challenges to financial stability. We believe that it is unlikely that Italy will lose market access in 2019-23 (the forecast period). However, owing to the sheer size of Italy's EUR2.3trn public debt stock and the fragility its banks, the economy would be too large to rescue without support from the ECB in the event of a major crisis.

On July 1st the government adopted measures intended to reduce the 2019 budget deficit by EUR7.6bn, to 2% of GDP, compared with a previous target of 2.4%. The EUR7.6bn correction includes an adjustment of EUR6.1bn contained in the "budget-balancing" law, comprising EUR6.2bn from higher than projected revenue, as well as a net spending overshoot of EUR100m. The government has also introduced a decree to freeze EUR1.5bn (0.08% of GDP) in unused budget funds that was earmarked to cover the cost of relaxing the 2011 reform of early pension requirements and the citizenship income-the administration's ambitious plan to fight poverty.
Given the distinct risk of higher outlays than expected, The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that this objective is implausible and expects a budget shortfall of 2.5% of GDP in 2019. The 2020 budget process, which will begin with an update to the government's fiscal and economic projections in late September, and the submission of a draft budgetary plan to the European Commission in mid-October, is likely to prove to be exceptionally difficult. The deficit is then expected to expand further, to 2.8% of GDP in 2020, and to an average of about 2.6% in 2021-23. Public debt, at 132.2% of GDP at end-2018, is expected to remain near this level for the next five years.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Short-term interest rate (av) -0.3 -0.3 -0.4 -0.2 0.1 1.9
Deposit rate (av) 0.8 0.8 1.1 1.7 1.7 1.7
Long-term interest rate (av) 2.6 2.6 3.1 3.5 3.7 4.0
The ECB adopted an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy in response to the European sovereign debt crisis, bringing major policy interest rates down to zero or below in order to raise inflation back to its target of "below, but close to, 2%". The ECB also ran a EUR2.6trn quantitative easing (QE) programme in 2015-18.
We have changed our monetary policy call and now believe that a 10-basis-point cut to the deposit rate will come in September (we previously expected a rise in June 2020). This change is underpinned by persistently low inflation, the recent de-anchoring of long-term inflation expectations from the target, our subdued outlook for US-China trade relations and the ECB's recent dovish communication. At its latest meeting, on June 6th, the bank delayed the next rate rise from early 2020 until mid-2020 at the earliest (we do not expect this until mid-2021), and strongly signalled its easing bias. A few weeks later Mario Draghi, the ECB president, announced that further stimulus would be forthcoming "in the absence of improvement", rather than only "if contingencies materialise". Funding conditions will therefore remain ultra-loose over the medium term. The ECB will reinvest principal payments from maturing securities past the date on which it starts tightening, and a third round of targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs-III) will begin in September. We do not expect the ECB to restart its QE programme this year; we believe that this would be politically and legally too challenging given the current state of the economy, with labour markets proving resilient and the risk of a recession low. Nevertheless, resuming QE remains a possibility, especially if the risk of deflation rises. The nomination of Christine Lagarde, the IMF director, for the ECB presidency is unlikely to lead to a significant change in the ECB's monetary policy strategy.
