In full-year 2018 real GDP expanded by 0.7%, down from 1.8% in 2017. Momentum was weak going into 2019, dampened by domestic political and economic uncertainty, as well as global trade tensions. In January-March 2019 the economy expanded by 0.1% (compared with the previous three months). This followed two consecutive quarters of negative growth, and resulted in a first-quarter contraction of 0.1% year on year. We expect that the economy will expand by a marginal 0.1% in full-year 2019, on the back of slower growth in private consumption and fixed investment, and less favourable external conditions. High-frequency indicators for the first half of 2019 paint a mixed picture, suggesting that the recovery from recession is fragile and could falter in the coming quarters.
Economic growth will remain subdued in 2020, at 0.4%. In that year the building effects of the ongoing US-China trade dispute, and weaker growth in the US, will weigh on the external sector and dampen sentiment. Growth should then pick up to an average of 1.1% per year in real terms in 2021-23 as domestic and global demand recover.
The boost to real household disposable income from recent tax cuts has faded, with real private consumption-accounting for about 60% of GDP-growing only modestly, by 0.6% in full-year 2018. Consumer spending also weakened as a result of heightened volatility in financial markets in the final two quarters of 2018, which weighed on consumer confidence, and it may wane in the second half of this year as political tensions with EU institutions mount. We expect weak job creation, modest wage growth and waning consumer confidence to continue to constrain household spending in 2019. After meagre expansions of 0.4% per year on average in 2019-20, we forecast that consumer spending will rise to about 1% per year in 2021-23 as domestic sentiment improves.
Public consumption rose by 0.2% in 2018, and we expect looser spending controls and limited fiscal stimulus efforts to result in a slight uptick in 2019-23. It will remain modest, however, at an annual average rate of 0.5% throughout this period. The current administration's looser stance towards deficit spending will raise the risk of higher levels of government consumption.
Fixed investment expanded for the fourth consecutive year in 2018, but was still more than a fifth less than its 2007 pre-crisis level. It rose by 3.2% in real terms last year, driven by transport-equipment spending in the first half of the year, as well as a slow recovery in construction. In 2019-20 investment growth will slow significantly, to an annual average of 1.2%, held back by the expiration of tax incentives, policy uncertainty and declining sentiment, as well as public capital spending constraints, still impaired credit channels and relatively high levels of corporate debt.
The pace of export growth decreased markedly in 2018, to 1.4%. Export growth is expected to remain weak in 2019-20, owing in particular to weaker growth in EU markets and global trade tensions, before picking up thereafter. Anaemic domestic demand growth and external demand constraints will also limit import growth to less than 2% in 2019-22, before stronger export performance and healthier domestic demand lead to firmer expansion in 2023.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Reflecting the severe impact on the industrial sector of the 2008-o9 global crisis and the subsequent ongoing euro area crisis, industry (excluding construction) accounted for 21.9% of employment in 2019, slightly up from 21.8% in 2007, and 24.1% of nominal gross value added, compared with 20.5% of gross value added in 2007. The manufacturing sector has long been the main strength of the Italian economy, especially Italy's family-owned small and medium-sized export-oriented companies specialising in products that require high-quality design and engineering. However, the sector faces major challenges owing to Italy's structural problems, and the uncertainties arising from the euro zone crisis and domestic political risk. Concerns about the global economic outlook stem from the ongoing trade war between the US and China, and rising trade tensions between the EU and the US.
Italian industry faces major challenges owing to structural deficiencies
In 2018 manufacturing accounted for 16.7% of gross value added, down from 17.8% in 2007 and 20.3% in 1997. The sector's decline has largely been driven by the prolonged weakness of domestic demand, but also by the difficulties that Italian exporters face in remaining competitive within the European single currency area. Unit labour costs have remained well above the euro area average since 2005 and have continued to rise in Italy since 2010, whereas they have fallen in other peripheral euro area economies such as Spain, Greece, Ireland and Portugal. Weak competitiveness and further transfers of low-value-added production out of Italy are likely to lead to a further decline in manufacturing's contribution to the economy during the forecast period.
The automotive industry is one of the flagship sectors of Italian industry. It accounts for about 8% of GDP-almost a quarter of the contribution from all manufacturing industries and about 10% of the total value of Italian exports. Fiat (Fabbrica Italiana Automobili Torino), which was renamed Fiat-Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) in 2014 after merging with a US-based producer, is the dominant producer in Italy, but the sector also comprises hundreds of firms that manufacture components or provide related services.
After declining in 2008-13, vehicle production in Italy picked up by 6% in 2014 and 45% in 2015, and slowed to 8.8% in 2016, 3.5% in 2017 and -7.2% in 2018. At 1.1m units, annual production is approaching 2007 levels. The fall in 2008-13 reflected the impact of the global economic crisis on demand in Italy and in export markets, as well as the transfer of production to lower-cost countries. A recovery in domestic and external demand drove the rise in output in 2014, whereas the double-digit increase in 2015 was largely driven by the addition of two new models to the FCA's production line at the Melfi factory in southern Italy. The drop in Italian production affected passenger-car output disproportionately. In 2013 passenger-car output was more than 70% lower than in 2000. Following a modest increase of 3% in 2014, Italian passenger-car production rose by 65% in 2015, before moderating to 7.5% in 2016 and 4.2% in 2017, and then contracting sharply, by 9.7%, in 2018.
Passenger-car production and sales suffered last year, mainly owing to the introduction of new EU emissions standards that distorted industry statistics. We forecast that growth will remain sluggish, averaging about 1.7% in 2019-22 and contracting slightly in 2020 as a result of a slowdown in economic activity linked to a cyclical cooling in the US. Commercial vehicle sales will expand more briskly in 2018, by 5.5%, following a modest contraction in 2017 after strong growth of 49% year on year in 2016. In 2019-23 commercial vehicle sales will also slow, to an average annual expansion of 1.6%, as small declines are expected in 2019 and 2020.
Fiat will face challenges in the wake of Sergio Marchionne's departure
Fiat's strategy to become a major global producer through mergers, acquisitions and alliances abroad is proving challenging and will probably not boost production in Italy, even if it is successful. The company has succeeded in raising margins globally, but has set ambitious targets through to 2022, which will be all the more difficult to fulfil following the sudden departure and death of Sergio Marchionne, the firm's iconic chief executive officer since 2004, in late July 2018. Given Italy's high labour costs and other difficulties of doing business in the country, the recent trend of shifting automotive production out of Italy is likely to continue, despite FCA's repeated promise to increase domestic production. Fiat now produces about two-thirds of its vehicles abroad, in China, Brazil, Turkey, Russia, Serbia, Poland and elsewhere. It closed its Termini Imerese plant in Sicily at the end of 2011 and began producing cars at a new plant in Serbia in the first half of 2012. Integration with Chrysler could also result in more production being transferred to plants outside Italy. Following an agreement with the trade unions to introduce more flexible working practices, and boost productivity and output at its plant at Pomigliano d'Arco, near Naples, the company transferred production of one of its models from Poland at the beginning of 2012. However, production at the plant was interrupted or reduced at various times during the economic crisis, when demand in the Italian and wider European car markets contracted.
Manufacturing sector performance will depend on the speed of the reforms
In the medium term the performance of the manufacturing sector will depend largely on the implementation of reforms to tackle Italy's structural deficiencies. These include issues such as lack of competition, particularly in the non­tradeable services sectors and utilities, which has meant that companies in Italy pay high prices for domestically produced inputs, such as electricity, compared with competitors elsewhere. The predominance of small companies and their lack of investment in areas such as innovation and research and development (R&D) has prevented them from moving up the value-added chain. There are about 388,000 manufacturing companies in Italy, about 97% of which employ fewer than 50 people. Firms with fewer than ten employees account for about 82% of the total.
Italian small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are often aggregated within sector-specific industrial districts, which, through a combination of co-operation and competition, help to mitigate the impact of the difficulties arising from a lack of expansion. According to the Edison Foundation, a think-tank that monitors 99 industrial districts, exports from these districts fell sharply in euro terms in 2009, but have risen strongly since the beginning of 2010, and previously marginal hi-technology districts have increased their weighting in the index as they have outperformed the overall index and Italy's traditional low-tech manufacturing sectors such as clothing and textiles, and home furniture.
Italian SMEs have begun to consolidate under the pressure of intense competition and the global crisis. However, the availability of domestic funds to support mergers or recapitalisations to start new projects is likely to be curtailed by the need to reduce the government debt burden. This has contributed to a rising number of internationally renowned Italian corporate brands being acquired by foreign companies in recent years, particularly in the luxury and consumer goods sectors. Global designer brands such as Bulgari, Valentino and Lora Piana have been sold to foreign groups, and as of mid­2014 Indesit, Italy's main manufacturer of white goods, is no longer majority Italian owned. This trend is likely to continue during the forecast period.
Construction sector activity is likely to remain subdued in 2020
Activity in the construction sector accounted for 4.7% of gross value added in 2018-down marginally from 2016, but well below an annual average of 6% of gross value added in 2006-09-and 6.2% of employment in 2016, compared with 8.6% in 2007. After nine full-year contractions, which left output in the sector about a third below its 2006 peak in real terms, the decline appeared to bottom out in the final quarter of 2014, but activity is likely to remain subdued during the forecast period, reflecting the impact of an eight-year decline in property prices up to 2016. On the EU's harmonised measure, house prices began to fall once again on a year-on-year basis in the fourth quarter of that year, and in January-March 2019, Italy was one of only three countries included in the index where house prices were still decreasing. This will weigh on the construction recovery, as will ongoing corruption investigations involving public works contracts, and large government spending cuts are also likely to dampen activity. Various governments have sought to accelerate EU co-financed infrastructure investment plans to provide some support to the sector, but little progress is likely to be made, largely owing to delays at the regional and ministerial levels.
The government will not enact wide-ranging liberalisations
Already accounting for almost 74% of gross value added, the services sector is expected to expand broadly in line with subdued average real GDP growth during the forecast period. Those subsectors that are exposed to foreign competition, such as tourism, are likely to struggle, although security concerns in several competitor markets could help. Sectors that serve mainly the domestic market and have so far enjoyed a high level of protection from competition, such as the professions and retailing, will come under pressure as a result of reforms to reduce barriers to entry, but this is likely to be only gradual. Over the near term, the M5S-Lega government is unlikely to embark on ambitious service-sector liberalisations and would be more likely to introduce protective legislation. High-value­added services sectors, such as design, which are closely tied to clothing, textiles and automotives, Italy's main export sectors, should continue to perform well, even though in some sectors production is increasingly being moved abroad to countries where labour costs are lower.

Consumer price inflation remained subdued in 2018, at 1.2%, as a 0.2% decline in core inflation (headline inflation excluding volatile food and energy prices) more than offset inflationary pressures that stemmed from a 30.7% increase in international oil prices and a rise in global food prices for the first time in seven years.
In 2019 consumer price growth should slow further, to 0.9%, owing to cheaper average global energy prices and still considerable slack in the labour market, meaning that upward pressure on prices from capacity constraints will not materialise in the near term. A positive demand shock from fiscal policy also appears unlikely. In 2020 headline inflation should increase slightly, driven by a forecast 4.8% increase in global food prices, which will offset downward pressures deriving from declining global energy prices. From 2020 inflation should recover gradually, to average 1.4% in 2021-23, as global energy prices rise.

The euro rallied in late 2017 on the back of the region's economic recovery and rising expectations of QE tapering. However, since peaking at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in February 2018, the euro has depreciated against the dollar, partly owing to monetary tightening in the US last year. Since the start of 2019 the euro has weakened further, mostly hovering around US$1.11:EUR1-US$1.13:EUR1, as high-frequency data and soft indicators continue to disappoint market expectations and point to a weak euro zone outlook. We expect the euro to remain broadly stable in the coming months and to average US$1.13:EUR1 in 2019. Next year it will appreciate to an average of US$1.18:EUR1 as the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) further eases policy. The euro should recover more pronouncedly from 2021 on the back of the ECB's policy tightening as growth in the region accelerates, which, together with the euro zone's large current-account surplus, should lift it to US$1.25:EUR1 by end-2023.

In 2018 the current account remained firmly in surplus, at 2.4% of GDP. We expect it to average 1.4% in 2019-23. This decline reflects considerably slower growth in export revenue until 2021, in line with slower global demand. Higher international energy prices in 2021-23 will have a negative effect on the trade balance in those years (Italy is a major energy importer).
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Italy
Stocks and flows
Net inward foreign direct investment (FDI) flows are low compared with most other EU countries, and Italy has generally been a net exporter of FDI. Net inflows to Italy picked up to US$34.4bn in 2011 (1.5% of GDP), from about US$10bn (0.5% of GDP) in 2010, but declined again to close to zero in 2012, owing to large disinvestments. Net inflows recovered moderately in 2013-15, averaging US$17.5bn per year (0.9% of GDP). Inward FDI rose to US$31bn in 2018 (equivalent to 1.5% of GDP), up from US$9bn in 2017. Italy attracts less greenfield foreign investment than other large European economies. The total stock of FDI was US$550bn in 2018, compared with about US$865bn in France, and about a third of total FDI in Germany and a quarter of that in the UK. In relation to GDP, the stock of FDI was 26.5% in 2018, compared with 22.9% in 2014-lower than in any other EU country apart from Greece. FDI outflows have also generally been quite small, mainly reflecting the prevalence of small and medium-sized companies in Italy. In 2005-09 Italy recorded substantial outward FDI flows as a result of several major investments abroad in the banking and energy sectors. A similarly large outflow, of about US$52bn, was recorded in 2011, the year that Italian car manufacturer Fiat bought the US Treasury's remaining stake in Chrysler.
Origin and distribution
FDI from Europe accounts for about 60-65% of company revenue and employment generated by foreign companies with operations in Italy. Companies from North America represent about 25-30% of revenue and employment, and those from Japan for about 3-4%. The manufacturing sector contributed about 40% of the total revenue and value-added of foreign­owned firms, but this has generally been on a downward path and dropped sharply in 2005, when General Motors (US) sold its stake in Fiat. The utilities and telecommunications sectors have registered the most rapid expansion. In 2016, the last year for which data are available (expressed according to the directional principle), the largest FDI stocks came from Luxembourg (EUR64.5bn), France (EUR60bn), the UK (EUR43bn) and Germany (EUR28bn).
Determinants
The main attraction for foreign companies to set up operations in Italy is the size of the domestic market, which offers a population of about 6om and average GDP per head of US$40,3oo at purchasing power parity (PPP). Deterrents include the complexity of Italy's legal system, inefficiencies in public administration, inadequate infrastructure-particularly in the south of the country-and often high regulatory barriers to entry, especially in services sectors. In addition, studies of the determinants of FDI in southern Italy have highlighted classical deterrents to investment, such as distance from major European markets, low presence of other foreign companies and a high level of organised crime. Such studies seem to indicate that fiscal incentives and the presence of specialised producer service providers have a low impact on foreign entrants' decisions, but that human capital is an important positive variable. Italy has an abundant workforce in the south, which has attracted a few high-technology investments to areas such as Catania in Sicily, where a Franco-Italian joint venture, ST Microelectronics, has a production plant and several research centres.
Impact
According to the Italian Trade and Investment Agency (ITA), foreign-controlled companies employ more than 1m people in Italy and generate revenue of about EUR5oobn per year. Foreign companies invest on average three and half times more in research and development (R&D) than Italian companies. However, because of the comparatively low level of inflows and their concentration in the north of Italy, the impact of FDI on the Italian economy as a whole has been limited. The depressed areas of the south, which attract limited Italian private-sector investment, would benefit substantially in terms of employment and through the spillover effect of advanced technology, management practices and production processes. However, almost all of the inward FDI stock is located in the north and centre of the country. Despite massive state investment in 1950-84, the south has continued to lag central Italy and the north in GDP per head terms (less than 55% of the average in the centre and north). The unemployment rate in the south is almost double the national average and about three times higher than that in the north.
Potential
The possibility of higher FDI inflows in the forecast period (2019-23) will be hampered by the uncertainty caused by the euro zone crisis and the fact that most of the factors that have deterred FDI in the past will remain in place. The Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-Lega administration has also signalled a less friendly policy stance towards foreign investment, marginally tightening labour contract regulations through its so-called Dignity Decree, definitively approved in August 2018, and enforcing penalties on foreign firms that take advantage of government investment incentives and then divest or relocate production to other markets. Over the forecast period a slight improvement is expected in the efficiency of the public administration, as a result of recent and ongoing reforms. The performance of the state body responsible for attracting foreign investors may also improve. Given Italy's need to reduce its dependence on imported energy, there could be potential for investment in the still state-dominated energy sector as liberalisation continues to make progress and the authorities are forced to focus on investment in renewable energy sources, following the decision in mid-2011 to abandon plans to return to nuclear-power generation. Under the M5S-Lega government, which has taken an economic nationalist approach to policymaking, political opposition to foreign interest in ownership of utility networks and possibly some companies in the manufacturing sector is likely to continue, as such companies are deemed to be of a "strategic" nature. M5S, which has taken strong environmental stances in the past, may also use potential ecological consequences as a justification for limiting inward investment, particularly in infrastructure or energy projects. Banking sector reforms may increase opportunities for foreign investment in smaller Italian banks, but there appears to be limited interest at present.

Population growth is projected to come to a virtual halt
Having declined for several years in the late 1990s, Italy's total population increased moderately in 1999-2013, rising by an average of 0.4% per year. Since then the population has increased only marginally, to 60.6m in 2018, according to the UN's population estimates. The meagre increase was mainly driven by the natural decline of the Italian population, which has almost outpaced immigration. We expect the population to fall in the long term, as the expectation of scarce job opportunities due to the weakness of the economy has probably reduced the influx of immigrants and driven further emigration of young Italians. The Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-Lega government's tough stance on immigration may further discourage foreigners from settling in Italy. Since the EU's March 2016 agreement with Turkey, the flow of migrants from Turkey to Greece and on to northern Europe has more or less ceased, but this has coincided with a sharp increase in migrant flows to Italy. Migrant inflows fell sharply in 2018. This is partly due to stepped-up collaboration with the Libyan authorities, but also to the inflexible stance of the M5S-Lega administration and of the Maltese authorities, which appears to be deterring migrant vessels from seeking to cross the central Mediterranean. In the past most migrants arriving in Italy moved on to other EU countries, notably Germany.
According to Istat (the national statistics office), the proportion of foreign residents in the total population has increased steadily in recent years, from 4.5% in 2005 to 8% at end-2013 and 8.7% at end-2018. The majority of immigrants live in the north and the centre of Italy, where foreign residents accounted for more than 10% of the population at end-2018. However, growth in the number of foreign nationals residing in the south has begun to outpace that in the north and the centre in recent years. The three largest national groups are Romanians, Albanians and Moroccans, who together account for about 40% of the total number of foreign residents. Even during periods of modest economic growth, shortages of skilled and even unskilled workers are likely to re-emerge in areas of high employment such as the north east, owing to deficiencies in the labour market.
Although almost 70% of Italians live in urban areas, the population is widely dispersed among numerous small cities and towns. As a result, local markets tend to be diffused and relatively small in scale.
Reforms seek to increase labour mobility
The steady rise in the employment rate (the percentage of people aged 20-64 in employment) since the mid-1990s came to a halt in 2008. At 62.3% in 2016-just below the 62.9% employment rate in 2008-according to Eurostat, it was 10 percentage points lower than the EU28 average and the third-lowest rate in the EU. The reasons for this include cultural factors, but also the low effective retirement age and limited mobility from areas of high unemployment in the south to those of high employment in the north. Low labour mobility has been perpetuated to a large extent by the greater use of temporary employment contracts, especially for young workers, poor active labour market policies and an inadequate system of unemployment benefits. The labour market reforms approved since 2012 aim to address some of these issues gradually during the forecast period (2019-23). In spite of the projected decline in the working-age population during the forecast period, the labour force will increase moderately. This will be attributable to greater female participation as well as pension reforms, which have reduced the incentive for early retirement.
The rise in the proportion of the elderly will put pressure on pensions and healthcare
During the forecast period the number of people of working age will be considerably lower than the number of people reaching 65. As a result, Italy's old-age dependency ratio (the ratio of people aged over 65 to those of working age) will rise further. At an estimated 39.2% in 2018, it is the highest in the EU, and will continue to rise. This trend, combined with the continued rise in life expectancy, will continue to put upward pressure on public expenditure on pensions and care for the elderly. Italy's public pension spending has been on a steadily rising trend and is among the highest in the EU as a share of GDP. According to figures from the Ministry of the Economy, public pension spending is projected to decline gradually over the next ten years, from a peak of about 16% in 2013-14, owing to a series of reforms introduced since the beginning of the 1990s. This trend could slow marginally, however, if the M5S-Lega government takes further measures to undo the 2011 Fornero pension reform, the most recent effort to improve the social security system's sustainability.

Italy is a major market, but growth potential remains limited
Italy is one of the largest markets in Europe, with a population of just over 60m, and is one of its most affluent nations. However, growth potential remains limited because the country is a mature consumer market with weak income and population growth prospects.
In 2015 the economy began to emerge from a protracted recession. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the recovery to continue during the forecast period (2019-23) but domestic demand growth will remain subdued, given high unemployment, weak business investment, the ongoing need for fiscal consolidation in Italy, high taxation and moderate wage growth.
In terms of private consumption per head, Italy is just below the euro area average, but well below Finland, Sweden, France and Germany. However, the relative weakness of Italian economic growth for much of the past 15-20 years means that GDP per head-at purchasing power parity (PPP) conversion rates that explicitly adjust for differences in price levels between countries-has fallen steadily as a percentage of the EU28 average, remaining below 100% since 2013. GDP per head at PPP rates stood at US$39,041 in 2016 and an estimated US$41,486 last year. Income levels differ greatly on a regional basis, with GDP per head in the south about 46% of that in the north. Development policies in the past 50 years have done little to close the gap.

Despite relatively high income levels, spending on food, beverages and tobacco is still high as a share of total consumer spending, at about 18%-just above the level in France, but significantly above that in the Netherlands (about 15%), Germany (13.9%) and the UK (12%). We expect it to decline only gradually during the forecast period, largely because of subdued spending on other categories of goods and services.
Consumer credit demand has begun to rise after several years of stagnation and/or contraction. Household indebtedness is relatively low, and interest rates on consumer loans have declined and are expected to rise only moderately in 2019-23, containing the proportion of disposable income spent on debt servicing. Still, we expect only moderately stronger demand for big-ticket items and branded goods, as consumers are likely to postpone purchases until sentiment improves further and risks to the recovery diminish. Rates of ownership of traditional consumer durable goods, such as white goods and passenger cars, are generally high, so demand will be driven by technological change and the need to replace ageing stock.
Demand for electronic goods, such as computers (especially laptops and tablets) and smartphones, has shown a tendency to outperform the rest of the consumer goods market. Growth will be driven by innovations such as smartphones, tablet computers and, more recently, wearable technology. However, weak income growth will dampen demand. Personal computer (PC) access lags well behind countries such as the UK and Germany, where the penetration rate is above 90% of households, and France, where it is about 84%, compared with about 73% in Italy.
The ageing population will drive growth in healthcare spending
Demographic trends will have an important impact on spending patterns. The ageing population will continue to drive overall healthcare spending, but we expect efforts to curb public healthcare expenditure to be introduced in order to meet budgetary targets.
Italians tend to live at home with their parents often until their mid-thirties. Thus, a larger portion of the disposable income of those aged 18-35 has tended to be spent on leisure and consumer goods than in other countries, although this trend is likely to be offset by low salaries for many young people who have work and by one of the highest youth unemployment rates (among the 15-24 age group) in Europe, despite its gradual decline in recent years. In June 2018 it was 32.6%, down from a peak of 43.5% in March 2014-almost double pre-crisis levels in 2007-08.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Initial conditions: Italy's economic growth performance has been poor in the past two decades, even in comparison with the sluggish average rate of growth achieved by core countries within the EU. Besides undergoing severe fiscal consolidation during the 1990s in order to join the euro area, which dampened growth in that decade, the Italian economy has suffered from a steady loss of competitiveness owing to low productivity growth and rising unit labour costs (reflecting falling output, despite wage moderation since 1993)-in contrast to the situation in its main trading partners.
The weakness of Italy's political and institutional framework policy hinders policy formulation, as reforms are frequently delayed or watered down under pressure from a wide range of interest groups. The current administration has denounced the emphasis on structural reforms advocated by the EU and, at least nominally, espoused by previous governments. It may undo some of the meagre progress made in recent years and is unlikely to enact policy changes that will improve the country's competitiveness. Italy's public finances also remain weak, limiting the scope to reduce taxation or stimulate demand during cyclical downturns. Major brakes on Italy's long-term growth will be the country's unfavourable demographic profile, low labour participation rates, a collapse in fixed investment during the recent recession, and low levels of investment in research and development (R&D).
Unfavourable demographic trends will weigh on long-term growth
Demographic trends: Italy's demographic profile is particularly unfavourable. Projected net immigration is expected to be insufficient to halt the continued decline in the working-age population in the long-term forecast period up to 2050. Italy's labour market participation rate is expected to rise from current low levels of about 66%, but only moderately, reflecting an increase in the number of women joining the workforce and a gradual rise in the minimum retirement age. However, it will remain well below the OECD average (about 72% in 2018) and will be insufficient to prevent an annual average decline in the labour force of 0.7% in 2019-50.
External conditions: The effects of the global crisis of 2008-09 and the height of the euro area crisis in 2010-13 will be felt for years. The risk that the sovereign debt crisis in financially stressed peripheral countries in the euro area, including Italy, will lead to a partial or even complete break-up of the single currency area, which would have severe negative consequences for Italy's long-term economic prospects, has eased, but The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that it is more likely than not that Greece will leave the euro area during our medium-term forecast period. Even without Greece in the euro area, the euro zone member states are still a long way from resolving the structural shortcomings of the single currency area, and the rhetoric of the Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-Lega government risks provoking instances of market volatility.
The rhetoric of the government risks provoking instances of market volatility
Italian companies have generally been slow to adapt to the rigours of fixed exchange rates in the euro area and the increase in competition from goods produced in low-cost developing countries, although some traditional manufacturing sectors have undergone restructuring in recent years, notably textiles and clothing, and automotive. This difficulty seems unlikely to change in the medium to long term. In the past, clusters of family-owned small and medium-sized export-oriented manufacturing companies located in the so­called industrial districts in the north and centre of the country showed greater flexibility and ability to adapt to changing external conditions than Italy's few large companies. However, more recently they have struggled to compete in some low- to medium-technology sectors. This is attributed to the lack of investment in R&D and innovation and marketing, as well as to difficulties in protecting and promoting the generic ''Made in Italy" brand, which has long been considered synonymous with good quality and style. To survive, Italian companies will have to expand in size and increasingly outsource low-value-added production to locations in central and eastern Europe and Asia, where costs-especially labour costs-are lower. The reluctance to relinquish control will hinder the expansion of family-owned businesses, which also often face difficult choices in terms of management succession.
With institutional change off the agenda, economic reform will be slow
Institutions and policy trends: Italy's poor growth performance has raised concerns among policymakers about the country's future economic prospects. Policy responses triggered by such debates in the past have generally been short lived. Some reforms have been introduced since the financial turmoil of late 2011. However, popular and political resistance to reform halted the Renzi government's attempt to overhaul Italy's institutional framework in 2014-16, taking institutional change off the political agenda for the foreseeable future. Without a substantial improvement in its political and institutional framework, Italy's efforts to carry out reforms will continue to lag the rapid pace of change in the world economy and the increase in competition. The M5S-Lega administration, which campaigned forcefully against the constitutional reform, has no intention of pursuing further institutional changes and will seek to loosen fiscal consolidation marginally and soften recent structural reforms.
In particular, Italy will need further liberalisation of its product and services markets, although recent reforms, if they are not reversed, should help to reduce labour market rigidities over the medium to long term. A more comprehensive system of unemployment protection envisaged under the 2012 and 2014 reforms could help to enhance labour mobility, but there may be a lack of resources without more drastic cuts in public spending on pensions, which is projected to ease from a peak of just under 16% of GDP in 2013-14 to just above 15% in 2019, according to the Treasury (before rising again until the late 2040 and falling again sharply thereafter). The M5S-Lega government has vowed to roll back the most recent reform, passed in 2011, which could lead to a deterioration in the pension spending profile. To raise long-term productivity growth, the country will also have to improve the quality of human capital. Recent education reforms have sought to address shortcomings in the education system, including high drop-out rates and mismatches between the skills needed by employers and qualifications held by potential employees.
A more favourable policy environment would boost long-term growth
Long-term performance: Our baseline forecast is that Italian GDP growth will average 0.8% per year in 2019-50, which is considerably weaker than what was until recently considered to be Italy's trend rate of growth (1.5%). The main brake on long-term growth will be an unfavourable demographic profile, which will be offset only partly by expected moderate improvements in labour productivity and technological infrastructure. Other industrialised countries will continue to grow faster than Italy, and so it will fall further behind in terms of GDP per head, which in the decade to 2017 fell from 107% of the EU28 average to 96%. In addition, decades of massive public-sector spending have done little to narrow the large income gap between the more developed centre and north of Italy, and the south of the country. This imbalance is expected to continue to weigh on Italy's overall growth performance in the long term. A more favourable political environment could produce a better economic growth performance in the long term, but the chance of improvements in Italy's institutional framework being implemented in the short to medium term is limited.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Climate change is expected to have a moderate, but clearly negative effect on Italian living standards and the economy. Hotter summers increase the risk of drought, particularly in the country's southern and island regions, in many parts of which water is scarce. This will have an impact on food crops and agricultural production, and could affect human health, especially among the country's growing elderly population, as well. In 2017 six of 20 Italian regions called on the government to declare a state of emergency owing to water stress. In addition to putting traditional agricultural products such as citrus fruits and wine grapes at risk, an increased incidence of drought will also heighten the risk of wildfires. Italy has about 7,600 km of coastline, and rising sea levels could put some low-lying coastal areas of the country at risk of flooding. Rising seas will be particularly problematic for the city of Venice, a major tourist destination and a regional capital, and more erratic weather patterns are likely to strain ageing infrastructure. This year The Economist Intelligence Unit has developed a model to show the impact of climate change on long-term growth and we find that the Italian economy will be 1.9% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
Technological developments
Despite Italy's sizeable manufacturing base and the presence of some notable high-technology firms, technological uptake has been limited, constrained in part by small average firm size and family management, which in some cases limits innovation. In 2017-18 a representative survey of nearly 24,000 industrial firms conducted by the Ministry of Economic Development found that only 8.4% had implemented technologies associated with "Industry 4.0", or the trend towards automation and data exchange in manufacturing, such as 3D printing, the Internet of Things, Cloud technologies, or Big Data analytics. The share rises sharply, from 6% of firms with fewer than ten employees, to about 47% of firms with 250 employees or more. In 2016 research and development (R&D) spending accounted for just 1.3% of GDP-well below the EU average of 2%. Meanwhile the trade balance of high-technology goods stood at -0.54% of GDP in 2015 (latest data available). Since 2016, a series of tax credits and deductions known as Impresa 4.0 has been introduced to encourage investment in R&D and productivity-enhancing technologies, but a higher level of direct support and possibly an upskilling of the labour force may be necessary to take full advantage of technological advances. Persons with a tertiary degree or employed in science and technology account for about 33% of total employment, and higher education suffers from relatively high dropout rates and long university completion times.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Thailand--highlights: Political outlook
The government elected in March 2019 will remain aligned to the military junta during its four-year term. It will consist of a 19-party coalition led by the Phalang Pracharat, with the former coup leader, Prayuth Chan-ocha, continuing as prime minister. The military's overarching influence will be ensured by the constitution drafted by the junta in 2016-17, which will lead to policy continuity on major infrastructure and investment reforms. Nonetheless, the presence of a large and vocal opposition, as well as governance through a coalition, will result in more delayed policymaking than was the case under junta rule. Other organised (but non-violent) challenges to the government cannot be ruled out, particularly later in the forecast period.
Thailand--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.44 6.88 41 36 9 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's business environment score rises in 2019-23, pushing up its global ranking to 36th, from 41st in 2014-18. Its regional position remains at ninth out of 17 countries. The macroeconomic environment will stabilise, although it will remain vulnerable to external conditions, particularly in the early part of the forecast period. Nonetheless, we expect improvements in policy towards private enterprise and foreign investment, as the new government strives to boost the country's regional competitiveness and to support high-value industries. The overall tax regime will remain stable and accommodative to business, although increases in the minimum wage and capital gains tax are likely later in the forecast period. Trade liberalisation will continue, with growing integration between Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) members and other countries in Asia. Construction will continue on big-ticket infrastructure projects, but will be hindered by the country's skilled labour shortage.

We expect Thailand's real GDP to expand by 3.2% a year on average in 2019-23. The relatively lacklustre performance reflects an easing of external demand in 2019-20, which will hit the country's strategic export-oriented sector. This will be further strained by elevated household debt, which will continue to crimp private consumption. Growth will nonetheless be buoyed by public investment in infrastructure development, expectations of policy continuity and growth in the tourism industry. Later in the forecast period, expansion will be supported further by a pick-up in global demand and the conclusion of several free-trade agreements.

The rate of population growth will slow in the forecast period as a result of effective family-planning programmes, sex education and changing social norms, such as later marriage and smaller families. Continued improvement in the prevention and treatment of infectious disease will contribute to a rising life expectancy and a growing share of the population over 65 years old. The ageing population will nonetheless put a burden on healthcare provision. Migrant labour from Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos will grow in absolute terms, helped by the development of economic zones at the border. This will serve to boost the labour force in 2019-23, against the trend of a declining domestic workforce.

Thailand is a sizeable market, with a population of 69.6m and nominal GDP equivalent to US$505.3bn (at market exchange rates) in 2018. The retail sector will create market opportunities, due in part to continued growth in the number of both domestic and foreign tourists. In the early part of the forecast period the new government will maintain populist policies for key interest groups in order to support the country's economic performance, but this will do little to address wide income gaps. Household debt will remain a dampener on consumer sentiment in the forecast period. Nonetheless, rising average incomes will support growth in the hospitality, leisure and technology sectors.
Thailand--highlights: Long-term outlook

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Thailand's long-term outlook hinges on the assumption that governments in the next ten years will possess sufficient political power to enact and continue structural reforms and develop infrastructure. Such reforms will improve the business environment and raise productivity. Nonetheless, there will be persistent challenges, owing to fiscal constraints, political tensions and strong regional competition. In later decades Thailand's unfavourable demographic profile and the impact of climate change will also start to reveal a significant, negative impact on GDP growth and political stability.

Background: Following a revolution in 1932, Thailand's absolute monarchy was replaced with a constitutional monarchy. While the elected government gained prominence, democracy was turbulent; there have been 19 coups since 1932. The last coup took place in 2014, when the democratically elected government led by Yingluck Shinawatra was removed following months of political turmoil, in a fate similar to that which befell her older brother and former prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, in 2006. Thailand returned to a limited form of democracy in 2019. Although orderly elections were held, a constitution effectively designed by the junta ensured that a military-aligned party, the Phalang Pracharat, assumed power (at the head of a coalition).
Political structure: Following the recent transition from junta administration to nominally civilian government, parliament takes the form of a 750-seat National Assembly, consisting of an elected 500-seat House of Representatives (lower house) and a 250-seat Senate (upper house) that was appointed by the NCPO. The prime minister is appointed by the National Assembly, and the king, Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, remains the symbolic head of state.
Policy issues: The new military-aligned government will continue to focus on improving the investment environment. It will pursue the public-investment drive in infrastructure initiated by the junta in an effort to boost the country's long-term economic performance. The military's focus on long-term policy continuity will reassure many foreign investors deterred by potential political instability, but growing regional competition will detract from Thailand's attractiveness as an investment destination. Governance through a 19-party coalition, as well as the presence of a large and vocal opposition, will also result in delays and gridlock on legislative issues not mandated in the junta-drafted constitution.
Taxation: Corporate income tax stands at 20%. Tax concessions are available for firms that list on the stockmarket. Value-added tax (VAT) stands at 7%. Personal income tax rises to 35% on annual taxable earnings exceeding Bt5m (US$150,000).
Foreign trade: Thailand recorded a merchandise trade surplus (fob-fob) of US$22.3bn in 2018, down from US$34.2bn in 2017. As a result, the current-account surplus stood at US$35.2bn in 2018, down from its 2017 level of US$50.2bn.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
A military-aligned government assumed power in July 2019 following the national legislative election held in March. The government consists of a 19-party coalition led by the Phalang Pracharat, with a former general and coup leader, Prayuth Chan-ocha, as prime minister. The National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO, the military junta) ruled Thailand following the military coup of 2014 and continues to exercise influence on public affairs through a constitution drafted by its members in 2016-17. The legislature comprises a 250-seat Senate (upper house) appointed by the NCPO and endorsed by the king, and a 500-seat House of Representatives (lower house), elected democratically. These features will incline future regimes to be aligned with the junta's preferences. Nonetheless, the military's grip is weakened by the fact that the Phalang Pracharat governs in a coalition and the lower house includes a large and vocal opposition (led by Puea Thai, the party of two former prime ministers-and siblings-Yingluck and Thaksin Shinawatra, and the newly formed Future Forward Party). We expect the government to complete its four year term.
King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, who was formally crowned in May 2019, will oversee stability in the monarchy. Although the king will remain removed from day-to-day politics, he will adopt a more centralised style of leadership than that adopted by his revered late father. Later in the forecast period, the military will look to the monarchy to legitimise its own political role. This will result in a greater intertwining of royal and military networks as the country navigates a return to quasi-civilian rule. Nonetheless, the king's prominent place in Thai society will diminish in coming years, as the new monarch fails to command the same level of reverence among the public that his father did.

Political outlook: Political stability
Although junta rule formally came to an end in mid-July, the military will retain a dominant influence over government in 2019-23. National legislative elections held in March under a new electoral system, which was in effect designed by the junta, resulted in a government led by the military-aligned Phalang Pracharat party, under the prime ministership of the coup leader, Prayuth Chan-ocha. The military establishment's control over government will be further assured by an entirely junta-appointed Senate (upper house) and a ministerial cabinet that retains several former military generals in key posts.
The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that political stability will be maintained in the short term. This will be largely because of the continued participation of opposition parties in the political process. Voter turnout for the election, at nearly 75%, was high, and the opposition gained a sizeable share of seats in the House of Representatives (the lower house). These factors will incline anti-coup forces to respect the results of the election in the medium term, and help to prevent large-scale public unrest.
Later in the forecast period, the risk of parties boycotting the formal political process and leading protests against the military-dominated government will rise as it becomes clear that even a sizeable parliamentary opposition cannot push through many of its preferred policies. Under this scenario, the military could revert to total control of government, with basic public order preserved via its command over the security forces.
The rule of King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun, who was formally crowned in May 2019 after two years on the throne, will have a minimal impact on political stability in 2019-23. The military establishment depends on royal endorsement for much of its political legitimacy. It has therefore ensured the continuance of the monarchy in line with the wishes of the late king and has proactively suppressed criticism of the new monarch via lese-majesty laws. This will continue under the next administration.
King Maha has sought to consolidate his position in the political sphere by customising rules concerning the delegation of the monarch's authority and control over the royal estate. However, royal intrusion into everyday politics will remain rare. Indeed, many of the changes were aimed at ensuring that the king could continue to reside outside the country for long periods without having to delegate his powers. The king's decision to block the prime-ministerial candidacy of his sister, Princess Ubolratana Mahidol, in early 2019 also reflects a commitment to remaining removed from parliamentary politics.
The insurgency in the Muslim-dominated southern provinces of Yala, Pattani and Narathiwat will continue. It will consist of small-scale attacks against the security forces and-occasionally-religious sites frequented by civilians. However, the insurgency presents only a minimal threat to overall political stability-the possibility of the insurgency spreading to other parts of the country remains low. We therefore do not expect the situation to trigger public unrest or threaten the tourism sector in 2019-23.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The outlook for political and institutional effectiveness will be underpinned by policy continuity under the military-aligned government, as well as broad respect for the junta-drafted constitution of 2016-17. In particular, the Phalang Pracharat's ability to pass and implement legislation will be supported by the constitutionally mandated 20-year "National Strategy"-a blueprint for development devised by the junta. Although the party will govern in alliance with 18 other parties, support on most issues (and especially those related to infrastructure and investment) will be guaranteed by the fact that the majority of party leaders are loyalists keen to remain in power. Nonetheless, occasional disagreements will emerge within the coalition, such as on the issue and scope of constitutional amendments. This will lead to a more delayed and negotiated form of policymaking than was the case under the junta's unilateral rule.
More significant threats to government effectiveness will arise from the vocal opposition, which has vehemently criticised the military's continued grip on power. Dissent will probably be voiced by prominent parties such as the Future Forward Party and Puea Thai, focusing largely on policy specifics and matters not mandated in the National Strategy. Issues such as income inequality, political accountability, military spending and the oversight of infrastructure projects will feature prominently on the opposition's agenda for scrutiny. This will lead to instances of legislative gridlock and stymied policymaking.
Nonetheless, the Phalang Pracharat will devote significant resources to populist policies, to appease interest groups such as agricultural producers, while simultaneously pursuing a pro-business push. Avoiding the creation of future political tensions will remain a key underlying priority. The junta did not make significant progress in reconciling the political differences between the rural population of the north (who supported Thaksin) and the elite in southern Thailand (who are represented by his detractors, the current establishment). The military-aligned government will thus continue to find it difficult to satisfy the two major camps and may face rising opposition from one or both in the medium term-the same tensions that have plagued its predecessors.
Corruption will remain a significant problem in many of the country's institutions, including the military. Cases under the new government involving unelected officials, particularly those with explicit military links, may serve as a flashpoint for discontent over the new constitutional system and its lack of accountability. If open discontent does materialise, it is more likely to be the result of a cumulative series of incidents and thus to occur later in the forecast period. Although the new administration will make efforts to show a tougher stance against corruption, for instance by encouraging use of a dedicated court, these measures will be pursued selectively in accordance with political influence. Given the slow progress of similar initiatives under previous military-aligned governments, there is little reason to believe that the new administration will be any more successful in clamping down on corrupt activities.
Political outlook: Election watch
National polls for the 500-seat House of Representatives (lower house) were held on March 24th 2019. The military-aligned Phalang Pracharat secured 116 seats (97 constituency seats and 19 party-list seats). This compared with 136 seats won by the Puea Thai party of former prime ministers Yingluck and Thaksin Shinawatra, and 81 seats won by the newly formed Future Forward Party under the leadership of Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit.
Despite obtaining a minority in the lower house, Phalang Pracharat forged an alliance with 18 parties, including the prominent Bhumjaithai and Democrat parties, to secure 254 of the total 500 seats in the lower house. In combination with the junta-appointed 250-seat Senate (upper house), this allowed the appointment of Prayuth, the junta's preferred candidate for prime minister, on June 5th. The next national elections are due in 2023.
Political outlook: International relations
We expect a swift and full normalisation of Thailand's ties with Western governments under the new government, despite the significant influence that the military will retain in public affairs. This normalisation will include the resumption of talks on an EU-Thailand free-trade agreement (FTA). Indeed, many Western countries that had severed links with Thailand after the coup in 2014 partially restored relations during the junta's rule for the sake of economic ties and in response to wider concerns about China's political influence in the region. Prayuth met the heads of state of the US, UK and France prior to the elections, and relations with these countries should deepen with a return to a democratic government. Meanwhile, Japan preserved most diplomatic engagement, including bilateral FTA negotiations, during the junta's rule. This reflects that country's concern that its economic influence in Thailand may be overtaken as Chinese investment in the country rises. This, as well as a relocation of Japanese firms to Thailand amid US-China trade tensions, should lead to a strengthening of Thailand-Japan economic ties between Thailand and Japan in 2019-23.
Nevertheless, China's influence in Thailand will also continue to grow in 2019-23. Crucially, the two countries have no conflicting territorial claims in the South China Sea and are important trading partners. Economic ties are set to strengthen further as Thailand focuses on forging bilateral deals with Chinese state-owned enterprises under its public investment drive. A public backlash against projects under this remit-similar to those that have been emerging recently in some other countries engaged in projects under China's Belt and Road Initiative-is unlikely, as the Thai government has negotiated more favourable terms on key projects. However, this approach has created its own setbacks, as illustrated by the stop-start progress of the planned China-Laos-Thailand high-speed rail project. Such tussles will continue to delay the economic benefits of greater regional integration.
Increasing bilateral co-operation with China is unlikely to obstruct Thailand's ongoing efforts to engage with its neighbours in the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN). This is in part because tensions between other ASEAN members and China in relation to territorial disputes in the South China Sea will remain subdued for much of the forecast period. This will allow Thailand to strengthen relations with ASEAN neighbours Cambodia and Myanmar through increased economic co-operation.

The macroeconomic environment will stabilise in the forecast period, although it will remain vulnerable to external conditions. An improvement in the scores for policy towards private enterprise and competition and policy towards foreign investment under an elected government will encourage a moderate rise in investment. Some relocation of supply chains to Thailand, amid regional trade tensions, will also provide a modest boost to manufacturing activity. This will be aided by an open capital account and a relatively stable currency.
However, lacklustre domestic demand will remain a major drag on business sentiment, with high household debt weighing on private consumption prospects. The Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) will remain independent and monetary policy will be fairly conservative. Ambitious transport infrastructure projects boost the score for infrastructure by the largest increment of all the categories, as a drive to make comprehensive improvements to the country's connectivity gets under way.
