Business environment outlook: Thailand's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The authorities reorganise the management of several state-owned enterprises but do not sell off significant assets.
2021-23: Thailand improves its domestic intellectual property rights (IPR) enforcement regime, which leads to the country's removal from the US Trade Representative's IPR watchlist.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The opposition's demands for greater oversight of infrastructure projects improve the quality of investment, despite occasional project delays.
2021-23: Opposition to the sale of assets to foreigners persists, particularly in the utilities sector. The authorities introduce new incentives to promote inward investment in targeted industries while removing incentives in low-value-added sectors.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Administrative procedures for trade transactions with other members of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) are streamlined amid efforts to step up the integration of the ASEAN Economic Community.
2021-23: Negotiations on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership agreement between ASEAN and Japan, Australia, China, India, New Zealand and South Korea enter their final stages.
Taxes
2019-20: New land and property taxes are enforced, but commercial rates remain low. Income tax is reduced for low-income households in order to support consumption and address inequality.
2021-23: Mandatory social-security payments for employers rise from 3% to 5%. The government raises the rate of value-added tax (VAT) slightly from its current level of 7%.
Financing
2019-20: Access to business financing benefits from the continued development of the local bond and equity markets.
2021-23: Commercial banks based in other ASEAN countries begin to offer retail services in Thailand under the ASEAN Banking Integration Framework.
The labour market
2019-20: A clampdown on unregistered migrants affects the availability of low-skilled labour in the short term. The minimum wage is raised gradually in industries that are able to absorb cost pressures.
2021-23: Shortages of skilled labour become more acute, driving up costs in high-value-added industries. The government loosens immigration controls on skilled foreign workers.
Infrastructure
2019-20: The expansion of road and rail infrastructure progresses slowly, providing a boost to the construction sector.
2021-23: Expansion programmes are completed at Don Mueang and Suvarnabhumi international airports in Bangkok.
Technological readiness
2019-20: The government implements regulations related to data privacy, electronic transactions and cybersecurity.
2021-23: The Board of Investment continues to prioritise projects under the ten sectors listed within the "Thailand 4.0" plan.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.5 7.8 32 35 9 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
There will be a slight improvement in Thailand's macroeconomic environment score during the forecast period, which will lead to a jump in the country's global and regional rankings: relatively low public debt, a firmly positive current-account balance and fairly stable fiscal, monetary and exchange-rate policies will underpin macroeconomic stability. Economic expansion will remain in line with the pace achieved in recent years, averaging 3.2% in 2019-23, compared with 3.1% in 2014-18. Growth will slump to a multi-year low of 2.4% in 2020, owing to muted private consumption growth and a slowdown in the US economy, a key trading partner. External and domestic demand will pick up in the later part of the forecast period, but growing competition with peers in the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) will keep a lid on growth.
Economic stability will improve gradually during the forecast period
The military's direct grip on economic affairs will loosen in 2019-23, leading to gradual implementation and approval of major spending plans. Nonetheless, adherence to the constitutionally mandated "National Strategy", the junta's 20-year blueprint for development, will underpin continuity in major infrastructure projects and demand-side stimulatory measures. This will ensure that business-oriented tax reform and investment incentives are maintained and expanded in 2019-23, and that major infrastructure investment projects continue beyond this period. In the early part of the forecast period, the export-dependent economy will remain vulnerable to external headwinds, which will weaken growth. Nonetheless, broad economic stability will be ensured by sound macroeconomic fundamentals, including a large current-account surplus and manageable levels of public debt. This will be helped by a recovery in growth in 2021-22, as global economic conditions improve.
The BOT will also remain independent and credible in its regulation of the financial sector and management of the economy. The central bank governor, Veerathai Santiprabhob, who took the reins in October 2015, is well respected and likely to be appointed for a second term in 2020. This will ensure that the BOT remains relatively free from political pressure in setting policy rates and managing excess volatility of the local currency, the baht.
The local currency has appreciated gradually against the US dollar since 2016, mirroring an increase in the current-account surplus and foreign-exchange reserves. We expect the baht to stabilise from 2020 as macroeconomic fundamentals strengthen. The BOT will intervene to prevent a strengthening baht by tightening foreign-exchange monitoring and implementing measures to curb hot-money inflows. This will be partly motivated by a preference for a weaker currency to aid exporters.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.3 7.0 35 26 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
We expect a significant improvement in the score for policy towards private enterprise and competition as the government makes more aggressive efforts to attract investment. This will help Thailand's global ranking to improve from 35th in 2014-18 to 26th in 2019-23. However, the country's regional ranking will remain unchanged owing to concurrent improvements in other Asian countries. Corruption and favouritism continue to hinder free-market dynamics, despite the growing prominence of the National Anti-Corruption Commission (NACC) in recent years. The political elite retains a disproportionate influence on commercial affairs: individuals with ties to military leaders and the traditional establishment tend to extract concessions from government and influence legal judgments. Nonetheless, the return to a quasi-civilian regime should lead to a modest improvement in government accountability.
Privatisation of SOEs will proceed at a sluggish pace
Reforms to bolster the operational efficiency of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) have been proposed in recent years, but have yet to be implemented. Privatisation remains a sensitive issue among both powerful interests and the public. It is unlikely that the military-aligned government will sell off lucrative state assets, as this would redistribute economic rents away from current holders. A long-standing area of concern is the lack of protection for intellectual property (IP): legal provisions are in place to control piracy of digital and online content, but enforcement is poor, even by regional standards. The government will continue to use price controls for some basic goods to keep them affordable; prices for goods on the "sensitive" list cannot be changed without the permission of the Ministry of Commerce.
The reform of corporate governance at 56 SOEs, controlling assets worth over US$300bn, will continue, albeit at a slow and uneven pace. The government will probably assign low priority to SOE reform in the early part of the forecast period, although the broad mandate will remain part of the junta-developed, constitutionally binding 20-year National Strategy. Later, we expect the passage of legislation to restructure SOEs and reform key parts of business processes, which was first introduced in 2017. This will expand and improve procurement processes, which will help to increase transparency, reduce corruption and boost competition in the public-private sphere. Meanwhile, "superboards" devised under the junta regime-to address public-sector corruption and oversee reform-will remain prone to political influence.
Thailand has been on the US Trade Representative's lower-priority Watch List for intellectual property since late 2017. While the country has made progress on matters related to patents and copyright legislation in recent years, instances of IP infringement remain relatively frequent. This is due to a combination of legislative and enforcement issues, such as the country's non-compliance with the World Intellectual Property Organisation's Copyright Treaty, a limited level of punitive measures and patent application backlogs. We expect weakness in this regard to slow the country's progress towards becoming a "digital economy" and to act as a disincentive to foreign brands looking to do business in Thailand.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.4 6.9 48 39 9 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for policy towards foreign investment will improve moderately in 2019-23, compared with the historical period, raising both the country's regional and global rankings. Thailand will continue to encourage inward investment, especially in higher-value-added industries, as part of the "Thailand 4.0" industrial policy. Further incentives are almost certain to be rolled out in 2019-23 and the BOI will continue to fast-track investment approvals. The government will also not revive proposals to amend the Foreign Business Act, which would make it more difficult for foreign companies to control Thai entities unless they own a majority of shares.
The BOI's investment promotion strategy for 2015-22 offers incentives and government support for foreign investors. The strategy's current focus is on advancing the use of technology, enhancing productivity and strengthening human capital, particularly in advanced, high-technology industries. It also focuses on the development of target areas by offering incentives to set up businesses in less developed parts of the country and promoting ten special economic zones (SEZs) along the land borders of Thailand and its neighbours. The latter are in place to take advantage of increasing international labour flows under the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC), which was formally established in 2015. Incentives in the ten SEZs include corporate income tax breaks in certain industries. These objectives dovetail with the longer-term Thailand 4.0 policy.
Incentives offered to foreign investment will increase
In addition to the ten border SEZs under development, a large coastal-situated economic zone in the form of the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) has also been designated, capitalising on an existing industrial belt along the eastern seaboard. Incentives for firms operating in the EEC include double tax deductions on some utilities for a ten-year period; access to cheap credit; and the ability to use unskilled foreign labour from neighbouring countries. Meanwhile, the EEC will benefit from transport infrastructure upgrades linking it more effectively with the capital, Bangkok, and major air- and seaports, in addition to a range of tax and regulatory incentives. The promotion strategy will also introduce industrial developments based around the notion of "super-clusters". These will be collective industry hubs targeting, for instance, the automotive, electrical appliances, chemicals, digital, food production and medical industries. The BOI and the Ministry of Finance will provide tax relief and other incentives related to land ownership and work-permit facilitation. These efforts will be undermined slightly, however, by delays in the implementation of key projects and the below-par prospects for private consumption, which are low by the standards of other countries at Thailand's income level.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.2 8.7 37 27 7 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The score for foreign trade and exchange controls rises in 2019-23, driven by improvements in the country's foreign-trade regime and increased regional integration. This causes Thailand's global ranking to jump from 37th in 2014-18 to 27th in 2019-23. Thailand's reliance on international trade, as well as signs of easing external demand in 2019-20, will ensure that the government maintains a favourable relationship with major export markets in the early part of the forecast period. Authorities will be more likely to accommodate the demands of influential domestic groups in 2021-23, when we expect to see a recovery in external trade conditions. The government will be keen to diversify export markets and to pursue trade agreements, both individually and in partnership with other ASEAN members. The bloc's agreements include those in place with China and India, and a combined agreement with Australia and New Zealand. Thailand will also be keen to complete negotiations on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), but progress will be slow.
In the meantime, the country will adhere to its commitments as a member of the World Trade Organisation. Thailand has accepted the obligations laid down in the IMF's Article VIII, which stipulates that transactions on the current account should be free of restrictions. Foreign investors do not face restrictions on the repatriation of profits and dividends. The central bank has eased restrictions on outward capital flows, but is likely to impose temporary measures to control capital inflows that pose a risk to macroeconomic stability.
Thailand will continue to liberalise its trade regime in line with its commitment to implementing the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC), which has already led to a lifting of most import duties on goods from other ASEAN member states. Freer movement of goods, services, investment and skilled labour (in eight selected sectors) between the ten member states came into effect at end-2015, although onerous customs regulations and non-tariff barriers continue to limit intra-regional trade. The share of services trade within ASEAN, which has remained flat in recent years, will grow in 2019-23 owing to the progressive implementation of the ASEAN Trade in Services Agreement (ATISA) from October 2019. This will replace the ASEAN Framework Agreement on Services (AFAS) and will cushion dwindling exports, increase the transparency in services trade and liberalise key subsectors such as healthcare.
Negotiation on a Thailand-EU FTA will resume
Formal talks on a bilateral free-trade agreement (FTA) between Thailand and the EU were put on hold after the 2014 coup and will probably resume in late 2019. European and Thai businesses are keen to conclude a deal, which would compensate in part for Thailand's loss of the EU's Generalised System of Preferences status in 2015. A Thai-EU deal is unlikely to be implemented before the end of the forecast period. In the interim, Thailand will face growing competition from regional peers such as Vietnam, which signed an FTA with the EU in mid-2019.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.9 8.0 11 11 5 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's score in the taxes category improves marginally in 2019-23, but this is not enough to prevent a drop in the country's regional ranking. The minor improvement in the score is due to our expectation that the government will raise value-added tax (VAT) later in the forecast period. Nonetheless, Thailand remains a very competitive territory overall for taxes. The country's tax regime is relatively simple and changes have been made in recent years to reduce the overall burden on households and firms. As a result, its ranking in this area has improved over time (although a relatively low tax/GDP ratio is a fiscal concern in the medium-to-long term). The standard rate of corporate tax was reduced from 30% in 2011 to 20% in 2013. We expect it to remain at 20%, given the government's aim of boosting the country's competitiveness as a destination for foreign investors and to mitigate the impact of higher minimum wage levels. Tax incentives are also widely available, particularly those aimed at drawing foreign investment in strategic, high-value industries. The personal income tax regime is also relatively favourable, with the top marginal rate standing at 35% for Thai and foreign workers with annual earnings over Bt5m (US$145,000). A cut in income tax for lower income thresholds is likely to be sanctioned in 2020, to support private consumption and gain populist support.
The VAT rate will be raised slightly towards the end of the forecast period
The junta repeatedly postponed an increase in the standard VAT rate in 2014-18. The government stated that it would maintain the rate at 7% until end-September 2019, although we expect this to be extended into 2020. The authorities will raise the rate in 2021-23 as they consolidate the public finances after private consumption returns to a stronger footing. This decision will also be influenced by calls from international organisations such as the IMF to push the rate back up. These calls will ensure that the VAT rate is not lowered earlier in the forecast period, despite calls from coalition parties such as the Bhum Jai Thai.
With changes to consumption taxes off the agenda in the earlier part of the forecast period, the military-aligned government will push for other tax reforms to address inequality and inject fiscal stimulus. This will include the provision of handouts in a bid to support consumption. These sops will range from allowing individuals to deduct income tax on purchases of selected consumer goods to income tax deductions for domestic hotel and travel expenses in particular tax years. Similarly, the government will support the real-estate market through subsidised loans and other targeted incentives, such as income tax deductions for first-time buyers in lower income brackets.
To cushion the fiscal impact of these measures, the government will make efforts to expand revenue collection, partly owing to pressure from the opposition. These will include measures to streamline tax-filing processes, an increase in the sugar tax in October 2019 and the imposition of capital gains tax later in the forecast period. Meanwhile, a property tax on land and building assets, which came into effect in March 2019, will have a minor impact on foreign business; the tax rates most applicable to them will be less than 2%.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.0 7.4 22 27 8 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's score for financing will improve in 2019-23, as the banking sector will be in better health. However, improvements in the financing environments of neighbouring countries will result in Thailand's regional ranking for the category remaining unchanged. Similarly, an improvement in countries outside the region will see its global ranking slip to 27th, from 22nd. Increased due diligence and prudential measures among banks helped to ensure that the ratio of non-performing loans to total loans remains relatively low, at 2.9%. This situation is expected to be sustained in 2019-23 as the BOT embarks on measures to tackle poor debt serviceability. This will bolster the overall health of the banking sector, ensuring that the supply of credit to private firms will not be significantly curtailed at any point during the forecast period.
There will be trend towards consolidation in the financial sector
The BOT and the finance ministry will continue to focus on increasing the competitiveness of the financial sector, principally via the consolidation of a number of private- and state-owned financial institutions, in anticipation of banking services liberalisation under the ASEAN Banking Integration Framework. Thailand is currently in negotiations with Malaysia, Indonesia and Myanmar to lower crossborder banking licence restrictions, which will lead to greater competition in the Thai banking sector. Thailand is also pursuing various efforts to reduce transaction costs for local banks, such as by facilitating local currency settlements with the Philippines, linking payment systems with Singapore and incorporating technology -such as quick response (QR) codes-to increase interoperability across markets. We expect the bulk of these financial liberalisation reforms to be implemented between Thailand and its ASEAN neighbours towards the end of the forecast period.
The local bond market will continue to expand under the guidance of the BOT. The market has experienced rapid growth in recent years, and is presently ASEAN's largest local-currency bond market. By March 2019 the size of the bond market stood at US$399bn, nearing the stock exchange market capitalisation of US$532bn. Although government bonds continue to dominate the market, at over 70% of all bonds issued, debt-laden large and medium-sized companies are increasingly using the bond market to refinance their bank loans and offshore borrowings. Strengthening demand in this market will continue in the early part of the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.5 6.2 29 43 8 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
The deterioration in Thailand's global and regional rankings in the labour market category reflects its waning competitiveness. The country is a labour-scarce economy and unemployment is low. Labour market conditions will, in general, remain adequate in terms of supporting the operations of foreign-invested enterprises, but weaknesses, especially rising wage costs and skill shortages, will persist. The country's advantages as a cost-efficient base for labour-intensive production are diminishing, amid growing competition from neighbouring economies such as Cambodia and Vietnam.
In addition to rising relative costs for low-skilled workers, shortages of labour trained to work in high-value industries pose a growing problem to the government's "Thailand 4.0" policy ambitions, which are premised on developing the country's advanced technology sectors. These skilled labour problems stem in large part from Thailand's underperforming education system, which ranks poorly both globally and regionally. Educational reforms in the last two decades have been poorly and inconsistently implemented, and there are currently no plans for a major overhaul of the system. The ability of the labour force to meet the needs of businesses (in terms of specialist skills) is thus likely to remain below global standards. Hiring foreign workers will continue to be relatively difficult and expensive, except for labour from other ASEAN countries in designated sectors. The scope for industrial unrest will remain limited by the country's relative attractiveness as an operating location and the low level of unionisation.
From January 2017 the nationwide daily minimum-wage schedule was replaced by minimum wages per province. The range of the wage floor was raised to Bt308-330 (around US$9) with effect from April 2018. An increase in the minimum wage has been floated by the new government, although it is likely to face opposition in parliament and among business associations owing to the damage it would incur on private sector costs and Thailand's regional competitiveness. Despite this, we expect the government to succeed in raising the minimum wage in 2020-21: this will be done gradually, beginning with industries that have the capacity to absorb inflationary pressure.
The retirement age will rise incrementally in 2019-23
Thailand is facing the social and economic consequences of a rapidly ageing society, including a steadily declining workforce as a share of the total population. The new government will introduce steps to mitigate this crisis towards the end of the forecast period. Proposals advocating a staggered increase in the retirement age of civil servants-from 60 years to 63-will be fully implemented in 2024. When the first increase is sanctioned, which we expect to happen in 2021-22, this will invariably put pressure on private employers to follow suit with a slight increase in the retirement age. This will be insufficient to address wider problems related to an ageing population, such as the need for matching skills and increasing elderly care.
Migrant workers account for over 10% of the total labour force, according to the UN. These workers typically come from neighbouring Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos, and fill low-skilled vacancies in industries such as agriculture, construction and domestic work. We expect the size of the local labour force to decline in Thailand during the forecast period, with the country becoming more reliant on migrant workers. This will be driven partly by the development of SEZs, which the government has opened in border areas in order to capitalise on the supply of low-cost migrant labour from neighbouring countries. Despite this, we expect structural issues related to the mistreatment of migrant workers to persist. International concern over potential human rights abuses in Thailand, especially in the fishing industry, have resulted in tighter regulation of protective measures for migrant workers, but the UN reports that exploitation still occurs. Occasional progress will be made to strengthen workers' legal rights, partly in collaboration with foreign governments such as Myanmar. Nonetheless, an accompanying crackdown on migrants without proper documentation will stymie the availability of foreign workers at the outset of the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.8 6.0 55 50 9 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand's infrastructure score will experience an improvement in the next five years, although faster developments in neighbouring countries will cause the country's regional ranking to fall from 9th to 10th. The military-aligned government will continue to prioritise long-pending "megaprojects", although these will still face occasional delays. Improvements in telecommunications services have also been slow. Although 4G coverage is widely available, average speeds remain slow by regional comparison. Electricity supplies have risen, but the potential for shortages remains. At present, over 70% of the country's electricity is generated using natural gas, according to the Energy Policy and Planning Office, making the country vulnerable to fluctuations in global gas prices. With gas supplies in the Gulf of Thailand in decline, the government's energy plans prioritise diversification of energy sources and the development of renewable energy. These goals are part of the Power Development Plan 2018, which lays out targets for energy production, consumption and imports from 2018 to 2037.
Many large infrastructure projects will be under way in 2019-23
The government has faced delays in the financing and implementation stages of its ambitious infrastructure development megaprojects owing to issues with land acquisition, environmental impact and commercial viability. This includes the high-speed railway linking Thailand and China, via Laos, which will near completion in 2021 after a decade of start-stop progress. Elsewhere, transport projects have faced delays due to wrangling over financing with Chinese and Japanese investors. This partly reflects the government's efforts to take advantage of the ongoing competition for geopolitical influence between the two countries; the Thai government has been seeking the best deal but has also taken a cautious approach to shifting its alliances, in light of China's growing economic influence and Japan's historical investment links. We expect these dynamics, as well as the return to democratically elected government, to result in uneven progress on priority projects in 2019-23. This is in large part because the government will no longer be able to use unilateral executive powers to fast-track priority projects, such as road and rail upgrades on the eastern seaboard and the expansion of the U-Tapao International Airport.
The state-run management company, Airports of Thailand, will upgrade three of the country's major airports in 2019-23 to increase passenger capacity: Don Mueang and Suvarnabhumi airports in Bangkok towards the end of the forecast period, and U-Tapao in Rayong province, south-east of the capital, in 2020. New airports will also be constructed in Chiang Mai and Phuket, although completion is likely to fall beyond the end of the forecast period. These will mainly be aimed at accommodating tourist arrivals from East Asia, especially China.
The telecoms sector will lag behind Thailand's regional peers
Thailand's telecoms networks have been slow to adopt the latest technology, exposing inefficiencies in the regulatory environment. The regulator expects the commercial launch of 5G bandwidth in 2020, although we believe that this will not take place before 2021, due to the high level of investment required and low business confidence. The new bandwidth will lag behind most other Asian countries in terms of speed, owing to shortfalls in service provider technology.
The government's Power Development Plan, which took effect in mid-2019, proposes to more than double the capacity of alternative energy sources by 2037 (primarily in solar and biomass), to import hydropower from neighbouring countries and to encourage the issuance of green bonds to finance energy projects. Nuclear power options are still under discussion but have faced significant public opposition. No new capacity from this form is expected to be added in the forecast period. This, and delays in transitioning to renewable energy, will ensure Thailand that remains reliant on natural gas for electricity production in 2019-23.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.5 6.1 51 48 11 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Australia, Bangladesh, China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam.
Thailand experiences a modest improvement in its technological readiness score in 2019-23, which boosts both its global and regional rankings. Nonetheless, internet use exerts a fundamental drag on Thailand's performance. Although the number of internet users per 100 population, at 56.8 in 2018, has increased in recent years, it remains below those of Malaysia (81.2) and the Philippines (60.1). This limits Thailand's viability for e-commerce and digital services. Its level of commercial innovation also falls below regional par. This is partly due to the preference of international companies with manufacturing operations in the country to carry out their research and development (R&D) elsewhere. This accounts in part for the low level of patent applications per capita.
Efforts to expand broadband access to villages will face delays
The new government has outlined plans to pursue digital infrastructure projects initiated by the junta as part of the Thailand 4.0 strategy and the 20-year digital roadmap. These include projects to bring national broadband to 25,000 remote communities, in order to develop rural areas and to give private-sector enterprises access to public infrastructure. We expect progress on this goal to be sluggish, owing to weak implementation capacity; the government has previously missed a target of delivering broadband to all villages by end-2018.
The Board of Investment has introduced import duty exemptions on raw materials used in R&D, to incentivise the development of innovative capacities in the private sector. Companies focused on biotechnology, nanotechnology, advanced materials or digital technology are also eligible for up to 13 years' exemption from corporate income tax if they co-operate with public research institutions in R&D.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Similarly to the junta that preceded it, the new government will continue to accord a high priority to economic revival and to pursue policies aimed at boosting the country's medium-to-long-term investment prospects, including ramping up public spending on infrastructure. This includes the development of a large special economic zone, the Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC), south-east of the capital, Bangkok, based on new and upgraded transport links. The drive to boost investment will also include the continuation of the sector-specific "Thailand 4.0" industrial policy package, which will provide significant investment incentives for foreign investors within and outside the EEC. Both of these plans fit broadly with the 20-year National Strategy, the junta's blueprint for the country's long-term social and economic development, and are likely to be pursued through large sums of foreign investment and ad hoc fiscal spending. Elsewhere, the government will look to diversify export markets in an effort to boost the flailing external sector.
Opposition efforts to scale back these reforms will often be unsuccessful owing to the new constitution, which restricts the alteration of policies deemed by the current military government to be important to Thailand's medium-to-long-term reform. Indeed, the military-aligned Senate will be permitted to join the House of Representatives in debating legislation pertaining to the National Strategy.
However, policy paralysis will sometimes occur on issues such as social welfare, inequality and military spending, where pro- and anti-junta forces tend to diverge, resulting in intermittent legislative gridlock and delays. Occasionally, policy disagreements will also emerge from within the Phalang Pracharat-led coalition. Demand-side stimulatory and relief measures to placate interest groups-such as farmers and low income households-will nonetheless remain prominent, but will lessen towards the end of the forecast period as the authorities seek to consolidate the public finances.

Economic forecast: Fiscal policy

We expect the budget deficit to average the equivalent of 2.7% of GDP in 2019-23. Infrastructure spending and populist handouts will form the bulk of government spending, particularly in the early part of the forecast period. The government will seek to mitigate the fiscal impact of these measures through incremental tax reform initiated under the junta. A reformed schedule of property taxes, which will be applied by 2020, will boost revenue later in the forecast period-albeit only modestly, as the original proposals were diluted in order to avoid public objections. Stronger trade growth in 2021-23 will boost revenue from import and export duties and help to ensure that the deficit remains below 3% of GDP throughout the forecast period. The slight raising of value-added tax (VAT) in the latter part of the forecast period, from the current rate of 7%, will also bolster revenue. The increase, however, will be gradual, as the government remains wary of dampening the modest rate of private consumption growth.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)

Short-term interest rate (year-end) 1.3 1.3 1.1 1.2 1.4 1.4
Money market interest rate (year-end) 1.5 1.6 1.5 2.0 2.4 2.4
We expect the Bank of Thailand (BOT, the central bank) to leave its policy rate, the one-day repurchase rate, unchanged at 1.75% throughout 2019. The BOT's decision to increase its policy rate in December 2018 was a precautionary measure against domestic financial risks after an extended period of low interest rates. The BOT is unlikely to reverse this decision in the short term for fear that household debt could rise to potentially destabilising levels, and has more firmly pursued measures to curb borrowing in recent months. Moreover, with the policy rate already at a low level, the central bank is likely to conclude that further rate cuts will have little positive impact on the real economy or managing exchange-rate volatility. In this context, the BOT will instead rely on fiscal policy and occasional capital controls to support economic performance.
Although inflation will firm from 2020, it will remain towards the lower end of the 1-4% target range set by the BOT. This will give the central bank the policy space to maintain an accommodative stance. Although a rate cut is not part of our core forecast, the likelihood of further loosening in early 2020 could heighten if falling household debt accompanies weak growth. The BOT will sanction rate rises from 2021 as domestic and external economic conditions strengthen, but the rate will not be high relative to historical standards.

We expect real GDP to average annual growth of 3.2% in 2019-23. This underwhelming rate of economic expansion will be attributable to muted private consumption growth, which will be weighed down by continued high levels of household debt and unremarkable real wage growth, and sluggish export-oriented production. Private consumption growth will be notably weak in 2020 owing to marginal real wage growth, amid subdued prospects for the global economy.
We expect exports of goods and services to grow by 3.5% per year on average in 2019-23, compared with 3.1% in 2014-18. Growth in this component will be underpinned by services exports, in the form of tourism. Volumes of goods shipments will be more uneven. A general easing of external demand for merchandise, driven in part by a slump in the consumer electronics cycle, is resulting in slower export growth this year. This will lead to a narrowing of the trade surplus, which will be exacerbated in 2020 as the US economy slows further. Merchandise exports will rebound after that as external demand from major global economies picks up again.
In the medium term, Thai automotive exporters are likely to reap benefits from the relocation of supply chains from China, partly as a result of US-China trade tension. In the short term, the boost to the external sector will be limited by the fact that Thailand's current manufacturing capacity covers only a small fraction of the automotive exports subject to higher tariffs. This limits the extent to which it can offer short-term, cost-effective solutions to businesses considering relocation, particularly in the light of the growth of other, lower-cost automotive manufacturing hubs in the region. Nonetheless, we expect positive benefits to be felt from 2020-21 onwards as producers of auto parts and vehicles move up the value chain through advanced manufacturing, and the development of the EEC boosts the hub's competitiveness.
We expect total fixed investment to grow at a significantly stronger pace in 2019-23 than in 2014-18. This is mostly owing to our baseline assumption that the military's influence over the elected government will ensure overarching stability, including in the business environment. Investment growth will be buoyed by major infrastructure projects, which will help to offset a downturn in private investment in 2020, amid weaker expectations for external demand. Investment will reach a peak of activity in 2022, supporting growth in capital goods imports as oil prices pick up. Despite a dip in 2020, private investment will be notably more robust in 2020-23 on average than in 2014-18 as foreign companies capitalise on incentives offered in the EEC and under the Thailand 4.0 initiative.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
On the supply side of the economy, we expect the industrial sector to grow most quickly, at an average annual rate of 3.9% in 2019-23. Thailand has been successful in taking the lead in certain industrial sectors, such as the automotive industry, in addition to some high-technology subsectors, most notably electronics and machinery components. However, its relative technical competitiveness will slowly decline owing to a lack of investment, growing regional competition and an easing of external demand early in the forecast period. These factors will put pressure on industrial growth in the early part of the forecast period, after which industrial production will accelerate amid increased public investment in infrastructure and a more stable policy environment. Stronger external demand in 2021-23 will also buoy investment sentiment in the largely export-oriented sector. Over the longer term, Thailand risks losing its role as a predominant producer of intermediate manufactured goods to rapidly growing regional economies with cheaper labour.
The services sector will continue to be dominated by the tourism industry
The services sector will grow by an annual average of 2.9% in 2019-23. Despite a coup in 2014, growth in the sector averaged 4.5% a year in 2014-18 amid surging tourist arrivals from the wider Asian region, especially China. In the forecast period the growth rate will normalise somewhat, due in part to slowing growth in tourist arrivals and related expenditure. Similarly, the retail sector-the largest component of services-will continue to expand at a slower rate over the forecast period. Meanwhile, the financial sector will remain relatively healthy. The ratio of non-performing loans to total loans, at 2.9%, has remained fairly stable since 2015, and banks are well capitalised. However, household debt remains elevated, which will crimp demand and dampen the expansion of the sector as a whole in 2019-23. In the first quarter of 2019 household debt stood at 78.7% of GDP and outstanding personal consumption loans (from commercial banks) grew at the fastest pace in nearly five years. Elsewhere, the telecommunications segment will see strong growth towards the end of the forecast period as the consumer electronics cycle recovers from its slump and the development of 5G networks takes place. This will allow firms to meet surging demand for mobile internet services and will dovetail with the continued expansion of e-commerce platforms in the country.
The agriculture sector will remain vulnerable to extreme weather cycles, including droughts and floods. Productivity is also likely to suffer as tentative efforts to reform the sector are repeatedly set back by inclement weather events, which will also mean that producers are largely unable to upgrade from current basic technologies. Some subsectors, such as fishing, will struggle early in the forecast period as the industry adapts to Western countries' market-access requirements regarding labour rights and the government clamps down on unregistered migrant labour. These weaknesses will ensure that farmers remain an important interest group for the new government. We expect the agriculture sector to grow by an annual average of 2.4% in 2019-23.

Consumer price inflation will average 1.6% per year in 2019-23. This compares with an average of 0.6% in 2014-18 and reflects stronger growth in domestic demand during much of the forecast period and a more stable outlook for global oil prices. In 2019 upward pressure on food prices, owing to drought conditions in parts of Thailand and the African swine fever in parts of Asia, will be partially offset by an anticipated decline in global oil prices in the second half of the year. Local price pressures will remain weak in 2020 against a backdrop of economic deceleration in the US, which will keep a lid on global commodity prices that year. Thereafter, stronger global economic activity and slightly firmer domestic demand will help to lift average annual inflation to 1.7% in 2021-23. This rate will be well below that of Thailand's regional peers, but is justified, given continued unimpressive growth in household consumption.

A large current-account surplus and sizeable foreign-exchange reserves will support the local currency, the baht, throughout the forecast period. We expect the current-account surplus to average 7.1% of GDP in 2019-23. This will broadly mirror fluctuations in the trade surplus, which will be determined in large part by global oil prices and external demand for Thai goods. Lacklustre demand, exacerbated by a slump in the consumer electronics cycle, has contributed to a weakness in merchandise shipments that will persist into 2020. Nonetheless, the trade surplus will widen next year as global oil prices fall. Conversely, a rise in oil prices in 2021 will offset the positive effect of a recovery in merchandise shipments that year, causing the current account to narrow from 7.9% in 2019 to 6.5% in 2021. It will widen in 2023, reaching 7.3% amid steadier merchandise shipments growth and still-rising oil prices.
Despite these downward pressures on the current account, the overall surplus will be supported by continual growth in services exports, stemming almost entirely from tourism spend. The primary income account will remain firmly in deficit in 2019-23, reflecting the continued repatriation of profits and dividends by foreign-owned firms. This will be partly offset by a consistent surplus on the secondary income account from personal transfers, notably remittances.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Thailand
Stocks and flows
Net foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows (including earnings reinvested by companies already operating in Thailand) were volatile in 2014-18 owing to political uncertainty and a downturn in external demand. Nonetheless, FDI inflows have increased steadily since 2015, owing to the previous junta's efforts to attract infrastructure investment, which included a range of incentives and the liberalisation of strategic industries. Expectations of policy continuity under the new government should help to support this upward trend during 2019-23. Outward investment, particularly to countries within the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN), is also expected to increase. In 2018 the stock of inward FDI stood at US$237bn, equivalent to 46.8% of GDP, while the stock of outward FDI stood at US$134bn.
Origin and distribution
The private manufacturing sector has traditionally attracted the largest proportion of FDI into Thailand. In particular, manufacturers of automotive parts and producers of electronics and electrical appliances have attracted significant foreign interest in recent years. However, the financial and real-estate sectors have also gained prominence, particularly as industrial production faces headwinds from weak external conditions. Japanese firms have historically been the main investors in Thailand, but investment from China has greatly increased in the past few years. Chinese investors, at least as much as their Japanese counterparts, are likely to gain from Thailand's infrastructure development plans, but this will come in the form of services contracts in construction and logistics planning.
Determinants
Thailand has traditionally been an attractive investment destination, owing to its relatively competitive labour costs, flexible labour laws and advantageous location within the region. Nonetheless, any sign of political instability, as well as growing regional competition, will pose a risk to Thailand's attractiveness in the medium term. The Board of Investment (BOI) offers incentives, which generally take the form of exemptions from corporate income tax and reduced taxes on imported machinery. The BOI also offers non-tax incentives, including granting permission to bring in foreign workers, to own land and to take or remit foreign currency abroad. Thailand has generally been regarded as open to foreign investment. Although regulatory uncertainties do exist, the new government is likely to address these quickly. Indeed, the new large-scale Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) special economic zone includes fast-tracked environmental assessments as an incentive. The EEC fits within the seven-year investment promotion strategy launched by the BOI in 2015, which extended incentives to newer industries such as "alternative energy and environmental services" and "hospitality and wellness", while removing existing incentives in certain low-value, labour-intensive industries. The BOI has also been encouraging investment into infrastructure, through a small number of big-ticket projects. In addition, it has expedited the investment application and approval process in recent years, and is likely to retain this as a priority under the new government. Disagreements from lawmakers will occasionally slow the pace of decision-making related to investment, with opposition parties keen to enforce greater oversight of infrastructure projects.
Impact
Inflows of FDI have been volatile over the past decade, amid global economic weakness, flood damage and repeated bouts of political uncertainty. Large FDI inflows have helped to support overall economic growth and have contributed to Thailand's development as a leading exporter to other countries in Asia in a number of sectors, including vehicles (particularly light pick-up trucks), electronics (especially computer parts) and electrical appliances. Reliance on FDI has nonetheless made the economy vulnerable to external conditions; investor sentiment has buckled in recent months, owing to political uncertainty and easing demand in key markets.
Potential
Thailand's political scene has stabilised since the public approval of the junta-drafted constitution in a referendum in 2016 and the smooth accession of the new king. After a brief period of uncertainty around the election held in March 2019, political stability will be maintained in 2019-23. Challenges to the new political structure are unlikely to materialise before the next election (due in 2023), which bodes well for steadier FDI flows in the forecast period compared with 2014-18. However, a number of other challenges may limit the potential for strong growth in FDI in the next five years. Thailand's attractiveness as a location for investment has been diminishing because of a rising relative cost base (particularly for labour) and sluggish domestic demand outside the tourism sector. Although the current administration will maintain the junta's commitment to liberalisation, mainly through the legally binding 20-year National Strategy, access to important sectors such as telecommunications and utilities remains in question. Although the standard of infrastructure in the country has improved in recent years, it remains poorer than in Malaysia, a rival manufacturing location, and, increasingly, Vietnam. The junta-drafted infrastructure development programme, which the new government will follow, will rectify this shortfall somewhat. Although Thailand will continue to attract foreign investment by virtue of its leading position in the development of the ASEAN Free-Trade Area, there is a risk that it may lose out to other countries in the region as they make improvements to their business environments at a faster rate.

Effective family-planning programmes, sex education and changing social norms, such as later marriage and smaller families, will keep Thailand's average population growth rate relatively low, at 0.2% a year, in the forecast period. By 2023 the population is forecast to reach 70.2m, with females accounting for 51.4% of the total. Owing to continued improvements in healthcare and childbirth procedures, the infant mortality rate will drop to an average of 8.4 per 1,000 live births in the forecast period, from 9.4 per 1,000 in 2014-18. Life expectancy will also improve, with men expected to live for an average of 72.1 years in 2019-23, up from 71 in 2014-18, while female life expectancy will rise from an average of 78.6 to 79.5 years over the same period.
Demographic ageing will exert strain on healthcare provision
Thailand's population is ageing, with the proportion aged under 15 set to fall to 15.5% in 2023, from 18.8% in 2011, and the proportion aged over 65 rising steadily. This will mean that the young-age dependency ratio falls to 0.22 in 2023, from 0.26 in 2012, while the old-age dependency ratio rises from 0.13 to 0.21 over the same period. This demographic trend will place further strain on healthcare provision. The country's health system is structured around a universal healthcare scheme that was introduced in 2001 and has been free for all citizens since 2006. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this scheme to remain free in the forecast period. It will, nonetheless, face growing burdens resulting from the country's rising levels of pollution and ageing population.
Road accidents will continue to be a leading cause of death
The crude death rate is forecast at 8.2 per 1,000 in 2019-23. Non-communicable illnesses such as heart disease, stroke and respiratory diseases are responsible for 74% of all deaths in Thailand, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO). The WHO also reports that Thailand has the world's second-highest road traffic fatality rate, accounting for 5% of total deaths (based on 2012 data). Deteriorating air quality-pollution levels in Bangkok and northern provinces hit record highs in 2019-also poses a threat of increased premature deaths and health burdens. Meanwhile, Thailand continues to confront the challenge of preventing the spread of HIV/AIDS, which emerged as the country's leading cause of death in the early 2000s. The WHO estimates the death rate from the disease at around 23 per 100,000 people in 2016, although 450,000 people continued to live with the disease in that year. Other infectious diseases such as cholera, measles and mumps have become less common but have not been eradicated.
The labour market will tighten owing to the ageing of Thailand's population, and shortages of skilled labour are likely in the next five years. Labour force growth will remain almost flat in 2019-23, reaching 38.6m by 2023, despite a decline in the working-age population. This will be largely due to increasing numbers of women choosing to work outside the home. Migrant labour will remain abundant, with workers from neighbouring Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos dominating unskilled jobs in the construction industry and as household employees. However, Thailand will gradually become a less attractive destination for unskilled migrants over the long term. In the near term this will partly reflect a less welcoming stance on the part of the authorities, who are keen to channel unskilled migrant labour into legitimate strategic industries in border-located special economic zones. In the longer term, job opportunities in Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos will expand as those economies grow.
Rural-urban migration is still a significant demographic trend
Despite slow population growth, the number of households in Thailand is expected to rise strongly in the forecast period, with a subsequent reduction in average household size. Internal migration and changing social patterns mean that it is increasingly common for households to consist of nuclear rather than extended families. Steady economic expansion in recent years has encouraged this trend, as migrant workers from rural areas have been moving to the major cities, and particularly the metropolitan area centred on the capital, Bangkok. Although Bangkok remains the main focus for the urban population, other cities, including Surat Thani, Chiang Mai and Hat Yai, have also been growing rapidly. This will result in the urban population increasing to 54.1% of the total in 2023, from 50% in 2018.

Thailand constitutes a sizeable market in its own right, with a population of 69.4m and nominal GDP equivalent to around US$505.3bn at market exchange rates in 2018. Moreover, the development of the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) Free-Trade Area means that firms located in Thailand will continue to enjoy almost entirely duty-free access to ASEAN's population of 500m, including a burgeoning middle class with growing disposable income.
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that aggregate personal disposable income will grow at a faster rate in 2019-23 than it did in 2014-18, as economic activity strengthens compared with the historical period on the back of greater policy stability. Nonetheless, national wealth distribution will remain alarmingly disparate between the regions. According to the latest data from the Asian Development Bank, of the 7.9% of the population defined as living below the nationally defined poverty line in 2017 (living on US$45 or less per month), the majority reside in the rural north and north-eastern parts of the country. The capital, Bangkok, remains the wealthiest region by far, with personal disposable income vastly exceeding the national average. Government measures to narrow the wealth gap, such as hand-outs and tax cuts, tend to be short-term in outlook and unsustainable. Structural issues, such as the fact that opportunities in rural areas remain limited compared with urban centres, will remain largely unaddressed.
High household debt will undermine disposable incomes in 2019-23
Household spending will be tempered by still-high personal debt. In particular, debt burdens among those on lower incomes have a significant negative impact on consumer demand overall and limit the prospects for social mobility among this group. This will particularly affect the share available for spending on consumer goods, ensuring that Thailand's retail goods market experiences relatively low growth. Nonetheless, the large tourism sector will lend some support to the retail sector during the forecast period. In 2021-22, as the level of debt subsides and the economy experiences a recovery, the release of pent-up demand will help to underpin retail sales. On average, retail sales volumes will grow by 2.4% a year in 2019-23.

Private consumption will grow by an annual average of 3.4% in 2019-23, faster than the rate of 2.7% in 2014-18 but below the country's full potential. In the early part of the forecast period elevated household debt and a slowdown in economic activity will dampen consumer sentiment. The new government will maintain policies aimed at supporting consumption through various subsidies and support packages aimed at helping low-income citizens. Given the still-frail state of private consumption, the value-added tax (VAT) rate is unlikely to be raised from the current level of 7% until later in the forecast period, despite discussion of such a move. The government will instead focus on wealth taxes, such as the new inheritance and property taxes, so that it can also provide some tax relief for lower-income households. Meanwhile, higher "sin taxes" on sugar, alcohol and tobacco will have a minor impact on the population at large.
Free public healthcare will hold down consumer expenditure in that area
Consumer expenditure on essential items, such as food, household goods and clothing, will fall slightly as a proportion of total expenditure as average incomes rise. The average individual outlay on hotels and restaurants is likely to increase as a result of several trends: a rise in the number of women who work (leading to a fall in the number of meals cooked at home); government efforts to promote domestic tourism; and cheaper domestic travel owing to the expansion of budget airlines and rail routes. Expenditure on leisure and education will rise at pace, as higher-income households experience the biggest gains from economic growth in the forecast period. Growth in healthcare spending is forecast to increase gradually in 2019-23, compared with 2014-18, owing to relatively comprehensive free public healthcare, which we do not expect to be rescinded in the forecast period. The projected increase in spending on transport and communications will largely reflect the expanding market for information technology products, which will be boosted by national upgrades to internet services.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Initial conditions: The past two decades have been characterised by political turmoil, with coups in 2006 and 2014 and many (sometimes violent) anti-government protests and rallies. Economic growth has been volatile in the years since the 2008-09 global financial crisis owing to natural disasters and political crises. The new government, despite its efforts to revive the economy, will oversee relatively lacklustre growth as the country returns to democratic rule. Physical infrastructure will also remain inadequate and strained in many respects. Reform of the education system, which is sorely needed, has long been promised, but successive governments have largely failed to modernise the curriculum. The workforce is therefore characterised by a low level of technical skills-a problem made worse by rapidly demographic ageing.
Demographic trends: Slower population growth and longer life expectancies will account for the ageing population. The female labour force participation rate will be relatively high by 2030, and is expected to rise only modestly from then on. This will lead to an average annual contraction of almost 1% in the labour force in 2031-50. Nevertheless, a gradual loosening of regulation concerning immigrants' right to work will preclude a steeper fall in the size of the workforce. Successive governments are likely to be forced to ease immigration policies further, owing to the country's negative demographic profile. The effectiveness of this will be limited by concerns among immigrants regarding political freedom, worsening air pollution and the growing attractiveness of neighbouring regions.
External conditions: Thailand faces a challenging external environment in the period to 2050. Although many export-oriented, labour-intensive industries will shift away from China, Thailand will struggle to capitalise on this opportunity owing to a lack of competitiveness compared with lower-cost locations, such as Cambodia and Bangladesh. New regional rivals will also gain ground, including Laos and Myanmar. Closer integration with China could open up market opportunities for Thai businesses in more niche subsectors. One possibility is that Thailand may develop itself as a services centre for China, meeting that country's increasing demand for foreign holidays, regional-specific agricultural goods and other niche products. The government is already spearheading a move in that direction under its "Thailand 4.0" industrial policy and, in part, via its new Eastern Economic Corridor special economic zone. This is particularly the case for the tourism industry, and the ongoing expansion of transport infrastructure will go some way to supporting these aims. Similarly, economic and trade links will be strengthened by the development of overland transport routes between China and Thailand in the next decade or so. The development of the ASEAN Economic Community, formally established in 2015, will motivate business and technical innovation in Thailand to the degree that the country retains its prominence in the region. In 2019-30 a relocation of regional supply chains will take place in order to capitalise upon changing tariff regimes and increased trade tensions. Although Thailand will benefit from these shifts, gains will be limited by the growing manufacturing capabilities of neighbours like Vietnam.
Institutions and policy trends: In the coming decades there will be no resolution of the power struggle between the established military and bureaucratic elites in the capital, Bangkok, who will continue to side with the palace to bolster their legitimacy, and the rural masses that form the majority of the Thai electorate. The level of political tension will depend on successive governments' ability to restructure the economy further away from agriculture, not least by moving a far greater proportion of the workforce into industry and services. Democratically elected governments might be successful in instigating such a shift with the introduction of appropriate electoral reform, as well as a focus on medium-to-long-term rural development policies, rather than just short-term relief measures.
Long-term performance: The long-term outlook for Thailand's economy is heavily dependent on whether the government retains the political authority required to initiate appropriate structural reform that will continue into the medium-to-long term, while also upgrading infrastructure. Implementing comprehensive liberalisation in a number of important sectors, such as power and communications, will help Thailand to regain some of its competiveness relative to its regional neighbours. The effects of an ageing population could be offset by improving educational attainment on the part of the existing workforce or by measures to facilitate greater immigrant access to the labour market. However, progress is likely to be slow in both areas.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Thailand published a long-term climate change adaptation plan in 2015, entitled the Climate Change Master Plan 2015-50. It outlines a three-pronged approach divided into mitigation, adaptation and capacity-building targets. The near-term goals included setting emission-reduction targets and establishing incentives for low-carbon emission development. Medium-term targets included reaching at least 25% of energy consumption from renewable sources. Longer-term targets are vaguer, with general goals to increase private investment in green industries and to reduce the carbon intensity of the economy. In line with this plan, Thailand signed and ratified the Paris Agreement of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP21) in 2016, committing to specific targets for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. Under COP21, Thailand has pledged to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 20% from the projected business-as-usual forecast by 2030.
The main determinant of emissions levels in Thailand in the coming decades will continue to be energy sourcing. Coal-fired power plants generate close to one-fifth of the country's electricity, while lesser-polluting liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities account for nearly two-thirds of electricity generation. Most of these plants are situated in the south of the country. The government will continue to push for the expansion of renewable energy sources as a share of the country's energy mix, and renewable energy is likely to account for around a quarter of total generation capacity by 2040. The commissioning of nuclear power plants in Thailand, which would reduce reliance on high-polluting forms, is also a possibility. However, the relatively low prices of coal and gas will mean that these continue to account for the majority of energy generation over the next two decades.
The country will be vulnerable to the intensified impact of climate change in the coming decades. This will be felt most acutely through the rising sea level, flooding, droughts and air pollution, which will in turn feed into economic insecurity, infrastructure strains, health burdens and social unrest. This year we have developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we find that the Thai economy will be 3.1% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
Technological developments
In May 2016 the junta unveiled "Thailand 4.0", a sector-specific industrial policy that aims to attract new investment in the transformation of the economy. The name of the strategy describes the intended next stage in the sectoral development of the economy, characterised by the industrial application of state-of-the-art technology. It follows the current domestic industrial situation, which is dominated by heavy industry with advanced machinery, in segments such as automotive and chemicals production. The Thailand 4.0 strategy focuses on ten strategic industries that are already found in Thailand, but where value can be added via new technologies; these include smart electronics, high-income and medical tourism, agriculture and biotechnology, food and beverages, and the automotive industry. It will also extend to the development of new industries, such as robotics, aerospace, digital services, bioenergy and biochemicals, and healthcare. Incentives for investment in these sectors will remain in place for several years and are explicitly targeted towards the introduction of new technology, for example by offering import-duty exemption on capital goods for listed industries. Thailand will make some progress in upgrading its industries, but is likely to be constrained by a limited supply of skilled labour.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.
