Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent Blend
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
Domestic data
GDP growth: Bank of Thailand, Annual Report; Asian Development Bank, Key Indicators
US$ GDP: IMF, IFS
Population: Asian Development Bank, Key Indicators; UN, World Development Report
GDP per head: nominal GDP divided by population
Inflation: consumer price index, Department of Business Economics, Ministry of Commerce
Budget: fiscal year (October-September)
Wages: local-currency wage data derived from minimum-wage data, inflated to correspond with occasional UNIDO data for US dollar manufacturing-sector wages
Exchange rates: IMF, IFS
Commercial banks' prime rate: Bank of Thailand, Quarterly Bulletin
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Foreign debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; OECD, External Debt Statistics (for data on short-term debt)
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
UNIDO: UN Industrial Development Organisation
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberal Party, led by the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, to remain in power after the October election. However, it will be a close contest, and the Liberal government's current parliamentary majority is at risk.
The renegotiation of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) has eased trade uncertainty, but we expect delays in the ratification process of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA, NAFTA's successor), probably until 2020. Trade policy will remain a risk during the administration of the US president, Donald Trump, owing to Canada's reliance on the US, its main export market.
We forecast that real GDP growth will slow from 1.9% in 2018 to 1.6% in 2019, owing to weaker private consumption growth and an economic slowdown in the US. Subdued domestic demand will keep growth below trend at 1.7% in 2020, but real GDP growth will pick up to an average of 2.3% per year in 2021-23.
The federal budget will remain in deficit in 2019-23, as higher receipts from the carbon tax, the legalisation of cannabis and other sources will be more than offset by increased spending on infrastructure and other measures.
Consumer price inflation will ease to 2% in 2019 and 1.9% in 2020, reflecting weaker domestic and external demand, and generally lower oil prices. It will pick up to an average of 2.1% per year in 2021-23 as the economy regains momentum.
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted the policy rate three times in 2018, to 1.75%. We expect it to keep rates on hold in 2019, before sanctioning a 25-basis-point cut in 2020, as global economic growth slows further. Modest tightening will resume in 2021 and continue in 2022-23.
The exchange rate, commodity prices and the health of the US economy will continue to shape the outlook for the current account, which will remain in deficit in 2019-23. The impact of softer global oil prices in 2019-20 (compared with 2018) will be more than offset by slower domestic demand and, therefore, import growth, causing the merchandise trade deficit to narrow. As a result, we expect the shortfall on the current account to ease to an average of 2.5% of GDP in 2019-20.

Canada's score improves in 2019-23, pushing the country up to ninth place in our global business environment ranking and first place in our regional ranking. The best features of the business environment are political stability and openness to trade, although tax policy and the labour market will remain constraints.
Country forecast overview: Canada's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The government revises the Canada Business Corporations Act to introduce provisions on board gender diversity, annual election of directors, single election of directors and shareholder empowerment.
2021-23: Progress on increasing competition in certain sectors, such as telecommunications and dairy, will be uneven.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The government will continue to welcome foreign investment but will sometimes reject foreign takeovers owing to national security considerations. Chinese investment and takeover bids will come under particular scrutiny.
2021-23: Foreign investment is likely to rise in value terms as resource nationalism in the oil and gas sector eases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Canada, Mexico and the US ratify the revised North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), now called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which retains the essence of the original treaty.
2021-23: Canada continues to diversify its trade ties. Free-trade talks with China resume.
Taxes
2019-20: The government provides benefits and tax breaks to improve business competitiveness compared with the US.
2021-23: The government introduces reporting mechanisms for multinational enterprises to reduce tax avoidance.
Financing
2019-20: The Bank of Canada (the central bank) develops a system-wide framework to measure stress in banking, insurance and investment funds.
2021-23: The government completes its update of financial legislation, including the Bank Act, the Co-operative Credit Associations Act, the Insurance Companies Act, and the Trust and Loan Companies Act.
The labour market
2019-20: Canada will enact policies to streamline processes and increase quotas to expedite the hiring of foreign talent by firms.
2021-23: The government further encourages the entry of skilled workers and professionals by raising its immigration target.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Work begins on the Trans Mountain Expansion project, which will pipe additional crude oil from Alberta, although further legal challenges could slow progress.
2021-23: After years of uncertainty, pipelines to carry more energy resources from Alberta begin to come on stream.
Technological readiness
2019-20: The technology sector benefits from workers moving from the US, especially those on that country's H1B visas, for whom the political climate becomes more difficult.
2021-23: Expertise in artificial intelligence takes root, particularly in the academic centres of Toronto and Montreal.

Background: The Canadian economy was the tenth-largest in the world in 2018 (measured in US dollars at market exchange rates). It is highly integrated with the US economy, which absorbs 75% of its goods exports and is the source of 51% of its imported goods. The US exerts a powerful economic and cultural influence on Canada. Fifty-eight per cent of Canadians say that English is their mother tongue; just over 21% say French and just under 21% have another language as their first. The majority of French speakers live in Quebec, Canada's second most populous province. Canada's unity is sometimes called into question, but support for sovereignty is currently muted in Quebec. Neither of the two leading political parties in the province is seeking an independence referendum.
Political structure: Canada is formally a constitutional monarchy, with the governor-general (always of Canadian nationality and appointed in Ottawa) acting as the representative of the British crown. In practice, the Canadian House of Commons is sovereign. Canada is a federation of ten provinces, each with substantial powers, and three territories. At the federal level are the Commons, the main seat of legislative power, and the non-elected Senate, which plays only a marginal role. The Liberal Party has led a majority government since 2015; the next general election will be held in October 2019.
Policy issues: The federal government must balance the assistance that it is providing to the fossil fuel industry through approving new oil pipelines with the need to maintain its green credentials. The government will increase its spending on infrastructure significantly, including through its Canada Infrastructure Bank.
Taxation: The federal corporate income tax rate is 15%. Provincial governments charge corporate tax at rates between 2% and 16%. In 2016 the government introduced a new top marginal rate of personal income tax of 33%, which applies to taxable income higher than C$210,371 (US$157,706) in 2019.
Foreign trade: The US absorbs about three-quarters of Canadian exports, so the health of its economy is crucial for Canada. Canada's trade deficit was US$17bn in 2018, and the current-account deficit was US$45.3bn (2.6% of GDP).

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The Liberal Party government, led by the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, won a majority at the federal election in 2015, ending a decade of Conservative Party rule. The government has made progress on most of its reform agenda; however, controversy over alleged political interference in a criminal corruption case has tarnished Mr Trudeau's political brand, and friction with provincial administrations over environmental policy has intensified. The next federal election is due on October 21st, and unofficial campaigning started after parliament went into recess in June. The opposition Conservatives remain slightly ahead in opinion surveys, but the Liberal Party has regained ground and the election results will be tight. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberals to remain in government after the election, but the party's parliamentary majority is at risk, raising the prospect of periodic legislative gridlock.
Mr Trudeau's popularity has been damaged by his mishandling earlier this year of allegations by the former attorney-general and justice minister, Jody Wilson-Raybould, that he and his officials put inappropriate political pressure on her to abandon the criminal prosecution for alleged fraud of SNC-Lavalin, a large Quebec-based construction and engineering firm, which denies the charges. Ms Wilson-Raybould and another cabinet minister, Jane Philpott, resigned from their positions, citing lack of confidence in the government. They were both expelled from the caucus in April and will run as independents in October. As a result, the issue is likely to fester in the run-up to the federal election.
Friction between the federal and provincial governments has intensified in recent months, owing mainly to disagreements on environmental legislation. Opposition parties have taken control of several provincial governments in recent years, setting the stage for policy battles ahead of the federal election. The most significant change of power has been the return to provincial government in Alberta of the United Conservative Party, which defeated the left-leaning New Democratic Party (NDP) government at the provincial election in April. The new Alberta premier, Jason Kenney, is a vocal critic of the federal Liberal government's environmental policies, which he argues have harmed Alberta's resource-based economy. In May he repealed the carbon tax in the province, which was introduced by the former NDP government. As a result, the Liberal government plans to introduce (in January 2020) the same federal carbon tax in Alberta that it imposed in April on four other provinces-Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario and New Brunswick-that did not have pricing plans that met federal standards. Like its counterparts in Ontario and Saskatchewan, the Alberta government contends that the federal carbon tax is unconstitutional, and the Supreme Court of Canada will ultimately rule on the matter. The Conservatives have pledged to repeal the federal carbon tax if elected in October.
The nationalisation in 2018 of the Trans Mountain oil pipeline and expansion project has also raised questions regarding federal jurisdiction. The expansion, designed to carry additional crude oil from Alberta to a port in British Columbia (BC), is opposed by the NDP provincial government in BC and by environmentalists, and the federal cabinet's decision in June to proceed with the project is controversial.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Following the SNC-Lavalin affair, the Conservative Party overtook the Liberals in opinion surveys in February 2019, although much of that lead has whittled away in recent weeks. According to an average of recent polls published by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation on August 12th, 33.8% of respondents supported the Conservatives, compared with 32.8% who backed the Liberals. The NDP was well behind, in third place, backed by 13.8% of those surveyed. Mr Trudeau's overall approval rating is on a par with that of the Conservative leader, Andrew Scheer.
We expect the Liberal Party to be in a position to form a minority government after the federal election, due on October 21st 2019, reflecting the advantages of incumbency and the implementation of much of the government's agenda, including the legalisation of cannabis. However, the contest will be tight. Conservatives have an experienced shadow cabinet and have built momentum under Mr Scheer. They will focus on the Liberal government's perceived vulnerabilities, namely taxes, government spending, the cost of its climate-change policies and its broken pledge to change the electoral system from first-past-the-post to proportional representation. The Conservatives also contend that the Liberals have lost control of the border by allowing more than 45,000 people to walk across from the US over the past two years and claim asylum.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
The Liberal government's foreign policy emphasises multilateralism over unilateralism, engagement over isolation, mitigating the effects of climate change and upholding human rights. The contrast with policies pursued by the US president, Donald Trump, will continue to strain bilateral relations with the US during the remainder of Mr Trump's administration. Canada will nonetheless seek to preserve relations with the US, its most important diplomatic and economic partner by far, in part by strengthening its ties to other levels of US government. Canada will also increase efforts to diversify trade.
The signing in November 2018 of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which will replace the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and preserve the trilateral arrangement, has mitigated some trade risk for Canada. The revised deal maintains most of the substance of the earlier one; in particular, the USMCA retains the Chapter 19 dispute-resolution mechanism, on which Canada relies to protect some of its industries (primarily lumber) from potential US anti-dumping measures. Canada also negotiated an exemption from any future tariffs that the US might impose on automotive imports, and the US has been granted greater access to the Canadian market for dairy, poultry and eggs (these sectors are managed by the government to ensure sufficiently high prices for farmers). The lifting in May of US tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminium imports has removed a major obstacle to ratification of the USMCA; however, the timing for ratification of the agreement poses a challenge for all three administrations. Ongoing delays on the US-Mexico side, and Canada's parliamentary recess until November 2019, will complicate the ratification process. Our central forecast is that the USMCA will ultimately be ratified by all three nations, but we now believe that this will be extended into 2020.
China was a major target for the government's trade diversification policy until December, when Meng Wanzhou, a senior executive of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, was detained in Canada at the request of US authorities on fraud charges (that she denies). Bitter exchanges between Canada and China since her arrest have cast a chill on bilateral relations. In March the Canadian government announced that it would proceed with hearings on her extradition. In response, China detained two Canadians on charges of spying, sentenced two others convicted of drug crimes to death and has used non-tariff barriers to impede agricultural imports from Canada, including canola (rapeseed). Bilateral relations will remain tense for as long as Ms Meng faces the threat of extradition to the US.
The implementation of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) is expected to provide enhanced access to major Asian markets over the 2019-23 forecast period. A trade deal signed with the EU in 2016 has removed 98% of the EU tariff lines; when the deal is fully implemented, that figure will rise to 99%.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government will seek to support domestic industries that are adversely affected by US trade protectionism and Canada's trade issues with China. Measures to boost the competitiveness of Canadian businesses following tax cuts in the US last year included a tax break on capital expenditure in manufacturing. However, the government will struggle to balance environmental policy with support for the fossil fuel industry. It has rolled out a national carbon tax of C$20(US$15)/tonne in provinces that did not have an equivalent carbon pricing programme in place. This tax will rise to C$50/tonne by 2022. However, the government has also approved the controversial C$7.4bn (US$5.5bn) expansion of the Trans Mountain pipeline, which it now owns. The project still faces some regulatory hurdles, and construction work, which is scheduled to begin this year, could be delayed further by legal challenges.
Policymakers will continue to monitor the residential property market, which will remain a risk owing to overleveraged Canadian households. Measures introduced by the federal government and provincial governments in Ontario and BC in recent years have helped to cool the tight housing market. In Vancouver and Toronto foreign buyers are subject to an additional tax on property purchases, and the federal government has tightened mortgage requirements nationwide, which has improved the quality of new mortgage lending. According to the monthly Teranet-National Bank National Composite House Price Index, prices softened in September 2018-April 2019 but edged up in May-June. Despite falling mortgage interest rates, we still expect the housing market to remain sluggish in 2019, reflecting a combination of tighter lending standards, continued affordability pressures and diminished investor activity. However, the risk of a major correction appears to have eased.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The government is committed to a programme of infrastructure and other spending that will entail a series of budget deficits, but these will be partially offset by increased receipts due to the introduction of the carbon tax and greater tax income as a result of cannabis legalisation. However, lower average oil prices in 2019-20 compared with 2018, and a slower pace of economic expansion, mean that government receipts are likely to undershoot official projections overall, weighing on plans to reduce the fiscal deficit.
According to the federal budget for fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March) handed down in March, the budget deficit for 2019/20 will be C$19.8bn-equivalent to 0.9% of GDP. Official projections show the budget deficit contracting to C$9.8bn (equivalent to 0.4% of GDP) by 2023/24. We project that the fiscal deficit will expand from 0.4% of GDP in 2018 (our fiscal forecasts are calendar-year based) to 0.9% of GDP in 2019 and 1% of GDP in 2020. The government will seek to reduce the shortfall in the longer term, and we expect the deficit to contract gradually, to 0.7% of GDP by 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
Between July 2017 and October 2018 the Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted its policy rate by 125 basis points. This was in response to rising inflation and to discourage highly indebted households from accumulating further debt. The BoC has since kept rates steady. The year-on-year inflation rate has picked up to close to the BoC's 2% target, and the economy appears to have perked up in the second quarter, following a slow start to the year. However, the BoC has cautioned that the economic outlook remains clouded by global trade tensions, which will continue to weigh on export growth and investment.
We forecast that the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) will follow up the cut to its policy rate in July with another in November 2019, and one more in March 2020. We continue to expect the BoC to keep its policy rate unchanged this year, as it views the current level of 1.75% as stimulatory. However, we expect it to sanction a 25-basis-point cut in early 2020 as US growth slows further; because of the close ties between the two countries, this will weigh on economic growth in Canada. The BoC will begin to tighten monetary policy gradually again from 2021.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth slowed to 1.9% in 2018, from 3% in 2017, and we expect the pace of economic expansion to soften further in 2019, to an average of 1.6%. Previous monetary tightening, high household debt levels and the subdued housing market will weigh on private consumption growth this year, although solid growth in government spending will help to cushion the impact. Export growth is also expected to moderate as a result of weaker economic expansion in the US, Canada's main export market.
The renegotiation of NAFTA reduces one of the major downside risks to our forecast, although it looks likely that the timeline for the ratification of the successor agreement, the USMCA, will be extended into 2020. Canadian producers and manufacturers will benefit from the removal in May of US tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminium imports, and the end of the retaliatory import tariffs that Canada imposed, but are feeling the pinch from trade restrictions imposed by China on some Canadian farm exports, such as canola. Global trade uncertainty remains a major downside risk to our forecast. Other risks to the economic outlook include a sharp drop in global oil prices, which would act as a drag on economic activity.
We have revised up slightly our real GDP growth forecast for 2020 to 1.7% (from 1.6% previously), reflecting a modest upward revision to our projection for world trade growth next year. However, with economic growth in the US and domestic demand in Canada continuing to lose steam, the overall pace of economic expansion will remain well below its long-term trend next year. Real GDP growth is expected to pick up again in 2021, and will average 2.4% per year in 2022-23. This will be supported by continued public investment in infrastructure and stronger export growth, driven by recovering demand in the US and enhanced trade ties with the EU and CPTPP members.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Rising oil prices through much of last year and the increasingly protectionist trade policy of the US added to price pressures in 2018, when the headline rate of consumer price inflation accelerated to an average of 2.2%. In the first quarter of 2019 the inflation rate fell back to 1.6% year on year, owing to lower petrol prices and the impact of previous monetary tightening by the central bank. However, in the second quarter it picked up to 2.2% year on year, underpinned by higher food and energy costs. Subdued economic growth and generally lower oil prices will keep inflation at around the BoC's 2% target rate overall in 2019-20. We forecast that the inflation rate will pick up from 2021 as the economy regains momentum and the unemployment rate starts to fall again.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Falling oil prices and slowing growth weighed on the currency late last year in the first few months of 2019, although the Fed's dovish stance has caused the Canadian dollar to firm against its US counterpart since June. Nevertheless, the Canadian currency will depreciate slightly this year, to C$1.32:US$1 on average. Downward pressure on the Canadian dollar next year from continued weak economic growth, soft oil prices and modest monetary easing by the BoC in early 2020 will be mitigated by deeper interest rate cuts from the Fed (which we expect will cut rates again in December 2019 and March 2020). As a result, the local currency will be broadly unchanged, at an average of C$1.33:US$1 in 2020. A pick-up in growth from 2021 and the resumption of monetary tightening will underpin a modest appreciation in the Canadian dollar in 2021-23, with the currency forecast to average C$1.30:US$1 in 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The exchange rate, commodity prices and the health of the US economy will continue to shape the outlook for the current account, which will remain in deficit in 2019-23. The impact of softer global oil prices in 2019-20 will be more than offset by slower domestic demand and, therefore, import growth, causing the merchandise trade deficit to narrow. As a result, we expect the shortfall on the current account to ease to an average of 2.5% of GDP in 2019-20. The CPTPP, the effects of which will begin to be felt from 2020, will result in higher trade volumes between Canada and Pacific nations. This will help to narrow the current-account deficit to a forecast 2.3% of GDP by 2023.

Country Forecast Greece August 2019 Updater

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-greece-august-2019-updater/docview/2272464710/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. [...]the new government, which is subject to strict policy conditionality under the EU's enhanced surveillance regime, will have limited room for manoeuvre to change course to a more growth-friendly policy mix. On this front, Greece has benefitted from a combination of global central banks' monetary policy shift to an easing bias since late 2018, as well as financial market optimism about the prospect of a change of government in Greece. Since returning to the debt markets after a three-year absence in July 2017, the secondary market interest rate on Greek ten-year government bonds has fallen by 345 basis points, to just 2.1% at end-July, narrowing the spread over equivalent German government bonds by about 250 basis points, to 255 basis points. Exchange rates The euro has depreciated against the dollar since peaking at almost US$1.25: Since the start of 2019 the euro has weakened further, mostly hovering around US$1.11:

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In a snap general election held on July 7th 2019, the main centre-right opposition party, New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, recorded a comfortable victory over the left-wing ruling Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza) led by Alexis Tsipras. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the single-party ND government will provide the basis for more stable and effective administration, but that it will struggle with the multiple challenges inherited from Mr Tsipras's administration.
Greece will remain under "enhanced supervision" by euro zone creditors during the forecast period (2019-23) and beyond, until its huge public debt of more than 180% of GDP is substantially reduced. We do not expect Greece's creditors to allow the new government to renegotiate the annual primary budget surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP for 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter in order to adopt more growth-friendly policies of tax cuts. Protests are likely to continue as the government continues striving to meet the ambitious budget targets.
Greece is facing its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it has exited its euro zone bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. However, it will not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments until the end of 2020. A Greek exit from the euro zone represents a risk over the long term.
After expanding by 1.9% in 2018, we expect real GDP growth to reach 1.8% in 2019 and 2020, and an annual average of about 2.1% in 2021-23. Meeting large primary budget surplus targets and restoring competitiveness will prove difficult. Public debt is forecast to remain high, at just over 170% of GDP in 2023.
Inflation (EU harmonised) will remain subdued, rising only slightly-from 0.8% in 2018 to an annual average of 1% in 2019-20-reflecting significant slack in the labour market, moderate domestic demand growth and low global energy prices. In 2021-23 we expect oil prices to rise, bringing inflation to 1.5% per year. We expect narrow current-account deficits in 2019-23, compared with an annual average of 7.1% of GDP since 2001, when Greece joined the euro zone.

Greece's business environment will improve moderately in the forecast period, with progress in most categories. However, Greece will remain subject to sub-optimal fiscal and other policy conditions, which will constrain real GDP growth and keep Greece's debt burden high.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The new government seeks to revive the country's privatisation programme, unblocking some delayed deals.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make modest progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Remaining capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eliminated. Ongoing US-China trade tension and risk of new trade tariffs between EU and US. Possible no deal Brexit poses risks for Greek services trade, especially tourism.
2021-23: Significant risk of Greece leaving euro zone in long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result in reintroduction of foreign-exchange controls and, possibly, restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base, but rates remain high despite moderate tax cuts, reflecting the need to reduce the large government debt burden. Mandatory introduction of electronic point-of-sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Pressure to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) intensifies. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: The need to increase provisions for still-high NPLs hampers lending. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU-funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Technical assistance from EU helps absorption of European funds to revive infrastructure investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. Private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of the EMU into question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA), but ND returned to power in July 2019 and XA failed to win enough votes to enter parliament.
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages, totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 28% (29% in 2018) and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR32.4bn and imports (fob) amounted to EUR54.9bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR5.3bn, equivalent to 2.9% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In a snap general election held on July 7th 2019, three months before the end of the parliamentary term, the main centre-right opposition party, New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, recorded a comfortable victory over the left-wing ruling Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza) led by Alexis Tsipras. ND obtained 39.85% of the national vote, which, along with a 50-seat bonus awarded to the party with the most votes, gave Mr Mitsotakis's party 158 seats in the 300-seat parliament.
The new government is the first single-party government since the start of the Greek crisis nearly a decade ago, which should provide the basis for a more stable and effective government. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit still expects the new administration to struggle with the multiple challenges inherited from Mr Tsipras's administration, not least reassuring Greece's international creditors that ND's programme of tax cuts and spending increases will not jeopardise the country's route to debt sustainability. This task has been made harder by the fiscal loosening of the outgoing government in the run-up to the elections this year. As a result, the new government, which is subject to strict policy conditionality under the EU's enhanced surveillance regime, will have limited room for manoeuvre to change course to a more growth-friendly policy mix. It is therefore unlikely that real GDP growth will rise to much more than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period, further hindering the new government's ability to reduce Greece's public debt of more than 180% of GDP to a more sustainable level.
Syriza performed better than might have been expected in the general election, winning 31.53% of the vote and 86 seats (compared with 35.5% in the September 2015 general election). This should be sufficient to ensure that Mr Tsipras maintains the leadership of the party. If the party remains united, it should provide strong opposition to the ND government.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The next general election is not due until mid-2023, when Greece will also hold local, regional and European Parliament elections. In early 2020 parliament is due to elect the next president, who has a mostly ceremonial role. The incumbent, Prokopis Pavlopoulos, was elected on February 18th 2015. An enhanced majority in the previous parliament approved an amendment to the constitution to abolish provisions requiring that a minimum three-fifths majority (180 out of 300 members of parliament) be secured in the third round of presidential voting to avoid a fresh general election being called. Another constitutional amendment to repeal electoral reform introduced by Syriza (that abolished the 50-seat bonus awarded to the party winning the most votes in the general election) will, however, require approval by a three-fifths majority in the current parliament. If ND cannot muster enough support, the restoration of the 50-seat bonus will not take effect until the general election after the next one--in other words, in 2027.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political instability, as well as protracted economic and financial crises, has limited Greece's influence in the EU and in the Balkans, but in its final phase, the Syriza government made successful efforts to restore influence on the international scene, including the Macedonia name-change deal, which was ratified in January 2019, and talks on closer co-operation with the US. The name-change agreement aims to end Greece's opposition to Northern Macedonia's accession to NATO and its application for EU membership. ND opposed ratification of the deal, but Mr Mitsotakis has said that he would only seek to renegotiate it if Northern Macedonia agreed.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey will persist. However, we believe that both sides will seek to prevent their historical enmity from escalating into military hostility. Points of contention include long-standing territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea and Turkish hydrocarbon exploration in the Eastern Mediterranean, as well as the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government has inherited a challenging economic policy environment. With the general election looming in 2019, the Syriza government opted to exit Greece's third economic adjustment programme in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line but with a substantial cash buffer to use while the government builds up market access. The buffer, estimated at EUR26bn, should be sufficient to cover the country's financing needs until end-2020. However, this will be more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need.
Intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the Syriza government to choose the more expensive option. Nevertheless, severe policy constraints will remain during the forecast period and beyond, until Greece's huge government debt is substantially reduced. General government debt was about 182% of GDP at end-2018, and also predominantly owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), making another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, highly unlikely. Economic policy and performance will be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries. In particular, the Syriza government has committed Greece to long-term fiscal prudence with ambitious annual primary budget surplus targets (budget balance minus interest payments) of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter until 2060 as well as implementation of reforms to tackle Greek banks' heavy burden of non-performing loans, revive the government's privatisation programme, remove remaining capital controls and eliminate state arrears to the private sector.
In exchange, Greece's EU creditors agreed in June 2018 to implement further debt-relief measures, including a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans; a reduction in the interest rates on loans of EUR130.9bn; and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprises the official sector holders of Greek debt--the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of this return is estimated to be about EUR5bn in total in 2019-22. However, the debt relief will be conditional on the government's adherence to its commitments in the quarterly "enhanced surveillance" reviews. As the reviews will be published (the most recent was released in June 2019, the fourth review will begin in September), transgression by Greece could adversely affect market access. A major bone of contention between Greece's international creditors and the new ND government could be the latter's desire to renegotiate the primary surplus targets with a view to lowering them from 2020 or 2021.
In the short term Greece has sufficient funds to meet its financing requirements, but it will need to have re-established itself in the debt markets before its cash buffer runs out. On this front, Greece has benefitted from a combination of global central banks' monetary policy shift to an easing bias since late 2018, as well as financial market optimism about the prospect of a change of government in Greece. Since returning to the debt markets after a three-year absence in July 2017, the secondary market interest rate on Greek ten-year government bonds has fallen by 345 basis points, to just 2.1% at end-July, narrowing the spread over equivalent German government bonds by about 250 basis points, to 255 basis points. However, any signs of tension between the new government and its international creditors, for example over Greece's primary budget surplus targets or an increase in risk aversion in the global financial markets, could cause Greek yields to rise again sharply.
In the past four years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such ambitious targets will remain a constraint on growth, as will other negative factors such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Greece's exit is not a short- or medium-term risk; however, given that Greece is unlikely to improve competitiveness in the euro zone or to grow its way out of its huge debt burden, Grexit will represent a possibility in the long term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
In 2018, after almost a decade of austerity, Greece recorded an overall budget surplus of 1.1% of GDP and a primary surplus of close to 4.5% of GDP, exceeding the bail-out programme target of 3.5% of GDP. From 2019, however, we expect fiscal performance to deteriorate gradually, with the budget balance returning to moderately widening headline deficits from 2020 and primary surpluses falling short of the official target of 3.5% of GDP for 2018-22 and 2.2% from 2023, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint in 2019 ahead of elections and only moderate economic growth. There is also uncertainty about the application of the Council of State's ruling that previous pension and bonus cuts implemented in 2016 were unconstitutional, raising the risk of retroactive payments.
The restructuring of government debt owed to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-18 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will still be over 170% at end-2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
We have changed our monetary policy call and now believe that an easing package will be announced in September. This is likely to include a small cut to the deposit rate, an adjustment to the ECB's forward guidance, and the announcement of a deposit-tiering system and another round of quantitative easing (QE2), which we expect to last 12 months, starting in December 2019. We previously expected only a small cut to the deposit rate in September, but at its last meeting on July 25th the ECB sent a strong signal of its readiness to intervene; it firmly underlined its intolerance towards both "realised and projected" weak inflation, and reaffirmed its commitment to symmetry in its inflation goal of "below, but close to, 2%". The ECB announced that it had tasked the relevant Eurosystem committees with examining options for further stimulus.
The ECB is taking pre-emptive action against rising deflation risk and a deteriorating economic outlook in the euro zone, mostly driven by global trade tensions. This means that, together with another round of targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs-III), to be started in September, funding conditions will remain ultra-loose in the medium term. Details of the size and scale of the QE2 programme have not been announced, and the ECB will have to overcome at least one of its self-imposed constraints. However, we expect it to announce monthly net asset purchases of about EUR50bn that should last for 12 months. The nomination of Christine Lagarde, the current IMF chair, as ECB president is unlikely to lead to a significant change in monetary policy strategy.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The return to growth of the Greek economy since mid-2016 has been modest and remains vulnerable to domestic and external developments. As at 2018 real GDP was still more than 25% below pre-crisis levels; meanwhile, government consumption remained almost a quarter lower, household consumption one-fifth lower and gross fixed investment almost two-thirds lower. Real GDP growth accelerated from 1.4% in 2017 to 1.9% in 2018, but we expect it to remain constrained, at 1.8% in 2019 and 2020, and at an annual average of about 2.1% in 2021-23. The risks to our forecast are balanced: upside risks include continued strong tourism performance if capacity constraints are addressed and competitiveness gains are not eroded; downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector, and political and financial market instability.
A combination of elevated unemployment, high direct and indirect tax rates, heavy private-sector debt relative to household disposable income, and tight credit conditions will continue to put pressure on private consumption growth. We expect a modest acceleration in 2019-23, but this will be from a low base. Although we forecast a return to government consumption growth this year following contractions in eight of the last ten years, the pace of expansion will be modest, at 1% per year in 2019-23.
Gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years, but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17 from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by an average of 12% year on year in 2018. We expect a pick-up from this year, to an annual average of 5.2% in 2019-23. Underinvestment during the economic crisis and the depletion of Greece's capital stock are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
External trade will be constrained by Greece's relatively small, uncompetitive goods exports. We expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 4.5% in 2019-23, down from 8.7% in 2018. However, the tourism sector faces considerable challenges, including the UK's planned departure from the EU, increased competition from Turkey and insufficient public investment.
The risk that Greece will exit the euro zone (not our core scenario) has abated since the height of the financial crisis. However, whether the country remains in the euro zone will depend on how the economy performs in the next five years (and beyond). We believe that Grexit risk could rise again in the long term, given the difficulties that Greece will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Grexit would lead to a sovereign default and severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then recover, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack in the labour market, subdued domestic demand and sharp decreases in global oil prices in the final quarter of 2018 will dampen inflationary pressures. We expect the annual rate of consumer price inflation to rise modestly, from 0.8% in 2019 to 1.1% in 2020 and 1.5% in 2021-23 as domestic demand growth accelerates and global commodity prices pick up.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
The euro has depreciated against the dollar since peaking at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in February 2018, partly owing to monetary tightening in the US. Since the start of 2019 the euro has weakened further, mostly hovering around US$1.11:EUR1-US$1.13:EUR1, as high-frequency data and soft indicators continue to disappoint market expectations and point to a weak euro zone outlook. We expect the euro to remain broadly stable in the coming months and to average US$1.13:EUR1 in 2019. Next year it will appreciate to an average of US$1.18:EUR1 as the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) further eases policy. The euro should recover more pronouncedly from 2021 on the back of ECB policy tightening as growth in the region accelerates, which, together with the euro zone's large current-account surplus, should lift the exchange rate to US$1.25:EUR1 by end-2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The economic crisis helped to reduce Greece's current-account deficit, which shrank primarily as a result of a compression of imports due to contracting domestic demand, but also partly because of improved competitiveness, particularly in the tourism sector. We expect continued deficits in 2019-23 as import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand, and as global energy prices rise moderately in the second half of the forecast period. However, these deficits will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.1% of GDP recorded since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

Abstract: [...]militants in the oil-producing south will remain aggrieved by inertia over their key demand for more federal revenue from hydrocarbons to be kept locally for development. In the next general election in 2023, custom dictates that the candidates of both main parties will be southerners, giving the PDP a chance to improve on abysmally low turnout there in the 2019 presidential vote, which cost them victory. [...]Nigeria's economic outlook is bleak, with growth barely keeping pace with a rapidly increasing population. [...]investor interest will be short of official expectations and parliament will resist selling off key public assets cheaply. [...]devaluation is not included in the core forecast.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Muhammadu Buhari won a second and final four-year presidential term on February 23rd. The policy agenda he campaigned on did not involve considerable reform, only cosmetic improvements to the business environment.
The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This will create a potent mixture that will lead to frequent violent instability and directly affect key economic sectors.
Policy will be interventionist. Import bans on agricultural and manufactured goods will be widened to support local industry and farmers, and the Central Bank of Nigeria will maintain an overvalued official naira rate with which to channel cheap US dollars to preferred buyers.
The multiple-exchange-rate regime will not be dismantled under a Buhari administration; the arrangement is critical for making petrol subsidies affordable and underpins the government's interventionist approach to industrialisation.
Even though a multiple exchange-rate system will persist, non-official rates will converge and so in reality Nigeria will run a dual exchange-rate regime. Oil prices will be high enough to prevent a return to capital controls (as temporarily imposed in 2016), and the official rate will be kept fairly stable.
Fiscal expenditure will remain dominated by recurrent spending, despite attempts to boost capital investment. Efforts to boost non-oil tax revenue will be constrained by weak bureaucratic capacity and low economic growth.
Constrained by a crippling infrastructure deficit, as well as tight monetary conditions and instability in key agricultural regions, economic growth will be well below levels needed to boost job creation and increase living standards. This will perpetuate instability in a vicious cycle.
Inflation will remain high over the forecast period (2019-23) amid expansionary fiscal policy and high food prices stemming from government efforts to limit imports and support local producers. This in turn will keep credit conditions tight; even with some relaxation of the policy rate from 2021, inflation will be running too high for sustained monetary loosening, and credit growth will generally be slow.
Exports will be flat in 2019 and fall in 2020 as global oil prices come under pressure, but imports will also fall. Imports and exports will expand in 2021-23 but a current-account surplus will be maintained throughout the forecast period.

Nigeria's business environment score will improve slightly but its global and regional rankings will worsen as the administration struggles with the reform process and other countries make more significant improvements.
Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. The upstream oil sector will remain characterised by joint-ventures between the state oil company and multinationals.
2021-23: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress will be slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: An attempt to sell the state's interest in oil joint ventures with multinationals will meet serious challenges (the policy has been around for years), with resistance in the legislature to the permanent loss of a revenue stream.
2021-23: Higher world oil prices and so easing fiscal pressures lessen the need to embark on a divestment programme. Energy companies will anyway be hesitant to increase their stake in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Import bans are widened, but capital controls will not be necessary, barring another oil price crash.
2021-23: A premium between the overvalued official and parallel-market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2019-20: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Value-added tax (VAT) is increased to fund a higher minimum wage, which will markedly increase the fiscal cost of the civil service.
2021-23: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation, particularly for offshore oilfields. The need for new consumer taxes is alleviated by higher world oil prices and, as a result, hydrocarbons revenue.
Financing
2019-20: Funding for well-planned projects becomes easier to raise domestically following the completion of the 2019 elections, as local capital markets deepen (with greater foreign participation) and the banking sector develops.
2021-23: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts savings and investment.
The labour market
2019-20: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2021-23: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff; unemployment remains high and the market loose.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints and is crowded out by other spending categories, including debt-servicing and higher public-sector wages. Although there should be growth in private-sector investment, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2021-23: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2021-23: Research spending is likely to remain low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multiparty democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in 2015, and Mr Buhari secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 has almost wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.
