Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Muhammadu Buhari won a presidential election in February 2019 and will remain in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. However, managing the country's myriad security threats will prove an insoluble challenge. The foremost reason for this is an overstretched military and police force, which will be unable to cope with simultaneous security crises. The government cannot afford to upgrade Nigeria's security capabilities to an adequate level without making sweeping reforms to increase the tax take, and no such overhaul is anticipated.
Conflict in the north-east between the government and two Islamist terrorist groups, Boko Haram and the Islamic State in West Africa Province (ISWAP), is heating up, with insurgents appearing better equipped and staging more audacious attacks than had been the case in recent years. Military setbacks are getting worse and, as this is one of Mr Buhari's voter strongholds, the president will be keen to reassert control over the situation. Boko Haram and ISWAP will be aggressively countered, but the north-east of Nigeria will remain a low-level conflict zone, albeit isolated, and the campaign will divert military resources from pockets of severe instability elsewhere. One such hotspot is just to the south, in the agricultural Middle Belt of Nigeria, where violent clashes between settled farmers and nomads competing for land have killed several thousand civilians in recent years. Formal land-titling is a potential solution to the crisis, but as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another, it would prove too contentious. Ultimately there is no foreseeable end to violence in the Middle Belt. Vigilantes will be used to make up for shortfalls in formal security personnel, but not be an effective substitute. Again, the direct effect of the conflict on the security situation will be localised, but the entire country will feel the secondary effects in the form of constricted food supply and, as a result, consumer prices.
The military and police will be too poorly equipped to suppress pervasive banditry and kidnapping in the north and north-west, where widespread poverty and unemployment are feeding into a cycle of crime that will be difficult (if not impossible) to break, given a bleak economic outlook. Finally, militants in the oil-producing south will remain aggrieved by inertia over their key demand for more federal revenue from hydrocarbons to be kept locally for development. Wholesale reform of the oil sector is a massive task and one that The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect to be achieved in the forecast period. Our assumption is that attacks by aggrieved militants and saboteurs on oil infrastructure will continue to be a major security problem in Delta state, with indirect consequences for the entire federation in the form of disrupted oil exports.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The election in February 2019 reaffirmed a deep electoral divide between the APC-supporting north and southern Nigeria, a stronghold of the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP). In the next general election in 2023, custom dictates that the candidates of both main parties will be southerners, giving the PDP a chance to improve on abysmally low turnout there in the 2019 presidential vote, which cost them victory. Moreover, Nigeria's economic outlook is bleak, with growth barely keeping pace with a rapidly increasing population. After two terms of lacklustre economic performance, it is likely that voter frustration will be turned on the APC, especially if the party proves as dysfunctional as it was during Mr Buhari's first term. The parliamentary election gave the APC a large majority in both houses, which in theory should be enabling, but divisions between the executive and party backbenchers were a major obstacle to reform during 2015-19. Even the basic functioning of the state was impaired, with crucial bills such as the national budget being delayed by months. As legislators typically prioritise the interests of their constituents over party and federation in Nigeria, similar tensions could easily reoccur in Mr Buhari's second stint. Disunity such as this will be easily exploitable for the PDP candidate, affording them a winning edge.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat that they pose. Relations with the US will be mixed; the administration of Donald Trump is willing to sell Nigeria military hardware, but Mr Trump's disapproval of the trade deficit the US runs with Nigeria (particularly owing to Nigerian import restrictions) could strain ties. Relations with the EU will be largely cordial but subject to tensions over Nigerian migrants seeking to enter Europe and Nigerian efforts to repatriate funds in European banks that were allegedly looted by former rulers.
India will remain important as the largest market for Nigerian oil and become a bigger source of foreign investment. China will also remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will fall short of the headline-grabbing pledges made, given an extremely challenging local business environment. Nigeria will remain an important player in Sub-Saharan Africa given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. For example, although Mr Buhari recently signed a continent-wide free trade agreement it is likely that protected sectors (notably in agriculture, where other countries would have a competitive advantage) will remain shielded from foreign competition.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Economic policy during Mr Buhari's second and final term is likely to carry over the interventionist policies adopted during his first. Measures to liberalise and unify foreign-exchange markets or move to more market-led pricing in the energy sector will not be pursued. An overvalued official naira rate is critical for maintaining fuel subsidies (over 90% of petrol is imported), and Mr Buhari will not willingly undo pump-price caps and risk a popular backlash. Although in practice very little foreign exchange is traded at the official rate, the existence of a multiple-exchange-rate system brings with it the risk of capital controls and will be off-putting to foreign direct investors or those acquiring illiquid assets. Concerns about this will be especially pronounced whenever global crude prices soften, but the omnipresent risk of convertibility restrictions will ultimately keep foreign direct investment well below Nigeria's potential, with inflows at less than 1% of GDP throughout the forecast period.
Elsewhere, efforts will be made to cleanse and reboot inefficient state-owned industries such as the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC)-which dominates all segments of the oil sector-but no structural reforms will take place. Generally, Mr Buhari's approach will be to make existing entities such as the NNPC profitable rather than relinquish state control over them. There will be some effort to reduce the NNPC's stake in the upstream oil joint ventures that it has with international oil companies, but demand will be held back by the difficulty of operating in Nigeria and uncertainty about fiscal terms (with deep political divisions about how to distribute hydrocarbons revenue having stalled critical legislation). As a result, investor interest will be short of official expectations and parliament will resist selling off key public assets cheaply. As a consequence, the NNPC will continue to dominate the oil sector, with politicians and other members of the political elite working to direct the flow of resources to favour specific geo-ethnic and political constituencies (as well as for illicit personal gain).
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
We expect small fiscal deficits throughout the forecast period. The government wants to diversify its revenue base away from oil, and non-oil revenue will rise through efforts to collect overdue taxes and a probable increase in value-added tax (VAT) from 5% now to 8% in 2020. Increases will be from an extremely low base however. Tax avoidance is widespread, and instability impedes collection in many parts of the country. Petrol subsidies (whereby losses incurred by the NNPC's retail arm are deducted from federal revenue) will be another drain, and budgeted revenue levels will be undermined by overambitious oil production targets. For example, in 2019 the government expects output of 2.3m barrels/day-a level not seen since the oil price slump, and one unobtainable given underinvestment and OPEC production quotas. In all, federally retained revenue is not expected to rise above 3.7% of GDP-a ratio only attained in 2022 when oil prices are at their highest point within the forecast period.
After expansion in 2018, spending will decline as a proportion of GDP in 2019 with a low capital budget and poor execution. Partly offsetting this will be higher spending on wages and public-sector benefits, including via the introduction of a new (increased) minimum wage. Generally, however, fiscal flexibility will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and, as a result, revenue-under pressure and there being considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. Altogether, we expect an average budget deficit averaging 1.9% of GDP in 2019-23.
Long-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against an abnormally low revenue base. Debt service has taken up to half of federal revenue in recent years, which is alarming even by heavily indebted emerging-market standards. A sovereign default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is weaker.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
Monetary policy will concentrate on fostering an economic recovery. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The private sector is desperate for cheaper credit, and the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) is minded towards boosting the supply side of the economy, but inflation is well above the targeted upper limit of 9%. On balance, we expect interest rates not to move much in 2019-20, notwithstanding a small rate cut by the CBN in March (upheld in May and July). This presupposes that core inflation is kept high by a recent increase in the minimum wage and increases in VAT. If this is not the case, then the CBN may sanction a rate cut in late 2019 or early 2020. Our baseline is for rates to fall in 2021 and stabilise during 2022-23 as economic activity picks up and inflation hovers above or around the target.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The economy will for the most part be mired in a low-growth cycle, although there will be improvements over time. In 2019-20 the economy will grow by an average of just 2.1%, held back by power shortages, insecurity, high inflation and tight credit conditions. With fiscal power being so limited, monetary policy is the main lever that can drive a recovery. In 2021-23, as global markets strengthen and inflation gradually decelerates-allowing for some monetary easing-the rate of growth will quicken to an average of 3.3%, which remains well below potential.
From a sectoral viewpoint, agricultural growth will be lacklustre. Although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will continue to be severe impediments. Industrial production will be curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, and investment will be held back by uncertainty about future fiscal terms. Egina, a new offshore oilfield, will drive higher condensate output, but hydrocarbons production is not expected to return to levels prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash. That said, a private refinery coming on stream by 2021 will be a boost to downstream oil activity in the latter years of the forecast period. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of cheap goods from abroad, which are often smuggled into the country to bypass import bans, as well as power supply gaps. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth than industry, but it will nonetheless be held back by protectionism (affecting trade), tight credit conditions affecting areas such as real estate and finance, and the struggle in the communications sector to profitably roll out data services beyond urban hubs.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
From a rate of 12.1% in 2018, average inflation will remain elevated at 11.8% in 2019, as a 67% increase in the minimum wage combines with disruptions to local food supply and widening import restrictions. In 2020 inflation at 10.9% will remain above the CBN's targeted ceiling of 9%, as demand-side forces from the minimum-wage rise continue. We also expect a 3-percentage-point rise in VAT that year, promoted by lower oil prices (and fiscal revenue coming under pressure). With base effects from this fading, core inflation will gradually ease over the rest of the forecast period, bringing the headline rate down with it to an average of 8.8% in 2023. Conflict and supply disruptions in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's agricultural heartland-will prevent a faster slide, together with widening import restrictions. Currently 43 items are barred from foreign-exchange access and the CBN wants to increase the list to 50 as a means of stimulating non-oil activity.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2019-23, with an official rate used for government business and a more market-determined rate applicable to investors and exporters, which will be broadly in line with retail rates and the parallel market. Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors deemed important for economic or political reasons, including the NNPC, which budgets for petrol imports at the official rate. Although we expect a fall in exports over 2019-20, the decrease will not be steep or sustained enough to force a devaluation of the official exchange rate. Over this period flat or declining interest rates in the US will also support foreign-exchange supply via portfolio flows into fixed-income securities. Higher global crude prices thereafter mean a flat official rate is likely throughout the forecast period. In real terms, currency stability (for both the official and more market-determined rates) means real appreciation of the naira against trading partners as inflation remains high. For this reason there is a downside risk of policymakers opting to devalue or allowing more market-determined rates to weaken in order to regain international competitiveness. However, the CBN governor, Godwin Emefiele, is set against the idea, and in any case industrial strategy is focused on supplying the domestic market. As a result, devaluation is not included in the core forecast.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. For example, the current market-determined rate, known as the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Rate Fixing (Nafex), has only been in full operation since April 2017, making historical calculations challenging. Indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued, which is in line with official calculations.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The profile of export earnings will move in tandem with oil production and price trends. Output gains will keep earnings in growth in 2019, and higher global prices in 2021-23 and continued output gains (with a new mega-refinery coming on stream in around 2021) will do likewise. Only in 2020-when prices fall faster than incremental production gains-will exports drop.
Nigeria's government actively promotes import-substitution through foreign-exchange restrictions on certain goods (mainly manufactures and agricultural produce). However, this policy is oriented more around stimulating local industry than reducing imports per se, and an overvalued naira will contribute to fairly strong consumer demand. Imports will fall slightly in 2019-20 all the same, reflecting lower global crude prices (Nigeria imports almost all its petrol requirement). As the economy gathers pace in 2021-23 and global oil prices rise, imports will then grow faster.
Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation in the oil sector will keep the services and primary income balances firmly in deficit. Workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, albeit dipping in 2020 as growth falters in the US (home to a large Nigerian diaspora). Overall, the current-account surplus will average 1.7% of GDP in 2019-20, widening to 2.3% of GDP in 2021-23 as oil prices strengthen and the new refinery comes on stream.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Italy&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Italy+July+2019+Updater&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2019-07-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Italy&amp;rft.issn=09668845&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The March 2018 general election produced a badly fragmented parliament. It also yielded a resounding victory for the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won about 33% of the vote, and the anti-immigration, Eurosceptic Lega, which secured about 17%. Following tortuous government-formation talks, which almost ended inconclusively, at end-May the two parties agreed to form a government, led by Giuseppe Conte, an independent.
Mr Conte and his technocratic minister of the economy, Giovanni Tria, have experienced tensions with Matteo Salvini, the leader of the Lega, and Luigi Di Maio, the M5S leader, both of whom serve as deputy prime ministers. Mr Di Maio and Mr Salvini are the de facto political leaders of the government, which The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect to complete a five-year term, ending in 2023. Amid a slowing economy and a resounding victory at the European Parliament elections, we believe that Mr Salvini is likely to press for an early election in late 2019. The soonest feasible date for a snap election would be sometime in early 2020.
The government will continue to prioritise tougher stances on migration and more defiant positions on EU rules, as well as the disarming of so-called safeguard clauses in the country's fiscal framework that would raise indirect taxes from 2020 if other consolidation measures are not approved. The government is also implementing means-tested "citizenship income" and is planning a "growth decree" to support the economy.
Following a protracted dispute with the European Commission over its draft 2019 budget plan, the government narrowly avoided the launch of an excessive-deficit procedure in early July. Tensions are likely to increase during the 2020 budget process, however, as the Lega is demanding the implementation of a costly "flat" income tax proposal, and the Commission believes that Italy is non-compliant with its rules on public debt reduction.
We expect Italian real GDP to stagnate in 2019, growing by just 0.1%. Risks to this forecast are balanced to the downside. This is likely to put this year's revised fiscal deficit target of 2% of GDP out of reach. Weaker economic growth and a wider deficit also mean that the government's goal of lowering the government debt/GDP ratio from 132.4% at end-2018 is unlikely to be achieved. Our core forecast for growth in 2020-23 is also weak, owing to slowing momentum both domestically and in the euro area. We forecast real GDP growth of 0.4% in 2020 and about 1.1% on average in 2021-23.

Italy's business environment score improves modestly in the 2019-23 forecast period. Reforms since 2012 have helped to raise the scores for foreign investment, financing and the labour market. Some of these will be reversed or diluted.
Country forecast overview: Italy's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Significant reforms to improve competition will not be a priority under the administration led by Giuseppe Conte.
2021-23: Improvements in competition policy will depend on stabilisation of the political environment.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Modest reductions in red tape. Government plans to charge penalties to foreign firms that collect state incentives and then relocate production to non-EU countries within five years of the incentivised investment.
2021-23: Organised crime, legal complexity and shortcomings in judicial system remain deterrents.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Quotas and tariffs are in line with EU practice. The Conte government could oppose new EU trade deals. EU focuses on EU-UK trade deal in Brexit negotiations, further bilateral free-trade deals and responding to US tariffs.
2021-23: An EU-US agreement will probably remain elusive. The risk of a euro area break-up, which could lead to capital controls, is low, although The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Greece to leave the bloc in the medium term.
Taxes
2019-20: Automatic rise in value-added tax (VAT) rate is averted in 2019, but implementation of two-rate "flat tax" is delayed owing to cost. Reduction in tax expenditure and some tax rises in order to finance costly social spending plans.
2021-23: Government seeks to implement a diluted corporate and income tax-reduction package.
Financing
2019-20: Bank mergers, recapitalisations and non-performing loan sales are slow, not least given political uncertainty.
2021-23: Banking sector exposure to the Italian sovereign will persist. Mergers of smaller co-operative banks and possible foreign takeovers accelerate, as does the sale of securitised bad loans. Profitability and credit provision remain weak.
The labour market
2019-20: Firms remain reluctant to increase open-ended contract payrolls. Universal unemployment benefit or "citizenship income" may be partly introduced. Some aspects of 2014-15 labour market reforms will be reversed.
2021-23: Decentralised private-sector productivity-related pay deals and changes to public-sector contracts face resistance.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Lack of fiscal space constrains government plans for higher investment spending.
2021-23: Infrastructure still lags that of other euro area countries, despite some new investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) presses for further digitalisation of public services. A preponderance of smaller and family-run firms, as well as high levels of corporate debt, keep research and development (R&D) spending low.
2021-23: Gradually improving economic prospects, as well as Brexit, encourage more information and communications technology graduates to seek work in Italy. Slight improvement in R&D and company-level technology investment.

Background: Post-war Italy has been characterised by a weak political structure and, since the 1970s, a declining economic base. Between 1996 and 2011 Italy had a bipolar political system, dominated by a centre-right alliance and a centre-left coalition. Since 2011 the political landscape has become more fragmented, with the break-up of the centre right, the emergence of the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and a recent splintering of the centre left. Since the 2013 general election Italy has had three broad centre-left/centre-right governments. Matteo Renzi's resignation as prime minister after his flagship constitutional reform was rejected in a referendum in December 2016 led to the formation of a government led by Paolo Gentiloni, a close ally of Mr Renzi. Following the 2018 general election an M5S-Lega government was formed.
Political structure: Parliament, which comprises two houses with equal powers, is elected for a five-year term. In the event of a political crisis the president, who is elected by parliament for a seven-year term, decides whether to call an election or nominate a prime minister to try to form a government. The president also promulgates laws and may return a law to parliament for reconsideration, but has no power of veto. Executive power lies with the cabinet, which is nominated by the prime minister and approved by parliament. The prime minister cannot dismiss ministers without forming a new government. The legislative system remains unchanged following the rejection in the December 2016 referendum of a reform to reduce the powers of the Senate (the upper house). A new, predominantly proportional, electoral system was adopted in October 2017.
Policy issues: The main issues are the management of, and attempts to reduce, Italy's large public debt (which stood at 132.2% of GDP in 2018), safeguarding the banking system and keeping Italy in the euro zone. In 2012 the government, led by Mario Monti, carried out a number of structural economic reforms to improve competitiveness. The process has since stalled, and the M5S-Lega government will seek to loosen fiscal policy, stimulate private consumption through tax cuts and income support to low earners, and seek to reverse or dilute recent pension and labour reforms.
Taxation: The top rate of personal income tax is 43%, and social security contributions are high, especially for employers. The corporation tax rate is 24%, reduced in 2017 from 27.5%, but additional regional and municipal taxes are levied, including the regional business tax (IRAP), to fund health services. The basic rate of IRAP is 3.5%, reduced from 3.9% in 2014. Income earned from most types of financial investment is taxed at 26%. The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 22%.
Foreign trade: The value of exports of goods (fob) stood at US$537.5bn in 2018, and imports (fob) were worth US$481.9bn. In the same year the current account recorded a surplus of US$50.6bn, or 2.4% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Slightly more than a year into its five-year term, the coalition government composed of the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and the far-right Lega is showing signs of strain. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that the leader of the Lega, Matteo Salvini, will trigger a political crisis, but probably not until later this year, when frictions with M5S and with the EU surrounding the 2020 budget will provide an opportunity to withdraw from the coalition. The president, Sergio Mattarella, would have limited options but to grant Mr Salvini-who tops opinion polls-an early election, but such a vote will probably only be held in the first half of 2020. At this contest we expect the Lega to win a commanding majority in parliament at the head of a right-wing coalition, including the centre-right Forza Italia and the small, post-fascist Fratelli d'Italia.
The coalition-led by Giuseppe Conte, an independent law professor-came into office in the wake of the March 2018 general election, at which M5S won 33% of the vote and the Lega won 17%. Since then, however, the Lega has dominated the government under the leadership of Mr Salvini (a deputy prime minister and minister of the interior) who has struck a chord with Italian voters, with his round-talking speeches, adept use of social media and a policy agenda focused on security issues, Euroscepticism and combating illegal immigration.
Meanwhile M5S's popularity has ebbed steadily under the leadership of Luigi Di Maio, also a deputy prime minister, and the minster of labour and economic development. Following disappointing performances in a series of regional and local elections in 2018-19 M5S won just 17% of the vote at the European Parliament elections, compared with the Lega's 34%.
In early July, following weeks of tensions with the European Commission, the government managed to evade a debt-based excessive-deficit procedure (EDP) by adopting measures intended to reduce the 2019 budget deficit by EUR7.6bn, to 2% of GDP (compared with a previous target of 2.4%). Nonetheless, tensions between the government and EU institutions are likely to resume regarding the draft 2020 budget in October. The drafting process in the weeks before the submission will be challenging, given the divisions within the government coalition and the need to disarm the so-called safeguard clauses written into the country's multi-year fiscal framework. This would raise the headline value-added tax (VAT) rate from an already high 22% to 25.2%, if EUR23bn (1.3% of GDP) is not raised through spending cuts or from other revenue sources. The Lega's landslide win at the European Parliament elections has emboldened Mr Salvini, who is determined to have his costly flat-tax reform-thus far applied only to lower- and middle-income VAT-account holders-extended to the personal income of all citizens in the next budget. This time the Commission may adopt a tougher line, as it will not have European Parliament elections looming. Against this backdrop, a combination of financial market pressures, electoral opportunism on Mr Salvini's behalf and political pressure from EU institutions are expected to cause the government to unravel, paving the way for a snap election in 2020.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The next parliamentary election is scheduled for early 2023, but we expect it to be held much sooner. Mr Salvini will probably try to capitalise on his party's gains in support by pulling the plug on the administration. Such a move would be an attempt to force Mr Mattarella to call a snap general election if he cannot find an alternative governing majority in parliament.
The result of the European Parliament elections has raised the likelihood that such a break will happen late this year. When combined with the Lega's vote share of 34%, those of Forza Italia (9%) and Fratelli d'Italia (6%) come to about 50%, which would be likely to produce a commanding majority under Italy's voting law for general elections. This system, the so-called Rosatellum 2, allocates about one-third of the seats in each house of parliament in single-member districts and about two-thirds via proportional representation.
It is possible that M5S and the centre-left opposition party, Partito Democratico (PD)-having reclaimed its place as the second most popular party in the context of the May European Parliament elections, surpassing M5S with a vote share of 23%-will align in the event of a government crisis in order to avert an election over the near term that returns a right-wing government. However, the parliamentary mathematics would be difficult, particularly in the Senate (the upper house of parliament), and the two parties would struggle to justify such a move to their respective electorates.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
We expect Italy to remain a member of the EU and the euro zone during the 2019-23 forecast period. Other foreign policy mainstays-including a close relationship with the US, and membership of NATO and the UN-will also continue. However, relations are likely to be strained. Mr Salvini has signalled a more confrontational stance towards other EU countries, taking a tough line on migration measures and has also protested against EU fiscal constraints.
Sino-Italian diplomatic relations will improve in the near term, following Italy's decision to sign in late March a memorandum of understanding (MoU) to participate in the Belt and Road Initiative, China's flagship global infrastructure integration plan. The MoU is unlikely to increase bilateral trade or investment flows significantly in 2019-23, but it will probably undermine EU attempts to find a common stance on China, and complicate Italy's relations with other EU countries and the US.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The M5S-Lega administration has departed from the more orthodox policies of previous governments. With regards to the labour market, the administration passed the so-called Dignity Decree in July 2018, reversing parts of the 2015 Jobs Act, a liberalising labour market reform. In April 2019 the government implemented an expansionary pension reform, easing the conditions for early retirement.
One of the administration's other flagship policies, M5S's citizenship income, provides a monthly stipend or top-up of other benefits, including EUR780 for poor pensioners and the unemployed. For working-age people, the citizenship income effectively functions in the same way as a means-tested jobseeker's allowance and has been paired with enhanced active labour market policies.
The government has also implemented a first step towards the Lega's promised 15% flat income tax, applying this rate to VAT-account holders earning up to EUR65,000 beginning in January 2019. Finally, the administration has approved a new anti-corruption law, as well as a security decree containing a series of tougher policing and immigration measures, and a growth decree intended to jump-start business activity.
The coalition's anti-reformist rhetoric and its open resistance to EU fiscal rules have rattled the markets. The banking sector also remains weak and highly exposed to government debt, which totals EUR2.3trn. However, credit quality has improved rapidly in the past two years, owing to regulatory pressures from the European Central Bank (ECB) to reduce stocks of bad loans on banks' balance sheets, as well as the rescue and restructuring of several troubled lenders.
Nonetheless, an abrupt uptick in market perceptions of political risk could still pose challenges to financial stability. We believe it is unlikely that Italy will lose market access in 2019-23. However, owing to the sheer size of Italy's public debt stock and the fragility its banks, the economy would be too large to rescue without support from the ECB in the event of a large-scale crisis.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
On July 1st the government adopted measures intended to reduce the 2019 budget deficit by EUR7.6bn, to 2% of GDP, compared with a previous target of 2.4%. The EUR7.6bn correction includes an adjustment of EUR6.1bn contained in the "budget-balancing" law, comprising EUR6.2bn from higher than projected revenue (about half from larger tax revenue and social security contributions, and half from higher dividend payments from government stakes in the Bank of Italy-the central bank-and the Cassa Depositi e Prestiti, a state-controlled investment bank that manages postal savings), as well as a net spending overshoot of EUR100m. The government has introduced a decree to freeze EUR1.5bn (0.08% of GDP) in unused budget funds that was earmarked to cover the cost of relaxing the 2011 reform of early pension requirements and the citizenship income-the administration's ambitious plan to fight poverty.
Given the distinct risk of higher outlays than expected, we believe that this objective is implausible and expect a budget shortfall of 2.5% of GDP in 2019. The 2020 budget process, which will begin with an update to the government's fiscal and economic projections in late September, and the submission of a draft budgetary plan to the European Commission in mid-October, is likely to prove to be exceptionally difficult. The deficit is then expected to expand further, to 2.8% of GDP in 2020, and to an average of about 2.6% in 2021-23. Public debt, at 132.2% of GDP at end-2018, is expected to remain near this level for the next five years.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The ECB adopted a remarkably accommodative monetary policy in response to the European sovereign debt crisis, bringing major policy interest rates down to zero or below; it also launched a EUR2.6trn quantitative easing (QE) programme in 2015, which it concluded in December 2018. Nevertheless, policy will remain ultra-loose in the forecast period, as the ECB will reinvest principal payments from maturing securities past the date on which it starts tightening. Euro zone inflationary pressures remain low, and there are pronounced downside risks to the euro zone's economic outlook. At its meeting on June 6th the ECB adopted a dovish stance, delaying the next rate rise from early 2020 until mid-2020 at the earliest. This was in line with our existing forecast; we expect the ECB to raise its deposit rate in June 2020 and the main refinancing rate in December 2020, with policy tightening proceeding thereafter at a gradual pace. The bank also announced that the interest rate on its third round of targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs-III) could go as low as -0.3%, to encourage lending. Should economic conditions deteriorate further, for instance given an escalation in the US-China trade war or a "no-deal" Brexit (not our core forecast), we would expect the ECB to resume its QE programme or to cut rates once again.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
In full-year 2018 real GDP expanded by 0.7%, down from 1.8% in 2017. Momentum was weak going into 2019, dampened by domestic political and economic uncertainty, as well as global trade tensions. In January-March 2019 the economy expanded by 0.1% (compared with the previous three months). This followed two consecutive quarters of negative growth, and resulted in a first-quarter contraction of 0.1% year on year. We expect that the economy will expand by a marginal 0.1% in full-year 2019, on the back of slower growth in private consumption and fixed investment, and less favourable external conditions. High-frequency indicators for the first half of 2019 paint a mixed picture, suggesting that the recovery from recession is fragile and could falter in the coming quarters.
Economic growth will remain subdued in 2020, at 0.4%. In that year the building effects of the ongoing US-China trade dispute, and weaker growth in the US, will weigh on the external sector and dampen sentiment. Growth should then pick up to an average of 1.1% per year in real terms in 2021-23 as domestic and global demand recover.
The boost to real household disposable income from recent tax cuts has faded, with real private consumption-accounting for about 60% of GDP-growing only modestly, by 0.6% in full-year 2018. Consumer spending also weakened as a result of heightened volatility in financial markets in the final two quarters of 2018, which weighed on consumer confidence, and it may wane in the second half of this year as political tensions with EU institutions mount. We expect weak job creation, modest wage growth and waning consumer confidence to continue to constrain household spending in 2019. After meagre expansions of 0.4% per year on average in 2019-20, we forecast that consumer spending will rise to about 1% per year in 2021-23 as domestic sentiment improves.
Public consumption rose by 0.2% in 2018, and we expect looser spending controls and limited fiscal stimulus efforts to result in a slight uptick in 2019-23. It will remain modest, however, at an annual average rate of 0.5% throughout this period. The current administration's looser stance towards deficit spending will raise the risk of higher levels of government consumption.
Fixed investment expanded for the fourth consecutive year in 2018, but was still more than one-fifth below its 2007 pre-crisis level. It rose by 3.2% in real terms last year, driven by transport-equipment spending in the first half of the year, as well as a slow recovery in construction. In 2019-20 investment growth will slow significantly, to an annual average of 1.2%, held back by the expiration of tax incentives, policy uncertainty and declining sentiment, as well as public capital spending constraints, still impaired credit channels and relatively high levels of corporate debt.
The pace of export growth decreased markedly in 2018, to 1.4%. Export growth is expected to remain weak in 2019-20, owing in particular to weaker growth in EU markets and global trade tensions, before picking up thereafter. Anaemic domestic demand growth and external demand constraints will also constrain import growth to less than 2% in 2019-22, before stronger export performance and healthier domestic demand lead to firmer expansion in 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Consumer price inflation remained subdued in 2018, at 1.2%, as a 0.2% decline in core inflation (headline inflation excluding volatile food and energy prices) more than offset inflationary pressures that stemmed from a 30.7% increase in international oil prices and a rise in global food prices for the first time in seven years.
In 2019 consumer price growth should slow further, to 0.9%, owing to cheaper average global energy prices and still considerable slack in the labour market, meaning that upward pressure on prices from capacity constraints will not materialise in the near term. A positive demand shock from fiscal policy also appears unlikely. In 2020 headline inflation should increase slightly, driven by a forecast 4.8% increase in global food prices, which will offset downward pressures deriving from declining global energy prices. From 2020 inflation should recover gradually, to average 1.4% in 2021-23, as global energy prices rise.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
The euro rallied in late 2017 on the back of the region's economic recovery and rising expectations of QE tapering. However, since peaking at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in February 2018, the euro has depreciated against the dollar, in part owing to monetary tightening in the US last year. Since the start of 2019 the euro has weakened further, hovering around US$1.12:EUR1-US$1.14:EUR1, as high-frequency data and soft indicators continue to disappoint market expectations and point to a weaker euro zone outlook. We expect the euro to remain broadly stable throughout the year, reflecting investors' concerns about Brexit and a further deterioration in US-EU trade relations. After averaging US$1.13:EUR1 in 2019, the euro should pick up more substantially in 2020, to US$1.18:EUR1, as these risks abate, momentum in the euro zone recovers and the ECB takes steps to tighten policy. The currency will rebound further in 2021-23, to US$1.23:EUR1, underpinned by the euro zone's large current-account surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
In 2018 the current account remained firmly in surplus, at 2.4% of GDP. We expect it to average 1.5% in 2019-23. This decline reflects considerably slower growth in export revenue until 2021, in line with slower global demand. Higher international energy prices in 2021-23 will have a negative effect on the trade balance in those years (Italy is a major energy importer).

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In a snap general election held on July 7th 2019 the main centre-right opposition party, New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, recorded a comfortable victory over the left-wing ruling Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza) led by Alexis Tsipras. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the single-party ND government will provide the basis for more stable and effective administration, but that it will struggle with the multiple challenges inherited from Mr Tsipras's administration.
Greece will remain under "enhanced supervision" by euro zone creditors during the forecast period (2019-23) and beyond, until its huge public debt of more than 180% of GDP is substantially reduced. We do not expect Greece's creditors to allow the new government to renegotiate the annual primary budget surplus targets of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter in order to adopt more growth-friendly policies of tax cuts. Protests are likely to continue as the government strives to meet the ambitious budget targets.
Greece is facing its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it has exited the bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. However, it will not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments until the end of 2020. A Greek exit from the euro zone represents a risk over the long term.
After expanding by 1.9% in 2018, we expect real GDP growth to reach 1.8% in 2019 and 2020, and an annual average of about 2.1% in 2021-23. Meeting large primary budget surplus targets and restoring competitiveness will prove difficult. Public debt is forecast to remain high, at about 175% of GDP in 2023.
Inflation (EU harmonised) will remain subdued, rising slightly-from 0.8% in 2018 to an annual average of 0.9% in 2019-20-reflecting moderate domestic demand growth and weaker global energy prices. In 2021-23 we expect oil prices to rise, bringing inflation to 1.5% per year. We expect narrow current-account deficits in 2019-23, compared with an annual average of 7.1% of GDP since 2001, when Greece joined the euro zone.

Greece's business environment will improve moderately in the forecast period, with progress in almost all categories apart from political stability. However, Greece will remain subject to sub-optimal fiscal and other policy conditions, which will constrain real GDP growth and keep Greece's debt burden high.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The new government seeks to revive the country's privatisation programme, unblocking some delayed deals.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make modest progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Remaining capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eliminated. Capital buffer of about EUR26bn sufficient to cover about two years of the government's medium- and long-term financing needs to end-2020.
2021-23: Significant risk of Greece leaving euro zone in long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result in reintroduction of foreign-exchange controls and possibly restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point-of-sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Pressure to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) intensifies. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: The need to increase provisions for still high NPLs hampers lending. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU-funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Technical assistance from EU helps absorption of European funds to revive infrastructure investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. Private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of the EMU into question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA), but ND returned to power in July 2019 and XA failed to win enough votes to enter parliament.
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages, totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 28% (29% in 2018) and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR32.4bn and imports (fob) amounted to EUR54.9bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR5.3bn, equivalent to 2.9% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In a snap general election held on July 7th 2019, three months before the end of the parliamentary term, the main centre-right opposition party, New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, recorded a comfortable victory over the left-wing ruling Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza) led by Alexis Tsipras. ND obtained 39.85% of the national vote, which, along with a 50-seat bonus awarded to the party with the most votes, gave Mr Mitsotakis's party 158 seats in the 300-seat parliament.
The new government is the first single-party government since the start of the Greek crisis nearly a decade ago, which should provide the basis for a more stable and effective government. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit still expects the new administration to struggle with the multiple challenges inherited from Mr Tsipras's administration, not least reassuring Greece's international creditors that ND's programme of tax cuts will not jeopardise the country's route to debt sustainability. This task has been made harder by the fiscal loosening that the outgoing Tsipras government pursued in the run-up to the elections this year. As a result, the new government, which is subject to strict policy conditionality under the EU's enhanced surveillance regime, will have limited room for manoeuvre to change course to a more growth-friendly policy mix. We also remain sceptical that real GDP growth will rise to much more than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period, further hindering the new government's ability to reduce Greece's public debt of more than 180% of GDP to a more sustainable level.
During his time in power since 2015 Mr Tsipras has lost much popular support, despite taking Greece out of the third bail-out programme in August 2018 after eight years of austerity and unpopular reforms. Nevertheless, Syriza performed better than might have been expected in the general election, winning 31.53% of the vote and 86 seats (compared with 35.5% in the September 2015 general election). This should be sufficient to ensure that Mr Tsipras maintains the leadership of the party. If the party remains united, it should provide strong opposition to the ND government.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The next general election is not due until mid-2023, when Greece will also hold local, regional and European Parliament elections. In early 2020 parliament is due to elect the next president, who has a mostly ceremonial role. The incumbent, Prokopis Pavlopoulos, was elected on February 18th 2015. The current election procedure requires a minimum three-fifths majority (180 out of 300 members of parliament) in the third round of voting to elect the president, otherwise a fresh general election must be called. An amendment to abolish this provision was approved by an enhanced majority in the previous parliament, so the presidential election now only requires a simple majority the second time around. Another constitutional amendment to repeal the electoral reform introduced by Syriza (that abolished the 50-seat bonus awarded to the party winning the most votes in the general election) will, however, require a three-fifths majority in the new parliament. If ND cannot muster enough support, the restoration of the 50-seat bonus will not take effect until the general election after the next one-in other words in 2027.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political instability, as well as protracted economic and financial crises, has limited Greece's influence in the EU and in the Balkans, but in its final phase, the Syriza government made successful efforts to restore influence on the international scene, including the Macedonia name-change deal, which was ratified in January 2019, and talks on closer co-operation with the US. The name-change agreement aims to end Greece's opposition to Northern Macedonia's accession to NATO and its application for EU membership. ND opposed ratification of the deal, but Mr Mitsotakis has said that he would only seek to renegotiate it if Northern Macedonia agreed.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey will persist. However, we believe that both sides will seek to prevent their historical enmity from escalating into military hostility. Points of contention include long-standing territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
With a general election looming in 2019, the Syriza government opted to exit Greece's third economic adjustment programme in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line but with a substantial cash buffer to use while the government builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR26bn, should be sufficient to cover the country's financing needs until end-2020. However, this will be more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. Intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the Syriza government to choose the more expensive option.
Nevertheless, severe policy constraints will remain during the forecast period and beyond, until Greece's huge government debt is substantially reduced. General government debt was about 182% of GDP at end-2018, and also predominantly owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), making another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, highly unlikely. Economic policy and performance is subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries.
The implementation of further debt-relief measures also agreed with Greece's EU creditors in June 2018 will be conditional on quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments, the most pressing of which include tackling Greek banks' heavy burden of non-performing loans, reviving the government's privatisation programme, removing remaining capital controls and clearing state arrears to the private sector. Greece has also committed to long-term fiscal prudence with annual primary budget surplus targets (budget balance minus interest payments) of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter until 2060. As the quarterly reviews will be published (the most recent was released in June 2019), transgression by Greece could adversely affect market access. The debt-relief measures include a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). Greece will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for EUR130.9bn worth of loans), and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprises the official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of the return is estimated to be about EUR5bn in total in 2019-22.
In the short term Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing requirements, but it will need to have re-established itself in the debt markets before its cash buffer runs out. After a three-year absence Greece has tapped the financial markets five times since July 2017, most recently in early March 2019 with a well-subscribed ten-year issue, yielding 3.9%. The spread on the secondary market between Greek ten-year government bonds and equivalent German government bonds has narrowed steadily in recent months, to about 260 basis points in mid-July. However, any signs of tensions between the new government and its international creditors, for example over Greece's primary budget surplus targets (ND has suggested that they could be renegotiated lower to create fiscal room for tax cuts) or an increase in risk aversion in the global financial markets, could cause Greek yields to rise again sharply.
In the medium and long term, the political and-arguably-economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. In the past four years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, as will other negative factors such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short- or medium-term risk; however, given that Greece is unlikely to improve competitiveness in the euro zone or to grow its way out of its huge debt burden, Grexit will represent a possibility in the long term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
In 2018, after almost a decade of austerity, Greece recorded an overall budget surplus of 1.1% of GDP and a primary surplus of close to 4.5%, exceeding the bail-out programme target of 3.5%. From 2019, however, we expect fiscal performance to deteriorate gradually, with the budget balance returning to moderately widening headline deficits from 2020 and primary surpluses falling short of the official target of 3.5% of GDP for 2018-22, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint in 2019 ahead of elections and only moderate economic growth. There is also uncertainty about the application of the Council of State's ruling that previous pension and bonus cuts implemented in 2016 were unconstitutional, raising the risk of retroactive payments. Although the primary surplus target will decline to 2.2% of GDP from 2023, it will still be difficult to achieve.
The restructuring of government debt owed to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-18 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will still be about 175% at the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The ECB adopted an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy in response to the European sovereign debt crisis, bringing major policy interest rates down to zero or below; it also launched a EUR2.6trn quantitative easing (QE) programme in 2015, which it concluded in December 2018. Nevertheless, policy will remain ultra-loose in the 2019-23 forecast period, as the ECB will reinvest principal payments from maturing securities past the date on which it starts tightening. Euro zone inflationary pressures remain low, and there are pronounced downside risks to the euro zone's economic outlook. At its meeting on June 6th the ECB adopted a dovish stance, delaying the next rate rise from early 2020 until mid-2020 at the earliest. This was in line with our existing forecast; we expect the ECB to raise its deposit rate in June 2020 and the main refinancing rate in December 2020, with policy tightening proceeding thereafter at a gradual pace. The bank also announced that the interest rate on its third round of targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs-III) could go as low as -0.3%, to encourage lending. Should economic conditions worsen, for instance given an escalation in the US-China trade war or a "no-deal" Brexit (not our core forecast), we would expect the ECB to resume its QE programme or to cut rates again.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The Greek economy is recovering from a protracted slump, but the recovery is modest and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. As at 2018 real GDP was still more than 25% below pre-crisis levels; meanwhile government consumption remained almost a quarter lower, household consumption one-fifth lower and gross fixed investment almost two-thirds lower. Real GDP accelerated from 1.4% in 2017 to 1.9% in 2018, but the economy lost momentum in the final three months of last year, contracting by 0.1% on a quarter-on-quarter basis. We expect real GDP growth to remain constrained, at 1.8% in 2019 and 2020, and at an annual average of about 2.1% in 2021-23. The risks to our forecast are balanced: upside risks include continued strong tourism performance if capacity constraints are addressed and competitiveness gains are not eroded; downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector, and political and financial market instability.
A combination of more-and higher-taxes, larger social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts will continue to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2019-23, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by large primary surplus targets (of 3.5% of GDP per year up to 2022 and 2.2% in 2023), continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
Quarterly gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years, but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17, albeit from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by an average of 12% year on year in 2018. We expect a pick-up from this year, to an annual average of 5.2% in 2019-23. Underinvestment during the economic crisis and the depletion of Greece's capital stock are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively small, uncompetitive goods exports. In the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 4.6% in 2019-23, down from 8.7% in 2018. However, the Greek tourism sector faces considerable challenges, including the UK's planned departure from the EU, increased competition from Turkey and insufficient public investment.
How the economy performs in the next five years (and beyond) will determine whether the country remains in the euro zone. Although the risk of Grexit has abated since the height of the financial crisis, we believe that there is a risk that Greece will exit the euro zone in the long term, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Greece's exit from the euro zone (not our core scenario) would lead to a sovereign default and severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then recover, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack in the labour market, subdued domestic demand and sharp decreases in global oil prices in the final quarter of 2018 will dampen inflationary pressures. We expect inflation to rise modestly, from an average of 0.8% in 2018 to an annual average of 0.9% per year in 2019-20 and 1.5% per year in 2021-23 as domestic demand growth accelerates.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
The euro rallied in late 2017 on the back of the region's economic recovery and rising expectations of QE tapering. However, since peaking at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in February 2018, the euro has depreciated against the dollar, in part owing to monetary tightening in the US last year. Since the start of 2019 the euro has weakened further, hovering around US$1.12:EUR1-US$1.14:EUR1, as high-frequency data and soft indicators continue to disappoint market expectations and point to a weaker euro zone outlook. We expect the euro to remain broadly stable throughout the year, reflecting investors' concerns about Brexit and a further deterioration in US-EU trade relations. After averaging US$1.13:EUR1 in 2019, the euro should pick up more substantially in 2020, to US$1.18:EUR1, as these risks abate, momentum in the euro zone recovers and the ECB takes steps to tighten policy. The currency will rebound further in 2021-23, to US$1.23:EUR1, underpinned by the euro zone's large current-account surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The economic crisis helped to reduce Greece's current-account deficit, which shrank primarily as a result of a compression of imports due to contracting domestic demand, but also partly because of improved competitiveness, particularly in the tourism sector. We expect continued deficits in 2019-23 as import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand, and as global energy prices rise moderately in the second half of the forecast period. However, these deficits will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.1% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In June 2018, in the first round of a snap presidential election, Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected to a second term. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP).
Mr Erdogan's re-election concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan to remain in power until 2023, and probably beyond. The concentration of power under Mr Erdogan and his party's control of parliament suggest that policy will retain an element of unpredictability.
Domestic and regional political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional rather than strategic.
The currency crisis in 2018 pushed the Turkish economy into a recession in the second half of 2018, which we expect to have continued in the first quarter of 2019, resulting in a full-year real GDP contraction of 1.7% in 2019 on average (mainly owing to base effects), followed by annual average growth of 3.7% per year in 2020-23.
The currency crisis and recession will put pressure on the government's finances, business sector solvency and banks' balance sheets. In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy (concerns about off-balance sheet trends will persist). This, and a recovering economy, will cause the budget deficit to narrow, from a forecast 2.3% in 2019 to 1.7% of GDP in 2023.
The total population is projected to rise from 82.3m in 2018 to 86m in 2023, with the female population continuing to far outnumber the male population. The total population is expected to grow by 0.9% per year during the 2019-23 forecast period, compared with growth of 1.6% in the historical period (2014-18).
The large consumer market is one of Turkey's main attractions as a place to do business. The population is young, growing and inclined to consume rather than save, and average incomes are rising steadily in local-currency terms. We expect GDP per head to rise from US$9,285 at market exchange rates in 2018 to about US$11,631 in 2023.

Our business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period (2019-23), and its global ranking falls by 13 places, to 59th. Political tensions, increased powers concentrated under the president, inadequate policy responses to tighter global liquidity conditions and higher domestic inflation have raised the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals.
2021-23: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2021-23: Further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors boost FDI inflows.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls are not considered, despite the scale of the currency collapse in 2018-19. Political tensions resulting in tit-for-tat tariffs and US sanctions will disrupt Turkish-US trade and relations.
2021-23: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2019-20: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2021-23: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced, but evasion remains widespread.
Financing
2019-20: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018-19. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of US imposing fines or sanctions on some Turkish banks.
2021-23: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2019-20: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Mismatches between education and labour market needs persist.
2021-23: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2021-23: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2021-23: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 1949 and NATO in 1952, and signed an association agreement with the then European Community in 1963. A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election, a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate was raised from 20% to 22% in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports totalled US$175bn and imports about US$216bn, creating a trade deficit of about US$41.8bn and a current-account deficit in the region of US$27.1bn (or 3.5% of GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".
