Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In June 2018, in the first round of a snap presidential election, Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected to a second term. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair; opposition candidates received little or no media coverage, the pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party (HDP) candidate, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison, and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote after a high turnout. Results published by opposition observers were similar to those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. Demonstrating Mr Erdogan's determination to further augment and make use of his presidential powers, on July 6th he dismissed Murat Cetinkaya, the governor of the Central Bank of Turkey, and replaced him with one of the deputy governors, Murat Uysal. This contravenes the Central Bank Act, which gives the central bank a high level of independence.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023. However, Mr Erdogan and his AKP suffered a clear blow to their credibility when the opposition candidate, Ekrem Imamoglu, increased his margin of victory over Binali Yildirim of the ruling coalition in the Istanbul mayoral election rerun at end-June. Although this represents a major setback for Mr Erdogan, we expect him to keep a tight grip on national institutions and the media in order to continue his dominance of Turkish politics in the coming years.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. The fact that the ruling coalition is made up of the AKP and the MHP will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the nationalist-minded MHP is pushing for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held in June 2018 (they had originally been scheduled for late 2019). Mr Erdogan was re-elected president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote on a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP), as the HDP managed to win more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament.
Local elections took place in March 2019. The AKP and the MHP retained a majority of the national vote. However, in the midst of an economic recession, the ruling parties lost vital cities such as Ankara, the capital, and Istanbul, the largest city. Given the public resources that major cities command, Mr Erdogan and the AKP put huge pressure on the Supreme Election Council (YSK) to annul the Istanbul election result. But although the YSK ordered a rerun of the mayoral election, the opposition candidate won with 54% of the vote on June 23rd.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional rather than strategic. We do not expect a collapse in relations, but this forecast is highly uncertain. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran; and US sanctions on Turkish officials following Turkey's detention of Andrew Brunson, a US pastor, on terrorism charges (sanctions were lifted after Mr Brunson was released in October 2018). In 2019 relations with the US will continue to be tested owing to Turkey's decision to purchase the Russian-made S-400 missile defence system. The US and NATO believe that the S-400 system can gather sensitive information on NATO equipment, and in particular the F-35 stealth fighter jet. The incompatibility of the S-400 with NATO systems is a further issue.
So far Turkey has not bowed to US pressure to cancel the missiles purchase, and Russia began delivering the first parts of the S-400 missile defence system to Turkey in the week of July 8th. Although Turkey believes that this is a sovereign issue, backing down would also negative affect Turkey's relations with Russia, a significant ally of neighbouring Syria. Russia props up the regime of Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president, and maintains a large military presence in the country. A deterioration in relations could therefore jeopardise Turkey's control of the border region, from the Mediterranean to the Euphrates River-territory that was gained to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK along the border. It could also limit Turkey's influence in Idlib, in northern Syria, which is controlled by Islamist rebel groups. In September 2018 Turkey, Russia and Iran reached an agreement to forestall a regime offensive against Idlib. Such an attack could result in another surge of refugee flows into Turkey.
In the near term we expect the US to hold back on major sectoral sanctions under the US Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act (CAATSA), which targets countries buying military equipment from Russia, for fear of pushing Turkey towards Russia and Iran. Recent statements from Lindsey Graham, a senator of the US Republican Party, member of the caucus on US-Turkey relations and main ally of Donald Trump, the US president, suggest that the country will only incur sanctions if Turkey activates the S-400 missile defence system (expected in October 2019). However, Turkey is likely to discontinue its participation in the F-35 programme (Turkey has ordered F-35s and is a participant in the construction programme, providing key elements), which would cause delays; the cancellation of the F-35s' delivery would represent a setback for Turkey.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised banking sector and its dynamic and diversified private sector. We expect the currency crisis in 2018 and the ensuing recession to put severe pressure on the government's finances, business sector solvency and banks' balance sheets.
With the 2019 local elections having past, and as the next parliamentary and presidential elections are not due until mid-2023, the government is in a position to defuse domestic political tensions and take a more long-term approach to policymaking. This would help to revive investor confidence and foster sustainable economic growth, reversing the pattern of the past three years of ad hoc policy measures, which boosted the economy but exacerbated Turkey's macroeconomic imbalances and diminished the government's credibility. However, an element of unpredictability and unorthodoxy will remain. The economy is in recession and, following its recent poor performance in local elections, the AKP will continue to feel pressure to support growth. Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches (a major factor behind the high unemployment rate) and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed in the 2019-23 forecast period. The removal of Mr Cetinkaya will add to the unpredictability of Turkey's policies, damaging financial market sentiment.
Should the recent currency crisis trigger a banking crisis (not our core forecast), Turkey's options would remain limited. Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries appear unwilling to offer financial support because Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, which has tense relations with Saudi Arabia. Furthermore, any potential IMF programme would include a level of foreign involvement that the government would be likely to view as unacceptable given Mr Erdogan's nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric. Only China appears able at present to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey (perhaps as part of China's Belt and Road Initiative).
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Under the AKP, the public finances have been one of the Turkish economy's most reassuring aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past.
Despite several tax increases in 2018 and official promises of budgetary tightening, higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits caused the budget deficit to widen in 2018, to 2% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017.
In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy (concerns about off-balance-sheet trends will persist). This, alongside a recovering economy, will cause the deficit to narrow gradually, from a forecast 2.3% of GDP in 2019 to 1.7% in 2023.
The central government debt/GDP ratio deteriorated slightly in 2018, rising to 28.9% of GDP in 2018 (from 28.3% in 2017), in the context of economic turmoil after the August currency crisis and various government handouts ahead of the June 2018 elections. The ratio will decline slightly, to about 26.6% by end-2023, as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
In September 2018 the Central Bank of Turkey's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) raised its main policy rate, the one-week repo (repurchase agreement) lending rate, to 24%, from 17.75% previously. The MPC's decision was a response to the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August, and the ensuing record rise in annual consumer price inflation. Subsequently, the lira staged an uneven recovery, and inflation fell to 15.7% at end-June, while economic performance remained weak. The bank has yet to start reducing rates-although it introduced a lower rate of 23% for limited amounts of lending to market-maker banks on June 17th.
We expect rate cuts totalling 3-5 percentage points in July-December, provided that further currency shocks occur and inflation continues to relent. The more dovish stance of the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) and major risks of cuts support our view. In 2021-23 we believe that the central bank will continue to overshoot its inflation target of 5% owing to the government's continued pro-growth stance, putting pressure on the central bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to reach its inflation target.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand caused real GDP growth to accelerate to 7.3% in 2017 (from 3.3% in 2016), but this surge exacerbated internal and external imbalances. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the central bank's independence, reliance on short-term capital inflows, tighter global liquidity and a diplomatic spat with the US-contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar in January-August 2018. The depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of large foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dented the economic outlook. The crisis pushed the Turkish economy into recession in the second half of 2018, which continued in the first months of 2019. As a result, we expect a 1.7% contraction in real GDP in 2019 on average (mainly owing to base effects), followed by annual average growth of 3.7% per year in 2020-23.
In 2020 we expect growth to rebound to 4.1% as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-23 economic growth will average about 3.6% per year. There are substantial downside risks to our forecasts: these growth profiles do not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
In 2018 the currency crisis and rising global commodity prices drove inflation higher, to 16.3% (from 11.1% in 2017). In 2019 inflation will remain elevated in the first half of the year and then moderate gradually in the second half, on the back of positive baseline effects, the appreciation of the lira, a lower average global oil price, continuing subdued consumer demand and the emergence of spare capacity in the economy. Accommodative fiscal policies in response to the economic weakness in the final months of 2019 will prevent inflation from declining faster than would otherwise be the case. On average, we forecast inflation of 16.1% in 2019-only marginally slower than in 2018.
We expect inflation to decelerate rapidly in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 10.2% as global oil prices continue to decline (owing to a slowdown in the global economy) and the exchange rate depreciates slightly (in nominal terms) against the US dollar. In 2021-23 we expect inflation to stabilise at an annual average of about 7.2%-still more than the central bank's medium-term target of 5%. Economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures).
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2018 the lira depreciated by 24.4% on average against the US dollar (in nominal terms). The lira depreciated significantly in January-August, with the exchange rate briefly reaching a low point of TL7.2:US$1 on August 13th. After a substantial recovery from September, the lira remained broadly stable against the US dollar for the remainder of 2018. In March-May 2019 the lira again depreciated against the US dollar owing to political uncertainty and polarising campaign rhetoric around the March local elections, declining central bank foreign-exchange reserves, the re-emergence of tensions with the US and the rerun of the Istanbul mayoral race following the AKP's defeat.
The lira again surpassed TL6:US$1 in early May but started appreciating again in June. We expect the lira to oscillate around its level of about TL5.70:US$1 throughout the second half of the year. This forecast rests on our expectation that the Turkey-US dispute will not result in damaging sectoral sanctions but rather only in individual sanctions at most, that government policy will be credibly reoriented, and that the central bank will lower interest rates only as price pressures fade. There are high risks to this forecast, both in terms of probability and impact. If any of our expectations do not materialise, the lira could again depreciate substantially.
In 2020 we expect the exchange rate to depreciate in line with a widening of the current-account deficit. Thereafter still elevated inflation and a significant current-account deficit (although smaller than in 2017) will result in a gradual depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in nominal terms, to near TL6.4:US$1 by end-2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
We expect the current-account deficit to narrow as a share of GDP in 2019, to 0.7% (a 16-year low), from 3.5% in 2018 and 5.6% in 2017, as the lira's depreciation against the US dollar and the euro depresses imports (owing to a decline in domestic demand) and boosts export competitiveness. From 2020 we expect the deficit to widen gradually, to a still relatively moderate 3.3% per year on average in 2020-23. The narrower deficits compared with historical levels reflect significant gains in competitiveness from the 2018-19 currency crisis that will boost exports and limit import growth throughout the medium term.

Full text: Brazil--highlights: Political outlook
The right-wing government of president Jair Bolsonaro lacks a majority in Brazil's highly fragmented Congress (featuring 30 parties in the lower house) and does not intend to build a formal coalition of parties as is customary. Negotiations with Congress will prove challenging, but will advance where there is a common agenda with centrist parties, such as on pension reform and tax simplification. Mr Bolsonaro's conservative social and law and order reforms will experience pushback, sustaining tensions with the legislature. His government is also subject to internal tensions owing to the fight for power between an ideological wing and a number of more pragmatic former military officials appointed to the cabinet.

The last government improved the business environment during 2016-18, and the Bolsonaro government will also bring advances in 2019-23, particularly in foreign trade (lower barriers and a EU-Mercosul FTA deal); policy towards foreign investment and private enterprise; and competition, owing to privatisations and more certain rules of the game. Brazil's large economy is attractive. But poor government effectiveness, a burdensome tax system (despite good prospects for some simplification), rickety infra-structure (notwithstanding improvements through concessions), deficiencies in factor markets and skills shortages will continue to impair business. Pension reform will buoy the public finances and help keep interest rates and inflation lower than before, bolstering macroeconomic stability.

The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the tepid recovery in 2017-19 from Brazil's brutal 2014-16 recession to gather momentum in 2020-23 aided by confidence-boosting pension and tax reforms and more business-friendly policies. Fiscal consolidation will halt the rise in the public debt/GDP ratio and will allow for lower interest rates and inflation, boosting private credit. However, absent the fiscal driver, GDP growth will be more reliant on the private sector. High unemployment will dampen consumption. Investment will recover somewhat, helped by infrastructure concessions and privatisations. The current-account deficit will widen but the external sector will pose few risks, buoyed by a large reserves cushion.

The rate of population growth will fall to 0.6% in 2019-23. But this growth rate will remain above the world average and well above Western European rates. The population will remain younger than in most industrialised countries, and the rise in the number of people of working age will outpace population growth as a whole. However, in the longer term, Brazil's demographic dynamics will deteriorate, heightening pressure on the pension system.

Brazil is Latin America's largest market, the world's fifth-most populous country and the eight -largest economy, offering huge investment opportunities. But GDP growth and loans to households will be weaker in the forecast period than during the boom in 2004-10, softening income gains and private consumption. Deepening capital markets will boost credit availability for businesses. It will be difficult to replicate the gains achieved in the decade preceding the 2014-16 recession in reducing income inequality, (reflecting job creation in low-skilled sectors, rises in the minimum wage and cash transfer programmes), in an environment of tepid GDP growth and fiscal constraints.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Our long-term growth forecast anticipates annual average GDP growth to 2050 of 1.9%. Improvements in infrastructure and education, trade expansion, a broader presence of multinational business, and the development of huge oil reserves will mitigate slower labour force growth and help to sustain labour productivity growth. If improvements in policymaking and the business environment were to exceed expectations, growth rates would be higher. For many years, performance will continue to fluctuate with commodity cycles, as agriculture and natural resource extraction continue to play an important role in the economy. Climate change will crimp agricultural growth, despite technological advances to make crops resistant to warmer temperatures.

Background: A new constitution was ratified in 1988 after more than 20 years of military rule. The government of Fernando Henrique Cardoso (1995-2002) ended hyperinflation and advanced reforms to liberalise the economy. Under Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (2003-10), Brazil reaped the benefits of the reforms and enjoyed a consumer-led, commodities-fuelled boom. When this cycle ended, discontent over a weak economy, corruption and poor public services led to street protests. Dilma Rousseff (2011-16) nonetheless won a second four-year term in 2014, but was impeached in 2016 over budget irregularities. Her vice-president, Michel Temer, finished her term (December 2018). Jair Bolsonaro, of the right-wing Partido Social Liberal, won the October 2018 presidential election and took office in January 2019.
Political structure: The president executes policy approved by the 513-seat Chamber of Deputies (the lower house) and the 81-seat Senate (the upper house). Constitutional review is conducted by an independent judiciary. Although the president can resort to temporary decrees to push through legislation, the constitution gives Congress ample scope to frustrate the executive. Thirty political parties are represented in the lower house, and party discipline has traditionally been weak.
Policy issues: Brazil's 1988 constitution established benefits and entitlements that have contributed to a doubling in central government spending since then, to over 20% of GDP. Congress has approved a federal spending cap and is expected to approve complementary social security reforms to stop the rise in the public debt/GDP ratio (nearly 80% currently) caused by undisciplined fiscal policies and the impact of economic recession under the administration of Ms Rousseff. The Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) cut the Selic policy rate from 14.25% in October 2016 to 6.5% in March 2018. The new Bolsonaro administration espouses free-market economic policies and privatisations.
Taxation: Brazil has a poorly structured revenue system, characterised by a heavy tax burden, a narrow tax base, complicated levies and widespread evasion. Both foreign and domestic companies employ tax professionals and devote considerable resources to managing their tax affairs. The corporate and indirect taxation systems are particularly complex, porous and unwieldy; the income tax system is considered to be relatively efficient, with a top rate of 27.5%.
Foreign trade: Recession and a weaker currency have led to import compression, supporting trade surpluses in recent years. The current-account deficit was 0.8% of GDP in 2018, which is modest.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Brazil is a federal republic, composed of 26 states and the capital district of Brasília, each with its own legislature and administration. Jair Bolsonaro of the right-wing Partido Social Liberal (PSL) took office in January 2018 for a four-year team after winning the October 2018 elections. In a break from the past, he is trying to govern without a formal, multi-party coalition and picked few party politicians for his reduced cabinet, which features a sprinkling of retired military officers. This poses governability risks given that Congress is highly fragmented (30 parties in the lower house) and that the ruling PSL only has 10% of the seats in the lower house. Mr Bolsonaro is seeking cross-party support for his socially conservative and liberal economic policy agenda. There is some support for his government's liberal economic policies from centrist parties that have formed a bloc, known as the Centrão, which wields considerable influence. But there is limited support for the rest of his agenda from centrist parties, including on conservative social policies and law and order, where he espouses a relaxation in gun control. Left-leaning parties in opposition to the government on both social and economic issues, have under 30% of the lower house seats.
Next elections: Presidential, congressional and state elections (every four years) are due in October 2022. Municipal elections will be held in October 2020.

Political outlook: Political stability
The president, Jair Bolsonaro of the right-wing Partido Social Liberal (PSL), who began office with a strong mandate, will face similar governability problems that have plagued previous administrations. With 30 parties represented, Congress will prove as unwieldy as ever, and on top of this Mr Bolsonaro will face challenges keeping the disparate factions of his own political movement together. The president has had a tumultuous first six months in office amid political infighting, strained relations with parties in Congress (even those allied with his economic agenda) and still-weak economic performance. His popularity has declined sharply-a poll by local polling firm Ibope put his approval ratings at only 32% in late June. He has nonetheless taken some pragmatic steps to try to bolster governability as Congress debates a pension bill, which is a key part of his agenda of liberal economic reforms. The pension legislation is currently being reviewed by a special commission in the Chamber of Deputies (the lower house). The Economist Intelligence Unit attaches a 75% probability that a version of the reform that will satisfy markets' view of Brazil's creditworthiness will be approved by October. The main risks to this assumption are political and surrounds the possibility of delays amid simmering tensions between the executive and Congress.
Mr Bolsonaro remains broadly reluctant to negotiate with the myriad parties in Congress as he continues his anti-establishment campaign rhetoric, criticising the "old-style politics" under which deals between Congress and the executive often involved patronage, "pork-barrel" politics and horse-trading that contributed to pervasive corruption. This has antagonised many parties in Congress, who have dealt the government legislative defeats on some minor bills. Faced with their congressional resistance, Mr Bolsonaro met with party leaders in April and it seems he may well, after all, offer some posts to their members in the state apparatus. The government is also likely to offer legislators additional funds for pet projects in their constituencies. In another pragmatic move, which bodes well for governability, in late May Mr Bolsonaro met with Rodrigo Maia (Democratas), the leader of the lower house (and therefore a key ally for Mr Bolsonaro's reform agenda) and the leader of the Senate (the upper house), Davi Alcolumbre, as well as the Supreme Court president, Dias Toffoli, to discuss a governability pact to advance a common reform agenda.
However, the potential for political infighting and tensions with most political parties to spill over and block reforms persists in the short term. Not only is Mr Bolsonaro himself an impulsive figure, he also faces challenges in managing strains between different groups vying for power in the government that he has assembled. These include his sons Flavio (a senator), Eduardo (a deputy) and Carlos (a local councillor, who is active on social media), who, together with PSL legislators in Congress, are pushing a right-wing ideological and socially conservative agenda. Another group comprises the economic team, led by Paulo Guedes, which espouses an ambitious structural reform and liberalisation agenda; and a third involves a handful of military figures in government, including the vice-president, who are playing a moderating role in foreign affairs and national security issues and see more of a role for state intervention in the economy.
Mr Bolsonaro's PSL and the leftist Partido dos Trabalhadores (PT), which governed Brazil between 2003 and 2016, are the biggest parties in Congress, but with only around 10% of seats each in the lower house. Tension between the political right and left will be a feature of Mr Bolsonaro's term. However, common ground on economic policies with centrist parties will provide opportunities to advance economic reforms. Mr Bolsonaro's aloofness towards Congress and party leaders carries risks to governability; the president will only be effective if he remains popular enough with voters to retain congressional support for his reform agenda. Furthermore, there is a low risk that he may not finish his term in office-some legislators are even starting to call for his impeachment-although we assume that he will complete his term despite the political noise as there wouldn't be enough congressional support to start the process.
We assume that the president will be able to count on cross-party backing from three leading groups represented in Congress, known locally as the "bancada BBB" (the bala, boi, biblia-bullet, beef and bible-caucus), which includes law-and-order conservatives, socially conservative evangelical Christians (a large demographic) and agriculture-sector interests (who want to expand the production frontier). However, it will still be challenging to reach the three-fifths majority needed for constitutional amendments, such as will be required for pension reforms and tax simplification. Nor can he count on their support for all of his policies. Vested interests are pervasive in Congress, and many will resist privatisation, efforts to reduce tax breaks and subsidies for businesses, and measures affecting public-sector workers. On this basis we expect pension reform approval and tax simplification thereafter, as well as piecemeal progress on other pro-growth reforms.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Mr Bolsonaro faces governability problems similar to those that have plagued previous administrations. With 30 parties represented, Congress will prove as unwieldy as ever, and, on top of this, Mr Bolsonaro will face challenges keeping the disparate factions of his own political movement together. This is composed of an ideological right-wing group revolving around his three politically active sons, the president himself and the foreign minister; a military wing playing a moderating role in national security and public affairs, led by the vice-president, Hamilton Mourão, and the economic team revolving around Paulo Guedes and his radical, free-market agenda. Mr Bolsonaro remains reluctant to negotiate with the myriad parties in Congress as he continues his anti-establishment campaign rhetoric, criticising the "old-style politics" under which deals between Congress and the executive often involved patronage, and "give and take" horse-trading that contributed to pervasive corruption. But having been a legislator for nearly 30 years before coming to office, the president knows what makes them tick and he has a pragmatic side that will allow him to curry favour at important times (such as voting on pension reform) by offering legislators special budget allocations for pet projects in their constituencies-just the sort of "pork barrel" politics that he regularly criticises.
Mr Bolsonaro's nationalist populism, nostalgia for Brazil's military dictatorship (1964-85) and his cabinet appointments of several retired military officials sustain concerns in some quarters over whether he would potentially trample over Brazil's fairly young democratic institutions. This seems highly unlikely, but a drift towards authoritarianism cannot be entirely ruled out, particularly if Congress unexpectedly blocks his government agenda completely. Voters broadly support democracy (even though they are disillusioned by the record of parties in power) and would not acquiesce in the event of an unexpected shift to military rule, reducing the probability of such a scenario. Neither does the top military brass show any signs of wanting to overthrow the constitution and govern the country.
Political and institutional weakness persist
During 2015-18 three developments highlighted political and institutional weaknesses that continue to shape politics: a deep and wide-ranging corruption scandal; the impeachment of Ms Rousseff; and subsequent corruption investigations into her successor, Mr Temer. However, Brazil's institutions have held up well and constitutional order has been maintained. These developments generated a serious setback to confidence in Brazil's political system and helped to catapult Mr Bolsonaro to the presidency. Many of the issues remain unresolved and absent political reform (to reduce drastically the number of parties represented in Congress), there is little prospect of a meaningful "renewal", even though nearly 50% of the legislators elected to the lower house in October 2018 are freshmen. However, the decisive action and independence of the judiciary is a sign that Brazil is beginning to tackle endemic corruption. Companies, including Petrobras, are strengthening corporate governance mechanisms, which is positive.
Governments hampered by party fragmentation and weak coalitions
A key problem related both to government effectiveness and to corruption is the deep fragmentation of Congress, which encourages "pork barrel" politics. Since democracy was restored to Brazil in 1985 governments have struggled to hold together multi-party coalitions. Low voter-registration thresholds have contributed to a large number of parties (around 30 parties are represented in Congress), and their leaders behave opportunistically.
This dysfunctional system has become known as "presidential coalition" politics. Since 1985 two of the five directly elected presidents have been impeached by Congress-undermining the presidency and reflecting the powers of the legislature. To hold together a working majority, governments in the past have resorted to a range of legal but politically dubious pork barrel behaviours, such as offering ministerial positions, awarding spending programmes and constantly adjusting and diluting their legislative programmes to meet the demands of smaller parties and regional special interest groups. The other main course of action has been the use of illegal bribery schemes, effectively to buy votes in Congress and enforce the necessary coalition loyalty.
Major corruption schemes discredit the political system
Since 2003 several major corruption schemes have come to light. The so-called Petrolão scandal emerged in 2014, unearthed by a task force of pro-active federal prosecutors based in Curitiba who spearheaded the so-called "carwash" investigations. It involved private contractors, including some of Brazil's top construction companies, which formed illegal cartels to manipulate the allocation of multi-billion-dollar contracts with Petrobras, the state oil firm; a proportion of these unfairly secured contracts (usually 3%) was then paid out as illegal political party campaign contributions. The revelation in 2017 that Joesley Batista, the then chairman of the board of JBS, Brazil's largest meatpacking firm, was involved in widespread corruption with politicians suggests that the irregularities were more widespread. The scandal implicated Mr Temer and the federal prosecution sought to open a trial against the president, but his allies in Congress twice voted against stripping him of his presidential immunity from prosecution and blocked a trial. Most of the political establishment has been implicated in these corruption scandals, including not just the PT and the MDB, which was part of the ruling alliance with the PT for many years, but also members of the PSDB, including its losing candidate in the presidential race in 2014, Aécio Neves. In a landmark ruling, a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, (2003-10), was jailed for 12 years in April 2018 on a corruption conviction. Under the Bolsonaro administration, the tourism minister, Marcelo Álvaro Antônio (PSL), is being investigated for campaign finance irregularities by the police (he denies the charges). Leaked messages that surfaced in June 2019 raise questions about the impartiality of Sérgio Moro (who is now the minister of justice) when he was the judge in the "carwash" investigations, including that of Lula and others. The leaks suggest that he advised state prosecutors how to make the case against politicians, notably Lula.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next elections (for municipal posts) are scheduled for October 2020. As is customary in Brazilian politics, this gives the incoming government just one year to pass bold reforms, such as pension and tax reforms, before legislators become wary of passing controversial measures. The munici-pal elections will serve as a barometer for sentiment towards the new right-wing government. Should the economy pick up as forecast, Mr Bolsonaro would be in a reasonable position to run for re-election in 2022, but his controversial ideological views and poor leadership skills would probably prove a huge handicap for his chances. Rivals on the left will include Ciro Gomes (of the Partido Democrático Trabalhista) and possibly Fernando Haddad (PT). It is currently uncertain whether a competitive centrist candidate will emerge, who could prevent Mr Bolsonaro from making it to a second round (this would then pit Mr Bolsonaro against a leftist, in a repeat of the 2018 elections). The Partido da Social Democracia Brasileira, traditionally the larger of the centrist parties, will struggle to regroup; João Doria, the governor of São Paulo state, hopes to lead the party.
Political outlook: International relations
Under the anti-globalist foreign minister, Ernesto Araújo, Mr Bolsonaro's presidency heralds changes in foreign policy that will have ripple effects across the region. It is being formulated as an antithesis to that of the PT governments of 2003-16, which curried favour with ideologically aligned, leftist governments in the region (including Cuba and Venezuela) and sought to gain geopolitical prominence through "South-South" co-operation among developing nations. Instead, policy will be more pro-Western, and, in particular, more closely aligned with the US. This was evident during Mr Bolsonaro's state visit to the US in March, when the US president, Donald Trump, pledged to support Brazil's membership of the OECD and make Brazil a major non-NATO ally. Mr Bolsonaro gave some trade concessions, but made few tangible gains on the trade front in return. Brazil's government now joins a group of other right-leaning administrations in the region-including Argentina, Colombia and Chile. A deal between the EU and Mercosur was announced at end-June, but ratification by EU governments will be a long process. The extent to which Mr Bolsonaro will cool Chinese investments in strategic energy and infrastructure areas (as he signalled he would during his campaign) remains uncertain. Any measures that could imperil Brazil's agro-exports to China would lead to pushback from the rural lobby that supports Mr Bolsonaro; moreover, his infrastructure concession and privatisation programme needs Chinese investment. Mr Bolsonaro sided with the US and other governments in no longer recognising Nicolás Maduro as the legitimate president in Venezuela. Despite the potential for a more hostile US-led approach to Venezuela, major Brazilian military intervention is unlikely, given that the military power group in government are opposed.

Brazil remains in the lower half of the business environment global ranking in the forecast period. Despite improvements in the overall score, Brazil slips in the global and regional rankings as other countries advance faster. Several categories register improvements over the forecast period, reflecting the Bolsonaro administration's liberal economic agenda, notably foreign trade and exchange controls (lower trade barriers), policy towards foreign investment and policy towards private enterprise (thanks to privatisation). There will be improvements in the labour market (greater flexibility) and infrastructure (through concessions and better rules of the game), although these will remain weaknesses.
More orthodox, market-oriented policies will help the recovery from crisis
After years of protectionism, the government intends to reduce trade barriers, with cuts in capital good and technology imports likely. Moreover, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the EU-Mercosul FTA deal announced in June 2019 to come into force later in the forecast period, potentially also encouraging other countries to engage Mercosul so as not to lose out to European companies. Brazil's large and diversified economy makes it attractive for investors and a resumption of growth after the brutal 2014-16 recession-albeit at modest rates of little above 2% in 2020-23-provides a boost. Brazil lost its investment-grade rating in 2015 and is unlikely to regain it for some time. Probable pension reform later this year will help curb the deterioration in fiscal and debt dynamics, but public debt/GDP will peak at a high level (nearly 85%). The political environment will remain another weakness, given a fragmented Congress. While the leftist opposition is weak and in a minority, powerful centrist parties are aligned with some aspects of the government's agenda, notably pension reform to bolster the public finances, and tax simplification, but are likely to resist some of the more radical, free-market measures espoused by Mr Bolsonaro's economy minister, Paulo Guedes. Corruption remains problematic, although companies are strengthening governance.

Business environment outlook: Brazil's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Supreme Court confirms that state-owned subsidiaries do not require legislative approval (only parent companies), facilitating ambitious privatisation agenda. Privatisation of Eletrobras (energy) is likely in 2020.
2021-23: Fiscal pressures open more room for private capital in infrastructure projects. Investment Partnerships Programme (PPI) advances with improved legal framework and regulatory agencies. Petrobras to relinquish control over natural gas market by 2021.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Foreign direct investment (FDI) boosted by PPI. Oil and gas attracts two thirds of FDI owing to huge pre-salt auction.
2021-23: Brazil's entry into the OECD boosts foreign investment. Yet, ideological issues within Bolsonaro's government put nationalist politics ahead of economic pragmatism in certain situations.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Despite anti-globalisation moves in advanced economies, some bilateral and regional trade negotiations advance.
2021-23: Steps to make the Brazilian Real a fully convertible currency. Ratification of EU-Mercosul FTA boosts market access.
Taxes
2019-20: The government's liberal orientation precludes fiscal adjustment via tax increases. But taxation on distributed profits and dividends is likely, if Congress approves the executive's proposals for corporate income tax cuts.
2021-23: Revenue-neutral tax simplification likely, unifying up to five taxes (federal, state and municipal) into one single value-added tax. Possible proposals, such as raising the individual income tax threshold and a financial transactions tax, are unlikely.
Financing
2019-20: Financial system to remain strong and liquid. The Banco Central do Brasil's (BCB, the central bank) microeconomic reform "BC+ Agenda" improves banking efficiency and competitiveness, reducing borrowing costs. Monetary easing and low inflation support a gradual rise in lending.
2021-23: Renewed growth in domestic equity and bond issuance as state banks dial back subsidised credit lines.
The labour market
2019-20: Unemployment remains high. Government implements additional measures to reduce the cost of labour.
2021-23: Steps to boost long-run labour productivity complicated by weaker education policies.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Infrastructure concessions to advance (through the PPI), but political and institutional constraints may cause delays.
2021-23: Incumbent construction companies hurt by corruption and recession leave greater room for newcomers, but their lack of experience causes project delays.
Technological readiness
2019-20: 5G frequencies auction held in March 2020. Quality of communication services improves as demand expands.
2021-23: Building of 5G infrastructure network to commence, but roll-out to consumers will be slow.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.1 6.1 63 65 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's performance will be weaker than that of other South American commodity exporters such as Chile, Peru and Colombia in the forecast period. Brazil´s recovery from a deep 2015-16 recession stumbled in 2018 amid electoral uncertainty and in January-June 2019 over pension reform approval.
Our baseline economic policy scenario-approval of a fiscally robust pension reform by October 2019-is subject to risks. This would pave the way for other productivity-enhancing reforms such as tax simplification and privatisation. Failure to approve pension reform would trigger a market sell-off over debt-sustainability concerns and take Brazil back into recession.
Fiscal consolidation means that the private sector will have to drive growth. Spare capacity, a weak labour market, and tepid international conditions are obstacles for renewed private investment, but infrastructure concessions and privatisations should provide a stimulus. Fiscal consolidation and fewer distortions in credit markets as the role of public banks is dialled back will contribute to lower interest rates and inflation than in the past. This should stimulate household credit and support business lending via a deepening of the local capital markets. Even so, Brazil's low savings rate means that the economy remains dependent on capital inflows for growth. FDI should perform reasonably well given the still-large market opportunities; portfolio flows will suffer from the global and US slowdown in 2020.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.3 6.8 35 33 2 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
We expect improvements in policy towards private enterprise and competition, particularly with privatisations later in the forecast period. Economic and political factors are much better aligned now to favour privatisation than in the past. The fragile finances of many state companies (partly because of corruption) have increased support for liberal economic solutions, where privatisation is a key element. Many important sectors still face some degree of monopoly power from major state players, like oil and gas (Petrobras), energy (Eletrobras), post services and distribution (Correios) and, to a lesser degree, banking (Banco do Brasil, Caixa and BNDES). Even though broader privatisation of most of these state giants is unlikely, the selling of part of their assets and subsidiaries should advance. However, the highly liberal orientation coming from the Ministry of Economy under Paulo Guedes tends to run counter to other less market-friendly ministries and institutions, such as the executive bureaus run by former military officials (including the president), the Congress and sometimes even the Supreme Court.
Political and institutional constraints are the greatest source of risk for the evolution of the privatisation agenda. Government efforts will be focused on pension reform to the extent that the rest of its privatisation agenda will take a back seat until approval is attained. In this sense, the selling of state companies should be stronger in the second half of the forecast period.
Differing views between the Ministry of Economy and former military officials in executive posts, such as at the Ministry of Infrastructure, and Mining and Energy, may hinder the privatisation impetus of some state companies. Former military officials, including the president to some extent, still prefer national ownership of infrastructure assets. This means that many firms and agencies will be restructured to improve governance, rather than being divested.
Legislators view state-owned companies as an opportunity to exchange political support for lucrative posts. As Mr Bolsonaro has promised to refrain from "give and take" politics (and privatisation of parent companies still requires congressional approval), legislators may resist divestments to keep some power.
Another obstacle to privatisation is that the Supreme Court (STF) is a source of legal insecurity. Changes in interpretation of laws and injunctions by judges are common. The STF has shown an increasingly active role in arbitrating disputes involving the sale of state-owned enterprises. For example, the announced sale in April 2019 of TAG, a gas distributor and Petrobras subsidiary, to an international consortium, was initially suspended by one of the STF's 11 judges, but then went ahead after the plenary made a ruling in June stating that the executive could sell state-owned subsidiaries (but not parent companies) without legislative approval and without bidding-in a boost to privatisation.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.3 7.8 30 27 3 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil ranks as one of the top 10 recipients of FDI globally and its score and global ranking improve. The government's pro-market orientation and the fiscal and governance crisis that have affected many local companies since 2014 create opportunities for higher participation of foreign capital in sectors such as transportation, logistics, power generation, sanitation, construction and housing, oil and gas, renewable energy and the airline industry. Brazil's probable entry into the OECD later in the forecast period will boost FDI.
Infrastructure concessions offer attractive opportunities
Recent successful infrastructure concessions examples include (i) the latest pre-salt auction held in September 2018, which attracted many foreign players, now that tenders for areas no longer require that Petrobras take a minimum 30% share (this delayed auctions as it did not have the capital)-rather, it now has an option to do so; (ii) the concession of 12 airports in three regional blocks in March 2019, which attracted national and international players in a very competitive bid and (iii) the sale of Embraer's commercial branch to Boeing. Moreover, the regulatory and legal framework has been continuously adapted to allow for a higher share of foreign funding in such assets. In mid-2019 Congress approved a presidential decree authorising aviation companies with headquarters in Brazil to have unlimited participation of foreign capital (previously limited to 20%).
Foreign investors are guaranteed national treatment by law, but restrictions apply to activities involving nuclear energy, mail and telegraph services (except parcel delivery), some aerospace activities (such as launching and deployment of satellites), acquisition or rental of rural property, media (including television networks, magazines, newspapers and radio broadcasting stations) and mining.
There is a risk that ideological factors will obstruct FDI from some countries. Mr Bolsonaro and some of his core supporters are more inclined to establish alliances with advanced western countries run by right-wing parties (like the US and some European countries) rather than countries under left-wing governments (like Mexico or China). During his election campaign, Mr Bolsonaro suggested some pushback in reference to the acquisition of energy assets, stating that, "The Chinese are not buying in Brazil, they are buying Brazil." It remains to be seen whether or not Mr Bolsonaro puts aside these ideological views in favour of economic pragmatism.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.3 7.8 51 47 6 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's score and rankings improve. The liberal agenda espoused by Mr Guedes involves opening the economy (exports and imports amount to 24% of GDP-Brazil is quite closed), removing or lowering existing barriers to imports, recovering the strategic importance of Mercosul (a customs union comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) as a regional trading bloc and making the Brazilian Real fully convertible. We expect the landmark EU-Mercosul free-trade agreement (FTA) struck in June 2019 to be ratified by governments later in the forecast period. The deal may well encourage other countries to seek a deal with Mercosur so as not to lose market share to EU countries, including South Korea and Japan. But anti-globalisation movements in the developed world could pose some limits to FTAs between countries and regional blocs. Mr Bolsonaro's preference for dealing with countries whose leaders share his ideological beliefs rather than those with which Brazil has long-term diplomatic ties may hamper the country's future strategic trade efforts.
The conclusion of the EU-Mercosul FTA deal, after 20 years of on-off negotiation, sends a positive signal to investors and has significant economic upside for both blocs. It brings together a combined population of 780m people in an agreement that will eliminate nearly 100% of EU tariffs and 90% of Mercosur tariffs, assuming that a signed deal is ratified by all Mercosur and EU member parliaments. The ratification process will be politically complicated (resistance from farmers and environmental groups in countries like France pose a risk), and the FTA will probably not come into effect until 2021 at the earliest. For Brazil (and Argentina) this will provide time for much needed economic reforms to boost competitiveness of the manufacturing and services sectors, which will now take centre stage on the reform agenda. South America's agro-industry has competitive advantages and will be a winner of greater EU market access.
While the Brazilian Real is not fully convertible, the country has no major restrictions on current and capital-account flows or on foreign exchange transactions. The solid international reserves position (about US$380bn, 19% of GDP), combined with a favourable balance of payments (the capital account fully finances the current-account deficit) shields Brazil from potential currency pressures. Policymakers have signalled they want to make the Real a convertible currency and turn it into a regional reference currency. We expect some steps in this direction once the government regains market confidence through pension and tax reforms.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.7 4.7 75 81 10 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
While we expect there to be some improvements in terms of simplifying the tax system, there is also uncertainty about other tax changes, so the score does not improve in the forecast period. The fiscal consolidation approach of the newly elected government follows a liberal orientation, with a greater emphasis on spending cuts (through structural reforms, such as the pension reform), rather than on tax increases. The tax burden will remain high for an emerging market, however (32.3%, according to the federal revenue service, on a par with OECD countries like the UK and Canada). Brazil has one of the most time-consuming and complex tax systems in the world, ranked 184th of 190 countries in the World Bank's annual Doing Business survey for 2019. According to the survey, it takes the average Brazilian company almost 2,000 hours a year of administrative effort to file its tax returns, against a world average of 253 hours/year. In addition, the high degree of indirect taxation reduces the country's global competitiveness, as it increases the costs of production and consumption. Besides, the huge array of sectoral benefits and tax exemptions is a big cause of inefficiencies and competition asymmetries within local markets. The government hopes to address some of these issues.
Tax simplification is on the cards
A bill is advancing in Congress that unifies three federal taxes (PIS, Cofins and IPI), one state tax (ICMS) and one municipal tax (ISS) into a single VAT-style tax to be called the Imposto sobre Bens e Serviços (IBS). Because of the complexities of the ICMS tax, and how it has become used to offer tax incentives as part of a "fiscal war" between states, there is an elevated risk that the ICMS (and ISS) taxes could be dropped from the final bill after pushback from state governors.
The tax simplification may have its core text amended during the legislative approval process, with the inclusion of other tax-reform measures proposed by the government, such as the reduction of corporate income tax rates (perhaps including, at least partially, reductions on payroll contributions), taxation on distributed profits and dividends and ending the deductibility of interest on equity. Other suggested measures, such as raising the individual income tax threshold (to up to five minimum wages) and taxing all types of financial transactions are less likely to go ahead.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.0 7.0 22 33 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The already strong and liquid financial system will benefit from measures to improve efficiency, competitiveness and to reduce the cost of credit. While the Selic policy interest rate is at historically low levels (under 3% in real terms), Brazil still ranks as one of the countries with the highest real rates in the world. The decline in the Selic and of banking spreads over the last three years has reduced the overall cost of credit for consumers and companies. Its level (around 20%) is still high, but should ease. The government is dialling down the availability of subsidised and abundant lending from state banks, especially from the Banco Nacional de Desenvolvimento Econômico e Social (BNDES, the national development bank). Still, state banks will continue to exercise an important role as sectoral lenders, such as in infrastructure (BNDES), agriculture (Banco do Brasil) and housing (Caixa).
Lower interest rate and inflation environment will boost credit
The "BC+ Agenda", fostered by the Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank), has been active since 2016 in promoting modern regulations to strengthen the financial system and reduce the cost of credit. This agenda is expected to advance further and should help to boost credit. The new market-based Taxa de Longo Prazo (TLP, the benchmark long-term financing rate), created in 2018 under this agenda, reduces the monopoly power of the BNDES and improves the effectiveness of monetary policy, since the new rate is more sensitive to the Selic rate (the TLP rate will converge with those of Notas do Tesouro Nacional-B series government bond, whose rates are based on a premium above inflation). The BC+ Agenda is also promoting the regulation of credit fintechs and facilitating the participation of foreign capital in this new market.
Broad and outright privatisation of public banks is unlikely, but the sale of some subsidiaries, the opening of capital to specific segments and measures to enhance capital markets are on the agenda. The BNDES is going through a change of orientation, diverting lending from big to mid-sized companies and primarily to infrastructure projects, combining both public and private funding. The new, more limited focus comes as BNDES returns over US$100bn in debt-creating government transfers extended following the global financial crisis.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.9 5.6 74 62 9 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The score improves as we expect the government will continue to introduce measures to make the labour market more flexible, consolidating the landmark labour reforms enacted in 2017. The transfer of the Ministry of Labour to the structure of the Ministry of Economy suggests that the government views the pension and labour reforms as complementary actions to reduce labour costs. Mr Guedes' idea of launching a "Carteira de Trabalho Verde Amarela" (Green and Yellow Labour Register), a more flexible labour contractual arrangement, depends on the approval of a new capitalisation pension scheme as a follow up to pension reform, which currently looks unlikely. While wages are relatively low in Brazil (the average monthly income is under US$600), the overall cost of labour for employers is still high, with social security obligations and labour benefits adding an extra cost of close to one-third of salaries.
The new labour legislation was expected to spur job creation as it made the labour market more flexible and dynamic. But the persistently high unemployment rate (over 12%) suggests that this is not yet happening. Still, there was a 34% decrease in the number of labour lawsuits entering courts in 2018, which reduces the high and unpredictable legal costs to firms. Under the new rule, employees who sue an employer and lose the case must pay attorney fees.
Measures to reduce the cost of labour in the short-to-medium term may well be implemented. First, the government seems inclined to alleviate the burden of formal labour by exempting or reducing payroll contributions. Second, the rules defining the monetary value of the minimum wage may change after wage rises in the past got well ahead of productivity gains. Up until 2019, the minimum wage increased every year according to past inflation (as defined in the constitution) plus the real GDP growth rate of two years earlier. The 2011 law formalising this framework expires this year. For 2020, the government has decided that the new minimum wage will be adjusted according to past inflation only, suggesting that this might be the future policy thereafter.
Actions to improve workers' productivity in the long run may be temporarily hurt or delayed given difficulties in the management of education policies. Under the new administration, the Ministry of Education has suffered from political turmoil, which led to the replacement of its former minister (Ricardo Vélez) and to protests across the country on May 15th criticising the spending cuts announced by the new minister, Abraham Weintraub. The ministry is a battleground for the ideological wing of the Bolsonaro government.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.8 5.0 55 64 5 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Brazil's already fragile infrastructure is currently suffering from a lack of public investment, which reached an all-time low of 1.85% of GDP in 2017 and is estimated to have fallen even further since. This reflects a combination of economic recession, fiscal deterioration and corruption scandals. While tax revenues plummeted during the economic crisis, government spending kept increasing, especially due to a rigid budget structure, where most spending items are mandatory current expenditures. In order to meet their fiscal targets, governments had little choice but to cut their investments. Pension reform will not provide much relief in the forecast period, as the savings will build over the longer term (to 1% of GDP annually later in the 2020s). Moreover, the corruption scandal set off by the Operação Lava Jato since 2014 (Car Wash Operation) has been a major negative shock to the investment projects of Petrobras and large construction companies involved, such as Odebrecht, OAS and Camargo Corrêa, which particularly affected the oil and gas sector. Finally, the deleveraging of the BNDES has resulted in more selective lending by the national development bank, which is traditionally a big funder of infrastructure projects in the energy and logistics sectors. The resumption of investment will hinge on the extent of macro and microeconomic reforms and improvements in the legal and regulatory framework for infrastructure concessions.
Infrastructure concessions envisaged under the Investment Partnerships Program (PPI)-the main state programme for concessions and public-private partnerships (PPPs)-should be one of the most promising initiatives of this government's microeconomic agenda. A legacy of the Temer administration (2016-18), the PPI introduces a series of business-friendly innovations in the governance models and legal frameworks of infrastructure projects. Collectively, auctions in the electricity (2017), oil and gas (2018), and airport sectors (2017, 2019) have raised about US$6bn in initial bids so far, with follow-up investments far exceeding this. The success of the latest auction of a batch of regional airports in March-the first under the Bolsonaro government-reaffirmed foreign investors' appetite for Brazilian assets and the government's commitment to promoting private-sector participation in infrastructure, including measures to facilitate the entry of foreign capital.
Over the last three years, the PPI board has approved 193 projects with expected investments of R365bn (US$94bn). Of those, 147 were completed (auctioned or renewed), with committed investments of about US$67bn, notably on oil and gas (US$45.5bn), energy (US$15.5bn) and airports (US$2.6bn). The remaining backlog of projects points to an estimate of US$27.2bn in investments, mainly in railways (US$15.2bn), roads (US$14.8bn) and ports (US$1.5bn).
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.8 6.1 47 48 3 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The federal government views information and communication technology (ICT) as a strategic area. In 2018, the Ministry of Science, Technology, Innovation and Communication (MCTIC), together with BNDES, drafted directives for a National Plan for the Internet of Things (IoT), containing the implementation of 76 actions in areas such as innovation support, international outreach, infrastructure for connectivity and data privacy regulations. Brazil already ranks as the country in the world with the 7th-highest level of investments in ICT and the highest in Latin America, with total investments of US$144bn in 2018, followed by Mexico (US$74bn) and Argentina (US$27bn). The sector employs 1.5m people and is expected to account for almost 11% of the country's GDP by 2020. Universities have an important role in producing innovation. Linkages with the industry are weak, but will continue to grow. According to the National Institute of Industrial Property (INPI), of the 20 organisations with the highest rates of patents registered in Brazil, 18 are public universities (mostly federal), having filed 674 patent requests in 2017. But this rate is low compared to the total of 5,480 resident patent applications filed that year, according to data from the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO). While Brazil is the 8th-largest economy in the world, it ranks 19th (out of more than 120 countries) on the number of Intellectual Property (IP) filing requests, according to the WIPO. This ranking includes patents, trademarks and industrial design filing requests.
Nearly 60% of mobile subscriptions use 4G technology. The National Telecommunications Agency (Anatel) will hold auctions of 5G frequency in March 2020; the network should begin to be built from 2021. The launch of 5G technology is the first major step towards the Internet of Things (IoT), providing a broad and direct connection of devices, computers and machines.
Brazilians are heavy internet users: the country ranks as third globally in terms of the number of hours per day spent on the internet, behind only Thailand and the Philippines, according to a 2017 survey by GlobalWebIndex, a market research company. Most of this internet usage is related to social media, but an important part is drifting to online shopping: according to data by eMarketer, by the end of 2019, 47.2% of the Latin American e-commerce revenue will be generated in Brazil, followed at a distance by Argentina (12.2%) and Mexico (9.9%).
Fixed broadband internet service is available to 45% of Brazilian citizens. The quality of communication services is reasonable and has been improving along with the expansion of demand. Among the five most populous countries in the world (China, India, the US, Indonesia and Brazil), the country has the third-fastest internet speed (mobile and fixed), behind China and the US.
The digital revolution in Brazil has fostered a continuous and promising increase in the number of start-ups, especially in banking and finance, education, transportation and logistics and food delivery. In 2018, six Brazilian start-ups became local "unicorns", each worth more than R1bn (US$260bn).
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Political alignments between the executive and centrist parties holding a majority in Congress bode well for imperative economic reforms, and on this basis The Economist Intelligence Unit expects progress in many areas, including but not limited to pension reform, tax reform and the privatisation and infrastructure concessions agenda. However, the window of opportunity will close as the October 2020 municipal elections approach and this creates some risks to our forecast, as do ideological differences within the administration and political tensions between the executive and Congress. The economic minister, Paulo Guedes, espouses free-market policies but Mr Bolsonaro's own interventionist tendencies-and those of the handful of retired military officers who are active in his government-may cause some tension and inconsistencies in programme delivery. We assume that Mr Bolsonaro will continue to push for-and succeed in passing-pension reform, as well as other adjustments required to ensure that public spending caps enacted in 2016-designed to stabilise a high (and rising) public debt/GDP ratio-are not exceeded, otherwise debt sustainability stresses and higher inflation would return.
The original pension reform proposal submitted to Congress in February envisaged fiscal savings of R1.2bn (US$310bn) over the next decade, mainly by gradually raising the minimum retirement age (to 65 for men and 62 for women). But its fiscal impact has already been watered down by the rapporteur in the lower house. We assume that pension reform will be approved by October (two rounds of votes in each chamber of Congress with a three-fifths majority each time are required, as consti-tutional amendments would be needed) in a diluted form-to around R800bn, representing fiscal savings of 1% of GDP annually in the long term, bolstering confidence in the public finances.
Reducing bureaucracy and lowering the custo Brasil (the additional cost of doing business in Brazil compared with other emerging markets, stemming from the high regulatory and tax burden) is one of Mr Guedes's objectives. However, these decades-old problems will be a struggle to fix amid push-back from vested interests. We currently expect piecemeal progress, given the fragmentation of Congress and the narrow window of opportunity for reform (typically the first 12-18 months in office). Moreover, we remain unconvinced that Mr Bolsonaro will be fully committed to Mr Guedes's proposals if these face strong resistance in Congress or from other stakeholders. But there is some upside risk to our economic growth forecasts if the government makes greater progress than expected on a long list of outstanding microeconomic reforms. These include:
Tax reforms. Our forecasts assume that some simplification of the tax system (revenue-neutral) will be approved and will offer a tangible productivity boost, particularly for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that cannot afford to hire legions of staff to comply with the complicated tax regulations. Mr Guedes wants to unify three sales taxes into a value-added tax (Imposto sobre Bens e Serviços, IBS). He is expected to announce his plans shortly, which may also include proposals to cut corporate taxes. Congress is advancing its own tax simplification bill, which adds a state (Imposto sobre Circulação de Mercadorias e Serviços, ICMS) and municipal (Imposto Sobre Serviços, ISS) tax too. But given probable pushback from stakeholders-governors and mayors, who would lose control over these important sources of revenue-the ICMS and ISS are less likely to be included in an eventual deal.
Privatisation and infrastructure concessions. Concessions in airports, roads, railways and ports will attract greater private investment than in the past owing to better terms and conditions, and we assume greater privatisation revenue in our forecasts than under previous administrations. Mr Guedes is proposing a sweeping privatisation programme, which aligns with Mr Bolsonaro's rhetoric of removing political appointees (which, in many cases, has led to mismanagement and corruption). A slew of state enterprises are operating at both the federal and the state levels, so there are many potential targets for privatisation. But Brazil's "crown jewels" will be mostly off the table, including Banco do Brasil and Caixa (two large retail banks) and Petrobras (some of its refineries will be divested, however). A priority will be the privatisation of Eletrobras (the state-owned electricity company) in 2020. Some companies on Mr Guedes's list may instead remain in state hands owing to pushback from stakeholders, but governance will be restructured.
Trade liberalisation. This is high on Mr Guedes's agenda and would oblige Brazil's cosseted industries to become more competitive. The objective would also be to integrate manufacturing more closely into global value chains.
"Rightsizing" the public sector. Reforms here would help to free up resources for public works, which have fallen below 1% of GDP. Mr Bolsonaro favours a slimmer state, but will be up against powerful civil servants' unions.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy
Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)

Central government revenue 24.0 24.0 24.0 24.0 24.0 24.0
Central budget balance -3.4 -3.5 -3.7 -4.3 -5.0 -5.8
Total public sector debt 77.2 81.8 82.2 80.5 80.2 80.1
We expect the primary balance to move into surplus in the forecast period, assuming that fiscal adjustments materialise and economic recovery boosts revenue. Mr Guedes initially said that he wanted to reduce the primary deficit to zero in 2019 through exceptional revenue from privatisation proceeds and an auction of Petrobras's excess reserves from a "transfer of rights", dating back to its 2010 capitalisation. However, this is unlikely and would only be a temporary solution, and other adjustments will be required over the medium term. Lower interest rates than in the past will ease debt-interest payments in 2019-20, but these will remain sizeable (and will rise slightly in 2021-23 as the policy rate returns to more neutral levels). Overall (including debt interest payments), we forecast that the public-sector deficit will fall from 8% of GDP in 2017 to 5.6% of GDP by 2023. Assuming that pension reform and moderate GDP growth materialise as forecast, the rise in the public debt/GDP ratio (from 77% in 2018) will slow, remaining below 85%. This forecast assumes some debt reduction from privatisation proceeds.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Lending rate (av) 39.1 36.3 35.0 34.8 34.0 33.0
SELIC overnight rate (av) 6.5 6.2 5.9 6.5 6.8 6.8
Fiscal consolidation and the likelihood that the Banco Central do Brasil (BCB, the central bank) will gain formal independence will help to strengthen the inflation-targeting framework. The central inflation target has been set to fall by 25 basis points annually from 4.25% in 2019 to 3.5% 2022. Amid a weak economy, spare capacity and well-anchored inflation expectations, we now expect the central bank to cut rates by a total of 50 basis points starting in September to 6% and remain on hold in 2020. We expect a mild tightening cycle to begin in mid-2021. Real policy interest rates are likely to converge to a neutral rate of around 3% thereafter (lower than in the past-based on the assumption of fiscal consolidation). An unexpected failure to pass the pension reform would produce a more hawkish stance in response to a souring of investor sentiment that would trigger capital outflows, currency pressures and higher inflation.
