Our forecasts currently assume pension reform approval and tax simplification, as well as piecemeal progress on other items on the microeconomic reform agenda. On this basis, we continue to expect Brazil's economy to pick up from the deep recession of 2015-16 and weak recovery in 2017-19-we forecast annual average growth of 2.3% of GDP in 2020-23. In the short term, investors will remain cautious until there is greater clarity regarding pension reform approval. After falling by 0.2% in January-March, GDP is estimated to have grown by only 0.2% in April-June, and although we expect some greater sequential gains in the rest of the year, we now expect GDP growth of only 0.8% for 2019. The upturn will be driven by an increase in investment and private consumption as the jobs market gradually improves and credit rises. Brazil's upturn will be capped by a US slowdown in 2020, before resuming thereafter.
On the supply side, most components of the services sector are unlikely to recover much dynamism, as they are impaired by low productivity and skills shortages. However, retail, financial services, telecom-munications and trade will benefit to the greatest degree from a forecast recovery in private consumption. Manufacturing suffered much more than services during Brazil's recession, and so its performance during the recovery phase will be weaker than suggested by the average growth rate of 2.3% that we are projecting for 2020-23; activity will continue to be held back by competitiveness and business environment problems.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Agriculture has an importance beyond its small share of GDP (under 6%), owing to its significance as an employer in rural areas and the importance of agribusiness industries for the domestic market and exports. Favourable weather led to record grains harvests in 2016/17 and 2017/18 of around 230m tonnes. The sector will remain vulnerable to adverse weather (particularly the cyclical El Niño weather phenomenon) but will be supported by technological improvements and more intensive land use, as well as by good fundamentals for soft-commodity exports, owing to rising demand in the developing world.
Competitiveness shortcomings persist despite reform efforts
Fiscal constraints will impede credit extension. Competitiveness shortcomings (including a high tax burden, poor infrastructure and high labour costs) will continue to hinder manufacturing (a sector worth 13% of GDP). Light manufacturing industries in particular have lost market share, owing to a surge in Chinese imports in recent years. Capital goods industries will face similar problems, but will be buoyed by domestic demand. Higher investment will enable some labour-intensive manufacturing activities to move up the value chain, but many will struggle to cope with rising import competition. Brazil's manufacturing sector has been mostly inwards-looking and, with a few exceptions, companies have failed to enter linkages with global production systems. Extractive industries are expected to perform reasonably well in the medium term. Although a slowdown in China has softened prices for Brazil's export commodities, demand growth will continue to support mining activity, notably of iron ore. Investment in other mining activities will be boosted following reforms to the mining law in 2018 (lifting royalties for the government and improving the regulatory framework).
Oil and gas provide opportunities
Brazil has the potential to be a major oil player, following a series of discoveries since 2006 in the "pre-salt" layer, a large area in ultra-deep waters off the south-eastern coast that could lift reserves to 80bn barrels, which would place Brazil among the world's top ten reserve-holders. However, supply bottlenecks caused by strict local-content laws in place for projects before 2016 and a huge corruption scandal have set back Petrobras's schedule for producing the oil. Pre-salt fields are producing over 1.7m barrels/day (b/d) of oil from nearly 100 wells, over half of total oil output (2.7m b/d). Petrobras now accounts for under 78% of total production as foreign companies increase their share. Royal Dutch Shell (UK/Netherlands) has an 11.6% share, followed by Repsol-Sinopec (Spain-China), with 3%; Petrogral (Portugal), 2.8%; and Equinor (formerly Statoil, Norway), 1.5%, among others. Most crude oil output is offshore in deep water and production is mainly of heavier grades. More than 80% of oil production and about 40% of natural-gas production is concentrated off the shores of Rio de Janeiro. We expect Brazil's total crude oil production to reach 3.5m b/d by 2023.
BG Group (UK) and Galp (Portugal) were among the few foreign companies acquiring pre-salt reserve fields before auctions were halted in 2006 pending a change in legislation. In 2016 Shell acquired BG Group and these assets. At the first pre-salt auction under the revised rules, held in October 2013, a consortium including Petrobras, CNOOC (China) and Total (France) acquired the Libra block with up to 12bn in reserves, and production began in late 2017. Changes to pre-salt legislation in October 2016 by the Temer government paved the way for the second and third auctions of the pre-salt area (covering eight fields) in October 2017. Out of those allocated, six went to a series of international consortia. Shell was the big winner, gaining three blocks in partnership with a number of other companies, including Petrobras, Total and CNOOC. BP (UK) gained two blocks, also in partnerships. The fourth and fifth pre-salt rounds in June and September 2018 attracted some of the largest oil companies in the world, including Chevron, ExxonMobil and Equinor, Galp and Shell, as well as Petrobras. A mega-auction of "excess" pre-salt reserves of 6bn-15bn oil barrels has been set for November 2019. The state awarded the fields to Petrobras as part of a "transfer of rights" contract dating back to 2010. Petrobras began production in the fields in 2013 and discovered that there was more crude than the 5bn barrels initially estimated. Burdened by massive debt, Petrobras lacked the capital to develop the discoveries, and policymakers want to auction the excess volumes and monetise the significant interest in the reserves.
Services sector is unlikely to recover much dynamism
Most components of the services sector, which accounts for almost 70% of GDP, are unlikely to recover much dynamism in the medium term, as they are impaired by low productivity and skills shortages. However, retail, financial services, telecommunications and trade will perform above the sector average. When credit growth recovers, it is expected to be weaker in the medium term (5-1o% in real terms) than during Brazil's credit boom in 2006-12. The retail sector will be supported by household expenditure growth and rising incomes among poorer households, but will also be weaker than in the past.

Higher food and transport prices lifted inflation to 4.7% in May. We expect inflation to ease and to fluctuate close to the gradually declining central inflation target. Inflation expectations are now better anchored than in the past. A mild monetary tightening cycle over the medium term will keep inflation close to the mid-point of the target range, barring periodic food shortages reflecting adverse weather cycles.

Other than associated volatility as the pension reform debate continues (jitters in May weakened the Real to R4.1:US$1, leading to central bank intervention, and it has since strengthened to R3.86:US$1), we expect the Real to fluctuate in line with Brazil's terms of trade and global financing conditions. Large trade surpluses will reduce the current-account deficit in the short term, but it is expected to widen as economic recovery lifts imports. Although prices for Brazil's commodities exports will be higher than in 2014-16, the country will not enjoy terms of trade as favourable as those seen during the 2004-11 economic boom.
A recovery in domestic demand and the resulting rise in imports will narrow the trade surplus from 2.9% of GDP in 2018 to 1.8% of GDP by 2023. The primary income deficit will average 2.2% of GDP in 2019-23, reflecting profit remittances and debt payments, and the services deficit will average 2.1%. These trends will widen the current-account deficit to 2.9% of GDP by 2023, up from an estimated 0.8% of GDP in 2018. Foreign direct investment will average 4.8% of GDP in 2019-23, owing to sizeable market opportunities.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Brazil
Stocks and flows
Brazil is one of the largest FDI recipients and preferred investment destinations in Latin America. Globally, Brazil ranks as one of the top 10 recipients of FDI in the world. According to data released by the Banco Central do Brasil (the central bank), in 2018 total FDI inflow reached US$88.3bn (including intercompany transfers and reinvested profits), a 26% increase over 2017. Foreign investments have shown some resilience during difficult economic times: the average FDI inflow of US$79.3bn seen during the post-crisis period (2017-18) was relatively similar to the US$81.4bn average observed during the pre-crisis period (2013-14). Even during the recession (2014-16), average FDI amounted to US$66.8bn (3.3% of the GDP). By the end of 2018, the stock of FDI reached US$762bn (40.8% of GDP).
Origin and distribution
According to UNCTAD, nine out of ten of the largest acquisitions by foreign companies in 2017 in Latin America occurred in Brazil, with seven involving Chinese buyers (the majority in the energy sector). The acquisitions were mostly related to companies in the electric, oil, infrastructure (gas transmission) and agribusiness sectors. Regarding crossborder transactions, the most active investor countries in Brazil are the US, UK, France, Canada and Germany, accounting for 65% of the 329 inbound crossborder transactions in 2018. Other relevant countries investing in Brazil via acquisitions are China, Mexico, Japan, Singapore and Argentina.
Determinants
Brazil's attractiveness to foreign investors has traditionally been determined by a combination of its market size, regional influence, macroeconomic stability, richness of natural resources and diversified industrial base. The country is a major global player in agribusiness, mineral commodities and bioenergy. However, its complex tax system, relatively unstable legal framework and high borrowing costs have limited a more abundant inflow of foreign investments.
Impact
FDI has played an increasingly important role in recent infrastructure concessions and in the latest pre-salt bids. In this sense, FDI is considered a key success factor in the promotion of higher capital productivity and sustained long-term growth. From a balance-of-payments perspective, FDI has fully covered the current-account deficit in recent years, therefore allowing a healthy and balanced exchange between Brazil and the rest of the world. Although it is hard to measure the direct effects of FDI on productivity, it is clear that the presence of international companies operating in Brazil has a positive correlation with an active research and development activity: patents filled by non-residents through the Brazilian offices amounted to 20,200 in 2017, way exceeding the 7,500 patents filed by residents.
Potential
While the recent economic and fiscal crisis has led to a slowdown of foreign investments, positive expectations about the government's ability to advance with the pension reform, the privatisation agenda and the opening of the economy make the country an interesting investment opportunity for the next five years. Besides the pension reform, expected to be approved at the end of this year, there is a mild chance that the current administration approves changes in the tax system, combining five taxes (federal, state and municipal) into one single value-added tax (VAT), which would greatly simplify the country's complex tax system, considered one of the major barriers to investment. Assuming the pension and tax reforms are implemented during the current administration, Brazil could recover the investment grade by 2023.

Brazil is undergoing a rapid demographic transition, marked by a strong reduction in birth rates and an increase in life expectancy. In 2000, there were 52.1m people in the country aged zero to 14 years, corresponding to 30% of the population, according to the National Institute of Geography and Statistics (IBGE). By 2015, this age group accounted for 45.3m people (22.3% of the population), equivalent to a 7.7 percentage points fall over 15 years. In the same period, the elderly population (over 65 years), grew by 2.8 points from 5.6% in 2000 to 8.4% of the population in 2015. Considering IBGE's projections for 2030, the share of the elderly population will reach 13.5% of the population, an increase of 5.1 percentage points over 2015.
Rapid demographic transition will hit the workforce
The ratio of the working-age population (15-64 years) over total population is currently reaching its peak, as it went from 68.9% in 2012 to 69.7% in 2017 and is expected to fall again to 69.6% in 2022. This will increase the old-age dependency ratio, that is, the degree to which elderly population depends on the working-age population. In 2023 the old-age dependency ratio is forecast to reach 0.15, meaning that there will be 15 old-aged people depending on 100 people at working age (in 2002 this ratio was 0.10, or 10 old-aged depending on 100 working-age people). This means that future workers will suffer a much harder pressure to finance the ever-increasing number of pension beneficiaries. This is unlikely to be resolved by productivity gains in the labour market, since the current levels of education and skills of the workforce are low and are not expected to advance significantly over the next decade.
Solving the pension system imbalance by raising taxes or labour contributions would be costly and counterproductive. Given the already relatively high tax burden in Brazil, additional tax increases would increase production costs, reduce the level of employment and ultimately limit consumption, growth and revenue collection. In sum, Brazil's demographic transition challenges the fiscal and financial sustainability of the country's current "pay-as-you-go" pension system, even after a probable pension reform in 2019.
The ageing of the population impacts not only the social security system but also the health system, as medical and hospital costs increase with ageing. The country has one of the largest public healthcare systems in the world, as the Constitution of 1988 made healthcare universal and decentralised according to the degree of treatment complexity (municipalities are responsible for basic care and states for medium-to-high levels of care). But the system is already overstretched with growing demand, recently boosted by the economic crisis, as many people migrated from private healthcare insurance (mostly through company schemes) to public health services. And the demands will increase, stretching budgets.
Despite the fact that Brazil is still a young democracy (the average age of the population is just under 30), the country spends 13-14% of GDP on pension-related payments and benefits, while the total sum of public spending on health and education does not go much beyond 10% of GDP.
Given the speed of the demographic transition and the pressure it imposes on the pension and health systems, labour productivity would have to rise to levels that are probably unthinkable in the long run. Real GDP is expected to grow by 2.2% a year on average over for the next five years, while total factor productivity (labour and capital) should only increase by 0.6%. Albeit positive, these growth rates are well below the average of 3.5% and 1% growth rates of GDP and TFP seen during the pre-crisis period (2007-14).
While immigration could be a potential driver for promoting labour productivity, there has not been a policy designed to attract skilled labour nor is there likely be one in the near future. Most of the recent immigrants (South Korean, Chinese, Bolivian, Haitian and Venezuelan) have been absorbed by low-skill functions in the retail sector rather than in the industry, where most of the demand for high-skill labour is found.

Exports of goods & services (% change) 4.1 2.7 0.5 3.4 3.9 3.9
Imports of goods & services (% change) 8.5 2.9 4.9 4.7 4.9 5.1
Brazil ranks as the eighth-largest economy in the world, with a total GDP of nearly US$2trn, similar to that of Canada and Italy and above Australia, Spain and Mexico. But, given its large population (over 210m people, the fifth-largest in the world), GDP per capita is around US$8,800 (at market exchange rates), rising to US$10,507 by 2023, placing Brazil as an upper-middle country, or the 60th to 70th (depending on the metrics used) richest country in the world, close to Mexico, above China, but below Argentina and Chile. When measured by purchasing power parity, per capita income is a bit higher (US$16,435 in 2019, rising to US$18,535 by 2023). The divergence between the GDP per capita measured by markets rates and PPP reflects the fact that, in emerging economies such as Brazil, lower wages make the price of services and non-traded goods relatively cheap compared to richer countries. Since services represent more than 70% of the GDP, per capita income measured by the PPP exchange rate tends to be higher than at the market exchange rate.
The relatively low median monthly personal income (around US$600) results in a low marginal propensity to save and high marginal propensity to spend. According to research by the Brazilian Association of Financial and Capital Market Entities (Anbima), 58% of Brazilians do not have any financial investments. The high share of income diverted to consumption means household consumption represents about 65% of the country's total GDP. The flipside of this equation is that both savings and investments are very low in the country, with gross fixed investments representing only 15% of the GDP. Even among families who save some of their income, most allocate it in very conservative instruments, primarily in savings accounts, with low interest rates, sometimes even below inflation rates (real savings interest are negative). Little knowledge about financial markets is another cause for low levels of savings in Brazil, so most families do not get much extra income from financial returns.
Low levels of savings reduce the amount of financial guarantees and collateral available to households to borrow from banks. This helps to explain why total domestic credit to the private sector by banks represents only about 60% of the GDP in Brazil, a much lower ratio compared to the average of 113.2% of the GDP for upper-middle income countries in 2017, according to the World Bank. All in all, this means most of the consumption is diverted to goods and services that are less dependent on credit, such as non-durable goods (food and beverages, health and beauty) and semi-durable goods (clothing, house goods, electronic equipment). Consumption of durable goods, such as automobiles and housing, which are based on lending, seem to have been too dependent on governmental stimulus in the past.
The boom and bust cycle experienced between 2003-14 illustrates these consumer and credit trends. During the 2003-11 upswing, private credit surged, buoyed by a reform allowing payroll guarantees, and fuelled purchases of automobiles and home appliances (refrigerators, washing machines, microwaves, etc.). Moreover, the government opted to lower taxation on industrial production, further triggering a consumption boom of durable goods. During the 2011-14 bust phase, there was strong growth in public credit, mainly for social housing programmes destined to poorer families (such as the Minha Casa Minha Vida housing programme). The huge expansion of credit supply during these two periods (the total stock of banking credit went from 27.7% to 66% of GDP between 2003 and 2014) led to a rapid increase in consumption, which was accompanied by an intensive increase in employment in construction and services. However, as these stimuli were not accompanied by productivity gains, the aftermath was a serious problem of indebtedness, both private and public. Working through this balance-sheet overhang has contributed to the tepid nature of Brazil's recovery in 2017-19.
The 2014-16 recession was a hangover effect from the previous fiscal and credit boom. Although credit concessions are showing signs of recovery since 2017, the stock of credit is still below the pre-crisis level (59.7% of GDP in 2017 against 66% in 2014). In this sense, consumption of durable goods should recover only at a moderate pace in the short to medium term, especially given the lack of public stimulus (directly through public budget or indirectly through public banks). The industrial sector, especially civil construction (including housing), has been one of the worst affected sectors and should only reach its pre-crisis levels by 2023, lagging behind other sectors, such as services (expected to recover the pre-crisis level only by 2021) and agriculture (already above the pre-crisis level).
The pace of recovery will also be different among regions due to high disparities in income and growth. Brazil comprises 26 states-plus the federal district-divided into five regions. The north and north-east regions, while comprising 36% of the country's population, represent 23.6% of the national income and almost 20% of GDP, specialising in industrial production of durable and semi-durable goods (as with the Tax Free Industrial Zone of Manaus, capital of the Amazonas in the north) and agriculture and mining (north-east). The south-east region alone concentrates 42% of the population, 51% of income and 53% of GDP, with a very diversified industrial, agricultural and services base, especially in the state of São Paulo. The central-west, Brazil's agricultural belt, specialises in livestock, grains (soybean and corn) and cotton, and concentrates 7.7% of the population, 8.5% of income and 10% of GDP. Finally, the South has 14.3% of the population, 17% of income and 17% of GDP, and mostly specialises in agro-industry.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecast anticipates slower average annual GDP growth over the next 31 years (1.9%) than in 1991-2014 (3%). Even this assumes that labour productivity growth will accelerate beyond recent historical levels, which have been poor. This is needed to help to offset worsening demographic factors. If policy improve-ments and structural reforms were to exceed expectations, faster growth rates would be achievable. Assuming that the potential of oil reserves materialises and that these are relatively well managed by the state, Brazil will figure among the world's largest exporters in the 2020s, which, in turn, will support GDP growth prospects.
Initial conditions: Brazil's advantages of vast natural-resource potential and a young labour force are mitigated by a series of structural constraints, including weak political effectiveness, a generally low level of education and skills, income disparities, low savings rates, difficult logistics (mainly due to chronic underinvestment in infrastructure), and a relatively high fiscal burden. Other than in the agricultural sector, productivity growth has been disappointing in recent years, notwithstanding the acquisition of more advanced technology by the manufacturing sector, which took advantage of exchange-rate appreciation between 2005 and 2014 to increase imports of machinery and equipment. Gradual improvements in the quality and availability of primary and secondary education, and efforts to address infrastructure deficiencies, simplify the convoluted tax system and reduce red tape will underpin stronger productivity growth in the long term. Our projections are based on expectations that a commitment to macroeconomic discipline will prevail.
Demographic trends: Brazil's demographic profile will become less supportive of growth prospects further into the long-term period. Despite the fact that a declining birth rate and a relatively static mortality rate will increase the median age of the population, this will remain low when compared with the major economies of the US, Western Europe and Japan. As population growth will begin to outpace working-age growth in the early 2020s, Brazil's "demographic dividend" is close to ending. Policymakers will have the challenge of addressing the fiscal burden of an ageing population.
External conditions: Although structural external vulnerabilities have declined, the Brazilian economy remains exposed to changes in external financial market conditions through its low domestic savings rates, and the volume of external capital inflows is strongly correlated with risk aversion. Although the public sector has been cautious about external borrowing, corporates have borrowed overseas, and can be affected by sudden stops in capital flows. A rising degree of trade openness and continued diversification of export partners will allow the country to continue benefiting from global trade growth. Some insulation from commodity price shocks is provided by Brazil's strong competitive advantage in the production of agricultural products and its large industrial export base. Global trade liberalisation is expected to make little headway, preventing Brazil from realising its full export potential, particularly in the agricultural sector.
Institutions and policy trends: Democracy has consolidated since the return to civilian rule in 1985. But many political institutions are still ineffective; in particular, the political spectrum is fragmented among several relatively weak parties, producing a legislature that is dominated by vested interests. This will improve slightly on the assumption that measures to enhance party loyalty are implemented. Fiscal pressures will mount, as lawmakers will shy away from watering down the benefits and entitlements enshrined in the constitution of 1988. Spending commitments will rise as the population ages. Tax revenue is already high (32% of GDP), so adjusting the public finances to stabilise and reduce Brazil's high public debt/GDP ratio will prove challenging. A heavy debt burden will keep interest payments high, crowding out the private sector. With much public expenditure characterised by poor effectiveness, fiscal policy will not make a major contribution to long-term growth. We anticipate gradual progress on structural reforms over the coming decade, which will help to ease other constraints on GDP growth, including the convoluted tax system, shortcomings in infrastructure and weaknesses in the labour market. These measures will start to improve Brazil's relative attract-iveness for investors only in the next decade. Regulatory issues will be addressed gradually and improvements in the efficiency of the judiciary should materialise over time.
Long-term performance: Brazil will continue to catch up only slowly with the US, with GDP per head (in US dollars at purchasing power parity) increasing from 26% of that in the US in 2017 to 33% in 2050. Macroeconomic stability will continue to reduce the volatility of economic growth, and forecast GDP expansion of 1.9% annually in 2018-50 will be weaker than the average in 1991-2014 (3%). Improvements in infrastructure, trade expansion, a broader presence of multinational business and a reduction in the debt-service burden will mitigate the slowing in growth of the labour force and help to lift labour productivity growth throughout the outlook period. This is dependent on progress in the politically difficult process of institutional reforms. Our outlook is based on the assumption that governments will remain broadly committed to pushing through changes in the long term. Otherwise, productivity growth and the average rate of GDP growth will fall short of our forecast. The country's political system makes it hard to advance structural reforms. Political reforms could alter this, although these appear intractable. The commercial exploitation and relatively prudent management of the proceeds of Brazil's huge reserves of deepwater oil are now factored into our baseline forecasts, and therefore major setbacks would pose a downside risk to our long-term forecasts. Our forecasts now capture the impact of climate change, as a result of which Brazil's GDP is forecast to be 4% smaller in 2050 than without climate change.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Brazil adopted its first National Plan on Climate Change Adaptation Goals in 2008 and ratified the UN-brokered December 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change in September 2016. Under the UN's Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Brazil has committed to greenhouse gas emission (GGE) control targets. A significant carbon polluter in its own right, Brazil's stance on the enlargement of climate commitments matters. Although Brazil now embraces cuts to GGE it remains a staunch defender of a country's prerogative for economic expansion. It does not pay into a UN climate fund, but instead shares its expertise with poorer nations on renewable energy sources and on slowing deforestation-serving as an example to the likes of China, India and Indonesia, whose shares of emissions are growing.
Brazil's own climate change projections raise considerable concerns over the potential impact on agriculture. An official model for the impact of temperature increases on crop areas for the nine most cultivated crops (responsible for 85% of Brazil's agribusiness) shows that only sugarcane planting would expand. Diminished crop areas occur for cotton, rice, coffee, beans, sunflowers, cassava, corn and soya beans, the latter being the worst affected with a projected decline of around 25%.
The government has developed a climatic risk zoning programme, which produces municipal maps that demonstrate the appropriate cultivation area for major crops, as well as the potential future shifts in these areas due to changes in temperature and rainfall patterns. The programme indicates to farmers "what to plant, where to plant and when to plant". The National Monetary Council has mandated that only farmers that grow crops deemed appropriate for their area are eligible for rural credit and insurance. Brazilian institutions have been actively investing in genetically enhancing crops to improve tolerance against dry spells and temperatures. For instance, Embrapa Soja and the Agronomy Institute of Parana created varieties of soybean tolerant to dry spells and heat, and Epagri (Santa Catarina) has made advances in more temperature resilient fruits. The Brazilian National Institute for Space Research has developed a state-of-the-art forest fire early warning system using satellite imagery. To mitigate the vulnerability faced by its energy sector due to a heavy reliance on hydroelectricity (around 64% of total installed electricity generation capacity), alternative renewable sources are being promoted.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; unless otherwise stated, The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: Dated Brent import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
GDP growth by demand component: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; 1995 prices
US$ GDP: IFS, various issues; in current prices, converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rates
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Brazil to prices in the US
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS, various issues; local currency GDP, converted to US$ at the estimated annual average PPP for consumer products
Demographic indicators: IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Real GDP growth per head: growth in real GDP divided by population growth
Inflation: Índice de Preços ao Consumidor Ampliado (IPCA, a national consumer price index based on surveys in ten cities, December 1993=100), calculated by the IBGE; IBGE website, www.ibge.gov.br
Budget balance: refers to nominal public-sector borrowing requirement
Exchange rate: IFS, various issues; market rates expressed as Reals per US$1
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average PPP for tradeable products to annual average exchange rate
Foreign direct investment: UNCTAD, World Investment Report; IFS
Balance of payments: IFS, various issues
Total external debt: sum of long-term and short-term debt, plus arrears; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services; World Bank, International Debt Statistics
Abbreviations
FGV: Fundação Getúlio Vargas
IBGE: Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística
IFS: IMF, International Financial Statistics
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberal Party, led by the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, to remain in power after the October election. However, it will be a tight contest and the Liberal government's current parliamentary majority is at risk.
The renegotiation of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) has eased trade uncertainty, but we expect delays in the ratification process of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA; NAFTA's successor), probably until 2020. Trade policy will remain a risk during the administration of the US president, Donald Trump, owing to Canada's reliance on the US, its key export market.
We forecast that real GDP growth will slow from 1.9% in 2018 to 1.6% in both 2019 and 2020, as private consumption growth moderates and an economic slowdown in the US dampens export demand. Real GDP growth will average 2.3% per year in 2021-23.
The federal budget will remain in deficit in 2019-23, as higher receipts from the carbon tax, the legalisation of cannabis and other sources will be more than offset by increased spending on infrastructure and other measures.
Consumer price inflation will ease to 2% in 2019, from 2.2% in 2018, reflecting recent monetary tightening, weaker external demand and generally lower oil prices. Inflationary pressures will ease further in 2020, in line with a subdued economy, before picking up from 2021 as growth regains momentum.
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted the policy rate three times in 2018, to 1.75%. We expect it to keep rates on hold in 2019, before sanctioning a 25-basis-point cut in 2020, as global economic growth slows further. Modest tightening will resume in 2021 and continue in 2022-23.
The exchange rate, commodity prices and the health of the US economy will continue to shape the outlook for the current account, which will remain in deficit in 2019-23. The impact of softer global oil prices in 2019-20 will be offset by slowing domestic demand and, therefore, import growth. The merchandise trade deficit and the shortfall on the current account will remain broadly stable as a proportion of GDP, with the latter averaging 2.6% of GDP during 2019-20.

Canada's score improves in 2019-23, pushing the country up to ninth place in our global business environment rankings. The best features of the business environment are political stability and openness to trade, although tax policy and the labour market will remain constraints.
Country forecast overview: Canada's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The government revises the Canada Business Corporations Act to introduce provisions on board gender diversity, annual election of directors, single election of directors and shareholder empowerment.
2021-23: Progress on increasing competition in certain sectors, such as telecommunications and dairy, will be uneven.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The government will continue to welcome foreign investment but will sometimes reject foreign takeovers owing to national security considerations. Chinese investment and takeover bids will come under particular scrutiny.
2021-23: Foreign investment is likely to rise in value terms as resource nationalism in the oil and gas sector eases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Canada, Mexico and the US ratify the revised North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), now called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which retains the essence of the original treaty.
2021-23: Canada continues to diversify its trade ties. Free-trade talks with China resume.
Taxes
2019-20: The government provides benefits and tax breaks to improve business competitiveness compared with the US.
2021-23: The government introduces reporting mechanisms for multinational enterprises to reduce tax avoidance.
Financing
2019-20: The Bank of Canada (the central bank) develops a system-wide framework to measure stress in banking, insurance and investment funds.
2021-23: The government completes its update of financial legislation, including the Bank Act, the Co-operative Credit Associations Act, the Insurance Companies Act, and the Trust and Loan Companies Act.
The labour market
2019-20: Canada will enact policies to streamline processes and increase quotas to expedite the hiring of foreign talent by companies.
2021-23: The government further encourages the entry of skilled workers and professionals by raising its immigration target.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Work begins on the Trans Mountain Expansion project, which will pipe additional crude oil from Alberta, although further legal challenges could slow progress.
2021-23: After years of uncertainty, pipelines to carry more energy resources from Alberta begin to come on stream.
Technological readiness
2019-20: The technology sector benefits from workers moving from the US, especially those on that country's H1B visas, for whom the political climate becomes more difficult.
2021-23: Expertise in artificial intelligence takes root, particularly in the academic centres of Toronto and Montreal.

Background: The Canadian economy was the tenth-largest in the world in 2018 (measured in US dollars at market exchange rates). It is highly integrated with the US economy, which absorbs 75% of its goods exports and is the source of 51% of its imported goods. The US exerts a powerful economic and cultural influence on Canada. Fifty-eight per cent of Canadians say that English is their mother tongue; just over 21% say French and just under 21% have another language as their first. The majority of French-speakers live in Quebec, Canada's second most-populous province. Canada's unity is sometimes called into question, but support for sovereignty is currently muted in Quebec. Neither of the two leading political parties in the province is seeking an independence referendum.
Political structure: Canada is formally a constitutional monarchy, with the governor-general (always of Canadian nationality and appointed in Ottawa) acting as the representative of the British crown. In practice, the Canadian House of Commons is sovereign. Canada is a federation of ten provinces, each with substantial powers, and three territories. At the federal level are the Commons, the main seat of legislative power, and the non-elected Senate, which plays only a marginal role. The Liberal Party has led a majority government since 2015; the next general election will be held in October 2019.
Policy issues: The federal government must balance the assistance that it is providing to the fossil fuel industry through approving new oil pipelines with the need to maintain its green credentials. The government will increase its spending on infrastructure significantly, including through its Canada Infrastructure Bank.
Taxation: The federal corporate income tax rate is 15%. Provincial governments charge corporate tax at rates between 2% and 16%. In 2016 the government introduced a new top marginal rate of personal income tax of 33%, which applies to taxable income over C$210,371 (US$157,706) in 2019.
Foreign trade: The US absorbs about three-quarters of Canadian exports, so the health of its economy is crucial for Canada. Canada's trade deficit was US$17bn in 2018 and the current-account deficit was US$45.3bn (2.6% of GDP).

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The Liberal Party government, led by the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, won a majority at the federal election in 2015, ending a decade of Conservative Party rule. The government has made progress on most of its reform agenda. However, controversy over alleged political interference in a criminal corruption case has tarnished Mr Trudeau's political brand, and friction with provincial administrations over environmental policy has intensified. The next federal election is due on October 21st and unofficial campaigning is already underway, after parliament went into recess in June. Although the opposition Conservatives remain ahead in opinion surveys, the Liberal Party is regaining ground and the election results will be tight. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberals to remain in government after the election, but its parliamentary majority is at risk, raising the prospect of legislative gridlock.
Mr Trudeau's popularity has been significantly damaged by his mishandling of allegations by the former attorney-general and justice minister, Jody Wilson-Raybould, that he and his officials put inappropriate political pressure on her to abandon the criminal prosecution for alleged fraud of SNC-Lavalin (a large Quebec-based construction and engineering firm, which denies the charges). Ms Wilson-Raybould and another cabinet minister, Jane Philpott, resigned from their positions, citing a lack of confidence in the government. They were both expelled from the caucus in April and will run as independents in October. As a result, the issue is likely to fester in the lead-up to the federal election.
Friction between the federal and provincial governments has intensified in recent months, owing mainly to disagreements on environmental legislation. Opposition parties have taken control of several provincial governments in recent years, setting the stage for policy battles ahead of the federal election. The most significant change of power has been the return to provincial government in Alberta of the United Conservative Party, which defeated the left-leaning New Democratic Party (NDP) government at the provincial election in April. The new Alberta premier, Jason Kenney, is a vocal critic of the federal Liberal government's environmental policies, which he argues have harmed Alberta's resource-based economy. In May he repealed the carbon tax in the province introduced by the former NDP government. As a result, the Liberal government plans to impose the same federal carbon tax on the province of Alberta that it imposed in April on four other provinces-Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario and New Brunswick-that did not have pricing plans meeting federal standards. The imposition of the carbon tax in these provinces, and the nationalisation in 2018 of the Trans Mountain oil pipeline and expansion project, has raised questions over federal jurisdiction. The Trans Mountain expansion, designed to carry additional crude oil from Alberta to a port in British Columbia (BC), is opposed by the NDP provincial government in BC and by environmentalists, and the federal cabinet's decision on June 18th to proceed with the project is controversial.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Political fallout from the SNC-Lavalin affair saw the opposition Conservative Party overtake the Liberals in opinion surveys in February 2019, although support for the Liberals has begun to recover in recent weeks. According to an average of recent polls published by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation on July 10th, the Conservatives were supported by 34.3% of respondents, compared with 31.4% for the Liberals. The NDP was well behind, in third place, backed by 13.7% of those surveyed. Mr Trudeau's overall approval rating remains slightly below that of the Conservative leader, Andrew Scheer.
We nevertheless expect the Liberal Party to be in a position to form a minority government after the federal election, due on October 21st 2019, reflecting the advantages of incumbency, and the implementation of much of the government's agenda, including the legalisation of cannabis.
However, the contest will be tight. Conservatives have an experienced shadow cabinet and have built momentum under Mr Scheer. They will focus on the Liberal government's perceived vulnerabilities, namely taxes, government spending, the cost of its climate change policies, and its broken pledge to change the electoral system from first-past-the-post to proportional representation. The Conservatives also contend that the Liberals have lost control of the border by allowing over 40,000 people to walk across from the US over the past two years and claim asylum.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Under the Liberals, Canadian foreign policy emphasises multilateralism over unilateralism, engagement over isolation, mitigating the effects of climate change and upholding human rights. This is in clear contrast to the policies pursued by Donald Trump's administration in the US. As a result, bilateral relations with the US will be strained during the remainder of the Trump administration. Canada will, nonetheless, seek to preserve relations with the US, its most important diplomatic and economic partner by far. Where possible, Canada will attempt to circumvent the White House by strengthening its ties to other levels of US government. Canada will also increase efforts to diversify trade.
The signing in November 2018 of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which will replace NAFTA and preserve the trilateral arrangement, mitigates significant trade risk for Canada. The revised deal maintains most of the substance of the earlier deal. In particular, the USMCA retains the Chapter 19 dispute-resolution mechanism, which Canada relies on to protect some of its industries (primarily lumber) from potential US anti-dumping measures. It also grants the US greater access to the Canadian market for dairy, poultry and eggs (these sectors are managed by the government to ensure sufficiently high prices for farmers). Canada also negotiated an exemption from any future tariffs that the US might impose on automotive imports. The lifting in May of US tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminium imports has removed a key obstacle to ratification of the USMCA. However, the timing for ratification of the agreement poses a challenge for all three administrations. Ongoing delays on the US-Mexico side, and Canada's parliamentary recess until November 2019 will complicate the ratification process. Our central forecast is that the USMCA will be ratified by all three nations, but this process could extend into next year. Downside risks to ratification will grow as time passes, owing to the start of the presidential election season in the US.
The implementation of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) is expected to provide enhanced access to key Asian markets over the forecast period. A trade deal signed with the EU in 2016 has removed 98% of the EU tariff lines. With full implementation, the figure is set to rise to 99%.
China was a key target for the government's trade diversification policy until December, when Meng Wanzhou, a senior executive of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, was detained in Canada at the request of US authorities on fraud charges (that she denies). Bitter exchanges between Canada and China since her arrest have cast a chill on bilateral relations. In March the Canadian government announced that it would proceed with hearings on her extradition. In response, China has detained two Canadians on charges of spying, sentenced two others convicted of drug crimes to death and used non-tariff barriers to impede imports from Canada, including canola (rapeseed), bull semen and meat. Bilateral relations will remain tense for as long as Ms Meng faces the threat of extradition to the US.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government will seek to support domestic industries that are adversely affected by US trade protectionism and Canada's trade issues with China. Measures to boost the competitiveness of Canadian businesses following tax cuts in the US last year included a tax break on capital expenditure in manufacturing. However, the government will struggle to balance environmental policy with support for the fossil fuel industry. It has rolled out a national carbon tax of C$20/tonne (US$15/tonne) in provinces that did not have an equivalent carbon pricing programme in place. This tax will rise to C$50/tonne by 2022. But it has also approved the controversial C$7.4bn (US$5.5bn) expansion of the Trans Mountain pipeline, which it now owns. The project still faces some regulatory hurdles, and construction work, which is scheduled to begin this year, could be delayed further by legal challenges.
Policymakers will continue to keep a close eye on the residential property market, which remains a key risk owing to monetary policy tightening last year and overleveraged Canadian households. Measures introduced by the federal government and provincial governments in Ontario and BC have helped to cool the housing market. In Vancouver and Toronto, foreign buyers are now subject to a 15% tax on property purchases, while the federal government has tightened mortgage requirements nationwide, which has improved the quality of new mortgage lending. National house prices have softened modestly since December, although trends vary across the country. We expect the housing market to remain sluggish in 2019, reflecting a combination of tighter lending standards, continued affordability pressures, and diminished investor activity, although a major correction is unlikely in the absence of higher interest rates.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The government is committed to a programme of infrastructure and other spending that will entail a series of budget deficits, but this will be partially offset by increased receipts due to the introduction of the carbon tax and greater tax income as a result of cannabis legalisation. However, lower average oil prices in 2019-20 compared with 2018 will weigh on plans to reduce the fiscal deficit, as increased government support will be expected to shore up the economy and government receipts are likely to undershoot official projections.
According to the federal budget for fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March) handed down in March, the budget deficit for 2019/20 will be C$19.8bn (US$14.8bn), equivalent to 0.9% of GDP. Official projections show the budget deficit declining to C$9.8bn, equivalent to 0.4% of GDP, by 2023/24. We project that the fiscal deficit will expand from 0.4% of GDP in 2018 (our fiscal forecasts are calendar-year based) to 0.9% of GDP in 2019 and 1% of GDP in 2020. The government will look to narrow the deficit in the longer term, and we expect it to fall gradually, to 0.7% of GDP by 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted its policy rate by 125 basis points between July 2017 and October 2018, in response to rising inflation, and to discourage highly indebted households from accumulating further debt. The BoC has since kept rates steady, reflecting a sharp drop in inflation in early 2019, and weak real GDP growth in the first quarter. The year-on-year inflation rate has since picked up to around the BoC's 2% inflation target, while the economy appears to have perked up in the second quarter. However, the BoC has cautioned that the economic outlook remains clouded by global trade tensions, which will continue to weigh on export growth and investment.
We forecast that the Federal Reserve (the Fed, the US central bank) will cut its policy rate in December 2019, with two more rate cuts to follow in 2020. We continue to expect that the BoC will keep its policy rate unchanged this year, as it views the current level of 1.75% as stimulatory. However, we now expect it to sanction a 25-basis-point cut in 2020, as US growth slows further; because of the close ties between the two countries, this will weigh on economic growth in Canada. The BoC will begin gradually to tighten monetary policy again from 2021.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth slowed to 1.9% in 2018, from 3% in 2017, and we expect the pace of economic expansion to soften further in 2019, to an average of 1.6%. Previous monetary tightening, high household debt levels and the subdued housing market will weigh on private consumption growth this year. However, solid growth in government spending will help cushion the impact. Export growth is also expected to moderate as a result of weaker economic expansion in the US, Canada's key export market.
Much of 2018 was characterised by the escalating trade dispute with the US. The renegotiation of NAFTA reduces one of the key downside risks to our forecast, although the timeline for the ratification of the successor agreement, the USMCA, could be extended into 2020. Canadian producers and manufacturers will benefit from the removal in May of US tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminium imports, and the end of the retaliatory import tariffs that Canada imposed, but are feeling the pinch from trade restrictions imposed by China on some Canadian farm exports, such as canola. Global trade uncertainty remains a major downside risk to out forecast. Other risks to the economic outlook include a sharp drop in global oil prices, which would act as a drag on economic activity.
Growth in the US and world trade will continue to lose steam in 2020, when we expect real GDP growth in Canada to remain well below its long-term trend, at 1.6%. The pace of economic expansion is expected to pick up again in 2021, and real GDP growth will average 2.4% per year in 2022-23. This will be supported by continued public investment in infrastructure and stronger export growth, driven by recovering demand in the US and enhanced trade ties with the EU and CPTPP members.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Rising oil prices throughout much of 2018 and the increasingly protectionist trade policy of the US added to price pressures last year, when the headline rate of consumer price inflation accelerated to an average of 2.2%. The inflation rate fell back to 1.6% year on year in the first quarter of 2019, below the BoC's 2% target rate, owing to lower petrol prices and the impact of previous monetary tightening by the central bank. However, it has picked up more quickly than we expected, to 2.3% year on year in May. In view of this, we have pushed up our forecast for consumer price inflation in 2019, which we now expect will average 2% (previously 1.8%). Subdued economic growth and generally lower oil prices will lead to a further easing in the inflation rate next year, before it picks up again from 2021 as the economy strengthens.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Falling oil prices and slowing growth weighed on the currency late last year and in early 2019. As a result, the Canadian dollar will depreciate slightly this year, on average, against its US counterpart, to C$1.32:US$1. Downward pressure on the Canadian dollar next year from continued weak economic growth, soft oil prices and modest monetary easing by the BoC will be mitigated by deeper interest-rate cuts from the Fed, keeping the local currency broadly unchanged at an average of C$1.33:US$1 in 2020. A pick-up in growth from 2021, and the resumption of monetary tightening, will underpin a modest appreciation in the Canadian dollar in the latter part of the forecast period, with the currency forecast to average C$1.30:US$1 in 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The exchange rate, commodity prices and the health of the US economy will continue to shape the outlook for the current account, which will remain in deficit in 2019-23. The impact of softer global oil prices in 2019-20 will be offset by slowing domestic demand and, therefore, import growth. The merchandise trade deficit and the shortfall on the current account will therefore remain broadly stable as a proportion of GDP, with the latter averaging 2.6% of GDP during 2019-20. The CPTPP, the effects of which will first be felt at the start of the next decade, will result in higher trade volumes between Canada and Pacific nations. We expect that this will help to narrow the current-account deficit to 2.1% of GDP by 2023.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), is under severe economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit has for some time believed that the Maduro regime's position is unsustainable, and we currently base our forecasts on a political transition within our five-year forecast period that introduces an interim administration led by Juan Guaidó, who we assume will undertake emergency adjustment measures, and prepare the ground for eventual free and fair elections. Currently, we assume that there will be some sort of regime change by the end of 2019. The timing and shape of the transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period (2019-23) to be characterised by political instability.
Our expectation of a change of government later in 2019 implies huge changes to policymaking as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms required to resolve the economic crisis.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under the transition and successor governments. Many of these policies have been outlined already, with the Guaidó administration seeking to reassure stakeholders in multilateral institutions and in potential donor nations such as the US and Europe of its capacity to stabilise the economy, address the humanitarian emergency, generate trust and legal security, ensure access to basic public services, and reactivate the oil industry.
The pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and how this stability might be impaired by likely demands for some politically difficult reforms from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.

Venezuela is in 79th position globally in the business environment rankings for 2019-23, up from 80th in the historical period. Assuming regime change, improvements are expected, but it will take time for reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment to bear fruit.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of rollback of interventionist measures like price controls, but political-instability concerns slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt at attracting investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on the private sector's access to foreign currency remain in place.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2021-23: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Large-scale emigration of skilled labour complicates hiring.
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid means that rationing and unpredictable blackouts continue. A new government undertakes some repairs to the power network.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and side-lining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$18bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply let to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the current-account surplus at 2% of GDP that year.
