Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), is under severe economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit has for some time believed that the Maduro regime's position is unsustainable, and we currently base our forecasts on a political transition within our five-year forecast period that introduces an interim administration led by Juan Guaidó, who we assume will undertake emergency adjustment measures, and prepare the ground for eventual free and fair elections. Currently, we assume that there will be some sort of regime change by the end of 2019. The timing and shape of the transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period (2019-23) to be characterised by political instability.
Our forecast for regime change is based on the extent of the economic and humanitarian crisis currently unfolding in Venezuela. This has deeply damaged support for Mr Maduro among the population at large; we believe that it will ultimately erode support for Mr Maduro among key supporters in the military who currently prop him up in power. It is less clear, however, what the exact trigger for regime change will be. There are three main paths to a political transition: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We believe that the risk of military action, by the US or Colombia, is very low; although negotiations have been ongoing in recent weeks, we believe trust issues on both sides will be insurmountable and do not expect a negotiated solution to Venezuela's crisis.
On this basis, we believe the most likely scenario for regime change is some sort of internal coup. With US sanctions adding to the problem of dollar scarcity, Mr Maduro can no longer guarantee the regime's raison d'etre-the enrichment of its members-and we expect pragmatists within government and within the military to turn on him and pave the way for some sort of political transition. A failed uprising on April 30th demonstrated the difficulty of this sort of effort, and has incurred a heavy political cost, as the regime has become ever more vigilant of discontent among its ranks. However, the April uprising, which apparently included the participation of top-ranking government officials alongside Mr Guaidó, confirmed the existence of cracks within the regime's ranks at the highest levels. On this basis, our forecast for regime change still stands.
This forecast is underpinned by three key assumptions. Firstly, that regime pragmatists will prevail over hardliners. Despite the ongoing collapse of the patronage system, there are risks to this assumption, considering frequent purges within the military and the presence of dozens of important military figures, leading to co-ordination problems. Secondly, that regime members will deem Mr Guaidó's amnesty offers credible. Risks to this assumption include a deep-seated distrust of the opposition and fear of being prosecuted outside of Venezuela (a credible fear given accusations of drug- and weapon-trafficking levied at regime members). The third assumption underpinning our forecast for a government transition is a continued lack of hard currency to sustain the patronage system. Risks to this forecast come in the form of greater than expected support from Russia or China, and from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities that could be providing the regime with more hard currency than we currently expect.
We recognise the very high risks to our baseline view, and believe there are two main alternate scenarios. The first, and more likely, alternate scenario is the maintenance of the status quo, with a protest-fatigued population, the regime hunkering down, the opposition deflating, and the country becoming increasingly isolated and impoverished. The second scenario is one of prolonged chaos-including, possibly, armed conflict among regime factions. That said, we expect neither of these scenarios to be tenable in the medium to long term: with no prospect of real reform, we believe that a chronically weak economy will ultimately make Mr Maduro's position untenable. Moreover, violent, chaotic conflict in Venezuela could prove the line in the sand that provokes some sort of military action by the US and by Venezuela's Latin American neighbours to put an end to the crisis. For these reasons, we continue for now to believe that regime change in the forecast period remains likely, even if it does not occur in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The opposition's recently announced plans for a transitional government call for the renovation of all electoral authorities and for elections within 12 months of the transitional government's formation. Although this timeline is extremely ambitious given the scale of the task, we tentatively expect national elections to take place by the end of 2020. International assistance in organising the elections would be necessary and forthcoming. The task will be huge, as deep reforms to the electoral authority, to the electoral registry and to the voting system will be required, and rebuilding trust in the system will be difficult.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community. Most governments in the Americas, under the banner of the Lima Group, have recognised his presidency. The US is Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, instituting crippling oil sanctions and openly calling for the military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. The US's hawkish approach introduces risks of a military intervention. We currently do not foresee large-scale military action, in part because such an initiative lacks international legitimacy. However, if tension ratchets up and domestic violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the necessary financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and the state oil company, PDVSA. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but with little apparent success in terms of investment, and we believe that Russia and especially China would be willing to work with a successor government in an attempt to protect their current investments in Venezuela. Indeed the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, recently expressed his willingness to potentially work with Mr Guaidó, with the condition that he is legitimately chosen via a presidential election.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Our expectation of a change of government later in 2019 implies huge changes to policymaking as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms required to resolve the economic crisis. There has been evidence in recent months of attempts to tighten monetary policy to rein in hyperinflation and to abandon foreign-exchange controls (with few foreign reserves left to protect). However, we believe such efforts are doomed to failure without comprehensive microeconomic reform and improvements in rule of law and policy predictability that will not be forthcoming under the present regime.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under the transition and successor governments. Many of these policies have been outlined already, with the Guaidó administration seeking to reassure stakeholders in multilateral institutions and in potential donor nations such as the US and Europe of its capacity to stabilise the economy, address the humanitarian emergency, generate trust and legal security, ensure access to basic public services, and reactivate the oil industry. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and how this stability might be impaired by likely demands for some politically difficult reforms from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$46bn in 2020-23) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect that the non-financial public-sector deficit this year will be well into double digit levels as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Under our expectation of substantial currency adjustment, the public debt/GDP ratio will rise dramatically in coming years; however, our forecasts assume that a combination of debt restructuring and deep fiscal adjustment gradually bring the debt ratios under control. The process will be complicated, however, by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds and all but one of PDVSA's bonds are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or a change in government. However, other investors have taken claims to the courts, and the results of these court battles will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining company, Crystallex, is seeking to collect an arbitration award by seizing shares of Citgo, PDVSA's US subsidiary. A ruling on the treatment of PDVSA as an "alter ego" of the government is pending, and will have implications for future debt restructuring. The US government now considers Citgo to be under Mr Guaidó's purview, but nonetheless, the risk of seizure of Citgo, its Caribbean facilities and even shipments, will remain high in the short term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to print money in the short term. However, a significant increase in reserve requirements for the banking sector since the start of the year has had a temporary stabilising effect, which has slowed hyperinflationary pressures and allowed the bolívar to stabilise somewhat over rcent weeks. On the basis that this measure is insufficient to tackle underlying inflation pressures, we expect monthly inflation to rise again in the short term. But based on our assumption that a transition government that places a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation will soon come to power, we do not currently project a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of over 1,000,000% experienced during 2018 (though there are substantial political risks to this forecast). Instead, under a new government, we expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of an emergency macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency, a temporary peg or outright currency substitution in such a context is highly likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 18.5% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. Our forecast for an economic recovery in 2021-23 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by international assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 60% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2019, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Moreover, power cuts are now very common-a result of severe underinvestment in the country's power infrastructure-and have further damaged Venezuela's overall economic capacity.
Our forecast for a recovery in investment from 2020 assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment. We expect oil output to bottom out at 700,000 barrels/day (b/d) over the coming quarters, kept from going lower by PDVSA's joint-venture partners. In line with our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in 2020 but will end the forecast period (2019-23) well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017.
Export volumes will start to recover in 2020 on the back of the oil sector recovery, but an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb some of the projected increase in oil output. At the same time, import demand will rise sharply in 2020. All this will constrain the rebound of GDP initially, but in 2022-23, we do expect real GDP growth to gather some pace.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Severely reduced domestic supply, dollar constraints on import capacity, and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official inflation data were recently published by the BCV, but there is a significant gap between these data and other sources. Amid continuing questions over the data, we will, for now, continue to use the monthly series produced by the National Assembly. These data have shown some disinflation in recent months, with monthly inflation falling below the hyperinflation "threshold" of 50% per month. Huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand persist, however, and we expect inflation to remain extremely high for as long as the Maduro regime remains in power. On the basis of our assumption of regime change in the short term, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation. However, supply bottlenecks and bouts of inflationary pressure are likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our current baseline forecast of a political transition later in 2019, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) to try to tackle the inflation problem is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such moves is hard to predict. Our forecasts currently assume extremely large currency adjustments that restore some competitiveness to the local currency in real terms over time. For now, and with few foreign reserves left to protect, the Maduro regime has announced a loosening of currency controls. However, access to dollars via formal means will remain extremely difficult, and we believe that the foreign-exchange system will remain highly controlled in practice. In this environment a strong black-market exchange rate premium is likely to re-emerge. By end-June the premium was widening but was still small by historical comparison, with the official rate at around BsS6,725:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of over BsS7,900:US$1.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
We have revised our current-account data in line with the recent publication of official data for 2017-18 by the BCV, which show that Venezuela continued to post current-account surpluses in the period on the back of higher non-oil exports than we had expected. However, we continue to project a shift into current-account deficit this year, bearing in mind the collapse of export earnings stemming from US sanctions on the oil trade. This deficit will emerge despite the non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2019 alone). We have also excluded repayments to Chinese lenders to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data, on which our debt forecasts are based. Later in the forecast period we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, but we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been severely reduced. These factors will keep the current account in deficit, although we expect the latter to narrow to a manageable level of around 3% of GDP towards the end of the forecast period.
We currently expect that a new administration will secure sufficient finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. It hinges on substantial IMF finance, rapid macroeconomic stabilisation, the fast resolution of a debt-renegotiation process, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services

BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Muhammadu Buhari won a second and final four-year presidential term on February 23rd. The policy agenda he campaigned on did not involve considerable reform, only cosmetic improvements to the business environment.
The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This will create a potent mixture that will lead to frequent violent instability and directly affect key economic sectors.
Policy will be interventionist. Import bans on agricultural and manufacturing goods will be widened to support local industry and farmers, and the Central Bank of Nigeria will maintain an overvalued official naira rate with which to channel cheap US dollars to preferred buyers.
Even though a multiple exchange-rate system will persist, non-official rates will converge and so in reality Nigeria will run a dual exchange-rate regime. Oil prices will be high enough to prevent a return to capital controls (as temporarily imposed in 2016), and the official rate will be kept fairly stable.
Fiscal expenditure will remain dominated by recurrent spending, despite attempts to boost capital investment. Efforts to boost non-oil tax revenue will be constrained by weak bureaucratic capacity and low economic growth.
Constrained by a crippling infrastructure deficit, as well as tight monetary conditions and instability in key agricultural regions, economic growth will be well below levels needed to boost job creation and increase living standards. This will perpetuate instability in a vicious cycle.
Inflation will remain high over the forecast period (2019-23) amid expansionary fiscal policy and high food prices stemming from government efforts to limit imports and support local producers. This in turn will keep credit conditions tight; even with some relaxation of the policy rate from 2021, inflation will be running too high for sustained monetary loosening, and credit growth will generally be slow.
The multiple-exchange-rate regime will not be dismantled under a Buhari administration; the arrangement is critical for making petrol subsidies affordable and underpins the government's interventionist approach to industrialisation.
Oil prices and exports will fall in 2019-20 but so will imports. Both imports and exports will then expand in 2021-23 but a current-account surplus will be maintained throughout the forecast period.

Nigeria's business environment score will improve slightly but its global and regional rankings will worsen as the administration struggles with the reform process and other countries make more significant improvements.
Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. The upstream oil sector will remain characterised by joint-ventures between the state oil company and multinationals.
2021-23: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress will be slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: An attempt to sell the state's interest in oil joint ventures with multinationals will meet serious challenges (the policy has been around for years), with resistance in the legislature to the permanent loss of a revenue stream.
2021-23: Higher world oil prices and so easing fiscal pressures lessen the need to embark on a divestment programme. Energy companies will anyway be hesitant to increase their stake in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Import bans are widened, but capital controls will not be necessary barring another (not expected) oil price crash.
2021-23: A premium between the overvalued official and parallel-market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2019-20: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Value-added tax (VAT) is increased to fund a higher minimum wage, which will markedly increase the fiscal cost of the civil service.
2021-23: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation, particularly for offshore oilfields. The need for new consumer taxes is alleviated by higher world oil prices and, as a result, hydrocarbons revenue.
Financing
2019-20: Funding for well-planned projects becomes easier to raise domestically following the completion of the 2019 elections, as local capital markets deepen (with greater foreign participation) and the banking sector develops.
2021-23: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts savings and investment.
The labour market
2019-20: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2021-23: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff; unemployment remains high and the market loose.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints and is crowded out by other spending categories, including debt-servicing. Although there should be growth in private-sector investment, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2021-23: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2021-23: Research spending is likely to remain low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multiparty democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in 2015, and Mr Buhari secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 has almost wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Muhammadu Buhari won a presidential election in February 2019 and will remain in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. For any Nigerian leader, managing the country's myriad security threats would be an insoluble challenge, but under Mr Buhari there are particular reasons to expect serious unrest.
The foremost challenge to stability is an over-stretched military and police force, which will be unable to manage simultaneous security crises. The government cannot afford to upgrade Nigeria's security capabilities to an adequate level without making sweeping reforms to increase the tax take, and no such overhaul is anticipated.
Conflict in the north-east between the government and two Islamist terrorist groups, Boko Haram and the Islamic State in West Africa Province (ISWAP), is heating up, with insurgents appearing better equipped and staging more audacious attacks than had been the case in recent years. Military setbacks are getting worse and, as this is one of Mr Buhari's voter strongholds, the president will be keen to reassert control over the situation. Boko Haram and ISWAP will be aggressively countered, but the north-east of Nigeria will remain a low-level conflict zone, albeit isolated, and the campaign will divert military resources from pockets of severe instability elsewhere. One such hotspot is just to the south, in the agricultural Middle Belt of Nigeria, where violent clashes between settled farmers and nomads competing for land have killed several thousand civilians in recent years. Formal land-titling is a potential solution to the crisis, but as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another, it would prove too contentious. Ultimately there is no foreseeable end to violence in the Middle Belt. Vigilantes will be used to make up for shortfalls in formal security personnel, but not be an effective substitute. Again, the direct effect of the conflict on the security situation will be localised, but the entire country will feel the secondary effects in the form of constricted food supply and, as a result, consumer prices.
The military and police will be too poorly equipped to suppress pervasive banditry and kidnapping in the north and north-west, where widespread poverty and unemployment are feeding into a cycle of crime that will be difficult (if not impossible) to break, given a bleak economic outlook. Finally, militants in the oil-producing south will remain aggrieved by inertia over their key demand for more federal revenue from hydrocarbons to be kept locally for development. Wholesale reform of the oil sector is a massive task and one that The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect to be achieved in the forecast 2019-23 period. Our assumption is that attacks by aggrieved militants and saboteurs on oil infrastructure will continue to be a major security problem in Delta State, with indirect consequences for the entire federation in the form of disrupted oil exports.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The election in February 2019 reaffirmed a deep electoral divide between the APC-supporting north and southern Nigeria, a stronghold of the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP). In the next general election in 2023, custom dictates that the candidates of both main parties will be southerners, giving the PDP a chance to improve on abysmally low turnout there in the 2019 presidential vote, which cost them victory. Moreover, Nigeria's economic outlook is bleak, with growth barely keeping pace with a rapidly increasing population. Much of the cause of rising poverty and high unemployment will be political in origin; the parliamentary election gave the APC a large majority in both houses, which in theory should be enabling, but Mr Buhari's first term was marked by divisions between the executive and parliament (as had happened to presidents before him), and crucial bills including the national budget were delayed by months. As legislators typically prioritise the interests of their constituents over party and federation in Nigeria, similar tensions could easily reoccur in Mr Buhari's second stint. This will prevent meaningful reform (for example on managing the oil sector), and inactivity on such fronts means that the APC will be the subject of voter frustration. The PDP candidate should be able to capitalise from this, giving them an edge from the start.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat that they pose. Relations with the US will be mixed; the administration of Donald Trump is willing to sell Nigeria military hardware, but Mr Trump's disapproval of the trade deficit the US runs with Nigeria (particularly owing to Nigerian import restrictions) could strain ties. Relations with the EU will be largely cordial but subject to tensions over Nigerian migrants seeking to enter Europe and Nigerian efforts to repatriate funds in European banks that were allegedly looted by former rulers.
India will remain important as the largest market for Nigerian oil and become a bigger source of foreign investment. China will also remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will fall short of the headline-grabbing pledges made, given an extremely challenging local business environment. Nigeria will remain an important player in Sub-Saharan Africa given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Economic policy during Mr Buhari's second and final term is likely to carry over the interventionist policies adopted during his first. Measures to liberalise and unify foreign-exchange markets or move to more market-led pricing in the energy sector will not be pursued. An overvalued official naira rate is critical for maintaining petrol subsidies, and Mr Buhari will not willingly attempt to dismantle consumer price caps and risk a popular backlash. Although in practice very little foreign exchange is traded at the official rate, the existence of a multiple-exchange-rate system will be off-putting to foreign direct investors or those acquiring illiquid assets, for fear of a return of capital controls (last imposed in 2016). Concerns about this will be especially pronounced whenever global crude prices soften, but the omnipresent risk of convertibility restrictions will ultimately keep foreign direct investment well below Nigeria's potential throughout the forecast period, with inflows expected to be below 1% of GDP in all years.
Elsewhere, efforts will be made to cleanse and reboot inefficient state-owned industries such as the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC)-which dominates all segments of the oil sector-but no structural reforms will take place. Generally, Mr Buhari's approach will be to make existing entities such as the NNPC become profitable rather than relinquish state control over them entirely. There will be some effort to reduce the NNPC's stake in the upstream oil joint-ventures that it has with international oil companies, but demand will be held back by the difficulty of operating in Nigeria and uncertainty about fiscal terms (with deep political divisions about how to distribute hydrocarbons revenue having stalled critical legislation). As a result, investor interest will be short of official expectations, and parliament will resist selling off key public assets for a low price. As a consequence, the NNPC will continue to domineer the oil sector, with politicians and other members of the political elite working to direct the flow of resources to favour specific geo-ethnic and political constituencies (as well as for illicit personal gain).
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
We expect small fiscal deficits throughout the forecast period. The government wants to diversify its revenue base away from oil, and non-oil revenue will rise through efforts to collect overdue taxes, and a probable hike to value-added tax (VAT), but any increase in revenue will be from an extremely low base. Instability in many parts of the country will also impede collection. Petrol subsidies (whereby losses incurred by the NNPC's retail arm are deducted from federal revenue) will be another drain, and budgeted revenue levels will be undermined by overambitious oil production targets. For example, in 2019 the government expects output of 2.3m barrels/day-a level not seen since the oil price slump, and one that will be unobtainable given underinvestment and OPEC production quotas. In all, federally retained revenue is not expected to rise above 3.9% of GDP, a ratio only attained in 2022 when oil prices are at their highest within the forecast period.
After some projected expansion in 2018, spending will decline as a proportion of GDP in 2019 with a low capital budget and poor execution. Partly offsetting this will be higher spending on wages and public-sector benefits, including via the roll-out of a new (increased) minimum wage. Generally, fiscal flexibility will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and, as a result, revenue-under pressure and there being considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. Altogether, we expect an average budget deficit averaging 1.9% of GDP over 2019-23.
Long-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against a low revenue base. Debt service already takes up close to one-third of federal government income. A sovereign default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is weaker.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
Monetary policy will concentrate on fostering an economic recovery. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The private sector is desperate for cheaper credit, but inflation will remain above the targeted upper limit of 9% set by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN). On balance, we expect interest rates not to move much in 2019-20, notwithstanding a small rate cut by the CBN in March (upheld in May). Rates will then fall in 2021 and stabilise during 2022-23 as economic activity picks up and inflation hovers above or around the target. However, real interest rates will be too high to be viable for much of the private sector.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The economy will for the most part be mired in a low-growth cycle, although there will be improvements over time. In 2019-20 the economy will be held back by power shortages, insecurity, high inflation and tight credit conditions. A slower global economy will also hold back export-oriented sectors. In 2021-23, as global markets strengthen and inflation gradually decelerates-allowing for some monetary easing-the rate of growth will quicken, although remain well below potential at an annual average of 3.3%. This is still abnormally low for Nigeria, especially as we forecast population growth of 2.6% a year for the 2019-23 forecast period.
From a sectoral viewpoint, agriculture will record only lacklustre growth; although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will continue to be severe impediments. Industrial production will be curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, and investment will be held back by uncertainty about future fiscal terms. Egina, a new offshore oilfield, will drive higher condensate output, but hydrocarbons production is not expected to return to levels prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash. That said, a private refinery coming on stream by 2021 will be a boost to downstream oil activity in the latter years of the forecast period. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of cheap goods from abroad, which are often smuggled into the country to bypass import bans, as well as power supply gaps. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth than industry, but it will nonetheless be held back by protectionism (affecting trade), tight credit conditions affecting areas such as real estate and finance, and the struggle in the communications sector to profitably roll out data services beyond urban hubs.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
From a rate of 12.1% in 2018, average inflation will remain elevated at 11.8% in 2019, as a 67% increase in the minimum wage combines with disruptions to local food supply and widening import restrictions. In 2020 inflation will remain well above the CBN's targeted ceiling of 9%, at 10.9%, as demand-side forces from the minimum-wage rise continue. It is also likely that there will be a three percentage-point hike to VAT, with oil prices (and, as a result, fiscal revenue) likely to come under pressure in that year. With the base effects from this fading, core inflation will gradually ease over the rest of the forecast period, bringing the headline rate down with it to an average of 8.8% in 2023. Conflict and supply disruptions in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's agricultural heartland-will prevent a faster slide, together with widening protectionist measures that limit relatively cheap imports from abroad. Currently 43 items are barred from foreign-exchange access, the most recent addition being textiles, and the CBN wants to increase the list to 50 as a means of stimulating non-oil activity.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2019-23, with an official rate used for government business and a market-determined rate applicable to investors and exporters, which will be broadly in line with retail rates and the parallel market. Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors deemed important for economic or political reasons, including the NNPC, which budgets for petrol imports at the official rate. Overall the set-up is not expected to be tampered with. Although we anticipate a fall in exports over 2019-20, the decrease will not be steep or sustained enough to force a devaluation of the official exchange rate. Over this period flat or declining interest rates in the US (we expect a 50-basis-point drop to be executed by the Federal Reserve, the US central bank, in 2020) will also support foreign-exchange supply via portfolio inflows. Higher global crude prices thereafter mean a flat official rate is likely throughout the forecast period. In real terms, currency stability (for both the official and more market-determined rates) means real appreciation of the naira against trading partners as inflation remains high. For this reason there is a downside risk of policymakers opting to devalue or allowing more market-determined rates to weaken in order to regain international competitiveness. However, the CBN governor, Godwin Emefiele, is set against the idea, and in any case industrial strategy is focused on import-substitution and supplying the domestic market. As a result, devaluation is not included in the core forecast.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. For example, the current market-determined rate, known as the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Rate Fixing (Nafex), has only been in full operation since April 2017, making historical calculations challenging. Indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued, which is in line with official calculations.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The profile of export earnings will move in tandem with oil production and price trends. Output gains will keep earnings in growth in 2019, and higher global prices in 2021-23 and continued output gains (with a new mega-refinery coming on stream in around 2021) will do likewise. Only in 2020-when prices fall faster than incremental production gains-will exports drop.
Nigeria's government actively promotes import-substitution through foreign-exchange restrictions on certain goods (mainly manufactures and agricultural produce). However, this policy is oriented more around stimulating local industry than reducing imports per se, and an overvalued naira will contribute to fairly strong consumer demand. Imports will fall only slightly in 2019-20, however, reflecting lower global crude prices (Nigeria imports almost all its petrol requirement). As the economy gathers pace in 2021-23 and global oil prices rise, imports will then grow faster. Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation in the oil sector will keep the services and primary income balances firmly in deficit. Workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, albeit dipping in 2020 as growth falters in the US (home to a large Nigerian diaspora). Overall, the current-account surplus will average 1.6% of GDP in 2019-20, widening to 2.4% of GDP in 2021-23 as oil prices strengthen and the new refinery comes on stream.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Full text: Fact sheet

Background: The political geography of Europe has been defined by two world wars. The EU's creation dates back to the Rome Treaty of 1957, which created the European Economic Community between the six founding EU member states (France, Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg). After four enlargements in 1973 (UK, Denmark, Ireland), 1981 (Greece), 1986 (Spain and Portugal) and 1995 (Austria, Finland and Sweden), the EU counted 15 members. The collapse in 1991 of the Soviet Union provided an opportunity to expand the EU eastwards. Ten new member states (eight from the former communist bloc) were admitted to the EU in 2004, followed by a further two in 2007, and Croatia in 2013. In June 2016 the UK electorate voted in a referendum to withdraw from the EU; UK-EU negotiations on the UK's exit from the EU have so far been difficult. The economic transition of the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) has proceeded more smoothly than those of other east European countries. The effects of war in the former Yugoslavia in the 1990s and a slower pace of reform have shaped developments in south-eastern Europe. In the Commonwealth of Independent States, many countries continue to have deep economic and political ties with Russia.
Political structure: All 28 EU member states are parliamentary democracies, although in some of the newer, former communist members in particular, the substance of democracy-including a political culture based on trust and political participation-is often absent. The communist period lasted much longer in the former Soviet Union, and political developments in most parts of that region have been characterised by a drift towards authoritarianism.
Policy issues: Many aspects of domestic policy for EU member states-notably those relating to the single market-are decided collectively at EU level. A total of 19 EU members share the euro as their currency and are subject to a single monetary policy administered by the European Central Bank. They are supposed to comply with common fiscal rules, although these have sometimes been ignored. During the euro zone debt crisis, several member states (Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain) received financial support from the EU and the IMF in return for fiscal and economic reforms. Outside the EU, the speed and extent of reform, and institutional change, vary widely. Countries with proximity to Western markets and with stable political outlooks have proceeded faster-and more successfully-with economic stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation. Institutional problems, such as weakness in the rule of law and widespread corruption, plague much of non-EU Europe.
Taxation: Individual tax regimes operate in all countries. All EU member states must operate a system of value-added tax (VAT), with a minimum of 15% as the standard rate.
Foreign trade: If intra-EU trade is included, the EU accounts for about half of all global trade. About 60% of trade conducted by EU member states is intra-regional.
EU28, leading non-EU export markets 2018 % of total EU28, leading non-EU sources of imports 2018 % of total

Summary
Political stability
Popular disaffection with the traditional mainstream parties will persist during the forecast period (2019-23), leading to greater success for far-right, far-left and centrist parties in elections; difficulties in government formation; and the creation of unusual (and in some cases unstable) coalitions.
The European Parliament elections resulted in a more fragmented political landscape. The centre-right European People's Party (EPP) and the centre-left Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) remained the two largest groups in the European Parliament in the 2019 elections, but lost their majority for the first time. The appointment process for a number of top EU jobs becoming available later this year will be tricky, and is likely to take some time.
The UK remains in political deadlock over Brexit. The EU has stated that it will not revise the Withdrawal Agreement Bill, but the British parliament has rejected both this deal and a "no-deal" Brexit. The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that a general election is the most likely way out of the current impasse, with a second referendum a subsequent possibility. A no-deal Brexit remains a significant risk.
Economic policy
We expect the euro zone to resist steps towards full fiscal integration, but the Franco-German axis will drive forward some reforms in the coming years.
A number of countries will continue to push back against EU and euro zone rules. Most notably, the dispute between the Italian government and the European Commission over the country's fiscal plans will continue later in 2019, with the imposition of an excessive-deficit procedure (EDP) now looking likely.
We expect the European Central Bank (ECB) to maintain a dovish stance, in view of the pronounced downside risks to the euro zone's economic outlook. We expect the ECB to raise its deposit rate in June 2020 and the main refinancing rate in December 2020, with tightening proceeding thereafter at a gradual pace.
Economic growth
The euro zone's economic recovery became broad-based and sustained in 2017, but sentiment indicators declined and growth slowed in 2018. This loss of momentum has carried through into 2019 and we expect a substantial slowdown in growth rates across the bloc this year.
The main reason for the slowdown is a deterioration of the external environment, with softer global trade and high geopolitical uncertainty, reflecting US-China trade tensions, the threat of a US tariff increase on EU automotive exports and the risk of a no-deal Brexit in the UK.
However, domestic demand has remained firm, with private consumption supported by widespread labour market improvements, and investment growth fuelled by high capacity-utilisation rates and favourable lending conditions.
Business environment rankings
The business environment has improved in most European countries, as the post-crisis economic recovery has gathered pace. However, fragilities remain.

Political outlook: Political stability
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects political risk to remain high in Europe throughout the forecast period (2019-23). The negative political fallout from the global financial crisis and euro zone crisis, coming on top of the long-term erosion of the traditional political party system, is proving to be electorally disruptive. The fragmentation of the political landscape is leading to delays in forming governments after elections, unstable coalition governments, and a gradual hardening in rhetoric and policy on migration. The rise in populism has also hampered significant reform efforts at both the national and regional levels, and a meaningful overhaul of the European institutional framework is unlikely.
Leading issues for European political stability as we approach the mid-point of 2019 include the ongoing fallout from the Brexit vote in the UK, the nomination process for the top jobs becoming available later this year at the EU institutions and the political impact of hardening attitudes towards migration.
Challenges for the EU today include Brexit, new leaders and migration
The UK's vote in June 2016 to leave the EU represents a challenge for the bloc, and the departure of one of the EU's largest members will continue to reverberate after the UK leaves (probably in 2019 or 2020). The country's departure will leave a hole in the EU budget, which will be difficult to overcome without generating antagonism within the bloc. However, so far Brexit has resulted in increased European solidarity rather than tensions between member states. This is because several member states-including France and Germany-are keen to send a strong political message to governments contemplating exiting the EU that a departure from the bloc is inevitably difficult, and must ultimately be inferior to EU membership.
In the wake of the European Parliament elections on May 23rd-26th the EU is hard at work on the appointments to a number of top jobs coming up in the second half of 2019. The presidencies of the European Commission, European Council, European Parliament and European Central Bank (ECB) will all become available, along with a new foreign policy high representative; and the nominations will need to ensure a balance across countries, genders and political preferences. The fact that the European Parliament elections have delivered a more fragmented parliament (compared with the 2014 Parliament elections) means that the process of choosing the next Commission president will be lengthy. The main point for financial markets, however, is that a hawkish new head of the ECB remains unlikely-we expect one of the dovish north European candidates to take this role.
Across the continent populist parties and politicians are putting pressure on mainstream parties to address their concerns, notably on migration and integration policies. The issue of refugee relocation has been a focal point since 2015 for tensions between the EU, which wants to avoid the burden of looking after migrants from falling exclusively on Greece and Italy, where most arrive, and a core of central European countries that do not want to accept these people. Elsewhere, popular concerns about the difficulties of integrating asylum-seekers have led to rising support for far-right parties, and a shift towards the right on the part of many centre-right parties with regards to social issues.
The political scene in Germany will be much less stable than in the recent past
Germany is a leading example of a country where support for the traditionally dominant mainstream parties has declined sharply as the landscape of voter support has become more fragmented. The government installed in Germany in March 2018 is another grand coalition comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU) with the Christian Social Union (CSU, its Bavarian sister party) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD). The election dealt a blow to the two leading parties, which recorded their worst results since the 1950s and brought the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) into the Bundestag (the lower house of parliament), where it is now the largest opposition party.
Germany has played an important role on the EU stage in recent years, under the chancellorship of Angela Merkel since 2005. However, Ms Merkel stepped down as leader of the CDU in December 2018, and her successor, Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, is unlikely to play as high profile an international role. Ms Kramp-Karrenbauer has a similar policy-positioning and consensus-building approach as Ms Merkel, but seems keen to shift the party slightly further to the right, especially on migration, and has made a series of gaffes since her nomination, suggesting that she will not be as adroit a politician as her predecessor.
At the same time, the SPD is in crisis, with its leader, Andrea Nahles, stepping down after an exceptionally poor performance in the European Parliament elections in May. The upcoming leadership contest is likely to hinge on whether the party should remain in the grand coalition, and this raises the risk of a pre-term federal election (before 2021).
In France political stability has returned, for now
In France Mr Macron enjoys the support of a solid majority of deputies in the National Assembly (the lower house of parliament), which has enabled him to make substantial progress on his ambitious legislative agenda since taking office in May 2017. He came to power determined not to give in to the sort of street protests that had derailed the policies of many of his predecessors and front-loaded difficult structural reform efforts in the hope that the results would materialise before the end of his term in 2022.
However, from late 2018 he found himself facing growing criticisms that he was "out of touch" and the "president of the rich", with a demonstration against a proposed fuel-tax rise in November escalating rapidly to a nationwide series of protests and significant violence. Protesters, who are named the "Gilets Jaunes" because of their high-visibility jackets, are angry about stagnant incomes, tax reforms that seem to be squeezing the lower-middle classes and a perceived decline in public services. The government announced EUR10bn in tax concessions in December and held an unprecedented national debate in January-March to allow people to air their grievances. At the end of April Mr Macron announced a raft of new measures to ease the tax burden, lift pensions and boost public service provision.
We expect reform progress to be slower now in France than at the start of Mr Macron's tenure. However, the overall direction of travel is unchanged, and the president's approval ratings have experienced a modest recovery, suggesting that political stability has been recovered in France-at least for now.
Political stability will improve in Spain, but the Catalan issue is still unresolved
In Spain politics has become increasingly unsettled in recent years. Parliamentary fragmentation, a litany of political graft scandals and rising regional nationalism in Catalonia have all posed serious challenges to governance. Against this backdrop, in late April 2019 Spain held its third general election since December 2015. The snap vote was triggered by the rejection at the hands of two Catalan pro-independence parties of the 2019 budget proposal made by the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) government. The PSOE, led by Mr Sánchez, won a decisive victory at the election, raising its vote share from 22.6% in 2016 to nearly 29%. The nationalist, far-right Vox entered the national parliament for the first time after surging to 10.3% of the vote. Government-formation negotiations will be tricky, but we believe that the most likely outcome is a left-wing minority government led by the PSOE, and supported by the far-left party, Unidas Podemos (UP) and several other parties.
Once the government has been formed, we expect an improvement in political stability relative to 2015-18. Removing a government from office is exceptionally hard in Spain (it requires proposing an alternative). And to pass legislation, the PSOE will be able to count not only on the parties that we expect would support its investiture, but also on the liberal Ciudadanos (Citizens). On the downside, the Catalan issue will persist with no clear solution in sight.
Brexit is likely to be delayed owing to a political deadlock in the UK
The UK is currently in a political deadlock over Brexit. If the UK were to exit the EU without a deal, which remains an active risk, this would be extremely disruptive to the British and EU economies. British members of parliament (MPs) have therefore voted against a "no-deal Brexit", and the speaker of the House of Commons (the lower house of parliament), John Bercow, has made clear that a no-deal Brexit cannot happen without parliamentary approval. At the same time, MPs have repeatedly voted against the agreement reached by Mrs May with the EU in November 2018, and against a variety of other potential post-Brexit configurations. The EU has made clear that renegotiating Mrs May's deal is not an option. Solving this impasse under the current parliament therefore looks unlikely.
After lengthy negotiations at an emergency summit in April, the EU agreed to delay Brexit for "as long as necessary", but to no later than October 31st. After failing to reach a cross-party agreement with the opposition Labour Party on how to move forward, Mrs May stood down as prime minister on June 7th. A Conservative Party leadership contest is taking place, which will determine who takes over as prime minister and the government's next steps. We believe that there is a strong chance of a new general election in order to resolve the deadlock, with no Brexit and no deal still both live options.
The Italian government will be unstable and will not last long
The general election in Italy in March 2018 produced a resounding victory for the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won 33% of the vote, and the Eurosceptic anti-immigrant Lega, which secured 17%. Following prolonged post-election negotiations, the two parties agreed to form a coalition at end-May. The administration is led by Giuseppe Conte, a law professor and an independent who is close to M5S. The leaders of M5S and the Lega, Luigi Di Maio and Matteo Salvini respectively, serve as deputy prime ministers. Giovanni Tria, an independent economist, serves as minister of economy and finance.
We expect the Conte government to be unstable and short-lived. It is likely that Mr Salvini will seek to engineer a political crisis later on this year in order to trigger an early general election in the first half of 2020-perhaps using the opportunity provided by frictions between the M5S and the EU over the budget. In this snap election we expect the Lega to emerge as the single largest formation, at the head of a broad centre-right alliance.
Turkey has completed its transition towards one-man rule
In Turkey we expect the conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) and Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the president who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in mid-2016, to remain in power until 2023, and possibly beyond. In mid-2018 Mr Erdogan was re-elected as president of Turkey for a second term in the first round of a snap election while the AKP secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP), in an election that was mostly free, but largely unfair.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concludes Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers with little oversight (including in the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary) and has abolished the role of prime minister. This will greatly curtail the role of parliament.
Mr Erdogan will continue to restrict political dissent and stifle the opposition. Although the government lifted a state of emergency when it expired in July 2018, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent barriers on freedoms.
There is an ongoing security risk from terrorist activities by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and the Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels.
The transition to a post-Putin Russia has led to greater political jockeying
The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, won a comfortable victory in the March 2018 presidential election. Although Mr Putin's re-election itself was a non-event, given Mr Putin's high approval ratings and the absence of credible opposition candidates, it has ushered in a period of political uncertainty as various factions of the elite jockey to secure their positions in the post-Putin political order-assuming that the president stands down at the end of his term in 2024 (our core forecast). This transition period will encounter an elevated degree of uncertainty owing to the weakness of most political and legal institutions, as well as the personalised and opaque governance system around Mr Putin.
Mr Putin's fourth term will be characterised by broad continuity in his policy agenda, which focuses on "conservative cultural values", an authoritarian political culture and overt anti-Westernism. We also expect a renewed focus on domestic policy in an effort to arrest the current decline in living standards and bolster growth following the 2015-16 recession. Even modest liberalising reforms are unlikely, and we expect the state to retain its dominant role in the economy.
On the international stage, we believe that Russia will continue to pursue a muscular foreign policy, with the aim of asserting its status as a major global player, on par with the US. Its influence will be strengthened by the conclusion of international deals in strategic sectors such as oil and gas, nuclear-power plants and military equipment.
The CIS region will be mostly stable
We do not expect political or economic upheaval in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) in the near term. The exceptions to this are Uzbekistan, where the new president will continue to pursue a reformist course, and Armenia and Georgia, where street protests in 2018 led to a change in government, and where economic growth will outpace that of most other countries in the region. Kazakhstan will undergo a successful managed political transition, with Kasym-Jomart Tokayev (the chosen successor of the former president, Nursultan Nazarbayev) winning a landslide victory in the June presidential election. We believe that no significant political or economic change will take place in the other central Asian countries (the Kyrgyz Republic, Turkmenistan and Tajikistan).
Political outlook: Election watch
General elections across Europe since 2017 have confirmed rising disaffection with the political establishment, which has been reflected in the decline of the two-party system and the rise of far-right parties. Increasing political fragmentation across the region has resulted in a more complicated policymaking outlook, but has also made forming governments more difficult and given rise to the emergence of some unusual coalitions. For example, in Italy a government composed of both far-left and far-right parties is now in office.
The far right is no longer in government in Austria, but its ideas remain
Austria provides another example. Following the election in October 2017 the centre-right People's Party (ÖVP), led by Sebastian Kurz, formed a government with the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ). This proved unstable: in May 2019 all of the FPÖ deputies resigned after a taped conversation emerged in which the party's then leader, Heinz-Christian Strache, appears to offer public contracts to a Russian oligarch in return for campaign help. Mr Kurz subsequently lost a vote of no confidence in parliament and stepped down as chancellor. Nonetheless, with the ÖVP having shifted further to the right (especially on migration) over this period, we expect it to win the largest share of the vote again in the snap election in September 2019.
European Parliament elections result in a more fragmented EU political scene
The European Parliament elections, held May 23rd-26th, reflected similar trends to those since 2017 at the national level. There were significant gains for the liberal, centrist Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE) and for the Greens/European Free Alliance, alongside a continued rise in support for nationalist, populist and Eurosceptic parties (most notably the single-issue Brexit Party in the UK). The traditional mainstream parties struggled in comparison, with the centre-left Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) and the centre-right European People's Party (EPP) losing their majority for the first time.
The result, as expected, is a more fragmented political landscape, which is likely to make EU governance more complicated. The nomination process for the next European Commission will be protracted and could hamper European reform efforts; the approval of the EU's 2021-27 multiannual financial framework will be lengthy; and any major decision on trade negotiations (especially with the US) will prove to be contentious.
Nonetheless, the results from May 2019 do not pose a threat to the European project, as some had feared before the event. We consider a coalition bringing the EPP and S&D together with the Greens and/or ALDE to be the most likely eventual result, and the balance of power within the European Parliament will remain largely pro-EU-even more so once the UK leaves the bloc and its members of European Parliament (MEPs) stand down. We do not expect the hardline Eurosceptic parties, which are highly heterogeneous, to be able to form a cohesive, united front.
Recent and upcoming Ukraine elections hinge on question of corruption
Another significant election in the second quarter of 2019 was the presidential election in Ukraine in April, in which Volodymyr Zelenskyi, a comedian and television celebrity with no political experience, won a decisive victory in a second-round vote against the incumbent, Petro Poroshenko. This victory was the result of a widespread popular rejection of political elites in general and of Mr Poroshenko in particular, as well as a perception that the changes promised after the 2014 revolution had never materialised. With currently no seats in parliament, Mr Zelenskyi's ability to govern will depend on the results of the parliamentary election, now due on July 21st 2019 (brought forward from October to capitalise on the momentum of Mr Zelenskyi's presidential election success). The new president has been in effect given a mandate to "clean up" the political class by the majority of Ukrainians, who see the parliament as inherently corrupt. He also has the backing of several other political forces, and we expect his party to win a majority of seats in parliament, which bodes well for political stability and legislative progress.
A number of elections in Europe are still upcoming this year. In Greece the ruling Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), led by the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, suffered a heavy defeat in the European Parliament elections (as well as regional and municipal polls the same day) at the hands of the main opposition party, the centre-right New Democracy (ND). Mr Tsipras then called a pre-term general election, which is scheduled to be held on July 7th. We expect that ND, led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, will win the election and could secure a clear parliamentary majority without the need for the support of another party. Nonetheless, the next government will face formidable challenges: ND has pledged, if elected, to renegotiate the North Macedonia name-change deal-opposed by a majority of Greeks-and Syriza has left to its successor the task of correcting fiscal slippage and backsliding on structural reforms.
Fine Gael minority coalition government will not survive a full term
The Fine Gael-led minority coalition government in Ireland does not have the capacity or cohesion to address effectively the mounting economic and political challenges in the country, and our view remains that the government will not survive a full term to February 2021. We currently expect a snap election to take place in late 2019 or early 2020-although we do not expect this to produce a government any more stable or effective than the current coalition. This existing administration, led by Leo Varadkar, relies on the support of a disparate group of independent MPs, and a three-year "confidence and supply" agreement between Fine Gael and the main opposition party, Fianna Fail. The agreement with Fianna Fail was extended in December, as neither Mr Varadkar nor Micheal Martin, the leader of Fianna Fail, was willing to trigger an early election while there was still great uncertainty regarding Brexit. Nevertheless, the durability of the government will be further tested by several challenges that lie ahead, including crises in housing and healthcare. There is also a public-sector pay deal to be negotiated, overspending in major departments to be managed and the awkward recalibration of the state's property tax. We expect the political environment to remain volatile, leaving the coalition vulnerable to a crisis.
