Political outlook: Intra-regional tensions
Policy-related tensions remain high within the euro zone, but the risk that they will prompt rows between EU members has fallen sharply since 2016, in the context of stronger economic growth across the bloc. The ECB has overcome objections in a number of countries-notably Germany-to its use of unconventional policy instruments. However, the breathing space created by the ECB's programme of sovereign quantitative easing (QE) has not been used by political leaders to bolster the economic recovery with a strong united position on fiscal policy and structural reform.
Huge political capital has been invested in keeping the euro zone together in recent years. There were fears that one or some euro zone countries might exit the bloc during the financial crisis; however, this scenario now seems highly unlikely, and the financial stability of the bloc looks strong despite the high public debt levels of some south European countries (such as Greece, which existed its bail-out programme in August 2018).
Italian government is testing the limits of the EU's patience on fiscal rules
The trend toward "sovereignist" and Eurosceptic politics has played out dramatically over the past year. In Italy, the government, composed of the anti-establishment M5S and the anti-immigration Lega, has tested the limits of EU rules, particularly on fiscal policy and immigration. The administration's draft government contract contained a series of incendiary proposals-such as plans for a renegotiation of the EU treaties to allow countries to leave the euro area or the EU, or the introduction of tradable tax refund notes, effectively a parallel currency, which were eventually watered down. The administration also sought to appoint a Eurosceptic minister of finance, whose appointment was vetoed by the Italian president.
Finally, the Italian government also insisted on passing an expansionary budget in 2019, which would widen the fiscal deficit from an officially projected 1.2% of GDP next year to 2.4%. In June 2019 the Commission recommended that the EU Council open an EDP against Italy for its failure to comply to the EU debt-reduction criterion in 2018. The 2020 budget negotiations are set to be difficult, as Mr Salvini has said multiple times that he will go forward with the Lega-sponsored so-called flat tax system, even if it means pushing the budget deficit wider than 3% of GDP. Meanwhile, so-called safeguard clauses built into the country's fiscal framework will raise the headline rate of value-added tax from 22% to 25.2% in 2020 if EUR23bn (1.3% of GDP) in alternative sources of revenue or expenditure cuts are not legislated in the budget. We expect a protracted dispute with the European Commission in the fourth quarter of 2019, and renewed volatility on financial markets. The opening of an EDP is likely.
Hungary and Poland will continue to clash with the EU over illiberal policies
The nationalist, socially conservative governments in Hungary and Poland have come into conflict with the EU over the EU's refugee-relocation policy and also over the creation of what the Hungarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, has called-in reference to his own country-an "illiberal" state. In addition to refusing to take their allocation of refugees, the Hungarian and Polish governments have curbed the independence of the judiciary, imposed government control over the public-service media and clamped down on civil-society groups. The Commission has referred several of these measures to the European Court of Justice (ECJ), but it has so far struggled to find an effective response. Steps taken by the Commission and the European Parliament since December 2017 to invoke Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, possibly resulting in the suspension of a member country's voting rights, are unlikely to succeed; they require the unanimous vote of all members, and Hungary and Poland have made clear that they would support one another in such an event.
Turkey's foreign policy with the EU and US will be increasingly confrontational
We expect that Turkey's relationships with the EU and the US will remain antagonistic, and fundamentally transactional rather than strategic. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations between Turkey and its Western partners, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the 2016 failed coup; US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups; Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran; tensions with Cyprus about the delimitation of the exclusive economic zones of Turkey and Cyprus in the Mediterranean; and US sanctions on Turkish officials between August and October 2018 owing to Turkey's detention of Andrew Brunson, a US pastor, on terrorism charges.
In 2019 relations with the US will continue to be tested owing to Turkey's decision to purchase the Russian-made S-400 missile defence system, which the US and NATO believe can allow Russia to gather sensitive information on NATO's equipment. We expect Turkey to purchase the S-400 system regardless, as Mr Erdogan wants to assert Turkey's sovereignty. Backing down would also have a negative effect on Turkey's relations with Russia, a significant ally of neighbouring Syria. The US will have to respond, probably through limited individual sanctions on Turkish officials. In addition, the US will probably freeze Turkey's participation in the F-35 stealth fighter jet programme and delay the delivery of Turkey's F-35 jets.
We do not expect a complete collapse in Turkey's relations with the EU or the US. Turkey and the EU have a common interest in handling migrant, and refugee, inflows from Syria and Iraq. The US will also want to avoid pushing Turkey towards Russia and Iran. However, this forecast is highly uncertain.
Russia-West tensions are at their highest level since the cold war
Political tensions between Russia and the West are at their highest since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Western countries have accused Russia of financing extremist opposition parties in western Europe, employing cyber-warfare against Western targets and engaging in a propaganda war through media outlets that it controls in the West. Meanwhile, Russia is seeking to reassert its role on the global stage and is dismantling the security and arms control agreements that were put in place at the end of the cold war. Russia's opposition to the post-cold war security architecture was evident in its decision to withdraw from the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe in 2015, and its subsequent breach of the 1987 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which bans short- and medium-range ballistic missiles.
Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea in 2014 and backing of separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine, resulting in an ongoing conflict in this region, has led to a further deterioration in Russia's relations with the West. The Minsk II agreement, signed in 2015, is unlikely to resolve the conflict; we expect a regularly breached cease-fire and contained levels of fighting to endure. This serves Russia's interests, as a frozen conflict prevents closer Ukrainian integration with the EU and NATO, which Russia would view as a direct threat to its national interests. In response to Russia's actions regarding Ukraine, the EU and the US have imposed sanctions on Russian officials, as well as on the Russian financial, energy and defence sectors. We expect these mutual sanctions to remain in place over the medium term.
The EU has labelled China a systemic rival. The BRI divides opinions
The EU has labelled China a "systemic rival" and recently adopted a regulation setting up a framework to scrutinise foreign investments from non-EU countries, a move that is widely understood to be directed towards foreign direct investment from China. Although the EU supports improving connectivity between Europe and Asia (as pointed out in the EU Connectivity Strategy), it has not formally come out in support of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)-China's flagship foreign policy initiative that aims to create a "New Silk Road" of trading routes, and to expand China's economic and diplomatic ties. However, despite the EU's hesitation to officially support the BRI, several European countries have signed onto this, including Italy, Portugal, Greece and several countries in the western Balkans. One of the points of concern for the EU regarding the BRI is the near monopoly that Chinese companies enjoy in implementing these projects. Until transparency regarding the terms of BRI funding improves and the procurement processes are made more inclusive and competitive (allowing for participation from European companies), the EU is unlikely to change its stance on the BRI.
Macroeconomic policy
The Franco-German axis will drive foward some euro zone reform plans
The commitment in 2012 by the president of the European Central Bank (ECB), Mario Draghi, to do "whatever it takes" to preserve the euro represented a turning-point for the bloc. In 2017 EU leaders renewed their push for further integration of the economic and monetary union to boost the bloc's resilience to future shocks, and in June 2018 Germany and France presented a shared set of proposals. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects progress to remain patchy.
We do not expect the emergence of the type of full fiscal integration that the French president, Emmanuel Macron, has been pushing for, but the strength of the Franco-German axis, with support from a number of southern member states, is likely to be sufficient to lead to a relatively ambitious set of reforms, which will nevertheless take several years to implement fully. These would include reform of the current bail-out fund, the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), which could be turned into something akin to a version of the IMF. Such a move could shift the responsibility for fiscal and economic monitoring of member states away from the European Commission to the revised ESM, and include restructuring of sovereign debt as a strict conditionality to any bail-out. One of the three pillars of the banking union, the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS), which has yet to be implemented, will continue to meet political resistance from several north European member states. The planned EDIS would increase the responsibility of healthy economies for bad debts in others.
France and Germany believe that a new EU industrial strategy is a priority
France and Germany have taken the lead in pushing for a new industrial strategy for the bloc, and also a potential revamp of EU competition policy, in the wake of the Commission's decision to block the planned merger between two train manufacturers, Alstom (France) and Siemens (Germany). Both countries' ministers of the economy are pushing for a revision to EU competition law to enable such mega-mergers in the future, in order to build European champions capable of competing with the largest of their US and Chinese rivals. Their manifesto also argues for greater funding for innovation, and a European strategy to become a world leader in artificial intelligence, among other areas. They are also emphasising the need to develop more robust rules for screening inward foreign direct investment (FDI), especially from China. We expect continued French-German co-operation on these issues, with the aim of developing a more protectionist stance for the bloc.
Talks over the EU's next seven-year budgetary framework will be tough
Tensions arising from negotiations over the EU's seven-year budget framework for 2021-27 will start to emerge in the second half of 2019. The most contentious issue is the European Commission's proposal to increase member states' financial contributions to meet the shortfall created by the withdrawal of the UK, a major net contributor. Although some southern member states and Germany are willing to contribute more, fiscally hawkish countries like Austria and the Netherlands oppose this. Another point of controversy is the Commission's proposed introduction of conditionality in the next budget cycle, linking the transfer of funds to rule-of-law compliance. This emerged in response to the illiberal drift in countries like Poland and Hungary. The idea has created an east-west split, but we expect a version of an introduction to conditionality to be approved.
The 2021-27 budget will also include a new, small euro zone budget, after a compromise was reached between France and Germany. Far from providing a fiscal stabilisation function-as favoured by the French president, Emmanuel Macron-the euro zone budget will instead be channelled to countries looking to improve competitiveness and convergence. The topic has proved contentious among the so-called New Hanseatic League, a group of fiscally hawkish Nordic and Baltic countries led by the Netherlands.

A conservative fiscal bias has prevailed across most of the region since the global crisis in 2008-09, leaving policymakers to rely on low interest rates and unconventional monetary policy tools as the main levers with which to manage their economies. This created a significant degree of exposure to the impact of the monetary policy cycle in the US, where the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) started to tighten monetary policy in late 2015. In contrast, we do not expect the ECB to start tightening its monetary policy until mid-2020 at the earliest. We continue to expect monetary policy to remain accommodative in most European countries, and believe that fiscal policies will be broadly supportive of economic growth during our 2019-23 forecast period.
Fiscal policies will be supportive of growth in the euro zone
Almost all European countries improved their fiscal position in 2009-18, and there has now been a widespread repositioning towards a looser stance. Although we expect fiscal policies to now be slightly more supportive of economic growth, significant fiscal loosening remains off the agenda for most countries, especially for those with high public debt loads, owing to the rigidity of the rules agreed by EU members at the height of the euro zone crisis.
The average euro zone government debt/GDP ratio was 87.2% at end-2018, but Belgium, Greece, Italy, Cyprus and Portugal all had ratios in excess of 100%, and those for France and Spain were only slightly below 100%. Hefty debt loads will remain a challenge for much of the zone for many years. Although the cost of debt servicing has fallen dramatically in recent years owing to exceptionally low interest rates across the bloc, borrowing costs are set to rise gradually as monetary policy is normalised.
Some national governments are pushing back against EU fiscal rules
Within the EU, a number of national governments are showing signs of pushing back against centralised fiscal constraints, which are significantly more rigorous as a result of changes introduced in response to the crisis. The Italian government has recently mounted a more serious challenge to euro area fiscal rules, proposing an expansionary 2019 budget that the Commission sees as violating the debt-reduction criterion of the Stability and Growth Pact. The administration eventually reached a compromise with the EU institutions on a deficit target of 2% of GDP in 2019. However, we expect the dispute between the Italian government and the Commission on Italy's fiscal plans to continue throughout this year, potentially resulting in the imposition of an excessive-deficit procedure (EDP).
The UK government has shifted towards a slightly looser fiscal stance
The UK's fiscal position improved in 2016-18, but a looser policy stance was announced in late 2018, meaning that the deficit will widen slightly in 2019, to 1.6% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2018. The objective was in part to cushion the economy through a period of softer growth owing largely to the impact of Brexit uncertainty that is largely the result of Brexit uncertainty. However, Mr Hammond has stated that fiscal "discipline will remain", and we believe that policy will remain relatively tight throughout our five-year forecast period. We expect the deficit to narrow again in 2020, to 1.5% of GDP, and to 0.6% by 2023. We forecast that public debt will decline from about 87% of GDP in 2017 to less than 80% of GDP by 2022.
Fiscal performance has improved markedly across central Europe
As a result of robust economic growth and tighter controls on spending, fiscal performance has improved markedly across the central European countries in recent years, with the Czech Republic posting a budget surplus in 2018 and Poland and Slovakia both having deficits narrower than 1% of GDP. In Hungary, in contrast, fiscal loosening ahead of the April 2018 parliamentary election led to a widening of the budget deficit, to 2.2% of GDP in 2017 and 2018. We expect little change in the main trends in fiscal performance in 2019-23, except in Poland where the lowering of the retirement age and the expansion of generous social benefits will result in a widening of the annual budget deficit from 0.4% of GDP in 2018 to more than 2% by 2020. We forecast that public debt, which is the equivalent of 50% or less of GDP in the Czech Republic, Poland and Slovakia-but is 71% of GDP in Hungary-will continue to decline in all these countries. Given Hungary's high public debt, the country's fiscal position and currency will remain vulnerable to volatility on world markets.
Higher oil prices are easing fiscal constraints in Russia
The tight budget constraints facing Russia's government are abating owing to higher global oil prices. We expect oil prices to stand at US$60-75/barrel in 2019-23-an improved but still challenging outlook for oil producers-up from an average of about US$50/b in 2015-17. However, the Ministry of Finance intends to relax fiscal policy only slightly in 2019-21. Military spending will remain high, but part of it will be redirected towards health and education, as recently promised by the president, Vladimir Putin. Meanwhile, higher global oil prices-and the government's conservative oil price forecasts (retaining a US$40/b oil price assumption)-almost guarantee that revenue will outperform expectations. We expect the budget, which returned to surplus in 2018, to remain greater than 1% of GDP throughout 2019-23.
Turkey's fiscal position looks relatively solid
The public finances have traditionally been one of Turkey's most reassuring economic aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past. Higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits widened the deficit to about 2% of GDP in 2018, from 1.5% in 2017.
In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy (concerns about off-balance-sheet trends will persist). This, alongside a recovering economy, will cause the deficit to narrow gradually, from a forecast 2.3% of GDP in 2019 to 1.7% in 2023. The central government debt/GDP ratio deteriorated slightly in 2018, rising to 28.9% of GDP in 2018 (from 28.3% in 2017). The ratio will decline slightly, to about 26.6% by end-2023 as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.
Macroeconomic policy: Monetary policy and exchange rates

US 10-year government bond yield 2.9 2.6 2.2 2.4 3.1 3.4
10-year German government bond yield 0.4 0.3 0.6 1.1 1.5 1.7
The ECB's asset-purchase programme, quantitative easing (QE), came to an end in December 2018, but monetary policy conditions will remain loose, especially if growth continues to soften in the euro zone. The ECB has decided to continue reinvesting the proceeds from maturing securities purchased under the QE programme "for an extended period of time past the date when it starts raising the main ECB interest rates, and in any case for as long as necessary to maintain favourable liquidity conditions and an ample degree of monetary accommodation". In 2019 policy rates will remain close to zero. Global uncertainty has increased in the past year, driven mainly by the US-China trade war and Brexit, which have started to weigh on growth. Combined with a slowdown in growth rates across the euro zone this means that the economic outlook for the bloc has become more subdued.
The ECB will maintain a dovish stance
At its latest meeting on June 6th the ECB adopted a dovish stance, delaying the next rate rise from early 2020 until mid-2020 at the earliest. This was in line with our existing forecast; we expect the ECB to raise its deposit rate in June 2020 and the main refinancing rate in December 2020, with policy tightening proceeding thereafter at a gradual pace. The bank also announced that the interest rate on its third round of targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs-III) could go as low as -0.3% to encourage lending. Should economic conditions deteriorate further, for instance given an escalation in the US-China trade war or a "no-deal" Brexit (not our core forecast), we would expect the ECB to resume its QE programme or to cut rates again. That said, we would expect the bank to change its stance only if data revealed that global uncertainty was disrupting the "virtuous circle" between employment, labour income and consumption, which-for the moment-is holding up.
When setting interest rates, other central banks will have to weigh up the net effect of a moderating euro zone economy and greater protectionism elsewhere against their desire to normalise monetary policy. Caution is likely among European central banks, and rate rises will be gradual.
The BoE has paused its tightening cycle
The Bank of England (BoE, the UK central bank) raised its policy rate for the first time in a decade in November 2017 and again in August 2018. However, this year it has adopted a more dovish stance. The BoE revised down its forecasts for economic growth and inflation in February, citing a weaker global environment and Brexit-related uncertainty. The bank still expects domestically driven price pressure to build gradually in the forecast period, but the timing of future rate rises will depend on the nature and outcome of Brexit. We expect the BoE to delay the next increase in the policy rate until the fourth quarter of 2019. However, there is a high risk that the next rate increase will be delayed until 2020 and that policy tightening will occur at a slower pace.
In the event of a disorderly UK withdrawal from the EU at end-October (not our baseline forecast), we expect the bank to make whatever policy changes are required to support economic activity. The BoE has emphasised that it is prepared for such an outcome; a worst-case scenario used in the bank's stress tests for the banking system involves a decline in the pound's value, higher unemployment and inflation, an increase in borrowing costs and a decrease drop in property prices, of about 35% after three years. However, the UK's banking system has sufficient capital, and monetary policy would be loosened.
In Scandinavia, the Riksbank (Sweden's central bank) started its tightening cycle in December 2018, amid strong inflationary pressures and firm economic momentum. Norges Bank (Norway's central bank) also started its tightening cycle, in September 2018, and will proceed at a faster pace than its peers, with the next rise set to take place in March. Meanwhile the Swiss National Bank (SNB, Switzerland's central bank) has reduced its foreign-exchange interventions in and will closely track the policy movements of the ECB.
Turkey still faces the risk of another sharp depreciation of the lira
Turkey's economy has displayed resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing to its solid public finances, well capitalised banking sector, and dynamic and diversified private sector. Nonetheless, we expect the currency crisis in 2018 and the ensuing recession to put severe pressure on the government's finances, business sector solvency and banks' balance sheets.
After the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August 2018, the Central Bank of Turkey raised its main policy rate to 24%, from 17.75% previously. From mid-2019 to 2020 we expect the central bank to gradually lower its policy rate in response to easing inflationary pressures and a normalisation of financial market conditions. However, we expect inflation to remain greater than the target of 5% in 2021-23.
We expect a gradual appreciation in the lira in the second half of 2019, to a year-end exchange rate of about TL:5.70:US$1. This forecast assumes that the Turkey-US dispute will not result in damaging sectoral sanctions; that government policy will be credibly reoriented; and that the central bank will maintain a tight monetary policy stance, lowering interest rates only as price pressures fade. However, there are large risks to this forecast, with another sharp lira depreciation still a possibility. In 2020 we expect the lira rate to depreciate gradually against the US dollar as the current-account deficit widens and central banks in advanced economies re-embark on a path of monetary policy tightening.
We expect one or two rate cuts in Russia in 2019
In Russia in December 2018 the Central Bank of Russia (CBR, the central bank) increased its policy rate by 25 basis points, to 7.75%, in anticipation of the inflationary pressures expected in 2019, driven by an increase of the value-added tax (VAT) rate and the resumption of foreign-currency purchases from January 2019. However, the CBR has since said that inflation accelerated less than expected in response to the increase in the VAT rate, and that its pre-emptive rate increase in December 2018 was sufficient to offset this one-off price rise. The central bank expects above-target inflation of higher than 5-5.5% in 2019, before a return to the targeted 4% in 2020. This is broadly in line with our inflation forecast. We expect the CBR to cut its policy rate by 25 basis points once or twice in 2019. However, any downward shock to global oil prices or new sanctions on Russia would prompt the CBR to tighten policy quickly to soften the resulting depreciation of the Russian currency against the US dollar.
Many currencies in eastern Europe remain pegged to the euro
For central and east European countries with currencies pegged to or managed against the euro (mostly in the western Balkans), risks of volatility have moved in line with expectations of the Fed's and the ECB's policy trajectory. However, we do not believe that there are significant risks to the currency boards in Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH) or Bulgaria, or to the peg in North Macedonia. Croatia had been more of a cause for concern, in the light of the 2015 legislation to force banks to convert Swiss franc-denominated loans into euro. However, the country's improved external and fiscal positions, and increased demand for the kuna as a result of a strong tourism performance, have driven appreciation, which we forecast will continue in 2019.
We expect broadly accommodative monetary policy stances in Central Asia
Currencies across the former Soviet Union depreciated sharply in 2015 as a result of the weakening of the rouble and lower oil prices, which hit commodity exporters. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan officially abandoned their US dollar pegs in 2015. In practice, only Kazakhstan has allowed its currency to float. Given Kazakhstan's trade ties to the Russian economy, it would lose competitiveness if the tenge appreciated significantly against the rouble. Azerbaijan appears to have returned to a US dollar peg since April 2017. The monetary policy stances of oil-exporting countries such as Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan are closely linked to oil price fluctuations, since the exchange-rate movements of these countries are closely linked to global oil prices (which determine export earnings). With global oil prices expected to remain firm in our forecast period, these countries will maintain an accommodative monetary policy, which will also support domestic economic growth.

Economic growth in the euro zone will lose momentum, but remain firm
The recovery of the euro zone economy from the global financial crisis of 2008-10 began in 2013, after the president of the European Central Bank (ECB), Mario Draghi, committed to doing "whatever it takes" to restore confidence in the euro. The recovery strengthened once this commitment was backed by a large-scale quantitative easing (QE) programme. By 2017 the euro zone's expansion had gathered sustained and broad-based momentum, and this, in turn, benefited neighbouring economies that receive EU funding and rely on EU trade. However, growth in the euro zone eased in 2018, and will moderate further in 2019. In the second half of last year the German economy stagnated and momentum softened in France, and Italy entered a technical recession.
Some of the reasons for the slowdown were temporary: adverse weather conditions, rail strikes and protests weighed on growth in France in 2018, and Germany's manufacturing sector was hit by changes to European car-emissions regulations and disruptions to freight transport. However, there has also been a marked deterioration in the external environment from 2018 and into 2019, with softer global trade and high geopolitical uncertainty, reflecting rising US-China trade tensions, the threat of a US tariff increase on EU automotive exports and the risk of a "no-deal" Brexit. Concerns about these issues, and a softening of demand across Asia, the euro zone, the UK and (to a lesser extent) the US, have fed into a decline in manufacturing data and sentiment indicators.
Against this less supportive external environment, domestic demand has remained firm, driving quarterly growth in the euro zone to 0.4% in the first quarter of 2019-stronger than in the three previous quarters. High-frequency indicators such as consumer confidence, employment data and retail sales are robust, supporting private consumption, and a buoyant housing market, high capacity-utilisation levels and favourable funding conditions are fuelling investment. Across most of the bloc recovering labour markets, accommodative monetary policy and gradual fiscal loosening are supporting growth.
Nonetheless, the risks to The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast remain skewed to the downside. The most immediate risk is the US administration's threat to raise tariffs on imported European autos and auto parts (from 2.5% at present). Our core view is that the US will refrain from raising these tariffs. There is significant opposition to doing so in the US market, and with the next presidential election in November 2020, opening yet another front in the trade war would be a risky move. However, should the current dispute over subsidies at Airbus and Boeing, two aerospace companies, result in mutual tariff imposition, this would change the calculation. The German economy is particularly exposed to this threat, given its dominant role in the European automotive industry and highly open economy.
Economic growth is slowing markedly in Germany
Real GDP growth accelerated to 2.5% in Germany in 2017, the strongest annual expansion since 2011, in line with a euro zone cyclical upturn. Growth slowed to 1.5% in 2018, driven primarily by weaker car production in the second half of the year-as the industrial sector scrambled to respond to new European car-emissions tests-and by a less supportive external trade environment. Given the openness of Germany's economy-with exports equivalent to 50% of GDP, far higher than in any other of the other major world economies-this external context is a significant factor influencing growth.
We expect a substantial further slowdown, to 0.8% in 2019, owing to the impact of the less supportive external environment on the industrial and export sectors. The main driver of growth will be private consumption as the tight labour market feeds into significant nominal wage increases while the government embarks on its strongest fiscal stimulus since 2010. Investment growth will also be robust, driven by capacity constraints, skills shortages, investment in new technologies, additional residential construction and favourable financing conditions. After this year we expect a gradual strengthening of growth, to 1.7% by 2023-near its potential rate. Over the longer term, the poor demographic outlook will increasingly constrain potential growth. A further challenge is that Germany's flagship industry, the automotive sector, risks being disrupted by technological change.
Growth will remain relatively solid in France, despite a slowdown in 2019-20
France's recovery from its slump in 2012 was slow by European standards, with growth recovering to its 2008 rate only in 2017, supported by a cyclical upswing in the euro zone. After real GDP growth of 2.4% in 2017, growth eased in 2018 and we forecast a sharper slowdown, to 1.2% in 2019, as external demand softens. In 2020-23 we expect annual average growth of 1.6% as recent reforms to the business environment start to bear fruit and external demand picks up. However, structural rigidities-especially regarding the tax system and the labour market-will not disappear entirely, and the country will continue to struggle to improve its competitiveness over the medium term, with often negative investor perceptions of the country likely to prove slow to change.
Italy's economy entered a recession in the second half of 2018
The Italian economy has softened since mid-2018, contracting on a sequential basis in the second half of last year. On the basis of weakening sentiment and high-frequency indicators, we now forecast real GDP growth of just 0.1% this year, after it registered 0.7% in 2018. Risks are firmly to the downside, as political and policy uncertainty, as well as flagging consumption and investment, may result in a deeper contraction than expected, pulling full-year growth into negative territory in 2019. In 2020 the euro area's third-largest economy will fare little better, expanding by a modest 0.4% in real terms, as cooling external demand in the euro area and the weight of global trade tensions and a slowdown in the US continue to hold back economic recovery. From 2021 to 2023 growth should return to closer to 1% per year on average, a respectable performance by Italian standards, but still weak in the context of euro area economies, as structural rigidities, a high level of sovereign debt, clogged credit channels and policy uncertainty continue to exert a drag on growth.
Structural reforms have improved the context for growth in Spain
In Spain, a combination of reform and austerity has given rise to a marked economic improvement since 2014. The financial sector is now in a better position, owing to reforms undertaken as part of Spain's EUR41.3bn bank bail-out process, and we believe that further episodes of instability-particularly at institutions of systemic importance-are unlikely. Meanwhile a landmark labour market reform implemented in 2012 lowered dismissal costs, clarified and narrowed the definition of unfair dismissal, reduced the collective bargaining power of trade unions, and made it easier for companies to cut wages and working hours. This has contributed to an improved domestic context for growth, supported by a more relaxed government stance towards wage growth, low interest rates and moderate inflation. We expect average annual growth of about 2% in 2019-23 (the forecast period), easing from more than 3% in 2015-18.
The recovery in Greece remains fragile, with political instability a central risk
Greece exited its third bail-out programme in August 2018, but we are sceptical that the country will experience rapid and sustained growth. Greece's economy has been in almost permanent recession since 2008. The recovery began in 2017 is fragile, and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than one-quarter, government consumption by almost one-quarter, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile, and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. Real GDP accelerated in 2018, but the economy lost momentum in the final quarter of the year. We expect real GDP growth to remain constrained, at about 1.9% in 2019-23. The risks to our forecast are balanced: upside risks include continued strong tourism performance if capacity constraints are addressed and competitiveness gains are not eroded; downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
The UK economy is suffering from the uncertainty stemming from Brexit
The UK economy was relatively resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote in 2016, but lost momentum in 2018. Real GDP growth slowed sharply in the fourth quarter of 2018 as weaker global demand reduced exports, and political turmoil over the outcome of Brexit hurt sentiment and business investment. Consumer spending has held up, as softer inflation and faster wage growth (reflecting a tight labour market) has supported a pick-up in real income growth. However, Brexit-related uncertainty will persist in 2019, and we expect an extended slowdown in real GDP growth, to about 1.3%, from 1.4% in 2018.
Consumer spending growth should strengthen gradually in 2020-22-owing to pent-up demand as uncertainty recedes (assuming that a solution to the current Brexit impasse has been found and implemented by this point). We also expect business investment to firm gradually for most of the forecast period from 2020 as uncertainty recedes and capacity constraints make capital spending necessary. However, during the forecast period industrial activity will continue to be weighed by the decisions of various companies to scale down or end production in the UK. In February 2019 Honda, a Japanese carmaker, announced that it would close its UK-based plant in 2022.

Euro area 1.9 1.3 1.5 1.7 1.7 1.7
The Visegrad countries will continue to post above-average growth rates
Much of central Europe faces a challenging environment in the longer term. However, countries that benefit from EU funding, such as the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) in particular, will register real GDP growth well above the EU average in 2019-23. Funding inflows for projects under the 2014-20 funding period were slow to begin in 2016, holding back activity in that year, but funds began to flow again in 2017-18, contributing to stronger economic activity, and projects are in progress that will support economic growth rates during 2019-23. Increased employment and soaring wages-driven in part by a tight labour market-have fuelled private consumption since 2017, and this will continue in the forecast period. We expect that growth in Germany-a major market for these countries-will remain solid, albeit slowing owing to trade tensions hurting car manufacturers and tight job markets weighing on growth. The German economy's changing structure, with investment and private consumption rising, will provide a boost to central and east European countries with strong trade links to their larger neighbour.
Economic activity accelerated in south-eastern Europe, but is now moderating
In south-eastern Europe the economic recoveries are continuing, although growth has generally lost momentum. In the region's largest economy, Romania, the economy grew by 4.1% in 2018 after growth of 7% in in 2017. We expect continued weak employment growth related to large demographic constraints, with a less certain global environment and the volatile policy environment weighing on economic growth in 2019. In 2020-23 we forecast average real GDP growth of abou 3.4%. The economy will remain excessively reliant on exports and consumption, with internal investment far below the levels required for achieving convergence with the EU. In Bulgaria, a recovery in domestic credit growth, a strengthening labour market and firmer real wage growth have underpinned the acceleration of economic growth in recent years. In 2019-23 we expect growth to decelerate to 2.7% per year on average, reflecting less favourable global conditions and labour capacity constraints.
Structural imbalances in the western Balkans have been largely corrected
Economic activity in the western Balkans (Albania, Bosnia and Hercegovina, North Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia) broadly picked up in 2015-18, reflecting a combination of favourable base effects and externally driven cyclical factors such as low oil prices in 2015-16 and a strong pick-up in demand from the euro zone in 2017. In 2018 the Serbian economy accelerated, bringing up the regional average after a decade of uneven growth. The region has undergone a significant economic adjustment in the years since the 2008-09 global financial crisis, largely correcting fiscal and current-account imbalances (with some exceptions, such as Montenegro). Inflation has fallen to historical lows for the region, allowing a more accommodative monetary policy that has supported growth. The revival of investment is set to continue, and over the medium and long term the western Balkans should benefit from the structural reforms that are now under way in most countries. On the downside, high public and/or private debt loads, and (in some cases) continued large fiscal deficits remain impediments to faster growth. We forecast average real GDP growth in the western Balkans of about 3.3% in 2019-23.
Exchange-rate volatility has pushed Turkey into a recession
In Turkey government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand caused real GDP growth to accelerate to 7.3% in 2017 (from 3.3% in 2016), but this surge exacerbated internal and external discrepancies. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short-term capital inflows, tighter global liquidity and a diplomatic spat with the US-contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar in January-August 2018.
The sharp depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of large foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dented the economic outlook. The crisis pushed the Turkish economy into recession in the second half of 2018, which we expect to continue in the first quarter of 2019, resulting in a contraction in full-year real GDP of 1.7% in 2019 on average (mainly owing to base effects), followed by annual average growth of 3.7% per year in 2020-23.
Growth in Russia will slacken this year
According to Russia's Federal State Statistics Service (Rosstat), Russian real GDP grew by a surprisingly strong 2.2% in 2018-the fastest growth rate since 2012. The strong growth rate was largely driven by the inclusion in output data of investment in construction work at the third phase of the Yamal gasfield, as well as high levels of exports. This is unlikely to be sustained in 2019 owing to weaker growth in external demand, a new deal with OPEC to constrain oil production, and a lower projected grain harvest. Domestic demand is also likely to slacken this year owing to higher interest rates and an increase in value-added tax (VAT). International sanctions-and broader political and business uncertainty-will remain significant constraints on investment, as will the lack of a "culture of failure" (the absence of entrepreneurial spirit weighs heavily on innovation and investment). We forecast that economic growth will ease to 1.2% in 2019. In the medium term outdated capital stock, a declining workforce, dependence on natural-resource sectors, institutional weaknesses, low productivity growth, a difficult business environment and statist policies will limit real GDP growth, to an annual average of 1.6% in 2019-23.
The possible end of Russian gas transit represents a large risk for Ukraine
Real GDP decreased by a cumulative 16.4% in Ukraine in 2014-15 amid conflict and a chaotic political situation. The disruption of these years accentuated a structural change in the Ukrainian economy away from heavy industry and towards agriculture. The economy has been recovering since 2016, driven by vigorous growth in private investment and private consumption. Real GDP growth stood at 3.3% in full-year 2018. Household spending continued to increase (supported by solid wage growth and high inflows of remittances) and investment remained robust. In 2019-23 we expect average annual average real GDP growth of about 2.7% per year, with household consumption making the largest contribution to GDP growth in each year. However, soft global steel prices, rising production costs and a worsening external environment will weigh on growth, especially in 2019-20. The probable end of Russian gas transit in 2019 or 2020-when the current transit contract expires and the Nord Stream 2 pipeline connecting Russia to the EU is supposed to begin operations-represents a significant risk.
Growth rates in the CIS will be similar in 2019 to those recorded in 2018
Growth and exchange-rate movements in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) are highly correlated to movements in global oil prices, especially in large oil exporters such as Russia, Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan. Owing to important trade links and high levels of remittance flows, the performance of the Russian economy has an impact on that of smaller countries in Central Asia (the Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan) and the South Caucasus (Armenia and Georgia, not CIS members). We forecast growth of 1.2% in Russia, 1.8% in Azerbaijan, 3.9% in Kazakhstan and 2.7% in Ukraine in 2019. Given our forecast for an oil price corridor of about US$60-75/barrel in 2019-23, the growth outlook for most countries is unlikely to diverge significantly from their 2018 final outturn.

Price pressures remain modest in Europe, but are building gradually. Inflation in the euro zone accelerated to 1.7% in 2018 from 1.5% in 2017 (and 0.2% in 2016), but this increase stemmed chiefly from higher energy prices, which have since reversed course. Nevertheless, in 2019 we expect domestic price pressure-stemming from tighter labour markets and firmer wage growth-to become increasingly responsible for driving inflation higher, offsetting a diminishing contribution from external price pressure. We forecast average inflation in the euro zone of 1.3% in 2019 and 1.8% per year in 2020-23. In the EU28 we expect inflation to average 1.9% per year throughout the forecast period. The most notable exception from this pattern is Turkey, which will struggle to bring its inflation rate down to its 5% official target in our forecast period.

Business environment rankings cover 82 countries
The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings model seeks to measure the attractiveness of a country's business environment and its major components. The model's assessment of the business environment-based on the opportunities for and hindrances to the conduct of business-enables us to rank each of the 82 countries covered on its overall position and in each of 11 categories on a global and a regional basis. The model uses quantitative data and expert assessments to measure the attractiveness of countries' business environments. The framework has been designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies in formulating their global business strategies and investment location decisions. The overall scores (on a 1-10 scale) and rankings are based on scores for 91 indicators, grouped into 11 categories.
There is a moderate improvement in Europe's aggregate regional scores between the historical period (2014-18) and the forecast period (2019-23), reflecting the transition from the post-crisis period to one in which recovery and repair are, in most countries, well under way. Western Europe is ranked second globally out of six regions, after North America, and eastern Europe is ranked fourth, after North America, western Europe, and Asia and Australasia, but it performs better than Latin America, or the Middle East and Africa.
EU countries and Nordics score particularly well in our rankings
EU countries remain well represented in the top 20 of our global rankings. Two non-EU countries, Switzerland and Norway, also occupy leading positions. The large number of west European countries in the top 20 reflects the high degree of political stability in the region (a post-crisis rise in social and political tension notwithstanding), large and competitive domestic markets and a strong degree of openness to world trade. Although we continue to highlight the risks of political fragmentation and rising anti-establishment sentiment, we do not forecast a marked anti-market backlash in policy choices.
Business environment in eastern Europe has improved since 1990s
The investment climate of central and eastern Europe has improved considerably in recent years. The early reformers among the countries of central Europe led the way in the early 1990s in adopting far-reaching stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation programmes. Reform in the Balkans has been much more uneven and subject to periodic reversals, but significant progress has been made even there. Factors such as a low-cost, but well-qualified, labour force, proximity to developed markets, and, in some cases, ample natural-resource endowments have attracted considerable foreign direct investment to the region over the past decade. However, many east European countries still face fundamental reform challenges; meeting those challenges will test already fraying relations between governments and electorates, and heighten the risk of political instability and social unrest.
The outlook for the business environment in the countries of the former Soviet Union is mixed. Throughout the region, the barriers to enacting wide-ranging reform remain formidable. In Russia, the business environment has suffered as a result of Western sanctions and a rise in tariff and non-tariff barriers. There is little evidence that the Russian government intends to undertake disruptive structural reform to improve the dynamism of the economy. However, low energy prices have prompted some regional commodity exporters, notably Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, to seek to open up and diversify their economies.
Data sources and definitions
Methodology
The forecast tables have been constructed from the individual data series available in the respective Economist Intelligence Unit Country Forecasts. In addition, the Economist Intelligence Unit runs the National Institute's Global Econometric Model (NIGEM), which is developed and maintained by the London Business School at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Muhammadu Buhari won a second and final four-year presidential term on February 23rd. The policy agenda he campaigned on did not involve considerable reform, only cosmetic improvements to the business environment.
The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This will create a potent mixture that will lead to frequent violent instability and directly affect key economic sectors.
Policy will be interventionist. Import bans on agricultural and manufacturing goods will be widened to support local industry and farmers, and the Central Bank of Nigeria will maintain an overvalued official naira rate with which to channel cheap US dollars to preferred buyers.
Even though a multiple exchange-rate system will persist, non-official rates will converge and so in reality Nigeria will run a dual exchange-rate regime. Oil prices will be high enough to prevent a return to capital controls (as temporarily imposed in 2016).
Fiscal expenditure will remain dominated by recurrent spending, despite attempts to boost capital investment. Efforts to boost non-oil tax revenue will be constrained by weak bureaucratic capacity and low economic growth.
Constrained by a crippling infrastructure deficit, as well as tight monetary conditions and instability in key agricultural regions, economic growth will be well below levels needed to boost job creation and increase living standards. This will perpetuate instability in a vicious cycle.
Inflation will remain high over the forecast period (2019-23) amid expansionary fiscal policy and high food prices stemming from government efforts to limit imports and support local producers. This in turn will keep credit conditions tight; even with some relaxation of the policy rate from 2021, inflation will be running too high for sustained monetary loosening, and credit growth will generally be slow.
The multiple-exchange-rate regime will not be dismantled under a Buhari administration; the arrangement is critical for making petrol subsidies affordable and underpins the government's interventionist approach to industrialisation.
Oil prices and exports will fall in 2019-20 but so will imports. Both imports and exports will then expand in 2021-23 but a current-account surplus will be maintained throughout the forecast period.

Nigeria's business environment score will improve slightly but its global and regional rankings will worsen as the administration struggles with the reform process and other countries make more significant improvements.
Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. The upstream oil sector will remain characterised by joint-ventures between the state oil company and multinationals.
2021-23: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress will be slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: An attempt to sell the state's interest in oil joint ventures with multinationals will meet serious challenges (the policy has been around for years), with resistance in the legislature to the permanent loss of a revenue stream.
2021-23: Higher world oil prices and so easing fiscal pressures lessen the need to embark on a divestment programme. Energy companies will anyway be hesitant to increase their stake in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Import bans are widened, but capital controls will not be necessary barring another (not expected) oil price crash.
2021-23: A premium between the overvalued official and parallel-market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2019-20: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Value-added tax (VAT) is increased to fund a higher minimum wage, which will markedly increase the fiscal cost of the civil service.
2021-23: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation, particularly for offshore oilfields. The need for new consumer taxes is alleviated by higher world oil prices and, as a result, hydrocarbons revenue.
Financing
2019-20: Funding for well-planned projects becomes easier to raise domestically following the completion of the 2019 elections, as local capital markets deepen (with greater foreign participation) and the banking sector develops.
2021-23: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts savings and investment.
The labour market
2019-20: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2021-23: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff; unemployment remains high and the market loose.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints and is crowded out by other spending categories, including debt-servicing. Although there should be growth in private-sector investment, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2021-23: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2021-23: Research spending is likely to remain low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multiparty democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in 2015, and Mr Buhari secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 has almost wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.
