Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Muhammadu Buhari won a presidential election in February 2019 and will remain in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. For any Nigerian leader, managing the country's myriad security threats would be an insoluble challenge, but under Mr Buhari there are particular reasons to expect serious, albeit localised unrest.
The election revealed a deep sense of voter apathy in southern Nigeria-an economically vital region, although prone to militancy and separatism. In his first term Mr Buhari was seen by many in the southern region as absent, rarely making visits there. With the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) vote share being heavily concentrated in Nigeria's north-and with that region facing various and urgent security issues-government attention will probably remain focused there. As a result, the disconnect between Nigeria's south and mainstream politics is unlikely to heal. Indeed, the government will give priority to containing banditry in the very far north-west and the Islamist militant group Boko Haram, which is resurgent in the north-east and is utilising new tactics and more sophisticated hardware. Mr Buhari's "zero tolerance" approach to terrorism was a major reason for the strong turnout and support for him in the affected regions, and steadily worsening security in states such as Borno means a concerted response is forthcoming. As was the case in his last tenure, substantial federal resources are likely to be channelled towards restoring law and order in the region. However, militants in the oil-producing south cite the use of oil earnings for far-flung causes such as combating Boko Haram-rather than for local development-as justification for the insurgency. Our assumption is that attacks by aggrieved militants on oil infrastructure will continue to be a major security problem in Delta state.
Boko Haram will probably be aggressively countered, but in the process the north-east of Nigeria will essentially become a low-level conflict zone. Just to the south of this region, in the agricultural Middle Belt of Nigeria, a more insoluble challenge will be addressing extremely violent clashes between settled farmers and nomads competing for increasingly scarce water and land resources. Formal land titling is a potential answer, but as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another it would prove too contentious. Ultimately there is no foreseeable end to violence in the Middle Belt. Moreover, in Mr Buhari's first term, it was clear that military engagements in other parts of Nigeria have priority when it comes to deploying the army's thinly spread resources, and the same is likely to be true in his second. Again, the direct security impact of the conflict will be localised, with little spillover into the administrative capital, Abuja, or the economic capital, Lagos. The entire country will feel the secondary effects, however, in the form of constricted food supply and high consumer prices.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The election in February 2019 reaffirmed a deep electoral divide between the APC-supporting north and southern Nigeria, a stronghold of the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP). In the next general election in 2023, custom dictates that the candidates of both main parties will be southerners, giving the PDP a chance to improve on abysmally low turnout there in the 2019 presidential vote. This low participation is largely what cost them victory. Moreover, Nigeria's economic outlook is bleak, with growth barely keeping pace with a rapidly increasing population. Much of the cause of rising poverty and high unemployment will be political in origin; the parliamentary election gave the APC a large majority in both houses which in theory, should allow for the swift passage of legislation, but Mr Buhari's first term was marked by divisions between the executive and parliament (as had happened to presidents before him), and crucial bills including the national budget were delayed by months. As legislators typically prioritise the interests of their constituents over party and federation in Nigeria, similar tensions could easily reoccur in Mr Buhari's second stint which will prevent meaningful reform (for example on managing the oil sector). Inactivity on such fronts means the APC will be the subject of voter frustration. The PDP candidate should be able to capitalise from this, giving them an edge from the start.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat they pose. Stretched resources, vast territories and porous borders will prevent complete military victories. Relations with the US will be mixed; the administration of Donald Trump is willing to sell Nigeria military hardware, but Mr Trump's disapproval of the trade deficit the US runs with Nigeria (particularly owing to Nigerian import restrictions) could strain ties. Relations with the EU will be largely cordial but subject to tensions over Nigerian migrants seeking to enter Europe and Nigerian efforts to repatriate funds in European banks that were allegedly looted by former rulers.
India will remain important as the largest market for Nigerian oil and become a bigger source of foreign investment. China will also remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will fall short of the headline-grabbing pledges made, given an extremely challenging local business environment. Nigeria will remain an important player on the Sub-Saharan African stage given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Economic policy during Mr Buhari's second and final term is likely to carry over the interventionist policies adopted during his first. Measures to liberalise and unify foreign-exchange markets or move to more market-led pricing in the energy sector will not be pursued. An overvalued official naira rate is critical for maintaining petrol subsidies, and Mr Buhari will not willingly attempt to dismantle consumer price caps and risk a popular backlash. Although in practice very little foreign exchange is traded at the official rate, the existence of a multiple-exchange-rate system will be off-putting to investors fearing a return of capital controls. Concerns about this will be heightened whenever global crude prices soften and foreign reserves decline (as The Economist Intelligence Unit expects in 2019-20).
Elsewhere, efforts will be made to cleanse and reboot inefficient state-owned industries such as the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC)-which dominates all segments of the oil sector-but again no structural reforms (such as full or partial privatisation) will take place. Generally, Mr Buhari's approach will be to make existing entities such as the NNPC become profitable rather than relinquish state control over them entirely. There will be some effort to reduce the NNPC's stake in the upstream oil joint-ventures that it has with international oil companies, but demand will be held back by the difficulty of operating in Nigeria and uncertainty about fiscal terms (with deep political divisions about how to distribute hydrocarbons revenue having stalled critical legislation). As a result, investor interest will be short of official expectations, and parliament will resist selling off assets for a low price. As a consequence, the NNPC will remain dominant, with politicians and other members of the political elite working to direct the flow of resources to favour specific geo-ethnic and political constituencies (as well as for illicit personal gain).
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
We expect small fiscal deficits throughout the forecast period. The government wants to diversify its revenue base away from oil, and non-oil revenue will rise through efforts to collect overdue taxes, but from an extremely low base. Instability in many parts of the country will also impede collection. Petrol subsidies (whereby losses incurred by the NNPC's retail arm are deducted from federal revenue) will be another drain, while budgeted revenue levels will be undermined by overambitious oil production targets. For example in 2019 the government expects output of 2.3m barrels/day (b/d)-a level not seen since the oil price slump, and one that will be unobtainable given underinvestment and OPEC production quotas. In all, federally retained revenue is not expected to rise above 3.9% of GDP, a ratio only attained in 2022 when oil prices are at their highest within the forecast period.
After some projected expansion in 2018, spending will decline as a proportion of GDP in 2019 with deep cuts to the capital budget. Partly offsetting this will be higher spending on wages and public-sector benefits, including via the roll-out of a new (increased) minimum wage. Generally, fiscal flexibility will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and so revenue-under pressure and there being considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. Altogether, we expect an average budget deficit averaging 1.9% of GDP over 2019-23.
Long-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against a low revenue base. Debt service already takes up close to one-third of federal government income. A sovereign default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is weaker.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
Monetary policy will concentrate on fostering an economic recovery while limiting inflation and maintaining currency stability. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The private sector is desperate for cheaper credit, but inflation will remain above the targeted upper limit of 9% set by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN). On balance, we expect interest rates not to move much in 2019-20, notwithstanding a small rate cut by the CBN in March (which was upheld in May). Rates will then fall in 2021 and stabilise over 2022-23 as economic activity picks up and inflation hovers above or around the target. However, real interest rates will be too high to be viable for much of the private sector.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The economy will for the most part be mired in a low-growth cycle, although there will be improvements over time. In 2019-20 the economy will be held back by power shortages, insecurity, high inflation and tight credit conditions, notwithstanding a recent 50-basis-point drop in the policy rate. Some sectors will benefit from targeted protectionist policies (via exchange-rate restrictions for imported goods), but this will be at the expense of preventing further rate cuts by the CBN and more broad-based growth. A slower global economy will also hold back export-oriented sectors. In 2021-23, as global markets strengthen and inflation gradually comes down (allowing for some monetary easing) the rate of growth will quicken, although remain well below potential at an annual average of 3.3%. This is still abnormally low for Nigeria, especially as we forecast population growth of 2.6% a year for the 2019-23 forecast period.
From a sectoral viewpoint, agriculture will record only lacklustre growth; although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will be severe impediments. Industrial production will be curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, and investment will be held back by uncertainty about future fiscal terms. Egina, a new offshore oilfield, will be a new driver of condensate output, but hydrocarbons production is not expected to return to levels prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash. That said, a private refinery coming on stream by 2021 will be a boost to downstream oil activity in the latter years of the forecast period. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of cheap goods from abroad, which are often smuggled into the country to bypass import bans, as well as power supply gaps. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth than industry, but it will nonetheless be held back by protectionism affecting trade, tight credit conditions affecting areas such as real estate and finance, and the struggle in the communications sector to profitably roll out data services beyond urban hubs.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
From a rate of 12.1% in 2018, average inflation will remain elevated at 11.8% in 2019, as a 67% increase in the minimum wage combines with recently loosened monetary policy, disruptions to local food supply and widening import restrictions. In 2020 inflation will remain well above the CBN's targeted ceiling of 9%, at 10.9%, as demand-side forces from the minimum-wage rise continue. With the base effects from this fading, inflation will gradually ease over the rest of the forecast period, to an average of 8.8% in 2023. Conflict and supply disruptions in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's agricultural heartland-will prevent a faster slide, together with widening protectionist measures that limit relatively cheap imports from abroad, particularly of food and manufactured goods. Currently 43 items are barred from foreign-exchange access, the most recent addition being textiles, and the CBN wants to increase the list to 50 as a means of stimulating non-oil activity.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2019-23, with an official rate used for government business and a market-determined rate applicable to investors and exporters, which will be broadly in line with retail rates and the parallel market. Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors deemed important for economic or political reasons, including the NNPC, which budgets for petrol imports at the official rate. For this reason, the set-up is not expected to be tampered with. Although we anticipate a fall in exports over 2019-20, the decrease will not be steep enough or sustained to a point where devaluation of the official naira:US dollar exchange rate will be necessary. Over this period flat or declining interest rates in the US (we expect a 50-basis-point drop to be executed by the Federal Reserve, the US central bank, in 2020) will also support foreign-exchange supply via portfolio inflows. Higher world crude prices thereafter mean a flat official rate is likely throughout the forecast period. In real terms, currency stability (for both the official and more market-determined rates) means real appreciation of the naira against trading partners in 2019-20 as inflation remains high. For this reason there is a downside risk of policymakers opting to devalue or allowing more market-determined rates to weaken in order to regain international competitiveness. However, the CBN governor, Godwin Emefiele, is set against the idea and so devaluation is not included in the core forecast.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. For example, the current market-determined rate, known as the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Rate Fixing (Nafex), has only been in full operation since April 2017, making historical calculations challenging. However, indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The profile of export earnings will move in tandem with oil production and price trends. In 2019-20, output gains will be outweighed by a drop in world crude prices, as well as periodic pipeline outages disrupting supply. Only in 2021-23 when prices recover and Nigeria begins to sell refined oil overseas (a new mega-refinery being developed is expected to be export-oriented) will export earnings grow.
Nigeria's government actively promotes import-substitution through foreign-exchange restrictions on certain goods (mainly manufactures and agricultural produce). However, this policy is oriented more around stimulating local industry than reducing imports per se, and an overvalued naira will contribute to fairly strong consumer demand. Imports will only fall slightly in 2019-20, however, reflecting lower world crude prices (Nigeria imports almost all its petrol requirement). As the economy gathers pace in 2021-23 and world oil prices rise, imports will then grow faster. Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation in the oil sector will keep the services and primary income balances firmly in deficit. Meanwhile, workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, albeit dipping in 2020 as growth falters in the US (home to a large Nigerian diaspora). Overall, the current-account surplus will average 1.4% of GDP in 2019-20, widening again to 2.4% of GDP over 2021-23 as oil prices strengthen and the new refinery comes on stream.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), is under severe economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit has for some time believed that the Maduro regime's position is unsustainable, and we currently base our forecasts on a political transition within our five-year forecast period that introduces an interim administration led by Juan Guaidó, who we assume will undertake emergency adjustment measures, and prepare the ground for eventual free and fair elections. Currently, we assume that there will be some sort of regime change by the end of 2019. The timing and shape of the transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period (2019-23) to be characterised by political instability.
Our expectation of a change of government later in 2019 implies huge changes to policymaking as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms required to resolve the economic crisis.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under the transition and successor governments. Many of these policies have been outlined already, with the Guaidó administration seeking to reassure stakeholders in multilateral institutions and in potential donor nations such as the US and Europe of its capacity to stabilise the economy, address the humanitarian emergency, generate trust and legal security, ensure access to basic public services, and reactivate the oil industry.
The pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and how this stability might be impaired by likely demands for some politically difficult reforms from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.

Venezuela is in 79th position globally in the business environment rankings for 2019-23, up from 80th in the historical period. Assuming regime change, we do expect improvements, but it will take time for reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment to bear fruit.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of rollback of interventionist measures like price controls, but political-instability concerns slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt at attracting investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on the private sector's access to foreign currency remain in place.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2021-23: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Large-scale emigration of skilled labour complicates hiring.
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid means that rationing and unpredictable blackouts continue. A new government undertakes some repairs to the power network.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity has plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and side-lining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$18bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply let to increasing import dependence. We estimate the current-account surplus at 2% of GDP that year.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), is under severe economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit has for some time believed that the Maduro regime's position is unsustainable, and we currently base our forecasts on a political transition within our five-year forecast period that introduces an interim administration led by Juan Guaidó, who we assume will undertake emergency adjustment measures, and prepare the ground for eventual free and fair elections. Currently, we assume that there will be some sort of regime change by the end of 2019. The timing and shape of the transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period (2019-23) to be characterised by political instability.
Our forecast for regime change is based on the extent of the economic and humanitarian crisis currently unfolding in Venezuela. This has deeply damaged support for Mr Maduro among the population at large; we believe that it will ultimately erode support for Mr Maduro among key supporters in the military who currently prop him up in power. It is less clear, however, what the exact trigger for regime change will be. There are three main paths to a political transition: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We believe that the risk of military action, by the US or Colombia, is very low; although negotiations have been ongoing in recent weeks, we believe trust issues on both sides will be insurmountable and do not expect a negotiated solution to Venezuela's crisis.
On this basis, we believe the most likely scenario for regime change is some sort of internal coup. With US sanctions adding to the problem of dollar scarcity, Mr Maduro can no longer guarantee the regime's raison d'etre-the enrichment of its members-and we expect pragmatists within government and within the military to turn on him and pave the way for some sort of political transition. However, a failed uprising in late April demonstrated the difficulty of this sort of effort: some high-ranking members of the military were apparently negotiating with Mr Guaidó in April before backing out of the coup attempt at the last minute. But April's failed uprising did seem to confirm the existence of further cracks among the regime's ranks, and at the same time it is clear that lower-ranking members of the military are deeply dissatisfied. On this basis, our forecast for regime change still stands.
This forecast is underpinned by three key assumptions. Firstly, that regime pragmatists will prevail over hardliners. Despite the ongoing collapse of the patronage system, there are risks to this assumption, considering frequent purges within the military and the presence of dozens of important military figures, leading to co-ordination problems. Secondly, that regime members will deem Mr Guaidó's amnesty offers credible. Risks to this assumption include a deep-seated distrust of the opposition and fear of being prosecuted outside of Venezuela (a credible fear given accusations of drug- and weapon-trafficking levied at regime members). The third assumption underpinning our forecast for a government transition is a continued lack of hard currency to sustain the patronage system. Risks to this forecast come in the form of greater than expected support from Russia or China, and from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities that could be providing the regime with more hard currency than we currently expect.
We recognise the very high risks to our baseline view, and believe there are two main alternate scenarios. The first, and more likely, alternate scenario is the maintenance of the status quo, with the regime hunkering down, the opposition deflating, and the country becoming increasingly isolated and impoverished. The second scenario is one of prolonged chaos-including, possibly, armed conflict among regime factions. That said, we expect neither of these scenarios to be tenable in the medium to long term: with no prospect of real reform, we believe that a chronically weak economy will ultimately make Mr Maduro's position untenable. Moreover, violent, chaotic conflict in Venezuela could prove the line in the sand that provokes some sort of military action by the US and by Venezuela's Latin American neighbours to put an end to the crisis. For these reasons, we continue for now to believe that regime change in the forecast period remains likely, even if it does not occur in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The opposition's recently announced plans for a transitional government call for the renovation of all electoral authorities and for elections within 12 months of the transitional government's formation. Although this timeline is extremely ambitious given the scale of the task, we tentatively expect national elections to take place by the end of 2020. International assistance in organising the elections would be necessary and forthcoming. The task will be huge, as deep reforms to the electoral authority, to the electoral registry and to the voting system will be required, and rebuilding trust in the system will be difficult.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community. Most governments in the Americas, under the banner of the Lima Group, have recognised his presidency. The US is Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, instituting crippling oil sanctions and openly calling for the military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. The US's hawkish approach introduces risks of a military intervention. We currently do not foresee large-scale military action, in part because such an initiative lacks international legitimacy. However, if tension ratchets up and domestic violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the necessary financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and the state oil company, PDVSA. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but with little apparent success in terms of investment, and we believe that Russia and especially China would be willing to work with a successor government in an attempt to protect their current investments in Venezuela.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Our expectation of a change of government later in 2019 implies huge changes to policymaking as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms required to resolve the economic crisis. There has been evidence in recent months of attempts to tighten monetary policy to rein in hyperinflation and to abandon foreign-exchange controls (with few foreign reserves left to protect). However, we believe such efforts are doomed to failure without comprehensive microeconomic reform and improvements in rule of law and policy predictability that will not be forthcoming under the present regime.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under the transition and successor governments. Many of these policies have been outlined already, with the Guaidó administration seeking to reassure stakeholders in multilateral institutions and in potential donor nations such as the US and Europe of its capacity to stabilise the economy, address the humanitarian emergency, generate trust and legal security, ensure access to basic public services, and reactivate the oil industry. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and how this stability might be impaired by likely demands for some politically difficult reforms from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$46bn in 2020-23) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect that the non-financial public-sector deficit this year will be well into double digit levels as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Under our expectation of substantial currency adjustment, the public debt/GDP ratio will rise dramatically in coming years; however, our forecasts assume that a combination of debt restructuring and deep fiscal adjustment gradually bring the debt ratios under control. The process will be complicated, however, by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
Most sovereign and state-owned bonds (including PDVSA's) are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or a change in government. However, other investors have taken claims to the courts, and the results of these court battles will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining company, Crystallex, is seeking to collect an arbitration award by seizing shares of Citgo, PDVSA's US subsidiary. A ruling on the treatment of PDVSA as an "alter ego" of the government is pending, and will have implications for future debt restructuring. Following the imposition of sanctions on January 28th, the US government now considers Citgo to be under Mr Guaidó's purview, but nonetheless, the risk of seizure of Citgo, its Caribbean facilities and even shipments, will remain high in the short term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to print money in the short term. However, a significant increase in reserve requirements for the banking sector since the start of the year has had a temporary stabilising effect, which has slowed hyperinflationary pressures and allowed the bolívar to stabilise somewhat in recent weeks. On the basis that this measure is insufficient to tackle underlying inflation pressures, we expect monthly inflation to rise again in the short term. But based on our assumption that a transition government that places a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation will soon come to power, we do not currently project a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of over 1,000,000% experienced during 2018 (though there are substantial political risks to this forecast). Instead, under a new government, we expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of an emergency macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency, a temporary peg or outright currency substitution in such a context is highly likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 18.5% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. A forecast recovery in 2021-23 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by international assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 60% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2019, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Moreover, power cuts are now very common-a result of severe underinvestment in the country's power infrastructure-and have further damaged Venezuela's overall economic capacity.
Our forecast for a recovery in investment from 2020 assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment. We expect oil output to bottom out at 700,000 barrels/day (b/d) over the coming quarters, kept from going lower by PDVSA's joint-venture partners. In line with our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in 2020 but will end the forecast period (2019-23) well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017.
Export volumes will start to recover in 2020 on the back of the oil sector recovery, but an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb some of the projected increase in oil output. At the same time, import demand will rise sharply in 2020. All this will constrain the rebound of GDP initially, but in 2022-23, we do expect real GDP growth to gather some pace.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Severely reduced domestic supply, dollar constraints on import capacity, and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official inflation data were recently published by the BCV, but there is a significant gap between these data and other sources. Amid continuing questions over the data, we will, for now, continue to use the monthly series produced by the National Assembly. These data have shown some disinflation in recent months, with monthly inflation falling below the hyperinflation "threshold" of 50% per month. Huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand persist, however, and we expect inflation to remain extremely high for as long as the Maduro regime remains in power. On the basis of our assumption of regime change in the short term, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation. However, supply bottlenecks and bouts of inflationary pressure are likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our current baseline forecast of a political transition later in 2019, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) to try to tackle the inflation problem is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such moves is hard to predict. Our forecasts currently assume extremely large currency adjustments that restore some competitiveness to the local currency in real terms over time. For now, and with few foreign reserves left to protect, the Maduro regime has announced a loosening of currency controls. However, access to dollars via formal means will remain extremely difficult, and we believe that the foreign-exchange system will remain highly controlled in practice. In this environment a strong black-market exchange rate premium is likely to re-emerge, although in mid-June this was small by historical comparison, with the official rate at around BsS6,500:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of over BsS6.350:US$1.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
We have revised our current-account data in line with the recent publication of official data for 2017-18 by the BCV, which show that Venezuela continued to post current-account surpluses in the period on the back of higher non-oil exports than we had expected. However, we continue to project a shift into current-account deficit this year, bearing in mind the collapse of export earnings stemming from US sanctions on the oil trade. This deficit will emerge despite the non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2019 alone). We have also excluded repayments to Chinese lenders to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data, on which our debt forecasts are based. Later in the forecast period we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, but we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been severely reduced. These factors will keep the current account in deficit, although we expect the latter to narrow to a manageable level of around 3% of GDP towards the end of the forecast period.
We currently expect that a new administration will secure sufficient finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. It hinges on substantial IMF finance, rapid macroeconomic stabilisation, the fast resolution of a debt-renegotiation process, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberal Party, led by the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, to remain in power after the October 2019 election. However, it will be a tight contest and the government is likely to lose its majority.
The renegotiation of NAFTA has eased trade uncertainty, but we expect delays in the ratification process of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA; NAFTA's successor), possibly until 2020. Trade policy will remain a risk during the administration of the US president, Donald Trump, owing to Canada's reliance on the US, its key export market.
We forecast that real GDP growth will slow from 1.9% in 2018 to 1.6% in both 2019 and 2020, as private consumption growth moderates and an economic slowdown in the US dampens export demand. Real GDP growth will average 2.2% per year in 2021-23.
The federal budget will remain in deficit in 2019-23, as higher receipts from the carbon tax, the legalisation of cannabis and other sources will be more than offset by increased spending on infrastructure and other measures.
Consumer price inflation will ease to 1.8% in 2019, from 2.2% in 2018, reflecting recent monetary tightening, weaker external demand and generally lower oil prices. Inflationary pressures will ease further in 2020, in line with a subdued economy, before picking up from 2021 as growth regains momentum.
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted the policy rate three times in 2018, to 1.75%. We expect it to keep rates on hold in 2019-20, owing to the weaker economy and housing market, and the benign outlook for inflation. Modest tightening will resume in 2021 and continue in 2022-23.
The exchange rate, commodity prices and the health of the US economy will continue to shape the outlook for the current account, which will remain in deficit in 2019-23. The impact of softer global oil prices in 2019-20 will be offset by slowing domestic demand and, therefore, import growth. The merchandise trade deficit and the shortfall on the current account will remain broadly stable as a proportion of GDP, with the latter averaging 2.7% of GDP during this period.

Canada's score improves in 2019-23, pushing the country up to ninth place in our global business environment rankings. The best features of the business environment are political stability and openness to trade, although tax policy and the labour market will remain constraints.
Country forecast overview: Canada's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The government revises the Canada Business Corporations Act to introduce provisions on board gender diversity, annual election of directors, single election of directors and shareholder empowerment.
2021-23: Progress on increasing competition in certain sectors, such as telecommunications and dairy, will be uneven.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The government will continue to welcome foreign investment but will sometimes reject foreign takeovers owing to national security considerations. Chinese investment and takeover bids will come under particular scrutiny.
2021-23: Foreign investment is likely to rise in value terms as resource nationalism in the oil and gas sector eases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Canada, Mexico and the US ratify the revised North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), now called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which retains the essence of the original treaty.
2021-23: Canada continues to diversify its trade ties. Free-trade talks with China resume.
Taxes
2019-20: The government provides benefits and tax breaks to improve business competitiveness compared with the US.
2021-23: The government introduces reporting mechanisms for multinational enterprises to reduce tax avoidance.
Financing
2019-20: The Bank of Canada (the central bank) develops a system-wide framework to measure stress in banking, insurance and investment funds.
2021-23: The government completes its update of financial legislation, including the Bank Act, the Co-operative Credit Associations Act, the Insurance Companies Act, and the Trust and Loan Companies Act.
The labour market
2019-20: Canada will enact policies to streamline processes and increase quotas to expedite the hiring of foreign talent by companies.
2021-23: The government further encourages the entry of skilled workers and professionals by raising its immigration target.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Work begins on the Trans Mountain Expansion project, which will pipe additional crude oil from Alberta, although further legal challenges could slow progress.
2021-23: After years of uncertainty, pipelines to carry energy resources from Alberta begin to come on stream.
Technological readiness
2019-20: The technology sector benefits from workers moving from the US, especially those on that country's H1B visas, for whom the political climate becomes more difficult.
2021-23: Expertise in artificial intelligence takes root, particularly in the academic centres of Toronto and Montreal.

Background: The Canadian economy was the tenth-largest in the world in 2018 (measured in US dollars at market exchange rates). It is highly integrated with the US economy, which absorbs 75% of its goods exports and is the source of 51% of its imported goods. The US exerts a powerful economic and cultural influence on Canada. Fifty-eight per cent of Canadians say that English is their mother tongue; just over 21% say French and just under 21% have another language as their first. The majority of French-speakers live in Quebec, Canada's second most-populous province. Canada's unity is sometimes called into question, but support for sovereignty is currently muted in Quebec. Neither of the two leading political parties in the province is seeking an independence referendum.
Political structure: Canada is formally a constitutional monarchy, with the governor-general (always of Canadian nationality and appointed in Ottawa) acting as the representative of the British crown. In practice, the Canadian House of Commons is sovereign. Canada is a federation of ten provinces, each with substantial powers, and three territories. At the federal level are the Commons, the main seat of legislative power, and the non-elected Senate, which plays only a marginal role. The Liberal Party heads a majority government since winning the general election in 2015.
Policy issues: The federal government must balance the assistance that it is providing to the fossil fuel industry through approving new oil pipelines with the need to maintain its green credentials. The government will increase its spending on infrastructure significantly, including through its Canada Infrastructure Bank.
Taxation: The federal corporate income tax rate is 15%. Provincial governments charge corporate tax at rates between 2% and 16%. In 2016 the government introduced a new top marginal rate of personal income tax of 33%, which applies to taxable income over C$210,371 (US$157,706) in 2019.
Foreign trade: The US absorbs about three-quarters of Canadian exports, so the health of its economy is crucial for Canada. Canada's trade deficit was US$17bn in 2018 and the current-account deficit was US$45.3bn (2.6% of GDP).

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The Liberal Party government, led by the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, won a majority at the federal election in 2015, ending a decade of Conservative rule. The government has made notable progress on its reform agenda. However, controversy over alleged political interference in a criminal corruption case has tarnished Mr Trudeau's political brand, and friction with provincial administrations over environmental policy is intensifying. Although the Conservatives are currently ahead in opinion surveys, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberal Party to regain ground in the coming months and remain in government after the next federal election in October 2019. However, the Liberals are likely to fall short of a parliamentary majority, raising the prospect of legislative gridlock.
Mr Trudeau's popularity has been significantly damaged by his mishandling of allegations by the former attorney-general and justice minister, Jody Wilson-Raybould, that he and his officials put inappropriate political pressure on her to abandon the criminal prosecution for alleged fraud of SNC-Lavalin (a large Quebec-based construction and engineering firm, which denies all charges). Ms Wilson-Raybould and another cabinet minister, Jane Philpott, resigned from their positions, citing a lack of confidence in the government. They were both expelled from the caucus in April and will run as independents in October. As a result, the issue is likely to fester in the lead-up to the federal election.
Friction between the federal and provincial governments has intensified in recent months, owing mainly to disagreements on environmental legislation. Opposition parties have taken control of several provincial governments in recent years, setting the stage for policy battles ahead of the federal election. The most significant change of power has been the return to provincial government in Alberta of the United Conservative Party, which defeated the left-leaning New Democratic Party (NDP) government at the provincial election in April. The new Alberta premier, Jason Kenney, is a vocal critic of the federal Liberal government's environmental policies, which he argues have harmed Alberta's resource-based economy. In late May he repealed the carbon tax in the province introduced by the former NDP government. As a result, the Liberal government plans to impose the same federal carbon tax on the province of Alberta that it imposed in April on four other provinces-Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario and New Brunswick-that did not have pricing plans meeting federal standards. The imposition of the carbon tax in these provinces, and the nationalisation in 2018 of the Trans Mountain oil pipeline and expansion project, has raised questions over federal jurisdiction. The Trans Mountain expansion, designed to carry additional crude oil from Alberta to a port in British Columbia (BC), is opposed by the NDP provincial government in BC and by environmentalists, and the federal cabinet's decision on June 18th to proceed with the project will be controversial.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The opposition Conservative Party has overtaken the Liberals in opinion surveys since the SNC-Lavalin affair in February. According to an average of recent polls published by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation on June 10th, the Conservatives were supported by 35.3% of respondents, compared with 29.6% for the Liberals. The NDP was well behind, in third place, backed by 15.4% of those surveyed. Mr Trudeau's approval rating is now slightly below that of the Conservative leader, Andrew Scheer.
We nevertheless expect the Liberal Party to be in a position to form a minority government after the federal election in October 2019, reflecting the advantages of incumbency, and the implementation of much of the government's agenda, including the legalisation of cannabis.
However, the contest will be tight. Conservatives have an experienced shadow cabinet and are building momentum under Mr Scheer. They will focus on the Liberal government's perceived vulnerabilities, namely taxes, government spending and the cost of its climate change policies. The Conservatives also contend that the Liberals have lost control of the border by allowing over 40,000 people to walk across from the US over the past two years and claim asylum.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Under the Liberals, Canadian foreign policy emphasises multilateralism over unilateralism, engagement over isolation, mitigating the effects of climate change and upholding human rights. This is in clear contrast to the policies pursued by Donald Trump's administration in the US. As a result, bilateral relations with the US will be strained during the remainder of the Trump administration. Canada will, nonetheless, seek to preserve relations with the US, its most important diplomatic and economic partner by far. Where possible, Canada will attempt to circumvent the White House by strengthening its ties to other levels of US government. Canada will also increase efforts to diversify trade.
The signing in November 2018 of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which will replace NAFTA and preserve the trilateral arrangement, mitigates significant trade risk for Canada. The revised deal maintains most of the substance of the earlier deal. In particular, the USMCA retains the Chapter 19 dispute-resolution mechanism, which Canada relies on to protect some of its industries (primarily lumber) from potential US anti-dumping measures. It also grants the US greater access to the Canadian market for dairy, poultry and eggs (these sectors are managed by the government to ensure sufficiently high prices for farmers). Canada also negotiated an exemption from any future tariffs that the US might impose on automotive imports. The lifting in May of US tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminium imports has removed a key obstacle to ratification of the USMCA. However, the timing for ratification of the agreement poses a challenge for all three administrations. Ongoing delays on the US side, and Canada's parliamentary recess from June 21st until November will complicate the ratification process in those two countries. Our central forecast is that the USMCA will be ratified by all three nations, but this process could be delayed until next year. Downside risks to ratification will nevertheless grow as time passes, owing to the start of the presidential election season in the US.
The implementation of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) is expected to provide enhanced access to key Asian markets over the forecast period. A trade deal signed with the EU in 2016 has removed 98% of the EU tariff lines. With full implementation, the figure is set to rise to 99%.
China was a key target for the government's trade diversification policy until December, when Meng Wanzhou, a senior executive of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, was detained in Canada at the request of US authorities on fraud charges (that she denies). Bitter exchanges between Canada and China since her arrest have cast a chill on bilateral relations. In March the Canadian government announced that it would proceed with hearings on her extradition. In response, China has detained two Canadians, sentenced two others convicted of drug crimes to death and blocked canola (rapeseed) imports, on the alleged grounds of biosecurity concerns. We expect tensions to persist, preventing progress on exploratory free trade.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government will seek to support domestic industries that are adversely affected by US trade protectionism and Canada's trade issues with China. In 2018 the finance minister, Bill Morneau, announced measures to increase the competitiveness of Canadian businesses after the introduction of tax cuts in the US at the start of last year. These included a tax break on capital expenditure in manufacturing. However, the government will struggle to balance environmental policy with support for the fossil fuel industry. On the one hand, the government has rolled out a national carbon tax of C$20/tonne (US$15/tonne) in provinces that did not have an equivalent carbon pricing programme in place. The federal tax will rise to C$50/tonne by 2022. On the other hand, the federal government has approved the controversial C$7.4bn (US$5.5bn) expansion of the Trans Mountain pipeline, which it now owns. The project still faces some regulatory hurdles, and the start of construction work could be delayed further by legal challenges.
Policymakers will continue to keep a close eye on the residential property market, which remains a key risk owing to monetary policy tightening last year and overleveraged Canadian households. Measures introduced by the federal government and provincial governments in Ontario and BC have helped to cool the housing market. In Vancouver and Toronto, foreign buyers are now subject to a 15% tax on property purchases, while the federal government has tightened mortgage requirements nationwide, which has improved the quality of new mortgage lending. Price growth has slowed markedly, with some measures showing a dip in house prices since late 2018, although trends vary across the country. We expect the housing market to remain sluggish in 2019, reflecting a combination of tighter lending standards, continued affordability pressures, and diminished investor activity, although a major correction is unlikely in the absence of higher interest rates.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The government is committed to a programme of infrastructure and other spending that will entail a series of budget deficits, but this will be partially offset by increased receipts due to the introduction of the carbon tax and greater tax income as a result of cannabis legalisation. However, lower average oil prices in 2019-20 compared with 2018 will weigh on plans to reduce the fiscal deficit, as increased government support will be expected to shore up the economy and government receipts are likely to undershoot official projections.
According to the federal budget for fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March) handed down on March 19th, the budget deficit for 2019/20 will be C$19.8bn (US$14.8bn), equivalent to 0.9% of GDP. Official projections show the budget deficit declining to C$9.8bn, equivalent to 0.4% of GDP, by 2023/24. We project that the fiscal deficit will expand from 0.4% of GDP in 2018 (our fiscal forecasts are calendar-year based) to, respectively, 1% of GDP in 2019 and 1.2% of GDP in 2020. The government will look to narrow the deficit in the longer term, and we expect it to fall gradually, to 0.7% of GDP by 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted its policy rate by 125 basis points between July 2017 and October 2018, in response to rising inflation, and to discourage highly indebted households from accumulating further debt. However, the BoC has kept rates steady at its last five scheduled interest-rate meetings, owing to lower energy prices late last year, which pushed down the headline inflation rate in early 2019, and slowing real GDP growth in the first quarter. The central bank is in no hurry to resume the process of returning interest rates to what it considers a neutral level, which it believes stands between 2.25% and 3.25%.
Given the benign outlook for inflation, weak household spending growth, the soft housing market and a loss in global economic momentum, we expect the BoC to leave the policy rate unchanged throughout 2019. We forecast that rates will remain on hold in 2020 as US growth slows further; because of the close ties between the two countries, this will weigh on economic growth in Canada. Modest monetary tightening will resume in 2021 and continue in 2022-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth slowed to an upwardly revised 1.9% in 2018, from 3% in 2017, and we expect the pace of economic expansion to soften further in 2019, to an average of 1.6%. Previous monetary tightening, high household debt levels and the subdued housing market will weigh on private consumption growth this year. However, solid growth in government spending will help cushion the impact. Export growth is also expected to moderate, as a result of weaker economic expansion in the US, Canada's key export market.
Much of 2018 was characterised by the escalating trade dispute with the US. The renegotiation of NAFTA reduces one of the key downside risks to our forecast, although we expect delays (possibly until 2020) in the ratification process of the successor agreement, the USMCA. Canadian producers and manufacturers will benefit from the removal in May of US tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminium imports, and the end of the retaliatory import tariffs that Canada imposed, but are feeling the pinch from trade restrictions imposed by China on some Canadian farm exports, such as canola. Global trade uncertainty remains a major downside risk to out forecast. Other risks to the economic outlook include a sharp drop in global oil prices, which would act as a drag on economic activity.
Growth in the US and world trade will continue to lose steam in 2020, when we expect real GDP growth in Canada to remain well below its long-term trend, at 1.6%. The pace of economic expansion is expected to pick up again in 2021, and real GDP growth will average 2.2% per year in 2022-23. This will be supported by continued public investment in infrastructure and stronger export growth, driven by recovering demand in the US and enhanced trade ties with the EU and CPTPP members.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Rising oil prices throughout much of 2018 and the increasingly protectionist trade policy of the US added to price pressures last year, when the headline rate of consumer price inflation accelerated to an average of 2.2%. The inflation rate fell back to 1.6% year on year in the first quarter of 2019, below the BoC's 2% target rate, owing to lower petrol prices and the impact of previous monetary tightening by the central bank. However, it has picked up more quickly than we expected, to 2.1% year on year in May. In light of this, we have revised up slightly our forecast for consumer price inflation in 2019, which we now expect will average 1.8% (previously 1.7%). Subdued economic growth and generally lower oil prices will lead to a further easing in the inflation rate next year, before it picks up again from 2021 as the economy strengthens.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Tighter monetary policy, a broader improvement in the global economy and the draining of the surplus in the oil market lent support to the Canadian dollar in the first half of 2018, but falling oil prices and weakening growth weighed on the currency late last year and in early 2019. As a result, the Canadian dollar will depreciate this year, on average, against its US counterpart, to stand at C$1.34:US$1. Downward pressure on the Canadian dollar from continued soft economic growth and oil prices next year will be mitigated by interest-rate cuts from the Federal Reserve (the US central bank), keeping the local currency broadly unchanged in 2020. A pick-up in growth from 2021, and the resumption of monetary tightening, will underpin a modest appreciation in the Canadian dollar over the remainder of the forecast period, with the currency forecast to average C$1.30:US$1 in 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The exchange rate, commodity prices and the health of the US economy will continue to shape the outlook for the current account, which will remain in deficit in 2019-23. The impact of softer global oil prices in 2019-20 will be offset by slowing domestic demand and, therefore, import growth. The merchandise trade deficit and the shortfall on the current account will therefore remain broadly stable as a proportion of GDP, with the latter averaging 2.7% of GDP during this period. The CPTPP, the effects of which will first be felt at the start of the next decade, will result in higher trade volumes between Canada and Pacific nations. We expect that this will help to narrow the current-account deficit to 2.4% of GDP in 2023.

Full text: Ecuador--highlights: Political outlook
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the president, Lenín Moreno, to continue to decline in popularity for the remainder of his term (ending in 2021) as his administration implements austerity measures and structural reforms as part of an IMF-backed economic programme. Mr Moreno will maintain a tenuous advantage over the fragmented opposition after securing sufficient support from opposition parties to make headway on certain structural reforms, including labour market liberalisation policies. More contentious reforms, namely tax reform measures, will weigh on political stability and governability. Although there is not an indication of who is running for Mr Moreno's party in the 2021 election, we expect a victory for a centre-right opposition candidate, such as Jaime Nebot. Provided that Mr Moreno doesn't exercise executive powers to push through reforms, we would not expect major policy reversals.
Ecuador--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c

4.69 5.50 69 67 10 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Some improvements in the business environment are likely under Mr Moreno's more market-friendly admin-istration, particularly in terms of official policy towards foreign investment and private enterprise. However, structural impediments such as weak legal security, inadequate access to local finance, the small market size and continued political risk will prove much more difficult to tackle. This explains why Ecuador continues to rank poorly in our business environment rankings. A modest uptick in investment is likely, but many investors are likely to steer clear until the government has demonstrated a solid and longer track record of policy stability.

The high public spending and investment that formed the pillars of growth under the former president, Rafael Correa (2007-17), will abate as Mr Moreno moves ahead with fiscal adjustment measures. Cuts to capital expenditure and a slowdown in consumption will keep growth weak. Following a small current-account deficit in 2018, the current has widespread support, as it has delivered macroeconomic stability and helped to tame inflation. As part of the government's IMF-backed economic programme, we expect a build up international reserves and measures that reinforce the foundations of dollarisation in 2019-23.

Population growth is slowing because of a falling birth rate and continued, albeit lower, emigration. However, at an annual average rate of 1.3% per year in 2019-23, population growth will be on a par with that of neighbouring Andean nations. The unemployment rate will rise to 4.7% by 2020 before falling to 4.1% in 2023. Underemployment will remain high, exceeding 50%. Despite forthcoming labour reforms, Ecuador's informal sector is expected to remain substantial, owing in part to deeply entrenched labour market rigidities.

Although Ecuador is one of the smallest markets in our business environment rankings, its significant mineral reserves will continue to attract oil and mining investors, and we expect the domestic market to grow moderately. Business opportunities outside of the extractive sectors will remain restricted by low purchasing power, with GDP per head estimated at US$6,370 in 2018 and forecast to reach US$6,951 in 2023. Persistent income inequality and anaemic growth will hinder robust growth in household consumption.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Low levels of productivity and a wealth of natural resources offer scope for Ecuador to catch up with more developed countries, provided that policies are implemented to transform its resource wealth into productive investment in other sectors. Ecuador will benefit from dollarisation and incremental improvements to the business environment. However, poor prospects for significant improvements to Ecuador's institutions do not bode well for a more stable economic policy direction. Assuming persistent structural deficiencies and inconstant policymaking decisions, we forecast that long-term investment will be lacking and income levels will continue to trail OECD levels in the long term.

Background: Ecuador restored its presidential democracy in 1979, but its institutions are fragile. External economic shocks have contributed to the ousting of three presidents by popular protests since 1997. The current president, Lenín Moreno, took office in May 2017, succeeding Rafael Correa (2007-17), the longest-serving president in Ecuadorean history. In February 2018 a series of constitutional reforms introduced by Mr Moreno (including the re-introduction of a two-term limit for the presidency) were approved in a referendum. Although this was a step towards deeper democratisation and has strengthened Mr Moreno's political power to a certain extent, persistent social and fiscal challenges will continue to weigh on governance.
Political structure: The political system is fragmented. Mr Moreno's Alianza País lost considerable standing in recent municipal elections. The 2008 Constitution granted more power to the executive, but has done little to foster the institutional capacity to tackle problems such as a politicised judiciary, powerful business lobbies, and mobilised grassroots and indigenous groups.
Policy issues: Dollarisation has provided macroeconomic stability, but has also exposed Ecuador's underlying lack of competitiveness. Reforms are needed to address business environment deficiencies, which include inefficient and costly utilities, legal insecurity, a rigid labour market and low skill levels. Mr Correa adopted expansionary fiscal policy in 2007-17, facilitated by high oil prices. Mr Moreno will not be as lucky: oil prices will remain modest by the standards of the previous decade during the forecast period, which will force the government to make fiscal adjustments. The government secured external financing from multilateral organisations and the IMF after borrowing in international capital markets became unsustainable, given high risks resulting from liquidity issues. This will lead to a bolder fiscal adjustment, with a three-year IMF deal dictating the policy direction for the remainder of Mr Moreno's administration (ending in 2021).
Taxation: Taxes have been subject to frequent changes. The main taxes in Ecuador are income tax, levied at rates of up to 35%, and value-added tax (VAT), levied at 12%. Private firms must distribute 15% of their profits among their employees.
Foreign trade: Ecuador posted a trade deficit of US$263m in 2018 (compared with a US$312m surplus in 2017), as a pick-up in imports surpassed oil export revenue. Efforts to boost competitiveness will produce a trade surplus in 2019-23.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Ecuador has a multi-party democracy. The centre-left president, Lenín Moreno, from Alianza País (AP), took office in May 2017 for a four-year term, after winning a run-off against Guillermo Lasso of the centre-right Creando Oportunidades (Creo). At the onset of Mr Moreno's term, the president's party had a legislative majority, but following a power clash with his predecessor, Rafael Correa (2007-17), the AP split in 2018 with Mr Correa's supporters forming a new political bloc, Revolución Ciudadana (RC). Lacking a majority, Mr Moreno counts on support from opposition parties.
The biennial reorganisation of the National Assembly in May 2019 gave rise to a novel legislative pact between the AP, Creo and two legislative blocs that include legislators from a series of small parties, among them the hard-left indigenous party Pachakutik, centre-left Izquierda Democrática, populist Partido Sociedad Patriótica and centre-left Fuerza Ecuador. The agreement provides a working majority, albeit tenuous, which allows Mr Moreno to pursue structural reforms that intend to ease employability, bolster public finances and restore central bank independence, as well as strengthen the public pension system. Explicit backing for more contentious legislation, such as tax reform, was lacking from the agreement and is likely to undermine co-operation in the second half of 2019. The redistribution of legislative committees led to the removal of the RC from the Consejo de Administración Legislativa (the legislative administrative committee), a powerful panel that vets incoming legislation, and prevents the party from presiding over any other legislative panel, effectively curtailing Mr Correa's influence in congress.
