Political outlook: Political stability
For the remainder of Mr Moreno's term in office, ending in May 2021, the president will face the political challenge of implementing ambitious structural reforms and austerity measures envisaged in his economic programme, which is backed by an Extended Fund Facility (EFF) agreement with the IMF. Although the government is poised to receive a total of US$10.3bn in multilateral financing over the next three years to cover its financing needs, bolstering political stability, adjustments are bound to fuel public discontent and test the government's commitment to the programme. This is likely to put Mr Moreno, of the ruling centre-left Alianza País (AP), under increased pressure and weigh on his already-waning popularity-and hence congressional support for him.
Governability will receive a boost from the biennial restructuring of the National Assembly in May. Although Mr Moreno lacks a congressional majority-requiring 69 legislators-his party forged a deal with the largest opposition party, Creando Oportunidades, and several small parties in the National Assembly, including Pachakutik, a hard-left indigenous party. With this pragmatic alliance, Mr Moreno is likely to receive sufficient backing to make headway addressing structural deficiencies, including labour market reforms (a bill is set to be submitted later in May).
Opposition parties, however, did not offer their backing for a tax reform that is set to be introduced in October. It is likely that Mr Moreno will make concessions to opposition parties to pass revenue-raising legislation, settling for a diluted bill. This is the most likely scenario given approaching elections and the presence of obstructionist legislative blocs. The probable conservative frontrunner in the 2021 presidential election, Jaime Nebot, the leader of the second-largest opposition party, Partido Social Cristiano (PSC), has previously spoken against any sort of IMF deal and is only likely to support the tax reforms if he decides that he can capitalise on the political cost to the AP. Members of the AP and legislators that support Mr Moreno may well be hesitant to back tax hikes out of fear that they may hurt their chances of re-election. Staunch supporters of Rafael Correa, the former president (2007-17) are likely to oppose any legislation pursued by Mr Moreno.
If Mr Moreno does succeed in passing legislation without concessions or dilutions, he will incur even greater political costs, as austerity measures are likely to cause social unrest. This would intensify political instability and greatly diminish governability. A similar end-result is possible if Mr Moreno unilaterally pushes forward the tax reform through emergency legislation, which would require two-thirds of the National Assembly to overturn. This would probably result in political gridlock, engender political backlash and raise the likelihood that the next government in 2021 reverses the policies enacted by Mr Moreno.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Deeply politicised institutions, an inefficient bureaucracy, a complex and archaic tax system, and corruption have long undermined institutional effectiveness. Although the former administration of Mr Correa initially increased government effectiveness by allowing the executive to bypass a deeply fragmented legislature, Mr Correa's constitutional amendments in 2008 and 2015 tilted discretional power in the executive's favour, reducing accountability.
Mr Moreno has made moderate progress in addressing institutional weaknesses. The 2018 referendum enabled Mr Moreno to restructure the judicial appointment process, introduce term limits for the executive, enact stricter penalties for corruption, move to rationalise real estate taxation and introduce market-friendly regulations regarding mining investment. However, despite impending structural reforms as part of the government's economic programme (with guidance from the IMF), challenges will remain: bureaucratic inefficiencies will persist and lawmaking will be subject to the demands of an array of vested interests, while enforcement will be inadequate.
Weak institutional effectiveness will remain a hindrance
Under the presidency of Mr Correa there was a marked decline in the independence of the judiciary. Reforms were enacted that conspicuously augmented the degree of control that the executive had on the courts system, and led to the dismissal of hundreds of judges. Since coming to power in 2017, Mr Moreno has attempted to remove political interference from the judiciary and curb graft. Results have been mixed. Mr Moreno successfully installed a new panel of judges to the Constitutional Court after the previous court was terminated amid a cloud of allegations of wrongdoing, with investigations into alleged malfeasance including money-laundering and other financial crimes, which intensified the court's already-poor reputational standing due to perceptions of favouritism towards the incumbent political leadership. Nonetheless, inefficiency and corruption remain deeply rooted in the judicial system. The Council of the Judiciary has shown little progress in handling corruption cases, while access to legal protection and law enforcement remains flawed, and the lack of effective protection of rights persists.
Although historically Ecuador has had a relatively low crime rate, the security environment has deteriorated over the past decade. There is little chance of marked improvement, unless measures are adopted to improve the competence and effectiveness of law-enforcement agencies. There are no home-grown terrorist organisations, but violence has spilled over from Colombia owing to a rise in drug-trafficking and related money-laundering by groups of dissident guerrillas from the FARC that oppose the peace deal signed in 2016 with the Colombian government. Mr Moreno will bolster Ecuador's existing international security co-operation efforts, through closer co-operation with the US as well as organisations such as Interpol and the Financial Action Task Force of Latin America (a regional financial intelligence and anti-money-laundering network). But anti-corruption initiatives will yield few tangible results. Mr Moreno established an International Anti-Corruption Commission to advise state institutions on preventing corruption that will expire at the end of his term, but has otherwise struggled to make sweeping progress in combating pervasive corruption, weighing on political effectiveness.
Mr Moreno has been less confrontational with the police force than his predecessor, whose relations soured following a police mutiny in 2010, when officers rioted in the capital, Quito, in protest against pension reforms. There is little evidence to suggest that foreign businesses are singled out as targets for crime, but inept and inefficient law enforcement means that firms must provide their own security, increasing operational costs.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next legislative and presidential elections will be held in February 2021. At this stage, Mr Moreno has not given a clear indication of whether or not he intends to run for re-election. Provided that the current administration remains committed to implementing its IMF-backed economic programme, we expect the AP to decline in popularity and weaken the chances that Mr Moreno will run or that an AP candidate achieves a presidential victory. A candidate backed by Mr Correa is unlikely to play a significant role in the presidential election, while the centre-right PSC, which performed well in municipal elections in March, is best poised to capitalise on the fragmented political landscape and mount a strong campaign.
Political outlook: International relations
Ecuador's pro-Western foreign policy realignment under Mr Moreno augurs closer diplomatic and economic co-operation with the US, its largest trading partner. Since taking office in 2017, Mr Moreno has initiated talks with the US on a free-trade agreement (FTA), aligned his government with the US by recognising Juan Guaidó as Venezuela's interim president and, in April, ending the political asylum of Julian Assange-an Australian citizen subject to a US Department of Justice investigation for conspiring to help a former US army soldier, Chelsea Manning, access secret US military documents.
Apart from consolidating relations with the US, Mr Moreno's foreign policy is geared towards deepening trade and investment links within Latin America and with Europe and Asia, partly to help to diversify the economy away from oil. Mr Moreno has launched the Foro para el Progreso y Desarrollo de América del Sur (Prosur, a centre-right regional public-policy bloc) with other Latin American leaders and initiated Ecuador's accession to the Pacific Alliance, a regional trade bloc. However, we expect negotiations over the latter to last beyond 2023, partly because relations with neighbouring Peru and Colombia will face strains owing to Ecuador's import tariffs. The government has also sought to raise its trade profile with the EU and develop its commercial ties with China, while also cultivating relationships with other countries in Asia and the Middle East.

a See Guide to the business rankings model at the end of this report. b Out of 10. c Out of 82 countries. d  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela. e New section, introduced in 2018.
Ecuador scores poorly in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings and, despite improving in the forecast period, the country will remain towards the bottom of our global rankings (at 68th out of 82 countries). The improvements in Ecuador's underlying scores and comparative rankings mainly relate to changes that are being introduced by the president, Lenín Moreno. His policies are proving significantly more market-friendly than those of his predecessor, Rafael Correa (2007-17), who demonstrated a preference for state-led development and introduced more obstacles to an already-weak environment for doing business.
As such, the main categories in which Ecuador sees the most marked improvements are those related to government policy: the country's global ranking rises for policy towards private enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, as well as those related to taxes. This progress mainly reflects the scaling-back of state-led development in favour of a renewed push towards private investment. The government is looking at ways of fostering competition and reforming tax legislation in order to attract investment, which will improve the regulatory backdrop (albeit from a low base of comparison).
Other areas of the business environment, however, will be harder to tackle. The small size of the market, financing constraints and difficulties arising from bloated government bureaucracy will continue to weigh heavily on Ecuador's investment climate. The political situation will also remain a concern for investors. Despite the current government's more pro-market policy stance, there is little evidence of sweeping national (or congressional) support for broad-based structural reforms. Notwithstanding his current tenuous working majority, the president, whose approval ratings have already dropped sharply, may face an increasingly obstructionist congress, which would complicate governability. There is a risk that Mr Moreno's reforms might be rolled back by a successor administration. This uncertainty will continue to deter many investors and helps explain why we do not expect a dramatic improvement in Ecuador's overall business environment.

Business environment outlook: Ecuador's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Fuel subsidies are gradually rolled back. Implementation of antitrust policies is subject to politicisation. Select industries, such as mining, benefit from policies promoting supply-side growth.
2021-23: Fiscal austerity requires a scaling-back of the state-led development model. Nonetheless, regulation and licensing continue to favour state-run companies over private-sector firms. A new public-private partnership model is trialled.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Overtures to foreign firms and pro-business reforms partly offset the government's continual interventionism.
2021-23: Inadequate property rights protection and questions over access to foreign arbitration deter investment. New mining projects attract investment.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Government maintains capital outflows tax and increases import tariffs to protect dollarisation.
2021-23: Supply-side reforms enhance national competitiveness and government begins to phase out capital outflows tax.
Taxes
2019-20: Government introduces tax-reform legislation in 2019 (to be implemented in 2020-21) to expand tax base and improve collection. Certain exemptions will be eliminated while other burdensome regulations are simplified.
2021-23: Efforts continue to increase tax collection to support revenue growth. Tax system remains complex.
Financing
2019-20: Deposit and credit growth are moderate and support banking stability.
2021-23: Financing is still below potential as public-financing needs curb growth of long-term lending to the private sector.
The labour market
2019-20: Government takes steps to reduce public wage bill and reduce labour market rigidities.
2021-23: Quality of workforce remains poor. Labour reforms slow to take effect.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Fiscal constraints lead to cancellation of several projects. Efforts to drum up large-scale foreign investment meet with little success.
2021-23: Renewed interest in port and airport development sustains new cycle of investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Investment to expand 4G broadband availability.
2021-23: Increasing adoption of civic technologies by the government. 5G technology remains in its infancy.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.5 7.8 32 32 3 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's ranking for the macroeconomic environment category-by some distance its strongest area of the business environment-will remain stable in the forecast period. However, Ecuador's score is flattered by dollarisation as it keeps inflation low and reduces the risk of periods of sharp currency volatility. Other areas of the macroeconomic environment score much more weakly, including the quality of official policymaking and strength of economic institutions. The public finances are also a particularly weak area, with large fiscal deficits in recent years resulting in a sharp rise in public debt. A recently signed agreement with the IMF will provide crucial financing support and will help to guide the reform process, but the government will need to rein in public spending throughout the forecast period in order to put the economy on a stronger long-term footing.
The previous government's failure to diversify the economy significantly beyond the mainstay of the oil sector will hamper medium-term growth potential. Oil prices are likely to remain relatively contained in 2019-23 (West Texas Intermediate prices, which are a proxy for Ecuadorean oil export prices, are forecast to average US$62.7/barrel, only marginally higher than US$60.2/b in the 2014-18 historical period) and production volumes are set to remain weak. Faster sustainable rates of growth in the non-oil economy would require greater legal stability and improvements in the regulatory environment, as well as expanded access to foreign markets. Investment and structural reforms in electricity, telecommunications and fuel refining would also be needed to reduce the cost of these goods and services to competitive levels. Although we do expect some improvements in these areas, it will take time for investment to feed through to lifting output.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.0 5.3 67 56 10 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
A slowly improving policy approach towards the private sector
Ecuador's score and ranking for policy towards private enterprise and competition improves during the 2019-23 forecast period. Its poor ranking in the historical period mainly reflects the Correa administration's erratic policy approach towards the private sector, but moderate improvements under the current president, Lenín Moreno, are under way. A preference for creating or developing state-owned companies has been abandoned, although a full reversal of state ownership is unlikely. This is likely to increase the scope for private-sector participation in some regulated sectors of the economy, including infrastructure and mining. However, a significant liberalisation of policy towards private enterprise and competition is unlikely, with monopolies and oligopolies remaining a feature of Ecuador's business environment (in particular in the cement, financial, supermarket and steel industries), while fixed prices or subsidisation in some areas will continue. Under Mr Correa, government regulations increased substantially and private-sector lobbies were able to exert less political influence over the Correa administration than in previous governments, but Mr Moreno has stronger ties to parts of the private sector, whose influence on policymaking we expect to increase. Although some modest reform progress is being achieved, high levels of bureaucracy will continue to constrain private investment and competition in 2019-23.
Although the government has indicated that it is considering welcoming foreign concessions in some state companies, we do not expect any significant moves towards full, or even part-privatisation of state-run assets during 2019-23. The main area identified so far by the government is the state-owned telecommunications company, the Corporación Nacional de Tele-comunicaciónes (CNT), with the authorities stating in early 2019 that they are looking to launch a tender for a stake in the company during the second half of the year. The country's 2019 budget includes US$1bn pencilled in from concessions; the government has stated that it is targeting US$250m per year over a 20-year horizon from the CNT concession, indicating that stakes in other public holdings are also being considered. However, we remain sceptical that this will materialise. There is significant public opposition to the sale of stakes in state assets, which is likely to hamper the government's plans. Moreover, it is unclear whether significant demand exists, as foreign firms may be deterred by mismanagement of state-run companies in recent years, as well as the fact that many lack fully audited accounts (which will complicate estimates of market value).
The Moreno government is pushing for all major infrastructure projects to be developed with private-sector investment, primarily using public-private partnership agreements (PPPs). The current PPP legislative framework is based on the Regulations for the Public-Private Partnership Regime, the Law of Incentives for PPPs and Foreign Investment, and the General Regulations for the Application of the Framework Law of Incentives for PPPs and Foreign Investment. These were all introduced in 2015-16 and essentially consist of tax breaks, including from import tariffs and value-added tax (VAT), during project construction, as well as a ten-year reprieve from income tax and from a tax on the repatriation of profits. However, institutional barriers will prevent the take-up of PPPs. A lack of staff at the national level with necessary resources to promote and support PPP development will hamper international interest in potential projects, while ongoing legal insecurity will also remain a concern for investors.
Bureaucracy will remain burdensome, albeit decreasingly owing to Mr Moreno's efforts to reduce restrictive regulations. The state will continue to be involved in price fixing. This practice is common for agricultural goods, agrochemicals, pharma-ceuticals, transport and some labour services. Energy prices (fuel, cooking-gas and electricity) are also fixed, representing a substantial fiscal burden. Mr Moreno has also supported the idea of subsidies in order to tackle poverty, despite fiscal pressures. Plans to lift subsidies on automotive diesel were abandoned in January. Efforts to control smuggling to neighbouring Peru and Colombia will remain in force, but progress will be slow and formal sector traders will continue to face disloyal competition from contraband.
In January 2019 new regulations clarifying the application of the Productive Development Law, originally enacted in August 2018 to encourage investment and generate employment, were published. These target export-oriented businesses, manufacturing and tourism. In addition to clarifying existing laws, the new regulations have been introduced to simplify environmental regulations and provide additional tax incentives. These include new processes intended to eliminate delays in the issuance of mining licences, streamline customs procedures and guarantee exporter liquidity.
An antitrust law was adopted in 2011 but parts of the legislation are poorly defined, in particular the scope for price setting by the government. Moreover, the anti-monopoly regulator, the Superintendencia de Control del Poder de Mercado, has limited resources, calling into question its efficacy. There have been some concerns that the legal framework provides ample ground for the government to extract concessions from industries on political grounds, at the expense of both market share and profitability, but Mr Moreno's efforts at conciliation with the private sector suggest that this will be less likely during 2019-23.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.2 6.0 72 59 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Interventionism and a burdensome bureaucracy will persist
Ecuador's score for policy towards foreign investment improves firmly in 2019-23 and its position in the global ranking rises to 59th from 72nd (although it remains unchanged in the regional ranking, in 10th place). The Moreno government is proving much more willing to engage with foreign investors. However, securing legislative support for deeper structural reforms to improve the business environment is far from certain. Ecuador's still relatively weak ranking reflects the likelihood of ongoing government intervention in key sectors, powerful domestic vested interests that will resist some of the government's reform efforts, and a weak legal framework.
The excessive cost of loans-for-oil deals between Ecuadorean state-owned enterprises, such as PetroEcuador, and Chinese entities, such as the China Development bank, the China Export-Import Bank and the China National Petroleum Company, have amounted to more than US$15bn since 2010. These loans have financed major infrastructure projects, including the US$2.6bn Coca Codo Sinclair hydroelectric project. This practice is likely to impel the Moreno administration to favour private-sector foreign direct investment (FDI; most loans carried rates higher than 10%, which is the average rate of Ecuadorean bonds' rates at issuance over the same period).
The government is more amenable to foreign investment, but pro-business reforms will be limited
There are successful examples of foreign investment in recent years (particularly in services, light manufacturing and banking), but private investment in oil and mining (the two sectors with most export potential) has been minimal, deterred by ongoing legal disputes between the government and foreign companies. A long-running dispute with a US oil company, Occidental Petroleum, was finally settled in late 2015, but Ecuador is still facing a number of outstanding claims at the World Bank's International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID). The fact that Ecuador has renounced further participation in ICSID and has denounced (but will renegotiate) a number of bilateral investment treaties-most recently with 12 countries including the US and China, in May 2017-will continue to spook foreign investors.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.4 6.4 59 67 8 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's economy has traditionally been one of the more open in the region, but repeated import and capital-account restrictions, as well as shifts in the government's stance on trade openness, has seen foreign trade as a share of GDP fall from close to 70% in 2006 to around 46% in 2018. We are not forecasting any significant improvement in the forecast period, and Ecuador's underlying score will remain unchanged, while its global and regional rankings will slip. Efforts to diversify export markets to Asia and Europe, the latter through a free-trade agreement (FTA) have seen limited success. The Correa government largely steered clear of signing FTAs with traditional markets, and-despite some limited progress on new FTA negotiations-we do not expect dramatic changes under Mr Moreno. Sporadic trade spats with regional partners are likely to continue, dragging down Ecuador's score in this area. Ecuador's terms of trade worsened in 2012-16-mainly reflecting oil price movements-and, despite improving slightly in 2017-18, they are expected to remain fairly weak in 2019-23.
Ecuador's trade integration with the US, the country's biggest export partner, will remain adversely affected by Ecuador's unilateral decision in 2013 to withdraw from the Andean Trade Promotion and Drug Eradication Act (ATPDEA). ATPDEA was an agreement that granted tariff-free access to the US market for around 6,000 goods. The government failed to secure an alternative trade agreement, forcing many non-traditional sectors such as cut flowers, fruit and vegetables to lose competitiveness against other Latin American countries that have maintained FTAs with the US. There are signs that bilateral ties are improving under Mr Moreno, with the US and Ecuador holding the first meeting of the two countries' Trade and Investment Council (TIC) in nine years. Representatives discussed a broad range of trade and investment-related issues, including bilateral trade and investment flows, co-operation projects, intellectual property aspects related to trade, investment issues, and trade in agricultural and fishery products. However, aside from negotiations there is little indication of a move to revive expired trading preferences.
The Correa government made some progress in streamlining custom procedures in order to improve efficiency, although corruption and drug smuggling via overseas shipments remain a problem. There are a number of electronic procedures and automation processes that have helped to speed up the delivery of goods. However, frequent changes to custom duties have acted as a major disincentive for legitimate businesses, and will continue to fuel contraband trade in 2019-23.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.3 6.6 62 42 8 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score and ranking for taxation improves solidly in the forecast period. In the historical period official tax policy stance was volatile and prone to abrupt changes in legislation to meet short-term financing needs. This fuelled uncertainty and was a major impediment to investment. However, under the auspices of the IMF agreement the current government is likely to table a tax reform bill in the second half of 2019. Although we expect a combination of congressional and public resistance to water down some of the measures, on balance we believe that it will raise tax revenue, help to lift compliance and streamline payment procedures. Over time, the Servicio de Rentas Internas (Ecuador's tax authority) will begin to establish a better reputation in terms of efficiency.
Tax reform will meet resistance but will help to raise revenue
The government has stated that it hopes a new tax reform will lift revenue by 1.5-2 percentage points of GDP by 2021. However we expect Mr Moreno will make concessions to opposition parties to pass revenue-raising legislation, settling for a diluted bill. Measures are likely to broaden the tax base, simplify the system through eliminating some tax breaks and removing some distortionary taxes on transactions and capital flows (including a 5% tax on overseas financial transfers). The government has indicated that it will unveil details of the bill before the end of August and that it will be submitted to the National Assembly by the end of October.
A progressive personal income-tax scale has been in place since 2007, with the upper limit set at 35% for those earning over US$115,000 a year. A minimum income tax threshold of US$11,270 is also in place. As in the corporate sector, ad hoc changes have become commonplace, including tax increases on luxury items and limits to tax deductions. For example, in May 2016 in response to a magnitude 7.8 earthquake, the government enacted a Solidarity Law with the purpose of financing rebuilding costs. This involved a one-time 3% surtax over the income tax basis for non-employed individuals and a one-time 0.9% net wealth tax on individuals with a net worth in excess of US$1m. A temporary contribution of 3.33% of monthly salary to be paid by employed individuals earning more than US$1,000 per month, for up to eight months, was also levied. Although the likelihood of these kinds of changes is reduced under Mr Moreno, it is not out of the question that the government might resort to putting in place new taxes, given the pressing need for fiscal consolidation.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.6 4.8 73 70 9 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score for financing in 2019-23 improves noticeably, but with similarly ranked countries also making improvements, Ecuador's global rankings remain relatively weak in this area. Indeed, financing will remain one of the worst areas of Ecuador's business environment. The country's financial sector remains underdeveloped in relation to the size of the economy; financial services are relatively rudimentary, with a small secondary market and two stock exchanges (Quito, the capital, and Guayaquil) vying with each other for a limited pool of bond and equity issuances. In this context, financing is (and will remain) dominated by bank loans, with only large companies able to secure the lowest rates of around 7%. Smaller companies face rates of upwards of 12%, with loan maturities often capped at three years. Long-term bank finance and capital market finance remain under-developed and difficult to secure.
State intervention in the banking sector has been a feature of the business environment in recent years, but is unlikely to pose as significant a risk during 2019-23. After years of outright hostility under the Correa government, the approach is more conciliatory under Mr Moreno. This has engendered greater confidence both amongst commercial banks and their customers, with deposit and credit growth both accelerating, albeit from a low base. Profit ratios are relatively low, although steadily rising, and the risk-weighted capital adequacy ratio has increased close to the Latin American average. Despite the improving outlook, structural weaknesses continue to affect Ecuador's financing score. Even with a legacy of several banking crises, most recently in 1999, the vast majority of deposits are still held in instant-access accounts, which means that the banks are at risk of a run on deposits.
Intervention in the banking sector will remain a risk, albeit at a lower level
Confidence in the banking system is tied to the management of reserve requirements at the Banco Central del Ecuador (the central bank), which is key to sustaining dollarisation but has been the target of regulatory changes. With the government's dollar liquidity needs likely to remain high in the forecast period, there is a risk of more aggressive control on bank deposits, with potentially damaging effects on lending and market confidence. The government will continue to seek broad stability in the banking sector, reducing the risk of directed lending policies in 2019-23. However, regulatory changes made since 2014 mean that the possibility exists, as the Junta Monetaria (the monetary board) technically retains important discretionary powers. This was most recently demonstrated by a ruling by the board in April 2017 that requests for commercial and personal credit must be guaranteed by assets worth 150% of the value of the loan, which will act as a disincentive to potential borrowers. Although not part of our central forecast given the current government's more market-friendly stance, further changes to the regulatory environment cannot be discounted during 2019-23.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.8 5.0 76 75 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Despite marginal improvements in the underlying score in 2019-23, the labour market will remain one of the weakest areas of Ecuador's business environment. An increase in spending on education and training programmes during the oil boom years failed to raise skills levels or productivity, with lower oil prices necessitating subsequent cutbacks. Although moves to increase flexibility in labour market regulation under the current government are positive, the need for fiscal adjustment will cap public investment in education, meaning that long-running and structural problems such as skills shortages are unlikely to be tackled. Access to social security has improved for some sectors of the population, but the labour market remains highly informal, which will be difficult to tackle. In comparative terms, labour costs will edge down slightly in 2019-23 but remain high, particularly in relation to productivity.
The government is likely to table a labour market reform bill in the coming weeks. The Ministry of Labour has indicated that it will include three central measures: increasing probation periods for new employees; allowing employees to work their contracted hours over a reduced or increased number of days, including weekends; and eliminating a tax that employers have to pay for temporary contracts (35% of salary levels). Increasing probation periods will give firms greater flexibility, as severance costs once employees are taken on in a permanent position are high. Allowing employees to work flexible hours is designed to encourage more women to join the labour market, while the elimination of the 35% tax on temporary contracts will make it cheaper for firms to hire. Prospects for a successful passage through Congress are relatively positive, although it will take time for the impact to be fully felt. The measures in isolation are unlikely to stimulate large-scale job creation in the formal sector, however, given that the overall investment climate remains weak.
The strength of the US dollar will compound competitiveness problems with other countries in the region in the short term (Ecuador's minimum wage is among the highest in Latin America in dollar terms, although productivity in Ecuador lags behind that of most neighbours). Although we expect some depreciation of the US dollar from 2020, this will be mild and insufficient to boost competitiveness significantly.
Mr Moreno will continue to build on initiatives begun under the Correa administration to improve public education. Initially, the president's focus appeared to be on provision at the tertiary level, with (overly ambitious) pledges to construct 40 new universities. More recently, however, the focus seems to have shifted towards early childcare: as part of the borrowing agreement with the IMF, the government has committed to drawing up an action plan by the end of September 2019 that focuses on ways of improving the efficiency and quality of primary education. The government's commitment is positive, but fiscal constraints will hamper progress. Aside from uncertainty over the source of funding for such investment, long-standing educational challenges will not be addressed. Although net secondary school enrolment rose from 56% in 2007 to 86% in 2017, student results continue to trail those of other countries in the region. Improving results and boosting skills levels will require a sustained and long-term commitment from the government; even assuming improved quality of education policies and increased spending, student results would be unlikely to improve until towards the end of (or beyond) our forecast period.
The official rate of open unemployment averaged 4.1% in 2018. This rate is fairly low, but fails to reflect underemployment (those working on an occasional or part-time basis but looking for full-time employment), which is above 50% of the workforce. The formal sector workforce in stable employment with social security benefits makes up the other 50%.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.5 5.3 62 59 8 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Infrastructure was one of Ecuador's stronger areas in the business environment rankings in the historical period, owing to major capital spending by the Correa administration. We expect some further improvements in 2019-23, which will lift both the score and rankings. A large public-investment programme previously put in place by Mr Correa means that multiple projects are likely to reach completion during the forecast period, given that financing has already been agreed and in many cases, the projects are under way (some, however, have been cancelled owing to project mismanagement, while others have been subject to large cost overruns). These changes mean that after decades of underinvestment-alongside frequent electricity shortages-the quality of transport, energy and road infrastructure is now comparable to the Latin American median, and telecoms development (measured in mobile and internet penetration) is above the regional average. However, given the need for fiscal consolidation, government efforts to modernise infrastructure will be reined in. The authorities will seek to attract private investment into infrastructure projects, but Ecuador lacks the solid track record of fostering successful public-private partnerships that have helped to upgrade infrastructure in other countries in the region.
Increased investment in hydroelectric generation is expected
A major focus of the government's infrastructure programme has been the development of new hydroelectric power plants to avoid importing costly energy for gas-fired and thermoelectric plants. In the medium term, there is potential not only to close the supply-demand gap but also, potentially, to allow the country to export energy. On the downside, there are some concerns that planned projects will fail to reach expected generation levels, or that government neglect of investment in transmission and distribution facilities will lead to supply bottlenecks.
Recent investment has led to road infrastructure improvements and the creation of new road networks. This is helping to boost domestic and intraregional trade but has also created challenges, including congestion (advances in traffic management have been more limited). Moreover, seasonal heavy rains that are costly and difficult to fully mitigate continue to cause seasonal disruption in some areas. The difficult topography adds an additional obstacle and there are concerns about misuse of funds. There has been much slower progress on developing mass-transport systems to relieve urban congestion, including a much-delayed underground rail system in the capital (Quito Metro) that is now projected to start operations in March-April 2020, and a tram project in Cuenca (Ecuador's third-largest city), which has been delayed but with no projected start-date.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.0 4.7 74 67 10 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Ecuador's score and ranking for technological readiness in 2019-23 are set to improve. However, its global ranking of 67th is still relatively low, reflecting weakness in areas such as advanced mobile technology (including low levels of smartphone penetration) and a lack of spending on research and innovation, which undermines the overall score. However, Ecuador scores relatively well in areas such as preparedness for e-commerce and cyber-security.
The government has set targets to grow the telecoms and information technology sectors. Internet access through mobile phones will drive wider mobile-phone usage during the outlook period, as handsets and data tariffs become more affordable and mobile phones are increasingly used in place of personal computers (PCs). We expect data services to be the fastest-growing segment of the mobile market. However, coverage remains inadequate and costs are high, limiting access. Efforts to loosen the grip of the two foreign-owned firms on the mobile market may boost competition, but both the investment climate and a complicated regulatory environment for foreign companies will remain impediments. Internet penetration, in particular broadband, has been limited but is expected to grow rapidly over the forecast period as technology becomes more widely available and connectivity improves. In line with this, the number of overall internet subscriptions will continue to grow strongly.
As at December 2017, the country had 70,713 km of fibre-optic transmission infrastructure installed, reaching over half a million homes, with a projected reach of 1.4m homes by 2020. As part of a state initiative to narrow the digital divide, the government has also embarked on an ambitious programme to provide 9,000 urban and rural schools with broadband internet, and to increase the penetration rate among the younger population. Over 7,000 public education institutions are connected to broadband, serving over 2.6m students. Ecuador also had 854 community telecentres (infocentros) in 736 local parishes as at May 2018, serving 7m people. However, 377 parishes continue to lack internet access, according to the Asociación de Empresas de Telecomunicaciones, an Ecuadorian telecoms industry association.
We expect internet access through mobile phones to increase rapidly as it becomes more affordable and poor fixed-line infrastructure encourages greater use of mobile data. PC ownership, which is low by global standards, will continue to grow steadily, by an annual average of 6.4%, well above the GDP growth rate. This will support increased broadband usage and penetration.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Under the auspices of an IMF External Fund Facility agreement, the Lenín Moreno administration will seek to implement structural reforms and undertake a sharp fiscal adjustment to tackle weaknesses underlying the Ecuadorean economy and restore sustainability to public finances. Technical and financial backing totalling US$10.3bn from the IMF and other multilateral institutions will be leveraged to address four priority areas: improving competitiveness, tackling fiscal imbalances, protecting the poor and tackling corruption. The fiscal consolidation process is likely to face public and political pushback, as the government begins to cut spending and raise revenues. Absent widespread support from opposition parties, it is likely that Mr Moreno will bear the political cost of fiscal consolidation.
The country's weak fiscal position precipitated the need for financial assistance and will be the primary economic policy challenge as the government aims to curb the rising public debt (estimated at US$46.2bn-around 42.6% of GDP-at end-2018) and improve access to finance without smothering already-weak economic growth. Structural reforms under the guidance of the IMF will help the government to move towards this goal, while also building upon market-friendly policies approved in August 2018 that include a combination of tax breaks, regulatory improvements and privatisations that aim to boost private investment.
The Moreno administration will have modest success in diversifying the economy away from a dependence on oil exports; a process that will remain a key policy objective. Public investment continues to account for nearly 10% of GDP and The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Mr Moreno's administration to bolster private-sector activity through IMF-backed business-friendly policies and complementary reforms, including tax incentives, privatisations, a public-private partnership (PPP) framework and promotion of the mining, telecommunications, electricity and transport-ation sectors.
The unpopularity of austerity measures under the IMF-backed economic programme will augment the risk that Mr Moreno's administration is unable to fully meet quantitative targets agreed with the IMF, posing risks to our forecast. However, the popularity of dollarisation, which bolsters living standards by fostering price stability, means that abandoning it would be politically difficult. Adherence to the IMF programme will reduce the risk of de-dollarisation.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy
Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Government revenue 35.9 35.1 36.1 34.1 33.4 33.8
Government expenditure 37.1 35.5 33.7 32.2 32.1 32.1
Budget balance -1.2 -0.4 2.4 1.9 1.4 1.7
As part of its arrangement with the IMF, the government will pursue a front-loaded five-percentage-point of GDP increase in the non-oil primary balance by 2021, an overall non-financial public-sector (NFPS) surplus of 2.9% of GDP by 2021 (from a deficit of 1.2% in 2018), and a public debt/GDP ratio of 40% by 2022. The government plans to reach these targets primarily through expenditure cuts, including reducing fuel subsidies, shrinking the public wage bill and dialling down capital spending. In addition, the government is developing a tax law that targets an increase in tax revenue of between 1.5% and 2% of GDP by 2021. Although we do not envisage the passage of a law that achieves these targets, we expect the government to pass legislation that does boost revenue to a lesser degree.
Our forecast assumes that the government will not fully achieve the quantitative targets set in its economic programme, as we assume that the bold fiscal adjustment plan is subject to implementation risks, given Mr Moreno's weakened political capital and the potential for social unrest. Moreover, in addition to the politically unpalatable nature of the front-loaded adjustment, the measures come amid softer international oil prices and a slowdown of the global economy. These external factors will compound the already difficult test that the government faces in implementing unpopular fiscal measures.
As the government attempts to meet its target of swinging its NFPS fiscal balance from a deficit of 1.2% of GDP in 2018 to a surplus of 2.9% by 2021, we expect expenditure cuts to take effect this year. We forecast that the deficit will narrow to 0.4% of GDP in 2019 before shifting into a surplus of 2.4% in 2020. This will support material improvements in the public debt/GDP ratio, and we expect public sector debt as a percentage of GDP to fall from 46.8% of GDP in 2019 to 41.4% by 2023. Moreover, we do not anticipate that the government will return to tap international capital markets during the duration of the IMF agreement. The sovereign most recently tapped global bond markets in January, prior to the multilateral financing deal, when it issued US$1bn in ten-year bonds at par, at a notably high yield of 10.75%, bringing the total amount of global bond issuance since the country returned to the global capital markets in 2014 to a hefty US$15.8bn. Despite still-high yields and relatively short maturities of recent issuance, we do not expect the government to undertake formal restructuring of its international bonds in the forecast period, owing to the IMF programme.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates

Deposit rate (av) 5.1 5.3 5.0 5.0 5.6 6.0
Ecuador has had a dollarised economy since 2000 and monetary conditions hinge on the foreign-exchange balance and the confidence of domestic lenders, both of which have been historically hindered by erratic policymaking. Foreign reserves cover only around 25% of total demand deposits, but we expect the Banco Central del Ecuador (BCE, the central bank) to make a concerted effort to build up reserves as part of the three-year IMF agreement. Further reforms will be implemented with guidance from the Fund to strengthen the autonomy of the central bank. Although it does not feature as part of our baseline forecast, the threat of de­dollarisation and a weak economy sustain the risk of capital flight, which could push interest rates above our current forecasts.

Ecuador's short-term economic growth prospects are primarily encumbered by the government's front-loaded fiscal adjustment that entails cuts to public spending and investment. We estimate that fiscal tightening will depress private investment and consumption growth, dampening GDP growth, which will slow to 0.2% in 2019, down from 1.4% in 2018. Exports are expected to decline marginally this year amid slowing global trade. Import growth will be minimal as domestic demand wanes. Ongoing spending cuts will continue to weaken consumption growth in 2020, resulting in subdued real GDP growth of 1.1%.
We expect more sustained growth in the second half of the forecast period, with the economy growing by an annual average of 2% in 2021-23. The fruition of structural reforms and recovery of oil exports on the back of higher oil prices will bolster growth, albeit below the annual average of 4.5% seen in the boom years of high oil prices and expansionary fiscal policy in 2011-15. Supply-side reforms will support higher hydrocarbons output, which will continue to dominate the economy. Pro-business tax reforms will yield modest results in terms of diversification efforts, but policies that support export-oriented sectors will primarily facilitate increased investment in mining (notably gold and copper). Manufacturing growth will continue to be positive, aided by a steady inflow in foreign direct investment (FDI), following a period of contraction in 2016-17. Private investment will rise only gradually, limiting the growth of non-oil industries.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Notwithstanding efforts to diversify the economy, the oil sector will remain a critical driver of growth in 2019. We expect Ecuador's oil production to average 541,000 barrels/day (b/d) in 2019-23, remaining below the government's ambitious goal of boosting production to 700,000 b/d by 2021 (the end of the current administration's term). Owing to domestic fiscal needs, the government will endeavour to push production higher, which will occur despite OPEC setting an output ceiling of 508,000 b/d in the first six months of 2019, compared with a maximum quota of 524,000 b/d in 2018. The minister of mining and non-renewable natural resources, Carlos Pérez, has acknowledged that, although the government will continue to target growth in the oil sector, Ecuador continues to have difficulty attracting exploration (partially owing to indigenous anti-oil activism).
Growth in the oil sector will primarily emanate from increased production at the 1.6bn-barrel, heavy crude Ishpingo Tambococha Tiputini oil field. However, problems in receiving environmental permits have impeded a faster expansion of production. This has also affected investment in some privately operated fields, which if allowed to proceed would help to lift production. The government has set January 2021 as a target date for the complete merger of the two state-owned oil companies, Petroecuador and Petroamazonas, that is likely to support future production. Petroecuador is currently the downstream company while Petroamazonas is responsible for upstream production. Assets of the former could potentially be under consideration for a concessionary model later in 2019, under which a private firm would administer operations and pass on a portion of net profits to the state.
The Moreno administration's more accommodative stance regarding participation by foreign private energy companies than that of its predecessor will be particularly evident in the mining sector. The sector attracted nearly US$800m in FDI in 2018 and output is poised to expand rapidly once the gold mine Fruta del Norte (projected investment stands at US$467m for the 2019-22 period, although execution of investment plans last year fell short of target), operated by a Canadian firm, Lundin Gold, and the copper mine Mirador, under development by ECSA (owned by the Chinese state company, Tongling Metals), begin production in the second half of this year. In addition, a series of further projects are underway with major mining companies competing for stakes, in contrast with the oil industry, where top-level interest is limited.
Government policy is being geared towards improving conditions for the mining sector. In the first quarter of 2019 the government overturned a 70% "windfall tax" on mining profits and plans on introducing further incentives this year. However, friction between local communities and mining firms is likely to slow investment. Many mineral deposits are located in environmentally sensitive areas, close to communities that have lodged complaints with local courts alleging that mining firms have failed to undergo consultation processes. A lack of cohesion among anti-mining activists and the differences in opinion within Ecuador means imminent cancellation of major mining projects currently under construction and under advanced exploration is unlikely. Our view is that the mining sector will continue to face difficulties that will prevent a more dramatic rise in extractive production.

Consumer prices rose by 0.17% month on month in April, bringing the annual rate of inflation to a muted 0.2%. We expect that weak demand-side pressures, in conjunction with softer oil prices, will keep inflation subdued in 2019, reaching 0.5% by year-end. We forecast that inflation will pick up later in the forecast period, to average 2.5% in 2021-23, as imports become more expensive owing to fresh dollar weakness and an increase in commodity prices, raising domestic supply costs and so generating price pressures. Although dollarisation helps to stabilise inflation, the economy will remain vulnerable to spikes in food and energy prices.

Dollarisation maintains high levels of public support and adjustments to fiscal policy will help to rein in imbalances. In the past, expansionary fiscal policies raised concerns that dollarisation might be abandoned, but this risk was mitigated by high oil prices and access to global financing. The government's adherence to more prudential fiscal policies will diminish the risk of de-dollarisation. The real effective exchange rate will remain far stronger than its long-term, pre-dollarisation average, despite low inflation.

Under the assumption that Ecuador will implement a front-loaded fiscal adjustment and pass supply-side reforms that enhance the country's competitiveness, we project that the current-account balance will shift from a deficit of 1.3% of GDP in 2018 to balance in 2019. Weaker domestic demand will support a contraction of imports that will help to generate a small trade surplus of 0.7% of GDP. We expect that the current account will not return to deficit during the remainder of the forecast period, widening to an average 0.8% of GDP in 2020-23. The services deficit is forecast to remain stable and just below 1% of GDP per year in 2019-23. Large debt-service payments will keep the primary income deficit large in 2019-23 (at roughly 2.5% of GDP per year), while firm inflows of workers' remittances will keep the secondary income surplus large (at 2.3% of GDP per year). Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows will register a slight increase in 2019-23, aided by more stable, pro-business economic policy, but will nonetheless remain below 1.5% of GDP annually, focused mainly on oil and mining. Foreign-exchange reserves are volatile, reflecting spikes related to periodic bond issuance and dollar outflows. But under the IMF-backed programme, we expect reserves to rise to around US$12bn by 2023, providing more than three months of import cover. Our external-sector forecasts account for the disbursement of large inflows of IMF and multilateral financing (averaging US$3.4bn in 2019-21 annually).

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Ecuador
Stocks and flows
Ecuador has historically attracted relatively little foreign direct investment (FDI). Annual inflows of FDI averaged US$700m in 1994-2008, driven mainly by the oil sector (which accounted for 80% of total FDI). After peaking at just over US$1bn in 2008 (1.8% of GDP), FDI inflows fell to only US$165m in 2010. They recovered somewhat to US$767m (0.8% of GDP) in 2016, but declined to around US$618m in 2017. However, FDI inflows jumped in 2018 and reached US$1.4bn, up by 127% from 2017. Although this is low by regional standards, it reflects the more conciliatory approach to the private sector of the current president, Lenín Moreno, than his predecessor, Rafael Correa (2007-17), whose policies led to the deterioration of investor confidence. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that FDI will rise moderately in the short term as the government promotes foreign investment in mining (which received 53% of inflows in 2018), as well as in the retail sector, and will average slightly above 1% of GDP in 2019-23. We estimate the total stock of inward FDI at US$18.7bn at the end of 2018. This is one of the smallest stocks among the major Latin American economies, equalling 17.2% of GDP. Ecuador's stock is also small on a per-head basis, estimated at US$1,098 in 2018.
Origin and distribution
The US, traditionally the main source of FDI inflows into Ecuador, went through a period of disinvestment in the country between 2008 and 2010, largely owing to uncertainty surrounding oil contract renegotiations and the global financial crisis. Investment from the US has since remained moderate, reaching US$61m in 2018, up from US$35m in 2017, but below inflows in in 2016 (US$87m) and 2015 (US$186m). FDI from China tapered off in 2018 and reached US$64m (accounting for 5% of inflows), but has grown since 2011 after Ecuador established closer trade and diplomatic ties. Low oil prices and erratic policymaking are factors that have hindered FDI, but we expect the latter to ebb in its influence on foreign investment. Investment flows in oil, mining and further infrastructure projects (such as a long-discussed US$12bn oil refinery in Manabí province) are likely to pick up as Mr Moreno implements pro-market policies. FDI in these sectors predominates other sectors and the origins of FDI reflect this. Investment from European countries, led by the Netherlands and Spain, rose precipitously in 2018, amounting to around US$186m (12% of inflows in 2018) and US$174m (13%) respectively, compared with much lower amounts in 2017. Ecuador's regional neighbours (especially Chile, Colombia and Peru) contribution to FDI inflows is moderate. Manufacturing attracted around 7% of GDP in 2018 and agri- and aqua-culture accounted for around 4%, considerably behind extractive industries (53% of GDP) and commerce (13%).
Determinants
The introduction of production-sharing contracts in the oil sector in 1993 was the main stimulus to the sharp rise in inward FDI during the mid-1990s. Under the administration of Mr Correa, government intervention in the oil sector and other strategic sectors hampered private investment levels from 2008 onwards. Given the complicated economic environment and the necessity of government austerity, the Correa government began overtures to foreign investors in 2014, including a 2014 amendment to the 2009 Mining Law, which allows for private investment under a service-contract framework, so as to reduce the tax and royalty burden. The government also introduced a framework for public-private partnerships in 2015 for infrastructure development and other industries. However, this has so far failed to prompt stronger interest from foreign investors, who remain concerned by the uncertain regulatory environment. Furthermore, weaker global prices deter interest. Elsewhere, Ecuador's weak institutions, small domestic market and low income levels will continue to deter FDI in most non-extractive sectors. The administration of Mr Moreno, which includes ministers with private-sector experience, has taken a more active role than its predecessor in attracting private foreign investment, particularly in the oil and mining sectors, including by re-introducing production-sharing contracts and eliminating the 70% "windfall tax" over profits in mining.
Impact
The impact of inward FDI on productivity and export competitiveness has been limited, because most investment has been directed towards capital-intensive natural resource sectors, which have weak links to the rest of the economy. However, FDI has helped to boost export earnings in the energy sector. Since 2008, when Mr Correa introduced a constitution that enshrines a greater role for the state in the economy, public investment has risen and FDI has fallen. However, these trends may be reversing slightly: FDI accounted for 5.2% of gross fixed investment in 2018-in excess of the 1% recorded in 2010, although far below a peak of over 14% in 2003.
Potential
FDI opportunities exist in Ecuador's petroleum, mining, manufacturing and services sectors. Unlike under Mr Correa, when foreign oil companies typically faced harsh contract terms, policy uncertainty, infrastructure deficiencies and low levels of labour productivity, Mr Moreno's mandate to boost an ailing economy and enhance the country's competitiveness under the auspices of an IMF deal is likely to raise FDI to slightly closer to potential during the forecast period. Carlos Pérez, the hydrocarbons minister (a private-sector executive with decades of in-country experience) has led a pragmatic approach to attracting private foreign capital and boosting production. Ingrained opposition from powerful domestic interest groups will continue to complicate efforts to open-up investment opportunities in the oil sector. The authorities will focus on attracting investment to develop the mining sector and infrastructure, and mining is expected to pick up moderately, although many foreign operators will remain wary about the fiscal framework, even after reforms to existing legislation. This, coupled with a slowdown in the global economy, will dampen interest in Ecuador.

Population growth is slowing
In 2018 the population reached an estimated 17m, and it is expected to rise by a further 1.2m people by 2023. With a falling birth rate and continued, albeit lower, emigration, population growth is slowing. However, at an annual average rate of 1.3% per year in 2019-23, growth will be high compared with developed-country standards and on a par with neighbours in the Andean region. The rate of urbanisation is relatively high: around 64% of the population lives in urban centres, compared with 55% in 1990, and this percentage is expected to rise to 65% by the end of the forecast period. Almost half of city dwellers reside either in the capital, Quito, or in the largest city and main business centre, Guayaquil. Rapid urbanisation over the past 50 years has increased the level of informality, as the creation of full-time jobs has risen at a much slower pace. The rate of unemployment was 4.6% at end-March 2019, which is low by historical standards (and has remained stable year on year), although underemployment remains high, affecting more than half of the workforce. The labour force is expected to continue to expand more rapidly than the overall population during the forecast period, with around 700,000 new labour market entrants in the 2019-23 forecast period. Despite attempts to liberalise the labour market by the administration of the president, Lenín Moreno, reform will take time. As a result, the formal economy will struggle to absorb the new entrants, particularly as diversification away from the energy-dominant labour market will also be slow (and will primarily focus on mining and agriculture). Consequently, informal employment, estimated at 46% of the labour force as at March 2019, is unlikely to subside significantly.
Although inflows of illegal migrants from Colombia have fallen in recent years, inflows from Venezuela may put renewed pressure on the domestic labour market. By end-2018 Ecuador had received over 200,000 migrants from Venezuela. Inflows of returning Ecuadorean migrants from Spain, where the labour market is still recovering, will also maintain pressure on the local labour market and public services. Meanwhile, outward migrant flows will stabilise, despite a more robust US labour market, as The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that Ecuador will maintain modest growth rates in the later half of the forecast period (2021-23).
In 2019-23 Ecuador's crude birth rate is expected to fall to an annual average of 19.4 per 1,000 population (down from 20.9 in 2014-18). The crude death rate will remain steady at an annual average of 5.1 per 1,000 population in 2019-23. The old-age dependency ratio, which will rise slightly to reach 0.13 by 2023, will remain low by developed-country standards. However, given constraints on public spending, an ageing population will place growing pressure on an already heavily indebted social security system. Since 2015, the Instituto Ecuatoriano de Seguridad Social (the social security institute) has disinvested an average of US$1.7bn from its retirement fund to pay a portion of pension funds, as personal contributions do not suffice. Although the government plans to reduce its divestments, we expect the state-run social security system to encounter difficulties ending its debt woes.
Education and healthcare standards remain low
Amid fiscal consolidation measures, the Moreno government will continue to commit to spending on education and healthcare, but standards will remain low, following decades of underinvestment. Regular labour conflicts with public healthcare and education workers, often resulting in industrial action, have further damaged the quality of services. There have been improvements in poverty levels and social indicators, in part owing to the previous government's targeted investment of strong oil revenue, but some of these gains have receded because of the 2015-16 recession, which resulted in a spike in underemployment. However, Ecuador remains slightly ahead of its Andean neighbours in average life expectancy. The 2008 constitution promised free universal healthcare and education but, despite increased spending, the government will struggle to achieve these goals during the forecast period. As a result, improvements in the quality of both will be only gradual.

Ecuador is one of the smallest markets included in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings, accounting for roughly 0.1% of global GDP, and a similar share of global exports. However, its oil and mineral reserves will continue to attract interest from foreign investors, although less favourable contract terms and doubts over the business environment, combined with tepid global commodity prices, have put off many private investors, with foreign state-owned companies securing a stronger position.
Market will expand modestly in forecast period
Boosted by a rising population but hindered by only moderate economic growth, Ecuador's market size will expand modestly in 2019-23. Although it has risen in recent years, GDP per head, which is estimated at US$6,370 in 2018 and forecast to reach US$6,951 in 2023, is relatively low, restricting business opportunities. Moreover, Ecuador's per-head income figures will continue to disguise wide inequalities. Despite a rise in consumption in 2018-19, we expect reductions in income inequality will be marginal at best in 2019-23 as unemployment and, in particular, underemployment increase and the government reduces the rate of minimum-wage increases. As the president, Lenín Moreno, pursues fiscal consolidation, we expect that capital expenditure will be cut more than social spending.
The government of Rafael Correa (2007-17) invested the proceeds of the oil price boom in upgrading Ecuador's underdeveloped infrastructure. Although substantial improvements were made, particularly to the road system, significant gaps remain. The Moreno administration is more accommodative to private-sector investors and efforts to improve the legal framework will provide a moderate boost for investment (domestic and foreign), notably in the export-oriented energy and mining sectors, and related services. However, despite a strong natural resource endowment, growth in exports will remain below potential, and Ecuador's share of world exports will stagnate at 0.1%.
As a result of dollarisation and successive years of guaranteeing a "living wage" (essentially a minimum wage), Ecuador is no longer a cheap-labour investment location. In US dollar terms, the country's minimum wage is one of the highest in Latin America. Also reducing the country's competitiveness are low skills levels. However, dollarisation facilitates greater overall macroeconomic stability for businesses to assess investment opportunities, particularly by reducing inflation and exchange-rate risks. Investment in most areas outside the oil sector will be slow to arrive, as Mr Moreno's attempts to improve the business environment will not be immediate and progress on increasing the transparency and efficiency of the judicial system is unhurried.

Business opportunities limited by low level of development
With family units shrinking, the number of households in Ecuador has grown faster than the population over the past decade, although an average of around five people per household is still large by international standards. This long-term trend will offer business opportunities, although it is limited by Ecuador's low level of development. A significant proportion of average income-around 23%-is still spent on food, which is high by both regional and global standards. In addition, price controls on some foodstuffs protect inefficient local producers at the expense of consumers. Pro-market policies are expected under Mr Moreno, but we expect the new government to extend restrictions introduced by Mr Correa in 2015 to protect the balance-of-payments position against weak oil prices. Real incomes will gradually rise, freeing up greater expenditure on transport and communications, leisure and education, and healthcare. Nonetheless, Ecuador's market will remain comparatively small.
