From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Ample scope for catch-up but challenges persist
Ecuador's wealth of natural resources, a young and expanding middle class, and a push to improve educational standards offer scope to catch up with more developed countries over the next four decades. However, a series of challenges need addressing over the short and medium term to build on these positive conditions. Although the investment rate has improved considerably, it remains overly reliant on public-sector spending, which in turn is vulnerable to changes in commodity prices. Private investment is scant and overall savings are low, two factors that are only likely to improve moderately in coming years, holding down productivity growth. Despite a more stable policy framework, Ecuador's institutions are likely to remain weak, and progress in tackling a large informal sector will be limited. Nevertheless, higher spending on health and education should help to improve labour productivity growth in 2031-50. In this context-and barring a sharp and prolonged deterioration in the country's terms of trade or a return to severe political instability-Ecuador should post modest GDP growth in 2019-30 (averaging 1.6%), with levels remaining roughly the same in 2031-50 (1.9%) as the working-age population expands more slowly.
Initial conditions: Rapid urbanisation in the past 30 years and faster integration into the world economy have produced few long-term benefits for the population. Political instability, weak institutions and high levels of poverty and inequality-combined with an economy overly dependent on oil-have yielded a rent-seeking and unproductive economy, plagued by low education levels and productivity, and high labour-informality. The government of Rafael Correa (2007-17) made efforts to address low social indicators and improve infrastructure, but failed to boost private investment and savings. In addition, the previous government harmed the legal framework for investment by constantly changing regulations and putting up hurdles to capital. Although dollarisation has brought macroeconomic stability since 2000, it has also made the country less competitive and accentuated the risks of inadequate fiscal management.
Demographic trends: Population growth is set to fall gradually over the long term, from an average of 1.2% in 2019-30, to 0.8% in 2031-50. The main causal factor will be lower fertility rates, in addition to some net migration. On the upside, The Economist Intelligence Unit projects that the growth of the working-age population will continue to outstrip overall population growth until 2040, providing a major demographic boom and keeping the dependency ratio low. The main challenge facing the country will be to create enough formal jobs for entrants to the labour market, so as to reduce informality. There has been some progress in expanding education across all levels to improve labour quality, but the lack of dynamism in the private sector means that there is a substantial risk of labour informality remaining high in the long term. An additional challenge is to tackle the pension needs of an ageing population, which could increase strains on the country's vulnerable social security system.
External conditions: As a small, open economy, Ecuador has benefited from rising global trade, but also remains vulnerable to changes in commodity prices. This, in turn, causes significant external and fiscal volatility. The potential for stronger integration with industrialised nations or blocs like the US and EU (traditionally Ecuador's main trade partners) will remain constrained by long geographical distances and the lack of a consistent trade policy. Rising trade integration with neighbouring countries could boost growth, but progress will suffer from sporadic trade spats, lack of supply-chain strategies and infra-structure constraints. Export diversification towards the Middle East, Russia and Asia has seen some success, but Ecuador's small and distant market will drag its competitiveness profile, particularly in relation to other emerging markets in Asia. With the economy likely to remain heavily dependent on hydrocarbons and some mineral and agricultural products, the external sector and GDP growth will be very dependent on the direction of terms of trade.
Future governments will struggle with a weak legal framework
Institutions and policy trends: Ecuador's institutions have long suffered from periods of instability, and despite a growing sense of macroeconomic and political stability in the past couple of years, they remain fundamentally weak. Inconsistent policymaking remains a major problem, both in conceiving and implementing new legislation. Successive administrations have changed policy directions. The government of Lenín Moreno does not enjoy the wide support of workers in all state institutions or a clear majority of the population, both of which allowed Mr Correa to pursue his policy agenda. Instead of strengthening the rule of law and cementing the division of power among the country's institutions, Mr Correa's policies resulted in the concentration of power in the hands of the executive, attacks on press freedom and poor regulatory quality. Mr Moreno faces a fragmented political landscape and public discontent amid anxiety over the future of economic growth and security, which will undermine his efforts to roll back some of his predecessor's excesses and hinder fiscal consolidation. Future governments (regardless of their ideological inclination) will continue to struggle with a weak legal framework, corruption and distorted policy priorities (such as oil subsidies) that either favour special interest groups or act as a major drag on the public finances.
Dollarisation will be protected by its persistent popularity
Dollarisation: A key policy decision will be whether to maintain dollarisation or opt for an independent currency. At present, we expect the current monetary framework to remain in place, as the costs of abandonment, in particular the fear of stoking social unrest, are very high. However, an abandonment of the system cannot be ruled out, especially if the government is faced with a prolonged fiscal and balance-of-payments crisis. Moves-albeit incremental-towards reducing fiscal dependence on oil, narrowing the structural deficit at the central government level and reducing external debt using oil-related windfalls would help to reduce the likelihood of such a crisis occurring. In the short term, commitment to an IMF-backed economic programme will strengthen the foundations of dollarisation. The government will endeavour to build up international reserves throughout the duration of its agreement with the multilateral institution (ending in 2021). This is likely to occur alongside central bank amendments that reinforce a dollarised regime and the bank's independence. The government's IMF-backed economic programme also entails a waning of public debt levels and a move to fiscal surplus. We expect that, although the government will not meet the quantitative targets established with the Fund, the long-term sustainability of dollarisation will be reinforced and the fiscal stance of the country will be more stable.
Long-term performance: Unattractive investment conditions and the lack of a competitive, skilled labour force will make Ecuador a relatively unappealing destination for foreign investment in labour-intensive or manufacturing activities. However, sustained improvements in education levels, topped with productive investment in non-oil sectors and technology transfer, could make Ecuador more competitive and boost long-term growth. For this to occur there is a need to strengthen the country's institutional framework and improve the business environment. Although Mr Moreno's administration is likely to pursue policies that strengthen private-led growth, our forecast suggests that the structural reforms his government will implement will not be deep enough for Ecuador to catch up, income-wise, with OECD countries in the long term.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Prone to earthquakes, the country will continue to suffer from natural disaster risk, but its adaptation and readiness will improve following a particularly devastating earthquake in 2016. Climate change preparedness, however, is more lacking. Ecuador's geographical location and diversity renders it particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Owing to the near constant temperature year-round, a rising temperature has threatened the development of glaciers, which have not been able to replenish lost density during colder seasons. Indeed, Ecuador has experienced a significant reduction in the size of its glaciers in the two main mountain ranges, the Cordillera Oriental and the Cordillera Occidental, which in aggregate have seen a reduction of around one-third over the past 50 years. By 2050 this trajectory will jeopardise the water sources for the country's major urban centres, such as the capital, Quito. Rising temperatures will also negatively affect agricultural production, as warmer winters cause crops to sprout prematurely and greater volatility in precipitation rates will also disrupt production.
Sustainability concerns will take centre stage in the medium to long term. Despite failing on the ambitious goal of reaching 90% of electricity generation from renewable sources by 2017 (currently renewable energy accounts for around 60% of electricity generation, with hydroelectric power, at 58%, accounting for almost all), hydroelectric and geothermal power primarily, and wind and solar power secondarily, will play an increasingly important role in the medium to long term. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the government will incrementally roll back its high fuel subsidies to make way for these renewable sources, which will offer increasing business opportunities. However, in the short term the government will continue to promote oil and mining production-particularly in the Yasuní region-which may pose long-term threats to environmental stability.
Migration and urbanisation
Urbanisation in Ecuador is a relatively recent phenomenon, and comparatively low for Latin America. The majority of the population has traditionally lived in rural communities in the mountainous region (sierra). Since crossing the 50% threshold in 1990, the percentage of people living in cities has grown slowly from around 62% in 2006 to 64% in 2016. The establishment of a middle class under a social spending and consumption-driven economic policy in the 2000s (particularly by the administration of Rafael Correa, 2007-17) will sustain a large urban population, while security concerns in the north and environmental degradation in the sierra are likely to accelerate the pace of migration from rural areas to cities in the medium term. The country's infrastructure and natural resources will be strained in the process, necessitating greater investment. There will be opportunities for public-private partnerships for infrastructure investment, but internal migration will also invite limited bouts of social unrest.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IMF, IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import prices
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IMF, IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IMF, IFS; The Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Costa Rica to prices in the US
Population and growth: CELADE
General government debt: includes debt of the non-financial and financial public sectors
Lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on non-preferential loans. The rate is weighted by loan amounts
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IMF, IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI), 2006=100
Real exchange rate: The Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CELADE: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Norway--highlights: Political outlook
The September 2017 general election produced a centre-right majority in parliament. The ruling coalition maintains the alliance between the centre-right Conservatives and the far-right Progress Party (FrP), but two centrist parties, the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF), joined in January 2018 and January 2019 respectively. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this government to last a full term to 2021, and but does not exclude tensions between the centrist parties and the FrP leading to the coalition's collapse. The current administration will push for a right-wing economic agenda while tightening abortion law, owing to the negotiations that brought the KrF into government. The government will also make further efforts on climate policy as part of the deal to bring the Liberals into government.
Norway--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.01 8.28 14 13 8 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Norway's business environment outlook improves slightly over the forecast period (2019-12), as its regional and global rankings rise to 7th and 13th place respectively. A solid macroeconomic outlook and sound financial institutions remain the country's strengths, placing it among the best in the world. Although the relatively fractious nature of the ruling coalition will reduce Norway's political stability, the government's tax reform will greatly improve business operating conditions. On the economic side, Norway's tremendous oil wealth insulates the economy from global shocks, notwithstanding the sharp decline in oil prices in 2014. However, Norway is outperformed in this ranking by other Scandinavian economies (Denmark and Sweden), as it is hindered by high labour costs, excessive state control and a small market size.
Norway--highlights: Economic outlook
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Real GDP growth (%) 1.8 1.7 1.9 1.9 2.0 2.0
Consumer price inflation (av, %) 2.8 2.6 2.3 2.0 2.0 2.1
Budget balance (% of GDP) 7.2 6.5 6.2 7.0 7.3 7.2
Current-account balance (% of GDP) 8.1 8.1 7.7 9.1 9.7 10.2
3-month Treasury rate (av; %) 1.1 1.4 1.5 1.6 1.7 1.7
Exchange rate Nkr:US$ (av) 8.1 8.6 8.5 8.3 8.1 8.1
In line with a weaker growth outlook in western Europe, Norway's real GDP growth is expected to decelerate to an average of 1.9% over the forecast period. The economy has recently recovered from the steep decline in global oil prices in 2014, led by painful adjustments in the oil and gas sector. Now that oil prices have revived, the outlook for future growth, driven by strong investment in the oil sector, is positive. The mainland economy (excluding the oil sector) is also strengthening, owing to resilient household spending. Macroeconomic conditions will be tied to the global energy market, and the government will continue its efforts towards diversifying the economy. The fiscal and current-account surpluses will remain substantial, albeit lower than historical levels.
Norway--highlights: Demographic outlook
Population (m) 2013 2018 2023

The demographic outlook is worsening as early waves of migration, firstly from eastern Europe and then later from outside Europe, have receded. Like most developed economies, the proportion of the population aged over 67 is expected to rise (to 18.3% of the total in 2023)-albeit not to the same extent as in other Nordic countries. The share of the working-age population will be 64% in 2023-higher than that of peer economies. We judge that migration from within the European Economic Area (EEA), typically from eastern Europe, will continue, and that improving living standards will raise the birth rate slightly, keeping annual population growth steady at 0.9% over the forecast period. Non-European migration will continue to be a contentious issue, with restrictions championed by the far-right party, the FrP, but we expect no further tightening of immigration law.

Market opportunities are constrained by the small size of the population (5.3m in 2018). However, Norwegian households are among the wealthiest in the world, with GDP per head of US$63,873 in 2018 measured in purchasing power parity (PPP) terms. At market exchange rates, GDP per head in US dollar terms has fallen sharply, to US$81,911 in 2018, from about US$100,000 in 2011-14. We expect GDP per head at market exchange rates to rise to US$97,791 by 2023.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
As there is little room to raise labour market participation further, Norway's long-term outlook will depend on productivity growth and investment, both of which we expect to rise steadily over the forecast period. The government must also reckon with the economic and financial effects of dwindling oil reserves, forcing further reform of the labour market and pensions system, although the vast Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG, the sovereign wealth fund) provides a near-term buffer.

Background: The Labour Party governed almost continuously in 1935-65 and largely dominated politics until 2001, when a minority coalition comprising the Conservatives, the Christian Democrats (KrF) and the Liberals swept to power. In 2005 Labour returned to office in a centre-left coalition with the Socialist Left Party (SV) and the Centre Party (Sp)-the first majority government for two decades. This coalition lasted until 2009. The September 2013 election led to a regime change, with a minority right-of-centre coalition of the Conservatives and the Progress Party (FrP) taking office. The centre right was re-elected in 2017. The Conservatives and the FrP were joined by the Liberals in January 2018 and by the KrF in January 2019.
Political structure: A general election is held every four years and there is no right of dissolution between elections. Norway uses a modified proportional representation system where 150 out of the 169 members of the unicameral Storting (parliament) are "district mandates" elected by open-list proportional representation. The remaining 19 seats, the "levelling mandates", are distributed only between the parties that get more than 4% of the national vote and whose initial seat count (out of 150) is not proportional to their share of the vote.
Policy issues: The centre-right government will try to implement additional business-friendly policies and tax cuts. Near-term efforts will be focused on further reducing the negative spillover effects of the lower oil price on wider economic activity and on strengthening the mainland economy. Spending from Norway's oil fund is expected to rise, but it will remain comfortably within the country's fiscal guidelines. Despite a cross-party agreement on tackling climate change, tensions will persist in the Storting over the balance between industrial development and environmental protection.
Taxation: At the start of 2016 most parties agreed on a multi-year corporation tax reduction (from 27% to 23% by 2018) to improve competitiveness in the economy. The government has further reduced this to 22% for 2019. Oil companies pay an additional flat-rate tax of 50% on income derived from the extraction, processing and transport of oil, but benefit from a 78% tax refund on the costs of exploration of oil and gas. The capital-gains tax was cut from 28% to 27% in 2014. The ordinary rate of value-added tax is 25%. The top marginal income tax rate is 54.3% (including employers' social security contributions).
Foreign trade: Oil and gas output and prices greatly affect Norway's trade flows. The petroleum industry contributes about half of total goods export revenue. In 2016 the trade account registered its lowest level since 1999, but has been recovering since. The current-account surplus increased to US$35.2bn in 2018, up from US$22.4bn in the previous year. The trade and current-account balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period (2019-23).

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Norway is a parliamentary democracy. The constitution, the second-oldest in the world after the US, provides for a single legislative chamber (Storting, or parliament) of 169 members, with elections every four years. The multi-party coalition government is well established, leading to some risk of government collapse during the parliamentary term. However, parliament does not have the right to call an early election, ensuring that political instability never results in a change of parliamentary arithmetic. This has resulted in a collaborative form of government that is remarkably stable compared with other developed countries. The Storting uses a committee system for passing legislation, with an emphasis on building cross-party consensus, with only the most contentious policies leading to a parliamentary vote. Extensive powers are also devolved to the 18 counties and 422 municipalities, although a recent "municipal reform" seeks to reduce their number. A centre-right bloc, consisting of four parties-the Conservatives, the Progress Party (FrP), the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (KrF)-has been in government since the 2017 election. However, tensions between the far-right FrP and the centrist Liberals and the KrF cause some risk of a government collapse.

Political outlook: Political stability
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the current centre-right coalition government to last a full term to 2021. The four-way coalition consists of the FrP, the Conservatives, the Liberals and the KrF, and has 87 members of parliament (MPs) in the 169 seat Storting. Risks to the outlook are high, emanating especially from the tension between the right-wing and centre parties of the coalition. The FrP, on the right of the bloc, is becoming increasingly combative within the government as it fights declining popular support and seeks to exert more influence on policymaking. The KrF, a centrist party, will seek to moderate the FrP's pugilistic messaging on migration and social policy. The coalition will depend on the willingness of the centrist KrF and the Liberals to tolerate a more provocative FrP in government.
Following the September 2017 parliamentary election the right-wing "bourgeois" parties formed the first majority government not to have any support from left-wing parties since the 1980s. A centre-right majority government was a long-held ambition of Erna Solberg, the prime minister and leader of the Conservatives. The coalition maintains the alliance between the Conservatives and the FrP from the previous minority government of 2013, but it expanded to include the Liberals in January 2018 (in exchange for concessions on environmental policy) and the KrF a year later.
Negotiations to admit the KrF into the coalition culminated in a 108-page agreement announced by all four parties on January 17th 2019; since the 2017 election the KrF had only supported the government in parliament, but had not joined a coalition. The agreement plans to tighten abortion law (a concession to the KrF) and has a strong emphasis on environmental protection. It also outlines tax cuts, reduced road-toll fees and rises in child benefits. However, the KrF's more controversial call to end the right to late-term abortion in cases in which the foetus presents a type of disability was rejected by the other parties. Kjell Ingolf Ropstad, who led the KrF's coalition negotiations, took over as party leader in April 2019.
Before Mr Ropstad, the KrF was led by Knut Arild Hareide, who pursued a more hostile strategy with the other right-wing parties, twice threatening to bring down the government. Firstly, in March 2018 the KrF threatened to side with the centre-left opposition in a no-confidence vote if Sylvi Listhaug, a member of the anti-migrant FrP and at that time minister of migration and integration, did not resign over a statement on social media that said the opposition Labour Party "cares more about the rights of terrorists than national security". Then, in September 2018 Mr Hareide announced his wish to break from the right-wing bloc and move the party to the left, eventually joining a Labour Party-led centrist administration. The attempt failed when a majority of delegates rejected this and voted to join the centre-right government in early November, paving the way for the elevation of Mr Ropstad to party leader.
Since Ms Listhaug returned to government as public health minister in May 2019, risks of conflict between the coalition's right-wing and centrist parties have risen. Nevertheless, we expect the coalition to last until 2021, as the parties have an extensive policy platform to implement and Ms Solberg is committed to ensuring the coalition's survival. Risks to this forecast stem from the diverging strategies of the KrF and the FrP, which could induce either party to bring down the government.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Norway will retain its high score for government effectiveness, and the country's apparatus to design and implement policy will remain one of its strengths. The government, on both the political and administrative side, remains largely free of corruption. However, the consensus-driven nature of Norwegian politics curtails the extent of liberal, pro-business reform, and the overweening extent of bureaucracy can stifle government effectiveness.
As European integration has proceeded since 2007, the Storting has taken a more strident role in scrutinising European rules transposed into law as part of Norway's membership of the European Economic Area (EEA). As negotiations for the UK's withdrawal from the EU proceed, there is some clamour within the FrP for a more distant relationship with Europe, but despite the FrP's inclusion within the government, we view a substantial revision of Norway's relationship with the EU, either for or against future integration, as unlikely.
Although policymaking is centred in Norway's capital, Oslo, implementation is largely left to regional authorities, which decentralises the government's functions. The system works well, with sub-national government comprised of municipalities and counties that have equal rights and responsibilities, regardless of their size. Functions are divided between these regional branches. Municipal government supervises junior education, health and social care, and town planning and infrastructure. County government oversees development and planning region-wide, including roads, public transport and senior education.
Substantial reform of local government is under way
A substantial reform of local government was launched in 2014 by the Conservative-led minority government. Known as "municipal reform" (kommunesammenslaing), it plans to merge Norway's 428 municipalities into 354 and halve the country's 18 counties, with the intention of reducing the cost and improving the quality of local government services by allowing local government to exploit economies of scale. However, political opposition to the reform has been mounting since 2017, when the government received parliamentary approval to reduce the number of counties. The agrarian-focused Centre Party (Sp) has been climbing steadily in the polls, campaigning against municipal reform, eroding the coalition's popularity. Despite these difficulties, we expect steady consolidation to continue in the coming years, supported by a broad consensus in parliament.
Political outlook: Election watch
The next local elections will be held on September 9th 2019. The Storting cannot be dissolved before completing a full four-year term, meaning that the next general election will be in 2021.
Political outlook: International relations
Diplomatically, Norway has been largely untouched by the souring of US-European relations since the election of Donald Trump as US president. This is due to Norway's position within NATO as one of the alliance's most important members and Norway's high bilateral trade surplus with the US, which stood at about US$476m in 2017. In a visit to the US in January 2018 Ms Solberg announced the purchase of F-35 fighter jets and P-8 maritime patrol aircraft from US suppliers, supporting stronger trade and military relations with the country.
Relations with the EU will remain one of the main foreign policy issues, particularly in the light of the UK's vote to leave the bloc. As a member of the European Economic Area, Norway has access to the single market (for a fee), but must accept most EU regulations without having any influence over them. The economic consequences of Mr Trump's protectionist stance remains a risk for Norway's exports to the EU, as US tariffs would dampen Norway's external demand.
Following the EU and the US, Norway imposed sanctions on Russia in response to the conflict in Ukraine and Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea in 2014; these are likely to remain in place in the medium term.

Norway's score in The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings rises solidly, from 8.01 in the historical period (2014-18) to 8.28 in the forecast period (2019-23), underpinned by a significant strengthening of underlying macroeconomic and financing conditions, as well as an improved tax environment. However, the improvement in the country's business environment lifts it by only one position in our regional and global rankings, to seventh and 13th respectively. This leaves Norway's business environment behind those of its Nordic neighbours. In the regional ranking, Denmark, Sweden and Finland are all in stronger positions than Norway.
In the forecast period there will be significant increases in the scores for macroeconomic environment, taxes and financing. There will be modest improvements in Norway's market opportunities, infrastructure and technological readiness categories. A primary source of weakness is political stability, reflecting the fractious nature of Norway's current government and tensions within the ruling coalition, which we expect to continue over the forecast period. Moreover, as the the economy approaches full capacity, there will also be a decline in labour market scores, due to higher labour costs.
Norway will remain one of the world's best locations for businesses
Although difficulties related to political turbulence and labour costs persist, Norway will remain among the world's top business locations, owing to a strong record of pro-business policy orientation, a welcoming attitude to foreign investment, a modest regulatory burden and excellent transport, energy and digital infrastructure. Weaker aspects include the country's high personal tax burden (albeit supporting high-quality public services and social welfare), limited market opportunities, labour market rigidities and skills shortages. Moreover, the erosion of political stability poses the risk of a gradual dilution of government effectiveness.
