Business environment outlook: Norway's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The Norwegian Competition Authority (NCA) maintains investigative vigilance to ensure effective merger control. Greater interaction with the public improves agency effectiveness and investigative abilities.
2021-23: A strategic plan guides the NCA to improve competition in numerous sectors and in procurement.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: An investment screening regime that can block foreign investment on the grounds of national security or financial stability comes into effect, to be applied to both EU and non-EU investments.
2021-23: The government takes further efforts to diversify the investor countries beyond fellow European economies such as Sweden and the Netherlands, although to limited effect.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Progress is made on a US-EU trade agreement. The risk that the US administration breaks off negotiations, however, is substantial. Focus on Brexit talks and the implications for Norwegian trade.
2021-23: No change in policy towards joining the EU or leaving the European Economic Area (EEA). A reassessment of EEA membership is possible, but unlikely. Efforts to promote bilateral trade deals continue.
Taxes
2019-20: The government looks into reducing income tax and value-added tax (VAT).
2021-23: The government investigates reform of the subsidy regime for oil and gas exploration. Expansion of environmental taxes to meet climate-change goals.
Financing
2019-20: Norges Bank (the central bank) tightens monetary policy against rising inflation and high household debt.
2021-23: Greater restrictions on financial leverage are implemented. In the wake of the Swedbank scandal, greater emphasis is placed on oversight of financial institutions. Foreign-exchange conditions remain benign.
The labour market
2019-20: Reforms introduced to increase workforce supply. Working Environment Act, tackling flexible contracts, is maintained.
2021-23: Wage bargaining is dominated by demands for catch-up wages. Skills shortages remain an issue.
Infrastructure
2019-20: The government applies the 12-year transport plan (2018-29) and raises the funds available for maintenance and construction of infrastructure projects. A decision on the provider of the fifth-generation (5G) rollout is made.
2021-23: Investments in new road and rail transport links are made, with upgrades to transport infrastructure. Digital infrastructure upgrades continue.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Implementation of Norway's cyber-defence strategy, after cyber-attacks on national infrastructure.
2021-23: The Open Artificial Intelligence (AI) lab grows in size and importance, underpinning AI preparedness.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.9 9.4 1 1 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Rising oil prices have generated an improvement in macroeconomic conditions, reflected in the labour market, the public finances and capital spending. Underlying conditions point to a broadly stable economic outlook, with solid public finances (supported by the Government Pension Fund Global, or GPFG, the vast sovereign wealth fund), a large current-account surplus, substantial corporate and household savings, and reduced imbalances (the housing market is a cause for concern for policymakers). Fiscally, the GPFG, supported by government restraint, should maintain the resilience of the public finances. Norges Bank (the central bank), which manages the fund, will continue a free-floating currency regime and a transparent monetary policy. Monetary policy tightening, compounded by high household indebtedness, may constrain growth. Interest rates are expected to rise steadily to curtail inflation, which is slightly above target. However, policy tightening will be limited by a desire to avoid a sharp appreciation in the krone. Variations in oil prices will remain a source of instability in the current account, although it is probable that government stimulus, similar to that used after the 2014 oil price slump, will be used to mitigate damage to the wider economy. Rising protectionism and the need for economic diversification away from oil represent the largest risks to near- and long-term prosperity respectively.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.3 8.3 13 13 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Norway's ranking points to a continuation of the country's rigorous approach to competition policy, albeit with further improvement restrained by the still significant degree of state influence in the economy. Norwegian governments of all persuasions tend to be strongly committed to competition, legislating in line with EU law as required by the country's membership of the European Economic Area (EEA). The current centre-right government will continue its efforts to defend private-enterprise culture; however, major privatisation attempts will be suspended. The power to investigate competition and enforce competition law will remain vested in the Norwegian Competition Authority (NCA). The NCA is well staffed (with more than 100 employees, mostly economists and lawyers), making it effective in merger control, the policing of cartels and abuse of market dominance, as well as in the investigation of the impact of government policy on competition. The NCA raids office premises when necessary, and has stepped up its merger control by banning three prospective mergers in 2016. The NCA has taken action against bid rigging, imposed large fines for collusion in the publishing industry and fined Telenor, Norway's largest telecommunications provider, for the abuse of its dominant position. The authority works closely with European regulators on crossborder mergers, and the newly established Competition Appeals Committee will improve the process of legal redress for companies contesting decisions. A revision to the Competition Act, passed in 2016, harmonises merger control with EU law and allows for Norwegian settlements in cartel cases.
Limited privatisation plans are set to be carried out
The centre-right government will prioritise its plans for a slight unwinding of state-owned assets, after mixed results previously. The Conservatives' attempt to partially privatise Statkraft, a renewable-energy company, was criticised by the opposition. The government did sell the state's remaining stake in Scandinavian Airlines (SAS), the flag carrier of Sweden, Norway and Denmark, but this move should not be seen as a privatisation drive by the government. The state retains significant holdings in crucial sectors, including Equinor (formerly Statoil, 67%), a petroleum company; Telenor (54.5%); Yara (36.2%), a fertiliser manufacturer; Norsk Hydro (40.8%), an aluminium producer; and DNB bank (34%). Statkraft, a renewable-energy company, and Statskog, a forestry and land-management company, remain fully public.
A campaign started in November 2018 by the NCA enables members of the public to report suspected anti-competitive practices directly, and removes any further fees for reporting activity. This was followed up by a series of lectures informing the public on illegal co-operation, and we expect this project to continue throughout 2019. The campaign led to an annual rise of 47% in reports of anti-competitive practices in 2019, according to the NCA, which may be followed up by further legal action. Although this policy will raise monitoring of anti-competitive practices, further investments in regulatory authorities will probably be needed to enforce them.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.7 8.7 10 10 8 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The ranking shows a slight improvement in Norway's regional ranking for foreign investment, although this is mostly driven by a protectionist turn among other European economies. Norway has long had a co-operative stance towards foreign investors, abiding by its obligations as an EEA member, and broadly welcoming foreign capital and know-how. Political resistance to foreign influence is limited only to takeovers in strategic sectors and some national cultural institutions. The long-term depletion of offshore hydrocarbon reserves and the pressing issues caused by the oil price crash in 2014 have given impetus to government efforts to pursue foreign investment to diversify the economy and complement the crucial offshore energy sector with new sources of wealth. The government is concentrating on attracting investment from China, principally in the seafood industry. However, diversification efforts have not been as fruitful as expected, leaving the oil and gas sector as the most important for foreign investors for the foreseeable future.
National security will play a larger role in foreign investment decisions
In line with developments across developed economies, concerns around national security are likely to play a larger role in decisions on foreign investment over the forecast period. An expanded national security law took effect in January 2019, which gives the government power to stop any foreign acquisitions of crucial sectors that may threaten national security. Companies wishing to acquire a third of any business of vital security interest will be required to notify the relevant ministry. This is in line with an increasingly general trend of political interference in business acquisitions. The new law is likely to lead to an increase in workload for the affected Norwegian businesses in terms of notifications, assessments and dialogue with the authorities. It could also impair the competitiveness of, and reduce the investment risk appetite for, Norwegian companies that will be subject to the new regime. Although the law has yet to be invoked in a foreign takeover, its application highlights a tightening of Norwegian policy towards national security threats.
Policy will attempt to diversify Norway's inward foreign direct investment (FDI). Although Swedish investors have historically dominated external investment, the US plays a reportedly underestimated role. The authorities will seek investment from elsewhere in Europe, and increasingly from China and the rest of Asia. Invest in Norway is a governmental investment promotion agency established in 2013 that focuses on attracting external investment. The agency will prioritise investments from non-traditional markets, but also within industries, such as maritime, fishing, renewable energy and biotech, that have been highlighted as means to diversify Norway's economy away from oil and gas.
Norwegian state railway's privatisation of certain routes will continue. In October 2017 a British public transport provider, Go-Ahead, won the first Norwegian railway tender for operation of a rail service. The service, covering the Sorlandet line to Stavanger, Arendal line services and Jaer line local services from Stavanger totalling 5.5m train-km/year, will be run over ten years. We expect a gradual widening of public-private collaboration in Norwegian infrastructure, including rail infrastructure, in accordance with the 12-year transport plan (2018-29).
The generous tax structure for oil investment will continue
Support for foreign investment on the Norwegian continental shelf is likely to remain generous. Investors will continue to be offered new blocks to explore for oil and gas, based on ordinary concession licensing rounds held every two years in frontier areas. In June 2018 the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy offered 12 new production licences to 11 companies in the 24th licensing round. The number of applicant companies fell to 11, from 26 in the previous round, which created some concern regarding interest in the Norwegian shelf. Nine of the licences are focused on the Barents Sea and three in the Norwegian Sea. No licences for frontier areas will be available in 2019. A coalition agreement that enforces a ban on exploring for oil off the Lofoten, Senja and Vesteralen islands, introduced by the centrist Liberal Party, will continue to be upheld through the parliament's term to 2021.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
9.1 9.1 13 20 8 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
As Norway is a net energy exporter, with a small domestic market and limited manufacturing capabilities, Norwegian governments of all persuasions adopt broadly pro-free-trade policies, despite the long-standing reluctance to join the EU and the protectionism afforded to home-produced agriculture. The deterioration in Norway's regional and global rankings in our assessment here largely reflects the improved performance of neighbouring countries and the lack of improvement in Norway's trade openness due to the country's remote location and undiversified export base. Trade openness notwithstanding, Norway's institutions remain largely welcoming to trade. Except in extremis, foreign investors in Norway are guaranteed the absence of foreign-exchange controls, with an independent central bank overseeing a free-floating krone. Profits and dividends earned in all areas of the economy, including oil and gas, may be repatriated without obstruction, with no restrictions on capital inflows or outflows. Through Norway's membership of the EEA, Norwegian and foreign-owned companies in Norway gain full access to the single market. EU access guarantees the free movement of persons, goods, services and capital between Norway and EU member states. Norway adopts around three-quarters of all single-market legislation, with the notable exceptions being laws that govern agriculture and fisheries. Norway will continue to work in favour of free trade, harmonising its duties and tariffs structure in line with World Trade Organisation (WTO) and EU agreements, and giving high priority to making new EEA rules applicable in Norway. This will allow it to maintain its excellent record of transposing EU rules into national law. Free trade outside the EU will be promoted mainly through the European Free-Trade Association (EFTA) by negotiating free-trade agreements (FTAs). There are currently 27 FTAs covering 38 countries. Norway has preferential trade arrangements with a growing number of countries outside the EU and has revived trade talks with China concerning energy sector co-operation and opening up the Chinese market for farmed salmon as relations have thawed since 2017. Norway has followed the EU's lead in placing sanctions on Russia since mid-2014, resulting in a Russian ban on EU (including Norwegian) food imports and other items.
Renegotiation of Norway's EEA membership is unlikely
Norway's position on the fringe of European institutions is unlikely to change. It is not a member of the EU and will not consider joining over the forecast period, as an increasing number of parties oppose membership. In addition to the well-known position of the Socialist Left Party (SV) and the Centre Party (Sp), the Progress Party (FrP) also made public its opposition to EU membership in 2016. Given insufficient political and public support, the Conservatives have set aside plans for another referendum on membership (the last one was held in 1994, when membership was rejected). There is a growing movement within the FrP, led by the party's deputy leader, Sylvi Listhaug, to renegotiate the terms of Norway's EEA membership, although centrist parties within the ruling coalition and the example of Brexit make the prospect of wider renegotiation unlikely.
US-EU trade relations will depend on the Boeing-Airbus dispute
Since the election of Donald Trump as US president trade relations between the EU and the US have become more fraught. The US administration's efforts have largely been focused on China, but tariffs were imposed on steel and aluminium in March 2018, and EU retaliation followed. More recently, concerns have centred around automotive trade, with the US considering raising tariffs on about EUR47bn (US$53bn) of European auto exports. Our core forecast is that this threatened tariff rise will not happen, given the lenient schedule of negotiations (which are to last until November 2019) and the upcoming 2020 US election campaign. However, should current discussions over the Boeing-Airbus dispute turn sour, this could spark a wider trade conflict involving other sectors, including the automobile sector.
Lobbying will intensify from businesses in northern Norway to withdraw from the EU's trade embargo on Russia, but Norway will remain party to the embargo as long as the EU's relations with Russia remain tense; retaliatory measures by Russia will continue to deprive Norwegian-based firms in the fisheries sector of an important market.
Steady trade integration with other trading powers is likely to continue, with the EU-Japan trade agreement coming into force in February 2019. The EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) will gradually be enforced in 2018-22. Both deals eliminate most trade tariffs, ease border procedures and increase regulatory co-operation. In both cases the immediate benefits of trade integration will be limited owing to an extensive transition phase, but the wider benefits to productivity, growth and employment are likely to be felt in the coming years.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.0 7.4 42 20 12 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The ruling coalition, led by the right-wing FrP and the centre-right Conservatives, has prioritised reform of the tax system. Norway's tax system scores relatively poorly compared with other components of the business environment, but the government's plans for tax reductions have raised the country's relative ranking substantially over the forecast period, to fifth in Europe. The reform measures seek to make the system more growth-oriented, making tax rates more competitive and tranferring the burden from direct to indirect taxation. The government is continuing its programme of steady reductions in the corporate tax rate, reducing the headline rate from 27% in 2014 to 25% in 2016 and 22% in 2019 This has brought Norway's effective tax rates closer to its regional peers (both Denmark and Sweden have 22% corporate tax rates) and in line with the OECD average. Offshore petroleum companies pay a higher rate on income, which has risen steadily, from 53% in 2016 to 56% in 2019, but effective tax rates remain largely unchanged, as the lower rate of investment-based depreciation, the "rate of uplift", has been reduced from 5.5% in 2016 to 5.2% in 2019. Taxation on hydropower production has also risen steadily, from 33% in 2016 to 34.3% in 2017 and 37% in 2019. Although the government is not likely to raise taxes further on hydrocarbon extraction, future governments may decide to review the generous conditions for oil exploration investment, as the right-wing FrP is gradually losing support from its 2010 peak. Currently the government covers 78% of the costs of searching for oil reserves if the company conducting the discovery does not make a profit.
Personal rates of income tax will probably fall over the forecast period
Personal rates of income tax are likely to fall steadily throughout the government's term. The 2019 budget cut personal income tax rates to 22%. Since 2016 the bracket tax is applied to four income brackets, which have been gradually adjusted over time; as at January 2019 the bracket taxes stood at: 1.9% on incomes between Nkr174,500 (US$21,087) and Nkr245,650, 4.2% on incomes between Nkr245,650 and Nkr617,500, 13.2% on incomes between Nkr617,500 and Nkr964,800, and 16.2% on incomes above this threshold. This replaced the surtax system (an additional tax that applied only to the two highest income brackets). A financial activities tax also came into force in 2017.
Under the Conservative-led coalition government there is likely to be further downward pressure on the tax burden. In the election campaign Erna Solberg, the prime minister, stated that she would pursue a more moderate reduction than the one implemented in 2013-17, worth Nkr22.4bn (US$2.4bn). Although a "wealth tax" is a long-term goal of the Conservatives, the party has already said that it will not seek to introduce it over the next parliamentary term.
The SkatteFUNN scheme acts as the framework for Norway's support for business innovation and targets enterprises that are at their early stage of development. It is a tax-deduction scheme for companies that are engaged in research and development activities. This fiscal framework is qualification-based and regulated in the statutory framework, and is open to all branches of industry and all types of companies, regardless of size.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.5 9.3 3 1 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Financial stability is guaranteed by well-supervised and funded banks
Norway has improved its position at the top of the regional and global rankings over the forecast period, reflecting the continuous improvement of the its financial regulatory framework. Distortions to the financial system are limited, as banks continue to be well supervised and in most cases exceed their requirements for for Tier-1 capital-adequacy ratios under Basel III. This helps to contain the risks stemming from commercial banks' exposure to the mortgage market and high household debt levels. Although financial institutions in Sweden and Denmark were faced with a money-laundering scandal earlier in 2019, stemming from operations in Baltic states (chiefly Latvia and Estonia), we do not expect similar problems to directly affect the financing abilities of Norwegian banks, as they have experienced strong underlying profit growth domestically, excluding their Baltic operations. The banking system has remained in a healthy state since the global financial crisis. This is because of lower risk exposures and only limited holdings of high-risk European government securities. Shared counterparty and foreign-exchange exposure risks are low, although Norway's banks may be vulnerable because of their exposure to oil and gas, property, and shipbuilding loan portfolios. Foreign companies have access to the same capital sources as domestic companies, but often work through foreign banks, which tend to have offices in Oslo, the capital, and in cities where the oil industry is based, especially Bergen and Stavanger. Access to investment finance is adequate, as tighter rules were established in the wake of the global financial crisis. Companies are able to obtain bank funding (subject to risk limits) and can also access the equity or bond markets, which-owing to the government's strong fiscal position-are more stable than in other countries. Foreign-exchange access will remain unhindered as the authorities maintain a free-float currency outside the euro zone, with no capital controls.
A tightening in mortgage lending rules has curbed household indebtedness
Bank lending will remain the primary source of credit for commercial enterprises. The tightening of regulation on lending, especially household lending, has succeeded in restraining household debt as a share of GDP. With the housing makret cooling, we do not expect further tightening of fianancing regulation. New measures were introduced in 2017, such as an interest-rate stress test (a sensitivity test) when assessing the borrower's repayment capacity, a cap on the loan/value ratio (at 85% for new homes and 60% for second homes) and a loan/income requirement. The countercyclical capital buffer requirement increased by 0.5 percentage points in 2018, to 2%. Equity capital requirements and fees for commercial borrowers will rise proportionately, mitigated by healthy competition in the market for company loans.
Bank financing of existing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and new start-ups will remain restricted. However, low-cost financing will continue to be available from other sources, including the debt and equity markets, non-resident banks and, increasingly, venture capital (which may be government sponsored) to facilitate the development of high-tech, niche sectors.
Borrowing rates will remain low but will rise steadily throughout our forecast period. Regulation of the financial sector will be continually improved, which may affect the ability to lend, but non-resident access to the financial system is assured for well-known corporations and for those with viable business plans and/or a solid track record.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.6 6.4 25 34 10 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Strong price growth since 2018 has raised pressures on labour costs
High standards of tertiary education and vocational training have helped to develop a highly skilled labour force in managerial expertise and language skills. Central-level bargaining between the government, the Confederation of Norwegian Enterprise and the Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions involves a high degree of co-ordination, with blue-collar manufacturing wages providing the benchmark for sector-specific and company-level bargaining. However, we expect the restrictive elements of this system, such as a large public sector and some scarcity of skills in the private sector, to become more prevalent as unemployment edges lower, weakening the country's ranking from 25th to 34th globally. The lack of labour mobility will restrict opportunities for economic development in remote regions, and a mismatch of education and skills among immigrants and asylum-seekers settling in Norway will hamper integration into the workforce. Political pressure to restrict migration will also remain high, stifling any surge in labour supply. High aspirations for wages and entitlements contribute to workforce welfare, but also add to business operating costs. This has become more acute since mid-2018, when rapid price growth put pressure on firms to maintain rising real wages. Strike action is a familiar feature of the main and intermediate settlement process in the public sector and among offshore petroleum industry workers seeking higher rates and benefits, which contributes to the lower score on this category. However, the government reserves the right to enforce arbitration in disputes that are likely to have a major impact on the economy or be detrimental to public health. Although industrial action has taken place recently, notably in the case of SAS employees, we expect future action to be largely avoided through arbitration.
Stricter immigration control, a tightening labour market and divergent sectoral trends will contribute to the mismatch of demand and supply of crucial skills, especially in the healthcare, engineering and construction sectors. The government is likely to take additional measures to close this gap.
Norwegian wages are becoming unmoored from productivity
High labour costs will continue to impede business operations. The importance of the oil sector has encouraged a "Dutch disease" phenomenon where wage growth is increasingly out of step with productivity in important sectors, especially in manufacturing. According to the OECD, Norway's manufacturing productivity has risen by about 50% since 1995, while compensation has risen by just over 250%. In Germany, by contrast, wages and productivity have risen in step, whereas in the wider Nordic economies productivity has outpaced wages. The resurgence of the oil sector since 2016 is likely to exacerbate this phenomenon, making the economy less competitive internationally, raising costs for domestic firms and hampering the government's objective for sustained diversification away from oil.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.0 8.5 12 8 8 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Norway's physical transport and digital infrastructure networks are adequate for a well-equipped, modern and advanced industrialised nation, with few of the problems, such as traffic congestion, that affect countries with higher population densities. Further investment according to a national infrastructure plan, released in 2018, will raise its regional ranking from eighth to fifth over the forecast period. Good ferry and internal air transport services, including oil-rig helicopter links, help to prevent Norway's diverse topography and weather-related vulnerabilities from creating logistical problems. Rock fall, flooding and landslide risks, alongside the ongoing requirement to increase the connectivity of cities and regions, place constant demands on the public purse to maintain roads, bridges and tunnels, and rail, air and maritime transport systems, as well as public transport links. However, the unpopularity of road tolls, which are an important source of funding for Norwegian infrastructure, are becoming a more salient political issue. Norway's digital infrastructure is among the most highly advanced in the world. In recent years many rapidly expanding start-ups have emerged, enhancing household and business online usage, with almost all basic services available digitally in the present day. Telecommunications coverage and quality is high. Providers are quick to roll out improvements to the high-speed broadband network. However, there are concerns about security, cost and international relations surrounding the upgrading of the country's network to fifth-generation (5G) in the near future.
A National Transport Plan, published in 2018, directs infrastructure spending
Infrastructure policy has been set out by a National Transport Plan for 2018-29, which focuses on maintenance of transport infrastructure, pollution reduction and stronger public-private co-operation, as well as the increasing use of intelligent transport systems. The plan's baseline scenario allocates 58% of the total budget of Nkr418.5m (US$45.6m) for road improvements; 32% for railways (which includes new double-track lines for intercity routes, Oslo-Skien and Halden-Lillehammer, and a second light-rail line in Bergen, to Fyllingsdalen, a borough in the south of the city); and another 3% to sea infrastructure that will benefit the fishing and shipping industries.
The government is expected to make a decision on rolling out Norway's 5G network by the end of 2019, similar to its European neighbours. The cabinet will have to balance concerns around the new network's security against cost and Norway's relations with its neighbours and its 5G providers.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.6 8.9 18 18 10 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Norway performs well on the technological readiness ranking, although the expected improvements over the forecast period are inadequate to improve its international ranking. The strong result reflects the high quality of e-commerce business and scope of e-government services, widespread internet usage, and a high number of patent registrations. Norway's score for cyber-security preparedness, research and development (R&D) spending, and quality of research infrastructure are weaker, but still high by regional comparison. Total investment in R&D was 2.1% of GDP in 2017-slightly below the OECD average of 2.4% and well below its Nordic neighbours' (3.1% for Denmark and 3.2% for Sweden). In the European Innovation Scoreboard 2018 the country scores particularly well for lifelong learning (aided by Norway's flexible education system) and the government's openness to innovation. Weaker aspects include low levels of patent application and intellectual property assets in the country.
A cyber-attack on an energy supplier led to a national plan for cyber-security
In May 2019, in response to the increasing prevalence of cyber-security attacks (exemplified by an attack on Norsk Hydro, a state-backed energy supplier, in March 2019), the government unveiled a national cyber-security strategy. This strategy places further emphasis on public-private collaboration across both civilian and military branches of government, with the aim of safeguarding national infrastructure against cyber-security threats.
Public-private partnership will be an increasing theme in technology research initiatives, in line with many other developed economies. In August 2018 some of Norway's biggest companies announced that they would jointly establish a national powerhouse for artificial intelligence (AI) to improve the country's quality and capacity for research, education and innovation in the field. The government has actively supported these partnerships, as it encourages the matching of technical skills to business need, reducing the extent of skills mismatches and raising productivity. However, their effect on innovation and the extent of spillovers to other industries is yet to be established.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Economic diversification, following the 2014 shock to world oil prices, is a main policy objective. Since the rebound in oil sector investment (evidenced by several large new oilfields being developed and the expanded maintenance of existing fields) after the oil price started to recover from 2016, the government has kept diversification as a central element of its policy. The administration identifies the aluminium industry, the healthcare sector, fish farming and fisheries, and green technology as potential areas for growth. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect substantial progress to be made in the medium term. This is due to the specialisation of the mainland economy in the oil sector; the government's fiscal policy, which allows limited room for state support to new industries; and diversification's diminished political salience now that oil prices have recovered.
In recent years the government's main priority has been to improve Norway's competitiveness by trying to bring tax and wage levels closer to those of its peers. The government hopes that this will boost activity and investment in non-oil tradable sectors. A multiparty agreement in 2015, aimed at reducing the headline rate of corporate tax from 27% to 23% in 2018, has been implemented, and a further reduction to 22% has been agreed for 2019. Efforts have also been made to reduce bureaucracy and public-sector inefficiencies.
Norway's fiscal policy framework is designed to insulate the budget from fluctuations in oil and gas revenue, with the government responsible for transferring the state's net oil revenue to the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG, the sovereign wealth fund), which is currently valued at Nkr9trn (US$1trn). According to Norway's fiscal rule, the government can use up to 3% of the fund's value annually, which corresponds to the estimated real return. The crash in oil prices in late 2014, and the following contraction in petroleum revenue and investment, led to smaller fiscal surpluses. The government counteracted the slowdown with a more expansionary fiscal stance, withdrawing more from the fund than it transferred. However, since 2016 the government has gradually tightened policy, reducing the fiscal impulse. As the oil industry recovers in the 2019-23 forecast period, fiscal policy will tighten further.

The 2019 budget, agreed between the ruling coalition and the Christian Democrats (KrF) in November 2018, has a fiscally neutral impact, contrasting with the fiscal stimulus in 2016. We expect the fiscal surplus in 2019 to average 6.5%, which partially reflects lower global energy prices on average. In 2020-23 the surplus should remain large, at an average of 6.9%, supported by strengthening oil prices, a pick-up in petroleum investment activity and steady economic growth. Strong wage growth, which helped to drive the surplus to 7.2% of GDP in 2018, will also support fiscal stability. The 2019 budget complies with the fiscal rule and estimates that withdrawals from the fund will total Nkr231.5bn (US$27.1bn), which is about 2.7% of the fund's estimated capital as at early 2019. The government's emphasis on improving competitiveness remains central to its fiscal plans, which include a further reduction in the corporate tax rate, and a long-term plan for research and higher education. This comprises three new investment initiatives amounting to Nkr1.5bn in 2019-22.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
3-month Nibor rate (av) 1.1 1.4 1.5 1.6 1.7 1.7
10-year government bond yield (av) 1.9 1.7 1.8 1.9 2.2 2.3
Norges Bank (the central bank), having initiated its tightening cycle in September 2018 and continued it in March 2019, is expected to raise rates twice in 2019 at its June and December meetings. The krone has remained stable against the US dollar and the euro since the start of 2019, reflecting the largely stable price of oil, freeing the bank to take greater action to bring elevated inflation towards its 2% target. From 2020 we expect Norges Bank to continue tightening at a more gradual pace, taking the policy rate to 2.5% by end-2023.
Norges Bank kept its main policy rate (on sight deposits) at a record-low 0.5% from March 2016 until September 2018, when it raised it to 0.75%. It then raised it by a further 25 basis points in March 2019, to 1%. Norges Bank targets inflation of "close to 2% over time". Nevertheless, contrary to its neighbours, its mandate is flexible to ensure stable output and employment, and to avoid the build-up of financial imbalances.
The bank adopted a more hawkish stance at its March meeting, signalling a faster pace of tightening in the near term, in response to stronger than expected inflation, which rose to 2.8% in 2018, from 1.9% in 2017, and remains elevated, at 3% from January to April 2019. We expect two more rises in 2019, lifting the rate to 1.5% in December. Strong core inflation and a tight labour market will strengthen nominal wage growth, pushing up domestic inflation, which we expect to remain above target until 2021. Norges Bank also wants to address household leverage in the country, which continued to grow in 2018, albeit at a slower pace; in October-December 2018 household debt totalled 218% of gross disposable income.

Strengthening oil output should support output growth over 2019-23
We expect growth to remain stable at 1.7% in 2019, from 1.8% in 2018, but this will be lower than the 2.7% expansion recorded in 2017. This slowdown will be due in part to strong growth of imports, which weighed on output in the first quarter, bringing annual growth to 1.4%. We expect the economy to strengthen later this year and over the forecast period, owing to resurgent petroleum-related investment, improved export performance (once technical difficulties on oil platforms in the North Sea are rectified) and solid wage growth driving private consumption. These factors should be supported by the gradual fall in inflation and the reduction of tax rates by the ruling coalition. We believe that these factors will outweigh the contractionary effects of steady monetary policy tightening by Norges Bank.
Risks to our short-term outlook are well balanced. On the one hand, downside risks stem from potential oil price volatility and the fallout from a steeper trajectory of monetary tightening. The ongoing US-China trade dispute could also escalate, impacting export growth, although this is not our baseline scenario. On the other hand, upside risks stem from the prospect of stronger than expected investment and wage growth.
We expect real GDP growth to remain close to potential, at an average of 2% in 2020-23. Investment growth should ease during this period, as the number of major oilfield development projects is lower than in the past, and fewer discoveries were made in 2018 to justify increasing future investment levels.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Norway's sectoral balance has changed only modestly since the exploitation of the country's oil reserves in the 1970s, which placed the oil and gas industry in a prime position in the Norwegian economy, composing about a fifth of GDP in 2018. Common to most developed economies, the services sector is the mainstay of Norway's output, contributing about 68.8% to the country's GDP in 2018, according to the World Bank. This share is below Norway's peer economies in Scandinavia: Finland and Denmark's share of services output is 77.3% and 71.3% respectively. The impact of other sectors, namely agriculture, fishing and forestry; and manufacturing, is also fairly muted, at just 1.9% and 6.3% of GDP respectively. Both sectors are predominantly export oriented, with fishing exports constituting 9.6% of all exports in 2018, and manufactures 8.5%.
Norway's cold climate and undulating landscape are not suited to farming
Norway's agricultural sector has a smaller role than that of its neighbours, providing 1.9% of GDP. The harsh winter weather, an undulating landscape not suited to agriculture and limited economies of scale in farming (about 60% of all Norwegian farms have less than 20 hectares of agricultural land) have all restrained output. Pastoral farming (of sheep, pigs and cows) contributes the most to total agricultural output-about 64.4%, according to Eurostat. Despite its small size, farming is well diversified, with no one produce for livestock, dairy and agricultural goods taking up more than 30% of production.
The oil and gas sector has been a mainstay of Norwegian prosperity since oil was first exploited in Norway, primarily in the North Sea (on the country's west coast) in the 1970s, but recent factors have pushed the sector into decline. The sharp fall in oil prices in 2014 caused the industry's share of GDP to drop from a peak of 25% in 2012 to 14% in 2016. The recovery in oil prices since mid-2014 has encouraged a modest revival in the sector, to 19% of GDP in 2018, and the near-term outlook remains favourable for oil production. By year-end 2018, 83 fields were producing-slightly fewer than in 2017 (when there were 85), and 14 new fields were in development, including Johan Sverdrup, the fifth-largest oil discovery ever made in Norwegian waters, which will account for 30% of all Norwegian oil production by the mid-2020s, according to the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate (NPD), a government agency. This leads us to expect a slight revival in oil production in Norway from its expected nadir in 2019, owing to higher prices and a stronger base of production, albeit not to the scale of the sector's peak in the mid-2000s. This rise in production has been presaged by an improvement in oil sector investment over the past six months.
Various concerns are making politicians wary of further oil sector growth
The long-term outlook for oil sector production remains uncertain. Although production peaked in 2001, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA), recent investment and a series of new discoveries have the potential to maintain oil production throughout the forecast period. However, various pressures are limiting the appetite of policymakers for further oil sector expansion. Firstly, there is a need for diversification in Norway's economy, highlighted by the damaging effects of the sharp decline in the oil sector since 2014. Secondly, environmental concerns have influenced government policy. The Liberals, as part of their agreement to enter government in January 2018, extracted a guarantee that oil exploration would not reach the Lofoten islands-a peninsula to the north of Norway-extending an arrangement that had been in place over 2013-17. Thirdly, the generous tax system for oil exploration, which refunds 78% of oil exploration costs, has been coming under increasing political pressure within the Labour Party. These pressures will probably constrain the oil sector's influence on the economy throughout the forecast period.
Since the exploitation of oil, Norway's manufacturing sector has receded in economic importance, from 17.7% in 1970, according to the World Bank, to 6.3% in 2017. This decline has been more pronounced than that of Norway's peer economies. Denmark, Sweden and Finland all have manufacturing sectors that comprise more than 12% of GDP. Manufacturing is split between an oil-oriented component, dominated by machinery, chemicals and ship-building, and a consumer-oriented component, based on production of food and beverages. The decline in oil prices in 2014 caused a sharp fall in machinery and chemicals production, leaving food and beverages the largest component of Norwegian manufacturing in 2018. Despite some government initiatives to support diversification away from the oil sector, the perpetually strong krona will keep the outlook for a wider recovery in the manufacturing industry muted.
The oil sector has supported shipping and engineering service growth
The services sector is expected to continue its steady growth throughout the forecast, growing in primacy as oil output recedes. The sector consists of business services common to advanced economies, with retail trade and financial services taking up a large share of output. Norway's geographical location and the extent of the oil industry has also enabled transport and shipping, alongside other professional or technical services (such as engineering, chemicals and research), to develop outside the oil sector, and Norwegian firms like Aker ASA and Yara International can compete globally.

Inflation is expected to recede gradually in 2019, as rising wages are counterbalanced by falling prices in electricity and energy. A spike in energy prices in 2018, owing to a decline in rainfall and hydroelectricity production, drove inflation to an average of 2.8%, up from 1.9% in 2017. These effects have largely passed and, together with cheaper oil prices in 2019, imply that inflation should ease to 2.6% on average. Monthly data for early 2019 have borne this out, and annual price growth has receded slightly. Price pressures will remain firm throughout 2019-23, owing to healthy wage growth.
Economic forecast: Exchange rates

Purchasing power parity Nkr:US$ (av) 10.44 10.53 10.46 10.68 10.87 10.98
The krone tends to follow developments in global energy markets, and has depreciated significantly on average against the US dollar and the euro since 2013. In 2019 we believe that the krone will depreciate slightly against the euro-a trend that will continue into 2020. This is primarily due to the falling price of oil, Norway's primary export, which weakens the country's terms of trade and undermines the amount of revenue that the state receives. After 2020, we judge the krone will remain largely stable as rebounding oil prices are counterbalanced by an end to monetary tightening. A sharp market reaction to the accelerated pace of tightening by Norges Bank, which will strengthen the krone, is a risk to our exchange-rate forecast.
We do not expect the krone to return to pre-2014 levels; since the sharp correction of oil prices in late 2014, investors have become more concerned about Norway's lack of economic diversification, and other factors-such as global monetary policy stances and geopolitical factors-have contributed more heavily to the krone's movements.

Rising imports of capital goods will reduce the current-account surplus
We expect that the current-account surplus will fall slightly in 2019, owing to the surge in import demand from investment projects, falling oil prices and declining production of oil in the North Sea (due to technical difficulties on some platforms). This should bring the current-account surplus to 7.7% of GDP in 2019, compared with 8.1% in 2018, despite the continued strong performance of the primary income balance.
Following the slippage in oil prices from 2014, Norway's dependable current-account surplus shrank, reaching a two-decade low (4%) in 2016. Falling oil prices in 2019 will place downward pressure on the current account, although surpluses are largely guaranteed by the vibrant oil sector and the Government Pension Fund Global, which supports Norway's substantial primary income balance. In 2020-23 the structure of the current account should remain unchanged, and we expect the surplus to remain large, averaging 9.2% of GDP.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Norway
Stocks and flows
Inward foreign direct investment (FDI) had been elevated prior to the sharp fall in oil prices in 2014, averaging US$18.9bn in 2007-12, with significant declines in the wake of the financial crisis and alongside fluctuations in the oil market. After the drop in oil prices in 2014, inward FDI flows weakened significantly, turning negative in 2016, at the nadir of the oil sector's performance. Inward flows also turned sharply negative in 2018, but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this disinvestment to ease over the forecast period, turning positive in 2020, in line with the strengthening of the oil sector. However, these flows are unlikely to reach the levels seen before 2014. By end-2018 stocks of inward FDI stood at US$230.9bn, or about 53% of GDP, although this will fall to about 44% by 2023. At US$43,395 per head, FDI remains above that of the EU15 and many peer economics in Scandinavia, with Finland and Iceland at US$29,147 and US$17,839 respectively.
Origin and distribution
Norway's oil-intensive economy means that FDI is largely focused on the oil and gas sector, in addition to ancillary services such as transport, infrastructure and finance. Most of the world's major oil and gas companies are involved in Norwegian oil production, including Chevron, ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil, Marathon (all US-based), BP, BG (both UK), Eni (Italy), RWE Dea (Germany) and Engie (France). FDI data for 2017, released by Statistics Norway, show that about 27% of all FDI goes to mining and quarrying (including the oil sector), whereas manufacturing, the next highest recipient, gets 14.2%. Financial services are also an important beneficiary of foreign investment, taking about 10.4%. Both manufacturing and financial services have considerable overlap with the oil and gas sector. The bulk of Norwegian inward FDI has its origins in fellow European countries, with the Netherlands, Sweden and the UK in the top five investor countries, with these three jointly holding about 40% of all FDI in Norway. The US has become a more prominent investor in Norway in recent years, now holding 15% of all foreign investment in 2017-higher than the 9% held by the US in 2014.
Determinants
The Norwegian government operates a system to encourage and regulate the exploitation of oil within its waters (the country has no onshore oil production). To ensure that the exploration of oil is intensive in previously explored, or "mature", areas, the government awards licences for the exploration of these regions annually-as opposed to unexplored, "frontier", areas, for which licences are awarded once every two years. This awards system has been in place since 2003 and comes with a taxation system, in place since 2005, which rewards exploration but penalises excessive production. The government imposes a special additional tax of 51%, on top of an oil-sector tax rate of 27%, on wells that are producing oil-higher than the marginal tax rate for UK oil producers, which stands at 40%. This high rate of taxation is compensated by a feature that enables upstream companies to write off 78% of losses on oil exploration if the search for oil proves unsuccessful. The presence of oil has led to high FDI stocks, but an onerous tax burden, high wages, Norway's limited market size and high house prices are all factors that restrain further growth in foreign investment. The market size is slightly limited by Norway's membership of the European Economic Area (EEA), which gives Norwegian firms full access to the wider European market. But Norway's trade access is made slightly more uncertain by Norway's retention of its own currency, the krone, which moves alongside fluctuations in the oil price and adds to exchange-rate risk.
Impact
FDI has encouraged a sustained transfer of foreign knowledge to Norway and has accelerated the development of the oil and gas sector. The oil sector has, in turn, encouraged wider growth in the mainland economy, through higher wages and stronger consumer spending but also through ancillary services such as transport and finance. Several of these ancillary services, notably the supply and maintenance services, have become internationally competitive, despite the strong krone. Moreover, high taxation on developed oil wells has led to a resilient fiscal balance and vast sovereign wealth fund, the Government Pension Fund Global, which is used as a "nest egg" for future public spending and an additional stock of public spending when fiscal stimulus is needed, as was the case after the 2014 slide in oil prices. Despite the sector's large influence on the wider economy, its impact on employment is limited, as just 1% of the labour force is involved in offshore activities. Much FDI outside sectors related to the oil and gas industry is through purchases of existing companies rather than the setting up of new companies or facilities. Slow progress on selling government stakes in a number of part-publicly owned companies may dampen FDI flows.
Potential
Despite recent efforts by the government to induce more investment and private-sector activity by reducing the tax burden, the economy will still remain broadly unattractive to foreign investment owing to high labour costs. Although the population is highly educated and well trained, many of the non-oil, non-agricultural industries remain centred in Oslo, the capital. The government has made the wider development of the "High North" (the areas adjacent to the Arctic) a wider policy priority, offering various incentives and grants, including a reduction in the scale of employer contributions, as the government attempts to encourage stronger growth in the maritime, healthcare and information technology sectors there also. Nevertheless, the bulk of opportunities for foreign investment will remain in the energy sector, encompassing oil, gas and green energy (notably wind power).

A decline in net migration has slowed population growth in recent years
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the population to maintain its steady rate of growth over the forecast period (2019-23), although long-run factors, such as the ageing of the population and the trend towards smaller family sizes, will weigh on population growth in the coming years. Spurred by the solid expansion in the economy, high levels of migration from eastern Europe and the wealth effect of a steady rise in house prices, population growth has been consistently above 1% since 2007, averaging about 1.3% in 2008-14, according to Statistics Norway. Since the start of 2013 the growth rate of the population has declined, from 1.3% to 0.7% in 2018, as the economic outlook has become more uncertain, reducing both births and immigration. Net immigration has declined from its post-crisis peak of more than 48,700 in 2012 to just 18,000 in 2018, driven by a subsiding of the migrant crisis in 2016 and a tightening of migration rules for those outside the European Economic Area (EEA). We expect the stronger economic environment to encourage some strengthening of population growth over the forecast, owing to both higher levels of economic migration and a stronger rate of natural increase among the domestic population.
Net migration has fallen since 2012, despite a rise in asylum-seekers
Net migration, which reached a peak of more than 47,000 in 2012, has been more subdued in recent years as migration from eastern Europe has subsided, to just 18,000. The arrival of more than 3,500 asylum-seekers from Syria in 2018 made up the bulk of recent inflows, but the 2018 data showed a significant decline on the previous year, when immigration from Syria amounted to more than 6,800 migrants. Despite these recent arrivals, Polish migrants remain the largest group within the migrant population, at a total of 98,961, according to 2019 data from Statistics Norway. This is followed by Lithuanians (39,300), Swedes (35,580) and Syrians (30,800). Strong migration inflows earlier in the decade should revive Norway's declining fertility rate, which peaked in 2009 at 1.98 (still below the replacement rate), and medical improvements should continue to raise life expectancy. Over the forecast period we expect the population to age gradually, with more than 18% of the population over the age of 67 by 2023, and we also expect a deceleration in the growth of the working-age population, from an average of 0.7% growth in 2014-18 to 0.6% in 2019-23.
The demographic challenge is not as severe as in other European countries
Despite this gradual ageing of the population, Norway's near-term demographic profile remains supportive for further economic growth. The share of the population below the age of 15, at 17.8%, is one of the highest in Europe (the comparable figure for the EU28 is 15.6%, according to Eurostat), encouraging a continued expansion in demand for consumer goods and housing, alongside innovation in the services sector. Growth in the young population will also mitigate the economic impact of an ageing population. The proportion of the elderly population (defined as over the age of 67) is smaller than other European economies, but this share is expected to rise steadily, in step with trends across developed countries. Norway is expected to face some economic penalties stemming from an aging population, as the burden of caring for the elderly population is placed on a smaller proportion of employed workers. However, we do not expect these effects to hinder economic growth until after 2023. Nonetheless, demographic concerns have motivated significant policy action since 1990, with the creation of the Government Pension Fund Global, Norway's vast sovereign wealth fund, partially motivated by a need to fund expanded health and social spending to care for an ageing population.
Owing to Norway's unique geography, with a long coastline and separated settlements, rural areas are far more dispersed than in other European countries, raising the cost of services provision for isolated communities. This is aggravated by an increasingly concentrated population as a whole, with 81.9% of Norway's population living in urban areas. Areas in the far north of Norway are remote and underpopulated; Finnmark, the northernmost county, had a population of just 75,000 in 2014. The cost of maintaining public service provision in rural areas was a central driver behind the "municipal reform" proposed by the Conservative-led government in 2014.

Despite its high wealth, Norway small market size limits its influence
Despite being one of the richest countries in the world (by GDP per head), Norway's limited population size, of just over 5m, and the country's high operating costs limit the scale of market opportunities available. When ranking countries by nominal GDP per head, Norway is third highest in the world, at US$81,695, according to the IMF, ahead of the rest of the OECD excluding Luxembourg and Switzerland. Measured using a purchasing power parity (PPP) measure, Norway performs less well, positioned sixth, with a GDP per head of US$74,356. This is due to the country's higher price level and the correspondingly weaker purchasing power of the currency in Norway, reflecting higher costs for labour and transport. However, despite the country's wealth, its overall economic size remains fairly small, with nominal GDP at just US$435bn, according to the IMF. Although this is larger than Finland (US$275bn), output is slightly smaller than in Austria (US$460bn) and Sweden (US$547bn), demonstrating Norway's limited size relative to other global markets. The OECD estimated Norway's Gini coefficient at 0.262 in 2016, the fifth-lowest in the group of advanced economies (a Gini coefficient of zero represents perfect income equality and 100 displays total income inequality). This low score reflects the low level of inequality in Norway, ensured by relatively high levels of marginal taxation and the high levels of trust and co-operation within its society.
Norway's consumer goods market is similar to those of other Scandinavian countries, albeit larger than Denmark's and smaller than Sweden's. Private consumption accounted for about 44.9% of overall GDP in 2018. Consumption growth accelerated in the late 1990s until 2007, averaging 4.1% year on year from 1996-2007 and contributing an average of 1.5 percentage points to annual economic growth over the period. Since the financial crisis, consumption growth has fallen, averaging 2.5% in 2010-18. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects this slowdown to continue over the 2019-23 forecast period, to an average of 1.8%, as investment takes a larger role in output growth. Nevertheless, the fundamental components for growth in consumption are in place. Unemployment is low, price growth has been receding in recent releases, and nominal wages have started to accelerate. By 2023 we expect GDP per head to reach US$97,791 at market exchange rates and US$72,263 at PPP exchange rates.

Norway's consumer market is highly developed, with room for competition
As an advanced, mature economy, Norway's consumers are well equipped with most consumer durables, including white goods, television sets, personal computers and home entertainment equipment. Much of consumer demand will be driven by a need to improve or replace existing consumer durables, a process aided by technological innovation. The non-food market is relatively open to competition, with many small, medium-sized and niche players competing. As the extent of domestic manufacturing remains limited the bulk of consumer goods are imported. High labour costs are one of the few downsides to producing in Norway, at about EUR50 (US$56) per hour, the hourly labour costs are among the highest in Scandinavia and the second highest in Europe after Switzerland (which has an hourly cost of EUR53 per hour). Norway also imports many agricultural products, especially fruit and vegetables. Fish are mostly domestically produced, as Norway has established itself as a global exporter of seafood, especially salmon.
Norwegian consumer spending tends to be leisure-focused
Norwegians tend to spend a higher proportion of their total income on food than most other European populations, although we expect this figure to fall during the forecast period. In part, this will reflect high tariffs and taxes on food products, as well as limited competition within the food retail sector. A higher proportion of spending is directed towards leisure, including hotel stays and restaurants. The standard of living is generally high, with two out of ten households owning more than one car and a similar proportion owning a second (or holiday) home. Among the sociological trends that will have an impact on consumption patterns are a rise in single-person households and the gradual ageing of the population.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Stemming the trend for early retirement is a long-term government challenge
Initial conditions: Aided by its rich endowment of offshore oil and gas, Norway's growth has outperformed that of its European neighbours over the past decade, with growth averaging 1.2% in 2008-18, compared with a euro area average of 0.8%. With only 48% of its petroleum reserves extracted to date, the country will retain its pre-eminence in European energy production throughout The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term forecast period, to 2050. However, pressures on the oil and gas sector are expected to mount over the short term as production is curtailed by technical difficulties, and over the longer term as government policy becomes less accommodative. Although participation rates are already high, one long-term challenge for the government will be to reverse the trend among older workers to take early retirement. To this effect, the pension system is undergoing reform, including by reducing longevity risk through a pension adjustment linked to life expectancy, and will be fully implemented by 2025. Technological change has also accelerated Norway's growth in recent years, with the application of communication and information technology becoming more widespread since 2008 and supporting productivity growth. However, the tightness of the labour market could dampen productivity growth in the near term as skills shortages appear in some sectors. Further risk factors are a slowing pace of product market reforms and Norway's comparatively poor record of investing in research and development (R&D), which accounts for about only 2.1% of GDP, and lifelong learning.
Demographic trends: Norway, like many other OECD countries, faces a steadily ageing population, driven by both a socioeconomic trend towards a lower birth rate and a preference for marrying later that have been evident since the 1960s. However, in the Norwegian case these trends have been slower to materialise, and immigration is higher than in the country's European neighbours, so Norway is in a more favourable position to face the challenges of an ageing population relative to other developed countries. Owing to consistent inward migration from eastern Europe and a comparatively large share of young people in the population, Norway will maintain positive population growth throughout the forecast period (2019-23), although the rate of growth will fall from the 2020s onwards. The growth rate of the working-age population will also remain positive, but will ease from about 1% per year from 2000-18 to about 0.5% in 2019-50. Concurrently, the proportion of those aged 67 or above, and the old-age dependency ratio (those 67 and over relative to those aged 15-66) will increase, leading to greater fiscal pressure on the government, which provides old age services and transfers. Further rises in the participation rate (which is already among the highest in the world) or improvements to worker productivity will be needed to maintain the social safety net.
Even taking into account the flow of oil revenue, pension liabilities will greatly exceed the expected assets of the entire Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG, the sovereign wealth fund that was created to ensure that future generations would benefit from the country's oil riches). There is concern that current pension reforms do not go far enough in tackling the problems related to work incentives and the generous scale of public-sector pensions. The government will need to take further action over the coming decade to avoid a sharply rising tax burden from 2023.
Slower European growth will hinder Norway's trade position
External conditions: As a small country that is highly dependent on open markets and free trade, Norway stands to benefit from its European Economic Area (EEA) agreement, which extends the EU's single market to include it. The EU is the world's largest and most integrated regional market, and accounts for the vast majority of Norwegian exports and imports. Set against this, the EU's long-term rate of growth is likely to remain moderate. Another uncertainty over the forecast period concerns Norway's position with respect to the EU. Within the EU, although some progress will be made in further advancing trade in goods and the liberalisation of trade in services, the focus-particularly in the next decade-will be on ensuring that there is no reversal of these policies, and especially on trying to prevent the break-up of the euro zone and on preserving the single market. In this context the UK's withdrawal from the EU has the potential to be disruptive. Meanwhile the increase in protectionism seen since Donald Trump became US president poses a concern for such a small, open economy. Although some effort has gone into improving Norway-China economic relations, we expect returns from these activities to be confined to specific sectors, such as fish or oil exports, limiting their effectiveness.
The sovereign wealth fund may not be adequate to guarantee pension costs
Institutions and policy trends: Norway has a long democratic history and enjoys stable, democratic and transparent institutions, along with a well-entrenched justice system. Corruption is largely absent from Norwegian political and business life. The prospects for stable growth are enhanced by high levels of benefits and state-funded education, including at tertiary level, which ensures a healthy and well-educated workforce. In the long term, however, the welfare state may not be as well funded as it is currently. Norway favours free enterprise and market competition to a lesser extent than Denmark and Sweden. The state remains a significant player in many sectors, such as telecommunications, banking, energy and the offshore sector, and progress on the government's plan to reduce its stakes in some companies has been slow. Norway also lags neighbouring countries in efforts to promote com-petition in major product and labour markets, in part because the country's oil riches provide little incentive for policymakers to enact potentially unpopular structural reforms. Similarly, there is a risk that the existence of the GPFG will mask the need for reforms to the social security system. A pension reform in 2011 improved incentives to work beyond retirement age and cut the link between pension payments and wages; further adjustments are expected in the coming years. However, government projections indicate that the assets of the pension fund will be insufficient to cover the state's liabilities arising from pensions and other demands on the public purse (such as healthcare) in the absence of further reform of both the pension system and the labour market. Measures would have to include further discouragement from taking early retirement or drawing disability benefits. (The proportion of the workforce drawing disability benefit in Norway is almost double the average for the OECD.) Ensuring the sustainability of Norway's generous welfare state will be an important challenge for future governments.
Strong investment and productivity growth will raise long term output
Long-term performance: As Norway has less scope than most other developed economies to raise its labour force participation rate, its long-term economic prospects will depend on a continued high rate of investment, as well as improvements in productivity, which we expect to rise during the forecast period (to an average of 0.9% in 2017-50), having been sluggish for much of the past decade (at an average of 0.2% in 2007-16). Long-term economic performance will also depend on how successive governments meet the challenge of structural reform. Given the current large surpluses on the general government budget, it is often easy for policymakers to ignore non-oil budget deficits. A failure to adapt social security and welfare systems to the challenge of population ageing would lead to large fiscal deficits towards the end of the long-term forecast period, which would necessitate a rising tax burden and dampen growth. This would be exacerbated should oil production decrease markedly, making continued investment in exploration important.
