Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
The majority of Norway's emissions come from the exploitation of the country's oil and gas reserves, with aluminium production also contributing. Domestic energy usage, which is largely met through abundant hydro-electric infrastructure, is not an important contributor to Norway's carbon emissions, unlike in other advanced economies. The Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG, the sovereign wealth fund) has become more strident in its support of environmental concerns over the past few years. In 2016 two new criteria were established by the fund, making it move away from, firstly, companies with unacceptable greenhouse gas emissions and, secondly, companies for which at least 30% of revenue is derived from thermal coal, or operations based on thermal coal. In March 2019 the government established a further criterion forcing the fund to divest from upstream firms specialising in oil and gas exploration, although its holdings of generalised energy firms, including all major publicly traded oil producers, have remained.
Norway will be relatively sheltered from the impact of climate change. With a small agricultural sector and a mostly urban population, the country is easily protected from the results of a warming planet. According to The Economist Intelligence Unit's newly launched climate change model, Norway's GDP will only fall by about 1% by 2050, relative to a world without climate change. With the majority of economic output concentrated in the area around Oslo, the capital, and the coastal cities of Bergan, Stavanger and Trondheim, the protection of urban areas against rising sea levels and weather events will be central to Norway's strategy. The opening up of new areas for oil exploration in the Arctic Circle (as ice cover falls) will be an upside risk to Norwegian growth and should slightly mitigate the costs to output.
Despite efforts by successive governments to bolster environmental policy, a substantial effort to reduce oil-related activities is unlikely, with further reform only likely to limit the sector's growth, rather than reverse it. Aided by the economic need for further diversification, political pressure is mounting from smaller parties, like the Liberals and the Christian Democrats (both of which are central to the coalition's majority) and an environmental element within the Labour Party to curtail the oil sector's development. This division within parliament is likely to be reflected in a gradual erosion of the country's generous tax incentives for oil exploration over the long term.
Migration and urbanisation
Norway has largely adopted an accommodative policy towards migration since the late 1970s and the migrant population (including those of Norwegian birth, but with two parents born abroad) in 2017 was about 888,700, making up 16.8% of the country's total population. Immigration to Norway has risen steadily over the decades-in 1992 migrants totalled about 183,000 people (4.3% of Norway's population) and net migration was relatively small (9,100). Net migration steadily rose thereafter, peaking in 2012 as 48,700 people entered the country, before dropping to 27,800 in 2016. The bulk of these migrants came from eastern Europe after the region's transition into the EU in 2004, but there remains a significant portion of German and Swedish migrants in Norway (totalling about 60,900 in 2016). Recent migration has come from non-European countries such as Syria, Somalia and Eritrea. These migrants have proved more politically contentious, as greater differences in cultural background and socioeconomic status have led to concerns about integration-the far-right Progress Party (FrP) has now included the reduction of non-European migration as part of its policy agenda. Although the FrP is a member of the centre-right coalition government, we expect Norway's collaborative political system to result in moderate government policy and the country to retain an accommodative stance on matters of immigration and integration.
Norway's population has become more urbanised as the economy has developed. According to the World Bank, urbanisation rates surpassed 50% in 1960, rising rapidly over the next 20 years to 70.5% in 1980. Since then the pace of urban growth has been more subdued, with the rate only surpassing 80% in 2013, and reaching 82% 2017. Norway remains the most rural of the Scandinavian economies, with urbanisation rates in Sweden and Denmark slightly higher, at 87% and 88% respectively. This is in part due to Norway's large land area and long sea coast, making rural communities more isolated, but also because Norway was historically rural and underdeveloped compared with its Scandinavian peers, and so has further to catch up with its neighbours. The difficulties of paying for high standards of public service provision to an ageing and diminishing population in rural areas are putting pressure on the government to reduce costs. This was the motivation behind the "municipal reform" circulated in 2014 which will aggregate the municipal and county authorities together to encourage greater economies of scale and information-sharing in local government services.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The March 2018 general election produced a badly fragmented parliament. It also yielded a resounding victory for the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won about 33% of the vote, and the anti-immigration, Eurosceptic Lega, which secured about 17%. Following tortuous government formation talks, which almost ended inconclusively, at end-May the two parties agreed to form a government, led by Giuseppe Conte, an independent.
Mr Conte and his technocratic economy minister, Giovanni Tria, have experienced tensions with Matteo Salvini, the leader of the Lega, and Luigi Di Maio, the M5S leader, both of whom serve as deputy prime ministers. Mr Di Maio and Mr Salvini are the de facto political leaders of the government, which The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect to complete a five-year term, ending in 2023. Amid a slowing economy and a resounding victory at the European Parliament elections, we believe that Mr Salvini is likely to press for an early election in late 2019. The soonest feasible date for a snap election would be sometime in early 2020.
The government will continue to prioritise tougher stances on migration and more defiant positions on EU rules, as well as the disarming of so-called safeguard clauses in the country's fiscal framework that would raise indirect taxes from 2020 if other consolidation measures are not approved. The government is also implementing means-tested "citizenship income" and is planning a "growth decree" to support the economy.
Following a protracted dispute with the European Commission over its draft 2019 budget plan, the government narrowly avoided the launch of an excessive-deficit procedure in mid-December. Tensions are likely to ratchet up during the 2020 budget process, however, as the Lega is demanding the implementation of a costly "flat" income tax proposal, while the Commission believes that Italy is non-compliant with its rules on public debt reduction.
We expect Italian real GDP to stagnate in 2019, growing by just 0.1%. Risks to this forecast are balanced to the downside. This is likely to put this year's revised fiscal deficit target of 2.4% of GDP out of reach. Weaker economic growth and a wider deficit also mean that the government's goal of lowering the government debt/GDP ratio from 132.4% at end-2018 is unlikely to be achieved. Our core forecast for growth in 2020-23 is also weak, owing to slowing momentum both domestically and in the euro area. We forecast real GDP growth of 0.4% in 2020 and about 1.1% on average in 2021-23.

Italy's business environment score improves modestly in the 2019-23 forecast period. Reforms since 2012 have helped to raise the scores for foreign investment, financing and the labour market. Some of these will be reversed or diluted.
Country forecast overview: Italy's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Significant reforms to improve competition will not be a priority under the Conte administration.
2021-23: Improvements in competition policy will depend on stabilisation of the political environment.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Modest reductions in red tape. Government plans to charge penalties to foreign firms that collect state incentives and then relocate production to non-EU countries within five years of the incentivised investment.
2021-23: Organised crime, legal complexity and shortcomings in judicial system remain deterrents.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Quotas and tariffs are in line with EU practice. The Conte government could oppose new EU trade deals. EU focuses on EU-UK trade deal in Brexit negotiations, further bilateral free-trade deals and responding to US tariffs.
2021-23: An EU-US agreement will probably remain elusive. The risk of a euro area break-up, which could lead to capital controls, is low, although The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Greece to leave the bloc in the medium term.
Taxes
2019-20: Automatic rise in value-added tax (VAT) rate is averted in 2019, but implementation of two-rate "flat tax" is delayed owing to cost. Reduction in tax expenditure and some tax rises in order to finance costly social spending plans.
2021-23: Government seeks to implement a diluted corporate and income tax-reduction package.
Financing
2019-20: Bank mergers, recapitalisations and non-performing loan sales are slow, not least given political uncertainty.
2021-23: Banking sector exposure to the Italian sovereign will persist. Mergers of smaller co-operative banks and possible foreign takeovers accelerate, as does the sale of securitised bad loans. Profitability and credit provision remain weak.
The labour market
2019-20: Firms remain reluctant to increase open-ended contract payrolls. Universal unemployment benefit or "citizenship income" may be partly introduced. Some aspects of 2014-15 labour market reforms will be reversed.
2021-23: Decentralised private-sector productivity-related pay deals and changes to public-sector contracts face resistance.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Lack of fiscal space constrains government plans for higher investment spending.
2021-23: Infrastructure still lags that of other euro area countries, despite some new investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) presses for further digitalisation of public services. A preponderance of smaller and family-run firms, as well as high levels of corporate debt, keep research and development (R&D) spending low.
2021-23: Gradually improving economic prospects, as well as Brexit, encourage more information and communications technology graduates to seek work in Italy. Slight improvement in R&D and firm-level technology investment.

Background: Post-war Italy has been characterised by a weak political structure and, since the 1970s, a declining economic base. Between 1996 and 2011 Italy had a bipolar political system, dominated by a centre-right alliance and a centre-left coalition. Since 2011 the political landscape has become more fragmented, with the break-up of the centre right, the emergence of the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and a recent splintering of the centre left. Since the 2013 general election Italy has had three broad centre-left/centre-right governments. Matteo Renzi's resignation as prime minister after his flagship constitutional reform was rejected in a referendum in December 2016 led to the formation of a government led by Paolo Gentiloni, a close ally of Mr Renzi. Following the 2018 general election an M5S-Lega government was formed.
Political structure: Parliament, which comprises two houses with equal powers, is elected for a five-year term. In the event of a political crisis the president, who is elected by parliament for a seven-year term, decides whether to call an election or nominate a prime minister to try to form a government. The president also promulgates laws and may return a law to parliament for reconsideration, but has no power of veto. Executive power lies with the cabinet, which is nominated by the prime minister and approved by parliament. The prime minister cannot dismiss ministers without forming a new government. The legislative system remains unchanged following the rejection in the December 2016 referendum of a reform to reduce the powers of the Senate (the upper house). A new, predominantly proportional electoral system was adopted in October 2017.
Policy issues: The main issues are the management of, and attempts to reduce, Italy's large public debt (which stood at 132.2% of GDP in 2018), safeguarding the banking system and keeping Italy in the euro zone. In 2012 the government, led by Mario Monti, carried out a number of structural economic reforms to improve competitiveness. The process has since stalled, and the M5S-Lega government will seek to loosen fiscal policy, stimulate private consumption through tax cuts and income support to low earners, and seek to reverse or dilute recent pension and labour reforms.
Taxation: The top rate of personal income tax is 43%, and social security contributions are high, especially for employers. The corporation tax rate is 24%, reduced in 2017 from 27.5%, but additional regional and municipal taxes are levied, including the regional business tax (IRAP), to fund health services. The basic rate of IRAP is 3.5%, reduced from 3.9% in 2014. Income earned from most types of financial investment is taxed at 26%. The standard rate of value-added tax (VAT) is 22%.
Foreign trade: The value of exports of goods (fob) stood at US$537.5bn in 2018, and imports (fob) were worth US$481.9bn. In the same year the current account recorded a surplus of US$50.6bn, or 2.4% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Just a year into its five-year term, the coalition government composed of the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and the far-right Lega is showing signs of strain. The Economist Intelligence Unit's baseline forecast is that the cabinet will fracture in late 2019, probably over difficult negotiations on the 2020 budget law, leading to an early election in the first half of next year. At this contest we expect the Lega to win a commanding majority in parliament at the head of a right-wing coalition including the centre-right Forza Italia and the small, post-fascist Fratelli d'Italia.
The coalition-led by Giuseppe Conte, an independent law professor-came into office in the wake of the March 2018 general election, at which M5S won 33% of the vote and the Lega won 17%. Since then, however, the Lega has dominated the government under the leadership of Matteo Salvini, a deputy prime minister and minister of the interior, who has struck a chord with Italian voters with his round-talking speeches, adept use of social media and a policy agenda focused on security issues, Euroscepticism and combating illegal immigration.
Meanwhile M5S's popularity has ebbed steadily under the leadership of Luigi Di Maio, also a deputy prime minister and the labour and economic development minister. Following disappointing performances in a series of regional and local elections in 2018-19 M5S won just 17% of the vote at the European Parliament elections on May 26th, compared with the Lega's 34%. Mr Di Maio has since come under internal pressure and was forced to call an online vote among M5S members at end-May to reaffirm his authority.
As a result of their electoral rivalry, as well as disagreements over issues such as infrastructure projects and the tenure in government of two Lega officials linked to graft allegations, M5S and the Lega have clashed frequently in recent months. This led Mr Conte to issue an ultimatum to Mr Di Maio and Mr Salvini in early June, urging his deputies to put their quarrels aside or else accept his resignation.
Mr Conte will not step down in the near term, as the tone of political debate is likely to soften in the aftermath of the European Parliament vote, but negotiations on the 2020 budget may prove to be an insurmountable challenge. The budget law will draw intense scrutiny from the European Commission, which will press to open an excessive-deficit procedure against Italy for failing to reduce the public debt stock and demand a significant fiscal correction that the government is unwilling to deliver.
At the same time Mr Salvini has renewed his demands for a flat corporate and personal income tax rate of 15%, which would be unaffordable in the absence of deep spending cuts or rises in other forms of taxation. The government will also seek to disarm the so-called safeguard clauses written into the country's multi-year fiscal framework, which would raise the headline value-added tax (VAT) rate from an already high 22% to 25.2% if EUR23bn (1.3% of GDP) is not raised through spending cuts or other revenue sources. Against this backdrop, a combination of financial market pressures, electoral opportunism on Mr Salvini's behalf and political pressure from the EU institutions are expected to cause the administration to unravel, paving the way for a snap election in 2020.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The next parliamentary election is scheduled for early 2023, but we expect it to be held much sooner. Mr Salvini will probably try to capitalise on his party's gains in support by pulling the plug on the administration. Such a move would be an attempt to force the president, Sergio Mattarella, to call a snap general election if he cannot find an alternative governing majority in parliament.
The result of the European Parliament elections has raised the likelihood that such a break will happen late this year. When combined with the Lega's vote share of 34%, those of Forza Italia (9%) and Fratelli d'Italia (6%) come to about 50%, which would be likely to produce a commanding majority under Italy's voting law for general elections. This system, the so-called Rosatellum 2, allocates about a third of the seats in each house of parliament in single-member districts (SMDs) and about two-thirds by proportional representation.
It is possible that M5S and the centre-left, opposition Partito Democratico (PD), which has reclaimed its place as the second most popular party, surpassing M5S with a vote share of 23% at the European Parliament contest, will align in the event of a government crisis in order to avert an election over the near term that returns a right-wing government. However, the parliamentary maths would be difficult, particularly in the Senate (the upper house of parliament), and the two parties would struggle to justify such a move to their respective electorates.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
We expect Italy to remain a member of the EU and the euro zone during the 2019-23 forecast period. Other foreign policy mainstays-including a close relationship with the US and membership of NATO and the UN-will also stay in place. However, relations are likely to be strained. Mr Salvini has signalled a more confrontational stance towards other EU countries, taking a tough line on migration measures proposed at the European Council in June 2018. He has also protested against EU fiscal constraints and has already begun to posture with respect to Italy's plans for its 2020 budget.
Sino-Italian diplomatic relations will improve in the near term, following Italy's decision to sign in late March a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to participate in the Belt and Road Initiative, China's flagship global infrastructure integration plan. The MoU is unlikely to increase bilateral trade or investment flows significantly in 2019-23, but it will probably undermine EU attempts to find a common stance on China and complicate Italy's relations with other EU countries and the US.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The M5S-Lega administration has departed from the more orthodox policies of previous governments. With regard to the labour market, the administration passed the so-called Dignity Decree in July 2018, reversing parts of the 2015 Jobs Act, a liberalising labour market reform. In April 2019 the government implemented an expansionary pension reform, easing the conditions for early retirement.
One of the administration's other flagship policies, M5S's citizenship income, provides a monthly stipend or top-up of other benefits to EUR780 for poor pensioners and the unemployed. For working-age people, the citizenship income effectively functions like a means-tested jobseeker's allowance and has been paired with enhanced active labour market policies.
The government has also implemented a first step towards the Lega's promised 15% flat income tax, applying this rate to VAT-account holders earning up to EUR65,000 beginning in January 2019. Finally, the administration has also approved a new anti-corruption law, as well as a security decree containing a series of tougher policing and immigration measures, and a growth decree meant to jump-start business activity.
The coalition's anti-reformist rhetoric and its open resistance to EU fiscal rules have rattled the markets. The banking sector also remains weak and highly exposed to government debt, which totals EUR2.3trn. However, credit quality has improved rapidly in the past two years, owing to regulatory pressures from the European Central Bank (ECB) to reduce stocks of bad loans on banks' balance sheets, and the rescue and restructuring of several troubled lenders, including Carige, the country's tenth largest, and Monte dei Paschi di Siena, its third largest. The country's two systemically important entities, UniCredit and Intesa SanPaolo, are considerably healthier and more resilient to shocks.
Nonetheless, an abrupt uptick in market perceptions of political risk could still pose challenges to financial stability. During our forecast period (2019-223) we believe it unlikely that Italy will lose market access. However, owing to the sheer size of Italy's public debt stock and the fragility its banks, the economy would be too large to rescue without support from the ECB in the event of a large-scale crisis.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Following a budget shortfall of 2.1% of GDP in 2018, the government is currently targeting a deficit of 2.4% of GDP this year. Given weak nominal GDP growth and revenue prospects, and the distinct risk of higher outlays than expected, we believe that this objective is implausible and expect a budget shortfall of 2.9% of GDP in 2019. The 2020 budget process, which will begin with an update to the government's fiscal and economic projections in late September and the submission of a draft budgetary plan to the European Commission in mid-October, is likely to prove exceptionally difficult. The deficit is then expected to contract marginally, to 2.8% of GDP in 2020 and to an average of about 2.6% in 2021-23. Public debt, at 132.2% of GDP at end-2018, is expected to remain near this level for the next five years.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The ECB adopted an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy in response to the European sovereign debt crisis, bringing major policy interest rates down to zero or below; it also launched an asset-purchase programme that amounted to EUR2.6trn and came to an end in December 2018. Nevertheless, policy will remain ultra-loose in the forecast period, as the ECB will reinvest principal payments from maturing securities past the date on which it starts tightening. Euro zone inflationary pressures remain low, and there are pronounced downside risks to the euro zone's economic outlook. As a result, we believe that the ECB will be reluctant to lift its deposit rate until June 2020. An increase in the main refinancing rate should follow in December 2020. At its last meeting, on April 10th, the ECB signalled that it was considering introducing a tiered deposit system, under which a portion of deposits at the central bank would be exempted from the deposit rate, which is currently -0.4%. The ECB's recent communication aims to show that it can hold rates at record-low levels for longer, or even cut them further later this year if necessary. Policy tightening should proceed at a gradual pace from 2021. Risks to our outlook stem from the nomination of a new ECB president in late 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
In full-year 2018 real GDP expanded by 0.7%, down from 1.8% in 2017. Momentum was weak going into 2019, dampened by domestic political and economic uncertainty, as well as global trade tensions. In January-March 2019 the economy expanded by a downwardly revised 0.1% (compared with the previous three months). This followed two consecutive quarters of negative growth, which resulted in a first-quarter contraction of 0.1% year on year. We expect that the economy will expand by a marginal 0.1% in full-year 2019, on the back of slower growth in private consumption and fixed investment, and less favourable external conditions. High-frequency indicators for the first half of 2019 paint a mixed picture, suggesting that the recovery from recession is fragile and could falter in the coming quarters.
Economic growth will remain subdued in 2020, at 0.4%. In that year the building effects of the US-led global trade dispute, and a business-cycle slowdown in the world's largest economy, will weigh on the external sector and dampen sentiment. Growth should then pick up to an average of about 1.1% per year in real terms in 2021-23 as domestic and global demand recovers.
The boost to real household disposable income from recent tax cuts has faded, with real private consumption-accounting for about 60% of GDP-growing only modestly, by 0.6% in full-year 2018. Consumer spending also weakened as a result of heightened volatility in financial markets in the final two quarters of 2018, which weighed on consumer confidence, and it may do the same in the second half of this year as political tensions within the government and with the EU institutions mount. We expect a stagnant labour market, modest wage growth and waning consumer confidence to continue to constrain household spending in 2019. After meagre expansions of 0.4% per year on average in 2019-20, we forecast that consumer spending will rise to 1.1% per year in 2021-23 as domestic sentiment improves.
Public consumption rose by 0.2% in 2018, and we expect looser spending controls and limited fiscal stimulus efforts to result in a slight uptick in 2019-23. It will remain modest, however, at an annual average rate of 0.5% throughout this period. The current administration's looser stance towards deficit spending will raise the risk of higher levels of government consumption.
Fixed investment expanded for the fourth consecutive year in 2018, but was still more than one-fifth below its 2007 pre-crisis level. It rose by 3.2% in real terms last year, driven by transport equipment spending in the first half of the year, as well as a slow recovery in construction. In 2019-20 investment growth will slow significantly, to an annual average of 1.2%, held back by the expiration of tax incentives, policy uncertainty and declining sentiment, as well as public capital spending constraints, still impaired credit channels and relatively high levels of corporate debt.
The pace of export growth decreased markedly in 2018, to 1.4%. Export growth is expected to remain weak in 2019-20, owing in particular to lower growth in EU markets and global trade tensions, before picking up thereafter. Anaemic domestic demand growth and external demand constraints will also constrain import growth to less than 2% in 2019-22, before stronger export performance and healthier domestic demand lead to firmer expansion in 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Consumer price inflation remained subdued in 2018, at 1.2%, as a 0.2% decline in core inflation (headline inflation excluding volatile food and energy prices) more than offset inflationary pressures coming from a 30.7% increase in international oil prices and a rise in global food prices for the first time in seven years.
In 2019 consumer price growth should slow further, to 0.9%, owing to cheaper average global energy prices and still considerable slack in the labour market, meaning that upward pressure on prices from capacity constraints will not materialise in the near term. A positive demand shock from fiscal policy-for instance, as a result of the government's means-tested citizenship income or its expansionary pension reform-also looks unlikely. In 2020 headline inflation should increase slightly, driven by a forecast 4.8% increase in global food prices, which will offset downward pressures coming from declining global energy prices. From 2020 inflation should recover gradually, to average 1.4% in 2021-23 as global energy prices pick up.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
The euro rallied in late 2017 on the back of the region's economic recovery and rising expectations of quantitative easing tapering. However, since peaking at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in February 2018, the euro has depreciated against the dollar, in part owing to monetary tightening in the US last year. Since the start of 2019 the euro has weakened further, hovering around US$1.12:EUR1-US$1.14:EUR1, as high-frequency data and soft indicators have continued to disappoint market expectations and point to a weaker euro zone outlook. We expect the euro to remain broadly stable throughout the year, reflecting investors' concerns about Brexit and a further deterioration in US-EU trade relations. After averaging US$1.13:EUR1 in 2019, the euro should pick up more substantially in 2020, to US$1.18:EUR1, as these risks abate, momentum in the euro zone recovers and the ECB takes steps to tighten policy. The currency will rebound further in 2021-23, to US$1.23:EUR1, underpinned by the euro zone's large current-account surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
In 2018 the current account remained firmly in surplus, at 2.4% of GDP. We expect it to average 1.5% in 2019-23. This decline reflects considerably slower growth in export revenue until 2021, in line with slower global demand. Higher international energy prices in 2021-23 will have a negative effect on the trade balance in those years (Italy is a major energy importer).

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
After being badly defeated in the European Parliament and local elections on May 26th 2019, the ruling Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), led by the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, has called a pre-term general election-scheduled to be held on July 7th. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the main opposition party, the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, will win the election and could secure a clear parliamentary majority without the need for the support of another party.
We expect the next government to face formidable challenges: ND has pledged, if elected, to renegotiate the Macedonia name-change deal, and the Syriza government will leave to its successor the task of correcting fiscal slippage-having loosened fiscal policy in the run-up to the May 26th elections-and of reversing backsliding on structural reforms. Failure to make progress could lead to renewed tensions with Greece's EU creditors.
Greece will remain subject to strict policy conditionality in the medium term, until its debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests are likely to continue as the government strives to meet ambitious annual primary surplus budget targets of 3.5% of GDP until 2022 and 2.2% from 2023, as agreed with Greece's international creditors.
Greece is facing its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it has exited the bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. However, it will not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments until the end of 2020. A Greek exit from the euro zone represents a risk over the long term.
After expanding by 1.9% in 2018, we expect real GDP growth to reach 1.8% in 2019 and 2020, and an annual average of 2% in 2021-23. Meeting large primary budget surplus targets and restoring competitiveness will prove to be difficult. Public debt is forecast to be still high, at about 175% of GDP in 2023.
Inflation (EU harmonised) will remain subdued, rising slightly-from 0.8% in 2018 to 1.1% in 2019 and 2020-reflecting moderate domestic demand growth and weaker global energy prices. In 2021-23 we expect oil prices to rise, bringing inflation to 1.5% per year. We expect narrow current-account deficits in 2019-23 (the forecast period), compared with an annual average of 7.1% of GDP since 2001.

Greece's business environment will improve moderately in the forecast period, with progress in almost all categories, apart from political stability. However, Greece will remain subject to sub-optimal fiscal and other policy conditions, which will constrain real GDP growth and keep Greece's debt burden high.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The country's privatisation agency (under new management) gains momentum, unblocking some delayed deals.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make modest progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Remaining capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eliminated. Capital buffer of about EUR26bn sufficient to cover almost two years of the government's medium- and long-term financing needs.
2021-23: There is a significant risk of Greece leaving the euro zone in the long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result in the reintroduction of foreign-exchange controls and possibly restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Pressure to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) intensifies. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: The need to increase provisions for still high NPLs hampers lending. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Technical assistance from the EU helps absorption of European funds to revive infrastructure investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of the EMU into question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 debt crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages, totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 28% (29% in 2018) and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR32.4bn and imports (fob) amounted to EUR54.9bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR5.3bn, equivalent to an estimated 2.9% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
At the European Parliament, regional and municipal elections on May 26th 2019 the ruling Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), led by the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, suffered a heavy defeat at the hands of the main opposition party, the centre-right New Democracy (ND). The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that the resulting pre-term general election, scheduled to be held on July 7th, will result in a win for ND and a change of government.
Since early January 2019 Mr Tsipras's government has not had a stable majority in parliament, following the withdrawal of the small, right-wing, nationalist Independent Greeks (AE) from the ruling coalition in protest to the government's agreement with Macedonia to change that country's name to the Republic of North Macedonia, which the Greek parliament ratified on January 25th. In August 2018, after eight years of austerity and unpopular reforms under three economic adjustment programmes, Greece exited the third bail-out programme, signed by the Syriza-led government in 2015. During his time in power, since 2015, Mr Tsipras has lost much popular support and has failed to revive his party's political fortunes, despite loosening fiscal policy in the run-up to the May 26th elections.
Political instability has intensified ahead of the next general election owing to the Macedonia name-change deal, which is opposed by a majority of Greeks. This instability has deepened political polarisation in the country, hampered government effectiveness and weakened commitment to political and economic reform. We remain sceptical that real GDP growth will rise to much more than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period, hindering the next government's ability to reduce Greece's public debt of more than 180% of GDP to a more sustainable level. The next government will also be left the task of correcting recent fiscal slippage and backsliding on some structural reforms, which could lead to renewed tensions with Greece's EU creditors.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
In the European Parliament elections, Syriza trailed ND, led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, by about 9.5 percentage points, winning about 24% of the vote-in line with recent polls and more than 10 percentage points less than the party received in the September 2015 general election. We therefore continue to expect ND to win the general election on July 7th. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, this will be offset by widespread popular disaffection with the Syriza government, which has increased owing to the Macedonia name-change deal and divisions within Syriza. If, as we expect, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Based on the result of the European Parliament elections, ND's chances of securing a clear majority in parliament without the support of another party have improved.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political instability, as well as protracted economic and financial crises, have limited Greece's influence in the EU and in the Balkans. Recent government efforts to restore influence on the international scene, including the Macedonia name-change deal and talks on closer co-operation with the US, are fraught with difficulty, as domestic pre-election tension is likely to condition foreign policy decisions. Ratification of the name-change agreement aims to end Greece's opposition to Macedonia's accession to NATO and its application for EU membership, but the leader of ND has said that, if elected, his government would seek to renegotiate the deal.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey will persist. However, we believe that both sides will seek to prevent their historical enmity from escalating into military hostility. Points of contention include long-standing territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey. Turkey's release in August 2018 of two Greek soldiers arrested in March of that year while on patrol in the border area of Evros has eased tensions slightly.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
With a general election looming in 2019, the Syriza government opted to exit Greece's third economic adjustment programme in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line. In June 2018 Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released in August. Of this, EUR3.3bn was earmarked for early repayment of a more expensive tranche of IMF debt-due to be completed in July 2019-and the balance to create a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR26bn, should be sufficient to cover the country's financing needs to end-2020. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
However, the government will still be subject to severe policy constraints during the forecast period and beyond, until its huge government debt is substantially reduced. General government debt was about 182% of GDP at end-2018, and also predominantly owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), making another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, highly unlikely. Economic policy and performance will be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries.
The implementation of further debt-relief measures also agreed with Greece's EU creditors in June 2018 will be conditional on quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments, the most pressing of which include tackling Greek banks' heavy burden of non-performing loans, reviving the government's privatisation programme, removing remaining capital controls and clearing state arrears to the private sector. Greece has also committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses (budget balance minus interest payments) of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter, until 2060. As the quarterly reviews will be published (the most recent was released on February 27th 2019 and updated on April 4th), transgression by Greece could adversely affect market access. The debt-relief measures include a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). Greece will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for EUR130.9bn worth of loans), and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprises the official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of the return is estimated to be about EUR5bn in total in 2019-22.
In the short term Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing requirements, but it will need to have re-established itself in the debt markets before its cash buffer runs out. After a three-year absence Greece has tapped the financial markets five times since July 2017, most recently in early March 2019 with a well-subscribed ten-year issue, yielding 3.9%. The spread on the secondary market between Greek ten-year government bonds and equivalent German government bonds has narrowed steadily in recent months, but it remains large, at about 335 basis points in late May. Amid rising domestic political instability, as well as global economic and financial uncertainty, further bond issuance will be challenging.
In the medium and long term, the political and-arguably-the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past four years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, as will other negative factors such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short- or medium-term risk; however, given that Greece is unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or to grow its way out of its huge debt burden, Grexit will represent a possibility in the long term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
After almost a decade of austerity Greece recorded an overall budget surplus of 1.1% of GDP and a primary surplus of close to 4.5% in 2018, exceeding the bail-out programme target of 3.5%. From 2019, however, we expect fiscal performance to deteriorate gradually, with the budget balance returning to moderately widening headline deficits from 2020 and primary surpluses falling short of the official target of 3.5% of GDP for 2018-22, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint ahead of the next general election and only moderate economic growth. There is also uncertainty about the application of the Council of State's ruling that previous pension and bonus cuts implemented in 2016 were unconstitutional, raising the risk of retroactive payments. Although the primary surplus target will decline to 2.2% of GDP from 2023, it will still be difficult to achieve.
The restructuring of government debt owed to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-18 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will still be about 175% at the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The European Central Bank (ECB) adopted an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy in response to the European sovereign debt crisis, bringing major policy interest rates down to zero or below. It also launched an asset-purchase programme that amounted to EUR2.6trn and came to an end in December 2018. Nevertheless, policy will remain ultra-loose in the forecast period, as the ECB will reinvest principal payments from maturing securities past the date on which it starts tightening. Euro zone inflationary pressures remain low, and there are pronounced downside risks to the euro zone's economic outlook. As a result, we believe that the ECB will be reluctant to lift its deposit rate until June 2020. An increase in the main refinancing rate should follow in December 2020. At its last meeting, on April 10th 2019, the ECB signalled that it was considering introducing a tiered deposit system, under which a portion of deposits at the central bank would be exempted from the deposit rate, which is currently -0.4%. The ECB's recent communication aims to show that it can hold rates at record-low levels for longer, or even cut them further later this year if necessary. Policy tightening should proceed at a gradual pace from 2021. Risks to our outlook stem from the nomination of a new ECB president in late 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The Greek economy is recovering from a protracted slump, but the recovery is modest and vulnerable to domestic, and external, developments. As at 2018 real GDP was still more than 25% less than pre-crisis levels; meanwhile government consumption remained almost a quarter lower, household consumption one-fifth lower and gross fixed investment almost two-thirds lower. Real GDP accelerated from 1.4% in 2017 to 1.9% in 2018, but the economy lost momentum in the final three months of last year, contracting by 0.1% on a quarter-on-quarter basis. We expect real GDP growth to remain constrained, at 1.8% in 2019 and 2020, and at an annual average of about 2% in 2021-23. The risks to our forecast are balanced: upside risks include continued strong tourism performance if capacity constraints are addressed and competitiveness gains are not eroded; downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
A combination of more-and higher-taxes, larger social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts will continue to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2019-23, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by large primary surplus targets (of 3.5% of GDP per year up to 2022 and 2.2% in 2023), continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
Quarterly gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years, but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17, albeit from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by an average of 12% year on year in 2018. We expect a pick-up from this year, to an annual average of 5.2% in 2019-23. Underinvestment during the economic crisis and the depletion of Greece's capital stock are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively small, uncompetitive goods exports. In the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of 4.5% in 2019-23, down from 8.8% in 2018. However, the Greek tourism sector faces considerable challenges, including the UK's planned departure from the EU, increased competition from Turkey and insufficient public investment.
How the economy performs in the next five years (and beyond) will determine whether the country remains in the euro zone. Although the risk of Grexit has abated since the height of the financial crisis, we believe that there is a risk that Greece will exit the euro zone in the long term, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Greece's exit from the euro zone (not our core scenario) would lead to a sovereign default and severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then recover, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack in the labour market, subdued domestic demand and sharp decreases in global oil prices in the final quarter of 2018 will dampen inflationary pressures. We expect inflation to rise modestly, from an average of 0.8% in 2018 to an annual average of 1.1% per year in 2019-20 and 1.5% per year in 2021-23 as domestic demand growth accelerates.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
The euro rallied in late 2017 on the back of the region's economic recovery and rising expectations of quantitative easing tapering. However, since peaking at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in February 2018, the euro has depreciated against the dollar, in part owing to monetary tightening in the US last year. Since the start of 2019 the euro has weakened further, hovering around US$1.12:EUR1-US$1.14:EUR1, as high-frequency data and soft indicators continue to disappoint market expectations and point to a weaker euro zone outlook. We expect the euro to remain broadly stable throughout the year, reflecting investors' concerns about Brexit and a further deterioration in US-EU trade relations. After averaging US$1.13:EUR1 in 2019, the euro should pick up more substantially in 2020, to US$1.18:EUR1, as these risks abate, momentum in the euro zone recovers and the ECB takes steps to tighten policy. The currency will rebound further in 2021-23, to an average of US$1.23:EUR, underpinned by the euro zone's large current-account surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The economic crisis helped to reduce Greece's current-account deficit, which shrank primarily as a result of a compression of imports owing to contracting domestic demand, but also partly because of improved competitiveness, particularly in the tourism sector. We expect continued deficits in 2019-23 as import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand and as global energy prices rise moderately in the second half of the forecast period. However, these deficits will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.1% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP).
Mr Erdogan's re-election concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan to remain in power until 2023, and probably beyond. The concentration of power under Mr Erdogan and his party's control of parliament suggest that policy will retain an element of unpredictability.
Domestic and regional political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional, rather than strategic.
The currency crisis in 2018 pushed the Turkish economy into a recession in the second half of 2018, which we expect to have continued in the first quarter of 2019, resulting in a full-year real GDP contraction of 1.7% in 2019 on average (mainly owing to base effects), followed by annual average growth of 3.7% per year in 2020-23.
The currency crisis and recession will put pressure on the government's finances, business sector solvency and banks' balance sheets. In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy (concerns about off-balance sheet trends will persist). This, and a recovering economy, will cause the budget deficit to narrow, from a forecast 2.3% in 2019 to 1.7% of GDP in 2023.
The total population is projected to rise from an estimated 81.9m in 2018 to 85.4m in 2023, with the female population continuing to far outnumber the male population. The total population is expected to grow by 0.8% per year during the 2019-23 forecast period, compared with growth of 1.6% in the historical period (2014-18).
The large consumer market is one of Turkey's main attractions as a place to do business. The population is young, growing and inclined to consume rather than save, and average incomes are rising steadily in local-currency terms. We expect GDP per head to rise from US$9,333 at market exchange rates in 2018 to about US$11,700 in 2023.

Our business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period (2019-23), and its global ranking falls by 11 places, to 59th. Political tensions, increased powers concentrated under the president, inadequate policy responses to tighter global liquidity conditions and higher domestic inflation have raised the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy.
Country forecast overview: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals.
2021-23: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2021-23: Further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors boost FDI inflows.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls are not considered, despite the scale of the currency collapse in 2018-19. Political tensions resulting in tit-for-tat tariffs and US sanctions will disrupt Turkish-US trade and relations.
2021-23: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2019-20: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2021-23: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced, but evasion remains widespread.
Financing
2019-20: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018-19. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of the US imposing fines or sanctions on some Turkish banks.
2021-23: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2019-20: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Mismatches between education and labour market needs persist.
2021-23: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2021-23: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2021-23: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 1949 and NATO in 1952, and signed an association agreement with the then European Community in 1963. A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate was raised from 20% to 22% in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports totalled US$175bn and imports about US$217bn, creating a trade deficit of about US$41.9bn and a current-account deficit in the region of US$27.1bn (or 3.5% of GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".
