Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair; opposition candidates received little or no media coverage, the pro-Kurdish Peoples' Democratic Party (HDP) candidate, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison, and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote after a high turnout. Results published by opposition observers were similar to those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023, and probably beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to restrict political dissent and stifle the opposition. Despite allowing the state of emergency to expire on July 18th 2018, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent barriers on freedoms.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and Islamic State (IS). Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. The fact that the ruling coalition is made up of the AKP and the MHP will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the nationalist-minded MHP is pushing for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held in June 2018 (they had originally been scheduled for late 2019). Mr Erdogan was re-elected president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote on a turnout of 86.2%. In the parliamentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP), as the HDP managed to win more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament.
Local elections took place on March 31st 2019. The AKP and the MHP retained a majority of the national vote. However, in the midst of an economic recession the ruling parties lost vital cities such as Ankara, the capital, and Istanbul, the largest city. Losing major cities is a blow to the AKP given the public resources that the cities command. However, Mr Erdogan's tight grip on national institutions and the media means that he will continue to dominate Turkish politics in the coming years. In Istanbul a rerun of the election will be held on June 23rd after the Supreme Election Council (YSK) invalidated the results. Available polls point to another victory for Ekrem Imamoglu, of the main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP). However, despite his apparent advantage, we expect that the AKP, having placed large pressure on the YSK to annul the vote, will do whatever is necessary and obtain a victory.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic, and transactional, rather than strategic. We do not expect a collapse in relations, but this forecast is highly uncertain. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup, US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups, Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran, and US sanctions on Turkish officials owing to Turkey's detention of Andrew Brunson, a US pastor, on terrorism charges (sanctions were lifted after Mr Brunson was released in October 2018). In 2019 relations with the US will continue to be tested owing to Turkey's decision to purchase the Russian-made S-400 missile defence system. The US and NATO believe that the Russian-made S-400 system can gather sensitive information on NATO equipment and-in particular-the F-35 stealth fighter jet. The incompatibility of the S-400 with NATO systems is a further issue.
We believe that Turkey will not bow to US pressure, and will proceed with the delivery of the S-400 air defence missiles; Turkey considers this as a sovereign issue, and is keen to show that it does not concede to US demands. Backing down would also have a negative effect on Turkey's relations with Russia, a significant ally of neighbouring Syria. Russia props up the regime of Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president, and maintains a large military presence in the country. Thus, a deterioration in relations could jeopardise Turkey's control of territory across the border region, from the Mediterranean to the Euphrates River-territory that was gained to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK along the border. It could also limit Turkey's influence in Idlib, a city in northern Syria, which is controlled by Islamist rebel groups. In September 2018 Turkey, Russia and Iran reached an agreement to forestall a regime offensive against Idlib. Such an attack could result in another surge of refugee flows into Turkey.
The US will have to respond to what it considers as aggressive behaviour from Turkey, probably through sanctions on Turkish individuals. However, the US will stop short of imposing damaging sectoral sanctions on Turkey for fear of pushing the country towards Russia and Iran. Turkey's participation in the F-35 programme, and the planned delivery of 100 F-35 jets to Turkey, will be frozen to allow both sides to negotiate quietly. Both sides have an incentive to reach an agreement on the F-35 jets: Turkey's threatened exclusion from the F-35 project would delay the whole programme, and the cancellation of the delivery of 100 F-35 would represent a setback for Turkey.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business, and investment, climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised banking sector, and its dynamic and diversified private sector. We expect the currency crisis in 2018 and the ensuing recession to put severe pressure on the government's finances, business sector solvency and banks' balance sheets.
With the March 2019 local elections completed, the rerun of the Istanbul poll scheduled for June, and the next parliamentary and presidential elections not due until mid-2023, the government will soon be in a position to defuse domestic political tensions and take a more long-term approach to policymaking. This would help to revive investor confidence and foster sustainable economic growth, reversing the pattern of the past three years of ad hoc policy measures, which boosted the economy, but exacerbated Turkey's macroeconomic imbalances and diminished the government's credibility. However, an element of unpredictability and unorthodoxy will remain. The economy is in recession and-following its recent poor performance in local elections-the AKP will continue to feel under pressure to support growth. Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mismatches (a major factor behind the high unemployment rate) and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed in the 2019-23 forecast period.
Should the recent currency crisis trigger a banking crisis (not our core forecast), Turkey's options would remain limited, as Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries appear unwilling to offer financial support. This is because Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, a country with which Saudi Arabia has tense relations. Turkey's ties with Saudi Arabia deteriorated (from an already low base) after Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist, was murdered in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul in October 2018. Furthermore, any potential IMF programme would include a level of foreign involvement that the government would be likely to view as unacceptable, and that would run counter to Mr Erdogan's nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric. Only China appears able at present to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey (perhaps as part of China's Belt and Road Initiative).
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
Under the AKP, public finances have been one of the Turkish economy's most reassuring aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past.
Despite several tax increases in 2018 and official promises of budgetary tightening, higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits caused the budget deficit to widen in 2018, to 2% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017.
In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy (concerns about off-balance-sheet trends will persist). This, alongside a recovering economy, will cause the deficit to narrow gradually, from a forecast 2.3% of GDP in 2019 to 1.7% in 2023.
The central government debt/GDP ratio deteriorated slightly in 2018, rising to 28.9% of GDP in 2018 (from 28.3% in 2017), in the context of economic turmoil after the August currency crisis and various government handouts ahead of the June 2018 elections. The ratio will decline slightly, to about 26.5% by end-2023 as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
In September 2018 the Central Bank of Turkey's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) raised its main policy rate, the one-week repo (repurchase agreement) lending rate, to 24%, from 17.75% previously. The MPC's decision was a response to the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August, as well as the record rise in annual consumer price inflation.
At its meeting on April 25th the MPC kept its one-week repo lending rate unchanged, at 24%. We expect the central bank to keep monetary policy tight in the first half of 2019. From mid-2019 to 2020 the central bank will lower gradually its policy rate in response to declining inflationary pressures and a normalisation of financial market conditions. In 2021-23 we believe that the central bank will continue to overshoot its inflation target of 5%. This reflects the government's continued pro-growth stance; it will put pressure on the central bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to lower inflation to the 5% target.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand caused real GDP growth to accelerate to 7.3% in 2017 (from 3.3% in 2016), but this surge exacerbated internal and external imbalances. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short-term capital inflows, tighter global liquidity and a diplomatic spat with the US-contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar in January-August 2018. The sharp depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of large foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dented the economic outlook. The crisis pushed the Turkish economy into recession in the second half of 2018, which we expect to continue in the first quarter of 2019, resulting in a contraction in full-year real GDP of 1.7% in 2019 on average (mainly owing to base effects), followed by annual average growth of 3.7% per year in 2020-23.
In 2020 we expect growth to rebound to 4.1% as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-23 economic growth will average about 3.6% per year. There are substantial downside risks to our forecasts: these growth profiles do not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
In full-year 2018 the currency crisis and rising global commodity prices drove inflation higher, to 16.3% (from 11.1% in 2017). In 2019 inflation will remain elevated in the first half of the year and then moderate gradually on the back of the appreciation of the lira in the second half of 2019, a lower average global oil price and the emergence of spare capacity in the economy. Accommodative fiscal policies in response to the economic weakness in the final months of 2018 will prevent inflation from declining faster than would otherwise be the case. On average, we forecast inflation of 16.1% in 2019-only marginally slower than the 2018 rate-slowing to 6.9% in 2023.
We expect inflation to decelerate rapidly in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 10.2% as global oil prices continue to decline (owing to a slowdown in the global economy) and the exchange rate depreciates slightly (in nominal terms) against the US dollar. In 2021-23 we expect inflation to stabilise at an annual average of about 7.2%-still more than the central bank's medium-term target of 5%. Economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures).
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
In 2018 the lira depreciated by 24.5% on average against the US dollar (in nominal terms). The lira depreciated significantly in January-August, with the exchange rate briefly reaching a low point of TL7.2:US$1 on August 13th. After a substantial recovery from September, the lira remained broadly stable against the US dollar for the remainder of 2018. In the first months of 2019 the lira has again depreciated against the US dollar owing to political uncertainty and polarising campaign rhetoric around the March local elections, declining central bank foreign-exchange reserves, the re-emergence of tensions with the US and the rerun of the Istanbul mayoral race following the AKP's defeat.
The lira again surpassed TL6:US$1 in early May, and we expect a gradual appreciation from this level in the second half of the year and a year-end exchange rate of about TL:5.70:US$1. This forecast rests on our expectation that the Turkey-US dispute will not result in damaging sectoral sanctions, but-at most-only in individual sanctions, that government policy will be credibly reoriented and that the central bank will maintain a tight monetary policy stance, lowering interest rates only as price pressures fade. There are large risks to this forecast, both in terms of probability and impact. If any of our expectations do not materialise, the lira could again depreciate substantially.
In 2020 we expect the exchange rate to depreciate as the current-account deficit widens and as central banks in advanced economies re-embark on a path of monetary policy tightening. Thereafter still elevated inflation and a significant current-account deficit (although not as wide as in 2017) will result in a gradual depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in nominal terms, to near TL6.4:US$1 by end-2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
We expect the current-account deficit to narrow as a share of GDP in 2019, to 0.7% (a 16-year low), from 3.5% in 2018 and 5.6% in 2017, as the lira's depreciation against the US dollar and the euro depresses imports (owing to a decline in domestic demand) and boosts export competitiveness. From 2020 we expect the deficit to widen gradually, to a still relatively moderate 3.4% per year on average in 2020-23. The narrower deficits compared with historical levels reflect significant gains in competitiveness from the 2018-19 currency crisis that will boost exports and limit import growth throughout the medium term.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
Global data
OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP growth and components: Turkstat
Population: UN Population database and Economist Intelligence Unit interpolation
Consumer prices: IMF, IFS; Turkstat
Industrial production: derived from OECD, Main Economic Indicators
Exchange rates and interest rates: IMF, IFS
External trade and balance of payments: IMF, IFS; Central Bank of Turkey; Turkstat
Central government financial balance: IMF, IFS; Turkish Treasury
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report; Central Bank of Turkey
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
Turkstat: Turkish Statistical Institute
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Country Forecast Venezuela May 2019

https://www.proquest.com/reports/country-forecast-venezuela-may-2019/docview/2246877332/se-2?accountid=14357

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://VS2GA4MQ9G.search.serialssolutions.com?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Apoliticalscience&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.atitle=Country+Forecast+Venezuela+May+2019&amp;rft.au=&amp;rft.aulast=&amp;rft.aufirst=&amp;rft.date=2019-05-01&amp;rft.volume=&amp;rft.issue=&amp;rft.spage=&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Country+Forecast.+Venezuela&amp;rft.issn=09669574&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Venezuela--highlights: Political outlook
The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts a transitional national unity government emerging this year. Reduced production capacity at the state oil firm, PDVSA, and the imposition of US sanctions amid the political crisis will put pressure on the patronage flows that support the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) government, led by Nicolás Maduro, leading to cracks in the regime and opening the door to a transition government led by Juan Guaidó, the leader of the opposition-controlled National Assembly (and self-declared interim president), and pragmatic members of the PSUV regime. However, such an administration and its successor would face considerable hurdles and substantial challenges to stability, as its attempts to correct the current severe macroeconomic distortions will affect entrenched interests. We expect the process to be chaotic and likely to feature several false starts. The possibilities of a prolonged period of chaos, an outright military dictatorship or a military-heavy government fronted by civilians remain potential outcomes.
Venezuela--highlights: Business environment outlook

Venezuela ranks as the least attractive location of the 82 countries covered in our rankings in 2019-23. Even though we anticipate a change of government early on in the forecast period, the depth of the economic crisis and years of deterioration across all areas of the investment climate will take time to address. Official policy will become slowly more welcoming to foreign investment, but until the economy stabilises, access to foreign exchange improves and institutions are overhauled, we do not expect fundamental improvements in the operating conditions for foreign businesses.

A combination of highly distortionary economic policies and subdued global oil prices will prolong Venezuela's recession in 2019-20. Large budget deficits-due to a narrow revenue base and dropping oil production-will continue to spur money printing, driving inflation. Oversupply of local currency, limited exports and foreign-exchange controls will fuel a black market for foreign currency despite continued devaluations of the official exchange rate. Our forecasts for 2021-23 are more positive, based on the benign assumption that substantial international financial assistance will help a pragmatist administration to stabilise the economy, but fiscal deficits will remain large (given the pressures of economic stabilisation) and the public debt burden will accelerate rapidly.

Amid the political and economic crisis, Venezuela's population has declined in recent years owing to outmigration, with some 3.7m Venezuelans estimated to have left since 2014; this has resulted in population growth declines in 2014-18. We forecast that only a small percentage of those who left will return, with population growth now occurring through natural growth. Given that many of the refugees and migrants will have been of working age, this will result in a higher old-age dependency ratio. This ratio will remain low by developed-country standards, but population ageing will place growing pressure on the heavily indebted social security system in a context of volatile public finances.

Years of economic crisis and hyperinflation have decimated the Venezuelan economy; in real terms it is now almost 60% smaller than it was in 2013. Our forecasts for recovery do not envision any rapid recovery under the subsequent government. The economic crisis and falling real incomes will continue to restrict purchasing power. Although Venezuela is generously endowed with natural resources, extremely challenging conditions will keep private-sector investment well below potential.
Venezuela--highlights: Long-term outlook

Assuming a political transition in 2019 that will lift economic distortions and improve the business environment, we expect that Venezuela's economy will begin to recover. But the damage inflicted on the economy in recent years will prove difficult to reverse. As such, recovery will be gradual, with GDP growth averaging just 0.1% annually in 2019-30. In 2031-50 we forecast that Venezuela's real GDP growth will pick up to 3.7% as rising investment in human capital boosts labour productivity growth, helping to offset deteriorating demographics. Persistent oil dependency will be difficult to undo, and a weak productive base will limit overall economic output.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s two parties, Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente, alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election in 1998 of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, won a presidential election in April 2013, but his popularity quickly plummeted as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression. Mr Maduro won re-election in May 2018 in an election that was neither free nor fair; the leader of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, declared himself interim president in January as a result.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition Mesa de la Unidad Democrática won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and side-lining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy mired in a years-long economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. At the same time, mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign-exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: Using IMF data, The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the merchandise trade surplus rose to US$22.3bn in 2018 amid massive import compression and acute foreign-exchange shortages. We estimate the current-account surplus at 4.1% of GDP that year

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The ruling party, originally called the Movimiento V República and transformed into the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) in 2006, has been in power since 1999. The populist-nationalist PSUV was initially ruled by the late president, Hugo Chávez (1999-2013). Since Mr Chavez's death, the party has been led by Nicolás Maduro. Over most of its tenure, the PSUV has wielded practically uncontested power, initially owing to Mr Chavez's immense popularity, and later through electoral manipulation and systematic campaigns to disenfranchise opposition parties and sideline them from state institutions. The opposition is diverse, and contested the 2015 election as part of the Mesa de la Unidad Democrática (MUD) coalition, winning a majority in the National Assembly (although the group's largest party, Acción Democrático, left the coalition in July 2018). However, following the opposition win, the government made the National Assembly essentially powerless, and convened a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly (ANC) that has granted itself remit over all legislative matters. The politicised Supreme Court and the executive have recognised the ANC, turning it into the country's de facto legislature and relegating the National Assembly.
Mr Maduro's controversial re-election in May 2018 was pronoucned illegitimate by the National Assembly, leading that body's president, Juan Guaidó, to declare himself interim president of the country in January 2019 (when Mr Maduro's disputed new term began). In this claim Mr Guaidó has been supported by 54 (mainly Western) countries, including most Latin American democracies. However, Mr Maduro remains in control of the military and most of the government apparatus. This has led to a stand-off between the two camps, which The Economist Intelligence Unit assumes will be resolved by the formation of a unity transitional government by Mr Guaidó and PSUV pragmatists later this year. Mr Maduro is extraordinarily unpopular-with approval of around 12% in May-and he relies on the support of the military to maintain power. For years the government has kept the military on side via a combination of purges and patronage. The latter has resulted in direct participation of the military in key government positions, and in a variety of opaque internal civic-military factions that coexist within the regime.

Political outlook: Political stability
The civic-military regime, led by Mr Maduro of the PSUV, is under severe economic and political pressure. We expect that a national unity government composed of opposition and regime "pragmatists" will form a transitional administration later in 2019. The transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period (2019-23) to be characterised by political instability.
On April 30th the opposition-controlled National Assembly and interim president, Mr Guaidó, together with a limited number of soldiers, staged a military uprising against Mr Maduro. Since taking oath as interim president in January, Mr Guaidó initially re-energised a disillusioned population, which has allowed him to convoke massive demonstrations. The recent uprising broke a stalemate that had developed since February; however, the attempt was easily controlled by the regime's security forces. Although unable to wrest power from Mr Maduro, the uprising does not appear to have been fruitless, revealing further cracks among the regime's ranks-particularly in the Servicio Bolivariano de Inteligencia Nacional (SEBIN, the secret police). Lower-ranking members of the military continue (gradually) to defect from the regime owing to Mr Maduro's incapacity to maintain the system of patronage flows underpinning the regime's internal stability. Mr Guaidó continues to enjoy strong support from most Western nations and, at the time of writing, no arrest warrant had been issued against him, despite his leadership of the uprising, and his continuing calls for indefinite protests until Mr Maduro forfeits power.
Mr Guaidó is presenting his leadership as a path out of the current quagmire for dissatisfied regime members. He has repeatedly called for the military to depose Mr Maduro, offering the lifting of sanctions on oil trade conducted by PDVSA-the state-owned oil company (and of targeted individual sanctions for defectors); the arrival of international aid and financing; and amnesty for defectors. Overall, considering that the regime's raison d'etre is the enrichment of its members, which Mr Maduro can no longer guarantee, we expect that pragmatists within the regime will eventually marginalise or expel "hardliners" in exchange for influence in Mr Guaidó's more prosperous government.
A Guaidó-led transition government is our baseline forecast; however, such an administration would face considerable hurdles and it is unclear how much muscle the opposition would have in a power-sharing transitional government. If opposition figures cannot deliver on its promises quickly enough, the government could well collapse, given the challenging tasks ahead. These include securing debt relief; rebuilding the rule of law; and attracting tens of billions of dollars in foreign investment. Through all this, the opposition would need to be careful to avoid upsetting its partners. Most of the opposition's economic rationalisation plans require reforms that eliminate the economy's distortions, closing the avenues for corruption and enrichment that regime members have used for years.
Three key assumptions underpin our baseline view. Firstly, that regime pragmatists will have enough capacity to overpower hardliners. Secondly, that regime members will deem Mr Guaidó's amnesty and transitional government offers credible. Risks to this assumption include a deep-seated distrust of the opposition and fear of being prosecuted outside of Venezuela (a credible fear given accusations of drug- and weapon-trafficking levied at regime members). The third assumption underpinning our forecast for a unity government is a continued lack of hard currency to sustain the patronage system. Risks to this forecast come in the form of greater than expected support from Russia or China, and from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities that could be providing the regime with more hard currency than we currently expect.
Given the very high risks to our baseline view, there are several alternative scenarios, with varying probabilities. Our main alternative scenarios are the following (in order of likelihood): firstly, a continuation of the PSUV's authoritarian rule (with or without Mr Maduro). Secondly, a complete collapse of the regime followed by an opposition-led government. Lastly, prolonged chaos-including, possibly, armed conflict-if divisions within the regime become clearer but no faction gains outright control of the state apparatus.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Despite our forecast for a political transition to begin this year, resulting in a national unity government, Venezuela in 2019-23 will continue to suffer from one of the weakest political and institutional frameworks in the region. Two decades of rule by the PSUV has engendered low institutional effectiveness and high levels of corruption largely due to the centralisation of power within the executive branch. Even under a new administration, there will continue to be questions around the credibility of the country's institutions, and a lack of accountability and transparency. Given the nature of power-sharing inherent under the scenario of a unity government, there is likely to be little progress in addressing these shortcomings owing to the vested interests that would need to be dismantled to achieve effective reform. For example, massive corruption and clientelism in the provision of subsidised goods and utilities would be hard to eliminate without upsetting regime insiders and risking political stability. Similarly, PDVSA will be a crucial part of this process. The company is an enormous source of direct and indirect profits for regime insiders, but mismanagement and corruption there will need to be curtailed to a minimum to stabilise both the company and the country's macroeconomy. Foreign investment will need to be secured to lift output, but this will require a wholesale reform of the oil sector's institutional framework. This is itself an endeavour that will require considerable political capital, which will probably be in short supply. The new government will also be constrained by public demands to punish corruption in the previous administration, balanced against the practical need to keep PSUV regime members and bureaucrats onside.
The political transition could similarly exacerbate existing problems, such as violent crime, which is currently fuelled by corruption in the judiciary and law enforcement. It could be aggravated by the disbanding of colectivos (armed pro-PSUV civilian groups), which will continue to operate as armed gangs under a future government. Drug-trafficking will remain a worrisome issue, with criminal networks well established in the country. US authorities have repeatedly accused high-ranking military and civilian government members of drug-trafficking (those accused deny the allegations). Furthermore, the homicide rate has risen sharply over the past 15 years. According to official figures, Venezuela recorded a homicide rate of 58 per 100,000 people in 2015, although private sources claim that the rate was much higher. Subsequent measurements by a well-regarded local think-tank, the Observatorio Venezolano de Violencia, put the national murder rate in 2018 as high as 81.4 per 100,000, a slight reduction from 2017, but still the highest regionally and among the highest in the world. Aside from homicides, there have been numerous high-profile kidnappings for ransom in urban areas, a development that has increased concern over police corruption and mismanagement. This increase in criminality will not be halted unless measures are adopted to improve the competence and effectiveness of law enforcement agencies and the criminal justice system, reduce rates of impunity, and boost youth employment.
Political outlook: Election watch
The opposition's recently announced plans for a transitional government call for the renovation of all electoral authorities and for elections within 12 months of the transitional government's formation. As we currently expect such a government to coalesce within 2019, we expect elections at some point in 2020. International assistance in organising the elections would be necessary and forthcoming. The task will be huge, as deep reforms to the electoral authority, to the electoral registry, and to the voting system will be required, and rebuilding trust in the system will be difficult.
Political outlook: International relations
Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community. Most governments in the Americas, under the banner of the Lima Group, have recognised Mr Guaidó. The US is Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, instituting crippling oil sanctions and openly calling for the military to accept Mr Guaidó in place of Mr Maduro. The US's hawkish approach introduces risks of a military intervention. We currently do not foresee large-scale military action, in part because such an initiative lacks international legitimacy. However, the US administration has sunk considerable political capital into Mr Guaidó, and the possibility of smaller-scale interventions, such as targeted bombings, cannot be discounted, especially given that the US no longer has substantial economic sanctions to throw at the regime.
Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the necessary financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and PDVSA. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but with little apparent success in terms of investment. Russia recently sent a limited number of military personnel to the capital, Caracas, which will further antagonise its relations with the US. Nevertheless, we believe that both Russia and China would be willing to work with a successor government in an attempt to protect their current investments in Venezuela.

a See Guide to the business rankings model at the end of this report. b Out of 10. c Out of 82 countries. d  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela. e New section, introduced in 2018.
The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings place Venezuela among the world's least attractive investment locations during the historical period (2014-18). The country deteriorates further during the 2019-23 forecast period, standing as the worst place to do business in the 82 countries covered by our rankings.
The poor score reflects a combination of political conflict, an erosion of the legal framework for investors and a state-led model that hampers private enterprise and competition. Highly distortionary macroeconomic policy measures have created critical economic problems that have paralysed the investment climate, most noticeably through extreme difficulties in purchasing foreign exchange and remitting profits. The associated problem of a runaway black-market exchange rate, combined with the government's highly expansionary fiscal and monetary policy stance, has generated hyperinflation.
The severe macroeconomic crisis poses a challenge for business because it has fundamentally altered income patterns and Venezuelans' purchasing power, and destroyed virtually all of the country's non-oil manufacturing capacity. The government has backed itself into a corner with relation to macroeconomic management with the result that policy in other areas is largely driven by economic constraints. This explains why we expect the business environment to remain extremely weak in 2019-23 even though we anticipate a change of government early on in that forecast period. The policy line under a new government is likely to be much more welcoming towards the private sector, but until the underlying macroeconomic situation stabilises, institutions strengthen, and there is better access to foreign exchange and fewer problems with basic power and water supply, foreign investors will remain wary.

Business environment outlook: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of rollback of interventionist measures like price controls, but political-instability concerns slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt at attracting investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange control
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque but restrictions on the private sector's access to foreign currency remain in place.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves only very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2021-23: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but the risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures falls.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns about economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Large-scale emigration of skilled labour complicates hiring.
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid means that rationing and unpredictable blackouts continue. A new government undertakes some repairs to the power network.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulator capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.5 3.0 81 82 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The macroeconomic environment will remain weak
During the forecast period, Venezuela's macroeconomic environment will rank as the least attractive of all 82 countries covered in our rankings. The economy has contracted sharply for five consecutive years, with estimated real GDP having contracted by almost 60% since 2013. Oil production has fallen steadily from around 2.5m barrels per day (b/d) in the mid-2010s to an average of 1.4m b/d in 2018, with further sharp falls to under 1m b/d in early 2019. This reflects a combination of long-running under-investment in the state oil firm, PDVSA, little private investment and-more recently-the impact of US oil sanctions and domestic nationwide power cuts. Price controls remain in place, but have failed to stop hyperinflation taking hold. Deep-seated corruption has aggravated chronic shortages of US dollars, with the government in default on much of its public debt stock.
Later in 2019 we expect that US oil sanctions will accelerate the collapse in oil production (which ultimately funds the patronage system that is keeping the Nicolás Maduro regime in power); this is expected to lead to an internal fracture and change of administration, which we currently believe is most likely to take the form of a pragmatic but uneasy alliance between various current government and opposition members. This administration will, out of necessity, seek substantial foreign aid and investment to help to return the economy to sustainable growth. With the help of this funding, a moderate improvement in the quality of macroeconomic policymaking will take place. However, political instability, the depth of economic distortions and the need to overhaul considerable portions of current regulations mean that changes will be slow. In addition, the government will face significant challenges such as a restructuring of defaulted and non-defaulted debt. Changes will take time to filter through to actual economic performance, explaining why Venezuela's macroeconomic ranking remains weak in 2019-23 even under a new administration.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.3 3.3 73 76 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition will remain unaltered in 2019-23 and Venezuela's ranking in this category will place it among the least business-friendly of the 82 countries assessed in the business environment rankings. In spite of our expectation of a new government later in 2019, we expect little immediate improvement in the overall stance towards private enterprise. Most of the restrictive policies enacted against private enterprise can be traced back to government partialism to either entrenched economic elites or the public. Given our expectation of limited political stability even under a successor administration, a reversal of current de facto and de jure restrictions is unlikely, as any future administration will need to retain support during what is likely to be a destabilising political and economic adjustment period.
Operating conditions have long been challenging, but the current government will refuse to alter its stance-characterised by bias against free markets, weak, politicised and inefficient institutions, and widespread price-fixing-despite the scale of the ongoing economic crisis. Uncertainty over contract and property rights, distortionary price and exchange controls, and the cumbersome burden of government regulation will continue to restrict businesses' freedom to compete under Mr Maduro.
Under Mr Maduro, there have been fewer takeovers of private companies compared with his predecessor, reflecting deteriorating performance in nationalised firms, as well as a lack of funds to pay for compensation of nationalised assets. However, the threat of state interference remains high, particularly in industries with access to foreign exchange, as the government has tended to use accusations of black-market transactions as a pretext for uncompensated state intervention. The government began a 90-day intervention in Venezuela's largest bank, Banesco, in May 2018, ostensibly to curb black-market foreign-exchange transactions. The intervention was subsequently extended and only ended in March 2019 without any further action, but the risk of state intervention in the economy remains elevated. Raids, fines and confiscations on retailers violating maximum prices are a common occurrence and will continue in the short term.
Our expectation of little improvement in 2019-23 reflects the complex legal framework that sustains the current economic distortions, and the political and economic instability that is expected to reign in the country in the forecast period.
In the context of the institutional decay that has occurred in recent years, improving competition policy (as well as restricting lobbying and corruption) will require an overhaul of regulatory bodies and legal frameworks that is likely to take several years.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.7 4.6 77 76 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Policy under a successor government is likely to be much friendlier for investors
Venezuela's score and global ranking for policy towards foreign investment improves slightly between the historical and forecast period, reflecting anticipated changes in policy stance under our forecast unity government. However, the score will remain low and Venezuela will continue to rank poorly by both global and regional comparison. We expect the next government to take a friendlier approach towards foreign investment in the hopes of inciting investors to rebuild the decimated domestic productive capacity. The improvement in the score and ranking therefore reflects our expectation that the risk of nationalisation and/or expropriation will be lower under the next government.
The fact that the World Bank's International Centre for the Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) is currently considering 18 cases lodged by companies affected by government nationalisation will deter foreign investment, particularly as there is little indication that the Maduro regime has either the desire or the funds to make compensation payments. Indeed, close to 30 cases have already been ruled on by the ICSID, but the government has only agreed payment plans on a limited number of these cases, and only under threat of seizures in foreign courts. Although we expect the next administration to demonstrate greater commitment towards abiding by international arbitration rulings, the authorities will encounter the same financial constraints facing the current regime.
We expect the next government to focus its efforts in attracting investment into the oil sector given its importance to the country's economic health. Even under the Maduro administration, PDVSA has partnered with private companies, with the majority of joint ventures being related to production or refining of extra-heavy oil from the Orinoco belt. Official data is not available but estimates on production suggest that it is these joint ventures that have kept production from collapsing further as output in operations fully controlled by PDVSA has plummeted. Under the new government, these efforts will be expanded. This will almost certainly require a reform of the current legal framework, which caps foreign participation in joint ventures at 40%. However, this will require considerable political capital and, as such, more aggressive measures (such as partly privatising PDVSA or the elimination of the requirement that PDVSA be involved in all oil projects) will be difficult to see through.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.3 5.1 78 75 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Easing currency controls will prove difficult and will progress only slowly
We expect a slight improvement in conditions in this category, leading to a small improvement in Venezuela's global ranking. Although official policy towards foreign investors will improve under a new government later in the forecast period, easing capital controls will prove extremely challenging, with the process likely to be gradual. Even by the end of the forecast period, access to foreign currency is likely to be restricted, hampering foreign trade.
In May 2019 the government loosened stringent currency controls that had been in place since 2003, permitting financial institutions to carry out the purchase and sale of foreign currency by individuals and businesses. The central bank will set the exchange rate based on the average exchange rate reported by banks the previous day. This is an acknowledgement that the central bank has exhausted its supply of liquid currency reserves and that the black-market exchange rate is the de facto official rate (the foreign-exchange market has traditionally suffered a large divergence between the official and black-market rates given that demand for dollars far outstrips supply). Although the removal of controls eliminates the government's role in the exchange market, it is unclear how the private sector will access dollars given that much of the country's export capacity remains in government hands. It is also unclear if the policy will last, or if the government will re-assert controls after a period of time. Given the depth of distortions, it is likely that the next administration will be forced to adopt a new domestic currency, which will most likely be pegged to the US dollar.
Difficulty in remitting profits earned in Venezuela will remain one of the most significant challenges of doing business for foreign companies operating in the country. Capital controls mean that official permission is required to remit profits, but with critical shortages of foreign exchange, remittances face long delays. Many foreign-owned companies have not been able to remit their profits for many years. With the Dicom rate (the rate offered by the government exchange authority) depreciating at such a rapid pace, the waitlisted profit remittances have seen their US- dollar value eroded significantly.
Bilateral trade partners will continue to struggle in their relations with the Maduro regime. Restricting foreign exchange to the private sector has resulted in a plummeting of imports. Outside of exchange controls, red tape, corruption and inefficiency also hinder trade, and corruption in the customs service will remain endemic. The acute foreign-exchange shortage has meant that even public-sector imports have been severely cut back, while the government has racked up significant debt to suppliers through unpaid bills. This is likely to change gradually under a successor administration, assuming that currency reform, large-scale aid inflows, a restructuring of debt obligations and a slow return of investment results in an increase in US dollar funds available to fund imports. However, the pace of these improvements will largely depend on how successful the new government is at restoring international credit and turning PDVSA around. Overall, we expect limited progress, as shown by the relatively low increase in Venezuela's score and ranking in this area.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.1 5.1 67 75 9 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Improvements in the tax regime are likely under an opposition government
The tax regime will remain a barrier to investment, with fiscal constraints prohibiting any significant improvements even under a new government. Rates of direct corporate taxation are currently moderate, with a top corporate income tax rate of 34% (excluding oil companies, for which the rate is set at 50%), but tax laws, regulations and procedures are complicated, inconsistent and subject to frequent arbitrary adjustments. A series of new taxes introduced in 2009 in many cases doubled the effective tax rate on earnings. These taxes formed part of wider reforms such as a sports law, a new science and technology law, a worker training law, and a municipal law, but included new fiscal charges on businesses, some of which are levied on gross revenue rather than net earnings. The new government may reverse some of these measures, but more pressing need for a consolidation of the public finances will severely limit the scope for tax cuts.
It is difficult to assess exactly how narrow the tax base is currently: according to the latest official data disclosed by Venezuela's tax authority (Seniat), tax income accounted for just 12% of GDP in 2012. The Seniat regularly reports massive increases in tax collection, but with hyperinflation, tax collection is actually shrinking in real terms, implying that the tax base has shrunk even further in recent years.
Despite the deterioration in the public finances, we do not believe that tax rises are likely under the current administration. Mr Maduro has shown little interest in raising revenue to offset massive increases in public spending and appears content with financing the huge fiscal deficit through public debt issuance, which is monetised, driving hyperinflation. Based on our assumption that a new government will take office and begin enacting policy adjustments, we expect that efforts will be focused-at least initially-on improving compliance; a difficult task, given the deterioration of state institutions over the course of the past 15 years.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.3 2.5 77 80 11 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Financing conditions will remain difficult
Venezuela's score for financing deteriorates further in the forecast period, given the weak state of the banking sector and on the assumption that improvements in access to medium-term finance for the private sector, and eliminating distortions in the financial sector, will only occur towards the end of forecast period. In the short term, the government will continue its policy of directed lending, which requires private banks to channel credit to specific sectors at preferential rates (including agriculture, mortgages and tourism).
In nominal terms, bank credit has soared in recent years, but massive currency devaluation means that in real terms, credit has fallen sharply. For companies borrowing from local banks, credit remains predominantly short term. As only a small percentage of the population has sufficient funds to purchase investment and savings products, the capital market also remains shallow. Following a political transition, we expect interest rates to be gradually rationalised, but sector-specific measures will also be required and financing will remain a major weakness of the business environment throughout the forecast period given that the deposit base will remain very low until the economy is on a significantly stronger footing (unlikely within our 2019-23 forecast horizon).
The soundness of the financial system and the quality of regulation will remain key concerns, even after an expected change of government. Legislative changes in recent years have not resulted in a tighter regulatory framework, but have simply established new layers of bureaucracy. There has been no concerted effort to tackle the patchy enforcement of existing regulations. Weak skills in regulatory agencies and political meddling in oversight decision-making will remain problems and will continue to undermine efforts to identify and support ailing banks at an early stage. Improving the quality of financial-sector regulation is unlikely to be achieved in the short term, and even under a new administration, it would take time to rationalise the bureaucracy.
A removal of the many price, export, capital and foreign-exchange controls after an expected political transition would be risky for the stability of the financial system. For instance, normalisation of interest rates would almost surely have an adverse effect on loan performance and credit creation. Careful co-ordination with the country's banks to reduce pressures on the financial system will be required. The gradual lifting of the directed lending system would also allow for better allocation of resources and the medium-term stabilisation of interest rates.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.7 3.9 79 81 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Recent large-scale emigration will hamper the labour market in 2019-23
Venezuela's labour market is forecast to deteriorate further in 2019-23 owing to higher costs of labour in the forecast period (after an exchange-rate adjustment removes the distortionary effect of hyperinflation on the dollar value of wages), as well as the quality of the labour force being affected by the outmigration of much skilled labour. Even though we assume that a new government will begin to take steps to ease the highly regulated labour market, the legacy of large-scale emigration in recent years will have significant implications on the quality of the labour market in the coming years, as few of the skilled Venezuelans who have left the country are likely to return until the economy is on a much firmer footing (if at all). The highly distorted exchange-rate system makes it virtually impossible to assess wage costs in US dollar terms in comparison with the rest of the region. However, a 2012 labour reform increased non-wage costs considerably: obligatory non-wage costs, employers' social security contributions, mandatory profit sharing, and childcare and food allowances added more than 70% to the basic wage costs for large and medium-sized companies, and 30% for smaller companies.
The mass exodus of Venezuelans leaving the country will pose significant constraints on the labour market during 2019-23, particularly in terms of companies' ability to find skilled labour. An estimated 3.7m of Venezuelans-around 12% of the population-had fled the country as at end-2018, with the UN expecting this number to reach 5.4m by the end of 2019. Anecdotal evidence suggests that among those who have left, a large proportion is made up of middle-class professionals with good employment prospects abroad. Although some are more likely to return to the country under our assumption of regime change, this is unlikely to gather substantial pace during the 2019-23 forecast period, as many Venezuelans will wait until the political and economic situation stabilises before returning. This will worsen skill shortages in the meantime. This situation will be aggravated by the fact that chronic underinvestment in education in recent years means that even basic skills are scarce in much of the workforce, while political interference in universities and technical colleges has damaged the quality of the country's tertiary education system.
Wage and non-wage costs come on top of a long-standing firing freeze, under which staffing levels (excluding managers, short-term workers and high-income earners) can be reduced only via collective agreement. Many workers cannot be fired at all, even in cases of stealing company property or failing to come to work. In practice, companies looking to shed staff are forced to negotiate "voluntary redundancy" agreements with workers; these typically centre on extremely generous severance payments, further adding to employment costs. Employment tribunals are generally hostile to private-sector employers, a factor used by workers and union representatives to their advantage. Moreover, companies that make recourse to voluntary redundancies have at times been targeted for nationalisation, representing a further disincentive for the private sector.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.5 3.3 74 78 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Electricity provision will remain a critically weak area of infrastructure
Following years of mismanagement and underinvestment, Venezuela's infrastructure has fallen into critical disrepair and we only expect marginal improvements in 2019-23. Repeated pledges by the government to implement ambitious infrastructure projects have come to nothing, with state-led investment drying up entirely in recent years. Even routine maintenance has not been completed, with current prolonged power shortages and limited access to running water the most visible manifestation of this failure to sustain basic service provision. A post-transition government will be keen on making up the shortfalls, but progress will be limited owing to fiscal constraints and the difficulties in attracting long-term foreign direct investment into infrastructure. Some multilateral assistance will be forthcoming, which will help to tackle the most immediate problems of limited power and fresh water supply, but reversing the long-term underinvestment in other infrastructure areas will take many years.
Reliable access to electricity will be one of the most significant challenges for businesses operating in Venezuela in 2019-23. Although the country has long faced sporadic power outages, the situation has deteriorated sharply in recent months. Massive prolonged nationwide blackouts have hit the country, with the government requesting that workers remain at home while the authorities try to restore power. Some companies have opted to install backup generators, but this is a costly solution that does not solve all operational problems, as businesses find it difficult to find fuel and staffs face difficulties getting to work during blackouts. The supply of fresh water has been seriously affected, while communication, financial and transport networks have also been interrupted. Insufficient investment in maintaining the generation and transmission systems in recent years are to blame. Electricity tariffs have been kept extremely low, leading to rapid growth in demand. Water levels at the Guri dam-which generates most of the country's hydropower (which, in turn, accounts for over 50% of total electricity generation)-have recovered from critically low levels, but with recent damage to several transformers at the dam, power generation currently stands at less than half the total installed capacity of 24,000 MW. Our forecast assumes that a successor government would focus immediately on repairing damage to existing generators, in order to ease the risk of ongoing power cuts. However, overhauling the entire system will take years, meaning that electricity rationing and blackouts will remain a risk throughout the forecast period.
Government policies complicate air travel. Long delays in authorising the remittance of international air carriers' profits outs of Venezuela have prompted most international carriers to suspend services (most recently American Airlines, which in March suspended all direct services to the US). A subsequent ruling by the US Federal Aviation Administration on April 30th prohibiting US carriers from flying below 26,000ft in Venezuelan airspace will be a further constraint going forward. The reduced service, coupled with firm demand (as Venezuelans have sought to travel overseas to bring US dollars back into the country, where they can sell them on the black market), has sent airfare prices soaring. Moving freight through the country's ports, which are under military control, has also proven complex; reports of corruption are common.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.3 2.7 72 78 8 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
This section, introduced as part of an upgrade to our rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption.
Venezuela is not well prepared for technological disruption
As in all other categories of the business environment rankings, Venezuela ranks extremely poorly at both the regional and global level. In 2019-23 the score drops further, on the expectation that the next administration will concentrate on stabilising the economy rather than modernising technology provision and digitalising services. The economic crisis has taken its toll on the telecommunications sector, with falls in disposable income leading to a decline in mobile phone penetration since 2013. Internet penetration peaked in 2015 but has since fallen and is now among the lowest in the region. Given that these areas are critical to driving broader technological developments, including mobile apps and cloud computing, Venezuela's slippage in these areas are important factors explaining the country's weak score. Regulation and governance also remain relative weak points, while the long-running economic crisis has deterred private investment, which in turn has hampered research and development and the number of patent applications.
Price and tariff regulations affect the quality of technological infrastructure in Venezuela, because high consumption levels are not matched by capital expenditure. Chronic underinvestment in scientific and technical skills, and massive "brain drain" also limit Venezuela's technological readiness. Moreover, acute skills shortages in technology will not be resolved in the short term, and private investors will wait for the political and economic situation to stabilise before making substantial capital expenditure commitments.
Although the Maduro administration, like the Chávez government before it, sought to direct state investment towards a variety of high-tech sectors, resources have been allocated inefficiently. For instance, the administration funded the construction of a factory to manufacture mobile telephones, but underinvested in the mobile network infrastructure, leading to poor service. Similarly, the government also built a factory to build educational computers, but school curriculums, educational materials and teaching standards have not been revised to train children in computer programming.
Internet and mobile network services are some of the cheapest in the world. However, lags in price adjustments make it difficult to cover the rising cost of maintaining the level and quality of the services. In addition, theft of equipment from companies' network infrastructure is common. As a result, service is unreliable and internet speeds are low compared with neighbouring countries.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The Economist Intelligence Unit's expectation of a change of government later in 2019 implies huge changes to policymaking, as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we foresee no fundamental change in policy by the Nicolás Maduro regime, which remains technically unable and politically unwilling to undertake the deep and wide-ranging policy and institutional changes needed. Monetisation of large public deficits, coupled with mismanagement of the state-dominated oil industry, has led to hyperinflation and shortages of foreign currency, basic goods and industrial inputs. Any efforts to tackle these issues have been self-defeating.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect that more orthodox economic policies will be implemented under the transition and successor governments. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and whether this takes precedence over the likely demands for reform from multilateral and bilateral lenders. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and multilaterals (totalling US$42bn in 2019-22) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Pockets of resistance are likely to exist. Internal stability within the ruling PSUV is a major risk to our forecast, as the success of any government will depend on PSUV pragmatists fending off more radical party members. PSUV hardliners could oppose international assistance, foreign investment and policy reforms on both ideological and personal grounds (as many regime insiders profit from the state's control of the economy); however, we expect the government of Juan Guaidó, the interim president, to steer policymaking. That said, real investment inflows will be limited, owing to investors' caution over the credibility and stability of the new government, with the vast majority going into the oil industry, which will restrict economic recovery.

The authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect that the fiscal deficit this year will be close to double figures as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency.
High inflation and the overvalued official exchange rate make debt/GDP ratios misleading indicators of fiscal stability. Considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA, the state oil firm, and development funds from China) understates the true size of total public liabilities. Most sovereign and state-owned bonds (including PDVSA's) are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy changes or a change in government. However, other investors have taken claims to the courts, and the results of these court battles will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining company, Crystallex, is seeking to collect an arbitration award by seizing shares of Citgo, PDVSA's US subsidiary. A ruling on the treatment of PDVSA as an "alter ego" of the government is pending, and will have implications for future debt restructuring. Following the imposition of sanctions on January 28th, the US government now considers Citgo to be under Mr Guaidó's purview, but it is unclear how much power Mr Guaidó will have over the company. None the less, the risk of seizure of Citgo, its Caribbean facilities and even shipments, will remain high in the short term.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a restructuring with external creditors in 2020. Owing to the need to maintain political stability, we do not expect the closure of the various handout programmes in operation, nor the complete removal of utility subsidies or the reformation of inefficient state-owned firms. Therefore, we expect public expenditure to be hard to reduce; the deficit will be substantial throughout the 2019-23 period.

The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to print money. Money supply (M2) continues to grow rapidly, expanding by 75% month on month in February. By end-January Venezuela had significantly raised reserve requirements for the banking sector, which "contained" hyperinflationary pressures and allowed the bolívar to stabilise somewhat in the short term. But this is a one-off effect; hyperinflation and significant currency depreciation will return in May. We expect a new administration to place much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation and expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of a macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) in such a context is highly likely.

After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 18% in 2018, we expect further contractions in 2019-20. A forecast recovery in 2021-23 rests on the assumption of a political transition that, supported by international assistance, produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will be limited in scope by a weak government, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of around 60% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2019, reflecting the effect on real wages of hyperinflation, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also contract, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Moreover, power cuts are now very common-a result of severe underinvestment in the country's power infrastructure-and have further significantly damaged Venezuela's overall economic capacity. Our forecast for a recovery in investment later in the forecast period assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment.
We expect oil output to bottom out at 900,000 barrels/day (b/d) over the coming quarters, kept from going lower by PDVSA's joint-venture partners. But until US sanctions on oil are lifted, margins will be smaller, as PDVSA has lost access to its closest and better-paying market. In line with our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government from 2019, production will start to recover in 2020 but will end the forecast period (2019-23) well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017.
Export volumes will only start to recover in 2020, as an increase in domestic demand, which has been artificially constrained, will initially absorb the increase in oil output. For the same reason, import demand will rise sharply in 2019.
