Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Oil sector: With proven levels approaching 300bn barrels, Venezuela has the largest reserves in the world, making it a major oil producer and exporter. However, the energy sector has suffered from disinvestment and mismanagement owing to political interference. The state is accorded exclusive ownership of PDVSA, the nationalised oil and gas firm, and its subsidiaries. Since 2007, oil exploration, extraction and storage activities have been reserved for state-owned enterprises or companies in which the state holds a stake of at least 60%.
The latest PDVSA data put oil output at an average of 2.6m barrels/day (b/d) in 2016, while OPEC estimates put it at 2.2m, in line with data from the International Energy Agency (IEA). But in early 2019 Venezuela's oil output has fallen dramatically as nationwide blackouts and US sanctions have taken a further toll on a sector decimated by corruption, underinvestment and mismanagement. Latest IEA data estimate output at 870,000 b/d in March (down from 1.5m b/d in March 2018); the report notes that production likely fell lower in April. Official data is not available, but production estimates suggest that it is joint ventures with foreign investors that have kept output from dropping further. As the joint ventures deal predominately in heavy and extra-heavy oil, and as production of lighter oil is collapsing, PDVSA has been forced to import more diluents from abroad. This was complicated by the imposition of US sanctions in January, and the US government has been pressuring international firms to stop selling diluents to Venezuela as well. This is likely to put further pressure on PDVSA this year.
PDVSA's main joint-venture partners are Russian firms (Gazprom, Lukoil and Rosneft), CNPC (the Chinese state oil company), Chevron (US) and Eni (Italy). The government has shown a preference for Russian and Chinese firms, but even co-operation with these partners has reportedly been rocky at times given, among other things, pervasive corruption at PDVSA, complex regulatory and planning requirements, difficulties securing foreign exchange to afford production imports, and criminality in areas surrounding at oil production and refining facilities.
Dwindling production and a punishing debt redemption schedule have stretched PDVSA's financing to its limits. Suppliers and oil services firms have denounced delays in payments. Schlumberger, a US-based oil services firm, reportedly scaled back operations in Venezuela in 2016 and in 2017 wrote off at least part of PDVSA's debts. PDVSA has also fallen behind on its external debt obligations, with a majority of its almost US$30bn in outstanding external bonded debt accumulating arrears. One of the bonds that PDVSA remains current on, which matures in 2020, has 50% of Citgo, a PDVSA subsidiary, as collateral. The opposition-controlled National Assembly voted to pay bondholders the US$71m interest payment in May to avoid Citgo's seizure. Another 50% of Citgo is reported collateral on a loan extended by Rosneft. Citgo traditionally has been a vital part of PDVSA's operations, as it refines and commercialises Venezuelan oil in the US, historically PDVSA's largest cash-paying market. Although US sanctions have complicated this, the hope is that Citgo will remain an important government asset in any future administration.
Given the challenges arising from PDVSA's financial difficulties and perennial mismanagement, as well as US sanctions, the current decline in output is irreversible for as long as the present regime remains in power. With PDVSA in debt arrears and unable to articulate a credible restructuring plan to creditors, we expect that a turnaround of the oil sector will only be possible after a new government is in office. We expect that any new government will prioritise the improved management of PDVSA and will attempt to open the company to increased co-operation with international investors (and perhaps even allow outright foreign operations in the country), a necessity given that PDVSA will be unable to afford the required investments. However, this will require a complete overhaul of the sector's current legal framework, which will require considerable political capital, and which remains uncertain.

Severely reduced domestic supply, severe limits on imports and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official data have not been published since 2015, but according to estimates from the opposition-led National Assembly monthly inflation was 18.1% in March. This was the lowest reading since May 2017; however, the current disinflationary trend is merely temporary and monthly inflation will jump over the coming months. In the context of a projected macroeconomic stabilisation plan later in 2019, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation. However, supply bottlenecks and bouts of inflationary pressure are likely.

Under our current baseline forecast of a political transition later in 2019, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) amid deep imbalances and as a means by which to try to tackle hyperinflation is highly likely. The exact nature and implementation of such moves are hard to foresee, but our baseline forecast includes the continuation of some currency controls for the duration of the forecast period.
Since the start of 2018, the government has repeatedly devalued the currency and promised liberalisation of exchange controls. The official rate is determined by an auction process, but the government-which monopolises the country's exports-does not supply the system with foreign exchange, making the system unsustainable and access to foreign exchange practically impossible. At end-April the official rate stood at BsS5,200:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of over BsS5,800:US$1.

We expect a small current-account surplus in 2019, buoyed by non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2019 alone). Our export data, which are based on IMF data, may overstate receipts, as some exports are actually payments in kind for loans, the repayment of which may not be included in their totality under forecast interest repayments (we have excluded repayments to Chinese lenders to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data, on which our debt forecasts are based).
By 2020, with a new government in power, we expect that-following debt renegotiation-external financing will be restored. Although we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, we also expect a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been severely reduced and imports have been compressed to artificially low levels. In addition, the government will be complying with its debt obligations, meaning that the restructured debt will actually result in increased outflows in interest payments. These factors will erode the current-account surplus to a deficit of 4.1% of GDP in 2023.
We currently expect that a new administration will secure sufficient finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this rosy outlook. In addition to assuming the installation of a pragmatic transition administration capable of retaining power, it hinges on substantial finance from the IMF, the quick implementation of a successful macroeconomic stabilisation package, the fast resolution of a debt-renegotiation process in 2019-20, substantial inflows of financial and real investment into the economy in 2020-23, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Venezuela
Stocks and flows
According to the IMF (whose figures differ somewhat from local sources), the stock of foreign direct investment (FDI) in Venezuela stood at US$30.1bn in 2016, the last year in which actual data have been provided. This is around one-third less than a peak of US$48.9bn in 2007 and is primarily the result of significant disinvestment, notwithstanding the government's strict capital controls. Given the massive decline in GDP in recent years, this means that the FDI stock is estimated at 19.4% of GDP in 2018 (forecast to rise to 51.9% of GDP this year, as GDP contracts further). Overall, FDI inflows have been very volatile in the past 20 years, affected by both political and macroeconomic factors. During the oil opening of 1996-98, inward FDI peaked at an annual average of US$4.5bn a year. By historical standards, inward FDI held up well in the first three years of the presidency of Hugo Chávez (1999-2003), averaging US$3.8bn per year in 1999-2001. As political conflict intensified, FDI inflows began to decline in 2002-08 (averaging US$1.8bn per year), and in 2009-a year of great volatility in the world economy and adverse domestic developments in Venezuela-the country registered disinvestment of US$1.1bn (some negative inflows were also the result of compensation for nationalisations). Inward FDI has recovered afterwards, averaging an estimated US$4.3bn per year in 2011-13, because of greater investment from China in energy and housing. It declined considerably afterwards, to US$1.9bn a year in 2014-16, likely as a reflection of both sliding international oil prices and foreign investors increasing disillusionment with the government's inability to comply with investment agreements and manage the economy. Outbound FDI in Venezuela is considerable, reaching a stock of US$32.7bn in 2016. However, this tally is dominated by investments abroad by PDVSA, the state oil company.
Origin and distribution
The energy sector, and oil in particular, remains the main magnet for FDI. US and European oil companies have major investments in the country, even after forced changes to the ownership structure of most contracts. After oil, banking and communications have been the main recipients of FDI. Spanish banks have the largest foreign presence in the financial sector, although the Venezuelan state has bought back some operations. Other notable FDI inflows come from Chile (in forestry activities) and Canada (in the mining industry). In recent years Venezuela has courted new investment partners in Brazil, China, Russia and Iran, with limited success. Domestic economic problems in most of these countries mean that short-term efforts will be focused on seeking investment from China and Russia.
Determinants
Following a period of booming FDI inflows in the 1990s, driven by oil and telecommunications openings, an uncertain political and policy environment-including threats of nationalisation-and a volatile macroeconomic climate have served to keep FDI well below potential, particularly in the non-extractive sectors. In the extractive sector, FDI inflows have been affected by the government's restrictive hydrocarbons investment regime, which mandates that PDVSA must hold a minimum 60% stake in the oil and gas sector and levies high taxes and royalties on private partners. The vast reserves of extra-heavy oil in the Orinoco Belt require substantial technical know-how and massive investment to be put to production, an environment where major oil companies would thrive. Many major companies are already present via joint ventures or were already present before nationalisation drives. Venezuela's oil sector will continue to be a major draw to FDI under more sustainable economic and regulatory policies.
Impact
Foreign investment in oil brought accelerated growth in output, from 2.4m barrels/day (b/d) in 1994 to a peak of 3.4m b/d in 1999. Foreign investment in the extractive sector has fallen since then, contributing to a decline in oil output, reinforced by PDVSA's inability to drive production. Foreign involvement has had a less dramatic impact in other sectors, such as domestic manufacturing or services, but this in turn has resulted in high levels of import dependence. As FDI has flowed mostly into capital-intensive industries, its impact on employment and skills levels has been limited.
Potential
Given the scale of economic mismanagement and poor maintenance of existing infrastructure and productive capacity, there is large potential for investment opportunities in Venezuela. Potentially attractive opportunities for FDI exist in an array of sectors, such as oil and gas, petrochemicals, coal, aluminium, gold, forestry, power, tourism and telecoms. There is additional potential in some manufacturing and agricultural niches (for example, leather goods, cocoa and rum). Further comparative attractions are Venezuela's transport infrastructure, which, despite lack of investment and maintenance, is still fairly good by regional standards, and the country's strategic geographic location. However, FDI inflows will be severely curtailed by concerns over the current government's policy stance, difficulties in accessing foreign exchange, the weak macroeconomic environment and the fragility of the legal framework. A more noticeable upturn in FDI inflows will have to wait until after a political transition takes place, insofar as the new government undertakes a commitment to improve the business environment, address corruption and exchange-rate distortions and controls local prices.

Population growth will resume under a new government, but will remain low
Population growth will remain weak because of a falling birth rate and -scale outmigration. The annual population growth rate has been steadily decreasing from 2.8% in the 1980s to 2.3% in the 1990s and 1.8% in 2000-10. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates that the population declined by 1% a year in 2014-18 as the economic crisis worsened. The UN High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) estimates that some 3.7m Venezuelans have left the country since 2014. Our estimates for population growth in 2019-23 factor mainly natural increase, and we assume that only a small number of those who have migrated during the crisis will return, even as political and economic stability improves with the arrival of a new government. Still, the resumption of a more normal economic environment will lead to a return to growth in the participation rate and a faster growth rate in the labour force compared with that of the working-age population. The total population is expected to reach 28.9m by 2023 (from an estimated peak of 30.9m in 2016), with just over one-quarter of the population under the age of 14 and two-thirds of the population between 15 and 64 years of age. Population density is low, at 34 people/sq km as per official estimates from 2017. Distribution between urban and rural areas is highly uneven, with around 90% of the total population living in urban centres. Underdeveloped rural infrastructure, limited job opportunities in the countryside and fixed agricultural prices (in many cases, below the cost of production) will result in a continuing trend of urbanisation in 2019-23, creating problems in the main cities.
The labour participation rate declined in 2004-12 (owing to an increased uptake of education linked to the government's social programmes), but ticked up marginally in 2013 and 2014, before falling again in 2015 as economic conditions worsened as job seekers became discouraged. The government has stopped producing labour data, but we expect that continued economic contraction and diminishing real wages (we estimate that, in real terms, the minimum wage plus food vouchers has lost some 95% of its value since mid-2013) has driven participation down further. Although we are forecasting some improvement later in the forecast period as the economic crisis is reversed, we expect the participation rate to remain below 70% until 2023. A very poor business environment, economic malaise and extremely restrictive labour regulation will continue to limit job creation, forcing more people to seek work in the informal sector, which is already estimated to account for around half of employment. According to the authorities, the official unemployment rate fell from 8.5% in 2010 to 6.8% in 2015. However, given that this coincided with a sharp deterioration in local economic conditions, it is likely that it reflects inflexible labour laws (which make it virtually impossible to lay off workers) rather than any significant job creation. It is also possible that the data are unreliable, as it is highly implausible that unemployment has remained low in the midst of a deep economic recession, with a growing number of companies folding.
Poverty indicators improved during the tenure of Hugo Chávez (1999-2013), but these data are no longer published by the authorities. Independent academic sources estimate that poverty rates have risen sharply in the context of collapsing economic activity and hyperinflation. A study by three well-regarded universities estimated the poverty rate at 87% in 2017. Shortages of medicines and surgical supplies are creating huge problems in the healthcare system, while insufficient vaccines are resulting in the re-emergence of diseases that had previously been practically eradicated.
Public services will remain under strain from a lack of resources
The old-age dependency ratio will remain low by developed-country standards but, in the context of volatile public finances, population ageing will place growing pressure on the heavily burdened social security system. Public hospitals will continue to suffer from crumbling infrastructure, and lack of supplies (including medicines) and equipment. The latter are mainly imported, or assembled from imported parts, and supplies have fallen victim to a lack of US dollars. Hospital building and rebuilding programmes have been a failure, owing to mismanagement of funds and shortages of building materials. Even a parallel welfare system, the Sistema Nacional de Misiones, is struggling to function as the government makes cuts and inflation erodes purchasing power. Overall, the provision and quality of public healthcare and education services is therefore expected to deteriorate further. This will also reflect long-running problems including a pronounced deficit of technical and basic skills, and the continued emigration of professionals, particularly doctors and nurses.

Imports of goods & services (% change) -1.4 15.9 7.7 13.3 8.6 7.5
The scale of Venezuela's economic crisis has led to a rapid decline in living standards, with GDP per head falling almost by half from a peak of US$12,291 in 2012, to an estimated US$6,281 in 2018. Estimates using purchasing power parity (PPP) give a higher figure of US$11,698. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a further decline in both GDP per head at market exchange rates and PPP by 2023, despite our expectation for a change of government and more normal economic policy making, as economic growth is likely to remain low amid the severe imbalances left by the previous government.
Several factors will restrict purchasing power, including hyperinflation, and persistently high levels of poverty and income inequality. Although national statistics show a dramatic improvement in social indicators in recent years, the data have been disputed, and independent studies have suggested that inequality has not fallen as quickly as the government indicates, and that the middle-income class has shrunk. According to the UN Human Development Programme, 6.6% of the population survived on less than US$1.25/day (in purchasing-power terms) in 2012, a higher proportion than in almost any other country in the region.
Investment potential will only be tapped after a political transition
Venezuela is a reasonably sized consumer market and has the potential to become an attractive investment location, although this will have to wait until a more market-friendly administration takes over from the ruling PSUV. The country has vast reserves of natural resources (including oil, gas, coal and precious metals), an array of spectacular natural tourist attractions, relatively good physical infrastructure and a fairly favourable geographical location given its proximity to the US. However, poor economic policies have contributed to a volatile GDP profile and a deterioration of public services and human capital over the past two decades. The unattractiveness of the business environment is compounded by inadequate contract and property rights. Moreover, continued high poverty levels and a deterioration in healthcare and education provision in the past three decades have contributed to an erosion of skills and productivity, which has also been exacerbated by an exodus of talented individuals to work abroad.

A weakened productive base will sustain demand for imported goods
In common with the rest of the Latin American region, spending on food, beverages and tobacco accounts for the largest share of total consumer expenditure, and this will remain the case throughout the forecast period. Sharp growth in mobile-telephone usage, and an underdeveloped urban public transport system and subsidised petrol (which have boosted car ownership) are the main factors behind the relatively heavy weighting of expenditure on transport and communications. Most consumer goods industries will remain underdeveloped, a legacy of "Dutch disease", whereby dependence on energy exports leads to currency appreciation and therefore a lack of competitiveness in manufacturing exports, with a consequent decline of the latter sector. Furthermore, shortages of foreign exchange have led to import controls, resulting in a scarcity of consumer goods that are not produced domestically.
The scale of the country's ongoing recession will lead to major contraction in retail sales volumes throughout most of the forecast period, and only a modest improvement from 2022 as the economy normalises.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook

Total factor productivity growth 0.2 2.2 1.4
The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term outlook is based upon a transition to a new government (in 2019) that pursues sounder policies and improves the business environment. However, despite the prospects of a more market-friendly government and the gradual elimination of the country's economic distortions, long-term growth will remain underwhelming, and will continue to be subject to boom and bust cycles linked to the oil market. We therefore project that Venezuela's real GDP per head will contract by an average of 0.5% in 2018-30 (this figure is also influenced by major contractions in 2018-19, and a small contraction in 2020). Growth will average a healthier 3.7% in 2031-50 but the country's population is unlikely to reach a high standard of living within the forecast period. Indeed, by 2050 we forecast that per head GDP at purchasing power parity will be US$35,560-a low value for a country with Venezuela's endowment of national resources. Although we expect the business environment to improve, the country's weak institutions, dependency on the extractive industry and a weak productive base will remain significant barriers to growth.
Initial conditions: After averaging growth of 10% in 2004-08, real GDP fell sharply in 2009-10. Although the economy recovered in 2011-12 on the back of aggressive fiscal spending, growth slowed sharply again in 2013, with the economy slipping into a deepening recession in late 2014. We estimate that by the time the economy returns to growth in 2021, real GDP will have fallen by almost 60%, making the recession the country's most severe since compilation of national statistics data began. The heterodox policy framework that has been in place for over a decade has been a major factor in hampering GDP growth, while an opaque and distorted exchange-rate system has provided opportunities for corruption on a large scale, further undermining the institutional framework and maintaining income inequality. Given the sharp deterioration in conditions in recent years, there is potential for improvement in the policy and political environment in the long term under new administrations, but there is significant risk of an outright economic collapse before then (or afterwards, if the transition is particularly chaotic). In addition, institutional deterioration is very deep-rooted and will prove harder to reverse.
On a more positive note, a higher skills base and reasonably good infrastructure by regional standards provide scope for faster overall growth and a rise in personal incomes. Nevertheless, underinvestment in human capital and infrastructure, as well as the emigration of most skilled labour, is eroding these advantages and, given fiscal difficulties, this trend will take time to reverse. Successive governments have failed to take advantage of Venezuela's proximity to developed US and European markets relative to its South American neighbours, as internal geography and a lack of investment in infrastructure in the interior have limited Venezuela's chances of becoming a regional hub for transport and commerce.
Demographic trends: As in most other emerging-market countries, growth in the working-age population will slow in the long term, while rising participation rates will ensure that the labour force will grow at a brisker pace. Venezuela will continue to enjoy supportive population dynamics, with the dependency ratio of old to young low by comparison to OECD levels even in 2050. Even with life expectancy growing steadily, the share of the population aged 65 and over will be only around 16% in 2050 (although rising from an estimated 6.6% in 2017), while the proportion of the population at working age will remain high, at 65%. A particular risk to productivity is the "brain drain" seen in recent years as many experienced professionals have left the country to work abroad with no guarantee of returning, even after economic conditions stabilise following a change in government.
Diversifying away from oil will be one of the key long-term challenges
External conditions: Oil, which we estimate currently accounts for some 95% of export revenue, will continue to dominate the Venezuelan economy. However, there will be an effort to diversify the productive base in the long term, given the severe consequences of the economy's dependency on oil (particularly on the external and fiscal balances). During the Hugo Chávez (1999-2013) and Nicolás Maduro eras Venezuela and its allies have taken a confrontational stance against US policy and US-led efforts at economic integration. This stance will soften once a new government is in power, which will result in an economic rapprochement with some of its faster growing neighbours, such as Colombia and Peru. It will also signal the end of programmes such as PetroCaribe, a scheme in which Venezuela provided subsidised oil to regional economies as a way of gaining international goodwill, which was financially viable only as a result of historically high oil prices. A gradual real devaluation of the exchange rate will be necessary for Venezuela to be competitive in non-commodity sectors, as will be the removal of state control over key productive sectors that have export potential. Capital control, trade restrictions and other barriers currently designed to keep foreign currency from leaking out will gradually be pared down as well, although further liberalisation of trade is unlikely to be a priority for the next government until well into the next decade. In the meantime, links with Asia will be strengthened, and the country's close relationship with China is not likely to be compromised, given that country's significant investment potential.
Institutions and policy trends: Under the assumption of a change in government that gradually ushers in improved policymaking over the long term, our long-term forecast assumes that there will be a gradual improvement to the policy environment. We assume that some of the most distortionary elements of the current policy framework, including price and exchange controls, will be scaled back gradually in the medium term, reducing the large black-market exchange-rate premium and increasing economic openness by the end of the long-term forecast period. However, the prospects for improvements in other aspects of the business environment are less encouraging, given that they will take far longer to address. For example, strengthening of the non-oil public finances will prove unfeasible until the economy is sufficiently diversified. Given that the economy will still be highly vulnerable to the fluctuations of the price of oil, the fiscal position will remain highly pro-cyclical. An overhaul of the overstaffed and inefficient bureaucracy will be difficult to achieve, even with an administration fully composed of the current opposition. This is owing both the political costs of redundancies, and the fact that many current opposition parties are ideologically inclined to have the state play a major role in the economy. Within the context of a deficient administrative framework, progress in reforming social security and labour legislation will be slow at best, as the new government will want to retain some of its powers of patronage in order to avoid a loss of support from the withdrawal of Chávez-era benefits. Endemic corruption and politicisation will be difficult to root out, even assuming other improvements in the policy environment.
Long-term performance: Even once the most distortionary elements of current economic policy are abandoned, the deterioration of the skills base over the past decade will mean that Venezuela's potential GDP growth will have been eroded, although there is still some scope for recovery in 2021-40, when growth will average a respectable 3.7%. It will then slow down to an average of 3.2% in 2041-50. A higher trend rate of GDP growth would be possible if a significant change in the policy direction is coupled with more favourable external conditions (mainly oil prices) than currently forecast, thereby allowing for rapid and thorough implementation of much-needed structural reforms. Under our baseline scenario, however, achieving reforms beyond those necessary for a post-transition adjustment will prove very complicated. As it is, the overall economy will remain vulnerable to continuing cycles of boom and bust, with negative consequences for macroeconomic stability and growth, and constraining the prospects for catch-up with more developed economies, despite some solid projected growth late in the forecast period. The key variables to a successful turnaround will be the degree to which the economy is diversified from oil and whether the business environment improves to the point that domestic and external investment become key drivers of growth.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Venezuela is vulnerable to the adverse effects of climate change owing to both geographical limitations and the government's inadequate focus on preparedness. Venezuela is deemed extremely vulnerable to climate change given its population distribution along coastal lines on unstable terrains. 75% of the country's population is estimated to live in the 20% of the territory facing the Caribbean Sea. Given low maintenance of infrastructure and little disaster preparedness, the population centres there are exposed to torrential rains, mudslides and flash floods. According to a recent study by a local and internationally recognised expert, Juan Carlos Sanchez, even within established rainfall patterns, variance has resulted in the number of extreme events per year growing in the past decade. Longer-term trends in rainfall will also affect the country. A study performed by the Universidad Simón Bolívar, a well-regarded university, has concluded that rainfall in the northwest of the country could fall by 25% by 2060. This would not only cause internal migration, but also drive the country into further food insecurity (Venezuela is already heavily reliant on imports of foodstuffs). In addition, changing rain patterns may disrupt hydroelectricity generation, a major problem given that this represents over 50% of the country's electricity.
The government has done little to address these challenges. Its public works programmes concentrate on traditional infrastructure projects and there is minimal focus in the way of disaster preparedness. In a recent forum with a United Nations delegation, authorities touted their plans to build apartment blocks in place of shantytowns, the logic being that concrete buildings would hold up to flooding better. There is scarce official data on carbon emissions or pollution in the country, but environmental policies are generally deemed poor by specialised observers. PDVSA, the state-owned oil firm, has been routinely accused of poor environmental protection in both its oil and gas operations. This year The Economist Intelligence Unit has developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we find that the Venezuelan economy will be 4% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
Migration and urbanisation
Venezuela experienced rapid urbanisation through the majority of the second half of the 20th century as the country's oil wealth was developed. According to data from the World Bank, the percentage of urban population grew from 60% in 1960 to almost 90% by the late 1990s-high by global standards but in line with most large Latin American countries. Oil exports, especially at the start of this process, funded large-scale real estate developments and infrastructure works in budding urban centres, attracting prospective workers from the countryside. In addition to a growing middle class fed by spill-over from the country's oil wealth, the rural exodus towards the cities also created sprawling shantytowns across major metropolises, which-public housing programmes have been unable to eradicate. Income inequality in urban centres is especially acute, feeding crime and political tension. This is perhaps best exemplified by Caracas, the capital, where income and wealth disparities have correlated with voter preferences for the ruling PSUV and the opposition parties.
Emigration, previously a limited phenomenon, has become a major issue. No official data exist, but out of a total population of around 31m, local estimates put total emigration in the past two decades at close to 3.7m people, with most having left in the past three years. These émigrés were initially primarily driven by political reasons, but the exodus is now also driven by criminal violence (Venezuela has one of the world's highest murder rates) and woeful economic conditions. Anecdotal evidence suggests that those leaving have been primarily young, well-trained professionals, which has harmed the economy's prospects further. Under our expectation of a political transition, some of these émigrés are expected to return; how many will and how fast remains unclear
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCV: Banco Central de Venezuela (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Turkey--highlights: Political outlook
In June 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day his conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP). Mr Erdogan's re-election concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan to remain in power until 2023, and probably beyond. The concentration of power under Mr Erdogan and his party's control of parliament suggest that policy will retain an element of unpredictability. Domestic and regional political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional, rather than strategic.
Turkey--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.96 5.81 48 59 17 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Our business environment score for Turkey deteriorates slightly in the forecast period (2019-23), and its global ranking falls by 11 places, to 59th. Political tensions, increased powers concentrated under the president, inadequate policy responses to tighter global liquidity conditions and higher domestic inflation have raised the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. On the positive side, with no major elections scheduled until 2023 we expect policymaking to be more orthodox compared with that in 2017-18. Large external imbalances leave Turkey's economy vulnerable to shifts in investor sentiment.

  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023

3-month Treasury rate (av; %) 19.8 22.9 14.5 12.5 10.0 9.5
Exchange rate TL:US$ (av) 4.8 5.7 5.7 5.9 6.1 6.3
We expect the currency crisis in 2018 and the ensuing recession to put pressure on the government's finances, business sector solvency and banks' balance sheets. In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy (concerns about off-balance sheet trends will persist). This, alongside a recovering economy, will cause the budget deficit to narrow gradually, from a forecast 2.3% in 2019 to 1.7% of GDP in 2023. The crisis pushed the Turkish economy into a recession in the second half of 2018, which we expect to have continued in the first quarter of 2019, resulting in a full-year real GDP contraction of 1.7% in 2019 on average (mainly owing to base effects), followed by annual average growth of 3.7% per year in 2020-23.
Turkey--highlights: Demographic outlook
Population (m) 2013 2018 2023
Total 75.8 81.9 85.4
 Male 37.3 40.4 42.1
 Female 38.5 41.5 43.3
Period averages (%)   2014-18 2019-23
Population growth   1.6 0.8

Labour force growth   3.6 1.9
The total population is projected to rise from an estimated 81.9m in 2018 to 85.4m in 2023, with the female population continuing to far outnumber the male population. The total population is expected to grow by 0.8% per year during the forecast period, compared with growth of 1.6% during the historical period (2014-18). The pace of population growth has slowed in recent decades, mostly owing to the declining birth rate, which in turn reflects the combined impact on fertility rates of higher urbanisation rates, an improvement in the education level of women and wider use of birth control measures. Nevertheless, population growth remains high by European standards and the average age is one of the lowest, at 32 years.
Turkey--highlights: Market opportunities
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023

Household consumption per head (US$) 5,380 5,030 5,740 6,180 6,650 7,040
The large consumer market is one of Turkey's chief attractions as a place to do business. The population is young, growing and inclined to consume rather than save, and average incomes are rising steadily in local currency terms. In 2018 GDP per head was US$9,333 at market exchange rates and US$29,132 at purchasing power parity (PPP) rates. We expect Turkey's GDP per head to be US$34,200 at PPP exchange rates in 2023. At this level, GDP per head in Turkey will be broadly unchanged, at about 63% of the EU28 average.
Turkey--highlights: Long-term outlook
  2019-30 2031-50 2019-50
Growth and productivity (% change; annual av)
Growth of real GDP per head 2.6 2.3 2.4
Growth of real GDP 3.2 2.7 2.9
Labour productivity growth 2.0 2.3 2.2
In the long term Turkey's economic growth performance is expected to be above that of other emerging markets such as Brazil, Russia and China. In 2019-50 we expect Turkey's economy to grow by an annual average of 2.9%. Brazil is expected to grow by an annual average of 2.1%, Russia by 1.6% and China by 3%. Nevertheless, GDP growth will be well below that recorded in 2004-07 and 2010-15. Average growth in GDP per head will be substantially lower, mainly reflecting the expected rise in the total population. Income levels will remain well below the EU28 average, but some catch-up is likely. As a result, Turkey will remain an attractive market for international companies through-out 2019-50.

Background: The Turkish Republic was formed in 1923. Nationalist resistance forces led by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk defeated the occupying allies after the first world war, establishing the country's current borders. Since then Turkey's political and economic structure has been oriented towards the West. The country became a member of the Council of Europe in 1949 and NATO in 1952, and signed an association agreement with the then European Community in 1963. A customs union with the EU took effect in 1996. EU accession negotiations were opened in October 2005, but progress has been slow, as Turkey's Western-EU anchor has weakened over the past decade.
Political structure: Turkey is a centralised secular democratic state, but checks and balances are limited and its secular character has been weakened by the religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP), which came to power in 2002. Turkey has a history of military coups-in 1960, 1971 and 1980-leading to periods of military rule, but a coup attempt in July 2016 failed. Turkey currently has a presidential system of government, with parliament elected for a five-year term. To win seats, parties need at least 10% of the national vote, but candidates can run as independents. Since the failed coup, power has been increasingly concentrated in the hands of the AKP leader, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who was re-elected as president for a second term in June 2018. Following his re-election a presidential system of government was introduced and the post of prime minister was abolished.
Policy issues: Maintaining macroeconomic stability and stabilising the lira following the August 2018 currency crisis are Turkey's biggest policy challenges. Fiscal policy has been prudent, but large external financing needs and tightening global liquidity conditions require the Central Bank of Turkey to keep monetary policy tight to attract adequate capital inflows and slow the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar. The Kurdish issue, which has blocked economic development in the south east, is one of Turkey's most pressing policy challenges, but peace talks with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) collapsed in July 2015, and there has been a resurgence in violence. Politicisation of the judiciary since the coup attempt has undermined its independence. Corruption and patronage are widespread.
Taxation: The corporation tax rate was raised from 20% to 22% in 2018. Personal income tax rates range between 15% and 35%. Reducing tax evasion was one of the elements of previous IMF programmes, but compliance remains weak.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports totalled an estimated US$175bn and imports about US$216bn, creating a trade deficit of about US$41.8bn and a current-account deficit in the region of US$27.2bn (or 3.6% of estimated GDP). The export figure includes estimates of earnings from "suitcase trade".

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his religiously conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) have dominated Turkish politics since 2002. In June 2018 they won the presidential and parliamentary elections respectively, with the support of their coalition partner, the right-wing Nationalist Action Party (MHP). In 2017 Turkey voted narrowly in favour, amid allegations of electoral fraud in the referendum, of overhauling the constitution to move to a presidential system of government with few checks and balances on the powers of the president. The relative economic stability that the AKP delivered during the initial phase of its dominance in the early 2000s has been instrumental in the party's electoral successes, as has been Mr Erdogan's personal appeal and his religious and conservative outlook, which is shared by much of the electorate. However, since 2013 political and economic instability has increased. Rather than focus on economic reform and action to ease political and social polarisation, Mr Erdogan and his party have used their control of the state institutions and two years of emergency rule introduced after the failed coup in July 2016 to silence their critics. The AKP-MHP coalition, the People's Alliance, won a combined 52% of votes at the local election on March 30th 2019, but lost control of Turkey's major cities: Ankara, the capital, and Istanbul, although result for the latter was overturned and a rerun has been scheduled to take place on June 23rd.
Since 2013 political and economic instability has increased
The opposition National Alliance was formed ahead of the 2018 elections between the Republican People's Party (CHP; a social democratic party), the Felicity Party (SP; a smaller, conservative Islamic party), and the Good Party (IP; a small, right-wing nationalist party, formed by MHP defectors in late 2017). In recent years the CHP-the largest party in opposition, led by Kemal Kilicdaroglu-has taken an active yet often ineffective stance in defence of the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary. The party performed poorly in the 2018 elections, but the National Alliance helped the IP to cross the threshold of 10% of national votes to enter parliament. National Alliance candidates also performed well in the 2019 mayoral elections.
The pro-Kurdish, left-wing People's Democratic Party (HDP) also managed to win enough votes in the 2018 elections to enter parliament, despite Mr Erdogan's repeated attempts to delegitimise and weaken the movement. The government has accused the HDP of having links with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), a militant pro-Kurdish group.

Political outlook: Political stability
In June 2018 Mr Erdogan was re-elected for a second term in the first round of a snap presidential election. On the same day the AKP secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the MHP. The election process appeared mostly free, but largely unfair; opposition candidates received little or no media coverage, the pro-Kurdish HDP candidate, Selahattin Demirtas, had to campaign from prison, and the government restrained freedom of speech and freedom of association. Mr Erdogan secured a majority of the vote after a high turnout. Results published by opposition observers were similar to those announced by the government.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concluded Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers-including the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary-and will greatly weaken parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in July 2016, to remain in power until 2023, and probably beyond.
Mr Erdogan will continue to restrict political dissent and stifle the opposition. Despite allowing the state of emergency to expire on July 18th 2018, parliament passed a security law on July 25th that imposes stringent barriers on freedoms.
Security risk remains high, as Turkey appears vulnerable to terrorist attacks by the PKK and Islamic State (IS). Neither the govern-ment nor the PKK is interested in reviving the peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, increasing the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels. The fact that the ruling coalition is made up of the AKP and the MHP will hinder attempts to resolve the Kurdish issue, as the nationalist-minded MHP is pushing for hawkish policies aimed at constraining and delegitimising the HDP.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
For much of the AKP's 16-and-a-half years in power, political and government effectiveness improved. The economy was well managed and significant social reforms were implemented. However, in recent years intensifying domestic power struggles, a resurgence of terrorist violence since mid-2015 and a failed coup attempt in July 2016 have delayed reforms. The increased concentration of power under Mr Erdogan and his party's control of parliament suggest that policy predictability and its overall long-term suitability, especially from the perspective of foreign investors, are likely to be suboptimal.
In response to the failed coup in 2016 the government introduced emergency rule, which remained in place until July 2018 and allowed the government to carry out an extensive purge of personnel in the military, the judiciary, the police force and academic institutions suspected of having links the movement of an exiled Muslim cleric, Fethullah Gulen. The extent of the purge initially undermined institutional capacity, although most gaps appear to have now been plugged. The quality of the bureaucracy remains moderate, and we do not foresee substantial improve-ments in 2019-23. According to the World Bank's Doing Business 2019 report, there have been improvements across most categories compared with the previous report, but starting a business in Turkey requires more time, procedures and funding than in an average high-income OECD country. Paying taxes also carries a greater burden, but registering property is simpler, even though the cost has risen since the previous report. Overall, relative to some of its peers, Turkey outperforms Brazil and China, but underperforms Russia. The World Economic Forum's Global Competitiveness Report 2018 ranks Turkey 61st of 140 countries in terms of the burden of government regulation.
Since 2013 economic policymaking institutions have become increasingly politicised-a feature that will persist in the medium term. The Central Bank of Turkey, which out of necessity displayed increased monetary policy indepen-dence in 2018, will remain subject to pressure from Mr Erdogan's credit-driven growth approach to economic policymaking. The use of unorthodox policy instruments will thus remain highly probable. Nonetheless, the need to regain investor confidence and an empty electoral calendar until 2023 will enable the central bank to act with relatively more autonomy in the coming years.
Concerns about judicial impartiality and efficiency unlikely to be resolved
Concerns about the impartiality and efficiency of the legal system are unlikely to be resolved over the forecast period (2019-23), given the continued politicisation of the judiciary. An AKP constitutional reform package, which was approved by referendum in 2010, changed the appointment procedure and composition of the High Council of Judges and Prosecutors (HSYK) and the Constitutional Court. The changes facilitated the replacement of conservative secularist-nationalists in the judiciary with Gulenists, who, until 2013, were close allies of the AKP. Shortcomings in the judicial process were highlighted in coup plot investigations and trials that began in 2007. These were only addressed at appeal stage and after suspected Gulenists in the judiciary began investigating allegations of government corruption in late 2013. The purge of Gulenists from the judiciary accelerated after the failed coup. Their replacements will probably display strong loyalty to Mr Erdogan and the AKP. The upheaval is likely to increase uncertainty in the judicial process and prolong cases further. The courts' tendency to interpret the law in favour of the state and at the expense of the individual is unlikely to change, especially in cases involving minority rights and freedom of speech. In our business environment ranking we expect transparency and fairness of the judicial process to remain poor and its efficiency to deteriorate over the forecast period.
Foreign businesses operating in Turkey can reduce some of the uncertainty caused by the legal process by incorporating international arbitration clauses into their contracts. These help to shorten the time that it takes to resolve commercial dis-putes and prevent, in most cases, the need for intervention by the Turkish courts.
Corruption in the public sector is seen as a major deterrent by potential international investors. Legislation has been introduced to tackle it but implementation will continue to be a problem and political patronage is likely to remain widespread. The public procurement law of 2003 was drafted to meet EU standards, but has since been watered down and amended so that important sectors, such as transport and energy, have been excluded. Turkey has improved compliance with the OECD's anti-bribery convention.
Political outlook: Election watch
Parliamentary and presidential elections were held in June 2018 (they had originally been scheduled for late 2019). Mr Erdogan was re-elected president in the first round, securing 52.6% of the vote on a turnout of 86.2%. In the parlia-mentary election the AKP lost its absolute majority (although it secured a coalition majority alongside its partner, the MHP), as the HDP managed to win more than the 10% threshold needed to enter parliament.
Local elections took place on March 31st 2019. The AKP and the MHP retained a majority of the national vote. However, in the midst of an economic recession the ruling parties lost vital cities such as Ankara, the capital, and Istanbul, the largest city (where a rerun of the poll will be held on June 23rd). Losing major cities is a blow to the AKP given the public resources that the cities command. However, Mr Erdogan's tight grip on national institutions and the media means that he will continue to dominate Turkish politics in the coming years.
Political outlook: International relations
Domestic political and security issues will continue to shape Turkey's actions in the foreign policy sphere. Turkey's relations with the EU and the US are likely to remain antagonistic and transactional rather than strategic. We do not expect a breakdown in relations, but this forecast is highly uncertain. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations, including a perceived lack of Western solidarity with Turkey after the failed coup, US military backing for PKK-affiliated Syrian Kurdish groups, Turkey's forging of closer relations with China, Russia and Iran, and US sanctions on Turkish officials due to Turkey's detention of Andrew Brunson, a US pastor, on terrorism charges (sanctions were lifted after Mr Brunson was released in October 2018).
In 2019 relations with the US will continue to be tested owing to Turkey's decision to purchase the Russian-made S-400 missile defence system. The decision puts Turkey at risk of being excluded from the ongoing development of the F-35 fighter jet programme and of facing economic sanctions under the US Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act (CAATSA). We expect that Turkey and the US will find a solution that will enable Turkey to obtain a waiver from US sanctions or avoid them altogether. With the economy in recession, Turkey can ill afford the cost of sanctions. The US is unlikely to want to pursue a course of action that would lead to a strengthening of Turkey-Russia ties and potentially set the stage for a complete collapse in US-Turkey relations.
Relations between Turkey and EU will remain transactional
We do not expect Turkey to back down from the purchase (delivery is due in July 2019). This is due to both Mr Erdogan's desire to assert Turkey's national sovereignty and the negative effect that such an action would have on Turkey's relationship with Russia, a necessary partner in neighbouring Syria. Russia props up the regime of Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president, and maintains a large military presence in the country. Thus, a deterioration in relations could jeopardise Turkey's control of territory across the border region, from the Mediterranean to the Euphrates river-territory that was gained to block the territorial expansion of Syrian Kurds affiliated with the PKK along the border. It could also limit Turkey's influence in Idlib, a city in northern Syria, which is controlled by Islamist rebel groups. In September 2018 Turkey, Russia and Iran reached an agreement to forestall a regime offensive against Idlib. Such an attack could result in another surge of refugee flows into Turkey.
Relations between Turkey and the EU will also remain transactional, as both have a common interest in handling refugee inflows from Syria and Iraq. However, EU-Turkey relations would deteriorate quickly if the EU was to suspend Turkey's moribund accession negotiations, or if Turkey re-imposed the death penalty, closed the Incirlik air base to NATO forces or withdrew from NATO altogether.

The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment score for Turkey deterior-ates slightly in the forecast period (2019-23), and the country's global ranking falls by 11 places, to 59th. Political tensions, increased powers concentrated under the president, and inadequate policy responses to tighter global liquidity conditions and higher domestic inflation have raised the level of uncertainty about the direction of economic policy. Large external imbalances leave Turkey's economy vulnerable to shifts in investor sentiment. After several turbulent months, with a currency collapse in August 2018, the authorities adopted measures to halt speculative trades in the lira, and in September 2018 the Central Bank of Turkey raised its main policy rate by 625 basis points, to 24%. Tighter monetary policy has dampened economic activity, as expected, but it has failed so far to restore macroeconomic stability, reflecting the absence of concrete structural reform plans to correct imbalances over the medium term.
Major business environment shortcomings include the politicisation of regulatory bodies and the judicial system, cronyism and corruption, mismatches between education and labour market needs, and widespread tax evasion. In addition, the government used emergency powers over the two years to July 2018 to seize or close about 1,000 firms suspected of having links to the Gulenist movement, which the government believes staged a failed coup in 2016. The seized firms are being liquidated or sold to government-friendly groups. Foreign companies' assets have not been seized, but the erosion of the rule of law will deter foreign investors. Turkey lags most central and east European countries for foreign direct investment (FDI). Major attractions for investors include Turkey's geographic location, its potential market size, its young and growing population, a customs union with the EU, free foreign-exchange and capital flows, and a large and dynamic private sector.
