Business environment outlook: Turkey's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Political instability and adverse market conditions will delay further privatisation deals.
2021-23: Networks of patronage remain a constraint on the free market. Competition is still limited in several sectors.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) remains a government priority, but macroeconomic instability and concerns about security, corruption and politicisation of the judicial system will curb inflows.
2021-23: Further privatisation and government incentives to attract investment in major sectors boost FDI inflows.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Capital controls are not considered, despite the scale of the currency collapse in 2018-19. Political tensions resulting in tit-for-tat tariffs and US sanctions will disrupt Turkish-US trade and relations.
2021-23: Negotiations with the EU to update the customs union are likely to be protracted, given poor Turkish-EU relations.
Taxes
2019-20: Efforts to improve tax collection and prevent evasion make limited progress. Tax rises introduced in 2018 to curb the widening of the budget deficit reduce company profits.
2021-23: Income tax base becomes broader as exemptions and exceptions are reduced, but evasion remains widespread.
Financing
2019-20: Asset quality likely to deteriorate on the back of financial market turmoil in 2018-19. Central Bank of Turkey to lower rates gradually as inflation moderates in 2019. Risk of the US imposing fines or sanctions on some Turkish banks.
2021-23: Lending growth to pick up again as banking system regains strength. Continued reliance on volatile capital inflows amid tighter global liquidity continues.
The labour market
2019-20: Relatively high labour costs, low workforce participation and widespread informal employment. Mismatches between education and labour market needs persist.
2021-23: Some improvements for employers, with legislation on severance pay and more flexible employment regulation.
Infrastructure
2019-20: First phase of third airport in Istanbul becomes operational. Slower progress made on other projects.
2021-23: Landmark road and bridge projects near completion. Other major urban infrastructure projects around Istanbul could progress. Nevertheless, gaps and bottlenecks might persist.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Spending on research and development remains moderate, at about 1% of GDP, holding back efforts to move the economy up the value-added ladder.
2021-23: Turkey's young population spurs further rapid digital transformation of the banking sector.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.8 5.5 70 75 18 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The quality of economic policymaking and its institutional underpinnings have deteriorated in recent years. Under the executive presidential system Recep Tayyip Erdogan has used his new powers to extend his control over the central bank and other nominally independent authorities, which has resulted in inadequate macroeconomic policies and a loss of foreign investor confidence in economic decision-making. Relative to 2017-18, we should see some improve-ment in the country's policy stance in 2019-23 (following the June 2019 Istanbul election re-run), given that the next election isn't until until 2023. However, progress is likely to be insufficient to substantially improve investor confidence in policy. Mr Erdogan will be likely to continue to favour a pro-growth approach to economic policy-making (not least to avoid potential social discontent).
Turkey's economy has shown resilience during past bouts of political and financial instability, largely owing to the country's solid public finances, and its well-capitalised and well-regulated banking sector. Turkey's public debt is currently low, at just under 30% of GDP, but increased public borrowing to support economic activity after the failed coup in 2016 has resulted in a steady widening of the budget deficit. Despite promising to maintain fiscal discipline to help to curb inflation, we expect the government to provide further support to the economy in the current slowdown and seek to address the risks to banks stemming from a sharp rise in non-performing loans (NPLs), in order to revive lending growth. Credit-driven economic growth will eventually feed through into higher levels of indebtedness and a widening of the current-account deficit, which has narrowed sharply in 2018-19. The financial system will remain vulnerable to political interference, high levels of private-sector foreign-currency debt, lira weakness and tighter global liquidity conditions.
Volatile domestic demand, reliance on indirect taxation, limited price competition in some sectors-particularly agriculture-and the sensitivity of prices to exchange-rate and commodity-price movements will make it difficult to reduce consumer price inflation to the officially targeted 5% in the medium term. Although down from the 2018 peak of 25% year on year in October 2018 caused by the sharp depreciation of the lira in July-August, inflation remained high, at just below 20% in February-April 2019.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.8 5.8 42 48 17 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Turkey has a large and dynamic private sector, and private property is generally well protected. However, the country's score and ranking will remain low in this category in the forecast period owing to the significant role of the state in many sectors, widespread political patronage and corruption, and politicisation of the legal system. The use of emergency powers introduced in response to the failed coup in 2016 to seize or close firms suspected of having links to the Gulenist movement has created uncertainty, particularly because of limited access to legal redress. The state of emergency was lifted in July 2018, but the security law passed in that same month and the concentration of power under Mr Erdogan means that a high degree of uncertainty will continue in the medium term.
Weak rule of law has created uncertainty
We expect government support for private-sector investment and employ-ment to continue. This will come through incentives such as tax breaks, and social security and credit subsidies, with an emphasis on underdeveloped regions, technology, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), production of currently imported intermed-iary goods and "strategic" sectors (such as defence, aerospace, automotive and pharmaceuticals). After the failed coup the Ministry of Treasury and Finance expanded its guarantees for banks, allowing them to lend to riskier customers, but it must now address the risks to banks from a sharp increase in NPLs. The government is seeking to help Turkish banks to clear their balance sheets and has pledged to inject TL28bn (US$4.7bn) into state banks to shore up capital reserves and stimulate fresh lending.
Government is seeking to help banks to clear their balance sheets
Free competition is likely to remain the norm in most sectors. The Competition Board has power over mergers and acquisitions (M&A), price-fixing and abuse of market position. Like most other regulatory agencies, however, the Competition Board will have limited effective independence, as it is appointed by the president. The state is also likely to remain dominant in many of the sectors in which it plays a leading role, such as gas and water, rail transport, tea and sugar production, infrastructure, and social services (including healthcare and education). The state also has a significant position in banking (about 30% of total assets), mining, the defence industry, postal services and legal gambling, and retains large stakes in Turk Telekom (30%) and Turkish Airlines (49%). There is a state-owned broadcaster (TRT) and a state-owned home-builder (TOKI). There are also sectors in which one or more private firms, including privatised companies, hold strong market positions.
Despite frequent legal challenges, privatisation is well advanced in numerous sectors, including oil refining, parts of the energy sector, steel, mobile telecommunications, and tobacco and alcoholic drinks. The sale of power-distribution networks has been completed, and the government aims to continue divesting some generation assets. However, we expect the slowdown in the pace of privatisation since 2014 to continue during the forecast period, owing to market volatility and the government's focus on retaining control and enhancing the value of strategic assets.
State assets transferred to the Turkey Wealth Fund unlikely to be privatised
Assets that have been slated for privatisation include operating rights for more ports, the national lottery and horse racing concessions, shares in toll roads and bridges, TOKI, Vakifbank, more power plants, Istanbul's municipal companies, and some state-owned land. Control of the three main state banks-Halkbank, Ziraat and Vakif bank-looks set to remain in state hands. These banks may sometimes be used as a source of patronage.
The establishment in 2016 of the Turkey Wealth Fund has removed some government assets from the control of the privatisation agency. The wealth fund is designed to help to finance large public works by using its assets as collateral, making sales of the assets under its control less likely. The fund now includes assets such as the state's stake in Turkish Airlines, Halkbank, Turk Telekom, Ziraat Bank, Borsa Istanbul and Botas-an oil and gas pipeline operator.
Price controls operate for various reasons in electricity, gas, petroleum, telecoms and pharmaceuticals. Competition will continue to be constrained by the large shadow economy; the smuggling of petroleum products, cigarettes and many other items; and the violation of intellectual property rights in many sectors, from software to fashion.
Political patronage and exclusive business networks will continue to play a significant role in business life. Companies close to government circles may be boldest in entering public tenders or operating in sectors where major decisions are taken by politicians, regulators or bureaucrats. Industrial policy may facilitate favouritism or uncompetitive arrangements. Some companies may face higher bureaucratic obstacles or tougher tax inspections than others.
Build-operate-transfer (BOT) or public-private partnership (PPP) schemes will increase the role of the private sector in the management of airports, water and irrigation facilities, and hospitals. The railways are being restructured, and the rail network has been separated from train services. The state will continue to play a dominant role in the sector for some time to come, as so far only a few freight rail transport licences have been granted to private operators.
Despite public ownership of major assets, a more liberalised energy sector will emerge as a result of privatisation, new investments, the Electricity Market Law of March 2013 and changes in regulations that will widen consumer choice over power providers. A wholesale trading platform aimed at setting a reliable market price for electricity has been established. Gas market reform is likely to continue to lag behind that of the electricity sector.
There is scope for further improvement in the protection of intellectual property. Legislation has been gradually brought in line with EU practices. In particular, a single, unified industrial property law came into force in January 2017 that replaced a patchwork of decrees regulating trademarks, patents, designs and geographical indications. Both Turkish and foreign companies are increas-ingly sensitive to this issue, so there is also likely to be progress in enforcement.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment

6.4 6.0 48 59 17 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Foreign direct investment will continue to be welcomed in most cases
Turkey's score and ranking deteriorates in this category in the forecast period, even though the government and most sections of society regard FDI in a positive light, and high levels of foreign ownership in industry and services are widely accepted and respected. Turkey's heavy dependency on foreign-capital inflows gives the government additional incentives to attract FDI. A law passed in 2012 has boosted sales of property to foreigners by easing restrictions and waiving the condition of reciprocity for most countries. However, foreign-ownership is restricted in a few areas, including broadcasting and civil aviation, and the government has become more suspicious of foreign capital. The courts and sections of the public are also occasionally hostile towards foreign investors when environmental issues or natural resources are at stake. Turkey's politicised judicial system, its poor record on corruption and widespread political patronage remain major deterrents for potential foreign investors.
Privatisation in energy and other sectors may provide opportunities for foreign investors, often in conjunction with local partners. The government will especially promote FDI in greenfield and expansion projects that can further its industrial policy goals, including import substitution and technological innovation. Low asset valuations as a result of the depreciation of the lira against most major currencies in 2018-19 may also attract investors, particularly to export-oriented firms that have receipts in US dollars.
In principle, foreign investors will continue to have the same access to government incentives as domestic investors do. Plans to improve the general investment environment by cutting red tape and streamlining the legal system will benefit foreign as well as domestic businesses. Restrictions on repatriation of profits are highly unlikely, even at times of financial market stress.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.8 8.2 45 41 17 16
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Political rifts with trading partners have caused disruption to bilateral trade
As a member of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) with a customs union with the EU, Turkey remains committed to a broadly open trading regime. However, global trade tensions and political rifts with trading partners have periodically caused disruption to bilateral trade and exacerbated exchange-rate volatility. Russian restrictions following the downing of a Russian military jet on the Turkish-Syrian border in 2015 imposed severe losses on the Turkish agri-culture and tourism sectors in 2016. In 2018 escalating tensions with the US resulted in tit-for-tat sanctions and tariffs on aluminium and steel trade between the two countries. Under the 1996 customs union with the EU, Turkey has customs-free trade in manufactured goods with EU member states and has adopted the EU common customs tariff. However, the country has refused to grant Greek Cypriot ships and planes access to its ports and airports unless the EU facilitates direct trade between the EU and the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus (TRNC), which is only currently recognised by Turkey. Turkey's import regime reflects the EU's free-trade agreements (FTAs). It has bilateral FTAs with the European Free-Trade Association (EFTA).
The Turkish lira has been fully convertible since 1989, and the authorities have not considered introducing capital-account controls, even during recent periods of severe exchange-rate and financial market volatility. The authorities in Turkey are keenly aware of the reputational damage that capital controls could cause, including potentially impeding Turkey's access to international financial markets for several years.
The government is unlikely to resort to outright protectionism, despite its efforts to encourage domestic production of items currently imported in large quantities. However, short-term protective measures will continue to be employed to limit imports of textiles, petrochemicals and other items from lower-cost countries. Some restrictions on agricultural imports exist, but, concerned by high food price inflation, the authorities have in recent years tinkered with tariffs and quotas in order to lower prices.
Turkey and the EU have agreed to revisit the current customs union agreement with a view to expanding it to potentially cover agricultural goods, services and public procurement, but talks have not yet started. Some EU politicians have suggested that talks should be linked to political criteria. If this were to be the case, the chances of reaching an agreement any time soon would be low. Turkey is negotiating or pursuing FTAs with several other economies, especially countries such as Mexico and Japan, which signed FTAs with the EU in 2018.
In the absence of a Cyprus settlement, Turkey is likely to resist EU pressure to open ports and airports to Greek Cypriot ships and planes. Similarly, without progress in its EU accession negotiations, Turkey is unlikely to lift restrictions on EU meat and used-car imports, eliminate discriminatory taxes on alcoholic drinks and tobacco products, or open up trade in services.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.4 6.1 58 59 16 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
As a percentage of GDP, tax revenue is low by OECD standards, owing to high levels of evasion and limited administrative capacity. According to OECD figures, tax revenue (including social security contributions) comprises about 25% of GDP, compared with an OECD average of about 34% (2017 data). The corporate tax rate was raised from 20% to 22% in 2018 for a period of three years. Personal income tax rates range from 15% to 35%. The tax-free allowance for wage and salary earners varies from the equivalent of 50-90% of the minimum wage, according to the number of their dependants. Seventy percent of tax revenue comes from indirect taxes, including value-added tax (VAT), which is levied at a standard rate of 18% (with lower rates of 8% and 1% for some items), and special consumption taxes on some goods and services such as petroleum, alcohol, tobacco products, motor vehicles, telecoms services and banking transactions.
Obligatory social security contributions normally consist of 20.5% of gross salary (up to a certain limit) from the employer, 14% from the employee and a combined total of 3% to the Unemployment Insurance Fund from both parties. Tax breaks, social security premium reductions and incentives are available to encourage investment in underdeveloped regions, important sectors and technological innovation, as well as to support employment.
Frequent changes in tax regulation and evasion are likely to persist
Frequent changes in tax regulation are likely to persist, as will widespread tax and social security evasion, which is encouraged by frequent amnesties and opportunities to restructure arrears. The latest example was announced in May 2018, mainly to garner political support ahead of the snap presidential and parliamentary elections. Plans to simplify the tax system have been on the government agenda for some time, but have been consistently postponed.
Foreign firms will continue to be treated in the same way as Turkish companies. During the forecast period Turkey is expected to expand the already large number of double taxation agreements that it has with other countries.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.6 5.9 28 56 10 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
The banking system is solid, but its vulnerability has increased
Turkey's financing score and rankings deteriorate during the forecast period, reflecting the banking sector's increased vulnerability in recent years to political interference, financial market volatility, currency weakness, high levels of private-sector foreign-currency debt and tighter global liquidity conditions. Reforms introduced under the guidance of the IMF and the World Bank in the wake of the financial crisis in Turkey in 2000-01 transformed the banking sector so that it has been well regulated, well capitalised and highly profitable. Three state-controlled banks and four large private banks dominate the sector, accounting for about 75% of total assets. The state banks have largely operated on a commercial basis, and government intervention in the private sector has been rare. However, after periodic surges in bank lending growth since 2010-driven by falling government borrowing needs, strong domestic and global liquidity, as well as government credit guarantees and pressure on banks to lend more and at lower interest rates-Turkish banks have become increasingly vulnerable to the risks from a sharp rise in NPLs as a result of the economic downturn triggered by the collapse of the lira in 2018-19. In the first seven months of 2018 bank credit to the non-financial sector expanded at an average annual rate of about 23%, but since the financial market turmoil in 2018 it has slowed sharply, to about 12% in the first quarter of 2019. NPLs have been increasing rapidly since mid-2018, rising by 62.5% year on year in March 2019.
Tighter global liquidity and high levels of corporate debt will restrict credit to the private sector, especially households and small businesses. However, the strongest Turkish companies, like banks, will continue to have access to loans from foreign banks and to local and international bond markets, albeit at high interest rates by international standards.
With economic activity slowing sharply and debt servicing more onerous, because of the weakness of the lira and higher interest rates, NPLs will continue to rise sharply. As at March 2019 the ratio of NPLs to total credit reached 4.4%-its highest level since November 2010, up from just 3.1% as at August 2018. Low domestic savings will also remain a constraint. The government has pledged further changes to the private pension system, which if implemented would help to increase the availability of finance with longer maturities, albeit only over the medium term.
Difficult financial conditions are likely to slow further the pace of share offerings on the volatile Borsa Istanbul, the country's main stock exchange. Market capitalisation is low and falling, at about 20% of GDP at end-2018, down from about 28% in 2017. About two-thirds of the free float is foreign-owned during periods of financial stability, but this figure has declined as a result of the sell-off of Turkish assets since April 2018. As at early May 2019 BIST 100, Turkey's benchmark share price index, was up by about 2% on end-2018, following a decline of about 21% in 2018.
Changes in bank ownership may occur, particularly among smaller banks, without changing the overall structure of the sector. The current government's antipathy towards private bank owners and sympathy for consumers and credit customers will encourage tighter regulation of certain banking activities, such as credit-card issuance.
In late 2017 a deputy managing director of Halkbank was convicted in New York of bank fraud and conspiracy to violate US sanctions on Iran. The case has raised the possibility of fines or sanctions against HalkBank or other Turkish entities. Such a decision would further raise risks for the banking sector. In December 2018 the bank announced that it would issue up to US$2bn in Eurobonds-the first such issuance since the arrest of the bank executive.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.2 6.2 36 41 13 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
We do not expect any improvement in Turkey's labour market score in the forecast period. There is a large, young labour pool, but workforce participation is only about 52%, partly owing to traditions that discourage female employment. Despite a greater number of years of formal education, the average level of education and skills remains below average European standards, and mismatches between education and the needs of the labour market persist. Employment of foreigners is rare, and obtaining work permits can be problematic, but some restrictions have been eased. Informal employment and subcontracting are common ways of avoiding tax, legal obligations and rigidities, and create unfair competition, undermine safety standards and hinder product-ivity gains. In formal employment, hours and conditions are generally regulated and inflexible. The seasonally adjusted jobless rate rose by 3.5 percentage points, to 13.3%, in the 12 months to January 2019 (14.7% unadjusted). The adjusted youth unemployment rate reached 24.5%, close to a ten-year high.
In response to employers' complaints about high labour costs, the government has sought to lighten the burden of social security contributions, especially for underdeveloped regions and the employment of young people, women and people with disabilities. Following rises of 30% in 2016, 8% in 2017, an estimated 14% in 2018 and a forecast 26% in 2019, the monthly gross minimum wage is relatively high in Turkish lira terms, at TL2,020. However, it has fallen sharply in US dollar terms, to about US$340, as a result of the depreciation of the lira, which has also weighed on growth in real wages owing to higher inflation rates.
The change to severance pay may take several years to implement
Companies complain that the system of severance pay, under which employers are liable to pay substantial lump sums to employees who retire, or are made redundant, is too generous, hindering formal hiring. The government's plan is to establish a severance pay fund, to which employers will contribute, but the plan has met with resistance from unions. The change to severance pay may take some years to implement.
The government aims to make the labour market more flexible while improving access to unemployment benefits. We expect the use of flexible employment contracts in the formal sector to increase only slowly. Labour market activation and education policies will raise skills levels and workforce participation only gradually. Despite the government's commitment to reducing it, unregistered employment is likely to remain a significant issue throughout the forecast period.
Restrictions on union membership, strikes and lock-outs that are incompatible with international norms promoted by the International Labour Organisation (ILO) and the EU are unlikely to be lifted. Unions may be influential in a few sectors, but are unlikely to become stronger or more militant.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.3 4.5 64 69 18 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Turkey's infrastructure is broadly adequate for doing business. In recent years investment by national and local governments, as well as the private sector, have led to some visible improvements, ranging from rapid growth of domestic air travel to the gradual extension of the natural gas pipeline network to almost all provinces, and the spread of broadband internet access and mobile-phone services. The Justice and Development Party (AKP) government's preference has been for large infrastructure projects with several grandiose projects in the pipeline. The contract for the construction and subsequent operation of a 3.9-km-long suspension bridge over the Dardanelles was awarded to a three-company consortium, including Limak, one of the contractors of the new Istanbul airport project, in 2017. Canal Istanbul, a canal linking the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara, and a three-tier undersea tunnel across the Bosphorus are also in the process of being tendered.
Fixed-line broadband internet access has expanded rapidly, but, at an estimated 16.3% in 2018, the penetration rate was still well below an average of 30-40% for most other European countries. Including large and rapidly rising numbers of mobile broadband subscriptions, the penetration rate is much higher. The take-up of fourth-generation (4G and 4.5G) technology launched in 2016 has been strong.
Major infrastructure projects are under way, but shortcomings persist
Infrastructure shortcomings-including urban overcrowding, congestion, earthquake risk, and strains on water supply, waste disposal systems and the energy network-will persist in most cities. Rural infrastructure should improve a little in most places. Major irrigation works will proceed slowly.
Improvements in road and rail transport infrastructure will be piecemeal, and as a whole will continue to lag behind EU standards, especially given the long distances between cities. Public and private investment will ensure that seaport capacity expands, despite bottlenecks and incomplete privatisation of management rights at some state-owned ports.
Energy sector privatisation and market liberalisation will continue gradually. Legislation facilitating the privatisation of lignite reserves is being implemented. Private investment (coupled with limited public investment) may be enough to increase power-generation capacity, cut transmission and distribution losses and prevent blackouts. Policies favouring energy generation from local and renewable sources will help to reduce gradually reliance on imported fuels.
We expect legislation to encourage private-sector oil and gas exploration to lead to an intensification of offshore activity in the Black Sea and the Mediterranean. The government is exploring the possibility of exploiting shale gas in the south east and other parts of Turkey. Plans to construct two nuclear plants are highly controversial. If built, they will not come on stream until the early 2020s.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.5 5.5 50 58 17 18
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 18 countries: Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the UK.
Turkey ranks 58th with Kazakhstan and Indonesia in the global rankings for technological readiness in the forecast period, but well behind Russia (33rd), Bulgaria (38th), and Romania (43rd)-some of its main competitors for FDI.
E-commerce is growing rapidly, but growth is from a low base
E-commerce is growing rapidly, reflecting steady improvements in the online environment in areas such as security and after-sales service, but growth is from a low base with online purchases accounting for only about 4% of total retail sales, compared with about 10% in developed economies. As in most countries, the number of fixed-line subscriptions has declined steadily, but mobile-phone penetration has risen rapidly, reaching almost 100% in 2018. Intense competition in the mobile-telecoms sector should ensure that infrastructure remains adequate and up to date, although there may be delays in adopting the latest technology or it may initially be expensive or concentrated in major cities. Computer ownership has risen rapidly. According to the Turkish Statistical Institute (Turkstat), an estimated 84% of households had access to the internet in 2018, up from about 30% in 2009.
Research and development (R&D) spending in Turkey rose only marginally in 2017, to 1% of GDP. However, given that nominal GDP growth was about 19% in that year, R&D spending rose strongly in nominal terms, which we expect to continue during the forecast period. R&D spending is significantly greater than in Romania and broadly in line with that in Greece, Bulgaria, Poland and Russia (which averaged 0.9-1% of GDP in 2017). As in most emerging economies, large, export-oriented private-sector firms account for the bulk of R&D spending in Turkey. The automotive sector, which is largely comprised of joint ventures between Turkish conglomerates and major global auto producers, accounted for 14% of total R&D spending in 2017.
FDI will continue to be the main driver of investment in technology and innovation. According to data from the Turkish Patent and Trademark Office, about 60% of total patent applications are foreign. As FDI into Turkey gradually recovers in our forecast period, we expect R&D spending to increase progressively.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The government's past focus on domestic power struggles and foreign policy challenges has blocked the economic reforms needed to improve the business and investment climate. Nonetheless, Turkey's economy has shown resilience during previous bouts of political instability and global financial market volatility, owing to its solid public finances, its well-capitalised banking sector, and its dynamic and diversified private sector. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the currency crisis in 2018 and the ensuing recession to put severe pressure on the government's finances, business sector solvency and banks' balance sheets.
With the March 2019 local elections out of the way, the rerun of the Istanbul poll scheduled for June, and the next parliamentary and presidential elections not due until mid-2023, the government will soon be in a position to defuse domestic political tensions and take a more long-term approach to policy-making. This would help to revive investor confidence and foster sustainable economic growth, reversing the pattern of the past three years of ad hoc policy measures, which boosted the economy but exacerbated Turkey's macro-economic imbalances and diminished the government's credibility. However, an element of unpredictability and unorthodoxy will remain. The economy is in recession and, following its recent poor performance in local elections, the Justice and Development Party (AKP) will continue to feel under pressure to support growth. Shortcomings such as cronyism and corruption, skills mis-matches (a major factor behind the high unemployment rate) and tax evasion are unlikely to be addressed in the 2019-23 forecast period.
Should the recent currency crisis trigger a banking crisis (not our core forecast), Turkey's options would remain limited, as Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries appear unwilling to offer financial support. This is because Turkey is forging closer ties with Iran, a country with which Saudi Arabia has tense relations. Turkey's ties with Saudi Arabia deteriorated (from an already low base) after Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist, was murdered in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul in October 2018. Furthermore, any potential IMF programme would include a level of foreign involvement that the government would be likely to view as unacceptable, and that would run counter to nationalist, anti-Western rhetoric of the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Only China appears able at present to offer a financial lifeline to Turkey (perhaps as part of China's Belt and Road Initiative).
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy
Fiscal indicators

Budget balance -2.0 -2.3 -2.1 -2.2 -1.9 -1.7

Under the AKP, the public finances have been one of the Turkish economy's most reassuring aspects. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past.
Despite several tax increases in 2018 and official promises of budgetary tightening, higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits caused the deficit to widen in 2018, to 2% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2017.
In 2019-23 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy (concerns about off-balance sheet trends will persist). This, alongside a recovering economy, will cause the deficit to narrow gradually, from a forecast 2.3% in 2019 to 1.7% of GDP in 2023.
The central government debt/GDP ratio deteriorated slightly in 2018, rising to 28.9% of GDP in 2018 (from 28.3% in 2017), in the context of economic turmoil after the August currency crisis and various government handouts ahead of the June 2018 elections. The ratio will decline slightly, to about 26.5% by end-2023 as macroeconomic conditions normalise and the budget deficit shrinks.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
3-month money market rate (av) 19.8 22.9 14.5 12.5 10.0 9.5
Deposit rate (av) 18.1 21.0 15.3 13.0 10.5 10.0
In September 2018 the Central Bank of Turkey's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) raised its main policy rate, the one-week repo (repurchase agreement) lending rate, to 24%, from 17.75% previously. The MPC's decision was a response to the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August, as well as the record rise in annual consumer price inflation. The average cost of central bank funding is currently above the main policy rate, however. The bank is providing funding for the banking system at its overnight lending rates, which are 1.5-3% greater than the one-week repo rate.
At its meeting on April 25th the MPC kept its one-week repo lending rate unchanged, at 24%. We expect the central bank to keep monetary policy tight in the first half of 2019. From mid-2019 to 2020 the central bank will lower gradually its policy rate in response to declining inflationary pressures and a normalisation of financial market conditions. In 2021-23 we believe that the central bank will continue to overshoot its inflation target of 5%. This reflects the government's continued pro-growth stance; it will put pressure on the central bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to lower inflation to the 5% target.

Government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand caused real GDP growth to accelerate to 7.3% in 2017 (from 3.3% in 2016), but this surge exacerbated internal and external imbalances. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredictability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short-term capital inflows, tighter global liquidity and a diplomatic spat with the US-contributed to the lira losing about 40% of its value against the US dollar in January-August 2018. The sharp depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of large foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dented the economic outlook. The crisis pushed the Turkish economy into recession in the second half of 2018, which we expect to continue in the first quarter of 2019, resulting in a contraction in full-year real GDP of 1.7% in 2019 on average (mainly due to base effects), followed by annual average growth of 3.7% per year in 2020-23.
In 2020 we expect growth to rebound to 4.1% as the economy recovers and spare capacity is depleted. In 2021-23 economic growth will average about 3.6% per year. There are substantial downside risks to our forecasts: these growth profiles do not reflect the possible impact of a severe banking crisis (not our core scenario), although we expect non-performing loans to rise and credit availability to be impaired in the coming quarters.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
As in most developing countries, the share of agriculture in nominal GDP has declined steadily in Turkey in recent decades, but at 6.4% of gross value added in 2018 agriculture remains an important sector, especially considering the input that it makes to Turkey's food, beverages and tobacco manufacturing industry. In addition, agriculture still accounts for a substantial share-of about 19%-of total employment, although almost half of those employed in the sector are classified as unpaid family workers. We expect the share of output of the primary sector to remain broadly stable during the forecast period, but it will remain large compared with most other European countries, at more than 6% of GDP in 2023. In 2016 the sector was hit by Russian sanctions on agricultural imports from Turkey, but most were lifted by mid-2017 following the rapprochement between the two countries in June 2016. The sector would benefit from investment in irrigation in the south east of the country and in some other regions, but investment is likely to remain on hold in areas affected by the conflict with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). More generally, the importance of modern, large-scale agricultural enterprises will spread gradually, but the problems of traditional agriculture and unclear policymaking are likely to persist.
Manufacturing will continue to play central role in the Turkish economy
Industry, including manufacturing, mining and construction, accounted for about 31% of GDP in 2018. The collapse in investment and export demand during the 2008-09 global crisis hit the manufacturing and construction sectors hardest. Since then manufacturing, and particularly construction, has re-bounded. In 2018 manufacturing accounted for about 21% of GDP, compared with about 25% at the end of the 1990s. Having fallen as low as 6.3% of GDP in 2009, the share of GDP generated by the construction sector rose to 9.7% in 2016 and 2017, before sliding back to 8% in 2018 as activity in the sector contracted.
Construction was a significant driver of economic growth in 2010-17. In 2017 real value added in the sector, which is dominated by housing construction and mega infrastructure projects, expanded by 9%, following growth of about 5% in the previous three years. The pace of housing construction outstripped demand for several years, even after allowing for strong demographically driven growth in the number of households and the continued replacement of existing buildings. In 2017 growth was bolstered by a strong expansion in credit as a result of pressure by the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, on banks to lower mortgage rates; the indirect effect of the credit guarantee fund; the relaxation of macroprudential measures and ample global international liquidity. This has resulted in a reported 1.5m-2m new homes being unoccupied, a situation that has weakened developers' finances and reduced the incentive for new investments. Infrastructure and building investments via public-private partnerships, which have picked up significantly over the past five years, have also contributed to robust construction growth. In 2018 construction output declined by 1.9%, and this weakness is likely to persist into 2019 given the oversupply of housing, rising NPLs in the sector, the depreciation of the lira against the US dollar, high interest rates and the slowdown in economic growth.
Although several manufacturing subsectors, such as automotive, and textiles and clothing, are strongly export-oriented and will continue to generate trade surpluses, Turkey's manufactured exports are generally import intensive. A large portion of the inputs-including energy, intermediates and capital goods-are imported, adding to Turkey's external imbalances, especially when inter-national commodity prices are high or the lira is weak, as it has been since mid-2013. This structural situation is unlikely to change much during the forecast period, as reducing the import intensity of exports and moving up the value-added chain will take time, even though these were explicit goals in the government's investment-incentive system, which was introduced in 2012.
Vehicle production will fluctuate in line with demand in Europe
The automotive sector was Turkey's biggest exporter in 2018, with exports valued at about US$21.9bn (including automotive parts), up from US$20.1bn in 2017, according to the Automotive Manufacturers Association (OSD). Despite the increase in value terms, there was a decline in overall production in real terms. Turkey runs a considerable trade surplus in its automotive sector, and this surplus has expanded owing to strong export demand but also import restrictions and the weak currency. Output fell by 8.6% in 2018 compared with 2017 (when production rose by 14%), but, boosted by the weaker lira, the US dollar value of exports rose by 10.3%, according to the OSD. Output of passenger cars was down by 10.2% year on year in 2018, and commercial vehicle production fell by 5.3%. In the first three months of 2019 car production fell another 17.4% year on year and truck output declined 16.6% year on year.
Most vehicle manufacturers will maintain facilities in Turkey
Almost 80% of motor vehicles produced in Turkey are exported, and the bulk of these go to the EU (Turkey accounts for almost 30% of vehicles imported by the EU). As a result, vehicle production will fluctuate in line with demand in Europe. Demand in Europe picked up between mid-2013 and mid-2018, reflecting the release of pent-up demand after several years of weakness and a broadening of the economic recovery across Europe. Demand in Europe has weakened since mid-2018, but the significant depreciation of the lira against the US dollar and euro is likely to continue to support firm export volumes over the medium term. Given its location and its trade agreement with the EU, Turkey will remain an important automotive hub, but political uncertainties will weigh on investor confidence. Over the medium term, considering the growth potential of the automotive market in Turkey and the wider region, manufacturers with production plants in Turkey may start to focus more on the Turkish, Middle Eastern and North African markets. Over the medium term the domestic market will be supported by rising incomes and replacement demand.
We believe that most manufacturers will maintain their production facilities in Turkey. These facilities are technologically advanced, and labour costs are much lower in Turkey than in core European countries, and probably lower than those in most central and east European countries, where wages have risen strongly following accession to the EU. However, if Turkey is to remain a major automotive production location in the medium to long term, manufacturers will have to move away from exporting low-end passenger cars, light commercial vehicles (LCVs) and components to north European markets, and towards developing and producing alternative energy engines and vehicles. There are signs that this transition is already happening; in 2017 sales of electric and hybrid cars rose by more than 350%, to 4,528 units, according to data from Turkey's Electric and Hybrid Vehicles Association. The market will be supported by recent cuts to taxes on hybrid and electric vehicles.
The textiles and clothing industries remain important
The textiles and clothing industries remain important to the Turkish economy, accounting for 16.3% of the country's export revenues in 2018. The industries have undergone restructuring under the intense pressure of competition from low-cost producers in Asia. The government has also been looking at ways to improve investment incentives and target higher value-added products. In the short term, high-frequency indicators suggest that both these industries will suffer from subdued domestic demand. However, over the medium term a more competitive currency and ample growth potential will underpin robust growth prospects. Competitive pressures from lower-cost centres of production will remain a risk.
Production of industrial machinery, and of white goods and other household durables, including furniture, recovered strongly as a result of a pick-up in domestic demand and export opportunities in 2010-11. After more moderate domestic and external demand dampened growth in output in 2012-16, growth surged in 2017 alongside the boom in housing and credit, but a weak lira in 2018 is likely to have curbed domestic demand. We expect Turkish consumer electronics companies to continue to be major exporters, although subdued domestic demand will constrain the sector in the near term. Businesses in the sector appear to have been slow to adopt technological innovations in some segments.
Reduced security concerns and price competitiveness will drive tourism growth
Tourism, one of the most important services sectors of the Turkish economy, has witnessed rapid growth in the past ten years, but remains vulnerable to geopolitical developments and changes in the exchange rate. Having reached a new record of 37m in 2014, the number of foreign visitors (excluding Turkish citizens living abroad) dipped slightly in 2015, reflecting mainly the impact of EU/US trade sanctions on the Russian economy (visitors from Russia, Turkey's second-largest tourist market, fell by 18.5%) and perceived security concerns following a spate of terrorist attacks in the second half of the year. In 2016 tourism was hit hard by Russian sanctions, which have now been lifted, and by terrorist attacks. Figures from the Ministry of Culture and Tourism put the total number of foreign visitor arrivals in 2016 at 25.4m-a year-on-year fall of 30%. In 2017 the number of foreign visitors rebounded, rising by an annual average of 27.8% per year. In 2018 the number of foreign visitors rose by 21.8%, to 39.5m, as visitors from Russia rose to a record 6m, from just 866,000 two years earlier (when bilateral relations hit a low point and Russia imposed sanctions on Turkey). Visitors from other European countries remained unchanged in 2017 from 2016 levels, when the number plummeted by 31.1%, to 13.2m, from 19.1m in 2015. Strong growth in visitors from countries such as Germany and the UK in 2018 suggest that security concerns are no longer deterring visitors from those important markets. The pronounced depreciation of the lira will contribute to robust growth in tourism inflows in the coming years.

In full-year 2018 the currency crisis and rising global commodity prices drove inflation higher, to 16.3% (from 11.1% in 2017). In 2019 inflation will remain elevated in the first half of the year and then moderate gradually on the back of a limited depreciation of the lira (against the US dollar), a lower average global oil price and the emergence of spare capacity in the economy. Accommodative fiscal policies in response to the economic weakness in the final months of 2018 will prevent inflation from declining faster than would otherwise be the case. On average, we forecast inflation of 16.1% in 2019-only marginally slower than the 2018 rate-slowing to 6.9% in 2023.
We expect the moderating trend in inflation to continue in 2020, with an average inflation rate of 10.2% as global oil prices continue to decline (owing to a slowdown in the global economy) and the exchange rate depreciates slightly (in nominal terms) against the US dollar. In 2021-23 we expect inflation to stabilise at an annual average of about 7.2%-still more than the central bank's medium-term target of 5%. Economic growth in these years will be close to the economy's potential growth rate (limiting upward inflationary pressures).

In 2018 the lira depreciated by 24.5% on average against the US dollar (in nominal terms). The lira depreciated significantly in January-August, with the exchange rate briefly reaching a low point of TL7.2:US$1 on August 13th. After a substantial recovery from September, the lira remained broadly stable against the US dollar for the remainder of the year. In the first months of 2019 the lira has again depreciated against the US dollar owing to political uncertainty and polarising campaign rhetoric around the March local elections, declining central bank foreign-exchange reserves, the re-emergence of tensions with the US-this time owing to Turkey's purchase of the Russian-made defence system-and the rerun of the Istanbul mayoral race following the AKP's defeat.
The lira again surpassed TL6:US$1 in early May, and we expect a gradual appreciation from this level in the second half of the year and a year-end exchange rate of about TL:5.70:US$1. This forecast rests on our expectation that Turkey and the US will resolve their disputes, that government policy will be credibly reoriented and that the central bank will maintain a tight monetary policy stance, lowering interest rates only as price pressures fade. There are large risks to this forecast, both in terms of probability and impact. If any of our expectations do not materialise, the lira could again depreciate substantially.
Economic forecast: External sector
In 2020 we expect the exchange rate to depreciate as the current-account deficit widens and as central banks in advanced economies re-embark on a path of monetary policy tightening. Thereafter still elevated inflation and a significant current-account deficit (although not as large as that in 2017) will result in a gradual depreciation of the lira against the US dollar in nominal terms, to TL6.4:US$1 by the end of 2023.

We expect the current-account deficit to narrow as a share of GDP in 2019, to 0.7%, from 3.6% in 2018 and 5.6% in 2017, as the lira's depreciation against both the US dollar and the euro depresses imports (owing to a decline in domestic demand) and boosts export competitiveness. From 2020 we expect the deficit to widen gradually, to a still relatively moderate 3.4% per year on average in 2020-23. The smaller deficits compared with historical levels reflect significant gains in competitiveness from the 2018-19 currency crisis that will boost exports and limit import growth throughout the medium term.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Turkey
Stocks and flows
Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows rose dramatically in 2005-08, to 2.9% of GDP, after averaging a modest 0.5% of GDP between 1990 and 2004. In the context of the global economic and financial crisis, they slowed again in 2009-10 and have remained below the average level of 3.2% of GDP reached in 2006-08. Inflows of FDI, including sales of real estate to non-residents, declined to about US$13.5bn, or 1.5% of GDP, per year in 2012-14, before picking up to about US$19.3bn, or 2.2% of GDP, in 2015. In 2016-18 FDI inflows fell to an average of US$12.8bn, or 1.6% of GDP. In 2019 we expect FDI inflows to be subdued owing to high economic and policy uncertainty. In 2020-23 we expect a gradual recovery in inflows as the economy strengthens and some delayed privatisations get under way. The stock of inward FDI stood at just 25.3% of GDP in 2018-well below levels in regional competitors such as Romania and Poland (between 40-50% of GDP), and Bulgaria and Slovakia (75-80%). Following a fall from US$4.1bn in 2012 to US$3.6bn in 2013, Turkish outward FDI jumped to US$7bn in 2014, largely reflecting a small number of large transactions, notably the acquisition of the UK-based United Biscuits by Yildiz Holding, a Turkish conglomerate of food manufacturers. The figure has eased, falling to US$2.7bn in 2017 and US$3.6bn in 2018, presumably owing to the high domestic funding needs and divestment by foreign firms due to greater economic and policy uncertainty.
Origin and distribution
The traditional sources of foreign capital in Turkey have been multinational companies based in major EU countries, especially the UK, the Netherlands, Spain and Germany, and in other OECD countries such as the US, Switzerland and Japan. Individual large investments from several smaller EU countries, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Saudi Arabia, Russia, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan and Brazil have amended this pattern in recent years, and there have also been some significant purchases by private equity funds. A majority of foreign investment appears to go to Istanbul-the commercial capital where most national Turkish companies have their headquarters. Investment projects of foreign capital companies are overwhelmingly concentrated in the Marmara region (which includes Istanbul), the Aegean region, the Mediterranean and Ankara, the capital. Historically, manufacturing (particularly the chemicals, food and automotive industries) and financial services attracted the most FDI. In 2012 construction featured prominently, with about 13% of net FDI inflows, although this was the result of the inclusion in this category of a single investment by the French-based Aéroports de Paris, which bought a 38% stake in Turkey's airport operator; TAV Airports; and a 49% stake in its construction arm, TAV Construction. In 2015 the share of FDI of financial services rose sharply, to 30% of the total, from about 17% in the previous year; this again reflected the impact of a single large investment in which a Spanish bank, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), increased its stake in Garanti Bank. Chemicals and pharmaceuticals was the second-largest category in 2015, accounting for 15% of total FDI inflows. Problems in developed economies, and the euro zone crisis in particular, together with the more recent deterioration in economic prospects in Turkey, has led to divestments by foreign financial institutions, many of which entered the Turkish market in 2005-08. As part of a plan to shore up its capital base, the National Bank of Greece has sold its 99.8% stake in Finans Bank, but because the sale, which was completed in mid-2016, was to Qatar National Bank, it did not affect net inward FDI figures in 2016. In 2017 OMV, an Austrian energy group, sold off its 100% stake in Petrol Ofisi, a Turkish petrol retailer. A neutral impact will also result from the planned sale of Denizbank by Sberbank to Emirates NBD (agreed in 2018). The lira crisis in 2018 delayed completion of the deal, which led to the terms of the sale being revised in April 2019. The sale is expected to be completed in the coming months.
Foreign property purchases, which are included in balance-of-payments statistics for FDI, have been making a solid contribution to net inflows since 2005. In 2005-13 net inflows averaged a solid US$2.5bn per year, before picking up to an average of US$4.6bn in 2014-18. In view of the excess supply, lira weakness and the deteriorating economic outlook, real estate inflows in US dollar terms are likely to decline in 2019.
Determinants
Foreign investment is mostly motivated by the size and potential of the Turkish market, but also increasingly because it offers access to neighbouring markets. The sharp rise in FDI in 2005-07 was partly driven by favourable global financial conditions, which have since evaporated. However, the upsurge was also made possible by the conjunction of several country-specific factors. The 2001 financial crisis led to a new drive for reform and privatisation, and reforms in sectors such as energy, telecommunications and banking began to take hold. The Justice and Development Party (AKP; in power since 2002) was more willing than its predecessors to sell majority stakes in state-owned companies to foreigners, even in sectors previously considered "strategic". The economy was relatively stable and grew strongly, and EU accession talks, which were expected to lead to further reform of the business environment, got under way. The private sector was also more willing to seek foreign partners than in the past. This may have reflected the thinking of a new generation of management, strategies of specialisation in certain sectors, a desire to raise capital for privatisation bids, fear of increasing foreign competition, lost appetite for bank ownership and temptingly high company valuations. From 2008, although the government remained willing to privatise, market conditions deteriorated, resulting in less interest from foreign investors. Since 2013 potential deterrents have multiplied: less buoyant economic growth, mass anti-government protests, financial market volatility, government corruption allegations, the spillover of violence from the conflict in Syria, the collapse of the peace negotiations with the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), an attempted military coup in July 2016 and increased social and political polarisation over the shift to a presidential system of government. Other significant structural deterrents, which vary by the sector, size and type of investment, include regulatory uncertainty, a slow and unpredictable judicial system, weak intellectual property (IP) protection and unfair competition from smuggled goods and the large informal sector.
Impact
The FDI stock as a percentage of GDP is relatively low when compared with other emerging markets such as Brazil or Russia. However, FDI has accumulated over many decades, and the outlook compared with several central and east European countries has improved. Several leading multinationals, such as Unilever and Ford, have had a long-standing presence in Turkey, and companies with foreign partners play a significant role in the economy, helping to spread modern management and business practice. In the automotive industry, foreign investment has ensured expansion, technology transfer and access to global markets, although some lament the lack of national technology or a national trademark and the focus on production of low-end vehicles. By contrast, much recent FDI has taken the form of acquisitions of existing assets in domestically oriented sectors, and has therefore had a limited direct impact on fixed investment or exports. Foreign ownership of banks has not demonstrably improved either access to international funds or services and productivity, which were already advanced, and nor have fears been realised that foreign-owned banks may attach a greater risk premium than local banks to lending to the Turkish government or Turkish companies. The arrival of Vodafone has gradually helped to increase competition and investment in telecoms, where Turkcell and Turk Telekom are dominant players. From a macroeconomic perspective, Turkey has relied on capital inflows, including FDI, to cover its large external financing requirement. In the years prior to the 2008-09 crisis, a growing share of FDI in capital inflows comforted the financial markets by reducing the vulnerability of the lira to trends in short-term capital inflows. After having declined in recent years, we expect the ratio to improve during the forecast period, helped by smaller, albeit still large external financing needs.
Potential
Our baseline forecast is that, assuming security and policy concerns are addressed during the forecast period, there will be a moderate pick-up driven by further privatisation and other crossborder mergers and acquisitions, as well as foreign interest in residential and commercial property, following the easing of restrictions on foreign ownership of real estate in 2012. Although the surge in foreign acquisitions in telecoms and banking of 2006-07 is unrepeatable, private corporations in many sectors may still be open to foreign investment, and several major assets are yet to be privatised. We assume that the government will make further progress in creating conditions for private-sector investment in infrastructure. The energy sector in particular has the potential to attract large amounts of foreign investment. Existing investors are likely to increase their investment through further acquisitions or projects, and some greenfield investment may take place. Subdued income growth may dampen foreign investors' earlier interest in retailing, but they may also become more active in other services, such as tourism, as well as in mining and agriculture. Investors from Asia and parts of the Middle East may play a larger role, in addition to Western multinationals and funds.

Population growth remains high by European standards
Turkey is the third-largest country by population in Europe, after Russia and Germany. Official population figures have been compiled using an address-based registry since 2009. These figures are lower than previous estimates from door-to-door censuses, but are believed to be more reliable. The total population is projected to rise from an estimated 81.9m in 2018 to 85.4m in 2023, with the female population continuing to outnumber that of males. The total population is expected to grow by 0.8% per year during the forecast period (2019-23), compared with 1.6% during the historical period (2014-18). The pace of population growth has slowed in recent decades, mostly owing to the declining birth rate, which in turn reflects the combined impact on fertility rates of urbanisation, an improvement in the education level of women and wider use of birth control. Nevertheless, population growth remains high by European standards and average age remains one of the lowest, at 32 years.
Infant mortality rate will continue to decline, but will be high
From an average of 17 births per 1,000 inhabitants in 2014-18, the crude birth rate is expected to fall to an average of 15.6 per 1,000 in 2019-23. The infant mortality rate will continue to decline, but will remain high compared with European countries, as the national average is pulled up by the south-eastern and eastern regions, as well as by rural areas. The crude death rate will remain broadly unchanged, at an average of 5.9 per 1,000 population in 2019-23.
Although ageing, the Turkish population is young in a European context and will remain so throughout the forecast period. In 2018 those aged 14 and under were estimated to comprise 24.6% of the total population, and the 65-plus age group accounted for just 8.4%. In 2023 the share of under-15s will still be high, at about 22.8% of the population, and over-65s are expected to account for 9.7%.
Urban population will rise further owing to better conditions in cities
The urban population, which is currently estimated at 75.2%, will rise further as rural families, insufficiently supported by agriculture, continue to seek better living standards in towns and cities. The drift of population from smaller and poorer urban settlements to larger and richer ones will also continue. As a result, all major cities in the west and south (including Ankara) will continue to grow rapidly. Although earthquake-prone, Istanbul and its surrounding area is likely to become the largest conurbation in Europe-the population was 15.1m at end-2018, up from about 12.6m at end-2007. Other cities and towns to witness particularly strong population growth include prosperous industrial centres like Bursa and Konya, and Antalya, on the Mediterranean coast.
The population of the mostly Kurdish-inhabited south east, which accounts for about 10% of the total population, has increased steadily, despite strong outward migration. The still-high natural population growth rate in the region will contribute to the rapid expansion of the populations of cities like Gaziantep, Sanliurfa and Diyarbakir. By contrast, the populations of many rural areas in northern, eastern and central Turkey will dwindle. Even some of the larger urban centres in these poorer and more remote regions could lose population as birth rates slow and migration westwards and southwards continues. Some western and southern areas that are still classed as rural may maintain their populations as a result of intensive agriculture, tourism and/or proximity to major cities. This may also be true of lowland parts of the south east benefiting from irrigation schemes.
Participation rates will remain well below the OECD average
Despite solid growth in the working-age population, Turkey has the lowest labour force participation rate of any OECD country. According to the Turkish Statistical Institute (Turkstat), it averaged 53.2% in 2018 (72.7% for men and just 34.2% for women), compared with an OECD average rate of more than 70%. Participation rates in urban areas are lower than in rural areas, reflecting that rural women are typically classified as "unpaid family workers" and are, therefore, counted as workforce participants and employed persons. Low workforce participation rates among urban women probably reflect inadequate job opportunities and the persistence of traditional gender roles. This situation is changing slowly, as illustrated by a gradual rise in recent years in the urban female participation rate. However, the rate is expected to remain low by European standards throughout the forecast period.

Overall spending power will rise, but income distribution will remain uneven
The large consumer market is one of Turkey's chief attractions as a place to do business. The population is young, growing and inclined to consume rather than save, and average incomes are rising steadily in local currency terms. In 2018 GDP per head was US$9,333 at market exchange rates (down from US$10,510 in 2017, reflecting lira weakness in 2018) and US$29,132 at purchasing power parity (PPP) rates (up from US$28,210 in 2017). Relative to other emerging markets, at PPP rates Turkey's GDP per head is broadly in line with that of Russia and Romania and above that of Brazil and China. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Turkey's GDP per head to be US$34,212 at PPP exchange rates in 2023. At this level, GDP per head in Turkey will be broadly unchanged as a percentage of the EU28 average, at about 63%.
Income distribution is uneven by European standards. According to the survey of incomes and living conditions by the Turkish Statistical Institute (Turkstat), the highest-earning 20% of households accounted for 47.4% of total income in 2017 (latest available data), up from 45.9% in 2014; the lowest-earning 20% of households accounted for 6.4%, in line with the 2014 figure. Geographical factors contributed to the discrepancies. In general, the regions with the highest and most rapidly growing concentrations of population were also the wealthiest regions-except in the south east, where spending power is low. Greater Istanbul, which accounts for about 20% of the population, represents about 25% of household consumption expenditure. By contrast, the statistical region of south-east Anatolia, with about 10% of the population, generated only 5.8% of household consumption. Income and consumer expenditure also vary widely between urban and rural areas, and within cities. These patterns are unlikely to change significantly in the forecast period (2019-23).
The household will remain the main consumption unit. Households typically consist of an average of 3.6 people, and more than 90% of households are made up of married couples. Although these patterns will change only gradually, the number of households will tend to increase faster than the population, underpinning medium-term demand for housing construction and household durables, including basics like furniture, washing machines and refrigerators.
Majority of Turkish consumers aspire to Western style consumer society
A large majority of Turkish consumers aspire to "Western style" consumer society, in so far as their incomes permit, although local factors affect lifestyle aspirations. Much of the population adheres to Islamic prohibitions, including on consumption of alcohol. The country has wide variations in geography and climate, which affect diet, leisure activities and demand for certain goods. Choices of entertainment vary between groups with different education levels.

Young population will encourage new products and services
The proportion of total household spending allocated to food, beverages and tobacco is high and expected to remain broadly stable during the forecast period. Housing and household fuel, goods and services will also remain major expenditure items. The wealthiest households, which enjoy standards of living close to those of west Europeans, spend significant amounts on entertainment, education and catering, as well as on transport, because of the high cost of running a car. These households will remain an important target market for environment-friendly and wellness products and services, which are relatively new. Other population segments are starting to provide additional demand for items that have been the prerogative of upper-income groups. Rising car ownership will continue to encourage supermarket shopping, residence in suburban areas and related lifestyle trends. Demand for branded fashion items, fast food, air conditioning and holidays is also spreading. That half of the population is under the age of 30 will encourage the introduction of new products and services in communications, information and entertainment technology. Tourists constitute a significant addition to the consumer market. About 55m, including both foreigners and non-resident Turks, visited Turkey in 2018, up from about 47m in 2017. Assuming that perceived security risk does not increase again in the coming years, we expect the weaker lira to boost arrivals further.

Long-term outlook: The long-term outlook
