Business environment outlook: Argentina's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The administration of Mauricio Macri works to address key weaknesses, including weak competition policy, the heavy burden of red tape and restrictive price controls.
2021-23: Continued work to build faith in legal and regulatory frameworks. State participation in key sectors continues.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Proactive, welcoming approach to foreign investment. Attempts to resolve outstanding disputes with creditors.
2021-23: Foreign direct investment (FDI) is welcome. Improvement made in investment dispute settlement and availability of investment-protection schemes.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Continued efforts to improve the workings of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union) and develop closer relations with the Pacific Alliance, comprising Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru.
2021-23: Possibility that new free-trade agreements (FTAs) are signed with the EU and Canada.
Taxes
2019-20: Temporary generalised export taxes implemented to narrow the fiscal gap. Risks of delays to implementation of tax cuts envisaged in 2017 tax reform.
2021-23: Temporary export taxes eliminated in 2021. Only very gradual cuts elsewhere to reduce tax pressure.
Financing
2019-20: Banking penetration remains weak and long-term credit restricted, particularly for small and medium-sized (SMEs) enterprises, owing to weak long-term deposit base.
2021-23: Non-bank financing grows, but is constrained by the relative smallness of the pool of institutional investors.
The labour market
2019-20: Tension with unions, due to inflation. Political and bargaining power of unions remains strong.
2021-23: Limited progress on labour reform. Continued potential for conflicts with unions. Ongoing skills shortages.
Infrastructure
2019-20: The Macri administration continues to improve contract rights and deficient regulatory regimes.
2021-23: Some public and private investment set to improve energy supply and upgrade export infrastructure, but the risk of energy shortages will persist as demand grows.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Quality of e-commerce business environment is good. Upgrade of 4G capabilities.
2021-23: More progress on increasing scope of e-government as part of the process to reduce red tape. Increase in research and development spending as a percentage of GDP, but still relatively low compared with more developed markets.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.1 6.1 78 64 11 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The macroeconomic environment will improve but remain weak
Despite a forecast improvement in Argentina's score and ranking between the historical and forecast period, the macroeconomic environment will be the weakest area of our business environment rankings (BER) during 2019-23. During 2014-18, the macroeconomic environment was one of the worst in all of the 82 countries covered in our BER. This was the legacy of heterodox policy measures introduced by the last government, led by Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15), which hampered the quality of policymaking and actual performance, both during her tenure and in the years following her departure from office.
Overall, the macroeconomic environment is forecast to improve during 2019-23, but certain areas (in particular relating to inflation, the exchange rate and public debt) will remain weak and will prevent a more marked consolidation of Argentina's score and ranking in this category. The main areas of the macroeconomic environment that register a notable improvement in the forecast period is the quality of policymaking and strength of institutions, as the current government's policy stance is much more investor-friendly than that of his predecessor.
We also expect some improvements in performance indicators over the course of 2019-23, with the fiscal deficit forecast to narrow moderately and the current account expected to shift from deficit to surplus. However, the pace of improvement will be relatively gradual and a challenging monetary situation-characterised by high, albeit decelerating, inflation and sporadic chronic currency volatility-will hamper the economy's medium-term growth potential and constrain the government's policy choices. We currently assume no marked deviation from the government's market-friendly stance, but should Ms Fernández win office again in the October general election, the macroeconomic environment would be likely to deteriorate once again.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.8 6.8 54 33 8 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The economy will benefit from the return to a market-friendly policy stance
Argentina's score and ranking for private enterprise and competition improves substantially for the 2019-23 forecast period, under our assumption that the Macri government will continue to introduce measures that actively encourage private investment and promote competition. The Fernández government had a track record of arbitrary decision-making that was often detrimental to the private sector, eroding confidence in the legal framework, hampering the freedom of businesses to compete and giving rise to allegations of crony capitalism. During the forecast period, we expect a revamped competition commission to focus on more rapid and thorough enforcement of antitrust violations. Across the public sector, a reduction in red tape is likely; legislation reducing red tape for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) was approved in 2017. Although the government has announced a number of policy measures in response to surging inflation, including price controls on some basic consumption items, higher export taxes and the suspension of utility tariff adjustments, we believe that these measures will prove temporary and in the medium term the authorities will remain committed to scaling back price controls and subsidies. Overall efforts will continue to be affected by lobbying by special interest groups in the context of Argentina's long tradition of political clientelism, but we expect significant improvements in all of these areas by the end of the forecast period. That said, state participation in key sectors, including energy, utilities and banking, is expected to continue.
Under Ms Fernández, the Comisión Nacional de Defensa de la Competencia (CNDC, the competition authority) was a weak and ineffective body, doing little to prevent monopolistic practices or protect consumer rights. This is changing under Mr Macri. He appointed a new head of the CNDC in 2016, Esteban Greco, who focused immediately on crafting a reform of the existing competition legislation. The reform, which was entered into effect in May 2018, transforms the CNDC into an independent body (the Autoridad Nacional de la Competencia), tightens penalties for companies found guilty of competition-related offences, improves controls on mergers and acquisitions, encourages greater disclosure and creates an under-secretariat responsible for investigation, training and education. Closer co-operation with US competition authorities to train staff on mergers and acquisitions will also raise standards in this area. Currently, the competition authority has scare resources, which will hamper the number of anti-trust investigations that it can conduct simultaneously, but this is expected to improve over the course of the forecast period.
Policy towards export taxes and agricultural quotas has oscillated somewhat in recent years. The Macri government took office pledging to scale these back, eliminating export taxes on wheat, beef and corn, while also reducing the tax on soybeans-the most important export crop-on a rolling monthly basis, from an initial level of 35% to 25.5% by mid-2018. However, the policy stance shifted in September 2018, with the government announcing a new generalised export tax of Ps4 on each US dollar of revenue for primary and services exporters, and Ps3 per US dollar for all other exports. Mr Macri has emphasised that generalised export taxes run contrary to his free-market policies, but that his government has run out of options in the context of broader fiscal challenges. The export tax was partially offset by conciliatory measures in other areas, with the export tax on soybeans reduced from 25.5% to 18%. Given that the authorities are counting on an export-led economic recovery, the generalised export tax is unlikely to remain in place throughout the entire forecast period.
We expect the process of scaling back price controls on consumer goods to remain on hold in the short term, before recommencing in the medium term. Upon taking office, the government kept a price-control programme, Precios Cuidados, in place, as it sought to curb the pass-through effect on inflation of currency devaluation, but it reduced the number of basic consumer items covered from 500 to 317. However, since then, a number of new products have been added to the list, with 560 products now covered, in response to rising inflation. In addition, in April 2019 the government reached an agreement with 16 leading suppliers to freeze the prices of 60 basic consumption items (including oils, flour, sugar, milk, beverages and canned food) for a period of six months. Renewed efforts to reduce price controls on consumer goods are unlikely until inflation begins to subside.
There was initially more progress on efforts to scale back government energy subsidies by raising electricity and natural gas tariffs, but recent economic difficulties will also affect the pace at which the authorities can continue to reduce these subsidies. After taking office, the government introduced hefty price increases for end-users, with gas bills jumping massively (albeit from an extremely low base), despite considerable domestic opposition. The authorities were aiming to align domestic rates with market rates by the end of 2019, but the rise in rates has generated significant public opposition, particularly in the context of rising inflation, and this timetable has slipped. In April 2019, the government suspended planned hikes in utility rates for the second quarter; similarly hikes in the second half of the year will be shelved. Electricity-rate hikes that had been scheduled for May and September will also be suspended. Despite these moves, we believe that the government remains committed to realigning utility tariffs once inflation has subsided. The government is likely to grant companies new subsidies to compensate for the lower prices.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.6 7.8 69 28 9 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Foreign investment to pick up
Argentina's score and ranking for policy towards foreign investment improve significantly between the historical and forecast period. This reflects Mr Macri's much more welcoming stance towards foreign capital and his efforts to make government policy towards foreign investment more transparent, clear and predictable. The sovereign's exit from default in April 2017 lifted a major constraint on foreign investment by reopening access to investment protection schemes (a key factor driving the increase in Argentina's score in this category for 2019-23). The government's more market-friendly approach means that the risk of expropriations is much lower, and government favouritism of domestic firms will be less marked. However, aside from occasional sales of some state-owned assets, we expect outright privatisation to remain off the agenda. The public still places much of the blame for the 2001-02 crisis on the privatisation process of the 1990s, in which foreign firms featured heavily.
Argentina's exit from default has facilitated access to capital markets, but the government's ambitious plans for infrastructure and housing development will still necessitate foreign participation in the context of fiscal expenditure constraints. Beneficially, a bill establishing a public-private partnership (PPP) framework for investment was signed into law in December 2016. However, official estimates that it could raise potential capital inflows by US$90bn are likely to prove extremely optimistic. In the short term, investment under PPP schemes will move very gradually. In January 2019 the government had initially suspended issuances of new tenders under PPP schemes owing to the country's high risk premium (which has boosted external borrowing costs and strained projects' financial feasibility). However, in early March the government once again floated a tender for the construction and operation of a 487-km high-voltage electricity network, through a 15-year PPP contract. The latest development bodes well for the investment outlook, even in a context of relatively high economic volatility.
In the medium term, energy reforms to liberalise tariffs and promote investment are likely to boost multinational interest in deals to commercialise Argentina's vast shale oil and gas reserves (the world's second-largest), particularly now that international energy prices have risen moderately from the 2015-16 lows. The Fernández government expropriated oil producer YPF in 2012 and paid heavy subsidies to suppress domestic petrol prices, with investment falling sharply as a result. Since then, the official policy stance has changed and YPF has signed a series of exploration and production (E&P) contracts with private-sector companies to develop the Vaca Muerta shale deposits in Neuquén province. The development of Vaca Muerta has been progressing slowly (even though the break-even price needed to make investment profitable is low, at US$35-40/barrel), because of the vast scale of the investment needed and the lack of local infrastructure. The government is seeking to boost investment in the energy sector by developing other areas, offering significant deepwater exploration contracts in the Austral (5,000 sq km), Western Malvinas (90,000 sq km) and North Argentina (130,000 sq km) basins. The last two are generally unexplored, while the Austral Basin is known largely as an offshore gas play. The first licensing round for these blocks was held in April, attracting bids from a large number of international oil majors.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.1 6.9 70 60 10 8
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Trade barriers remain high, but fresh capital controls are unlikely
Notwithstanding some modest improvements during 2019-23, foreign trade and exchange controls will remain a weak point of the investment climate, relative to other areas of the business environment. Trade restrictions remain high, with Argentina currently holding free-trade agreements (FTAs) with relatively few countries (accounting for only around 10% of global GDP, compared with levels of 70-80% in Chile and Peru). Under Mercosur, external tariffs on non-Mercosur trade stand at 9% for capital goods and 6% for intermediate goods. Meanwhile, non-tariff barriers to trade are high; according to World Bank data these apply to 95% of imports (above the global average of 72%) and 76% of exports (much higher than the global average of 27%). Non-tariff barriers to trade mainly take the form of export and import taxes, registration requirements, as well as trading bans on certain items. Nonetheless, the currency devaluation in 2018, accompanied by productivity-enhancing reforms during the forecast period, will significantly improve export competitiveness and help to produce much-needed adjustment on Argentina's current account. Despite vulnerabilities to external shocks, the government will refrain from putting in place outright capital controls. We expect the monetary authorities to continue to respond with conventional tools, rather than the re-imposition of controls.
On-off free-trade negotiations between the EU and Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) have been ongoing since 2000. Five negotiating rounds took place and one has so far been completed in 2019 (in March). During 2018, officials had hinted that the two sides were close to reaching a deal, reflecting greater consensus on several significant obstacles that have long hampered talks, including treatment of agricultural products. However, work is still required on key outstanding issues, which include market access in Mercosur for cars and car parts. In addition, there is greater uncertainty about prospects for finalising a deal under the new Brazilian government, led by Jair Bolsonaro. Our forecasts do not currently assume that the FTA will be signed and implemented within the forecast period, but there is some upside risk to this assumption. Meanwhile, Mr Macri is also likely to continue to focus on expanding relations with the Pacific Alliance, a trade bloc comprising Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru, as well as Asia.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.9 6.4 81 46 12 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Tax reform is likely to address long-running deficiencies at a fundamental level
The tax system is one of the areas of the business environment in which Argentina registers the most significant improvements between the historical and forecast periods. The approval of a comprehensive tax reform bill in December 2017 is the main factor explaining the improvement. During the historical period, Argentina's score in this area was dragged down by a high level of corporate tax (35%-one of the highest in the region), significant complexity (over 35 different types of tax were collected), as well as a series of distortionary taxes (including agricultural export taxes, a financial transactions tax and a gross turnover tax). The tax reform addressed several of these long-running weaknesses; we expect that it will help to create a more equitable and efficient tax system that supports investment and encourages formal employment. Although we expect further improvements to the tax regime-to improve compliance and to reduce tax disincentives-the government is unlikely to pass reforms that are not revenue-neutral (so as to ensure fiscal consolidation continues apace).
The tax reform was designed to boost investment. The corporate income tax rate was reduced from 35% to 30% in 2018 and it will be cut again to 25% from 2020 as long as profits are reinvested (if they are not, a 10% tax on distribution of dividends will be applied). The reform also set a tax-free threshold for payroll tax in order to encourage formal-sector employment, introduced gradually over the course of 2019-23. The counterpart of these tax cuts is an increase in some consumption taxes (including adjustments to excise taxes to make them more progressive) and the introduction of a new capital gains tax. The latter is set at a rate of 15% for dollar-denominated financial assets and inflation-linked assets, and falls to 5% for non-inflation-linked, peso-denominated financial assets. Financial assets include corporate and public bonds, central bank notes, and banks' long-term deposits. There will be a tax-free threshold of Ps52,000 (US$3,000). The government has opted to maintain the financial transactions tax (which it had initially wanted to phase out) until 2022, partly to compensate for lost revenue.
Improvements to the system of revenue-sharing with the provinces are also expected in 2019-23. Along with tax reform and the budget, Congress also passed a provincial fiscal responsibility law and so-called provincial "fiscal pact". Together, the measures will secure the commitment of the provinces to restraint in spending and tax pressure, and to the reduction of distortionary taxes. It will also put an end to lawsuits by the provinces related to the transfers of federal government revenue and lays out a series of changes to this system of transfers, called "co-participation", a reform that was attractive to provincial governors and the legislators that are influenced by them.
The Macri government has passed several tax measures to improve conditions for SMEs that have been particularly badly hit by deteriorating economic conditions. Since the start of 2017, SMEs have been exempt from the minimum notional income tax levied on companies' assets. This tax accounts for a very small share of total tax revenue (well under 1%), but is burdensome for SMEs (particularly for manufacturing companies who generally have more assets in the form of equipment than service providers), as it must be paid even in the event of losses. In addition, SMEs are now able to offset bank debit and credit tax against income tax. SMEs are also able to pay value-added tax (VAT) on sales every three months rather than monthly, which will assist with cashflow. Finally, to encourage investment, the law offsets up to 10% of new investment in capital goods and infrastructure against income tax.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.0 6.3 72 48 8 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Argentina's score and ranking for financing improve sharply between the historical and the forecast periods. For the most part, this reflects the huge constraints on finance in place during the first half of the historical period, which resulted from continued sovereign default. Argentina's deal with holdout creditors and exit from default paved the way for much-improved access to external credit for corporate borrowers. That said, ongoing macroeconomic volatility will hamper the availability of long-term finance domestically, at least in the short term. Large foreign companies will, therefore, have to secure most of their financing needs from external sources. Banking sector regulation and supervision are expected to improve, while financial soundness and profitability indicators will remain solid. However, some weaknesses in the system will persist: notwithstanding an improvement, financial markets will remain relatively shallow by comparison with similarly ranked peers, as will levels of banking penetration.
Argentina's particularly weak score and ranking in the historical period is explained by several factors. Apart from the fact that the sovereign remained in default for part of the historical period, these included the nationalisation of private pension funds in 2008, which was a serious blow to the funds' growth and had a lasting impact in the following years. Argentina's private pension-fund administrators were the country's most important institutional investors and were a growing source of finance in the local capital markets. The Administración Nacional de Seguridad Social (Anses, the social security agency, which took over the nationalised pension fund assets) was able to allocate up to 50% of assets in local private companies' shares and up to 10% of assets in foreign government securities.
A capital markets reform passed in May 2018 is likely to improve financing conditions in two main ways: by facilitating access to credit for SMEs and by boosting the mortgage market. A new electronic credit invoice system will improve access to credit and also improve the risk rating of SMEs that supply big companies. The reform also establishes the conditions for the creation of a market to securitise mortgage loans, a development that will require increased supervision, particularly of inflation-indexed mortgages.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.7 5.7 55 59 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Labour market reforms are unlikely
The labour market is the only area of the business environment in which we expect stagnation in Argentina's underlying score between the historical and forecast periods, with Argentina's global ranking slipping by four places. The labour force is well-educated, productive and flexible, and labour costs are relatively competitive by international standards (the latter largely resulting from peso devaluation in 2018, which helped unwind years of real peso appreciation). That being said, we do not expect significant progress on labour market reform, or in addressing a highly unionised labour market that produces a high incidence of strikes. In the short term, difficult economic adjustments that are contributing to a decline in real wages and a cut in purchasing power will result in continued frequent strikes, particularly as the government seeks to rein in wage increases against the backdrop of extremely high levels of inflation.
The passage of comprehensive labour reform is unlikely during 2019-23, given weak relations between the government and organised labour. Mr Macri has effectively shelved plans for a broad-based reform bill, instead choosing to focus on only one aspect-an amnesty for employers who register informal workers. The government is likely to submit a bill to encourage labour formalisation by forgiving fines due by employers for having informal workers, as long as they have formalised the employees' contracts. However, even by the government's estimates, the measure would be likely to lead to the incorporation of only around 200,000 of the country's 4.5m informal workers into formal labour markets (and potentially far fewer). As such, these measures are unlikely to boost Argentina's score in this area over the course of the forecast period.
Skills shortages and mismatches remain a problem, compounded by a lack of effective training programmes in both the public and private sectors. Secondary and tertiary enrolment are very high by regional standards, but educational outcomes are not as strong as would be expected given high enrolment rates, and vary widely by province. At the same time, access to job training tends to be unequal and informal. We do not expect any significant improvement in these areas during the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.8 6.0 55 49 5 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
More private investment will help to upgrade infrastructure
Argentina's score and ranking for infrastructure improve moderately between the historical and forecast periods, remaining one of the stronger areas of the country's business environment. The country boasts a well-developed telecommunications network, as well as relatively low property rental costs. However, physical infrastructure has suffered over the past decade from a lack of investment. Although recent political and economic uncertainty will hamper investment in infrastructure in the near term, we currently assume that the passage of PPP legislation and improvements in contract rights will help to boost investment both in transport infrastructure and energy in the medium term. However, such projects will take time to come on stream, limiting further improvement to the score in 2019-23, and raising the risk that infrastructure bottlenecks will continue to hamper growth in the meantime.
The risk of energy shortages will persist in the short term at least, given long project completion times. Demand for electricity and gas has soared in the past decade, but as tariffs for residential and business consumers are lifted, demand growth is expected to slow. Talks are ongoing between the Argentinian and Chinese authorities over the construction of a nuclear reactor in Argentina, but, apart from this, prospects for fresh construction in the energy sector are less certain. Despite Argentina's vast hydroelectric potential, no further large projects are under way. The government has undertaken auctions in the renewable sector since 2017, under its RenovAR project, but progress remains slow, as firms have reportedly found it virtually impossible to secure local financing for renewables projects amid the economy's difficulties. Even assuming greater progress in the medium term, successful auctions are unlikely to translate into new capacity until late in the forecast period (or even after). In the short term at least, the lack of new energy capacity coming on stream will maintain dependence on imports, and increase exposure to weather-related problems at existing hydropower facilities.
Although the mobile telecoms market has matured in recent years, there remains scope for development in the quality and scope of mobile-telecoms services. Although substantial investments have been announced by telecoms companies, whether these materialise (thereby resulting in noticeable improvements during the forecast period) will partly depend on the ability of the government to draft and pass a new communications law to improve competition and operating conditions. The bill is unlikely to be submitted to the legislature in the short term owing to political and economic constraints, but we expect progress in the medium term, as the reform measures are relatively uncontroversial. Broadband penetration is the highest in Latin America, owing to high per-head income and strong competition, which has kept subscription fees low and the quality of service high. 4G coverage is among the highest in the region, with the government targeting 93% coverage by the end of 2019 and 100% coverage by the end of 2020.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.1 6.6 41 40 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
This section, introduced as part of an upgrade to our rankings in 2018, aims to show how future-oriented the business environment is-the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption.
Argentina registers one of its highest scores in this area of the business environment, and although it is only mid-ranked by global comparison, it is the highest-ranked in Latin America, after Chile. High levels of mobile subscriptions and broadband penetration underpin the score, given that they are critical to driving broader technological developments including mobile apps and cloud computing, which in turn helps to drive economic growth across a variety of sectors and facilitate an increase in productivity. However, regulation and governance remain relative weak points (and are what distinguishes Argentina from higher-ranked global peers), while the backdrop of a highly distorted macroeconomic policy environment has prevented significant private investment, which has hampered research and development and the number of patent applications.
The process for applying for a patent in Argentina has traditionally been a long one, with complex procedures and administrative deficiencies contributing to large backlogs in the Instituto Nacional de la Propiedad Industrial (INPI, the national institute of industrial property). However, an agreement signed between the European Patent Office (EPO) and the INPI in February 2018 is likely to facilitate the granting of patents during the forecast period. Similar agreements that already exist between the EPO and Mexico, Chile, Colombia and Brazil have made the application process simpler and quicker, resulting in an increase in successful patent applications. Alongside collaboration with the EPO, Argentina has agreed a "Patent Prosecution Highway" with the US Patent and Trademark Office that similarly aims to expedite the review of patent applications. Argentina is also focusing on other measures, including fast-tracking applications that have already received approval in other countries, taking on more specialist staff at INPI and digitalising internal processes, in an attempt to boost efficiency.
The e-commerce environment is expected to remain strong. Online retail was quicker to develop in Argentina than in many other countries in the region, supported by an early and rapid take-up of mobile broadband. According to the Cámara Argentina de Comercio Electrónico, the e-commerce chamber, purchases via the internet grew by 47% year on year in 2018 (a similar growth rate to 2016), reaching Ps229.8bn. Online and mobile banking is already popular and is used to conduct routine transactions, aided by well-developed mobile banking services and a modern payments system that meets international standards. Logistics is somewhat weaker, with most delivery companies failing to deliver as rapidly as in similarly ranked countries. This reflects a legacy of weak investment in physical infrastructure, which has hampered the quality of the road network and led to some port delays.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Recent events have demonstrated the difficulty of pushing forwards with economic adjustment in a country with a history of hyperinflation and currency crisis. Inflation expectations are unanchored, and sensitivity to exchange-rate movements is extremely high. In this context, and also reflecting growing market concern about the possibility of a Fernández victory in the presidential race, inflation has drifted above 50%, the policy interest rate has moved above 70%, and the peso has been subject to periodic depreciation pressures. Notwithstanding these complications, the government remains committed to the adjustment measures put in place in September 2018 to confront the country's currency crisis, and The Economist Intelligence Unit still assumes that these will guide economic policymaking. Adjustment is centred on a package of tax increases and spending cuts intended to eliminate the primary fiscal deficit this year, and on extremely tight monetary policy. In combination with recent currency devaluation, the latest emergency economic package should in theory be sufficient to reduce concern over the twin deficits. However, it entails pro-cyclical policy tightening that will complicate recovery in 2019 from last year's recession.
Adjustment is taking place under the auspices of an IMF lending deal, which will provide the financial breathing space that the government needs this year and next. A revised stand-by arrangement (SBA) was approved by the Fund in October 2018. It will see Argentina receive US$57bn, allowing the government to close its financing gap in both 2019 and 2020 without having to raise finance in international capital markets. We expect that programme targets will, on the whole, be met, and will engender macroeconomic stability over time. On this assumption, we expect that, later in our forecast period-after the IMF deal expires-external financing conditions for Argentina will improve.
The biggest risks to this outlook are political, and are centred on the strong risk of Mr Macri failing to secure a second term, which would raise questions as to the future direction of economic policy. In our view, a moderate Peronist administration led by Mr Lavagna or Mr Urtubey would be likely to retain the IMF lending arrangement and the broad economic policy stance of the current administration (although some sort of renegotiation of the deal would be likely). A Fernández administration would see sharp adjustments to economic policy and huge volatility in financial markets that would dampen the economic outlook for the foreseeable future.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy
Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)

Government expenditure 22.9 23.7 22.8 22.6 22.6 22.6
Government revenue 17.9 20.3 20.8 20.2 20.4 20.4
Budget balance -5.0 -3.4 -2.0 -2.4 -2.2 -2.2
Government debt 85.8 75.5 74.3 71.2 68.8 67.9
The government has had to adjust its expenditure and revenue plans somewhat as it seeks to ease the burden of recession on consumers, but fiscal adjustment is nonetheless ongoing and our forecasts continue to assume a sharp narrowing of the primary deficit this year, and a shift into primary surplus thereafter. The official target for 2019 is primary balance, but the IMF SBA includes provisions for a larger deficit in the event that conditions warrant increased social safety-net spending, and the government has indeed announced such spending measures. On this basis, we forecast a primary fiscal deficit of 0.5% of GDP in 2019. This remains an ambitious target, and in order to accomplish it, the government has introduced measures split fairly evenly between spending cuts and tax increases. In total, the government is planning 1.4% of GDP in spending cuts (centred on capital spending and economic subsidies) and 1.3% of GDP in increased revenue from temporary, across-the-board export taxes in 2019. In our view, these fiscal adjustment measures are sufficient, in theory, to allow the government to meet its targets, and our forecasts assume that the targets will be met. However, notwithstanding increased social safety-net spending, the government will have a tough task ahead of it, particularly in 2019, an election year, and the risk of setbacks will be high.
A major factor in the government's plan for rapid fiscal adjustment is the deterioration of public debt indicators. Peso devaluation in 2018 led to a massive expansion of the public debt burden, and despite strongly contractionary fiscal policy we expect the public debt/GDP ratio to stand at a significant 75.5% this year and to fall only slowly thereafter. Concerns about debt sustainability will serve to dampen investor confidence for an extended period and take several years of austerity to reverse. That said, around half of the public debt is intra-government debt held by the Banco Central de la República Argentina (BCRA, the central bank) and the social security agency.

Monetary policy will remain extremely tight for the foreseeable future, and we expect the ex ante real reference Leliq interest rate to be high not only this year and next, but also in the remainder of the forecast period as the BCRA seeks to establish policy credibility. Under the money supply targeting system in place since October 2018, the Leliq could also be volatile. Volatility has been evident so far this year, but we think that the general trend in the nominal rate in the rest of the year will be downward (albeit slowly), from the currently extremely high level of over 70%. The key risk to this benign outlook is the vulnerability of the peso to sudden, sharp movements, and this vulnerability (which will, if anything, increase in coming weeks as the election nears) means that the scope for rates to fall will be fairly limited in coming months.

The latest available data are mixed; the data for December-February showed a sustained sequential increase in economic activity, but leading indicators for March suggest that the inflation spike and credit squeeze have damaged sentiment and set back the incipient recovery. With consumer and business confidence still weak, and with extremely tight fiscal and monetary policies raising concerns about growth outside the agricultural sector, we have revised our forecast for GDP for this year, from a contraction of 0.9% to a contraction of 1.1%. But this full-year contraction partly reflects base effects and disguises the fact that, on a seasonally adjusted, quarter-on-quarter basis, the economy will be growing. This forecast rests in turn on a number of key assumptions, an improved harvest (the latest indicators suggest a record crop year), and a positive contribution of net exports to growth, reflecting a combination of import compression and a pick-up in export-related industry in response to much-improved competitiveness. However, there is an unusually high degree of uncertainty attached to our short-term forecasts, and we are likely to see volatility in economic data in the months to come. There is a not insubstantial risk that continued policy tightening could tip Argentina into a deeper, longer recession. Furthermore, Argentina's growth strategy for 2019 is highly export-dependent, which presents further risks, given our forecast for slowing global growth.
Our forecasts for the second part of the forecast period (2020-23) assume a return to moderate growth of around 3% per year. We recognise that such a prompt turnaround represents a benign forecast that is dependent on a successful economic adjustment that finally addresses the problem of the twin deficits and persistently high inflation. We do believe that this adjustment process is achievable; we also believe that the medium-term prospects for energy, mining, export-oriented industry and agriculture are good.

Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
The agricultural sector will be the key driver of economic resurgence in 2019, as it recovers from severe drought in 2018. Harvests of key crops such as maize and soybean are estimated to have reached recent highs in the 2018/19 (October-September) agricultural campaign. Notwithstanding output volatility, as a result of weather conditions, agriculture will continue to be a key contributor to the Argentinian economy. Although it has accounted for around 10% of GDP over the past decade, and for around 20% of private employment, these figures underestimate its contribution, as they do not include agro-industry. Moreover, empirical evidence suggests that the multiplier effects on production and employment of the principal agricultural value chains in Argentina are higher than the average multipliers of the economy. Nonetheless, in the near term, the agricultural sector will face a number of headwinds. Soft commodity prices have been weakening, owing to a combination of strong global supply and ripple effects from an ongoing bilateral trade war between China and the US. In addition, the Macri administration's decision to reinstate generalised export taxes (of Ps4 on every US$1 of revenue) for primary exporters, as a temporary revenue-raising measure, will also weigh on investment in the sector. A soy-specific export tax (of 18%) also currently remains in place. We currently assume that these distortionary taxes will be lifted after 2020 (although the soy-specific tax will be reduced only incrementally), when both economic and political scenarios are on a more solid footing. A more stable, clear and attractive environment for agriculture producers will boost output. It will also support agro-industry (including the processing of Argentina's key crop, soybean) and bolster a manufacturing sector that is currently struggling amid still-weak demand both at home and in Brazil. We expect a mild economic recovery in Brazil in 2019-23, which will also help to produce a moderate pick-up in Argentinian manufacturing in 2019-23.
Better incentives should boost key sectors
Mining and energy are two sectors with great potential. Argentina has vast shale and gas resources, but, to date, commercialising them has proven difficult, particularly in the wake of the nationalisation of the country's largest energy company, YPF, in 2012. The Macri administration made significant progress in tackling some of the main problems constraining investment, including a lack of confidence in the rule of law and extremely restrictive product market regulation. The government has also made strides in rolling back energy subsidies, which kept domestic energy prices artificially low and deterred investment in the sector. Although political and economic constraints have led the government to halt utilities tariff increases temporarily, we assume that these will resume over the forecast period. In 2017 the government announced a series of measures to boost investment and domestic production, thereby reducing reliance on imports. The measures include the "flexibilisation" of labour conditions in Vaca Muerta, a 30,000-sq-km oil field located in southern Argentina that is the world's second-largest shale gas reservoir and fourth-largest shale oil reservoir. The government had also initially sought to subsidise investment in Vaca Muerta by setting above-market prices for unconventional gas between 2018 and 2021. However, it has since been forced to scale back these subsidies considerably in order to meet its strict fiscal targets. This development, along with currently constrictive financing conditions, will deter greater investment in the sector in the near term. However, as macroeconomic conditions improve over the course of the forecast period, we are likely to see exploration and productive activity rise in tandem.
The mining sector also has substantial potential. It shares the mineral-rich southern Andes mountains with Chile, long recognised as one of the world's mining powerhouses. But mining has been slow to develop in Argentina relative to its potential, partly because international companies are put off by a patchwork of different provincial taxes and regulations, some of them restrictive; for example, various provinces ban open-cast mining. In an effort to boost investment in the sector, the federal government persuaded most provinces to agree in June 2017 to harmonise regulations, with provincial mining royalties capped at 3%. Under the deal, there will be a separate 1.5% levy for provincial infrastructure funds. At the signing ceremony Mr Macri said that mining was a "pillar of job creation" capable of creating 125,000 new jobs, and made clear that the government's position that it is possible to develop the industry and employment while protecting the environment. The government's aim is to more than double total mining investment to US$25bn over the next eight years, up from US$10bn in 2007-15.
There are reasons for optimism-not least because of growing interest in Argentina's lithium deposits-Argentina has the third-largest lithium reserves in the world-at a time when global demand for the metal is rising, owing to its use in a new generation of batteries. But both mining companies and environmental groups have approached the new code with some caution, saying that there has been little consultation on it, and noting that it will need legislative approval at both federal and provincial level, a potentially lengthy process.
While noting the benefit of harmonised regulations, mining companies are particularly wary of the tax burden, on the basis that provinces currently charging lower royalties may use the new code as an excuse to raise them up to the 3% ceiling (although government officials have claimed that there will be no changes in royalties on existing mines). Mining companies have also complained that a change in the taxable base from the total "pithead" value (before transport or transformation) to total gross sales would imply an increase in the tax burden. Despite these reservations, we believe that the code is a positive signal for a neglected industry, and, along with rising metals prices, it will help to attract additional investment inflows and boost the sector's growth in the medium term.

Inflation has drifted up above 50% amid unanchored inflation expectations and continued large regulated price adjustments. Right up until the fourth quarter of 2019, inflation is likely to stay above 40%. However, as last year's price spike falls out of the index, and as extremely tight restrictions on money-supply growth curb price pressures, we expect disinflation to take hold, bringing inflation down to around 37% at end-2019. Later in our forecast period, we expect disinflation to continue, assuming that macroeconomic policy remains tight and that domestic supply improves on the back of an improved regulatory environment for agricultural and other producers.

The BCRA has been forced to adjust its exchange-rate framework once again, highlighting the difficulty of shifting to a free float in Argentina, where trust in the peso is extremely weak, large domestic transactions have become increasingly dollarised, and a stable peso has become synonymous among the population at large with a strong and stable economy (and vice versa). In this environment, small currency fluctuations have tended to spiral into extreme volatility, and the BCRA has gained Fund approval to jettison its moving "non-intervention band" and intervene directly in the forex market to protect the peso's value. Notwithstanding intervention, we expect the peso to continue to depreciate this year, from around Ps45:US$1 currently to Ps52:US$1 at year-end, amid fairly large swings in the value of the currency related to economic pressures and to pre-election jitters. Thereafter, our forecasts assume some continued nominal depreciation, although the competitiveness gains from the 2018 devaluation will be eroded gradually amid still-high inflation. However, on average, according to our forecasts for the peso and for inflation, the currency will be undervalued in 2019-23 in real trade-weighted terms compared with its ten- or 20-year averages, with positive implications for the external sector.

Last year's currency adjustment will help the current-account deficit to more than halve in 2019, to 2.2% of GDP, on the back of a moderate expansion of goods and services exports and steep import compression amid recession. Assuming that investment in a more competitive industrial sector continues, and that Argentina becomes less dependent on oil imports as energy sector investments start to come on stream, we expect the current account to continue to narrow in the reminder of the forecast period. Reserves coverage will be supported by fresh inflows of funds from the IMF under the SBA. As adjustment in the current account gathers pace, and assuming moderate inflows of foreign direct investment averaging 2.6% of GDP in 2019-23 and an eventual recovery of portfolio flows, a rebuilding of foreign reserves is likely.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Argentina
Stocks and flows
The inward foreign direct investment (FDI) stock was US$73bn (14% of GDP) in 2018 and the outward stock of FDI was US$42bn (8% of GDP). Inflows of FDI to Argentina have been volatile in recent decades and have followed economic cycles of boom and bust. In the 1990s inflows to Argentina increased substantially, reaching 3.7% of GDP in the second half of the decade, reflecting a privatisation programme and acquisitions of domestic private firms. This was followed by a collapse in inward FDI to 1.4% of GDP in 2001-03, reflecting Argentina's default on its foreign debt in 2001 and a subsequent deep recession. Devaluation stimulated a rapid recovery of inward FDI in subsequent years, with inflows averaging 3.7% of GDP in 2003-08. Since then, however, FDI inflows have weakened, from 3% of GDP in 2008 to an annual average 1.8% of GDP in 2009-15. Since Mauricio Macri became president in December 2015, the government has worked to address concerns about the strength and predictability of the legal and regulatory environment. For now, however, inward FDI remains subdued (at 2.3% of GDP in 2018), amid investor concerns over the long-term sustainability of recent improvements to contract rights and rule of law.
Origin and distribution
US firms account for a quarter of the stock of FDI, followed by Spanish firms (16%), and Dutch firms (11%). Chilean, Brazilian and Uruguayan companies account for around 5% each. Spanish firms have invested in privatised utilities, banking and energy. European firms in the utilities and banking sectors were hit hard by the 2001-02 crisis. As many companies disinvested after the crisis, firms from Brazil, Mexico and Chile bought up cheap assets. In 2015 the largest foreign direct investor in Argentina, by some distance, was the US, followed by Spain. The potential for an influx of Chinese FDI, focused in particular in agri-business, is substantial. However, the latest local-source data on FDI inflows into Argentina by country show that, in 2016, only 2% of FDI flows came from China (with the main flows of FDI coming again from the US and the EU, particularly Spain).
Determinants
FDI into Argentina is quite broadly spread; oil accounts for 20% of the stock, followed by chemicals, the automotive sector, metal minerals, the financial sector and telecommunications, although in the past decade almost half of FDI inflows have gone into manufacturing. Historically, Argentina has attracted investors hoping to take advantage of a relatively affluent and protected domestic market. During the 1990s, and as a result of rapid trade liberalisation, domestic market-seeking investment focused on sectors that showed comparative (or even absolute) advantages or were naturally protected from foreign competition (non-tradeable services, such as utilities). Efficiency-seeking investments have been less common, and have been mainly limited to the automotive industry, where government incentives have been in place for over a decade. Recent FDI in services (including information technology-IT) has been attracted by Argentina's skilled workforce and relatively low wages.
Impact
The presence of foreign subsidiaries has brought positive spillovers (both within and across industries) in manufacturing, but only in sectors where domestic firms have proven sufficiently adaptable. In other cases, increased competition from foreign investors, or a preference on the part of the latter for foreign suppliers, has damaged local firms. Telecoms is one example of a sector where the quality of service and technology has been transformed by foreign investment. Foreign investors own most of the privatised utilities. After the 2001-02 maxi-devaluation, which in effect broke the terms of foreign investors' contracts (and after the government declined to renegotiate), investment declined. The contribution of foreign firms to local research and development activities has been limited, as technical progress has been mainly embodied by imported capital goods and turnkey plants. Foreign firms account for a large share of Argentina's exports.
Potential
The major attractions for FDI will be a growing and relatively high-income domestic market, strong natural-resource endowments and, to a lesser extent, Argentina's potential as a manufacturing base. A relatively large pool of skilled human capital and a large stock of natural resources constitute Argentina's long-term advantages. Argentina's exit from default in 2016 will also act as a spur to FDI inflows, by facilitating investor access to investment guarantees and trade finance, which has until recently been lacking

Population growth will remain slow
Population growth has slowed in recent decades and is expected to remain below the Latin American average. Owing to a relatively low birth rate, the percentage of the population aged 14 or under is low by Latin American standards, and is falling. A declining gross birth rate and longer life expectancy also account for the high and rising share of the population aged 65 years and over, although, at close to 12%, this is still below that of OECD countries, where shares above 15% are the norm. Even so, the ageing population places increasing demand on Argentina's healthcare system which, despite its universal coverage, suffers from significant disparities at the provincial level.
The forecast rise in the economically active portion of the population is chiefly the result of an expected increase in the female participation rate. The latter was 49% of the working-age female population in 2018, up from 43% in 1990 but still below a total labour force participation rate of 60% (and below the OECD average female participation rate of 52%), and can be expected to rise in the forecast period. Although the gross birth rate is forecast to fall over the next decade, the gross mortality rate is expected to stay broadly constant as the ageing of the population offsets improvements in healthcare conditions. Argentina has in the past been the recipient of much inward migration (an estimated 85% of the population is of European descent) and has established quite a flexible approach to immigration. Although outward migration from countries such as Venezuela and Haiti in recent years has caused some political tension in other countries in Latin America, such as neighbouring Chile, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects Argentina's policy in this area to remain relatively flexible in the forecast period, enabling economic sectors such as agriculture and construction to continue to benefit from immigrant labour. Our positive medium-term economic forecasts for Argentina suggest that inward migration could pick up in the forecast period, following a period of substantial outward migration in recent decades. Partly owing to strong ties to Europe, 600,000 Argentinians are estimated to live abroad. Around one-third of these emigrated in the years immediately following the 2001-02 economic crisis. These newer emigrants are mainly middle-class young people who have moved to Spain, Italy and the US, many of whom benefit from dual Italian or Spanish citizenship.
An urban population with marked regional disparities
The population is highly urbanised. More than 90% of the country's population is concentrated in urban centres-one of the highest ratios in the world. The Buenos Aires metropolitan area contains almost one-third of the national population; when the hinterland of Buenos Aires (the pampas) is included, the proportion rises to two-thirds. Overall, population density is low, at 13 inhabitants per sq km (around one-third of the Latin American average), although this aggregate figure masks wide regional disparities: in the capital there are 13,679 inhabitants per sq km, whereas in the southern provinces of Santa Cruz and Chubut population density is just 0.8 and 1.8 inhabitants per sq km, respectively. Most measures of social and economic development show marked disparities between rural and urban areas, with per-head incomes and healthcare and education indicators much better in the Buenos Aires area than elsewhere.
Argentina's lead in regional healthcare and education standards will erode
Although Argentina's healthcare indicators still compare favourably with those of most of its neighbours, social conditions worsened markedly during the 1998-2002 recession, and in many areas problems have persisted ever since, suggesting that expenditure has become inefficient. Spending on obras sociales, union-run health insurance schemes financed through social security contributions, remains elevated owing to high administrative costs and weak governance mechanisms. The healthcare and education systems are in urgent need of reform. Even so, a high level of educational attainment by regional standards means that the stock of human capital will remain a source of comparative strength, although improvements in some other Latin American countries will close the gap within the region.

Argentina's wealth of natural resources, large domestic market (with high per-head incomes relative to much of the rest of the region), and proximity and preferential access to the large Brazilian market represent attractive long-term opportunities for foreign investors. However, an ongoing economic adjustment to address macroeconomic imbalances and rein in inflation will deter investment in the very short term, especially as businesses await greater political and economic certainty. On the assumption that Mr Macri wins a second term in the presidential election in October, and that orthodox economic policy is given continuity, The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts a shift to moderate GDP growth rates of an annual average 2.9% in 2020-23. Improvements to the business environment throughout the forecast period should create additional domestic market opportunities in the medium term.
Some improvement in purchasing power expected
Argentina is a middle-income country with one of the highest levels of GDP per head in the region-US$21,720 at purchasing power parity (PPP) exchange rates in 2018. Demographics are generally supportive of growth: the population is estimated at around 45m (the fourth-largest in Latin America), and is reasonably young, albeit not as young as that of most other countries in the region. Moreover, urbanisation is high, at more than 90% of the population. However, as in much of the region, income inequality and poverty remain high. According to recently released data from the Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Censos de la República Argentina (INDEC, the national statistics institute), the poverty rate came in at 32% in the second half of 2018. The extreme poverty rate was 6.7%. These numbers illustrate the detrimental impact of last year's recession on Argentinians' living conditions. However, there is significant variation in the incidence of poverty by region, with the highest poverty rates recorded in the Northern provinces of Corrientes (49.3%) and Chaco (41.4%). By contrast, the poverty rate was much lower in cities in the Patagonian (24.9%) and the Greater Buenos Aires (31.3%) provinces. In fact, in the capital, Buenos Aires, the poverty rate was only 12.6%.
A full analysis of the poverty data over time is complicated by a lack of historical data. A deterioration of statistical quality during the previous administration led to unreliable poverty statistics; in the latter years of the previous administration, INDEC stopped publishing poverty statistics altogether. Under new leadership, INDEC began publishing poverty data in mid-2016, using new methodology that is not comparable with the discredited historical data. However, the mid-2016 INDEC data are similar to figures published by the Centro de Estudios Distributivos Laborales y Sociales (Cedlas), a social policy research institute at the Universidad Nacional de La Plata. According to Cedlas, the poverty rate is roughly similar to data from the first half of 2011, implying that there was no progress on poverty reduction between 2011 and 2016. In the medium term, lower inflation rates and steady economic growth should help to reduce poverty through spillover effects. In the meantime, however, poor social conditions will contribute to insecurity and social unrest.

A long-term shift in consumer attitudes towards cheaper brands and lower-cost, high-volume outlets was brought about by the economic crisis of 2001-02. However, we expect the proportion of income spent on food, beverages and tobacco to fall gradually in the forecast period, and for the proportion of consumer spending on hotels and restaurants, healthcare, leisure and education to grow. This assumes growth in purchasing power as real disposable incomes rise over the course of the forecast period, driven by growth in employment, income redistribution via Argentina's relatively new conditional cash transfer schemes, and greater efforts at financial inclusion, which suggest a steady increase in access to bank credit during the forecast period. One difference between Argentina and the rest of the region will be the age of the population. Argentina's population will remain markedly older; just over 11% were aged 65 years and over in 2018. This will affect consumption patterns, notably pushing up overall expenditure on healthcare.

Abundant natural resources and a skilled labour force underpin potential
Argentina has historically been susceptible to cycles of boom and bust, reflecting both a vulnerability to external conditions and domestic policy challenges. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecast rests on the assumption that Argentina will adopt a more sustainable economic model that reduces fiscal and external imbalances, allowing the economy to grow by an average of 2.5% in 2019-50.
Initial conditions: Argentina's GDP per head of US$11,599 in 2018 (US$21,720 at purchasing power parity) is one of the highest in the region. However, as it is still only one-third of the US figure, there is clearly potential for Argentina to catch up to developed-country levels. The internal market is relatively large and, although the territory is extensive, there are few internal geographical obstacles, although Argentina is distant from developed-country markets and high transport costs will place an extra burden on exporters. For a decade after the 2001 maxi-devaluation, labour was cheaper than during the 1990s, but the gains from devaluation had been eliminated by 2012 amid high inflation and sustained real wage growth. Despite two decades of gradual de-industrialisation, Argentina retains a solid skilled labour base, and the capacity to carry out high-level research and development. It will attract manufacturing investment, but its competitiveness as a global manufacturing centre will lag behind Asian rivals. Argentina has a strong comparative advantage in agriculture, although, as a commodity producer, it will face more volatile terms of trade than Asian competitors. This means that growth is likely to be uneven.
Demographic trends: Argentina shares demographic as well as cultural features with Europe. The average age of the population is higher than in most of the rest of the region and population growth both in percentage and absolute terms is expected to be slightly lower. We expect population growth of 0.7% per year in 2017-50, less than half the average recorded in 1980-2000. At present, the working-age population is still growing faster than the overall population, but we expect this trend to change from around 2030. Although the share of the working age population will continue to rise gradually towards OECD levels, from an estimated 64% in 2020, growth in the labour force will be modest. Particularly towards the end of the long-term forecast period, the contribution of labour to GDP will therefore be weaker.
The population is more urbanised and better provided with healthcare than in other Latin American countries, leading to a life expectancy of around 77 years, similar to that of many developed countries. Given the existence of the welfare state and the severe weakening of the finances of the state and private pensions systems in the past two decades, the growing elderly population will increasingly generate strains on the public finances.
External conditions: Growth-determining factors exogenous to Argentina will include the level of developed-country interest rates (in the past this has been strongly correlated with the volume of capital flows into Latin America and has had a major impact on growth) and commodity prices. Argentina will remain highly dependent on income from exports of agricultural commodities to provide an investible surplus for deployment elsewhere in the economy. Restricted access to finance since the 2001 default has raised the cost of capital in the past decade by forcing reliance on financing from the shallow, more expensive domestic market. However, Argentina's exit from default in April 2016 implies improved access to international capital markets to facilitate stronger growth in investment, particularly in agriculture, energy and infrastructure.
Institutional weaknesses will constrain growth
Institutions and policy trends: Disappointing economic outcomes have been the indirect result of shortcomings in policymaking and institutions. Argentina scores moderately to poorly on measures of corruption, security and the rule of law. Our analysis suggests that an improvement in the overall institutional climate would have a significant impact on long-term growth, but institutional reforms will take a long time to bear fruit. The quality of policymaking is likely to improve more rapidly. The government of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner (2007-15) clashed with foreign investors over the terms of contracts, and oversaw a phase of ad hoc intervention in the economy. A more market-friendly administration, led by Mauricio Macri, is seeking to address these problems, and under our assumption that the president will win a second term at October elections, we expect that the government will succeed early on in the long-term forecast period in establishing a new framework for foreign investors in sectors such as utilities.
Long-term performance: We forecast that average annual GDP will grow by 2.5% in 2019-50, with the growth rate peaking at 3% in 2021-30, before slowing to 2.2% by 2041-50. Our forecasts assume that the contribution of capital to growth will be firm in the first part of the 2018-50 forecast period, before tapering off somewhat over the latter part of the period. We also assume that as growth in the working-age population slows, the increase in the availability of labour will slow, meaning that growth will become more dependent on productivity gains. To the extent that they are achieved, these gains are likely to be made via technology transfer and higher foreign investment. Firms will increasingly look beyond national borders in order to achieve economies of scale, and this will stimulate efficiency gains. Having said this, and although Argentina's abundant natural resources and relatively strong skills base represent solid economic potential, the country will struggle to achieve the productivity gains needed to converge with developed-market income levels. This is particularly the case in the light of low levels of domestic investment in research and development, and we expect limited progress in catching up with developed country incomes, even in the long-term forecast period.
