Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Climate change represents a risk to Argentina's long-term growth rate, most obviously through its impact on the important agriculture sector. Argentina has suffered four major droughts in the period since 2009 alone, which has produced a severe knock-on impact on real GDP each time. Since it came to office in late 2015, the Macri administration has worked to develop a comprehensive climate change plan; one element of this is the increased use of renewable energy, including hydroelectric, wind and solar power. Despite having some of Latin America's most abundant natural energy resources, less than 2% of the country's electricity currently comes from renewable energy. Under the "RenovAr" programme, Argentina is now targeting a total of 20% of electricity from renewable sources by 2025. As part of its climate change mitigation efforts Argentina is aiming to surpass its nationally determined contribution (NDC) originally submitted under the Paris Agreement.
The Macri administration is also in the process of developing sectoral mitigation and adaptation plans for agriculture, transport, infrastructure, forests, industry and energy, with a view to unveiling a new national climate change plan in 2019. The central government is also working on the development of a climate change map, to work with local and provincial authorities to determine geographical vulnerabilities and develop adaptation and mitigation plans, and financing, accordingly. In the Uruguay River area on the border between Argentina and Uruguay, a joint initiative between the two countries is in progress to try to increase the resilience of vulnerable coastal populations in this area. Continued progress in all these areas, both in the planning and implementation stages, will be necessary to reduce the long-term impact on growth as a result of climate change.
Technological developments
Argentina's high skills base by regional comparison will be a key factor supporting the country's ability to adapt to technological disruption in the long term. Combined with high per-head incomes, this helps to explain the country's leading position in Latin America with regard to mobile and broadband penetration, e-commerce and m-commerce, and the strength of sectors such as software development and financial technology (fintech). The capital city, Buenos Aires, is a hub for both these industries in Latin America. It is the largest exporter of software in the region, and is a large and rapidly growing centre for fintech centred on payment systems, corporate financial management, consumer and business lending, and new technologies for existing financial institutions
The e-commerce environment is expected to remain strong, and m-commerce will grow, supported by high penetration of mobile broadband. Online retail has been quicker to develop than in many other countries in the region, and is still growing rapidly (by 47% in 2018). Online and mobile banking is already popular, and is used by customers to conduct routine transactions, aided by well-developed mobile banking services and a modern payments system that meets international standards.
Regulation and governance remain relative weak points, while a backdrop of still-high inflation and macroeconomic distortions will in the short term continue to deter significant private (including foreign investment), to the detriment of research and development, and the number of patent applications. Recent reforms to simplify patent applications should, however, produce improvements going forward.
A continuing weakness that shows fewer sign of progress as yet is logistics, with most delivery companies failing to deliver as rapidly as is the case in similarly ranked countries. This reflects a legacy of weak investment in physical infrastructure, which has hampered the quality of the road network and led to some port delays. We assume better progress in this area in the long term, which will be necessary to insert Argentina into global value chains, and allow for "leapfrogging" to tilt industrial production more rapidly towards high-tech, high-value-added products
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and European GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Commodity prices: IFS; non-oil
Oil prices: Brent average import price
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
US effective exchange-rate index: IFS; nominal weighted index, 1990=100
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics Yearbook
US$ GDP: IFS; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at annual average market exchange rate
US$ GDP at PPP: IFS; The Economist Intelligence Unit; local-currency GDP converted to US dollars at estimated annual average of consumer products' PPP
Population and growth: Celade
Non-financial public-sector (NFPS) balance: excludes privatisation revenue
Prime lending rate: simple average rate charged on local-currency 30-day loans to creditworthy businesses
Deposit rate: average rate weighted by deposit amount on 30- to 59-day time deposits
Inflation: IFS; derived from consumer price index (CPI) for Buenos Aires metropolitan area, 1999=100
Labour costs: hourly wage in industrial sector
Real exchange rate: The Economist Intelligence Unit; a real exchange rate of less than 100% indicates that the currency is undervalued vis-à-vis relative prices and vice versa
Balance of payments: IFS
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding with an original maturity in excess of one year, plus arrears and year-end IMF debt outstanding
Total external debt: sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and arrears
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
Celade: Centro Latinoamericano y Caribeño de Demografía
IFS: International Financial Statistics
PPP: purchasing power parity; average ratio of prices in Argentina to prices in the US
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Nigeria--highlights: Political outlook
The government will largely fail to achieve its promises of tackling corruption, improving stability and boosting living standards. A period of lower oil revenue in 2019 and 2020, after a largely squandered decade of higher prices, will hinder the government's ability to boost development, particularly of infrastructure. Non-oil tax rises are unavoidable over the long term, but the revenue/GDP ratio will remain among the world's lowest, limiting the effectiveness of fiscal policy. High levels of poverty and unemployment will combine with the country's ethnic and religious divisions to ignite into outbreaks of violence. Nonetheless, Nigeria has a high tolerance for political instability, and much of it is localised. There is little significant threat to the government's position outside of the election cycle.
Nigeria--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a     Global rank b     Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23   2014-18 2019-23   2014-18 2019-23
4.29 4.41   75 77   13 14
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The business environment in Nigeria is unlikely to improve significantly. Even if progress is made, it will often be at a slower rate than in the country's peers. Systemic problems in infrastructure and the labour market mean that Nigeria remains towards the bottom of the global business environment rankings for the forecast period, at 77th out of 82 countries in 2019-23. On a regional basis, Nigeria is ranked 15th out of 17 countries for the forecast period. Efforts to create a more attractive business environment are likely to produce only modest results, owing to parliamentary divisions (which reflect societal divisions more widely), the ongoing problem of corruption, the absence of effective government institutions and the weak capacity of the civil service to implement changes. It will remain largely beyond the capacity of Nigeria's policymakers, even in the medium term, to push through much-needed and comprehensive reforms, especially when they challenge the status quo.

Although economic growth in 2019-23 will continue to recover from the recession of 2016-17, the pace will remain well below historic averages. Trends in the oil sector and elections in 2019 will have a negative effect on the economy. Inflation will remain in double digits, amid currency depreciation and politicised monetary policy. Economic policymakers will struggle to resist calls from the legislature to increase spending, given pressing development needs. Set against this, oil sector revenue is likely to underperform, leading to continual fiscal deficits of about 2% of GDP. The current account will post small surpluses after several decades of large surpluses amid weaker revenue from oil exports.

The population growth rate will remain high enough to retain a relatively stable age profile. However, the formal economy will not grow quickly enough to provide the employment needed to absorb 3% annual growth in the working-age population. This will jeopardise attempts to reduce poverty. Furthermore, high numbers of poor young unemployed people will provide a fertile recruiting ground for militant groups, thus prolonging violent instability in large parts of the country.
Nigeria--highlights: Market opportunities

Nigeria remains an important market for many multinationals because of its abundant natural resources and the size of its population (the largest in Africa), despite the very low level of income on average. Indeed, in absolute, let alone relative terms, Nigeria has more people in extreme poverty than any other country in Africa. However, the relatively large wealthy elite and growing middle class make up important submarkets. Nigeria has the potential to be a profitable market for multinational companies that know how to operate in its complex and chaotic regulatory environment and can overcome the logistical difficulties posed by the almost non-existent infrastructure. Strong growth in consumption towards the end of the forecast period will increase this attractiveness.
Nigeria--highlights: Long-term outlook

Nigeria's long-term economic performance will pick up moderately, driven by a stronger export sector as large projects come on stream. However, reforms to improve the business environment and unlock investor confidence are unlikely to be sufficient to promote fundamental diversification of the economy, meaning that Nigeria will remain heavily exposed to the oil and gas sector. Moreover, income levels will remain very low.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multiparty democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in 2015, and Mr Buhari secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 has almost wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Muhammadu Buhari-a former military dictator turned civilian politician-first became president in 2015 and won a second four-year term in office in February 2019. Mr Buhari's ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) also retained a majority in both houses, which it had achieved in 2015. The ascension to power of Mr Buhari and the APC in 2015 ended the domination of politics by the People's Democratic Party (PDP), which had lasted since the start of civilian rule in 1999. The cabinet must contain representatives from each of Nigeria's 36 states, although very few are elected politicians. Mr Buhari and his ministers are scrutinised by an elected bicameral National Assembly. State governments enjoy considerable autonomy under governors and elected state assemblies.

The cracks in the APC are expected to widen
The APC is far from a united entity, however. It is an amalgamation of the three largest former opposition parties and a faction of a fourth (all with separate geographic and ethnic power bases, as well as varying ideologies), together with PDP defectors. Political appointments have therefore been based in numerous instances on distributing the vestiges of power among the APC's constituent elements rather than merit. In late 2018 there were mass defections from the APC, with many crossing the floor to join the PDP. Although in a sense this refreshed the party ahead of Mr Buhari's second term, dissension within the ranks is likely to re-emerge as the administration struggles to turn around Nigeria's struggling economy and the next election approaches, in 2023.
Political outlook: Political stability
Mr Buhari won a presidential election in February 2019 and will remain in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. For any Nigerian leader, managing the country's myriad security threats would be an insoluble challenge, but under Mr Buhari there are particular reasons to expect serious, albeit localised unrest.
The election revealed a deep sense of voter apathy in southern Nigeria-an economically vital region, although prone to militancy and separatism, and where voter turnout was less than 20% in some places. In his first term Mr Buhari was seen by many in the southern region as absent, rarely making visits there, and with the ruling APC vote share being heavily concentrated in the north-and with that region facing various and urgent security issues-government attention will probably remain focused there. As a result, the disconnect between Nigeria's south and mainstream politics is unlikely to heal. Indeed, the government will give priority to containing banditry in the very far north-west and the Islamist militant group Boko Haram, which is resurgent in the north-east and is utilising new tactics and more sophisticated hardware. Mr Buhari's "zero tolerance" approach to terrorism was a major reason for the strong turnout and support for him in the affected states. As was the case in his last tenure, substantial federal resources are likely to be channelled towards restoring law and order in the region. However, militants in the oil-producing south cite the use of oil earnings for far-flung causes such as combating Boko Haram-rather than for local development-as justification for the insurgency. So it seems likely that attacks by aggrieved militants on oil infrastructure will continue to be a major security problem in Delta state.
Boko Haram will probably be aggressively countered, but in the process the north-east of Nigeria will essentially become a low-level conflict zone. Just to the south of this region, in the agricultural Middle Belt of Nigeria, a more insoluble challenge will be addressing extremely violent clashes between settled farmers and nomads competing for increasingly scarce water and land resources. Formal land titling is a potential answer, but as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another it would prove too contentious. Ultimately there is no foreseeable end to violence in the Middle Belt. Moreover, in Mr Buhari's first term, it was clear that military engagements in other parts of Nigeria have priority when it comes to deploying the army's thinly spread resources, and the same is likely to be true in his second. Again, the direct security impact of the conflict will be localised, with little spillover into the administrative capital, Abuja, or the economic capital, Lagos. The entire country will feel the secondary effects, however, in the form of constricted food supply and high consumer prices.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Institutional effectiveness will remain poor in Nigeria. The National Assembly is very slow at moving through new legislation, owing both to inefficiency and to tensions between the executive and legislative branches of government. With the APC largely a coalition of convenience, competing ideologies and priorities will continue to hinder the legislative process, as will tensions over spending priorities between the federal government and powerful state governors. Furthermore, vested political interests, inefficiency and corruption have slowed reform in Nigeria for decades, and these issues are unlikely to change in the forecast period.
Corruption will prove impossible to tackle comprehensively
Nigeria has traditionally had a relatively strong economic team, led by able technocrats generally in favour of structural reform. In his first term Mr Buhari maintained this practice, given the need to bolster confidence among international investors and lenders, and he will probably continue in this vein in his second term. However, as always, the team's capacity to translate good intentions into action will be hampered by Nigeria's complex political environment, entrenched rent-seeking interest groups and weak administrative system. Despite some reforms of the civil service-including the removal of so-called ghost workers by the new administration-the public sector will remain overstaffed, highly bureaucratic and largely ineffective, given internal resistance to reform and a lack of desire among the leadership to upset deep-seated patronage networks and finely balanced factions within the APC. Although some progress has been made in strengthening institutional capacity to check more blatant forms of corruption, rent-seeking officials and politicians have found more subtle ways to defraud the Treasury, with continued corrosive effects on politics and economic management. Perceptions of corruption willremain high and extend across state institutions. Accusations from some businesses about "round tripping", whereby individuals and companies access foreign exchange at the overvalued official rate and then sell it on the parallel market for a profit, will also abound.
A weak judiciary will undermine the fight against corruption
Fighting corruption has long been a government priority, and is a key objective for Mr Buhari, but the administration's efforts are likely to yield limited results. Structural deficiencies-in particular inadequate checks and balances-mean that graft will remain a problem despite the periodic headline-grabbing arrests. In addition, allegations of political score-settling are often levelled at the authorities in their anti-corruption efforts-something that will stoke acrimony and prevent greater co-operation across the political, legal and social spheres. The judicial system is still deeply undermined by corruption and hugely underfunded. This has resulted in poor administration of justice, including long delays in the hearing of cases.
Political outlook: Election watch
Nigeria's national elections took place on February 23rd and were marred by violence, delays and voter apathy, but Mr Buhari of the ruling APC secured 56% of the vote. Participation across the country, at 35%, was well down on the 44% turnout rate in 2015, partly reflecting a delay to the poll but also disengagement with the two main candidates. There was especially low participation in the south-a traditional PDP stronghold-with voters there evidently feeling alienated by the two main candidates (who are both northern). The parliamentary election gave the APC a large majority in both houses; in theory, this should allow for the swift passage of legislation, but Mr Buhari's first term was marked by divisions between the executive and parliament (as had happened to presidents before him), and crucial bills including the national budget were delayed by months. As legislators typically prioritise the interests of their constituents over party and federation in Nigeria, similar tensions could easily reoccur in Mr Buhari's second stint. The next election will be in 2023, and a new APC presidential candidate will stand. Custom dictates that after two terms for a northerner, the next APC and PDP nominees will be from the country's south.
Political outlook: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat they pose. Stretched resources, vast territories and porous borders will prevent complete military victories. Relations with the US will be mixed; the administration of Donald Trump is willing to sell Nigeria military hardware, but Mr Trump's disapproval of the trade deficit the US runs with Nigeria (particularly owing to Nigerian import restrictions) could strain ties. Relations with the EU will be largely cordial but subject to tensions over Nigerian migrants seeking to enter Europe and Nigerian efforts to repatriate funds in European banks that were allegedly looted by former rulers.
India will remain important as the largest market for Nigerian oil and become a bigger source of foreign investment. China will also remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will fall short of the headline-grabbing pledges made, given an extremely challenging local business environment. Nigeria will remain an important player on the Sub-Saharan African stage given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused.

Nigeria's business environment will remain among the most challenging in the world over the next five years. Small improvements in the political environment and minor pro-business policy measures will not be enough to prevent the country dropping by two places in the global rankings, to 77th (out of 82 countries) as others improve at a faster rate. Similarly, in the regional rankings Nigeria slips by one place, from 13th to 14th (out of 17 countries).
Efforts to create a significantly more attractive business environment in the country will continue to be hindered by the slow pace of market-oriented structural reforms, the ongoing problem of corruption, the absence of effective government institutions, the weak capacity of the civil service to implement changes and extremely poor infrastructure. It will remain largely beyond the capacity of Nigeria's policymakers, even in the medium term, to push through the much-needed and comprehensive reforms.
Efforts to diversify economy away from oil will require pro-business reforms
Although Nigeria will continue to recover from the economic recession of 2016 during the forecast period, prices for its export and fiscal mainstay, oil, will remain well below the peaks seen in the early 2010s. This will place ongoing strain on the economy. However, there is good to come from this, as it will force the administration to do more to improve the business environment and facilitate growth in the non-oil sector. Furthermore, with the government unable to afford a sustained large-scale public spending spree to try to boost growth (the revenue/GDP ratio is too low), it will instead edge towards sanctioning a greater role for private companies in the provision of public services. This includes the domains of healthcare, education and infrastructure building, although the benefits of this will only be felt after the end of the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. The upstream oil sector will remain characterised by joint-ventures between the state oil company and multinationals.
2021-23: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress will be slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: An attempt to sell the state's interest in oil joint ventures with multinationals will meet serious challenges (the policy has been around for years), with resistance in the legislature to the permanent loss of a revenue stream.
2021-23: Higher world oil prices and so easing fiscal pressures lessen the need to embark on a divestment programme. Energy companies will anyway be hesitant to increase their stake in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Import bans are widened, but as oil prices decline, the naira weakens anyway as foreign-exchange inflows lessen.
2021-23: A premium between the official and parallel market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2019-20: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Value-added tax (VAT) is increased to fund a higher minimum wage, which will markedly increase the fiscal cost of the civil service.
2021-23: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation, particularly for offshore oilfields. The need for new consumer taxes is alleviated by higher world oil prices and, as a result, hydrocarbons revenue.
Financing
2019-20: Funding for well-planned projects becomes easier to raise domestically following the completion of the 2019 elections, as local capital markets deepen (with greater foreign participation) and the banking sector develops.
2021-23: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts national savings and investment.
The labour market
2019-20: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2021-23: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff, although unemployment remains high and the market generally loose.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints and is crowded out by other spending categories, including debt-servicing. Although there should be growth in private-sector investment, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2021-23: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2021-23: Research spending is likely to remain low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment

The economy will perform less badly than in 2016, but not by much
Nigeria will maintain positive economic growth during the forecast period. However, although marking an improvement on the contraction recorded in 2016, that remains a long way from saying that the country has a strong economy. Real GDP per head growth remains too low to significantly reduce poverty rates in the country. Indeed, Nigeria's ranking for this category actually deteriorates in 2019-23. Nigeria's macroeconomic environment will remain constrained by insecure property rights, a weak civil service, confusion caused by overlaps and contradictions between local, state and federal government actions, and deeply entrenched vested interests opposed to free-market competition. Macroeconomic policy will continue to espouse the promotion of market-led growth and poverty reduction, but action is unlikely to match rhetoric.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.5 4.5 70 69 12 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
During his time as military leader in the 1980s, the current president, Muhammadu Buhari, demonstrated a penchant for heavy state intervention at the expense of private-sector endeavour, and his policy statements while in power since 2015 imply that he still sees a large regulatory role for the state. However, he has pro-business reformers with private-sector experience in his inner circle, although there are others opposed to such reforms, and the state's limited capacity (in terms of both skills and finances) to expand its role will act as a constraint on its interference. The net result is likely to bring modest policy improvements, but not quickly enough to affect Nigeria's global ranking.
Despite the rhetoric of the government's Economic Recovery and Growth Plan (ERGP), which was released in early 2017, it is highly unlikely that Nigeria will embark on major market-oriented structural reforms during the forecast period. The ERGP offers a vision of an economy that is largely private-sector-driven, recognising the power of free markets. However, vested interests will hinder such an agenda, including politicians wanting to protect patronage networks across geopolitical faultlines, consumers used to price controls and large subsidies, and, in particular, powerful business interests.
Given the small number of politically connected companies operating in many formal sectors, and the existing barriers to entry into many sectors, competition is expected to remain limited. Companies in the formal sector have been dependent on state subsidies and have been shielded by protectionist policies for so long that many are unlikely to respond favourably to government implementation of fundamental free-market reforms. The Buhari administration will find extra-governmental support for continued state intervention, both openly and discreetly, particularly with regard to foreign trade.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.1 5.5 65 65 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
An opaque and slow-moving policy environment has historically limited-but not entirely deterred-foreign investors in Nigeria. Although governments are keen to access global capital as a means of propelling economic development, there is also a nativist sentiment; local companies with political links are often given favourable treatment. Little change is expected in the government's policy towards foreign investment over the forecast period, due to deeply entrenched vested interests. With other countries showing improvement, Nigeria's position will remain unchanged in both the global and regional rankings.
Various factors will limit investor interest
A lower oil price environment compared with earlier boom years will limit investor interest in that sector. Despite government efforts to drum up higher levels of non-oil investment, this will be limited by the complexities of the local business environment, along with the bureaucracy, corruption, low productivity, poor infrastructure, cash-call arrears by the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) to joint-venture partners and generally low income levels that restrict the potential market. Ongoing foreign-exchange restrictions will remain an off-putting factor for investors.
In addition to the weaker oil price environment, inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) into the hydrocarbons sector will also remain constrained until the regulatory and tax environments get finalised. The Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB) was designed to do this; it was first submitted to the National Assembly (parliament) in 2008, and after several years of delay the complex piece of legislature was broken down into four separate bills to make passage easier. Nonetheless, progress remains slow, largely because of the rival claims of the stakeholders, both local and foreign, who continue to lobby to advance their interests, which invariably relate to the control and sharing of the benefits derived from Nigeria's considerable oil and gas endowment. Although there is general agreement among all parties that the country's petroleum sector has long been in need of structural and regulatory reform to enable it to operate more efficiently, there is lack of consensus on how to achieve this, both internally, such as between federalists and resource nationalists in the oil-producing areas and between the government and the multinationals responsible for most of the country's hydrocarbon output. A less controversial part of the PIB was passed in 2018, but the president returned the bill to parliament unsigned, possibly because the bill would reduce the power of the oil minister to award, amend, renew, extend or revoke oil licences and contracts. Accordingly, we expect further progress in improving the regulatory environment to be limited during the forecast period.
Most disconcerting for investors is the lack of progress in establishing a new oil and gas fiscal regime. With the government having often declared its intention to change the fiscal regime to increase its take of oil profits, oil companies cannot be sure whether any new arrangement-when finally enacted-will match their profit expectations. Nigerian oil officials and civil society groups have for many years complained that the existing regime is outdated and under-rewards their country for its oil production, especially the deepwater terms that were negotiated in the early 1990s when oil prices were only US$20/barrel. For example, Nigeria Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative, a government-funded watchdog, said in a study in March 2019 that Nigeria had lost at least US$16bn over a ten-year period (between 2008 and 2017), owing to the non-review of the production sharing contracts signed with oil companies in 1993.
The proposed petroleum industry fiscal bill introduces a price-based assessment for royalties, with rates scaled according to daily production. It also includes a provision for an additional petroleum income tax when the price of crude exceeds US$60/b. The additional tax rate is 0.5% for every additional US$1 price increase to a maximum additional tax rate of 60%. Executives of major international oil companies have argued that increases in oil taxes in the proposed petroleum industry legation are too high and liable to deter investment in exploration. Concern has also been expressed over the complexity of the proposed changes. In May 2018 the NNPC advocated for the simplification of the fiscal system in the PIFB to ease implementation and ensure progressivity. Overall, the process is still in an early conceptual stage, and the authorities will continue to face conflicting demands from various stakeholders as the legislative process moves forward, slowing progress. These include ethnic nationalists demanding a greater share of oil revenue for impoverished communities in oil-producing areas (so-called host communities); federal officials wanting to maximise Nigeria's share of oil profits; and multinational oil companies seeking to hold on to their profits, while also demanding improvement in the local operating environment. Given all of this, it is difficult to envisage any rapid improvement in the investment environment in the hydrocarbons sector.
The administration plans to sell some oil and non-oil state assets in the coming years to raise money to help to cover the budget deficit. However, despite including substantial amounts of privatisation proceeds in its revenue projections in the 2018 and 2019 budgets, the administration has been slow to quicken the pace of its slow-moving privatisation programme. The authorities will be cautious in selling state enterprises, given the likely opposition from local interest groups that have benefited from the status quo or believe that the state should retain its control of strategic public utilities. The government's ability to sell loss-making state enterprises that rely on some form of state subvention to survive will depend on its willingness to allow these concerns to adopt free marketing pricing for their goods and services. For example, the NNPC will find it difficult to find suitable buyers for its underperforming oil refineries while official domestic petrol prices remain below cost recovery.
The government announced in March 2019 that it intends to reduce the NNPC's stake in joint venture oil companies (JVCs) to 40% in order to bolster the public finances. Through the parastatal the government currently holds a 55% stake in the JVC operated by Shell (UK/Netherlands) and 60% equity in the other ventures operated by other multinationals. Doing so would give foreign partners a freer hand to develop new projects, but existing investors will be wary of enlarging their stake in Nigeria's upstream sector before the enactment of the new petroleum industry laws, especially with respect to the fiscal regime (where the prospective regulatory environment remains highly uncertain). This will be reflected in price, and parliament will be unsupportive of selling off key assets, should it be low. Overall, the equity restructure is unlikely to take place soon, and in any case the government, as advised by the IMF, would want to amend the Petroleum Profit Tax Act first to ensure that sales of oil assets do not generate new tax exemptions that result in a revenue loss for the state.
Public mistrust of foreign investment will remain high
Given the government's desire to attract foreign capital, outright expropriation of foreign-owned assets is unlikely. However, legal disputes and accusations of corruption can easily ensnare investors. A running dispute between MTN, a major South African-owned telecommunications company, and the Nigerian government over large financial demands made on the firm for alleged infringements illustrates the risks faced by foreign companies that fall foul of the country's regulators. In October 2015 the Nigerian Communications Commission fined MTN a record US$5.2bn for failing to disconnect unregistered SIM cards. After negotiations, the company paid a reduced fine of just over US$1bn. In August 2018 the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) directed MTN to return US$8.1bn that it alleged was illegally repatriated out of Nigeria. Shortly after this, the government demanded that the company pay US$2bn owed in back-dated taxes. MTN has disputed both claims.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
2.8 3.3 80 79 16 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Nigeria will remain one of the worst-ranked countries for foreign trade and exchange controls during the forecast period. We expect the administration to continue to struggle with the management of the foreign-exchange system in an economy prone to fluctuations in supplies of hard currencies, largely owing to reliance on volatile crude oil sales. The Buhari administration has inched towards relaxing the foreign exchange regime with the creation in April 2017 of a special foreign-exchange window for investors and exporter (I&E window) for trading currencies at more market-determined rates, although the CBN still targets particular rates with interventions. This arrangement falls well short of full currency flexibility, and the government continues to retain an over-valued official exchange rate and implement import restrictions aimed at curtailing domestic demand for foreign exchange. The result has been a multiple exchange-rate environment that further complicates the already challenging business conditions. Whenever oil prices decline, investor concern about omnipresent risk of capital controls being reintroduced (as they temporarily were in 2016) will be heightened, which can reduce long-term financial flows in particular. While we expect some devaluation of the naira to be allowed over the forecast period, ongoing attempts to manage the currency's value will prevent the official naira rate from reaching market-clearing levels, and a large premium with the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Fixing, used by the I&E window, and parallel market rates will persist.
Protectionist sentiment will persist
Protectionist sentiment will remain strong in Nigeria, and it is unlikely that the Buhari administration will have either the political will or the ideological inclination to promote free trade. The government maintains high import tariffs and import bans on several dozen goods, including many foodstuffs, with the view of promoting local production and development of the non-oil sector. In March 2019 the CBN added textiles to a list of categories of goods and services for which importers are barred from accessing regulated foreign-exchange markets. The financial regulator indicated in January 2019 that the foreign-exchange restrictions may be increased from 43 items to 50 items. Because of these restrictions, cross-border smuggling is likely to remain an important feature of the Nigerian economy and exert additional pressure on locally based businesses.
The capacity and efficiency of Nigerian ports have improved following the implementation of an ambitious concession programme in the mid-2000s that transferred management of terminals to private operators. However, although the reforms have improved port operations and ship turnaround times, there remains the problem of corruption in the customs service, which can complicate and delay the clearance of goods, adding to the cost of doing business. Furthermore, port operations are still hampered by inadequate infrastructure, including the poor condition of the roads leading to the main seaports in the commercial capital, Lagos.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.3 5.4 62 68 10 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The government will attempt to increase tax rates and broaden the coverage of collection during the forecast period. It is likely to use a carrot-and-stick approach; although there will be increases in tax rates for corporates and consumers, some of the initial burden will be offset by offers of amnesties and moves to make it easier to pay taxes. The net result is little change in the score for this category, with Nigeria's ranking falling as other countries improve.
Widening the tax net is a priority
With the total tax-to-GDP ratio at only 6% across all tiers of government, Nigeria has one of the lowest tax takes in the world. The Federal Inland Service (FIRS) has made some progress in its various campaigns to widen the tax base, increasing the national tax roll to 19m people by December 2018, from 14m in 2014. The administration is considering raising value-added tax (VAT) from the current rate of 5% to 7.5% but this is unlikely to happen before 2020, as it requires an amendment of the Value Added Tax Act and will be deeply unpopular at a time when the economy is underperforming and living standards are declining. The extent of the increase is likely to be restrained by concerns about the effect on consumer price inflation, which is already high. The tax authorities will seek new ways to boost tax compliance and reduce tax exemptions, but it is doubtful whether their efforts will be sufficient to make a significant improvement to government finances from such a low base.
Many companies would be able to absorb moderate tax rises as long as they were accompanied by major improvements in the whole tax payment system. Companies in the formal sector complain about being subjected to multiple taxes as a result of tax authorities at the different tiers of government imposing a variety of levies, sometimes illegally. The fiscal rivalry between federal and subnational administrations makes it difficult for the central government to establish any new tax body with significant autonomy and the power to impose tax harmonisation. The efficacy of tax administration varies considerably by state. It is most sophisticated in the commercial capital, Lagos.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.8 5.1 61 68 10 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Nigeria's banking sector will continue to face a number of severe challenges, with the country's ranking for this category deteriorating in the forecast period as a result. The recession of 2016 (and prospects for only a weak recovery in the coming years) and deep exposure to the depressed oil and power sectors will continue to challenge banks' financial soundness. Non-performing loans surpassed 15% of total loans during 2017 and although it has been coming down (to 11.7% at end-2018), the NPL ratio is likely to remain high in the coming years as the oil sector continues to underperform and the wider economy posts weak growth, hindering businesses' operations. A weakening exchange rate adds to this gloomy picture. Lending denominated in US dollars accounts for almost half of banks' loan books, and lending to the oil and gas sector makes up about one-third of gross loans.
Some improvements to the financial sector are in prospect, but not many
Although the restructuring of the banking sector that took place after a major financial crisis in 2009 means that Nigerian banks are better placed to develop the domestic financial sector further, large challenges remain in raising standards to international levels, and crossborder supervision needs to be improved. Bank lending to private businesses-especially small and medium-sized firms-has been subdued in a high interest-rate environment, combined with low demand due to broader economic weaknesses. Nevertheless, as the forecast period progresses, greater competition in the banking sector should drive down the cost of banking and improve the availability of lending in the longer term, especially for corporate clients. Moreover, the government's efforts to create a long-term government bond market, as seen in its plan announced in April 2019 to issue 30-year federal government bonds, will help with the pricing of corporate debt and may allow the development of a more active corporate bond market in the future. Coupled with new listings and greater liquidity on the Nigerian Stock Exchange, this should make it easier to raise funds as the forecast period progresses.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.0 5.0 71 74 12 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The government of Mr Buhari has made reducing unemployment and boosting job creation one of its top priorities, particularly with regard to young people. However, the risk is that, rather than attempting to make liberalising changes to the economy as a means to improve job creation, the administration will instead adopt a more nationalistic approach, attempting to boost local employment by restricting that of foreigners. This prospect has led to the ranking for this category deteriorating in the forecast period.
Poor education system will continue to generate skills deficiency
The dire state of the education system, notably the vocational system and apprenticeship schemes, means that skilled manual labour-from bricklayers to mechanics and electricians-will remain in short supply. Additionally, poor standards of education, healthcare and transport mean that, in terms of unskilled labour, productivity levels are very low. Nigeria's university system will continue to churn out large numbers of graduates, with a bias towards the arts and social sciences, but the economy will still suffer from a large deficit of skilled personnel, particularly in the fields of science and technology, as well as business management. Foreign skilled personnel will also remain scarce. The government's reform drive to enhance the business environment has made obtaining entry visas easier for foreigners, but the process of securing work permits for expatriates will continue to be complex and costly, ultimately stemming the inflow of skilled foreign labour.
More and more Nigerians are no longer reconciled to a life earning poverty-level wages; they aspire to modern standards of living, but there are not enough of the jobs that would bring them to this level. The dilemma facing the authorities is that the supply of workers seeking good jobs is likely to continue to outstrip demand from employers. This imbalance has both economic and political consequences in a nation that is susceptible to sectarian conflicts, often fuelled by competition for scarce resources. High unemployment and underemployment are set to remain worrying features of the Nigerian economy, particularly among the young, and could well become a source of greater social and political instability.
Unions often stand in the way of reform
Although labour law reform in 2005 weakened the capacity of the unions to organise political or sympathy strikes, the labour movement remains powerful, capable of organising paralysing national strikes. Partly as a result of union pressure, the government has been forced to increase the minimum wage significantly in recent years, with the latest rise enacted in early 2019. Although such increases have been required to offset the rising cost of living over the past decade, and should not affect the more skilled jobs in much of the private sector, where pay is already above this level, it is a move likely to diminish any prospects of rapid growth in the formal economy for lower-skilled and labour-intensive sectors such as manufacturing. Furthermore, given deficiencies in infrastructure, as well as healthcare and education provision, productivity in Nigeria will remain a long way below that in other developing countries.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
1.8 1.8 82 82 17 17
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Nigeria's dire infrastructure is a major hindrance to sustained economic growth. Indeed, Nigeria is the worst ranked country for infrastructure in both regional and global terms. This sad state of affairs is unlikely to change in the forecast period, given the magnitude and long-term nature of the challenges faced. Nigeria's poor infrastructure has been a major constraint on growth since the mid-1970s. Successive governments have failed to deliver on promises to improve and expand basic services in key areas such as power, water, transport, healthcare and education. Gains will be made where the private sector becomes more involved, although significantly developing private-sector investment in many parts of the economy will require politically difficult changes, such as establishing pricing systems that adequately allow for earning profit. For example, notwithstanding the ongoing construction of a 650,000-barrels/day oil refinery near Lagos by a Nigerian billionaire, Aliko Dangote, which is expected to come on stream by 2022, there is little prospect that other private investors will commit to building new refineries in Nigeria as long as petrol subsidies remain in place. The NNPC, which is virtually the sole importer of fuel into the country, showed in its latest financial report that in the 12 months to September 2018 it incurred N731bn (US$2.45bn) in 'under-recovery', which is an implicit petrol subsidy.
Energy policy is the wrong way round
Nigeria will probably remain beset by inadequate power supply over the forecast period. A lack of private investment in the development of power infrastructure and the failure of privatised electricity companies to invest more in upgrading and expanding their deficient facilities are largely due to the government imposing energy price ceilings that do not allow for cost recovery. Similarly, the main reason that thermal power-generating stations have been hampered for years by shortages of gas supplies-in a country with abundant natural gas reserves-is that official gas prices have been too low to entice companies to invest in developing the costly infrastructure needed to harness gas for domestic use. The ERGP states that the gas pricing structure will be reviewed to recover all prudent costs as services improve, but government officials and investors will invariably have different views on what constitute "prudent costs". Policymakers also seem to have got the relationship between pricing and service improvement the wrong way round. To begin providing a better service, companies often need to generate more revenue to invest in the physical and human resources required to achieve the desired improvements. The APC's manifesto for 2019 pledges to pursue the expansion of electricity generation and distribution to up to 40 GW, up from installed capacity of 12.5 GW now. As with previous Nigerian governments that aimed to reach the 40 GW target by 2020, the goal of the current administration is ambitious, given current levels of production; actual peak output has not reached much above 5,000 MW in recent years, owing in part to inadequate transmission capability. The administration has promised to further liberalise power generation and supply and seek to establish an efficient cost-recovery tariff system. As this would inevitably mean large tariff hikes-with regular follow-up increases to take high inflation into account-it is doubtful that it will muster the political will to allow for an independent, market-driven pricing system. However, such a system is needed to make electricity production and distribution viable businesses and to improve the creditworthiness of existing utilities to enable them to invest.
Railways expensive in a challenging business environment
After several decades of decline in the railway network, the revival at the start of 2013 of the 1,126-km Lagos-Kano line, after a ten-year closure, marked the first significant result of multiple government plans aimed at improving rail transport. However, Nigeria's railway revival has not been fast or cheap. In his first term, Mr Buhari asked parliament for approval to borrow US$5.85bn from China to continue the modernisation of the network. An additional issue is that although infrastructure funding from China has the potential to provide capital, precedent shows that the announcement of large Chinese funding lines does not match up to actual disbursements as projects become bogged down in Nigeria's difficult operating environment.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.0 2.4 74 80 14 15
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Nigeria scores poorly in this category, reflecting a lack of formal-sector innovation compared with more developed peers. Patent applications and research-and-development (R&D) expenditure are low, and linkages between universities and the corporate sector in the field of technology are lacking. Mobile-phone ownership and internet usage are high, but these are largely concentrated in urban hubs; millions of Nigerians in rural areas lack a reliable telecommunications network. Few-if any-of these shortcomings are set to improve much in the coming years, with Nigeria's score and ranking remaining low in the forecast period.
Mixed prospects for mobile services
Mobile-phone subscriptions reached a peak of 174m in January 2019, but dropped slightly to 173.7m in the following month. After several years of phenomenal growth, from only 19m subscribers in 2005, the development of the telecoms industry now hinges on the challenge of expanding services profitably beyond largely urban markets, and many rural markets are relatively unpenetrated. Although there are high concentrations of subscribers in some states, especially in the south-west, many states in more remote parts of the country have low subscription rates. For example, Lagos state, with a population of 12.1m people, had 23.1m active subscriptions in the fourth quarter of 2018, up from 19.4m a year earlier. In contrast, fewer than 60% of the populations of Bayelsa state (in the oil-producing Niger Delta region), Ebonyi state (in the south-east) and Borno state (in the north-east) had subscriptions, and the number of subscriptions in Zamfara state (in the north-west) was equivalent to just half of the population. As mobile subscriptions approach saturation levels in urban areas, telecoms firms will have a greater incentive to grapple with the challenges of extending and improving their networks in less accessible parts of the country. There has been steady growth in mobile internet subscription in Nigeria over the past seven years, with the notable exemption of the period of economic recession in 2016. Active internet subscriptions totalled 114.8m in February 2019, up from 100.9m a year earlier and only 28m in September 2012. Less progress has been made in expanding fixed-broadband access that provides high-speed connectivity vital for industrialisation in a digital age. According to latest data available from the International Telecommunication Union, fixed broadband subscriptions in Nigeria rose to a peak of 110,834 (just 0.06% of the population) in 2017, from 107,931 in 2016. As with voice telephony, access to the internet is uneven across the country, with the highest numbers of users in the south-west, and many of the country's more remote states struggling to get connected. The challenge of expanding infrastructure (profitably) to often remote locations blighted by insecurity will remain a limiting factor.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Economic policy during Mr Buhari's second term is likely to carry over the interventionist policies adopted during his first. Measures to liberalise and unify foreign-exchange markets or move to more market-led pricing in the energy sector will not be sought out. An overvalued official naira rate is critical for maintaining petrol subsidies, and Mr Buhari will not willingly attempt to dismantle consumer price caps and risk a popular backlash. Although in practice very little foreign exchange is traded at the official rate, the existence of a multiple-exchange-rate system will be off-putting to investors fearing a return of capital controls. Concerns about this will be heightened whenever global crude prices soften and foreign reserves decline (as The Economist Intelligence Unit expects in 2019-20). Elsewhere, efforts will be made to cleanse and reboot inefficient state owned industries such as the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC)-which dominates all segments of the oil sector-but again no structural reforms (such as full or partial privatisation) will take place. Generally, Mr Buhari's approach will be to make existing entities such as the NNPC become profitable rather than relinquish state control over them entirely. There will be some effort to reduce the NNPC's stake in the upstream oil joint-ventures that it has with international oil companies, but the difficulty of operating in Nigeria and uncertainty about fiscal terms (with deep political divisions about how to distribute hydrocarbons revenue having stalled critical legislation). As a result, investor interest will be short of official expectations, and parliament will resist selling off assets for a low price. As a consequence, the NNPC will remain dominant, with politicians and other members of the political elite working to direct the flow of resources to favour specific geo-ethnic and political constituencies (as well as for illicit personal gain).
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy

Budget balance -2.6 -2.3 -2.1 -1.8 -1.8 -2.0
Government debt 15.9 17.1 18.4 18.7 19.1 19.7
We expect small fiscal deficits throughout 2019-23. The government wants to diversify its revenue base away from oil, and non-oil revenue will rise by raising consumer taxes and collecting overdue taxes, but from an extremely low base. Instability in many parts of the country will be another impediment to collection. Hydrocarbons earnings will be held back by petrol subsidies (whereby losses incurred by the NNPC's retail arm are deducted from federal revenue), and budgeted revenue levels will be undermined by overambitious oil production targets. For example, in 2019 the government expects output of 2.3m barrels/day (b/d)-a level not seen for well over a decade, and one that will be unobtainable, given underinvestment, militancy and antiquated oil infrastructure. Despite a new offshore oilfield coming on stream, total production stood at 1.64m b/d in February. Federally retained revenue is not expected to rise above 3.7% of GDP, a ratio attained only in 2023 when oil prices are at their highest in the forecast period.
After some projected expansion in 2018, spending will decline as a proportion of GDP in 2019 with deep cuts to the capital budget. Partly offsetting this will be higher spending on wages and public-sector benefits, including via the roll-out of a new (increased) minimum wage. Generally, flexibility on spending will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and so revenue-under pressure and there being considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. Altogether, we expect an average budget deficit equal to 2% of GDP over 2019-23.
Long-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against a low revenue base. Debt service already takes up close to one-third of federal government income. A sovereign default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is weaker.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
