Monetary policy will concentrate on fostering an economic recovery while limiting inflation and maintaining currency stability. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The private sector is desperate for cheaper credit, but inflation will remain above the targeted upper limit of 9% set by the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN). On balance, we expect interest rates not to move much in 2019-20, notwithstanding small rate cut by the CBN in March. Rates will then fall in 2021 and stabilise over 2022-23 as economic activity picks up and inflation hovers above-or-around target. However, real interest rates will be too high to support private-sector activity outside of highly profitable ventures.

The economy will for the most part be mired in a low-growth cycle, although there will be improvements over time. In 2020-21 the economy will be held back by falling oil prices, which will dent investor confidence (as lower oil prices heighten fears of capital controls being imposed to protect foreign liquidity), as well as high inflation and tight credit conditions, notwithstanding a recent 50 basis point drop in the policy rate. In 2020 a slowdown in the global economy will also hold back export-oriented sectors. In 2021-23, as global markets strengthen and external demand picks up, the rate of growth will quicken, although remain well below potential at an annual average of 3.3%. This is still abnormally low for Nigeria, especially as population growth of 2.6% a year is forecast for the 2019-23 forecast period.
From a sectoral viewpoint, agriculture will record only lacklustre growth; although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will be severe impediments. Industrial production will be curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, and investment will be held back by uncertainty about future fiscal terms. Egina, a new offshore oilfield, will be a new driver of output, but hydrocarbons production is not expected to return to levels prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash. That said, a private refinery coming on stream by 2021 will be a boost to downstream oil activity in the latter years of the forecast period. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of cheap goods from abroad, which are often smuggled into the country to bypass import bans. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth than industry, but it will nonetheless be held back by protectionism affecting trade, tight credit conditions affecting areas such as real estate and finance, and the struggle in the communications sector to profitably roll out data services beyond urban hubs.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Even amid a lower price environment compared with the boom years of the early 2010s, Nigeria's oil and gas sector will remain crucial to the prospects of the wider economy, dominating the export profile and accounting for the majority of government revenue. Nevertheless, despite the best intentions of reformists in government, oil production is unlikely to stage a rapid recovery following a slump in investment in recent years, amid policy uncertainty over fiscal terms (with the Petroleum Industry Bill, PIB, having languished in parliament since the start of the century) and rising militancy by local groups seeking greater control of oil revenue. This lack of investment means that in spite of the oil sector being a source of great financial windfall for Nigeria, the infrastructure that supports it is old and rickety.
Achieving a workable consensus between the various political and economic interest groups that depend on the oil industry will probably continue to confound policymakers. The PIB includes provisions to create a national oil company that is self-financing and profit-driven; to enshrine greater transparency and openness in the management of oil resources; to protect the environment; and to alter revenue-sharing. However, successive governments have failed to implement the legislation, given the conflicting demands of the various stakeholders. The multinational petroleum companies responsible for most of Nigeria's hydrocarbon output oppose the PIB's proposed increase in the government's take of oil profits, claiming that it would deter investment in the industry. However, Nigerian officials and civil groups have long complained that their nation has been under-rewarded for its oil production, particularly from offshore deposits. With global oil prices now substantially lower than they were when the PIB was initially brought before parliament, the government is under even greater pressure to maximise its share of oil profits. But divisions within the legislature-and between parliament and the executive over how Nigeria's oil dividend should be shared-still impede progress.
Gradual overhaul of oil sector makes some progress
The Buhari administration has taken a slightly different approach, breaking the bill up into smaller parts. This initially yielded some progress, with the Petroleum Industry Governance Bill (PIGB) being passed by parliament in early 2018, but it was later rejected by the president without explanation. A credible explanation is that the oil minister would have been stripped of some decision-making powers under the arrangement. In practice this brings the reform process back to square one. Even if the PIGB were to be passed, it is a subset of larger legislation and does not begin to tackle the more controversial aspects of the original PIB, including how petroleum is taxed and funding for the development of host communities. These omitted issues will be dealt with in subsequent bills, but the further delay in establishing new fiscal terms for upstream operations will continue to generate uncertainty that undermines the industry's investment prospects. The PIB proposed that 10% of the net profit of upstream oil firms be paid into a fund for the development of oil-producing areas, and the failure to actualise the plan is one of the grievances of militants in the Niger Delta, who demand local control of mineral resources or a greater share of the country's oil wealth. However, politicians from non-oil states, especially in the north, oppose this provision. Opponents argue that increasing the slice of oil revenue allocated to oil-producing states, which are already entitled to a 13% oil-derivation payment, will disadvantage non-oil parts of the country by reducing the amount of federal revenue available for them. They argue that some of these areas are as needy (if not more so) and susceptible to political instability as the oil-producing Niger Delta.
Gas production could be scaled up if pricing issues are resolved
Nigeria's proven gas reserves, both oil- and non-oil-associated, are among the largest in the world. In the gas sector the key issue is flaring; a succession of deadlines to end wastage has been missed in recent years, and the next deadline for 2020 is unlikely to be met, with many firms still employing the practice. There is therefore intense competition to find commercial outlets for gas. The government hopes to use much of the new gas production coming on stream to fuel domestic power stations, thus easing the electricity crisis. However, pricing remains an issue, as despite government pledges to increase the price that it pays for gas, prices on the export market remain more attractive for companies in the sector.

From a rate of 12.1% in 2018, average inflation will increase to 12.7% in 2019, as a 67% increase in the minimum wage combines with recently loosened monetary policy. A small devaluation in the naira expected later in the year will add to upward price pressures. Inflation will remain elevated, at 11.4% on average in 2020, as demand-side forces from the minimum wage hike continue and the currency weakens further in that year. As the currency stabilises, inflation will ease over the rest of the forecast period to an average of 8.8% in 2023. Conflict and supply disruptions in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's agricultural heartland-will prevent a faster slide, together with widening protectionist measures that limit relatively cheap imports from abroad, particularly of food and manufactured goods. Currently 43 items are barred from foreign-exchange access, the most recent addition being textiles, and the CBN wants to increase the list to 50 as a means of stimulating non-oil activity.

We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2019-23, with an official rate used for government business and a market-determined rate applicable to investors and exporters, which will be broadly in line with retail rates and the parallel market. Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors deemed important for economic or political reasons, including the NNPC, which budgets for petrol imports at the official rate. For this reason the set-up is not expected to be tampered with. Oil prices will in large part dictate where the authorities are able to hold the official rate and what the premium is between it and market-sensitive rates. In 2019 lower oil prices, as well as looser monetary policy and high inflation, will cause the market-determined Nafex rate to drop and the official rate with it, from N306.5:US$1 at end-2018 to N319.5:US$1 at end-2019. With oil prices forecast to decline again in 2020 we expect a further fall in the value of the naira, to N337:US$1 at end-2020. As oil prices pick up on average over the rest of the forecast period and petroleum exports increase as a new refinery comes on stream, we broadly expect the naira to stabilise, with an average rate of N338.4:US$1 in 2023.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. For example, the current market-determined rate, known as the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Rate Fixing, has only been in full operation since April 2017, making historical calculations challenging. However, indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued.

The export profile will move in tandem with oil production and price trends. In 2019-20 limited output gains will be outweighed by a drop in world crude prices and pipeline disruptions. Only in 2021-23 when prices recover and Nigeria begins to sell refined oil overseas (a new mega-refinery being developed is expected to be export-oriented) will there be any growth in earnings.
As Nigeria imports most of its petrol, lower world crude prices will ease pressure on the import bill in 2019-20. In 2019 there will be a sharp drop in imports relative to 2018, when there was a one-off surge in capital goods imports. Wider restrictions on foreign-exchange access and a weakening naira will also hold back consumer demand. In 2020 world oil prices will decline further and the naira will continue to depreciate, causing imports to flatline in that year. As the economy gathers pace in 2021-23, the naira stabilises and world oil (and so petrol) prices rise, imports will then grow faster. Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation in the oil sector will keep the services and primary income balances firmly in deficit. Workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, albeit dipping in 2020 as growth falters in the US (home to a large Nigerian diaspora). Overall, the current-account surplus will broadly track movements in global oil prices, narrowing from 1.8% of GDP in 2019 to 0.7% of GDP in 2020, then widening again to 2.4% of GDP by 2023.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Nigeria
Stocks and flows
Flows of foreign direct investment (FDI) into Nigeria in 2018, at US$2bn, were less than a quarter of levels registered a decade earlier. In particular, a steep decline has been occurring since the partial liberalisation of the exchange rate since April 2017; although exporters and investors can now access foreign exchange at market-determined rates, the central bank maintains an overvalued policy conversion. Although this window accounts for only a small proportion of total foreign-exchange transactions, it allows targeted (or at least well-connected) industries and suppliers access to hard currency cheaply and so has clear political importance (for example, the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation budgets for petroleum imports at the official rate, which allows it to subsidise retail sales). Given this, investors are apprehensive about the possible return to capital controls should oil prices fall and the new multiple exchange-rate system become untenable. Short-term capital inflows have been relatively unaffected and even surged in 2018 (a product of high yields on Treasury bills and improved confidence about shorter investment cycles), but long-dated securities and FDI have registered a notable downturn. The stock of FDI in 2018 was US$99.8bn, which as a percentage of GDP equated to 23.6%, down from 28% in 2016.
Origin and distribution
Most FDI inflows into Nigeria are from the oil multinationals. Until the oil price crash in 2015-16 there had been a modest surge in non-oil-sector foreign investment after it became clear that civilian democracy and macroeconomic stability had become established. Although much of the investment was by large multinational companies that were already operating in the country, South African companies strongly increased their presence, with Asian companies leading the next wave. However, the challenging market has seen some prominent withdrawals by South African firms and international banks and greater caution by Asian investors. In sum, the initial flurry of interest peaked some time ago.
Determinants
The main factors attracting investment by oil firms are low production costs and high-quality crude oil, both of which offset economic problems and political instability. A number of gas projects have moved ahead, stimulated by abundant supplies, growing demand and the government's policy goal of eliminating gas flaring. So far, privatisation has been a stop-start process. However, the opening-up of the mobile-phone market has been a success. Otherwise, the main rationale for investment by multinationals is to establish a presence in Africa's largest market, which could be highly profitable despite the difficult operating environment.
Impact
The energy sector, which has received most foreign investment to date, provides the majority of government revenue and the vast majority of foreign-exchange earnings. However, it is also a capital-intensive sector with limited linkages to the rest of the economy and little effect on employment. One area in which FDI has had a high-profile impact is mobile-phone networks, led by MTN of South Africa. However, MTN fell foul of regulators over its failure to register SIM card users during 2015 and again in 2018 over alleged non-compliance with capital repatriation requirements. Both have resulted in large fines. This is likely to make investors more wary.
Potential
With the largest economy and population in Africa, Nigeria is an important market, although the awkward business environment-characterised by impenetrable bureaucracy and idiosyncratic regulation-is likely to keep FDI inflows below potential. Established multinationals that have mastered operating in the complex and chaotic regulatory environment make substantial profits, despite the country's low income levels and the logistical difficulties caused by the almost non-existent infrastructure, which obliges companies to provide their own power and water supplies and to distribute goods on a road system that is in poor repair. The government will continue to promote Nigeria as a rewarding target for foreign investment, especially for the commercial exploitation of a range of minerals. The privatisation programme will have a relatively high profile over the next few years, but progress is likely to remain erratic. Parastatals are an important source of patronage, and privatisation faces considerable political opposition, as it is often associated with large-scale job losses. However, the failure of public enterprises to provide an adequate level of service, notably in the electricity and water sectors, and the successful liberalisation of the telephone market make privatisation almost inevitable.

Nigeria will have a population of over 222m in 2023, ensuring that it remains by far the most populous nation in Africa; it accounts for almost half of the population of the West Africa region and about 20% of the Sub-Saharan region. Nigeria has a very young population, with over 40% under 15 years of age and almost 2m entering the job market each year.
Underemployment is more of an issue than unemployment
The population growth rate will be high enough to retain a relatively stable age profile, but such a youthful population will have difficulty in finding suitable employment within the formal economy. However, it is not unemployment that is the main issue; few Nigerians in the labour force can afford not to work in a country with no government social security support for the unemployed. Instead, the main challenges are underemployment and low pay. For this reason the local definition of unemployment is working less than 20 hours a week. This suggests that the task facing the government is not so much job creation as the implementation of reforms to help to raise productivity and enable employers and employees to upskill existing jobs. Indeed, the country's ability to capitalise on this demographic opportunity will depend on raising health, employment and educational standards, on which only gradual progress can be expected. With the participation rate increasing gradually, largely as a result of more women entering the workforce, the pressure on the job market will be keenly felt throughout the forecast period.
Much will depend on the manufacturing and services sectors, but the prospects are mixed. The oil and gas sector will remain capital- rather than labour-intensive, and a gradual switch from subsistence to commercial farming is likely to result in less employment in agriculture rather than more, as hoped by the government. Many young Nigerians will have to resort to low-paid work in the informal sector, but others are likely to turn to crime or militancy-another challenge for policymakers.
Rapid urbanisation will present a challenge
A further problem will be to provide enough housing for young Nigerians leaving home. Given that the government's efforts to boost house-building are expected to make only limited progress, owing to inefficiency and capacity bottlenecks, the number of slums and the level of resentment are likely to grow. This issue will be intensified by ongoing urbanisation. The share of the urban population will surpass 55% of the total in the forecast period, up from 36% in the 1991 census. This will strain the capacity of municipal authorities to provide adequate services. Nevertheless, competition for the best agricultural and grazing grounds will continue in some parts of the country. Access to land has been a key source of violence in the country's "middle belt", and this is set to continue.
Weak infrastructure compounds health challenges
Although the reported incidence of HIV/AIDS is relatively low in Nigeria, with UNAIDS putting the prevalence rate in 2015 at 3.1%, the country's large population means that Nigeria has one of the highest numbers of sufferers of the disease in the world. Furthermore, there are geographical pockets of infection where the level is above 20% of the sexually active population, and there are major differences in the prevalence rate between states. Other health concerns include the high incidence of malaria, tuberculosis and Guinea worm disease. Furthermore, there have been outbreaks of measles and cholera across parts of northern Nigeria that have led to local healthcare infrastructure being decimated by insecurity. Internally displaced persons' camps often have poor hygiene and are lacking in medicines and medical equipment. More positively, in mid-2015 Nigeria celebrated one year without a case of polio, prompting the World Health Organisation (WHO) to remove it from the handful of endemic countries in September of the same year. A few isolated cases were reported during mid-2016, showing that the fight is not yet over-especially as insecurity will remain a persistent threat where these diseases are most prevalent. However, the WHO projects the complete eradication of the disease in the country by 2020. In other, more prosperous areas of the country, diseases associated with improving living standards are also a growing issue; for example, 1.56m Nigerians suffer from diabetes-a figure that looks likely to increase, given weak healthcare provision.

Market potential is high, but the operating context will be unfavourable
With Africa's largest economy (or second largest, depending on the exchange rate used) and highest population, Nigeria will grow in importance as a market for many multinationals. However, its attractiveness over the next five years should not be overstated. Extremely low income levels for the majority of the population will continue to mean that most people have little to spend on goods other than basic necessities. Furthermore, owing to low economic growth GDP per head in US dollar terms will only recover to 2014 levels by 2023. Nevertheless, Nigeria's growing middle class and wealthy elite-the sizes of which dwarf those in most other African countries-will remain important markets. Nigeria is potentially a profitable market for multinational companies that know how to operate in its complex and chaotic regulatory environment and have overcome the logistical difficulties posed by the almost non-existent infrastructure, for example by providing their own (expensive) power and water supplies.
As the problems associated with working in Nigeria substantially push up the cost of operations (particularly given low productivity), competition from low-cost imports will remain an issue. Providing goods through imports may seem a more attractive option for many companies seeking to exploit the market. However, given the authorities' desire for control over the exchange rate, foreign exchange restrictions on various banned import categories will continue to impede business operations.

There will be little shift in spending patterns amid economic hardship
Given the country's low level of income, consumer expenditure is dominated by the purchase of foodstuffs. Food, beverages and tobacco account for more than half of household expenditure. When spending on fuel, clothing and footwear is taken into account (and given that households also face emergency outlays, for example on healthcare), little disposable income is left for expenditure on other consumer goods, leisure, services, or eating out. These trends will broadly continue in 2019-23, albeit with a faster pace of growth towards the end of the forecast period opening up some new opportunities. There will be some increase in spending on consumer goods, driven largely by the burgeoning middle class, but the vast majority are, and will remain, poor. The middle classes are almost exclusively located in urban areas, with a geographic concentration in the south-west of the country, around the commercial capital, Lagos.

Initial conditions: Although the hydrocarbons sector accounts for just over 10% of GDP (and was at about this level, even before the end of the oil price boom), its performance has a major bearing on overall economic conditions, given its domination of government and export revenue. Consequently, the lower price environment since late 2014 and periodic but severe supply disruptions, caused by labour strikes and sabotage by militant groups, have severely weakened the local economy. The government's ability to spend what oil revenue it does still earn in a way that would benefit the majority of Nigerians is hugely constrained by the extremely weak civil service, high levels of corruption and the requirement that a large proportion of revenue be allocated to states, which are even less accountable than the federal government. Although there is more dynamism in certain parts of the non-oil private sector, such as trade, entertainment, banking and communications, a background of weak infrastructure and decades of underinvestment in healthcare and education means that the initial conditions for the country to enter a period of sustainable and diversified growth are poor.
Population changes bring opportunities, but also threats
Demographic trends: One factor in Nigeria's favour is its large and young population. However, most indicators of the health of the population are low, reflecting decades of underinvestment in healthcare facilities, which will take years to turn around even if the commitment is found. Increasing urbanisation will also put strain on service provision in the cities, as well as housing. An additional problem for the government is provision of education and training facilities for the rapidly growing population, as well as long-term employment opportunities. Internal migration, as Nigerians search for jobs in the urban centres and climate change and environmental degradation (which is fuelling conflict in Nigeria's 'Middle Belt' agricultural heartland) put strain on natural resources, will add to population pressures. Access to land is already a major driver of unrest in central Nigeria, and this phenomenon is only likely to intensify in the coming years. Overall, it is difficult to be optimistic about the outlook without a substantial improvement in economic governance and policy implementation. There is time to turn the situation around over the timeframe to 2050, but the precedent is not positive.
External conditions: There has been a structural shift in Nigeria's export markets in recent years, away from the US, which is steadily reducing its oil imports as result of its shale boom, and towards Asia, particularly India. Oil reserves will not be exhausted by 2050 but are likely to have peaked by then, which will present the additional challenge of finding external markets for the growing non-oil economy. The importance of Nigeria, due to its size and influence on the African continent, means that the international community will retain an interest in political developments in the country and will try to address the issues of insecurity, corruption and poverty. However, Nigeria's oil and gas revenue means that the international community will have limited influence. Without real commitment from the domestic leadership, Western countries will promote largely cosmetic changes rather than more fundamental reforms.
Institutions and policy trends: The real challenge for successive governments is to raise average incomes and living standards through a sustained period of economic reform and to deliver a real improvement in governance. However, the omens are not good. Nigeria remains one of the most corrupt and poorly governed countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. Considering how ingrained these problems are, they will be hard to resolve, even in a long-term timeframe. The gap between economic policy rhetoric and implementation will remain huge, and improvements will continue to be slow, given that the vast range of vested interests that benefit from the chaotic status quo remain opposed to change. In addition, policy formulation will continue to be hampered by the country's federal structure; even if a positive reform agenda is promoted at the national level, it is often not implemented or is openly contradicted at the state level.
Long-term performance: Nigeria's long-term economic performance will pick up during 2020-50, albeit at a slower pace in 2018-30 than in 2031-50, given the long-term nature of many of the challenges restricting the country's economic potential. Indeed, growth in real GDP per head will remain below 1% per year in real terms. Although some non-oil sectors will perform well (agriculture has enormous potential, as do retail and communications), others, such as manufacturing, are likely to struggle to become internationally competitive. Income levels will remain low. Moreover, Nigeria's exports and government revenue will continue to be dominated by the hydrocarbons sector. Once the next wave of new developments in the offshore oil and gas sector has run its course, Nigeria will face difficult choices in terms of economic development, and it remains unclear whether fundamental policy decisions can be made and implemented to ensure that the country is able to enter a longer period of sustained and more diversified growth.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
More extreme climate change will have a major adverse impact on not only Nigeria's economy but also the country's stability. With the country already prone to violent unrest across a variety of ethnic, religious, economic and social faultiness, an upturn in the number and severity of events associated with climate change will foster greater upheaval. As a large country spanning a number of differing meteorological zones, the impacts of climate change will be various and unevenly distributed. The country will suffer from greater incidence of desertification, soil erosion, land inundation from rising sea levels and the drying-up of surface freshwater levels. The economic impacts will be mixed. Agriculture accounts for a little over 20% of GDP but employs about two-thirds of the labour force, and the degradation of land will diminish its productivity over time. The knock-on effects on economic growth and personal consumption will be significant. Nigeria has been unable for decades to satisfy total food demand via domestic production alone, and, as climate degradation reduces potential yields, lower food production will drive even higher imports of food (it can be assumed that foreign-exchange restrictions on staple goods such as rice will eventually be lifted as domestic supply falls under local requirements). Rising food costs will fuel higher inflation, further eroding purchasing power, especially with the currency falling as a result of weaker economic conditions. The political and social effects will potentially be even more severe. Shortages of feed and water in the arid and semi-arid savannah regions of northern Nigeria, largely caused by desertification and drought, will drive ever larger numbers of pastoralists southwards and outside their normal grazing routes. This will drive them into greater conflict with local farmers in central Nigeria, who, seeking greater agricultural production, have expanded their crop cultivation into new areas, thereby limiting the land available for herders to graze their stocks. These frictions will cause outbreaks of significant violence. Nigeria already experiences thousands of deaths every year from conflicts over land access, and these numbers will grow notably, especially as we expect little progress by forthcoming governments on the contentious issue of land ownership.
A blockchain revolution
Blockchain technology-in which a continuously growing list of records (blocks) are linked and secured using cryptography-offers a number of advantages for Nigeria, where investors are often deterred and development stifled by challenges ranging from a lack of extensive infrastructure to uncertainty caused by political instability. Notably, blockchain-based cryptocurrencies do not depend on stable governments and balanced budgets in order to guarantee monetary value. A lack of useful civil-service offices, courts, transport hubs and even airports is no barrier to the exchange of data or property on the blockchain, which also offers the potential of an alternative financing system that is both decentralised and multinational. Blockchain technologies offer the potential for greater clarity regarding land and property rights, which could tackle a major barrier to investment in Nigeria, where land ownership is a thorny issue. All of these developments are of course taking place in a global economy, and indigenous efforts to create a critical mass of blockchain developers will be crucial to ensure that the technology remains on the path to innovative advancement in Nigeria. Blockchain solutions imported from other regions are likely to struggle to adapt as well and as rapidly as ones developed locally, and there is a clear risk that Nigerian developers will be lured away to work in places where blockchain technology is currently more established but less necessary. The loss of skilled personnel is a regular challenge for Nigeria, and is unlikely to become less of a problem. There are additional risks around regulatory and security requirements. For example, the ability to transfer large sums of money anonymously and across borders has clear attractions for non-legitimate businesses (as well as corrupt officials). Moreover, the adoption of blockchain technologies might face resistance from vested interests, for whom increased transparency would be an unwelcome development. Nonetheless, the attractions of a technology that allows individuals and firms to bypass stringent capital controls, high currency risk or simply inefficient existing systems are clear, suggesting that take-up in Nigeria is likely to be substantial.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit

Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The government, led by Alexis Tsipras of the Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), is likely to hobble along following the departure of the nationalist Independent Greeks (AE) from the coalition after the Macedonia name-change deal, which the Greek parliament ratified on January 25th. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects political instability to persist during a busy electoral cycle in 2019 and probably beyond, further weakening Greece's governance and its commitment to political and economic reform.
We now expect that Syriza will cling onto power until the end of the parliamentary term in October to attempt to pass legislation intended to boost its electoral support. However, we expect New Democracy (ND) to win the election, but it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to accrue a majority, complicating the government-formation process.
Greece will remain subject to strict policy conditionality in the medium term, until its debt to its international creditors is substantially reduced. Protests are likely to continue as the government strives to meet ambitious annual primary surplus budget targets of 3.5% of GDP until 2022 and 2.2% from 2023, as agreed with Greece's international creditors. Mr Tsipras's promises to lower taxes, and reverse spending cuts, could cause tensions with the EU and investors.
Greece is facing its biggest macroeconomic challenge now that it has exited the bail-out programme and no longer has access to official borrowing at preferential interest rates. However, Greece will not face short-term financing difficulties, as it will have sufficient funds to cover its debt repayments until the end of 2020. A Greek exit from the euro zone represents a risk over the long term.
After expanding by 1.9% in 2018, we expect real GDP growth to reach 1.8% in 2019 and 2020, and an annual average of 2% in 2021-23. Meeting large primary budget surplus targets and restoring competitiveness will prove to be difficult. Public debt is forecast to be still high, at about 175% of GDP in 2023.
Inflation (EU harmonised) will rise slightly, from 0.8% in 2018 to 1.3% in 2019 and 1.1% in 2020, reflecting moderate domestic demand growth and weaker global energy prices. In 2021-23 we expect oil prices to rise, bringing inflation to 1.5% per year. We expect narrower current-account deficits in 2019-23 (the forecast period) compared with an annual average of 7.1% of GDP since 2001.

Greece's business environment will improve moderately in the forecast period, with progress in almost all categories, apart from political stability. However, Greece will remain subject to sub-optimal fiscal and other policy conditions, which will constrain real GDP growth, and keep Greece's debt burden high.
Country forecast overview: Greece's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The country's privatisation agency (under new management) gains momentum, unblocking some delayed deals.
2021-23: Efforts to valorise public property through concession management and long-leasehold development agreements.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The Investment Incentives Law of 2016 offers more tax relief and fewer subsidies, and focuses predominantly on small firms. Plans to cut down on bureaucracy make modest progress.
2021-23: "Fast-track" legislation could become more important if the economy normalises. It will cover "strategic" investments in energy, tourism, transport, communications and health.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Remaining capital controls introduced in June 2015 are eliminated. Capital buffer of about EUR26bn sufficient to cover almost two years of the government's medium- and long-term financing needs.
2021-23: There is a significant risk of Greece leaving the euro zone in the long term if growth continues to disappoint. Grexit would probably result in the reintroduction of foreign-exchange controls and possibly restrictions on trade.
Taxes
2019-20: Extensive efforts to widen the tax base. Government pledges to pursue aggressive tax collection, but implementation is difficult. Indirect taxes increase. Mandatory introduction of electronic point of sale terminals helps.
2021-23: Limited progress in cutting corporate income tax or value-added tax (VAT). Measures to tackle tax evasion stepped up.
Financing
2019-20: Liquidity tight. Uncertainty constrains lending capacity. Pressure to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs) intensifies. A moratorium on foreclosures is lifted for the majority of debtors.
2021-23: The need to increase provisions for still high NPLs hampers lending. More Greek bank foreign subsidiaries are sold off.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour market reforms now mostly passed, but implementation is problematic. Unemployment remains high.
2021-23: EU funded job-creation schemes, particularly for youth, raise employment, but create few productive jobs.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Energy infrastructure comes to the fore as Trans-Adriatic Pipeline (TAP) nears completion. Privatisations pick up pace.
2021-23: Technical assistance from the EU helps absorption of European funds to revive infrastructure investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Greece rolls out high-speed internet, at a slow pace. The private sector adopts electronic payments by law.
2021-23: Significant financial and technical assistance from the EU, but Greece remains a laggard.

Background: After 400 years of Ottoman rule Greece emerged as a sovereign state in 1830. A devastating civil war followed the retreat of German occupying forces in 1944. A military junta ruled the country from 1967 to 1974, but since then a democracy has been in place. In 1981 Greece joined the European Economic Community, now the EU. It became a member of the economic and monetary union (EMU) in 2001, but its public finances became unsustainable, resulting in a sovereign debt crisis in 2009-10. Greece's public debt has put its continued membership of the EMU into question.
Political structure: Greece is a parliamentary republic, with deputies elected for four-year terms. The prime minister and the government hold executive powers. The president is elected by the 300-member parliament for a five-year term. The government requires the support of parliament to hold office. Since the 2010 crisis the traditional party system has broken down. Voters blamed the parties that ruled Greece after the return of democracy in the mid-1970s-New Democracy (ND) and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement (Pasok)-for causing the crisis, which led to the imposition of painful austerity by the country's external creditors. The result has been political fragmentation and the rise of populist parties such as the left-wing Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza), which came to power in 2015, and far-right parties such as the neo-fascist Golden Dawn (XA).
Policy issues: The ND-Pasok government of 2012-14, like its two predecessors, imposed draconian austerity packages. It also enacted fiscal and some structural economic reforms to meet the conditions of two EU-IMF bail-out packages, totalling EUR240bn. Implementation proved difficult and ultimately brought down the government. After a seven-month confrontation with Greece's creditors, the Syriza-led government negotiated a new three-year European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme in August 2015. In 2012 Greece restructured its public debt, reducing the value of private-sector creditors' holdings by EUR107bn. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any further debt write-down. Now that Greece has exited the programme, it is subject to an "enhanced supervision" monitoring regime by its euro zone creditors.
Taxation: The tax rate on corporate profits is 28% (29% in 2018) and on distributed dividends is 10%. The top marginal personal income tax rate is 45% for income of more than EUR40,000. Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at rates of 24%, 13% and 6%.
Foreign trade: In 2018 goods exports (fob) were worth EUR32.4bn and imports (fob) amounted to EUR54.9bn. The current account registered a deficit of EUR5.3bn, equivalent to an estimated 2.9% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The government led by the prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, of the Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza) is in its final stage. Since early January 2019 it no longer has a majority in parliament-just 145 out of 300 seats-following the withdrawal of the small, right-wing nationalist Independent Greeks (AE) from the ruling coalition in protest against the Macedonia name-change deal. Since January the government has had to rely on the help of members of the opposition and AE defectors to win votes in parliament. On May 10th it won a confidence vote with external support, the second in less than six months. The Economist Intelligence Unit now expects the Syriza minority government to cling to power until the end of the parliamentary term in October 2019 to try to pass legislation aimed at boosting its electoral support before the next general election. We had previously expected a snap election before October, possibly in conjunction with local and European Parliament elections that will be held on May 26th.
Ahead of the next general election political instability has intensified owing to the agreement with Macedonia to change that country's name to the Republic of North Macedonia, which the Greek parliament ratified on January 25th. This will continue to hamper government effectiveness, and commitment to political and economic reform beyond Greece's busy 2019 electoral cycle. We remain sceptical that real GDP growth will rise much higher than 2% during the 2019-23 forecast period and expect that failure to implement other structural reforms could lead to renewed tensions with Greece's EU creditors.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Despite Greece's exit in August 2018 from the third economic adjustment programme that the Syriza-led government signed in 2015, Mr Tsipras's party continues to trail the centre-right New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, by more than 10 percentage points in opinion polls from the past few months. ND's lead may narrow during the election campaign, as Mr Tsipras is a formidable campaigner and there is little overt enthusiasm for Mr Mitsotakis or his party. However, given widespread popular disaffection with the Syriza government, which is likely to have increased owing to the Macedonia name-change deal, the election-due by October 2019-is ND's to lose. If, as we expect, ND wins the largest share of the vote, it would benefit from the 50-seat bonus rule for the winning party. Even so, it would probably have to secure the support of at least one other party to muster a majority in parliament.
Turnout in Greece at local and European Parliament elections tends to be significantly lower than at general elections, and voters are more likely to show support for smaller parties. However, the elections in late May will be a significant bellwether for the next general election.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Domestic political instability, as well as protracted economic and financial crises, have limited Greece's influence in the EU and in the Balkans. Recent government efforts to restore influence on the international scene, including the Macedonia name-change deal and talks on closer co-operation with the US, are fraught with difficulty, as domestic pre-election tension is likely to condition foreign policy decisions. Ratification of the name-change agreement aims to end Greece's opposition to Macedonia's accession to NATO and its application for EU membership, but the leader of ND has said that, if elected, his government would seek to renegotiate the deal.
Tensions between Greece and Turkey will persist. However, we believe that both sides will seek to prevent their historical enmity from escalating into military hostility. Points of contention include long-standing territorial disputes in the Aegean Sea and the Greek courts' rejection of Turkey's extradition request for Turkish soldiers who fled to Greece on the night of the July 2016 failed coup in Turkey. Turkey's release in August 2018 of two Greek soldiers arrested in March of that year while on patrol in the border area of Evros has eased tensions slightly.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
With a general election looming in 2019, the Syriza government opted to exit Greece's third economic adjustment programmes in August 2018 without a precautionary credit line. In June 2018 Greece's official creditors agreed to close the final review of the third bail-out programme, paving the way for a disbursement of EUR15bn, which was released in August. Of this, EUR3.3bn was earmarked for early repayment of a more expensive tranche of IMF debt-due to be completed in July 2019-and the balance to create a buffer for Greece to use while it builds up market access. The total buffer, estimated at EUR26bn, should be sufficient to cover the country's financing needs to end-2020. This is more onerous than a precautionary credit line would have been, as Greece will be accruing interest on money that it does not currently need. However, intense political pressure not to invite further policy conditionality led the government to choose the more expensive option.
However, the government will still be subject to severe policy constraints during the forecast period and beyond, until its huge government debt is substantially reduced. General government debt was about 182% of GDP at end-2018, and also almost entirely owed to official creditors (the EU and the IMF), making another debt write-down, as happened in 2012, highly unlikely. Economic policy and performance will be subject to an "enhanced surveillance" regime, which is a more exacting system of post-programme monitoring than those applied to other former bail-out countries.
The implementation of further debt-relief measures also agreed with Greece's EU creditors in June 2018 will be conditional on quarterly reviews of the state of the economy and of the government's adherence to its commitments, the most pressing of which include tackling Greek banks' heavy burden of non-performing loans, reviving the government's privatisation programme, removing remaining capital controls and clearing state arrears to the private sector. Greece has also committed to long-term fiscal prudence. It must achieve annual primary budget surpluses (budget balance minus interest payments) of 3.5% of GDP in 2018-22 and 2.2% thereafter, until 2060. As the quarterly reviews will be published (the most recent was released on February 27th and updated on April 4th), transgression by Greece could adversely affect market access. The debt-relief measures include a ten-year grace period and a ten-year maturity extension on EUR96bn of its loans (provided by the European Financial Stability Facility). Greece will also get a reduction in the interest rates (for EUR130.9bn worth of loans), and a return of profits from the securities market programme and from the Agreement on Net Financial Assets, which comprises the official sector holders of Greek debt-the European Central Bank (ECB) and national central banks of euro area countries. The value of the return is estimated to be about EUR5bn in total in 2019-22.
In the short term Greece should have sufficient funds to meet its financing needs, but it will need to have re-established itself in the debt markets before its cash buffer runs out. After a three-year absence Greece has tapped the financial markets five times since July 2017, most recently in early March 2019 with a well-subscribed ten-year issue, yielding 3.9%. The spread on the secondary market between Greek ten-year government bonds and equivalent German government bonds has narrowed steadily in recent months, but it remains large at about 360 basis points in early May. Amid rising domestic political instability ahead of the next general election in Greece, as well as growing global economic and financial uncertainty, further bond issuance will be challenging.
In the medium and long term, the political and-arguably-the economic price of meeting high annual primary surplus targets may become unbearable. During the past four years Greece has exceeded its annual primary surplus targets, but at the expense of economic growth, which has been disappointing. Meeting such targets will remain a constraint on growth, as will other negative factors such as poor demographics and a weak business environment. Grexit is not a short- or medium-term risk; however, given that Greece is unlikely to improve competitiveness inside the euro zone or to grow its way out of its huge debt burden, Grexit will represent a possibility in the long term.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
After almost a decade of austerity Greece recorded an overall budget surplus of 1.1% of GDP and a primary surplus of close to 4.5% in 2018, exceeding the bail-out programme target of 3.5%. From 2019, however, we expect fiscal performance to deteriorate gradually, with the budget balance returning to moderately widening headline deficits from 2020 and primary surpluses falling short of the official target of 3.5% of GDP for 2018-22, reflecting constraints on revenue collection, a relaxation of spending restraint ahead of the next general election and only moderate economic growth. There is also uncertainty about the application of the Council of State's ruling that previous pension and bonus cuts implemented in 2016 were unconstitutional, raising the risk of retroactive payments. Although the primary surplus target will decline to 2.2% of GDP from 2023, it will still be difficult to achieve.
The restructuring of government debt owed to the private sector cut the debt/GDP ratio to 159.4% at end-2012, from 171.9% in 2011. However, large primary surpluses in 2016-18 were insufficient to arrest the growth of gross consolidated government debt. We expect that, without a debt write-down and assuming moderate nominal medium-term GDP growth rates, the public debt/GDP ratio will still be about 175% at the end of 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The ECB adopted an exceptionally accommodative monetary policy in response to the European sovereign debt crisis, bringing major policy interest rates down to zero or below; it also launched an asset-purchase programme that amounted to EUR2.6trn and came to an end in December 2018. Nevertheless, policy will remain ultra-loose in the forecast period, as the ECB will reinvest principal payments from maturing securities past the date on which it starts tightening. Euro zone inflation pressures remain low and downside risks to the euro zone's economic outlook remain pronounced. As a result, we have revised our monetary policy forecast and now believe that the ECB will not lift its deposit rate until June 2020 (December 2019 previously). An increase in the main refinancing rate should follow in December 2020. At its last meeting, on April 10th, the ECB signalled that it was considering introducing a tiered deposit system under which a portion of deposits at the central bank would be exempted from the deposit rate, which is currently -0.4%. The ECB's recent communication aims to show that it can hold rates at record-low levels for longer, or even cut them further later this year if necessary. Policy tightening should proceed at a gradual pace from 2021. Risks to our outlook stem from the nomination of a new ECB president in late 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The Greek economy is recovering from a protracted slump, but the recovery is modest and vulnerable to domestic, and external, developments. As at 2018 real GDP was still more than 25% below pre-crisis levels in 2007 levels, government consumption by almost one-quarter lower, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. Real GDP accelerated from 1.4% in 2017 to 1.9% in 2018, but the economy lost momentum in the final three months of last year, contracting by 0.1% on a quarter-on-quarter basis. We expect real GDP growth to remain constrained, at 1.8% in 2019 and 2020, and at an annual average of about 2% in 2021-23. The risks to our forecast are balanced: upside risks include continued strong tourism performance if capacity constraints are addressed and competitiveness gains are not eroded; downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political instability.
A combination of more-and higher-taxes, higher social security payments, debt repayments and spending cuts will continue to put pressure on household disposable income. Although we expect a modest acceleration in household spending in 2019-23, this will be from a low base and will be constrained by large primary surplus targets (of 3.5% of GDP per year up to 2022 and 2.2% in 2023), continued high unemployment and insipid lending growth.
Quarterly gross fixed investment has been volatile in recent years, but recorded strong full-year growth in 2016-17, albeit from a low base. However, reflecting base effects and a loss of momentum, investment contracted by an average of 12% year on year in 2018. We expect a pick-up from this year, to an annual average of 5.2% in 2019-23. Underinvestment during the economic crisis and the depletion of Greece's capital stock are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term.
Greece's external trade will be constrained by its relatively uncompetitive goods exports. In the medium term we expect tourism to continue to support services export growth, contributing to annual average growth of exports of goods and services of about 4.6% in 2019-23, down from 8.8% in 2018. However, the Greek tourism sector faces considerable challenges that range from the UK's planned departure from the EU and increased competition from Turkey to insufficient public investment.
How the economy performs in the next five years (and beyond) will determine whether the country remains in the euro zone. Although the risk of Grexit has abated since the height of the financial crisis, we believe that there is a risk that Greece will exit the euro zone in the long term, given the difficulties that it will face in attaining rapid growth while meeting large primary surplus targets and in restoring competitiveness without a currency devaluation. Greece's exit from the euro zone (not our core scenario) would lead to a sovereign default and severe recession in the first few years, but the economy would then recover, assuming a responsible fiscal policy guided by the necessity to achieve a primary surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
The economy has returned to growth, but significant slack in the labour market, subdued domestic demand and a sharp decreases in global oil prices in the final quarter of 2018 will dampen inflationary pressures. We expect inflation to rise modestly, from an average of 0.8% in 2018 to an annual average of 1.2% per year in 2019-20 and 1.5% per year in 2021-23 as domestic demand growth accelerates.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
The euro rallied in late 2017 on the back of the region's economic recovery and rising expectations of quantitative easing tapering. However, since peaking at almost US$1.25:EUR1 in February 2018, the euro has depreciated against the dollar, in part owing to monetary tightening in the US last year. Since the start of 2019 the euro has weakened further, hovering around US$1.12:EUR1-US$1.14:EUR1, as high-frequency data and soft indicators continue to disappoint market expectations and point to a weaker euro zone outlook. We expect the euro to start strengthening again towards the end of the year, as we expect growth to firm in the second half. We have revised our forecast for 2019 to US$1.14:EUR1 (US$1.16:EUR1 previously). The euro will resume its appreciation against the dollar from 2020, reaching US$1.20:EUR1 on average in 2020-21 as monetary policy in the euro zone is tightened gradually and growth in the US softens, and US$1.24:EUR1 in 2022-23 supported by the large current-account surplus.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The economic crisis helped to reduce Greece's current-account deficit, which shrank primarily as a result of a compression of imports owing to contracting domestic demand, but also partly of improved competitiveness, particularly in the tourism sector. We expect continued deficits in 2019-23 as import volumes pick up in line with higher domestic demand, and as global energy prices rise moderately in the second half of the forecast period. However, these deficits will be much smaller than the average annual deficit of 7.1% of GDP since Greece joined the euro zone in 2001.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberal Party, led by the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, to remain in power after the October 2019 election, but fallout from the controversy over alleged political interference in a criminal corruption case means that the result will be tighter than previously envisaged.
The renegotiation of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) has reduced trade uncertainty, although the new agreement has yet to be ratified. Trade policy will remain a risk during the administration of the US president, Donald Trump, owing to Canada's reliance on the US, its key export market.
The federal budget will remain in deficit in 2019-23, as higher receipts from the carbon tax, the legalisation of cannabis and other sources will be more than offset by increased spending on infrastructure and other measures.
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted the policy rate three times in 2018, to 1.75%. We expect it to keep rates on hold in 2019-20, owing to the weaker economy and housing market, and the benign outlook for inflation. Modest tightening will resume in 2021 and continue in 2022-23.
Consumer price inflation will ease to 1.7% in 2019, from 2.2% in 2018, reflecting generally lower oil prices. Inflationary pressures will ease further in 2020, in line with a subdued economy, before picking up again from 2021 as economic growth regains some momentum.
We forecast that real GDP growth will slow from 1.8% in 2018 to 1.6% in both 2019 and 2020 as private consumption growth moderates and an economic slowdown in the US dampens export demand. Real GDP growth will average 2.1% per year in 2021-23.

Canada's score improves slightly in 2019-23, pushing the country up to ninth place in our global business environment rankings. The best features of the business environment are political stability and openness to trade, although tax policy and the labour market will remain constraints.
Country forecast overview: Canada's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The government revises the Canada Business Corporations Act to introduce provisions on board gender diversity, annual election of directors, single election of directors and shareholder empowerment.
2021-23: Progress on increasing competition in certain sectors, such as telecommunications and dairy, will be uneven.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The government will continue to welcome foreign investment but will sometimes reject foreign takeovers owing to national security considerations. Chinese investment and takeover bids will come under particular scrutiny.
2021-23: Foreign investment is likely to rise in value terms as resource nationalism in the oil and gas sector eases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Canada, Mexico and the US ratify the revised North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), now called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which retains the essence of the original treaty.
2021-23: Canada continues to diversify its trade ties. Free-trade talks with China resume.
Taxes
2019-20: The government provides benefits and tax breaks to improve business competitiveness compared with the US.
2021-23: The government introduces reporting mechanisms for multinational enterprises to reduce tax avoidance.
Financing
2019-20: The Bank of Canada (the central bank) develops a system-wide framework to measure stress in banking, insurance and investment funds.
2021-23: The government completes its update of financial legislation, including the Bank Act, the Co-operative Credit Associations Act, the Insurance Companies Act, and the Trust and Loan Companies Act.
The labour market
2019-20: Canada will enact policies to streamline processes and increase quotas to expedite the hiring of foreign talent by companies.
2021-23: The government further encourages the entry of skilled workers and professionals by raising its immigration target.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Plans to construct new oil pipelines from Alberta progress slowly, as the projects face opposition from environmental groups.
2021-23: After years of uncertainty, pipelines to carry energy resources from Alberta begin to come on stream.
Technological readiness
2019-20: The technology sector benefits from workers moving from the US, especially those on that country's H1B visas, for whom the political climate becomes more difficult.
2021-23: Expertise in artificial intelligence takes root, particularly in the academic centres of Toronto and Montreal.

Background: The Canadian economy was the ninth-largest in the world in 2017 (measured in US dollars at market exchange rates). It is highly integrated with the US economy, which absorbs 76% of its goods exports and is the source of about 51% of its imported goods. The US exerts a powerful economic and cultural influence on Canada. Fifty-eight per cent of Canadians say that English is their mother tongue, just over 21% say French and just under 21% have another language as their first. The majority of French-speakers live in Quebec, Canada's second most-populous province. Canada's unity is sometimes called into question, but support for sovereignty is currently muted in Quebec. Neither of the main parties in contention to lead the provincial government after the 2018 election is seeking an independence referendum.
Political structure: Canada is formally a constitutional monarchy, with the governor-general (always of Canadian nationality and appointed in Ottawa) acting as the representative of the British crown. In practice, the Canadian House of Commons is sovereign. Canada is a federation of ten provinces, each with substantial powers, and three territories. At the federal level are the Commons, the main seat of legislative power, and the non-elected Senate, which plays only a marginal role. The Liberal Party heads a majority government since winning the general election in 2015.
Policy issues: The federal government must balance the assistance that it is providing to the fossil fuel industry through approving new oil pipelines with the need to maintain its green credentials. The government will increase its spending on infrastructure significantly, including through its Canada Infrastructure Bank.
Taxation: The federal corporate income tax rate is 15%. Provincial governments charge corporate tax at rates between 2% and 16%. As at 2019 the top federal income-tax rate, on taxable income above C$210,371 (US$157,300), is 33%.
Foreign trade: The US absorbs about three-quarters of Canadian exports, so the health of its economy is crucial for Canada. Canada's trade deficit was US$16.6bn in 2018 and the current-account deficit was US$45.5bn (2.7% of GDP).
