Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The Liberal Party, led by Justin Trudeau, has shifted Canadian politics to the left since it won a majority at the 2015 election. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects challenges to policy initiatives and friction with provincial administrations to intensify ahead of the next federal election, due in October 2019. The ongoing controversy over alleged political interference in a criminal corruption case also risks permanently tarnishing Mr Trudeau's political brand.
The political scandal centres on allegations by the former attorney-general and justice minister, Jody Wilson-Raybould, that Mr Trudeau and his officials put inappropriate political pressure on her to abandon the criminal prosecution for fraud of SNC-Lavalin, a large, Quebec-based construction and engineering firm. In late March Ms Wilson-Raybould provided the parliamentary justice committee with a secret recording of a telephone conversation between herself and the clerk of the Privy Council, from December 2018. In that conversation the clerk highlighted the prime minister's concerns about the damaging impact of a prosecution on SNC-Lavalin, continuing a debate that had been under way internally for months about the option of proceeding under a deferred prosecution agreement, which would have let the company off with a fine. Ms Wilson-Raybould refused to intervene, and the company faces the prospect of a trial.
The secret taping angered many Liberal members of parliament, who believed that it was time for Mr Trudeau to act, after weeks of him and other Liberals trying to broker a compromise with Ms Wilson-Raybould. She had quit the cabinet in February. Another cabinet minister, Jane Philpott, followed suit in March. Citing the unwillingness of the pair to state that they had confidence in him and his government, Mr Trudeau expelled them from caucus on April 2nd and indicated that they could not run as Liberals in the federal election. Just as it seemed that the Liberals had drawn a line under the issue, the leader of the main opposition Conservative Party, Andrew Scheer, revealed on April 7th that he had received a letter from Mr Trudeau's lawyer, threatening to sue him for libel over his comments relating to Mr Trudeau's role in the controversy. The affair is likely to result in further political fallout for the government and give added momentum to the Conservatives in the lead-up to the federal election.
Friction between the federal and provincial governments will intensify following the election in April of a United Conservative Party provincial government in Alberta and a minority Progressive Conservative Party provincial government in Prince Edward Island. On April 1st the Trudeau administration imposed a carbon tax in four provinces-Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario and New Brunswick-that did not have pricing plans meeting federal standards. This will be extended to Alberta, when the new premier, Jason Kenney, repeals the carbon tax in the province. The imposition of the carbon tax in these provinces, and the nationalisation in 2018 of the Trans Mountain pipeline expansion project, which is fundamentally opposed by the provincial government in British Columbia (BC), has raised questions over federal jurisdiction.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
Political fallout from the SNC-Lavalin affair has seen the Conservatives edge ahead of the Liberals in opinion polls since February. However, we still expect the Liberal Party to form the government after the federal election due by October 2019. This reflects the advantages of incumbency, the renegotiation of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), which has helped to ease trade uncertainty, and the legalisation of cannabis. However, the Conservatives have an experienced shadow cabinet and are building momentum under Mr Scheer. They will be further boosted by the victories of provincial colleagues in the Alberta and Prince Edward Island elections in April. At the federal level, the Conservatives will focus on the Liberal government's perceived vulnerabilities, namely taxes and government spending. The Conservatives also contend that the Liberals have lost control of the border by allowing 40,000 people to walk across from the US over the past two years and claim asylum. The profile of the New Democratic Party (NDP) leader, Jagmeet Singh, will be lifted by his election to parliament in February. However, the NDP trails well behind the two larger parties in terms of fundraising ahead of the election. The Conservatives are in the best shape in this regard.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Under the Liberals, Canadian foreign policy emphasises multilateralism over unilateralism, engagement over isolation, mitigating the effects of climate change and upholding human rights. This is in clear contrast to the policies pursued by Donald Trump's administration in the US. As a result, bilateral relations with the US will be strained during the remainder of the Trump administration. Canada will, nonetheless, seek to preserve relations with the US, its most important diplomatic and economic partner by far. Where possible, Canada will attempt to circumvent the White House by strengthening its ties to other levels of US government. Canada will also increase efforts to diversify trade.
The successful negotiation of the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which will replace NAFTA and preserve the trilateral arrangement, mitigates significant trade risk for Canada. The new agreement was signed in November 2018 and is awaiting ratification by the three governments. However, there is a significant risk of delay from the US side. The revised deal maintains most of the substance of the earlier US-Mexico deal. In particular, the USMCA retains the Chapter 19 dispute-resolution mechanism, which Canada relies on to protect some of its industries (primarily lumber) from potential US anti-dumping measures. The new deal grants the US greater access to the Canadian market for dairy, poultry and eggs (these sectors are also managed by the government to ensure sufficiently high prices for farmers). This concession is broadly similar to what Canada had offered during negotiations for the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, from which the US withdrew in 2017. In another move that should ease regional trade tension, Canada negotiated an exemption from any future tariffs that the US might impose on automotive imports.
The implementation of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) is expected to provide enhanced access to key Asian markets over the forecast period. A trade deal signed with the EU in 2016 has removed 98% of the EU tariff lines. With full implementation, the figure is set to rise to 99%.
China was a key target for the government's trade diversification policy until December, when Meng Wanzhou, a senior executive of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, was detained in Canada at the request of US authorities. Bitter exchanges between Canada and China since her arrest have cast a chill on bilateral relations. On March 1st the Canadian government announced that it would proceed with hearings on her extradition, and shortly afterwards China blocked canola (rapeseed) imports from two Canadian canola producers, on the grounds of biosecurity concerns. We expect tensions to persist throughout 2019, preventing progress on exploratory free-trade talks.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Canada will continue supporting domestic industries that are negatively affected by US trade protectionism. In 2018 the finance minister, Bill Morneau, announced measures to increase the competitiveness of Canadian businesses after the introduction of tax cuts in the US at the start of last year. These included a tax break on capital expenditure in manufacturing. Environmental policy will also be important in the remainder of the parliamentary term. Government support for the fossil fuel industry is crucial for economic growth in the short and medium term but appears incompatible with the federal government's green credentials. The Liberal Party will continue to seek a balance between these two objectives to preserve its voter base. On the one hand, the government has rolled out a national carbon tax of C$20/tonne (US$15/tonne) in provinces that did not have an equivalent carbon pricing programme in place. The federal tax will rise to C$50/tonne by 2022. However, the consensus on taxing carbon emissions seems to be weakening as opposition mounts. On the other hand, the federal government supports the controversial expansion of the Trans Mountain pipeline (which it now owns). The expansion, which is designed to enable higher volumes of crude oil from Alberta to be transported to a port in BC, is deeply unpopular with environmentalists and opposed by the BC government. The final decision on whether to proceed with the project has been postponed until June, but could be delayed again, given the looming election.
Policymakers will continue to keep a close eye on the property market, which remains a key risk owing to recent monetary policy tightening and overleveraged Canadian households. Following the imposition of tighter mortgage-lending requirements since 2016, the market appears to be rebalancing as the quality of new mortgage lending improves. Price growth has slowed markedly, with some measures showing a dip in house prices in late 2018/early 2019, although trends vary across the country.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The government is committed to a programme of infrastructure spending that will entail a series of budget deficits, but this will be partially offset by increased receipts due to the introduction of the carbon tax and greater tax income as a result of cannabis legalisation. However, lower average oil prices in 2019-20 compared with 2018 will weigh on plans to reduce the fiscal deficit, as increased government support will be expected to shore up the economy and government receipts are likely to undershoot official projections.
According to the federal budget for fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March) handed down on March 19th, the budget deficit for 2019/20 will be C$19.8bn (US$14.8bn), equivalent to 0.9% of GDP. Official projections show the budget deficit declining to C$9.8bn, equivalent to 0.4% of GDP, by 2023/24. We estimate that the fiscal deficit stood at 0.9% of GDP in 2018 (our fiscal forecasts are calendar-year based), and expect it to expand slightly, to 1.1% of GDP, in 2019 as the government looks to support the fossil fuels industry through rebates and additional incentives amid a softer price environment. In 2020 the government will respond to continued weak growth with additional fiscal spending, which will push the deficit up to 1.3% of GDP. The government will look to narrow the deficit in the longer term, and we expect it to fall gradually, to 0.7% of GDP by 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) lifted its policy rate by 125 basis points between July 2017 and October 2018, in response to rising inflation and tightening monetary policy in the US. However, it has kept rates steady at its last four scheduled interest-rate meetings, owing in part to lower energy prices, which have pushed down the headline inflation rate. The central bank indicated in October that interest rates would need to rise over time to a neutral rate of between 2.5% and 3.5%, to keep inflation at around the BoC's 2% target and discourage highly indebted households from accumulating further debt. The central bank lowered its assessment of the neutral range to between 2.25% and 3.25% in the monetary policy report that accompanied the latest rate decision on April 24th, and signalled that it was in no hurry to lift rates.
Given the benign outlook for inflation, weak household spending growth, the softer housing market and signs of a loss in global economic momentum, we expect the BoC to leave the policy rate unchanged throughout 2019. We forecast that rates will remain on hold in 2020 as US growth weakens further, which, because of the two countries' interlinkages, will cause economic growth in Canada to slow. Modest monetary tightening will resume in 2021 and continue for the remainder of the forecast period.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
Real GDP growth slowed to 1.8% in 2018, from 3% in 2017. This reflected weaker growth in most GDP components, notably private consumption and business investment, although export growth picked up. We expect real GDP growth to soften further in 2019, to an average of 1.6%. Previous monetary tightening and high household debt levels will dampen private consumption growth this year, and export growth is also expected to moderate, as a result of weaker economic expansion in the US, Canada's key export market.
Much of 2018 was characterised by the escalating trade dispute with the US. The renegotiation of NAFTA reduces one of the key downside risks to our forecast, although the agreement has yet to be ratified, and the steel and aluminium tariffs imposed on Canada by the US in 2018 remain in place for now. Other risks to the economic outlook include a renewed drop in global oil prices, which would act as a drag on economic activity.
Growth in the US and world trade will continue to lose steam in 2020, although we expect the slowdown to be more modest than previously forecast. As a result, we have revised up slightly our forecast for real GDP growth in Canada next year to 1.6% (previously 1.5%). Economic expansion in Canada is expected to pick up again in 2021, and real GDP growth will average 2.1% per year in 2022-23. This will be supported by continued government spending on infrastructure and stronger export growth, driven by recovering demand in the US and enhanced trade ties with the EU and CPTPP members.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Rising oil prices until October 2018 and the increasingly protectionist trade policy of the US added to price pressures for much of 2018, when the headline rate of consumer price inflation picked up to an average of 2.2%. The headline inflation rate fell back to 1.6% year on year in the first quarter of 2019, below the BoC's 2% target rate, owing to lower petrol prices, although core inflation was 1.9%. We expect the headline inflation rate to average a benign 1.7% in 2019, reflecting the lagged effect of previous monetary tightening by the central bank, slowing export demand and generally lower oil prices. Subdued economic growth in 2020 will lead to a further easing in the inflation rate next year, before it picks up again from 2021 as the economy strengthens.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Tighter monetary policy, a broader improvement in the global economy and the draining of the surplus in the oil market lent support to the Canadian dollar in the first half of 2018, although falling oil prices have weighed on the currency in recent months. We expect the Canadian dollar to depreciate further against its US counterpart, from a full-year average of C$1.30:US$1 in 2018 to C$1.35:US$1 in 2019 and C$1.38:US$1 in 2020, reflecting weaker global oil prices, softer economic growth and a more dovish approach from the BoC, which we now expect will leave its policy rate unchanged in 2019-20. A pick-up in growth from 2021, and the resumption of monetary tightening, will underpin an appreciation in the Canadian dollar over the remainder of the forecast period, with the currency forecast to average C$1.30:US$1 in 2023.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The exchange rate, commodity prices and the health of the US economy will continue to shape the outlook for the current account, which we expect will remain in deficit in 2019-23. The impact of softer global oil prices in 2019-20 will be offset by slowing domestic demand and, therefore, import growth. As a result, the merchandise trade deficit and the shortfall on the current account will remain broadly stable as a proportion of GDP, with the latter averaging 2.7% of GDP during this period. The CPTPP, the effects of which will first be felt at the start of the next decade, will result in higher trade volumes between Canada and Pacific nations. We expect that this will help to narrow the current-account deficit to 2.3% of GDP in 2023.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US, Japanese, EU and OECD growth and inflation: OECD
World trade growth: total world exports, quantum index, UN
Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 2000=100
Domestic data
GDP growth: Statistics Canada; at chained 1997 prices
Growth in expenditure components of GDP: Statistics Canada; chained 1997 prices
Sectoral GDP: Statistics Canada; chained 1997 prices
US$ GDP: Statistics Canada; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
Population: Statistics Canada
Average hourly earnings in manufacturing: Statistics Canada
Consumer prices: Statistics Canada; all items, annual % change
Exchange rates: IMF, IFS; Bloomberg; average market rates
3-month market rate: IMF, IFS; Bank of Canada Review
Current-account balance: IMF, IFS (figures may differ slightly from national source)
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
